headline: Fish Overpowers Jaziri
text: Eighth-seeded Mardy Fish of the United States rolled into the third round of the U.S. Open with a convincing victory over Malek Jaziri of Tunisia, 6-2, 6-2, 6-4.

headline: Scanning Eyes and Fingers in India
text: In India, workers are creating what will be the world’s largest biometric database, a collection of 1.2 billion identities.

headline: Mickelson Is Turning to Belly Putter
text: NORTON, Mass. — Spectators on Friday afternoon at the first round of the Deutsche Bank Championship, the second of four events in the FedEx Cup playoffs, will get a chance to see at least one thing they have not seen before: Phil Mickelson using a belly putter.

headline: A Haunting in the E.R.
text: Natalie Zea’s somber glamour — a combination of earnestness, sad eyes and otherworldly cheekbones — just might be enough to hold your attention through “InSight,” a psychological-supernatural thriller that’s light on thrills.

headline: Marijuana and Children
text: To the Editor:

headline: Clinic Rejects Immigrants After Impasse With Hospital
text: ATLANTA — After the collapse of negotiations between Atlanta’s public hospital and the world’s largest dialysis provider, a dozen immigrants suffering from renal failure were refused treatment at an Atlanta clinic on Thursday and advised to wait until their conditions deteriorated enough to justify life-saving care in an emergency room.

headline: Verizon’s Tax Bill
text: To the Editor:

headline: No Easy Answers for Those Who Share Williams’s Disease
text: It often starts out as an uncomfortable feeling in the eyes and mouth. Patients say their eyes are dry and red, even though they are using eye drops. Often too, they say, their mouths are dry. Food is becoming tasteless. Some get swollen glands in their necks, making it look like they have mumps.

headline: For Refugees, the Price of Dignity
text: Somalia is now suffering its worst drought in 60 years. A quarter of the population has fled famine and conflict, heading west into Kenya. More than 1,300 people a day stream into the complex of refugee camps at Dadaab, Kenya, which is now housing more than 430,000 people in camps designed for 90,000. Many Somalis arrive near death after journeys of weeks with little food. Large numbers of them are children, often without parents.At Dadaab they receive food, medical care, basic shelter — the emergency relief they need. But they will probably spend years in that desolate grid of white tents, eating gruel that gets thinner toward the end of the month. The camp lacks the money to provide even subsistence rations. In exchange, the refugees give up their rights to move freely and to work.

headline: Purists Gone Wild
text: I reached for an Irish whiskey — two fingers, neat, as my uncle used to say in trying to teach me how to drink — just after finishing “Last Call,” Daniel Okrent’s haunting and entertaining book on Prohibition. The drink was necessary, in part, because his gallop through one of the most otherworldly episodes in American history made me shudder at the parallels to this age.

headline: Bloomberg Hid Crucial Detail as Aide Resigned: An Arrest
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s management style has its hallmarks: unwavering loyalty to aides and a deep distaste for exposing private lives to public scrutiny.

headline: Desormeaux Prevented From Riding After Arrest
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — The Hall of Fame jockey Kent Desormeaux was not permitted to ride at Saratoga Race Course on Thursday afternoon, one day after he was arrested and charged with reckless endangerment.

headline: A Little Give in the Dress Code
text: As more and more schools adopt dress codes, back-to-school shopping is often a rather dull exercise. Polo shirts. Khaki pants. Plaid skirts. As the students might say, bo-ring.

headline: Greens Gain in Germany, and the World Takes Notice
text: BERLIN — A string of Green Party victories and strong electoral showings across Germany, from the conservative south to the port cities of the north, are helping to redefine politics among voters who are increasingly losing faith in the more established parties.

headline: Oh, Grow Up
text: Whenever we think Washington couldn’t get more cynical or more craven, it proves us wrong. So we will resist the temptation to say it’s hard to imagine anything more base than the food fight over President Obama’s planned speech to Congress.

headline: T-Mobile May Suffer if AT&T Deal Fails
text: When AT&T agreed to buy T-Mobile USA in March, the deal looked like a happy fate for a company that had been losing customers and facing declining sales.

headline: Return to Hydrate Ridge
text: Jeffrey Marlow, a graduate student at the California Institute of Technology, writes from off the coast of Oregon, where he is studying life around deep ocean vents.

headline: In Libya, Former Enemy Is Recast in Role of Ally
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Abdel Hakim Belhaj had a wry smile about the oddity of his situation.

headline: Justice Dept.’s Top Officials in Pursuing the AT&T Lawsuit
text: The names of 25 government lawyers are listed on the last page of the Justice Department’s lawsuit seeking to block the proposed $39 billion merger between AT&T and T-Mobile USA.

headline: Hockey Players’ Deaths Pose a Tragic Riddle
text: Three N.H.L. players, all enforcers entrusted with protecting teammates through intimidation and the occasional flurry of fists, have been found dead since May, stirring debate over the role of fighting in hockey, the stress placed on enforcers and the possible impact of brain trauma on the men who absorb the sports’ biggest beatings.

headline: Stormy Weather for a Utility Merger
text: Hurricane Irene may not have done much damage on Wall Street. But she ought to blow one deal off course: the $4.2 billion merger of the electric companies Northeast Utilities and NStar. Huge blackouts after the storm have exposed Northeast Utilities’ deficiencies in serving customers despite charging some of America’s highest rates. Regulators should take a critical look before approving the deal.

headline: Nature’s Stimulus Package
text: To the Editor:

headline: For the Governor of Vermont, a Crash Course in Disaster Management
text: PITTSFIELD, Vt. — After helicoptering into this flood-ravaged town and delivering a pep talk to residents who had been stranded for three days and counting, Gov. Peter Shumlin asked if anyone had questions for him. It took a minute for anyone to speak up, and even then, the queries were polite to the point of apologetic.

headline: Different Leaders, Different Approaches
text: Here is how some governors in the East handled Hurricane Irene.

headline: Epstein or Cashman Moving on? Not Likely
text: BOSTON

headline: The Confederate of the Sierra Madre
text: José Quintero’s reputation was soaring upon his return to Richmond in mid-August 1861. He had travelled the width of the Confederacy to deliver the rarest of gifts for the Southern capital: much better than a fine box of cigars, the Cuban-born Southern special agent brought good news from Mexico.

headline: The Vigorous Virtues
text: There’s a specter haunting American politics: national decline. Is America on the way down, and, if so, what can be done about it?

headline: Beauty Might Not Be Blind, but the Casting Call Was
text: ARE you just another pretty face? Or are you truly beautiful? A new campaign from the mineral cosmetics company Bare Escentuals hopes women will realize that the former is not enough.

headline: Battle for Libya | Sept. 1, 2011
text: Libyan rebels waited on the road between Misurata and Surt for the Saturday deadline for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and his fighters to surrender to expire.

headline: Aerial View of Beaches Shows More Danger Than Damage
text: Its doors opened wide and the wind whipping, a Black Hawk helicopter swooped low alongside the carnival rides in Coney Island on Thursday. Then it cut across the Rockaways and hugged the shoreline heading east.

headline: Eric and Irene
text: “Have you left no sense of decency?” That’s the question Joseph Welch famously asked Joseph McCarthy, as the red-baiting demagogue tried to ruin yet another innocent citizen. And these days, it’s the question I find myself wanting to ask Eric Cantor, the House majority leader, who has done more than anyone else to make policy blackmail — using innocent Americans as hostages — standard operating procedure for the G.O.P.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Manor That Has Stood for Centuries Teeters in Storm’s Wake
text: AMSTERDAM, N.Y. — Ann Peconie pressed her face close to the shattered glass windows of the Guy Park Manor.

headline: Plan to Create Jobs Is a Balancing Act for the President
text: WASHINGTON — Anticipation of President Obama’s plan for creating jobs while cutting deficits, now heightened by the scheduling controversy over his prime time address to Congress next Thursday, has turned on a question: Will he go big and highlight his sharp differences with Republicans, or will he be pragmatic and downsize his ideas to get Republican votes?

headline: Port Jervis Train Line Will Take Months to Repair
text: The 2,300 weekday commuters on the Metro-North Railroad’s Port Jervis line through the mountains and lush valleys of Orange and Rockland Counties compare the line to a small-town community. On homeward rides that can last more than two hours, they sit together as if they are at a town meeting, catching up on gossip, sharing their latest vacation photos and planning their annual on-train holiday reception. And they still seem to be awed by the views.

headline: Argentina’s Turnaround Tango
text: Buenos Aires

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,740 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Fantasy U.S. Open: Stefan Edberg
text: George Vecsey explains how Stefan Edberg could defeat Roger Federer in a hypothetical U.S. Open match.

headline: Dr. William Wolff, Colonoscopy Co-Developer, Dies at 94
text: Dr. William I. Wolff, who with a colleague revolutionized the diagnosis and treatment of colon cancer by developing the colonoscopy as the procedure is practiced today, died on Aug. 20 at his home in Manhattan. He was 94.

headline: Fantasy U.S. Open: Roger Federer
text: Gerry Marzorati explains why Roger Federer was a great U.S. Open champion and how he could defeat Stefan Edberg in a hypothetical Open match.

text: Palo Alto, Calif.

headline: Rebels Yank Open Gates of Infamous Libyan Prison, Seeking Clues to a Massacre
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — The liberators of Abu Salim prison came swinging sledgehammers. The inmates flashed victory signs, locks fell, a crowd cheered and the doors swung open.

headline: Defendant’s Plea Bargain Leads to Buyer’s Remorse
text: As one might imagine, agreeing to go to prison is a decision a person might easily balk at.

headline: Feldman, Embattled Writer, Leaves ESPN for CBS
text: For six weeks, Bruce Feldman had been silent about the outsize Twitter reaction that followed his one-day benching by ESPN over the book he wrote with the former Texas Tech football coach Mike Leach.

headline: In Parks and on Streets, a Toll of Thousands of Trees
text: While New York City may have dodged a bullet from Tropical Storm Irene, its trees did not. From shade trees on side streets in Elmhurst, Queens, to towering tulip trees in Prospect Park in Brooklyn, many toppled, snapped or splintered.

headline: Bare Escentuals Advertisement
text: The company’s new campaign says, “Be a force of beauty.”

headline: Gravenstein Apples Struggle to Survive in Sonoma County
text: SEBASTOPOL, Calif. — It would be almost impossible to visit this town, in the heart of Sonoma County, and miss the Gravenstein, the sweetly tart (or tartly sweet) apple whose name suggests a Transylvanian undertaker. The Gravenstein is harvested in August and often gone by Labor Day, and its name emblazons a local highway, a couple of schools, a town shopping center and an annual festival that draws thousands of visitors — and apple-a-day acolytes — to this mellow Bay Area getaway.

headline: Friday: Fresh Air
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Take a deep breath, everyone – it’s Friday.

headline: Protecting Innovation and Competition
text: After a decade-long merger spree in which AT&T and Verizon amassed more than 60 percent of the nation’s cellphone subscribers, the Justice Department was right to call a halt to the consolidation process, filing an antitrust suit on Wednesday to block AT&T’s $39 billion attempt to buy the nation’s fourth-largest carrier, T-Mobile.

headline: U.S. Is Set to Sue a Dozen Big Banks Over Mortgages
text: The federal agency that oversees the mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac is set to file suits against more than a dozen big banks, accusing them of misrepresenting the quality of mortgage securities they assembled and sold at the height of the housing bubble, and seeking billions of dollars in compensation.

headline: Mets Seeking ‘Small Ball’ Investors
text: Now that the Mets are no longer planning to sell a $200 million share of the team to David Einhorn, their owners are dusting off Plan B: selling smaller stakes to people willing to invest perhaps $20 million each.

headline: Driver in Deadly Bus Crash Knew He Was Dangerously Tired, Prosecutor Says
text: When Ophadell Williams climbed behind the wheel of a bus to drive to New York City from a Connecticut casino, prosecutors said on Thursday, he knew that he lacked a valid driver’s license and enough sleep.

headline: U.S. Open Point/Counterpoint: Roger Federer vs. Stefan Edberg
text: Fantasy U.S. Open Tournament: Who are the two greatest U.S. Open champions from the past 30 years? It’s up to you to decide, with a little help from The Times’s tennis experts. Watch our video debates, vote on the winner and then explain your position in the comments section. The winner from this match will advance to the next round of our virtual tournament. View the bracket.

headline: Power Out to Hundreds of Thousands Around New York
text: House by house and block by block, power was steadily restored on Thursday to parts of the New York City area that had lost electricity because of Tropical Storm Irene.

headline: Ruin and Hope on Haiti’s Reefs
text: Volunteers from Port-au-Prince begin training for a team of eco-divers that will be responsible for surveying, and perhaps one day helping save, Haiti's endangered coral reefs.

headline: Mars Rover Discovery Elates NASA
text: It has been driving on and off for more than seven years, but now it has reached its new destination. Opportunity, a small exploratory rover that landed on Mars in 2004, has trundled to a crater called Endeavour.

headline: In House Race, Democrat Is Far Ahead in Fund-Raising
text: The Democratic candidate running in the special election to replace former Representative Anthony D. Weiner has raised more than twice as much as his Republican opponent, according to campaign finance filings made public on Thursday.

headline: His Father’s Name, His Own Success
text: TAMPA, Fla. — After his first day of kindergarten, Skip Holtz returned home and told his parents the teacher never called his name. He mentioned there was another boy in the class named Holtz, with the first name of Louis. “He wasn’t there,” he said, “but I’m looking forward to meeting him.”

headline: Consumer Advocates Withdraw From Talks on Improving the Safety of Window Blinds
text: Four consumer advocates said that they would no longer participate in discussions by a task force that was intended to draft new guidelines to make window blinds safer for children.

headline: Sloane Stephens, Another Rising American
text: After Sloane Stephens upended Shahar Peer, the 23rd seed, on Thursday, Stephens seemed less enthused with advancing to the third round and more excited about the car she planned to buy when she returned home to California.

headline: Reverie in Yellow
text: Most New Yorkers depend on public transportation. And when it is suspended — as it was during Hurricane Irene — we realize just how much we need it. But there are times when, if you can afford it, only a taxi will do. You raise your arm, a cab pulls over, and off you go. Sometimes it occurs to you that if you raised an arm at the curb on most of the streets in America, nothing would happen. Someone might wave, but that’s about it. Sometimes you realize that in most of America, two adults in a car almost never ride one in front, one in back.

headline: Holtz Sees the Good in College Sports
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Don’t tell Skip Holtz that college athletics is broken and can’t be fixed. Holtz, whom I wrote about in advance of South Florida’s game Saturday in South Bend, Ind., walked on at Notre Dame to play football, and he continues to regard college sports much as he did then: as a privilege that affords the lucky few an opportunity to compete and be part of something bigger than themselves.

headline: At Columbia, Faith of Some in President Is Shaken
text: Several Columbia University professors said this week that the recent resignations of two high-ranking black administrators have shaken their confidence in the institution’s president, Lee C. Bollinger, and reignited concerns among their colleagues about other aspects of his leadership.

headline: Holiday on Monday Labor Day
text: NEW YORK

headline: G.O.P. vs. Obama: Disrespect or Just Politics?
text: WASHINGTON — American presidents often have highly disagreeable relationships with members of Congress from the opposing party.

headline: Jets and Eagles Hit by Quarterback Injuries
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Jets and the Eagles can only hope that their regular-season meeting in Philadelphia on Dec. 18 will bear no resemblance to their preseason finale Thursday night at MetLife Stadium. If it does, then Michael Vick and Mark Sanchez have much to worry about.

headline: Giants Pluck Cornerback From His Living Room
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — When Giants cornerback Terrell Thomas sustained a season-ending knee injury against the Chicago Bears last month, it did not take long for the team’s front office to fall into a familiar routine.

headline: A Vital Liberty
text: In an important decision last week, a federal appeals court affirmed that the First Amendment protects the right to videotape the activities of police officers in public. When three officers arrested a man in Boston Common one evening in 2007, a bystander named Simon Glik, concerned that the officers were using excessive force, pulled out his cellphone and made an audio and video recording of the arrest. Unhappy about being recorded, one officer handcuffed and arrested Mr. Glik, too. He was charged with wiretapping, along with other crimes.

headline: Scanning 2.4 Billion Eyes, India Tries to Connect Poor to Growth
text: KALDARI, India — Ankaji Bhai Gangar, a 49-year-old subsistence farmer, stood in line in this remote village until, for the first time in his life, he squinted into the soft glow of a computer screen.

headline: Two Mets Debuts: A First Start and a First Day
text: The Mets’ 7-5 win over the Florida Marlins on Thursday night marked the franchise debuts of sorts for two players with disparate paths in baseball but intriguing backgrounds away from the game.

headline: Traveling Far and Wide to Treat the Players’ Aches
text: It was the third day of the United States Open qualifying tournament and Elaine Brady was already sipping an afternoon coffee during a rare break from the training room, where many of the 128 qualifiers had been filing in and out. The Open was just beginning, but Brady’s hectic schedule was already forcing her to rely on a caffeinated boost.

headline: Ronald Fernandez, Scholar on Plight of Puerto Ricans, Dies at 67
text: Ronald Fernandez, a professor of sociology whose curiosity about a daring $7 million armored car robbery near his Connecticut home set him on a career path of scholarly investigation into the history of American colonialism in Puerto Rico, died on Tuesday in West Hartford. He was 67.

headline: Scrutinizing Perry’s Extensive Execution Record
text: As Gov. Rick Perry touts his tough-on-crime policies on the national political stage, the case of Cameron Todd Willingham will continue to be scrutinized. Scientists have raised questions about whether Mr. Willingham set the blaze that killed his three daughters and led to his 2004 execution.

headline: Bogomolov’s Resiliency on Display at Open
text: There’s a stereotype of tennis — fair or not — that it is a gentlemen’s sport. The players, like the game itself, are supposed to be polite and mild-mannered individuals with affluent backgrounds.Alex Bogomolov is not like that. And he knows it.

headline: Spread of Leaked Cables on Web Prompts Dispute
text: WASHINGTON — All 251,287 diplomatic cables obtained by WikiLeaks last year are now accessible in multiple locations on the Internet, a development that touched off a dispute on Thursday between the group and the British newspaper The Guardian about who was responsible for their release.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Doggett vs. G.O.P. And a Democrat as Well
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Same Top Ranking, but Worlds Apart
text: Late Thursday, Caroline Wozniacki of Denmark and Novak Djokovic of Serbia shared twin billing in the night session at the United States Open. Both took the court in the second round at Arthur Ashe Stadium seeded first and ranked No. 1 in the world.

headline: For Disabled, Cuts Could Affect Lifelong Improvement
text: For Milla Powell, a 12-year-old from Austin with cerebral palsy, the little things make all the difference. Massage therapy to ease her tightened muscles. Recreational programs, in which therapists take her into the community to help her build her social skills. Music therapy to help Milla, who cannot speak, connect without words.

headline: Cable Implicates Americans in Deaths of Iraqi Civilians
text: A recently disclosed diplomatic cable shows that a top United Nations human rights official warned the United States government five years ago that he had received information indicating that Iraqi reports of American troops executing a family were true.

headline: Burnett Pitches Better, and Rally Beats Red Sox
text: BOSTON — Through all of A. J. Burnett’s recent failings, the Yankees have supported their struggling pitcher. They took a lot of criticism for allowing Burnett to continue to start, but on Thursday night Burnett finally rewarded them for their faith.

headline: Arrest of Pair Adds to Woes of Berlusconi
text: ROME — An Italian businessman and his wife were arrested Thursday, accused by Naples prosecutors of extorting money and favors from Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi in return for what prosecutors described as “cooperation” in an investigation into a high-end prostitution ring in the southern city of Bari.

headline: City Is Subpoenaed for Files on Minority Company
text: Federal investigators, who long have found corruption in City Hall’s minority-contracting efforts, have subpoenaed the city’s files on a construction company that was paid at least $26 million in taxpayer money in the past decade.

headline: TIF Report Cheers Reformers, but Only as a Start
text: The king of Chicago’s public-policy nerds, Representative Mike Quigley, a Democrat, basked in the hype surrounding this week’s release of a report from Mayor Rahm Emanuel’s TIF Reform Panel.

headline: A Haunting Old Photographic Process Reappears
text: David Bornfriend, a San Francisco-based photographer and filmmaker, began researching wet-plate collodion, a format made famous during the Civil War by battlefield photographers, after his brother returned home from serving in the Middle East in 2007 with post-traumatic stress disorder.

headline: France: Reporter’s Phone Records Were Reviewed, Government Says
text: Interior Minister Claude Guéant confirmed Thursday for the first time that the Central Directorate of Interior Intelligence had requisitioned the telephone records of a reporter for the newspaper Le Monde in an effort to trace the source of a leak in a politically charged case. The reporter, Gérard Davet, had obtained leaked police testimony in the case, a tangled controversy over claims of tax evasion and political malfeasance involving the L’Oréal heiress Liliane Bettencourt, France’s wealthiest woman and a supporter of President Nicolas Sarkozy’s political party. Le Monde last year accused the government of violating a law protecting journalists during its investigation of the Bettencourt case. French laws protect the right of journalists to refuse to disclose the identity of confidential sources, and restrict communications surveillance to matters involving the “defense of national interests.” The government has said that any surveillance it employed in the Bettencourt case met that standard. Mr. Guéant said the government did not wiretap Mr. Davet’s telephone but did review his telephone records.

headline: A Small Iron Squatter Who’s Soon to Be Evicted
text: When construction workers begin taking apart the old Bay Bridge, they will have to contend with a squatter.

headline: A New Plan for Public Toilets Shows Promise
text: Scott James writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

headline: Tech Industry Becomes a Force in Local Politics
text: Last spring, in an effort to spur economic growth in San Francisco, Mayor Edwin M. Lee and David Chiu, president of the Board of Supervisors, engineered legislation to waive millions of dollars in taxes for technology companies like Twitter and Zynga.

headline: PGA Tour and Networks Reach Lengthy Rights Deal
text: NORTON, Mass. — The PGA Tour said Thursday that it had reached an agreement with CBS Sports and the NBC Sports Group that secured the tour’s network broadcast rights into the next decade.

headline: Highway Bill Could Face Congressional Gridlock
text: Here we go again?

headline: With the Yankees in Town, It’s Always a Boston Marathon
text: BOSTON – A weary Terry Francona slumped into his seat at the postgame news conference at Fenway Park, a few minutes before midnight on Thursday. Francona’s Red Sox had just taken 4 hours 21 minutes to lose a nine-inning game, 4-2, to the Yankees.

headline: Evert, Connors and the Significance of Sept. 2
text: Forty years ago Friday, Chris Evert and Jimmy Connors, two Americans who defined their era and helped create a tennis boom in the United States, won their first matches at the Open.

headline: The North Dakota Paradox
text: North Dakota was barely dented by the recession. Its unemployment rate never rose above 4.3 percent and sits at 3.3 percent today.

text: FRONT PAGE

headline: News Quiz | September 2, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Sept. 2, 2011
text: Today’s question was written by Susan Behrens, who is a professor at Marymount Manhattan College and the author of “Grammar: A Pocket Guide.” Her question comes from the article “The Met’s Next Blockbuster Is Expected to Stay for 10 Years.”

headline: Tormenting the Tenderfoots
text: WHO are being forced to wear schoolgirl backpacks to transport baseball gear?

headline: What to Watch on Friday
text: On Wednesday, Christina McHale scored one of the biggest upsets of the tournament, ousting the No. 8 seed Marion Bartoli in straight sets. Things don’t get any easier as the 19-year-old steps on court against the 25th-seeded Maria Kirilenko.

headline: Sept. 2, 1945 | Japan Formally Surrenders to End World War II
text: On Sept. 2, 1945, Japan formally surrendered in a formal ceremony aboard the U.S.S. Missouri, ending World War II.

headline: South Korean Police Detain Island Activists Opposed to Base
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The police on Friday detained nearly three dozen activists and villagers on the southern island of Jeju who have been camping for months to resist the construction of a naval base in their scenic seashore village.

headline: Japan Leader to Keep Nuclear Phase-Out
text: TOKYO — Japan’s new prime minister, Yoshihiko Noda, promised on Friday to keep Japan on its path of phasing out nuclear power, saying it was “unrealistic” to build any new reactors in the wake of the Fukushima nuclear crisis or to extend those at the end of their life spans.

headline: In Mexico, the Glamour of Narco-Culture
text: PERPIGNAN, France — Shaul Schwarz was among the first photographers to focus on documenting the drug wars that have ravaged the Mexican city of Juárez. Mr. Schwarz has been working in Juárez, a few yards from the border with the United States, since 2007. He can’t get the story of a city “so vicious and so close to home” out of his system.

headline: South Korea Will Allow a Buddhist Group to Visit the North
text: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea said Friday that it would allow a 37-member Buddhist delegation to visit North Korea, a sign that it might be ready to ease restrictions on civilian contacts with the North.

headline: What Are the Right and Wrong Ways to Commemorate 9/11?
text: As the 10th anniversary of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, approaches, people, organizations and institutions are gearing up to commemorate it. The question is, how? Where’s the line between respectful remembrance and crass opportunism? When are tributes meaningful and when are they excessive?

headline: Giants’ Clint Sintim Out for Year With Another Knee Injury
text: In a game in which one of the major goals was not to have someone get hurt, one of the Giants was hurt Thursday night.

headline: The Psychology of the Comeback
text: Allen Fox coaches Igor Kunitsyn, a Russian journeyman who came back from two sets down to defeat Germany’s Matthias Bachinger on Tuesday. (Kunitsyn plays Jurgen Melzer of Austria on Friday.) Fox is a former world-class player who has written “Tennis: Winning the Mental Match,” and other superb books on the psychology of tennis. He coached Pepperdine to the top of the college rankings, and passed on a lot of his coaching wisdom to Brad Gilbert, who credits Fox with helping him develop his game and his mental toughness.

headline: 2011 N.F.L. Season Previews
text: A look, via links, of the N.F.L. season previews written by Andy Benoit for The Fifth Down. If you’ve missed them, the analysis and level of detail are impressive.

headline: How a Chevy-Powered Boat Delivered Five Dutchmen From the Nazis
text: A new exhibition in the Netherlands commemorates the North Sea escape of five Dutchmen from Nazi occupation in 1944, a voyage made possible by Chevrolet power and a Hispano-Suiza racecar’s fuel tank.

headline: What Does ‘Economic Growth’ Mean for Americans?
text: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

headline: Prague Towers Offer More Than Just Views
text: Prague has many nicknames, of of which are the City of 100 Spires and the Golden City. Experience both at a new exhibition on alchemy in the Malostranska Bridge Tower on the Lesser Town side of Charles Bridge. Not only will you learn more about the golden period of alchemy and Rudolf II in Prague, you’ll get superb views of Charles Bridge and Prague Castle.

headline: Tip of the Week: An iPod Nano as an Alarm Clock
text: School is starting up again — which means many people will reluctantly have to start paying closer attention to the time. As some music lovers have discovered, the small, square iPod Nano model can also pull double duty as a wristwatch with one of the optional watchband accessories available for it. Getting to the clock function is easy — just tap the Clock icon on the Nano’s home screen—but there are other time-related functions built into the Nano that are not as obvious.

headline: Lessons Learned
text: New Yorkers came away from the 9/11 attacks with greater understanding of their country, the world and themselves.

headline: Turkey Expels Israeli Envoy in Dispute Over Raid
text: ANKARA, Turkey — Turkey said Friday that it was downgrading its diplomatic and military ties with Israel and expelling its ambassador in a display of anger at Israel’s refusal to apologize for a deadly commando raid last year on a Turkish ship bound for Gaza.

headline: London Stock Exchange Owner in Talks With Clearinghouse
text: London Stock Exchange Group confirmed Friday that it was in talks with the LCH.Clearnet Group, the latest effort by a suitor to woo the swaps clearinghouse.

headline: Perry’s Book Gives Rivals Ammunition
text: Rick Perry, the governor of Texas, talks in broad, vague terms on the campaign trail about the need to get America working again.

headline: SABMiller’s Takeover of Foster’s Gets More Hostile
text: 2:30 p.m. | Updated

headline: Workers Wearing Toeshoes
text: IN 1903, when ballet had been a prolific subject of Edgar Degas for over 30 years, an American collector, Louisine Havemeyer, asked him, “Why, monsieur, do you always do ballet dancers?” His quick reply was, “Because, madame, it is all that is left us of the combined movements of the Greeks.”

headline: Zero Job Growth Latest Bleak Sign for U.S. Economy
text: August brought no increase in the number of jobs in the United States, a signal that the economy has stalled and that inaction by policy makers carries substantial risk.

headline: Friday Reading: Getting Doctors to Wash Their Hands
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Lineup for Telluride Film Festival Is Announced
text: The Venice Film Festival started on Wednesday, at or below sea level. I headed in the other direction, to Telluride, the former mining town in Colorado whose high-altitude festival occurs every year on Labor Day. Some people — and a handful of movies — manage to be in both places at once.

headline: Here Comes the Groom
text: Start your day with our curated set of grooming products.

headline: The Beatles on the Beach
text: Beatles photos from the Astrid Kirchherr archive,.

headline: Hugh Laurie's 'St. James Infirmary'
text: Actor Hugh Laurie releases an album of 15 New Orleans blues covers, titled "Let Them Talk."

headline: Decision Fatigue
text: John Tierney doesn’t mention one form of decision fatigue with major consequences. Seriously ill patients face many choices about how to manage their conditions. Add these decisional demands to the other burdens of illness, and you have a recipe for bad outcomes. When I was going through intensive chemotherapy and radiation treatment for cancer, I eventually shut down and refused to cooperate with medical recommendations. Fortunately, I was talked out of my bad choices. Patients today are free to make their own decisions, but this freedom can be exhausting.

headline: What Would Hillary Have Done?
text: Rebecca Traister writes that Hillary Clinton’s presidency would probably not have looked so different from Obama’s. Really? Would Hillary have spent all her political capital passing a watered-down health care act? Would she have bailed out the banks and corporations? Surged in Afghanistan? Extended the Bush tax cuts? Signed a deficit-reduction act that balances the budget on the backs of the poor and working people of this country? I think not. The difference between Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama is that Clinton knows that the Republicans don’t play fair. People have a right to be bitterly disappointed, and it is only human nature to ask, “What if?”

headline: What They Think Now
text: I immediately recognized the cover photo of Jaime King and well remember the story that appeared with the original photograph in 1996. It was a disturbing portrait of exploitation and abuse, and prompted me to write a letter that was published in the magazine on March 3, 1996. My fears then were partially realized. Today, King appears diminished, less vital and — in an apparent contradiction — young and vulnerable, yet so old and weary. But I found her reflection about the photo to be positive: she has clearly matured. The portraits and updates made “Time Lapse” wonderful reading.

headline: What the Left Doesn’t Understand About Obama
text: This has been the summer that liberal discontent with Obama has finally crystallized. The frustration has been simmering for a while — through centrist appointments, bank bailouts and the defeat of the public option, to name a few examples. But it has taken the debt-ceiling standoff and the threat of a double-dip recession to create a leftist critique of the president that stuck.

headline: Dollar-Store Economy
text: Jack Hitt’s article on dollar stores missed the mark. The article focused on “gee whiz, what unusual things one can find when slumming in a dollar store.” That misses their real significance. The dollar store is the new A. & P. for many Americans. I am disappointed that The Times approached this from the perspective of an economic tourist exploring an exotic destination, rather than from the viewpoint of the underprivileged citizens who have no choice but to dwell in the land of the dollar store.

headline: Dangerous Lesions
text: Recently, I was at an outdoor concert where I sat next to a woman who was wearing a halter top. I could clearly see that she had two growths on her back that looked like ones that I had had removed because they were basal-cell carcinomas. I am not a doctor, but I felt conflicted about whether or not I should have said something to alert her. She left, and I felt guilty about not having mentioned it to her. Did I have an obligation to do so? JERI Y. GREENBERG, WASHINGTON, D.C.

headline: Questions for Carine Roitfeld
text: Before you became editor of French Vogue in 2001, you were best known for being an inspiration to Tom Ford. And in your new book, “Irreverent,” you include a handwritten note from him in which he writes that he’d like to take you out for a romantic dinner. What exactly is a romantic dinner like between a gay man and a straight woman?  Ask each woman that ever met Tom, and they will tell you that they were under the charm of Tom. O.K., Tom, unfortunately for the woman, is gay. But he is very not so gay. Even the way he touches a woman, the way he puts his hand on your back or the way he opens the car for you, he’s a gentleman. You’re dying that he likes everything you’re wearing, everything you’re doing, because his taste is very important to you. You want to seduce him all the time.

headline: How Tabloid Trainwrecks Are Reinventing Gothic Literature
text: In the blustery wilds of Suffolk County on Long Island, in a seaside hamlet that was once a thriving whaling village, a young girl is raised by a prominent family. Her father — an impulsive and reckless figure given to fits of sudden rage — had been beset by legal troubles and was sent to prison for three years. During this time, the girl is pressed into service, perhaps to help with the cost of rearing her younger siblings, and soon she is projecting her phantasmagoric doppelgänger out into the cinemas of the world.

headline: The Beatles on the Beach
text: On Saturday, April 27, 1963, the Beatles played Memorial Hall in Northwich, England —— the concert poster described them as “Hit recorders of ‘Please, Please Me.’” The next day, Paul McCartney, George Harrison and Ringo Starr flew down to Tenerife to unwind with two of their closest Hamburg pals, the graphic artist Klaus Voormann and the photographer Astrid Kirchherr. (John Lennon took his own holiday in Barcelona with the band’s manager, Brian Epstein.) For the upstart combo, it would be their first taste of the jet-set life and, in the saga of their ascent, a momentary breather about halfway up Mount Olympus. The first No. 1 record was in the bag, the next one was heading up the charts and full-blown Beatlemania was just a few months off. The island’s black sand, towering volcano and opportunities for sunstroke were as exotic to the Beatles as their newfound celebrity. But none of that notoriety followed them to Tenerife, where they stayed at the Voormann family cottage. The bandmates ran around asking the locals: “You know us? The Beatles?” — only to be met with bewilderment.

headline: Hugh Laurie Sings the Blues
text: Hugh Laurie was in pain. This is often true, but usually it’s because of self-inflicted psychic wounds. The immediate source of his torment, though, was a female voice, flat and affectless, inside a glass elevator at the Natural History Museum in London.

headline: Block Quotes: Gothic Writing, Then and Now
text: Young Conrad’s birthday was fixed for his espousals. The company was assembled in the chapel of the Castle, and everything ready for beginning the divine office, when Conrad himself was missing. Manfred, impatient of the least delay, and who had not observed his son retire, despatched one of his attendants to summon the young Prince. The servant, who had not stayed long enough to have crossed the court to Conrad’s apartment, came running back breathless, in a frantic manner, his eyes staring, and foaming at the mouth. . . . In the meantime, some of the company had run into the court, from whence was heard a confused noise of shrieks, horror, and surprise. . . .

headline: In a Quiet Period, Groupon Feels the Noise
text: Groupon’s initial public offering is about to hit some very rough turbulence.

headline: Bolt, Back in Character, Advances to 200 Final
text: DAEGU, South Korea — It was always a long shot that Usain Bolt would have a long look in the mirror after his now-notorious false start and decide that the way forward was to become a poker-faced introvert.

headline: The City Stirs | Midtown, 5:15 A.M.
text: “Never miss a chance to have sex or appear on television.” — Gore Vidal

headline: Bloomberg Cancels Radio Talk Amid Furor Over Aide
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg canceled his weekly radio appearance, scheduled for Friday morning, amid a growing outcry over his handling of a top aide’s arrest over a domestic violence complaint, said a person told of the mayor’s decision.

headline: Hope, Fear and Insomnia: Journey of a Jobless Man
text: On June 25, 2010, Frederick Deare punched out for the last time from his job driving a forklift at the Old London factory in the Bronx. That summer, everyone at the plant was being laid off: the oven operators, the assembly-line packers, the forklift drivers, the sanitation workers. Total jobs lost: 228. Old London, the snack manufacturer that invented the Cheez Doodle, was moving its operations to North Carolina. At 53, Mr. Deare, known as Freddy or Teddy Bear to his co-workers, would have to find a new job.

headline: Comparing Recessions and Recoveries: Job Changes
text: Source: Labor Department. Chart by Amanda Cox. Horizontal axis shows months. Vertical axis shows the ratio of that month’s nonfarm payrolls to the nonfarm payrolls at the start of recession. Note: Because employment is a lagging indicator, the dates for these employment trends are not exactly synchronized with National Bureau of Economic Research’s official business cycle dates.

headline: When Wheels Pile Up: Plant a Bike; Save the City
text: “In 1880, New York City removed 15,000 dead horses from its streets,” the historians Joel Tarr and Clay McShane wrote in an essay called “The Centrality of the Horse to the Nineteenth-Century American City.” Horse carcasses, they added, “were sometimes dumped with garbage into the bays or the rivers, often floating there or washing up on the beaches.”

headline: Wall St. Tumbles After Bleak Jobs Report
text: A grim report on the job market and news that major banks are facing federal lawsuits hit Wall Street on Friday, sending the broader market lower as crucial financial and industrial stocks spiraled down by more than 3 percent.

headline: Accel’s Breyer to Join News Corp. Board, as 2 Depart
text: News Corporation, which is in the midst of a phone-hacking scandal, is reshuffling the board.

headline: Curtain Calls | John Lithgow
text: In his revelatory memoir, ‘‘Drama’’ (HarperCollins, $27), John Lithgow, the consummate character actor, talks about infidelity, Oedipal striving and the awfulness of acceptance speeches.

headline: Lots of Vitriol for Fed Chief, Despite Facts
text: Attacks on the chairman of the Federal Reserve aren’t new. For years I’ve received a well-organized volley of vitriolic e-mails every time I mention Ben Bernanke. I dismissed them as missives from the lunatic fringe, at least until recently.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: Calling on the Fed
text: What I would give to be a fly on in the wall at the Federal Reserve right now, where Ben S. Bernanke is probably doing a double take on Friday’s horrible jobs report.

headline: News Corp. Board Undergoes a Shuffle
text: 7:24 p.m. | Updated The News Corporation’s board of directors underwent significant reshuffling on Friday with the departure of two long-serving members and the nomination of a new independent voice.

headline: How Are You Preparing for the First Day of School?
text: It’s that time of year again: a hint of fall is in the air, and New York City’s youngest will re-enter the halls of learning, leaving parents and caretakers in peace.

headline: E.U. Bans Syrian Oil as Protests Continue
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — European Union members escalated the pressure on Syria’s government on Friday by banning all imports of Syrian oil in response to its violent suppression of the nearly six-month-old uprising there. It was the most punitive action by the European Union to date over the crackdown in Syria, which sells nearly all its oil to Europe and relies heavily on that export income.

headline: Bank of America Loses Its Bounce
text: Bank of America shares have shed the Warren E. Buffett bounce, opening sharply lower on Friday morning after a flutter of bad news for the financial firm.

headline: G.O.P.’s New Obama Label: President Zero
text: It took the Republican National Committee exactly 94 minutes to coin a new, demeaning title for Barack Obama: President Zero.

headline: For M.L.S., Fixtures at an Exhibition
text: The world is focused over the next five days on two international game days — World Cup qualifiers, African Cup of Nations, Euro 2012 qualifiers — around the world.

headline: Spin City
text: Justin Miller, the handsome face of DFA Records and a regular fashion-event D.J., suggests a playlist to get the party started.

headline: The Bachmann Namestorm
text: Yesterday we asked for your help naming Michele Bachmann’s “currently untitled” new memoir. Below, a few of your best responses, tweeted to us at @nytmag using the hashtag #namebachmann.

headline: A Challenge for Unions in Public Opinion
text: A new Gallup poll has found that a slim majority of Americans, 52 percent, approve of labor unions and that the difference in views between how Democrats and Republicans feel toward unions has reached record levels.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Justice Dept.’s Top Officials in Pursuing the AT&T Lawsuit  |  The names of 25 government lawyers are listed on the last page of the Justice Department’s lawsuit seeking to block the proposed $39 billion merger between AT&T and T-Mobile USA.

headline: Obama Administration Abandons Stricter Air-Quality Rules
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama abandoned a contentious new air pollution rule on Friday, buoying business interests that had lobbied heavily against it, angering environmentalists who called the move a betrayal and unnerving his own top environmental regulators.

headline: A New Sideline for Serena Williams: Relationship Advice
text: When she’s not delivering aces, Serena Williams doles out relationship advice. She and her sister, Venus, were in the locker room Wednesday at the United States Open when they bumped into Caroline Wozniacki, the world No. 1 and girlfriend of the golfer, Rory McIlroy, the reigning United States Open champion from Northern Ireland.

headline: A Veteran Questions a Proposed Overhaul of Military Pensions
text: Proposed changes to the military’s retirement system have been much in the news lately. According to the Defense Business Board, a Pentagon advisory committee tasked by former Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates with finding ways to reduce the Department of Defense budget, “the current system is unsustainable and in dire need of repair.” The board proposes that the military abandon its traditional pension system in favor of a 401(k)-style contribution program.

headline: In Reykjavik, a Glittering New Home for Music
text: After the economic meltdown and a couple of ash-spewing volcanoes, Iceland still has plenty to be optimistic about.

headline: ‘Straw Dogs,’ Then and Now
text: A look at the film “Straw Dogs.”

headline: U-Turn for T.I.: From Halfway House Back to Prison
text: 1:34 p.m. | Updated The rap artist T.I. was sent back to prison Thursday after he showed up at a halfway house in Atlanta in a luxury bus with an entourage.

headline: A Helping Hand, Paid on Commission
text: Let’s say you are wading into the deep water. You think your parent or another older relative needs more care, perhaps at home, perhaps in an assisted living facility or other residence. You don’t know where to turn, which places or agencies to consider. Online, you find a referral service that can provide assistance — and it’s free.

headline: Reader Photos and Recipes: Essential Summer Dishes
text: This week, food writers for The Times shared recipes for warm-weather dishes they consider essential eating. The Times asked readers to chime in by submitting the best dishes they’ve made since Memorial Day. The first batch of photos and recipes is up, with more to come. The collection includes the above photo by Nikki Gardner of Massachusetts, who submitted a recipe for summer squash noodles with tomato-basil cream sauce (the sauce, she wrote, was inspired by recipes from Alice Waters and Lauren Ulm of the blog VeganYumYum).

headline: Randall Kennedy’s “The Persistence of the Color Line”; Ginia Bellafante on the Big City Book Club; best-seller news
text: This week, Harvard scholar Randall Kennedy discusses racial politics in America in his new book, “The Persistence of the Color Line”; columnist Ginia Bellafante talks about the new Big City Book Club at the Times; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: German Farmer Captures a Famous Runaway
text: Yvonne, the bovine runaway that confounded German authorities and tickled the funny bone of the international press, was back on the farm on Friday after three months of evading capture in a Bavarian forest.

headline: TimesCast | Banks Face Mortgage Lawsuits
text: September 2, 2011 - Lawsuits by a federal agency are expected to accuse the banks of misrepresenting the quality of mortgage securities they assembled and sold at the housing bubble's peak.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Sept. 2
text: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include dogs in bars, a dinner in white, and Tropical Storm Irene.

headline: Samurai Shopper | Hair Cares
text: Not long ago the Samurai popped into Sally Hershberger’s Downtown Salon to slap palms with the superstar stylist Matt Fugate. How can you tell a superstar stylist from the rest? He’s the one with the worst hairstyle in the place. The late John Sahag taught me that and it’s true. So here’s Matt with his hair bunched up like a pregnant Milk Dud protruding from his nape. After some mutual what’s ups, Matt cops a feel of my hair and goes glum.

headline: A Texas Man’s Campaign Results in Recall of 241,000 BMW 3 Series Models for Faulty Tail Lamps
text: BMW is recalling almost a quarter of a million vehicles as the result of a Texas man’s request that the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration investigate what he thought was a safety problem.

headline: Choosing Cinematheque Over Cineplex
text: ONE way to trace the history of the movies is to look at the evolution of alternative cinemas — to consider, in other words, how an inventive approach to showing films can foster a new way of understanding them.

headline: A One-Touch SOS for BlackBerry Users
text: It is a time of rapid-fire earthquakes and hurricanes. Wouldn’t you like a panic button in your pocket?

headline: AOL Says Arrington No Longer Works at TechCrunch
text: 6:38 p.m. | Updated

headline: Weekend Fare
text: For the first time since it opened more than 25 years ago, Union Square Café, will begin serving brunch this weekend, from 11 a.m. to 2:30 p.m. on Saturday and Sunday. Carmen Quagliata’s menu features traditional brunch fare and dishes inspired by produce available at the nearby Greenmarket. 21 East 16th Street (between Broadway and Fifth Avenue), Reservations can be made at (212) 243-4020 or on Open Table.

headline: The Too Black, Too White Presidency
text: The next time you see Barack Obama gliding into a White House press conference, take note of that jazzy walk. It is a dead ringer for the strut that was the bearing of choice among ­inner-city cool guys in the 1960s, when Barry Obama was still a tyke growing up in the exotic precincts of Hawaii and Indonesia. The Obama glide represents his embrace of a black aesthetic that was not his by circumstance of birth. It speaks on an intimate frequency to African-­American men, who have been smiling in recognition and rating it for style ever since he stepped into the national spotlight. President Obama is acutely aware of how to deploy the physical self to excellent effect. If we looked back closely at 2008, we would no doubt notice him amping up the glide for black audiences and dialing it back elsewhere.

headline: Steven Millhauser’s Ghost Stories
text: Among the various impostures of book reviewing, the suggestion that a book is encountered in a vacuum of preconceptions is one that’s bound to be debunked when faced with the phrase “New and Selected Stories.” Presented with a career capstone on behalf of a writer good enough to receive the honor, yet not only still walking the earth but also still adding goodies to the pile — that’s no time to play dumb. If you weren’t already reading the fellow, what business would you have weighing in now?

headline: Cuomo Calls for Volunteers to Clean Up After Irene
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Friday a statewide volunteer effort aimed at cleaning up the damage in upstate communities that were hit hardest by Tropical Storm Irene.

headline: From New Haven to Northern Montana
text: In one chapter of her new memoir, “This Is Not the Ivy League,” Mary Clearman Blew splices the story of a shooting spree in Moscow, Idaho, into an account of raising her children while going to graduate school: “When cornered, I lashed out, if not with a rifle, and then turned the blame on myself.” This is extreme, to say the least, and Blew admits it. But she insists the comparison holds.

headline: Here’s Looking at You, Katydid
text: In the realm of insects, unlike in the realm of mammals, say, there’s plenty of room at the bottom. Room for millions of species — and quintillions of individuals — to coexist, and room for biologists to make significant discoveries about them by peering closely at their behaviors and their brains. In “Sex on Six Legs,” the biologist Marlene Zuk argues that insects — because they are both unlike us and, in surprising ways, like us — provide excellent fodder for studying the relative value of inheritance versus environment, the evolution of personality, the definition of language and the downside of growing bigger brains.

headline: Gender-Free
text: Hilton Als, a writer for The New Yorker, probably did Justin Vivian Bond a disservice by contributing the preface to Bond’s novella-length childhood memoir, “Tango.” That’s not to say that the preface is bad — quite the opposite. It is poetic and affecting, and it features revealing descriptions of Bond, a transgender singer-songwriter and performance artist with a fervent following among New York City’s avant-garde. “Justin Vivian has learned to dance with V’s self,” Als writes, “to wear the heels and the suit that fit V’s being, all cut and formed to suit V’s soul, having earned it as so many of us earn it, through being brutalized and suppressed and sometimes through love, too.” (“V” is Bond’s preferred, gender-free pronoun.)

headline: Why Good Writers Aren’t Good Talkers
text: There’s a hall-of-mirrors quality to writing about a book by a writer who writes about books. For example, “By candlelight a goat is ladylike.” That’s me quoting Arthur Krystal quoting A. Roger Ekirch quoting an old French adage.

headline: Daughters Under Duress
text: The women in Elissa Schappell’s new story collection ought to come with a warning label. Danger: Contents under pressure. Emotionally sensitive compounds may be present. Toxic sentiments could be released if disturbed or shaken. Prone to self-destruct. Unprotected contact may result in shock, burns, emotional distress or, in rare cases, death. Keep hands out of reach at all times, because also: These women bite.

headline: In Africa, a Child’s Nightmare Becomes a Writer’s Dream
text: “I’m going to write an Awful Book and this time it really will be about you,” Alexandra Fuller promises when her mother complains over a favorite walking stick’s being broken in a battle with a poisonous snake. Another Awful Book, as far as her mother is concerned. Fuller had not yet been forgiven for publishing the first one in 2001, the intoxicating “Don’t Let’s Go to the Dogs Tonight.”

headline: The Sugary Secret of Self-Control
text: Ever since Adam and Eve ate the apple, Ulysses had himself tied to the mast, the grasshopper sang while the ant stored food and St. Augustine prayed “Lord make me chaste — but not yet,” individuals have struggled with self-control. In today’s world this virtue is all the more vital, because now that we have largely tamed the scourges of nature, most of our troubles are self-inflicted. We eat, drink, smoke and gamble too much, max out our credit cards, fall into dangerous liaisons and become addicted to heroin, cocaine and e-mail.

headline: Living the Varieties of Virtual Experience
text: In the first lecture from “The Varieties of Religious Experience,” entitled “Religion and Neurology,” William James criticizes as “simple-minded” what he calls “medical materialism,” the system of thought that “finishes up St. Paul by calling his vision on the road to Damascus a discharging lesion of the occipital cortex, he being an epileptic” or that “snuffs out St. Teresa as an hysteric, St. Francis of Assisi as an hereditary degenerate.” Such thinking, James said, isn’t strictly wrong, but extremely wrongheaded, since all thoughts and feelings, including those of the medical materialists themselves, are “organically conditioned” and thus equally prey to being dismissed. James concluded that St. Paul very likely did have a seizure, but that this had no bearing on the spiritual significance of his visions, which needed to be judged pragmatically, by the extent to which they offered “delight” or “good consequential fruits for life.”

headline: The Man Who Ruled the Lodz Ghetto
text: The diabolically well-planned implementation of genocide that was the Holocaust has been narrated many times over, in the form of fiction and non-fiction. Indeed, it has been argued that the Holocaust, like everything else in our mercantile culture, has become commodified (“There’s no business like Shoah business”), and the existence of an item like the “Holocaust Survivor Cookbook” as well as the fetishistic value placed on Nazi memorabilia (this past July an ultra-Orthodox Jewish buyer snapped up a collection of writings by Dr. Josef Mengele for $245,000) would suggest that there is some uneasy truth to the charge.

headline: Was Coco Chanel a Nazi Agent?
text: Gabrielle Chanel — better known as Coco — was a wretched human being. Anti-Semitic, homophobic, social climbing, opportunistic, ridiculously snobbish and given to sins of phrase-making like “If blonde, use blue perfume,” she was addicted to morphine and actively collaborated with the Germans during the Nazi occupation of Paris. And yet, her clean, modern, kinetic designs, which brought a high-society look to low-regarded fabrics, revolutionized women’s fashion, and to this day have kept her name synonymous with the most glorious notions of French taste and élan.

headline: Fate, Feathers and Death
text: Sometime in the late 1990s, Anders Brekhus Nilsen started drawing little comic strips about birds: tiny doodled finches with dots for eyes, chatting about seeds and philosophical inquiries. In 1999 he put together a bunch of those strips as a photocopied comic book he called “Big Questions.” A few more issues followed, in which he started imagining more about the birds’ personalities and establishing who was responsible for the crumbs that fed them: an old, bent-over woman, living in a shack with her idiot grandson.

headline: A Piece of the Action
text: The big question left hanging at the end of THE CUT (Reagan Arthur/Little, Brown, $25.99), George Pelecanos’s latest Washington, D.C., crime novel, is whether he can keep his cocky new hero from flaming out. At 29, Spero Lucas, an unlicensed investigator for a criminal defense attorney (and anyone else who’ll give him a cut of the action), is considerably younger and friskier than the heavy-lidded private eyes who have imprinted their world-weary stamp on this genre. His values are also different, shaped by the street culture of his tough neighborhood and by his experiences as a Marine in Iraq. Even his musical tastes are more contemporary. (No moody blues for this guy, who prefers reggae, ska and dub.) “There are certain bars I don’t hang in,” Lucas explains. “I’m not gonna sit around and have drinks with people who are, you know, ironic.” He’s also man enough to put flowers on his father’s grave and pay regular visits to his mother.

headline: ‘Class Warfare’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Intimate Art
text: To the Editor:

headline: Missing From the Picture
text: To the Editor:

headline: Paperback Row
text: MY HOLLYWOOD,  by Mona Simpson (Vintage Contemporaries, $15.95.) This novel of manners about modern motherhood revolves around Claire, a Guggenheim-­winning composer and new mother living in Los Angeles, and Lola, a mother of five from the Philippines hired by Claire as a nanny. Shifting between the perspectives of these two women, Simpson highlights clashes of culture and class.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE LEFTOVERS,  by Tom Perrotta (St. Martin’s, $25.99.) In Perrotta’s novelistic version of the biblical prophecy known as the rapture, Hindus, Buddhists and Muslims as well as Christians mysteriously disappear.

headline: Inside the List
text: READING SEPT. 11: After the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, Graydon Carter, the editor of Vanity Fair, declared the end of irony. It may not also have been the end of inanity on the best-­seller list, but it was the beginning of a new interest in the Muslim world among Americans previously more preoccupied with Anne Heche’s “Call Me Crazy” and the television psychic John Edward’s “Crossing Over,” to name two top sellers for the week that ended Sept. 8. At first, Americans seemed too stunned to go to the bookstore, but by Sept. 22, “Germs,” an account of biological weaponry and America’s readiness against it by the New York Times reporters Judith Miller, Stephen Engelberg and William Broad, had hit the hardcover list (no doubt thanks in part to the anthrax scare that killed five Americans and landed a threatening letter laced with white powder in Miller’s own mailbox), while titles like Ahmed Rashid’s "Taliban" and Yossef Bodansky’s “Bin Laden” started climbing the paperback list.

headline: Up Front: Brent Staples
text: Brent Staples, who reviews Randall Kennedy’s “Persist­ence of the Color Line” in this issue, is working on a history of mixed-race identity in the United States. “One of the things that interested me in the last campaign,” Staples wrote in an e-mail, “was the byplay having to do with Obama’s racial origins. It struck me that the press and the public generally reserve the ‘mixed race’ label for the offspring of racially mixed marriages. But there is a paradox here. Obama, half black and half white, is, genetically speaking, not much whiter than I am, even though my nearest white forebears were Virginia slave owners who lived and died in the 19th century. Similarly, there are people who think of themselves as black who are, genetically speaking, 70 percent white or more.”

headline: From Scroll to Screen
text: Something very important and very weird is happening to the book right now: It’s shedding its papery corpus and transmigrating into a bodiless digital form, right before our eyes. We’re witnessing the bibliographical equivalent of the rapture. If anything we may be lowballing the weirdness of it all.

headline: Is the New York Times Biased Against Religion?
text: My column urging journalists to be less squeamish about questioning candidates on their religious beliefs drew a heated response – some pro, more con, many stimulated by conservative pundits, a few not suitable for a family newspaper. Among the readers who took issue was Wilburn Smith III, a lawyer in Laguna Niguel, Calif. Our e-mail exchange this week is excerpted below with Mr. Smith’s permission.

headline: Using an Inheritance to Teach Your Problem Child a Lesson
text: PARENTS want to raise their children to be independent and successful and to use whatever resources they have to give their offspring a leg up in life.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Bloody Wolverines, Vampires and Baked Goods
text: Our Best Sellers lists are filled with movement this week: The deluxe edition of WE3, by Grant Morrison and Frank Quitely, enters at No. 1 on the hardcover list with their compelling and beautifully illustrated tale about household pets turned into lethal weapons. There’s also a particularly bloody Wolverine story by the novelist Charlie Huston at No. 6, which introduces the X-Man to a new foe named Contagion. Fan reaction was not kind. On IGN.com, one review declared, “Stay as far away from this book as possible” and gave it a 1.5 rating out of 10.

headline: Fatal Distraction
text: Zero job growth, with unemployment still at nosebleed levels. Meanwhile, the interest rate on 10-year US bonds is down to 2.04%, and it’s negative on inflation-protected securities.

headline: About That Inheritance
text: Paul Sullivan, in his Wealth Matters column this week, writes about an issue many parents — no matter their wealth — deal with: how to encourage their children to grow into independent adults. The issue gets more complicated when money is involved.

headline: Across the Hall, Diversity of Incomes
text: MARIETTA HILL lives in a luxurious studio in one of Manhattan’s newest rental high-rises.

headline: PETA Aims Campaign at an Older Audience
text: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, the organization known as PETA, is aiming a new campaign about the treatment of circus elephants at older Americans.

headline: The Bright Side of Unemployment?
text: On Thursday the Heldrich Center for Workforce Development released its latest report on the hundreds of unemployed workers it has been following (and surveying) for two years. As you might expect from the report’s title — “Out of Work and Losing Hope: The Misery and Bleak Expectations of American Workers” — the report’s findings are discouraging.

headline: Venus Williams Brings Attention to Sjogren’s Syndrome
text: Before this week, many people had probably never heard of Sjogren’s syndrome, one of the most prevalent autoimmune disorders. But the recent announcement by tennis star Venus Williams that she was suffering from fatigue and other symptoms related to Sjogren’s has brought needed attention to a troubling condition.

headline: ‘Sex on Six Legs’
text: CHAPTER 1

headline: For the Recently Widowed, Some Big Financial Pitfalls to Avoid
text: There are few more wrenching events in life than losing your spouse.

headline: The Conservative Hot Tub Time Machine
text: I was struck by a passage in David Brooks’s column today:

headline: On Dutch Game Show, Competing for Cash Before Being Deported
text: It sounds like a cruel joke: a game show in the Netherlands that pits failed asylum seekers against one another in a test of their mastery of the country’s language, history and culture, with the prize being a little extra pocket money to take back home after the Dutch government shows all of them the door.

headline: On ‘Project Runway,’ Two Strikes and You’re Out
text: This week’s challenge on “Project Runway” was to create an “avant-garde look” based on a piece of artwork the designers would collaborate on with young students from the Harlem School of the Arts.

headline: Steve Jobs Changed Games, Too, Without Trying
text: Playing Angry Birds the other day, I was struck by what I no longer play: Xbox and PlayStation. Having children has something to do with that. So does Steve Jobs.

headline: ‘Cocktail Hour Under the Tree of Forgetfulness’
text: Nicola Fuller of Central Africa Learns to Fly

headline: The Best Financial Advice for Widows
text: In this week’s Your Money column, I took the best shot I could in 1,400 words or so at helping widows avoid the financial pitfalls that so many of them fall into. They need not rush into making financial decisions, they should think hard about housing, they should not be a “purse” for anyone and they should be wary of blindly following financial orders left by their dead husbands.

headline: How to Know When the River is Rising
text: Consistent with the predictions of climate science, we seem to have entered an era of erratic weather and rising weather extremes. We are only halfway through 2011 and it’s already been a crazy weather year — the third such year in a row. The science offers us no reason to believe this situation is going to get better, so it is time to start thinking about ways to cope.

headline: The Caucus | No Lull in Partisanship
text: Jackie Calmes on the dysfunction in Washington after the fight over the timing of the President Obama's jobs speech. Also, a look at the heath care records of three governors running for president.

headline: One City’s Plague Years, in Small Details
text: SAN FRANCISCO

headline: On a Manhattan Rooftop, Talking Tail Fins With the Designer of the Cadillac Ciel
text: After its debut at Pebble Beach last month, the Cadillac Ciel concept has been on a whistle-stop tour en route to the Frankfurt auto show, turning up in Michigan on Monday and New York on Thursday. The car was displayed on the rooftop of a gallery building here in Chelsea, against a backdrop of wooden water towers and blue September skies.

headline: Ravenous | Thit Heo Kho
text: In this new column, Monique Truong, author of “The Book of Salt” and “Bitter in the Mouth,” shares food stories and recipes from her kitchen table.

headline: Caucus Video: Dysfunction in Washington Continues, Health Care Records vs. Campaign Rhetoric
text: Jackie Calmes on the dysfunction in Washington after the fight over the timing of the President Obama’s jobs speech. Also, a look at the health care records of three governors running for president.

headline: A Shorter Charlie Parker Festival Is Rescheduled
text: Postponed last weekend because of inclement weather, the Charlie Parker Jazz Festival will be pared back to one day with a smaller lineup later this month, the City Parks Foundation said on Thursday.

headline: Wellington, New Zealand’s Flyover Capital, a Must-Stop
text: IT was a Saturday night in Wellington, New Zealand, and the denizens of Cuba Street were proving that the ’80s aren’t dead. A performance group decked out in unitards, Lycra G-strings, leg warmers and fluorescent wigs was dancing almost in rhythm to tunes like “Pour Some Sugar on Me” and “Like a Virgin,” occasionally inspiring the crowd to join in. Farther down Cuba Street, clutches of the young and restless spilled out along the pedestrian mall on their way from bar to restaurant to cafe, many ending up at nightspots like the Matterhorn to catch the latest hot D.J. from Ireland or Ethiopia. In the middle of the mall, one of the city’s signature landmarks, the Bucket Fountain, dropped water from one bucket to another and onto passers-by, causing them to shriek and jump into one another’s arms to dodge the spray.

headline: Wellington’s Revival
text: Once a flyover city, Wellington has become a tourist draw in its own right.

headline: In Bollywood, Female Directors Find New Respect
text: Mumbai, India

headline: StellaService Revises Airlines’ Hurricane Grades
text: StellaService, a customer research firm that says it provides “mystery shoppers on steroids,” has issued a mea culpa to some big airlines. The firm concedes that it made some mistakes while ranking carriers’ responses to inquiries sent via Twitter, as Hurricane Irene approached.

headline: Sorting Through the Mystique of the Morgan
text: FEW motor vehicles have remained as true to their heritage as those made in England by Morgan Motor Cars. The new 3-Wheeler model, which the company has promised will arrive in American showrooms at the end of this year, may be the purest expression yet.

headline: 2 Wheels or 4? Let’s Just Split the Difference
text: Malvern Link, England“NOT everything good has to be an iPod or iPad,” said Charles Morgan, the dashing chairman of the Morgan Motor Company. “Brand new ideas are wonderful when they happen, but sometimes there’s good in older ones, too.”

headline: Opera Recalls A Hero’s Life, Love and Song
text: HAVING coined the phrase “the banality of evil,” Hannah Arendt went on to suggest that the most heinous crimes have often been committed by morally desensitized ordinary people. The inverse may be equally true: that “ordinary” heroes like Rick Rescorla, who saved almost 2,700 lives on Sept. 11, 2001, only to lose his own, are the yang to Arendt’s yin, demonstrating what you might call the profundity of virtue.

headline: Making Vegetables the Meal

headline: The Package
text: Yesterday, while riding the N train uptown, I started chatting with a young woman I knew to be a model. Of course she was: the elongated body, the strawberry-blonde hair, the pale, vague face.

headline: Letters: When Teenagers Fly Alone
text: To the Editor: Re the Practical Traveler column (Aug. 28), minors traveling alone should have a mobile phone and a debit card, and should be briefed about going through security, changing planes, etc. If they are reasonably mature teenagers, they should be able to handle it just fine. I’ve let my 12- and 14-year-olds travel unaccompanied, and will probably do so again. No way should I have to pay an extra $200 for my kid to go to camp.

headline: Lessons of a Daybreak Rider
text: TO begin my cross-country cycling trip, I spent a day and a half on the Oregon coast, climbing to witness glorious vistas above the Pacific. Then I rode east up the verdant corridor alongside the Columbia River Gorge, the river itself keeping me company as I made my way into sun-blanched wheat country. I turned north through the Palouse region in eastern Washington, where the undulating hills and scorching heat nearly wore me out, and made it to Spokane, where the world turned green again. My stay in Idaho was brief — I crossed the panhandle — though I stopped to relax for a day on the beach at Sandpoint, where you can look out over Lake Pend Oreille at the distant hills of a national forest.

headline: Restaurant Report: El Real Tex Mex in Houston
text: In the darkness of the Montrose neighborhood of Houston, the blaring neon Art Deco sign of a 1930s former movie theater stretches high into the sky. Its bright letters now spell out El Real Tex Mex.

headline: Jewels of Olmsted’s Unspoiled Midwest
text: FEW people can claim to know America as deeply as Frederick Law Olmsted did. During a long, full and peripatetic life (1822-1903), he crisscrossed the country by rail, stagecoach, horseback and on foot. “I was born for a traveler,” he once said.

headline: Charleston’s (Now) Great Hall
text: ON the June morning when the Great Hall at the Charleston City Market, in Charleston, S.C., reopened to the public after an 18-month renovation, spotting the locals amid the vacationing throngs was easy. While the outnumbered Charlestonians tended to favor muted office attire over the kaleidoscopic cruisewear of some tourists, what truly set them apart as they entered the overhauled, 204-year-old structure was their amazed expressions.

headline: Sharpton Explains Silence in Strauss-Kahn Case

headline: Sept. 4 — Sept. 10
text: Art

headline: The Jam | Henrik Vibskov
text: This week’s playlist — which the Jam’s Sean Hanratty calls “atypical” — comes from the Danish designer Henrik Vibskov, who is known primarily for his untraditional, fantastical and almost childlike take on fashion. But Hanratty says that Vibskov’s “wildy inventive talents” extend far beyond just clothing. “I have always had such a love for his work, but even more because of his varied interests and artistic nature,” says Hanratty of the established artist whose autumn-winter 2009 show featured models donning oversize Amish hats while powering black and white striped, human-size hamster wheels in an echoing warehouse outside of Copenhagen. His collection was called Human Laundry. “He is an interdisciplinarian and renaissance man in the truest sense,” Hanratty says. Vibskov also drums for the Danish electro outfit Trentemoller. His new unisex fragrance line, which will be introduced during New York Fashion Week, is called Type. “It reflects geographical locale rather than specific mood,” says Hanratty of the three scents, each called Type A, B and C. “I knew, given his varied interests, that I would get a very atypical selection.”

headline: Video: Out this Week
text: X-MEN: FIRST CLASS  In this origins appendage to the comic book franchise, two lives unfold in fateful parallel: in 1950s New York the future Professor X (Laurence Belcher) grows up amid wealth and plenty, while in Soviet-dominated Poland the boy who will become Magneto (Bill Milner) lives in want. Eventually they become James McAvoy and Michael Fassbender (on their way to evolving into Patrick Stewart and Ian McKellen). Matthew Vaughn directed; with Kevin Bacon, Rose Byrne and Oliver Platt. “Like ‘Mad Men,’ this new ‘X-Men’ indulges in period nostalgia as it gazes into the future, using the backdrop of the cold war (and its turtlenecks) to explore how the past informs the present (while also blowing stuff up),” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times in June. (Fox, Blu-ray $39.99, DVD $29.98, PG-13)
