headline: Potential Awaits Its Moment
text: DECADES have gone by, but all around Mott Haven in the South Bronx, certain physical characteristics provide an echo of the bad years in the 1960s and ’70s. Of the scores of lots emptied by fires and neglect back then, some have been transformed into lush community gardens, and some have been rebuilt into tidy subsidized town houses by nonprofit developers. Others are just empty, with signs on their fences advertising developments that never materialized.

headline: My Kailua
text: WALKING to the beach with my family on a hot Kailua afternoon, let’s say 1972. My toy foam surfboard clip-clopping against my knees, towel scratching my neck, rubber slippers squeaking on steamy blacktop. Around the corner of Kuuala Street, across Kalaheo Avenue, then down the skinny beach path, hugging  a cinderblock wall under a thick, shady row of octopus trees and bougainvillea. Footfalls echoing on packed dirt.

headline: Power to the People, but Quietly
text: IN 1967 a young Swedish journalist named Ingrid Dahlberg traveled to New York to interview the black militant activist Stokely Carmichael for the Swedish National Broadcast Company. As she sat in the home of his mother, Mabel, she found herself unable to make the older woman feel at ease on film. Suddenly Carmichael, who had met Ms. Dahlberg on a Scandinavian book tour several months earlier, and who had popularized the term “black power” the previous year, rose from his seat and grabbed the microphone. With the camera running, he gently prodded his mother into recalling the struggles of her husband, who had died but in his lifetime attributed his constant layoffs during Carmichael’s childhood to the prevailing racial biases of the era.

headline: Boldface Name Is Added to Upset List
text: For much of her third-round match at the United States Open on Friday, Maria Sharapova played with all the outward joy of someone watching her car being repossessed. For every great shot and gritty turnaround she fashioned and celebrated with a pumped fist, she inevitably followed with a flurry of errors that brought the agonized look back to her face.

headline: On the Fringe, With Benefits
text: “HEY, look out!” cried a man on the street as he grabbed an elderly woman from the path of a bicyclist whizzing down the steep slope of West 181st Street, toward Riverside Drive. The cyclist was gone in a flash, trailed by a few choice expletives from the pedestrians in his wake. No one was hurt, yet there was plenty of harrumphing on the sidewalk. People gathered to commiserate, to make sure the woman was O.K., and to see if anyone needed help carrying packages up the hill.

headline: One on One: Cole Stryker, Author of ‘Epic Win for Anonymous’
text: Cole Stryker, a freelance writer and media consultant living in New York, spent years digging into Internet culture and communities, both as a participant and as a blogger covering viral phenomena. He’s the author of a new book called “Epic Win for Anonymous: How 4chan’s Army Conquered the Web.” He discussed with me what it’s like exploring the seedy underbelly of the Internet, the rise of Anonymous, and why it and 4chan, widely considered one of the darkest and most subversive corners of the Internet, may be one of the most important and influential creations to emerge from the modern Web.

headline: ‘Straw Dogs,’ Stirring Up Trouble Again
text: LIKE the children poking at scorpions in the opening shots of “The Wild Bunch” Sam Peckinpah knew how to stir things up. In 1971, two years after that exhilarating and phenomenally bloody western made him one of the most famous — or infamous — directors in America, Peckinpah took a crew to the Cornish countryside and came back with a movie called “Straw Dogs,” which upset audiences in a new, and perhaps more intimate, way.

headline: ‘Big Brother’ Triumphs on a Night of Preseason Football

Of the nonfootball players, “Big Brother” on CBS (one of two network programs not in repeats) was the night’s victor, according to Nielsen estimates. CBS finished the night in first place in overall audience and won the 18- to 49-year-old category most coveted by advertisers.

headline: The Little Bullies Are the Worst
text: On my daily walk to the subway, I pass a schoolyard where a gang of 10- and 11-year-old boys taunts me by pointing and shouting: “Botox! Botox!” I am not sure whether they think I need Botox, or are trying to tell me I look 10 years younger than my actual age. At any rate, I haven’t come up with an adequate response, and I hope you can help.

To the chair’s back is affixed a jointed metal arm, possibly on loan from a desk lamp. At the end of the arm, where the bulb and shade would have gone, hangs instead a sparkly gold motorcycle helmet, a vintage, visorless number with a chin strap.

Bank of America, Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase, Deutsche Bank, Citigroup, Barclays and Nomura are among the defendants in the suits, brought by the Federal Housing Finance Agency, which oversees Fannie and Freddie. Read more »

headline: Reaching the Heights
text: To get pictures like the ones in this week’s cover story — a photo portfolio of ironworkers 70-plus stories off the ground at One World Trade Center — you have to do more than ride a couple hoists, climb a couple flights of temporary stairs and then open the camera shutter. You have to decide a year earlier that you want to get to the top, and then spend months persuading the Port Authority to let you do so. Then your photographer has to take two five-hour Occupational Safety and Health Administration classes devoted to construction-site safety, and a four-hour fall safety-awareness class. (Otherwise, how would you know that you really don’t want to be tethered to anything that can’t hold at least 10 times your weight? Because falling has the effect of making you heavier.) Finally, you have to go back-and-forth with the Port Authority for days to make sure you’re on the building at the very beginning of a new two-floors-per-fortnight cycle, before the safety “cocoon” goes up, so your photographer can get the best possible views of the ironworkers against the skyline.

headline: In a Marathon, Young Advances
text: Donald Young has long been burdened by the lofty expectations that came with being the youngest-ever world junior number one at age 16. Pegged as a talented underachiever who flailed due to poor coaching, the Chicago native went a long way to silencing his critics on court 17 Friday, showing stamina and heart in a dramatic, potentially career-changing, four-hour, 21-minute victory over the No. 14 seed, Stanislas Wawrinka, 7-6, 3-6, 2-6, 6-3, 7-6 (1).

headline: Huge Teeth and Teenie-Weenie Bikinis

headline: Albacore Deserves a Little Extra Attention
text: Albacore, which I write about this week in City Kitchen, is quite delicious when it is fresh, but most of it ends up in cans. When buying canned, it is a good idea to look for albacore that comes from small boats that take smaller fish: tastier, sweeter and lower in mercury. These cans are usually marketed by cooperatives, and contain no additives, like soy or vegetable broth. And at the risk of sounding un-American, generally speaking, better-quality canned tuna comes from elsewhere, like Italy or Spain. Imported tuna belly, ventresca, packed in olive oil, tends to be pricey, best thought of as a delicacy rather than a commonplace lunchbox item.

headline: Group Says It Has New Evidence of Cisco’s Misdeeds in China
text: SAN FRANCISCO — An advocacy group that accuses Cisco Systems of aiding the Chinese government in monitoring and apprehending members of the banned Falun Gong organization said Friday that it had new evidence to suggest that Cisco specifically tailored its technology for that purpose.

headline: A Queen Pushes Out a King, Squashes a Jack
text: The turnout at the second World Youth Congress in Opatija, Croatia, last month was disappointing. This was partly explained by the tournament’s proximity to the 23rd European Youth Team Championships, held in Albena, Bulgaria, from July 13 to 23.

headline: Dr. King’s Legacy, From Different Angles
text: To the Editor:

headline: The President’s Speech
text: To the Editor:

headline: How to Find the Best Prices for Your Used Tech
text: Maybe it’s anticipation for the new iPhone 5, but something has electronics trade-in sites coming out of the walls. They pretty much all offer the same proposition: the best price for your used electronics. They can’t all be right, which leaves it to you to find the sites, enter your data and sort out the results. Hardly worth the $2 you’d get for a fourth-generation iPod Shuffle.

headline: Reviewing the Morgan 3-Wheeler
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Jamie Lincoln Kitman reviews the Morgan 3-Wheeler, a spirited if anachronistic slice of automotive design unveiled earlier this year at the Geneva auto show.

headline: Genetically Modified Food
text: To the Editor:

headline: Podcast: Job Creation, Cantor Fitzgerald and Keynes
text: The government’s report on hiring, which showed no gain in jobs in August, provided fresh evidence that the recovery has fizzled without ever gaining momentum.

headline: Brian Dennehy as a Troublemaker, Times Two
text: STRATFORD, Ontario — Brian Dennehy is making mischief all over the place at the Stratford Shakespeare Festival this summer. I refer not to the actor himself, of course, but to the two contrasting miscreants he’s portraying onstage here in the fine productions of Shakespeare’s “Twelfth Night” and Harold Pinter’s “Homecoming” that are among the highlights of the company’s season.

headline: Why Wireless Markets Are Concentrated
text: In its suit to block AT&T’s $39 billion purchase of T-Mobile, the Justice Department leans heavily on the argument that consolidated market power is bad for consumers. More companies in an industry mean more competition and all the benefits that flow from competition — lower prices, more choices and more innovation.

headline: Clip From 'Straw Dogs'
text: A scene from Sam Pekinpah's 1971 film "Straw Dogs."

headline: Struggling to Keep Up With Those Mormons
text: The new Broadway musical “The Book of Mormon” has been setting box office records, and this has been the best summer yet for the long-running hits “Wicked” and “The Lion King.” But this blockbuster bounty has not trickled down to everything on Broadway; several major musicals have struggled to fill seats during an especially lucrative time of the year, with some shows closing, while others are bracing for the traditionally slow-selling fall.

headline: Apple’s Unusual Hunt for a Missing iPhone
text: 9:58 p.m. | Updated  Revised throughout to reflect new information about the search for the phone.

headline: Clip: 'Straw Dogs' (2011)
text: A scene from the 2011 remake of "Straw Dogs."

headline: Rain From Gulf Storm Expected to Cause Flooding
text: NEW ORLEANS — A slow-moving and soggy storm that has been dawdling in the Gulf of Mexico for days is expected to come ashore this weekend, bringing rainfall so heavy that officials say excessive flooding is all but inevitable in areas along the coast.

headline: Euro 2012 Qualifying: If You Took San Marino Getting 10 Goals, You Lost
text: No one, well, almost no one, is pining for the days of the Soviet Union. But you have to say this, the dissolution of the original Evil Empire also unleashed a cascade of new nations. Wonderful for those peoples, but for European soccer, it has injected creatures beyond the cliched minnows — plankton, if you will — into a sea already inhabited by the likes of Andorra, San Marino and Liechtenstein.

headline: Excerpt: 'Sons of Anarchy'
text: Katey Sagal in a scene from the season premiere of "Sons of Anarchy."

headline: ‘Straw Dogs,’ Then and Now
text: A clip from the 1971 version of “Straw Dogs” and one from the 2011 remake.

headline: Arizona’s G.O.P. Primary Stays Put, for Now
text: Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona said Friday that she would not move up the state’s Republican presidential primary to Jan. 31, a carefully watched decision that would have led Iowa to move its caucuses and New Hampshire its primary to immediately after New Year’s Day.

headline: Pre-Emptive Moves
text: It’s tough to make plans. We’re all so busy, no? Have you tried to schedule a simple lunch lately? Who has time? And the second you put it on the calendar you remember that other thing that absolutely can not be rescheduled. Or someone reminds you.

headline: AT&T Plans to Woo U.S. And Fight It
text: WASHINGTON — AT&T plans to approach the Justice Department to discuss conditions, including the sale of assets or the transfer of subscribers to other companies, that would allow its merger with T-Mobile to be completed, people close to the transaction said Friday.

headline: One Eye on the Door, the Other on His Photography
text: BERLIN

headline: No Testing for H.G.H. Before Start of Season
text: The N.F.L. told teams in a memo Friday that blood testing for human growth hormone, which was conditionally part of the new collective bargaining agreement completed last month, would not begin with the start of the regular season next week. The league said the players union had concerns about the validity of the tests used by the World Anti-Doping Agency.

headline: Doing Unto Others, Off and on the Tennis Court
text: Last Saturday was overcast and forbidding. Hurricane Irene was supposed to strike late that night, and there had already been an afternoon rain delay at the New Haven Open, a tuneup for the United States Open. I was watching the final, between Caroline Wozniacki, the eventual winner, and Petra Cetkovska. My 4-year-old daughter and I were guests of my friend Andy, who had also brought Sam Owen, a tennis enthusiast and Episcopal seminarian.

headline: Murray Outlasts Haase
text: Unheralded Robin Haase of the Netherlands, ranked 41st in the world, held fourth-seeded Andy Murray of Great Britain in a vise for 93 minutes at the U.S. Open on Monday before falling in a five-set marathon, 6-7, 2-6, 6-2, 6-0, 6-4.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Cycles
text: Could Henry Ford have imagined Park Avenue as a bike path for every wheeled alternative to the car?

headline: Coffee, Bagels and Pigskin
text: For Lisa Staiano-Coico, who became president of the City College of New York last year, Sundays mean football, football and football. A native of Brooklyn, with a background in microbiology and immunology, Dr. Staiano-Coico, 55, does her red-meat screaming in Larchmont, N.Y., where she lives with her husband, Richard Coico, the vice dean of research and scientific affairs at SUNY Downstate Medical Center. On Sundays they often entertain their son, Jonathan, 28, who lives in Mamaroneck, and their daughter, Jennifer, 24, who lives in Larchmont.

headline: U.S. Open Fantasy: Jimmy Connors
text: Harvey Araton explains why Jimmy Connors was a great champion and how he would defeat Rafael Nadal in a match at the Open.

headline: Amid the Memorials, Ambiguity and Ambivalence
text: Has any attack in history ever been commemorated the way this one is about to be? What might we have anticipated, that morning of Sept. 11, as we watched the demonically choreographed assault unfold? What could we have imagined when New York City was covered in the ashes of the twin towers and their dead, or when a section of the Pentagon — the seemingly invulnerable core of the world’s most powerful military — was reduced to rubble? Or when we finally understood that but for the doomed bravery of several heroes, the destruction of the Capitol or the White House was assured?

headline: Fiat’s Retro Return
text: AUBURN HILLS, Mich. — Fiat, the Italian auto company, is getting a rare second chance to make a good first impression among American car buyers. And unlike the disastrous end to its first go-round decades ago, the carmaker has already managed to create a buzz.

headline: Jason and Medea Together Again
text: The mythological affair between Jason and Medea ended on a gruesome note, but in true 17th-century Venetian style, tragedy and comedy are interwoven in Francesco Cavalli’s infrequently performed “Giasone.” The work opened on Thursday evening at Le Poisson Rouge in a staged production by Opera Omnia, a fledgling company that specializes in repertory from that period.

headline: Memorials and the Forgotten
text: WHEN the National September 11 Memorial opens next week, it will be in good, if crowded, company. New York fairly bristles with memorials. They are so numerous, in fact, that no one knows exactly how many there are. Citywide estimates hover around 3,000; south of Canal Street, there are roughly 300.

headline: Turkey to Install U.S.-Designed Radar, in a Move Seen as Blunting Iran’s Missiles
text: Turkey announced Friday that it would install a radar system designed by the United States as part of a new NATO shield against a missile attack in Europe, a decision that pleased American military officials but was greeted with conspicuous silence by Iran, one of the perceived threats.

headline: Alvin Bunis, Creator of a Senior Tennis Circuit, Dies at 87
text: Before Alvin Bunis came along, a professional tennis player’s career seldom lasted past his early 30s.

headline: When Doctors Become Patients
text: FRANK SINATRA’S greatest hits album, filtered through the jet engine noise of the Varian linear accelerator, was not what I felt like hearing at 9 a.m. I made a mental note to bring a Steely Dan CD for my next appointment.

headline: Pay Attention, Houston: We Have Company
text: “Apollo 18,” a drab combination of science-fiction horror film and conspiracy thriller, accomplishes something the world wasn’t really crying out for: it recreates the tedium of watching the later Apollo missions.

headline: U.S. Open Fantasy: Rafael Nadal
text: Thomas Lin explains why Rafael Nadal would defeat Jimmy Connors at the hard courts of the Open.

headline: The Dog-Eared Paperback, Newly Endangered in an E-Book Age
text: These are dark and stormy times for the mass-market paperback, that squat little book that calls to mind the beach and airport newsstands.

headline: On Race, the Silence Is Bipartisan
text: THE economic crisis in the United States is also a racial crisis. White Americans are hurting, but nonwhite Americans are hurting even more. Yet leaders in both political parties — for different reasons — continue to act as though race were anachronistic and irrelevant in a country where an African-American is the president.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
text: Dressing Up, and Down

headline: Murky Edges of Darkness and Bouncy Teen Pop
text: Breathe Carolina

headline: Tough Assignment for an Accidental Conductor
text: WELL before “Nine Rivers,” a major work by the Scottish avant-garde composer James Dillon, was given its premiere by the BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra in Glasgow last November it had acquired a singular reputation. Interviewed in The Telegraph, a London newspaper, Mr. Dillon referred to his nine-part cycle as “the most canceled premiere ever.” Five previous attempts to mount it had been called off, casualties of its elaborate technical requirements, daunting difficulty and four-hour duration.

headline: Savoring the Last of Summer
text: After a triumphant first summer at the Dutch — the New York Times critic Sam Sifton called it “a ‘21’ Club for post-Reagan youth” — a suspicion of autumn had settled the other day over the SoHo restaurant, which specializes in American cooking. Heirloom tomatoes, sweet corn and watermelon garnishes were still on the menu, but a fall-spiced breeze was coming through the windows, open to a tree-shrouded corner of Prince and Sullivan Streets that felt both busy and secluded at once. The Dutch expects its clientele to know good food but not make a fuss about it, and there, under the architectural lighting fixtures, was just such a group: two culinary-minded friends and the men they had brought along, discussing not only the seafood but also the passage of the season. ALAN FEUER

headline: Television’s Men of Substance, Not Decoration
text: PITY the pretty boys. They have the rugged handsomeness of Kirk Douglas or the scruffy good looks of Jake Gyllenhaal, and as they were growing up, girls pined for them, and high school drama coaches favored them with choice roles. Now, in Hollywood, they have landed series: a role as a CW heartthrob or a slick 1960s advertising executive or a crime fighter with a soft side and an obligatory personality quirk.

headline: Don’t Fear Islamic Law in America
text: New Haven

headline: With Eye Toward Postseason, Yanks Rest Rodriguez and Teixeira
text: The Yankees entered Friday a half game behind the first-place Boston Red Sox in the American League East, with 26 games to play. But there were higher priorities for the Yankees than imminently grabbing first place — foremost among them to get healthy, or at least healthier.

headline: Teaching the Art of Surviving the Duel
text: IT was a perfectly peaceful late summer evening in downtown Manhattan, but a few steps off the sidewalk on Broome Street, two swordsmen tilted heavy Spanish rapiers at each other. Each keenly focused on the other’s three-foot-long steel blade. After a circular, predatory dance, they clashed, laying into each other with a great clanking as furious overhead chops led to slices toward the torso.

headline: Big City Book Club
text: From Herman Melville’s “Bartleby, the Scrivener” to Tom Wolfe’s “Bonfire of the Vanities,” New York has been a compelling character in American letters. The Big City Book Club intends to generate lively online discussion of works — classic and current, obvious and obscure, fictional and non — that centrally feature the city.

headline: Bloggingheads: Can the Fed Save Us?
text: Tim Fernholz, left, of Good magazine and Megan McArdle of The Atlantic debate the Federal Reserve and higher inflation.

headline: Nearly Out of Tricks, Fed May Pare Longer Rates
text: News that the economy added zero jobs in August raises the chances that the Federal Reserve will announce another round of stimulus when it meets in two weeks, Fed-watchers say, most likely by pushing down long-term interest rates.

headline: Updating the Open Experience
text: APP: US Open

headline: Teachers Lament Loss of School-Supply Funds
text: The city budget approved in June may have saved teachers’ jobs, but it did not save the Teacher’s Choice program, dampening teachers’ summer ritual of shopping for fresh classroom supplies.

headline: Labor Day Road Trip: What’s Your Fail-Safe Game?
text: The arrival of Labor Day means the unofficial end of summer, barbecues in the park and, for tens of millions of Americans, road trips.

headline: In Russia, Harsh Remedy for Addiction Gains Favor
text: YEKATERINBURG, Russia — The treatment center does not handcuff addicts to their beds anymore. But caged together on double-decker bunks with no way out, they have no choice but to endure the agonies of withdrawal, the first step in a harsh, coercive approach to drug treatment that has gained wide support in Russia.

headline: Going to the Mat for Ohio State
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — This spring, as uncertainty surrounded Coach Jim Tressel’s job, Luke Fickell flipped on the radio in his car.

headline: California Professor Leads a Methamphetamine Ring, the Police Say
text: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif. — For nearly a decade Stephen Kinzey worked as a professor of kinesiology, the study of human movement, at California State University, San Bernardino. A few students complained online that he showed up late for class and could lose his focus. But that was about it.

headline: For Zvonareva, No Bananas Today
text: As the end of a topsy-turvy first week nears at the United States Open, the spotlight has fallen squarely on the new crop of American women and men. Christina McHale, 19, ended the hopes of No. 8 Marion Bartoli; Irina Falconi, 21, ousted No. 14 Dominika Cibulkova before losing Friday to No. 22 Sabine Lisicki; Sloane Stephens, 18, outplayed Shahar Peer, a former top-20 player; and Vania King, 22, took out No. 29 Jarmila Gajdosova. Donald Young, 22, just advanced to the third round, drawing a capacity crowd to Court 17, where he won a thrilling fifth-set tiebreaker against No. 14 Stanislas Wawrinka. And Jack Sock, 18, takes on Andy Roddick in Friday night’s featured match.

headline: Bloomberg Is Chastised Over Silence on Deputy
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Friday ducked questions about why he had concealed the arrest of a top deputy, canceling a weekly radio appearance and disappearing from public view even as the city’s public advocate accused the mayor of lying about the episode.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,741 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

headline: The Truth Behind Stop-and-Frisk
text: Judge Shira Scheindlin of Federal District Court in New York made the right call when she refused to dismiss a lawsuit against the New York City Police Department, which alleged that officers use race as a basis for stopping and frisking citizens, rather than reasonable suspicion. The trial will provide an important opportunity to evaluate this increasingly troubling program, which resulted in 600,000 people being stopped on the streets last year alone.

headline: Files Note Close C.I.A. Ties to Qaddafi Spy Unit
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Documents found at the abandoned office of Libya’s former spymaster appear to provide new details of the close relations the Central Intelligence Agency shared with the Libyan intelligence service — most notably suggesting that the Americans sent terrorism suspects at least eight times for questioning in Libya despite that country’s reputation for torture.

headline: Karin Hoy and Nathan Hulme
text: THE soft rain that began falling the morning of Karin Hoy’s and Nathan Hulme’s wedding was but a harbinger of what Irene had in store for the couple.

headline: Turkey, Israel and the Flotilla
text: A United Nations report on Israel’s attack last year on a Gaza-bound aid ship should have been a chance to ease fraught relations between Israel and Turkey. Instead, both sides dug in their heels.

headline: To Dodgers, Bankruptcy Incurs Cost by the Hour
text: On July 6, Bruce Bennett analyzed a letter from a Los Angeles Dodgers fan about the team’s stunning bankruptcy filing. For his time — one-tenth of a legal hour, or six minutes — Bennett earned $97.50, exactly what he billed for a more standard task, such as examining the day’s docket.

headline: A Bad Call on Ozone
text: President Obama’s decision not to proceed with stronger air-quality standards governing ozone is a setback for public health and the environment and a victory for industry and its Republican friends in Congress.

headline: Interim Dean of Columbia College Is Named in Aftermath of Criticism
text: Facing criticism in the wake of the recent resignations of two important administrators, the president of Columbia University announced on Friday the appointment of an interim dean.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Battered Vermont Looks First to Its Roads
text: WARDSBORO, Vt. — Scattered around the smooth gray boulders of a burbling brook here, jagged shards of black asphalt — the double yellow lines still visible in places — are all that remain of a stretch of Route 100 that ran along the foothills of the Green Mountains.

headline: More Chinese Dissidents Appear to Disappear
text: BEIJING — Last Jan. 27, an Inner Mongolian rights activist, Govruud Huuchinhuu, suddenly vanished after leaving a hospital where she had undergone treatment for cancer. On Feb. 16, the Beijing human-rights lawyer Tang Jitian vanished after being forcibly taken away by police officers. On May 30, an ethnic Uighur, Ershidin Israel, vanished after being deported to China from Kazakhstan as a terrorism suspect. In the next two weeks, three other Uighurs vanished as well.

headline: Dickey Gets Some Run Support, and Two New Relievers Pitch In
text: WASHINGTON — The Mets clubhouse at the start of September has had something of a back-to-school feel, with fresh faces being introduced and familiar ones re-emerging.

headline: Learning to Talk It Out
text: SARAH CROPLEY HENLEY still likes the looks of her husband’s kneecaps. Those were the physical attributes she first noted about Steve Henley when they met. He was dressed as a 13th-century Scotsman, in kilt and handmade shoes, at an outing organized by the Society for Creative Anachronism, to which they both belonged.

headline: All-Cash Bid for the Dodgers Faces Obstacles and Doubters
text: A $1.2 billion cash bid for the Los Angeles Dodgers that would be financed in part by state-run financial institutions in China would face substantial obstacles before being considered by Major League Baseball, several sports business experts said.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: A Time of Drenching Rain, Gusting Wind and Peculiar Crimes
text: Three guys robbed the office of a $10-an-hour, cash-only parking lot in the Bronx in the wee hours of Sunday morning. It looked like a nice, fat, golden goose, as the lot was full of cars, and there was no one around. But the thieves got away with just $46.

headline: The Story of a Dead Sailor, His Widow and a Bunch of Boneheaded Politicians
text: Robert Keyserlingk died in December 2009 of mesothelioma, a cancer usually caused by exposure to asbestos. Mr. Keyserlingk, a neighbor and good friend on the Canadian mountain lake where we spend our summers, had been a history professor and a wonderful gardener. Forty years earlier, he was a cadet in the Canadian Navy, in an era when the plumbing and wiring in naval vessels were routinely coated with asbestos.

headline: Jets’ No. 3 Quarterback Out After Thumb Surgery
text: The Jets are searching for a third-string quarterback after Greg McElroy had thumb surgery Friday morning. McElroy, who was injured Thursday in a preseason loss to the Philadelphia Eagles, is expected to be sidelined for several weeks.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: With Win, Young Provides Delayed Glimpse of Future
text: As Friday afternoon stretched into Friday evening, Donald Young stole repeated glances at the clock. Already, his second-round United States Open match against 14th-seeded Stanislas Wawrinka had gone over four hours, into a fifth set.

headline: Perry’s Blunt Views in Books Get New Scrutiny as He Joins Race
text: WASHINGTON — Rick Perry, the governor of Texas, believes that climate change is a “contrived, phony mess.” The federal income tax was the “great milestone on the road to serfdom.” And the Boy Scouts of America are under attack by “a radical homosexual movement.”

headline: The ‘Jack of Clubs’ Makes His Move
text: Some of the most colorful characters in the Union cavalry could be found not in the saddle of a foam-flecked charger, but in the seat of a company wagon. These ubiquitous drivers of teams of horses or mules, known as teamsters, occupied the bottom of the chain of army command. But the Union Army was a fluid hierarchy, where men of talent and drive could rise quickly — even men who started out on the lowest rung.

headline: In Gulbis Loss, a Question of Focus
text: There’s a walkway between Courts 6 and 7 that has a few trees set back from the aluminum bleachers. I found some shade in time to watch Ernests Gulbis play Gilles Muller of Luxembourg. This was a particularly tough part of the draw for Gulbis, who upset the 16th seed, Mikhail Youzhny, in straight sets on Tuesday.

headline: New Urgency in the Battle for Stimulus
text: WASHINGTON — Having battled for months over deficit reduction, President Obama and Congress on Friday each confronted new urgency to shift their focus to job creation after the most anemic employment report in many months.

headline: How a Cinema’s Fresh Start Revived a Town, Too
text: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y.

headline: Kitchenware Through the Centuries
text: THE imposing 1898 stove that stands at the entrance to “What’s Cooking: 300 Years of East Hampton Kitchens” was still being used until about six years ago in a private home on Newtown Lane that was sold to the Village of East Hampton after its owner died.

headline: An Unbalanced Barber Returns, With Ample Blood
text: “Sweeney Todd,” Stephen Sondheim and Hugh Wheeler’s meditation on vengeance, madness and the nature of good and evil, has shown itself to be a surprisingly malleable play.

headline: London Protesters Disrupt Israeli Orchestra’s Concert
text: LONDON — For the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra, marking its 75th anniversary, it was a jarring first, and in a city that has been one of the orchestra’s most welcoming hosts: the repeated disruption of its concert at Royal Albert Hall in London on Thursday night by pro-Palestinian demonstrators, to the point that the BBC cut off its live broadcast and played recordings of the evening’s program instead.

headline: Where Storm Takes Food Off Tables
text: The farmers’ market at the Whitehall Terminal of the Staten Island Ferry will have no heirloom tomatoes from Wilklow Orchards in upstate New York. Mike Betit, a farmer from Vermont, will not be taking summer squash to the Union Square Greenmarket, and Hector Tejada, another New York farmer, will not show up at all this fall at the markets in Union Square or Fort Greene, Brooklyn.

headline: In ‘Summer,’ Quintessential Williams Themes
text: A description of baby sea turtles sets the tone for “Suddenly Last Summer,” the intense, atmospheric production currently at the Westport Country Playhouse.

headline: Priest Officiates Play From Above
text: So a Catholic priest walks onto a tennis court. Seriously. It happens, for Father Paul Arinze, every day at the United States Open.

headline: In Honor of Teachers
text: Since it’s back-to-school season across the country, I wanted to celebrate a group that is often maligned: teachers. Like so many others, it was a teacher who changed the direction of my life, and to whom I’m forever indebted.

headline: Rocket Financed by Amazon Founder Crashes in Test
text: A spacecraft financed by Jeffrey P. Bezos, the billionaire chief executive of Amazon.com, crashed during a test flight in West Texas, Mr. Bezos said on Friday.

headline: Exploring Arson, Recovery and Friendship
text: THE Los Angeles-based filmmaker Guido Verweyen says he gravitates toward “stories about people who’ve been dealt quite a bit of hardship in their life, but get transformed positively through it.”

headline: Civilian Plane Intercepted Near Camp David
text: An F-15 fighter jet intercepted a small civilian plane that flew into the restricted airspace above Camp David, the presidential retreat in Maryland, the Associated Press is reporting.

headline: The Bradley Celebration Tour Goes Home
text: NORTON, Mass. — When Keegan Bradley starts to talk about “living the dream,” there is none of the bored sarcasm or rehearsed earnestness some jaded pro athletes apply to the phrase. There is only an unaffected exuberance impossible to feign and a smile that has lighted living rooms — and brightened Twitter feeds — across the United States.

headline: A Fall Theatrical Season Full of Collaborations
text: THE fall season for New Jersey’s professional theaters lights up this week as two new musicals, “Ten Cents a Dance” and “The Break Up Notebook,” begin previews and other companies across the state present revivals and new plays.

headline: Saturday: Stirring Things Up
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Come one, come all! This Saturday is going to be A HOOT.

headline: A Sport Fails in the Most Important Category: Integrity
text: College football, in all its seedy glory, has returned. What I find amazing about the sport is that fans watch the games, knowing all the time that players will barter their trophies for tattoos (Ohio State) and cavort with grubby boosters supplying earthly pleasures (Miami).

headline: U.S. Open Point/Counterpoint: Jimmy Connors vs. Rafael Nadal
text: Fantasy U.S. Open Tournament: Who are the two greatest U.S. Open champions from the past 30 years? It’s up to you to decide, with a little help from The Times’s tennis experts. Watch our video debates, vote on the winner and then explain your position in the comments section. The winner from this match will advance to the next round of our virtual tournament. View the bracket.

headline: Iran Has New Equipment to Speed the Production of Nuclear Fuel, Panel Is Told
text: WASHINGTON — International nuclear inspectors reported on Friday that Iran had finally begun operating a new generation of equipment that over time should give it the capability to produce nuclear fuel much faster, after years of delays made worse by Western sanctions and sabotage.

headline: Severance of $2 Million for Departing Bank Chief
text: Bank of New York Mellon has agreed to pay its departing chief executive, Robert P. Kelly, severance of $2 million, according to a statement filed Friday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The bank said Mr. Kelly was also eligible for up to $4 million in compensation based on the bank’s performance this year and $11.2 million from vested equity awards. Mr. Kelly is also entitled to a pension currently valued at $16.6 million, Bank of New York said. The bank said it would take a charge of $22 million in the third quarter to account for the compensation. Mr. Kelly stepped down late Wednesday because of “differences in approaches to managing the company,” the bank said.

headline: Little Shop, Big Scents
text: For lovers of Indian food, the intoxicating perfumes of India might not be sandalwood, jasmine and patchouli but cardamom, curry leaves and coriander — the heady scents that greet customers entering the Little Kabab Station, the newest of eateries lining the short blocks of Moger Avenue and East Main Street in Mount Kisco.

headline: Alfresco Dining Just Off the Saw Mill
text: SITTING on La Lanterna’s patio, facing a border of dark trees aglitter with hundreds of tiny lights, with drifting conversations and music in the background, one can forget that a major road is almost at the restaurant’s back door. La Lanterna’s proximity to the Saw Mill River Parkway in Yonkers, however, is not something you’d want to forget completely. It makes stopping there convenient; on and off couldn’t be easier. Drop in to make an evening of it or to take a break en route. Just look for the Hearst Street exit.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Battle for Libya | Sept. 2, 2011
text: A Qaddafi volunteer fighter was captured by rebels in Tripoli and Libyans celebrated Id al-Fitr in Misurata.

headline: Personal Expressions
text: At a quick glance, the Peconic storefront named the Winemaker Studio by Anthony Nappa Wines suggests a gallery. Although works by local artists are in fact displayed on the walls and sold, the place is primarily a tasting and sales room for the wines made personally by four small-scale East End vintners.

headline: Evoking Hamptons Style in an Old Bank Building
text: THE Riverhead Project looks like a Hamptons transplant, with the sleek décor and high prices that are more typical of the East End than of the Suffolk County seat. As for the name, the owners wanted Riverhead to be part of it because “we’re proud to be in Riverhead,” Keith Kraus, the general manager, said on the phone after my visits. The word project reflects the fact that the restaurant, which opened in May, remains a work in progress, he added.

headline: Palin Says ‘There’s Room for More’
text: URBANDALE, Iowa — Sarah Palin arrived here on Friday evening to greet passionate supporters who traveled from across Iowa and the around the nation to hear her deliver a weekend speech that could offer an indication of whether she intends to join the Republican presidential race.

headline: Formulaic Approach Doesn’t Serve Schedule
text: Juan Martín del Potro was gassed and it wasn’t as if he had gone five sets in the steamiest of New York conditions. But the late-summer sun was high over the grandstand court at high noon on Friday, in the middle of his 6-2, 6-1, 7-5 victory over a fellow Argentine, Diego Junqueira.

headline: E-Mails Show Three Officials Were Informed of Gun Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON — Three White House officials were told about the existence of a gun trafficking investigation in Arizona that led to the replacement of the administration’s top firearms official, according to newly disclosed e-mails the Justice Department sent to Congress this week.

headline: Man Wins $3 Million Lottery but Is Tricked Out of Prize
text: On Feb. 3, a man walked into N&K Quick Pick in the Rockland County village of Spring Valley and purchased a $10 scratch-off instant lottery ticket. It was a $3 million winner, but it turned out to be anything but instant.

headline: Decadent Vegan Chocolates
text: Of the numerous businesses in Manchester’s Parkade shopping plaza, the biggest surprise may be Divine Treasures Belgian Chocolates. The pleasure of coming upon the store, which is wedged between a tobacco shop and a Chinese eatery, is easily matched by its delightful handmade sweets.

headline: Scandinavian Chic With Local Freshness
text: ALONG a densely forested road in Washington sits an off-white colonial-style building that could easily pass for a private residence, save for the burnt-orange letters running right below the attic window that spell Community table (with a lowercase “t”) — an apt name for a restaurant dedicated to all things local.

headline: Protesters in Yemen Vow to Stay on Streets
text: SANA, Yemen — Seven months after Yemen’s political uprising began, with the threat of civil war still looming, defiant protesters continue to take to the streets in the tens of thousands every Friday to call for the government to step down. They vow not to stop until their demand is met.

headline: Where Budding Magnates Experiment With Recipes
text: BRIDGETON, N.J.

headline: Corrections: September 3
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Nearly Week Later, Thousands in Region Still Lack Clean Water
text: KILLINGWORTH, Conn. — Gurmeet Singh thought that she had squirreled away enough water. In her preparations before Tropical Storm Irene, Ms. Singh, whose house has water supplied by a private well, filled her largest pots and the hot tub to the brim. That should have been enough to flush the toilets for a couple of days if the well’s pump lost power.

headline: U.S. vs. Costa Rica Lineups
text: The United States lineup for its exhibition match against Costa Rica on Friday night at the Home Depot Center in Carson, Calif., includes five changes from the one Coach Jurgen Klinsmann used in his first game last month:

headline: Drug Treatment in Russia
text: As the number of drug addicts has risen in Russia, increasingly desperate citizens have turned to treatment centers employing regimens that would be considered excessively harsh in many Western countries.

headline: Steady Nova Recovers From an Early Stumble
text: Ivan Nova, the slender and precocious Yankees rookie right-hander, gave up two runs before he got two outs Friday, which was not a very positive start for a pitcher whose team was without Mark Teixeira and Alex Rodriguez, two sluggers who can erase deficits with big swings.

headline: Arizona: Voters Remove an Embattled Mayor
text: Voters in the small western town of Quartzsite removed Mayor Ed Foster in a recall election, replacing him with Jose Lizarraga, a firefighter and former Town Council member who had promised to run for office without spending money on campaign signs and mailers. La Paz County election officials said that 574 votes were cast on Tuesday, with Mr. Lizarraga receiving 53 percent of the vote. In recent months, Mr. Foster had accused other city officials of abusing their authority and battled with the town’s police chief. Earlier this summer, more than half of the Police Department cast a no-confidence vote against the chief.

headline: Iraq Calls for New Inquiry on Deaths in 2006 U.S. Raid
text: BAGHDAD — A spokesman for Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq said Friday that the government would reopen an investigation into a March 2006 raid in which American troops were accused of executing an Iraqi family.

headline: A Future for the Used-Up Tools of the Tennis Trade
text: Tennis balls are the lifeblood of every match, and as ubiquitous as rackets, shoulder bags and sweatbands. But the cans they come in create a mountain of garbage that the United States Tennis Association is working hard to recycle during the United States Open.

headline: Brooklyn Special Election Could Upset Politics as Usual
text: One recent Saturday in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, Jon Norville stepped out of his home to listen to the pitch from a slight young man who was the first candidate to come to his door.

headline: Suicide Bombs in Iraq Have Killed 12,000 Civilians, Study Says
text: BAGHDAD — While sophisticated roadside bombs have taken a heavy toll on American troops over the course of the war here, suicide bombings have largely been a hallmark of sectarian warfare. Independent researchers have now tried to quantify their damage, poring through data compiled from death reports to conclude that more than 12,000 Iraqis have been killed in at least 1,000 suicide attacks since the American-led invasion.

headline: Baseball’s Alternate Universe
text: The Red Sox and the Yankees go at each other as if there were no tomorrow morning. They play absurdly long games that extend to four hours and beyond, as if no one watching at home, or in the stands, might have to call it quits and get some sleep.

headline: Halston’s Rise and Waver
text: Without its founder, the house struggles to reclaim its place.

headline: The Men (and Women) Who Would Be Halston
text: WHEN New York Fashion Week begins on Thursday, more than 250 design companies will be showing at the pitched white tents at Lincoln Center and points beyond. But the once-storied house of Halston will not be among them.

headline: Learning Begins at Home
text: An innovative principal in the Bronx uses home visits to introduce his new teachers to their students’ lives and convince parents that the school is taking the child’s future seriously.

headline: Meeting Students on Their Own Turf
text: In a poor neighborhood in the Bronx, teachers set out to visit their new students at home before the beginning of the school year.

headline: Before the First School Bell, Teachers in Bronx Make House Calls
text: JASON McCORKLE, all of 11, stepped back into his family’s living room in the South Bronx wearing the gray slacks and crisp white shirt his new teachers had just handed him, tags still dangling from a sleeve. He puffed out his chest, stuffed his hands in his pockets and flashed his pearly teeth, standing near a poster of a beachfront mansion, a five-car garage and the words “Justification for Higher Education” lighted by rays of sunshine.

headline: Maurice M. Rapport, Who Studied Serotonin, Dies at 91
text: Maurice M. Rapport, a biochemist who helped isolate and name the neurotransmitter serotonin, which plays a role in regulating mood and mental states, and who first described its molecular structure, a development that led to the creation of a wide variety of psychiatric and other drugs, died on Aug. 18 in Durham, N.C. He was 91.

headline: Christie Says ‘Get Back on the Beach’ His Way
text: Angry that stragglers were still soaking in the sun hours before Hurricane Irene was to arrive last week, Gov. Chris Christie chastised Jersey Shore beachgoers with some slightly salty language. “Get the hell off the beach,” he said at a news conference, a phrase that was celebrated later for both  its forthrightness and criticized for its vulgarity.

headline: South Korea Halts an Anti-Base Protest
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The police on Friday detained nearly three dozen activists and villagers on Jeju Island who had set up a camp where they have resisted the construction of a naval base in their seashore village.

headline: John Cullen, Coast Guardsman Who Detected Spies, Dies at 90
text: In the spring of 1942, Seaman John Cullen was assigned to one of the Coast Guard’s less glamorous tasks in an America newly at war.

headline: After a Tiff Over Greek Aid, Questions Arise Over Europe’s Response to Debt Crisis
text: LONDON — Concerns about the euro zone’s ability to cohesively respond to its debt crisis resurfaced Friday after talks between Greece and its foreign creditors were interrupted and the head of the European Central Bank warned Italy to stick to its austerity program.

headline: Mexico: Police Officer Arrested in Deadly Casino Fire
text: The federal police have arrested a state police officer in connection with the arson attack on a casino in northern Mexico that left 52 people dead, while five others detained earlier remain in custody. The unidentified state officer, arrested Thursday, was one of several men seen in surveillance camera video arriving at the casino in Monterrey in a caravan. Some of the men rushed in to set the building ablaze in what the authorities suspect may have been retaliation for not paying an extortion demand. Also, Jonás Larrazabal, the brother of the mayor of Monterrey, was questioned by prosecutors on Thursday after he was seen in another casino accepting wads of cash. He has said the payments were for selling cheese and other products from his native state, Oaxaca.

headline: Oklahoma Expects to Make Decision on Big 12 Future Soon
text: The University of Oklahoma will decide whether to leave the Big 12 within the next three weeks, its president, David Boren, said Friday. Oklahoma’s departure could further weaken a league already shaken by the losses of Nebraska and Colorado and Texas A&M’s seemingly inevitable move to the Southeastern Conference next week.

headline: Fordham’s New Approach Could Lead It Out of Patriot League
text: Fordham football has a national championship to its credit and a gloried past that includes names such as Vince Lombardi, who was a member of its famed Seven Blocks of Granite. Sellouts at Yankees Stadium and the Polo Grounds were once the norm, so much so that the program generated enough interest to play in the first two televised football games.

headline: Baylor Upsets T.C.U. After Squandering 24-Point Lead
text: WACO, Texas — Baylor quarterback Robert Griffin III entered the first game of his redshirt junior season with more than 30 Baylor records to his credit. What he was missing was a signature victory.

headline: South Africa: Hearing on Youth Leader to Proceed
text: The governing African National Congress party in South Africa on Friday denied an effort by its firebrand youth leader, Julius Malema, to have it drop charges brought against him by a disciplinary committee that accuses him of sowing division and bringing the party into disrepute. The committee opened hearings this week to determine whether Mr. Malema, 30, should be suspended. Mr. Malema’s latest brush with party authorities took place July 31, when he called for a change of government in Botswana, embarrassing South African officials. In past years he has also promoted a colonial-era song advocating the shooting of white settlers.

headline: Readers’ Photos from Woodstock
text: Readers share images and memories of the 1969 festival.

headline: Russia: Officer Charged in 2006 Killing of a Journalist
text: Investigators have charged a former police officer with providing surveillance information and a murder weapon to the killer of the prominent journalist Anna Politkovskaya, whose shooting death in 2006 brought widespread condemnation of violence against journalists in Russia. But like the earlier arrest of a person suspected of being a gunman, the announcement left unanswered the larger question of who ordered the killing of Ms. Politkovskaya, a crusading reporter who had persisted in writing critical articles about the war in Chechnya. The defendant, Dmitri Pavlyuchenkov, a former lieutenant colonel in a police surveillance unit, has denied the accusation.

text: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

headline: The World This Week, Part 2
text: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

headline: Klinsmann Is Winless as United States Men Fall to Costa Rica
text: CARSON, Calif. — As the United States played Costa Rica in Jurgen Klinsmann’s second game as coach of the national soccer team, a banner draped the knoll at the northern end of Home Depot Center.

headline: A Priest in Umpire's Clothing
text: Father Paul Arinze works for the Diocese of Madison, Wis. At tournaments, he trades his altar for the umpire’s chair.

text: Tommy Haas may be 33 — the oldest player left in the draw — and ranked 400-something in the world, but when healthy, he can still play, as he demonstrated by ousting Alejandro Falla in straight sets Thursday.

headline: Small Leaps of Faith
text: When Betsy Wiggins opened her front door and saw the woman in a full black face veil coming up her flower-lined walkway, she wondered if she had done the right thing.

text: Some rehabilitation centers in Russia take a harsh approach to fighting addiction.

headline: Waiter, There’s A Dog in My Kitchen
text: A sous chef stirs vegetables for the clam chowder for table 74 when he absently looks downward and sees something unusual and says, “Whose pit bull is this?”

headline: Broken Windows, Ozone, and Jobs
text: I’ve actually been avoiding thinking about the latest Obama cave-in, on ozone regulation; these repeated retreats are getting painful to watch. For what it’s worth, I think it’s bad politics. The Obama political people seem to think that their route to victory is to avoid doing anything that the GOP might attack — but the GOP will call Obama a socialist job-killer no matter what they do. Meanwhile, they just keep reinforcing the perception of mush from the wimp, of a president who doesn’t stand for anything.

headline: The Austerity Economy
text: Do the dismal economic numbers really reflect the turn to fiscal austerity? I keep hearing people say no, because austerity hasn’t actually happened yet in America. But they’re wrong.

headline: 30 Seconds With Scott Hanson
text: Scott Hanson is in his sixth year as a reporter and host for NFL Network. But he is best known as the host of the addictive NFL RedZone channel, which whips from game to game on Sunday afternoons, excising the 1-yard runs and tedious timeouts and focusing only on the most jaw-dropping plays and touchdowns.

headline: N.F.L.’s Road to Recovery Grows Longer
text: With no players to talk to, no practices to oversee, Coach Ron Rivera filled the hours of spring and early summer by devising schedules. Over and over, he adjusted his vision for his first Carolina Panthers team, cross-referencing lockout updates with blitz installations.

headline: Troops Kill Man Linked to Al Qaeda and Attacks
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A combined Afghan and coalition force killed a suspected insurgent leader in eastern Afghanistan, NATO officials said on Saturday. The man was believed to be a former detainee at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, who at one time was accused of helping Osama bin Laden escape from Tora Bora after the fall of the Taliban.

headline: Stung by the President on Air Quality, Environmentalists Weigh Their Options
text: For environmental groups, it was the final hard slap that brought a long-troubled relationship to the brink.

headline: Passion and Improvisation Sustain a Frequent Traveler
text: The ageless Jamie Moyer has started workouts at the Philadelphia Phillies’ complex in Clearwater, Fla., hoping to come back from reconstructive surgery on his ancient left elbow. He continues to inspire a younger version with Kansas City.

headline: Erratic Tropical Storm Brings Heavy Rain to Parts of Gulf
text: Tropical Storm Lee continued to behave erratically off the Gulf of Mexico throughout most of the day on Saturday, dropping more than 10 inches of rain in some areas of the coast, while breaking up and letting the sun shine through on others. Officials throughout southern Louisiana cautioned residents not to be misled by the on-and-off nature of the storm into thinking the worst was over.

headline: It’s Called a Season; It Lasts 11 Months
text: For many players at the United States Open, it all started the first week of January, maybe in Australia, maybe in Qatar, definitely after an off-season they hoped would be longer.

headline: Away from the Spotlight, a Match to Savor
text: After watching the Gulbis-Muller match on Friday, I turned to watch the drama unfolding on Court 6 between the 17th seed, Jurgen Melzer, and Igor Kunitsyn, a Russian who had come back from two sets to love to beat Matthias Bachinger in the first round. There’s an intimacy to these matches that appeals to me. The crowd was small–perhaps 400 people were watching–and I found some more shade in the bleachers on the western side of the court.

headline: ‘Lockout League’ Is Set to Tip Off in Las Vegas
text: A swarm of Knicks, Clippers and Rockets players will soon descend on Las Vegas for two weeks of intense competition — only without coaches, contracts or the imprimatur of the N.B.A.

headline: David Gillen with Susanne Craig on the rebuilding of Cantor Fitzgerald, Phyllis Korkki and Shaila Dewan on Friday’s jobs report, and Phyllis Korkki and Robert Shiller on stocks.
text: This week: David Gillen with Susanne Craig on the rebuilding of Cantor Fitzgerald, Phyllis Korkki and Shaila Dewan on Friday’s jobs report, and Phyllis Korkki and Robert Shiller on stocks.

headline: Variety: Split Ends
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE —There’s an old story that goes something like this: When Carl Gauss, a German mathematician, was still a child prodigy blazing his way through school, his teacher assigned the class the tedious task of counting up all the numbers from 1 to 100. While his classmates began the timely process of adding up the numbers sequentially, the young wunderkind thought of a shortcut and arrived at the answer in a snap. What the young Gauss did was work from the outside in: he knew there were 50 pairs of numbers that added up to 100 (0+100, 1+99 etc. through 49+51), and that 50 times 100 is 5,000. Then he simply tacked on the middle 50 and announced to the class that the grand total was 5,050 — astounding his teacher and probably making him the target of more than a few wet-Wilhelms.

headline: Games to Watch on Saturday
text: NO. 3 OREGON VS. NO. 4 LOUISIANA STATE, ARLINGTON, TEX.

headline: Final Week of Preseason: Theater of the Absurd
text: The third preseason game is often called a dress rehearsal for the regular season. Extending the live theater metaphor, the fourth preseason game is an afternoon performance at the Piscataway Summer Stock Playhouse to work out the kinks of the production and integrate the new songs Bono wrote.

headline: Republican Candidates Turn Attacks on One Another
text: INDIANOLA, Iowa — Gov. Rick Perry is privately being coached to come across as more presidential — cautious in his comments, deliberate in defending his Texas record — while building on his fast start by trying to consolidate support across the Republican spectrum, from the Tea Party and evangelicals to the party establishment.

headline: Not a Perfect Start, but a Perfect Ending for Bolt
text: DAEGU, South Korea — First the essential: Usain Bolt actually got to run this final. There was no false start, no anticlimax, no great debate, no bare-chested Bolt howling and slamming his hands against a wall as slower men took off without him.

headline: The Survivor Who Saw the Future for Cantor Fitzgerald
text: TEN years and a lifetime ago, Howard W. Lutnick was a prince of Wall Street. Forty years old, and already the head of a powerful financial house, he could peer down on rivals from his office on the 105th floor of One World Trade Center.

headline: Vatican Rebukes Ireland Over Claims on Sexual Abuse
text: VATICAN CITY — In a strong rebuke to the Irish government, the Vatican said Saturday that it had never discouraged Irish bishops from reporting the sexual abuse of minors to the police and dismissed claims that it had undermined efforts to investigate abuse as “unfounded.”

headline: At Arthur Ashe Stadium, a Long Night’s Journey Into the Day Session
text: As Novak Djokovic left the Arthur Ashe Stadium court after his three-set, 90-minute dismantling of Carlos Berlocq on Thursday, he was corralled by a disgruntled fan who told Djokovic he had paid $100 for his ticket and for that price expected to see more tennis.

headline: Live Analysis: College Football Kickoff
text: Paul Myerberg will be reporting on all of the day’s action on the first college football Saturday of the season. Check back throughout the day for updates. You can also follow Paul on Twitter for additional updates on the day’s action.

headline: And Now, a Season of Booth Reviews and Touchbacks
text: Are you ready for some touchbacks, punts, penalties and long replay reviews? If so, you are in luck: the N.F.L. lockout, coupled with the league’s rule changes and clarifications, will make this a banner season for low-scoring games, delays and general on-field milling about.

headline: Libya’s Interim Leaders Aim to Harness Rebel Fighters
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Libya’s interim government plans to begin bringing irregular rebel militias under government control, either disbanding them or incorporating them into regular police and military forces, said Ali Tarhouni, the deputy chairman of the rebels’ executive board, speaking at a news conference here on Saturday.

headline: Wozniacki Wins in Straight Sets
text: Top-seeded Caroline Wozniacki of Denmark easily defeated a struggling Vania King of the United States, 6-2, 6-4, to gain the fourth round of the U.S. Open on Saturday.

headline: Wild Cards and Tame Division Races
text: In 1994, when the division series and the wild card were added to baseball’s playoff system, one of its expected benefits was the creation of four more playoff races (from four divisions to six divisions and two wild cards) that would keep fans in more markets more interested in September games.

headline: Forensics From Sept. 11
text: While waiting for new DNA technology, still sifting through remains from Sept. 11.

headline: New York’s Big Break: Surfing Sees Opportunity
text: The teenager from Long Island was so comfortably gliding through the barreling waves of G-Land, the storied Indonesian surf break, promoters on hand from Quiksilver came to a realization: there must be waves — real, contest-worthy, maybe even tubing waves — just beyond the flat, gritty concrete jungle of the big city.

headline: In the Big 12, Sure Things Are on the Ground in Pieces
text: WACO, Tex. — When the game finally ended Friday night, after 98 points, 143 plays and countless cramps, Baylor’s gold-clad student section poured onto the field to celebrate. Baylor, the perennial Big 12 punch line, had just beaten No. 14 Texas Christian, 50-48, in dizzying fashion. The Bears held a 24-point fourth-quarter lead, surrendered 25 consecutive points and won on a late field-goal drive kept alive by a trick play.

headline: Amid Fighting, South Sudan Plans New Capital
text: KAMPALA, Uganda — With battles still raging in disputed territory along its border, the new nation of South Sudan announced plans on Saturday to move its capital from the main city of Juba to a small town in the north.

headline: Dreading the Americanization of Romulus and Remus
text: When the Boston businessman Thomas DiBenedetto bought a majority stake in the Italian soccer club A.S. Roma in April, I cannot say I rejoiced.

headline: Weekness

headline: Back to the Gym
text: I  WAS born in Queens. When I was a teenager, my parents moved to Florida because my father was tired of his commute to Manhattan, where he worked as a property loss adjuster.

headline: Berdych Is Added to List of Retirements

headline: Soldier, Thinker, Hunter, Spy: Drawing a Bead on Al Qaeda
text: WASHINGTON — Every day, Michael G. Vickers gets an update on how many in Al Qaeda’s senior leadership the United States has removed from the battlefield, and lately there has been much to report. Al Qaeda’s No. 2 died in a C.I.A. drone strike late last month, another senior commander was taken out in June, and the Navy Seals made history when they dispatched Osama bin Laden in May.

headline: Wounded Iraqi Veterans Face a New Battle
text: BAGHDAD — It is hard to say which is a worse indignity to the thousands of Iraqi soldiers and police officers who have suffered crippling injuries fighting alongside the Americans in a war that continues today: receiving subpar medical care from the government they fought to preserve, or a new law that could slash their already paltry benefits.

headline: Trust the Evidence, Not Your Instincts
text: CONSIDER this hypothetical situation: You have a serious illness. Your doctor prescribes an intrusive, painful and costly treatment. What she doesn’t say — because she hasn’t consulted the research — is that most studies find the treatment ineffective and fraught with negative side effects.

headline: Before Wal-Mart, There Was A.& P.
text: THIS is the story of a retailer that because of its sheer size could command volume discounts from its suppliers — and pass along the savings to customers. In the process, many mom-and-pop stores, unable to match its prices, went out of business.

headline: Emerging Markets Are Down, Not Out

headline: The Beauty Contest That’s Shaking Wall St.
text: THE extraordinary surge of stock market volatility during the last month can’t be explained by conventional means. Yes, hundreds of scholarly papers have tried to predict the size of such swings, and whole markets — like those for futures and options — thrive on these movements. Yet we still don’t have a clear, mathematical understanding of volatility’s source.

headline: Amid Mud and Floods, Push to Restore Power

headline: Leo-Arthur Kelmenson, Ad Man Who Helped to Save Chrysler, Dies at 84
text: Leo-Arthur Kelmenson, an advertising executive who helped Lee Iacocca save the Chrysler Corporation and conceived the TV ad campaign that made Mr. Iacocca the most famous car salesman in the world, died on Tuesday at his home on the East End of Long Island, in Remsenburg. He was 84.

headline: Tropical Storm Lee: Latest Updates
text: Tropical Storm Lee has stalled off the coast of Louisiana and is expected to make landfall later Saturday afternoon or evening, my colleague Campbell Robertson reports. Due to an influx of dry air into the storm, some residents of southern Louisiana below New Orleans have already begun reporting a welcome respite from the torrential rainfall.

text: The weekly karaoke contest at Bar 107 epitomizes the evolution of downtown Los Angeles from slum to hip urban enclave. There is the self-conscious kitsch (a stag head wearing a football helmet mounted on the cluttered walls, along with the Elvis portrait), the skinny jeans, the men with mustaches, the ‘80s tunes from Journey and Depeche Mode.

text: In anticipation of President Obama’s prime time address to unveil his job-creation proposal on Thursday, the Sunday shows are fittingly taking Labor Day weekend to discuss jobs.

headline: G.O.P. Candidates’ Stances on Health Care Mask Their Records as Governors
text: The three most prominent current or former governors running for president — Rick Perry, Mitt Romney and Jon M. Huntsman Jr. — are firmly united in their commitment to repealing President Obama’s health care law. But that unanimity masks a broad divergence in their approaches to the issue while in office, spanning the spectrum of Republican positioning.

headline: Cano Cleans Up in the Fourth Spot for the Yankees
text: Robinson Cano grounded into an inning-ending double play in his first at-bat Saturday, but he did not allow himself to forget about it. He loves to be dropped into situations — the tenser the better — in which he can make something happen. He had wasted his first chance to do so, but fortunately for the Yankees, it was not his last.

headline: Fears in Miami That Port Expansion Will Destroy Reefs
text: MIAMI — As Miami prepares to dredge its port to accommodate supersize freighters, environmentalists are making a last-ditch effort to protect threatened coral reefs and acres of sea grass that they say would be destroyed by the expansion.

headline: New Dramas on the Hill (and a Few Reruns)
text: Congress returns to work this week, with spending cuts and regulations on its agenda. Before leaving for August recess, lawmakers were caught up in the Republican-created debt ceiling crisis, which ended with a compromise that is supposed to cut $917 billion from the federal deficit over 10 years. They also kicked the can on finding $1.5 trillion more to a “supercommittee” that is expected to release a plan by Nov. 23.

headline: California Dreaming
text: California is on the brink of making a wise investment in its future and delivering a powerful rebuke to poisoned immigration politics at the national level. This week, the Legislature is expected to pass the California Dream Act, a bill to allow undocumented immigrants to receive state-financed college scholarships and loans. Earlier this summer, the state gave such students access to privately financed aid. The new bill should open even more doors to college degrees for young Californians, and Gov. Jerry Brown should quickly sign it.

text: Kate Murphy is a journalist in Houston who writes frequently for The New York Times.

headline: Arizona Redistricting Panel Is Under Attack, Even Before Its Work Is Done

headline: The Fuller Story from Libya
text: My Sunday column tells the extraordinary tale of Salem al-Madhoun. A year ago, he was a senior naval officer in Qaddafi’s Libya. Six months ago, he was a defector and a leader in the underground battle to overthrow Qaddafi. Two weeks ago, he was enduring torture in prison. And now he’s the military commander for the Tajoura area.

text: INDIANOLA, Iowa — Sarah Palin did not say whether she would seek the Republican presidential nomination, but she made clear during a speech here on Saturday that she has no intentions of simply falling into line behind one of the party’s leading candidates.

headline: What Will School Look Like in 10 Years?
text: Computers, electronic whiteboards and other interactive technologies are fundamentally changing American education. That is the view of the experts whom The Times spoke with about what the classroom will look like 10 years from now. Listen to excerpts from their predictions below, and share your own thoughts about their comments and Matt Richtel’s article about technology in schools in the comments section.

headline: In Classroom of Future, Stagnant Scores
text: CHANDLER, Ariz. — Amy Furman, a seventh-grade English teacher here, roams among 31 students sitting at their desks or in clumps on the floor. They’re studying Shakespeare’s “As You Like It” — but not in any traditional way.

headline: Sunday: That’s Disgusting!
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Dana Delany and I share a title, and no, it’s not celebrity. She was a guest-blogger back in April, and now she has teamed up with Matt Ginsberg to bring us this Sunday puzzle which, contrary to its title, is actually very pleasant.

headline: The Keys to Schiavone’s Comeback Victory

headline: At Fordham, Steps to Return to Glory

Sellouts at Yankee Stadium and the Polo Grounds were once the norm, so much so that the program generated enough interest to play in the first two televised football games.

headline: Santana’s Rehab Gets Back on Track
text: Johan Santana resumed his comeback from a torn capsule in his shoulder with a rehab start Saturday afternoon for the Class A Port St. Lucie Mets against Palm Beach. Santana threw 30 pitches, 21 of them for strikes, during two innings of work. He gave up three hits, one run and no walks and struck out two batters.

headline: Fish Wins, But the Last Two Sets Are Tough
text: Eighth-seeded Mardy Fish of the United States built a two-set lead in two hours of energetic shotmaking against Kevin Anderson of South Africa, then dropped into a lower gear before forging a straight-set victory, 6-4, 7-6 (4), 7-6 (3). The win moved him into the fourth round.

headline: Players Bowing Out in a Record Number
text: Six days into the United States Open, tournament organizers released a rare tennis-tournament injury report. This is common in the N.F.L., in which teams are required to release similar lists each week. But for the Open to take such measures took a retirement rate of record proportions.

text: NORTON, Mass. — There is just something about the long ball. The tape-measure jobs — the kind that scream power, raise the hair on the backs of necks, bring gasps and ovations from the crowds — have always been a vital part of golf’s appeal, even if very long hitters themselves often occupied the fringes of the sport.

Then, a few lines later: “One flag, one star, one state, one school.”

headline: Summer of Protest in Israel Peaks With 400,000 in City Streets

headline: At Telluride Screenings, the Awards Race Begins
text: Telluride is a friendly, informal, remote place where movie stars shed some of their glamor and mingle with the friendly crowds. George Clooney strolled into the patron’s brunch on Friday — an al fresco, invitation-only event held on the first morning of the film festival at a mountainside ranch with stunning views — and suddenly everyone seemed to be plotting a route to the beverage tent that would allow for an accidental elbow-brush and an impromptu chat. Eventually Mr. Clooney found his way to a table, and later to a semi-secret screening of “The Descendants,” Alexander Payne’s new film, his first feature since “Sideways” in 2004.

headline: Havre de Grace Becomes Second Filly to Win Woodward Stakes
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — When 4-year-old filly Havre de Grace trounced seven older males in the Woodward Stakes on Saturday, the best reaction did not come from her owner, her trainer, or the jockey who rode her to victory.

headline: Stumbling on Big Stage, Last Teenager Goes Out

text: PARIS — It was not quite like the arrival of a pope, with a kiss of the tarmac, but the press attention was comparable on Sunday morning when a relieved Dominique Strauss-Kahn returned to France.

headline: The Repository

A gauzy drapery divides the tent space: on one side, a quiet makeshift chapel; on the other, three walk-in storage units containing nearly 14,000 human remains from the World Trade Center catastrophe, air-dried and vacuum-sealed.

headline: Portraits Redrawn: Talat Hamdani
