headline: The Supply-side Virus
text: A correspondent suggests that now might be a good time to get my old Slate article on supply-side economics back into circulation. It does look pretty good, 15 years later.

headline: At Open, a New Look for the Bookstore
text: Four or five straight hours of tennis doesn’t seem to faze the players—even if Donald Young looked a bit wobbly after his marathon Friday night—but it’s tough on spectators. Not the matches themselves, but the heat, the sun, above all the surging crowds moving in a constant swarm through the grounds and inducing the claustrophobic feel of a subway platform with no train in sight.

headline: Journal Economics
text: Rereading my old supply-side article, I was reminded of just how consistently, awesomely wrong the Journal opinion section has been for two decades now. Think about it (no time for full links); by reading that section you could have learned, either from the editorial page proper or from the paper’s favorite op-ed guys, that

headline: Leaked Cables Offer Glimpses Into Relations of U.S. and China
text: BEIJING — This capital city’s skies were clogged with pollution, as is often the case, and China’s government was concerned. So it summoned officials of the American Embassy here to a meeting.

headline: After the Storm, a Treasure Hunt
text: Ana Ramirez, 35, of Coney Island swung her metal detector over the sand just off the Coney Island Boardwalk in the shadow of the Wonder Wheel ride.

headline: China Aims to Rein In Car Sales
text: TIANJIN, China — After a decade of nurturing China’s auto industry to become the largest in the world, this country’s leaders are having second thoughts.

headline: China Sought to Sell Arms to Qaddafi, Documents Suggest
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — In the final weeks of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s battle with Libyan rebels, Chinese state companies offered to sell his government large stockpiles of weapons and ammunition in apparent violation of United Nations sanctions, officials of Libya’s transitional government said Sunday. They cited Qaddafi government documents found by a Canadian journalist, which the officials said were authentic.

headline: In Final Event, Jamaica Sets a World Record in Relay
text: DAEGU, South Korea — It was not the most symbolic finish: Usain Bolt sprinting unaccompanied with a 10-meter lead on his way to another world record.

headline: Cheney Wonders: What Would Hillary Do?
text: It has become a popular refrain for Democrats bemoaning a president who has spent the summer slamming into one political road block after another: If Hillary Rodham Clinton had won the party’s nomination and the general election in 2008, would she have been a more effective president?

headline: In New Jersey, Obama Vows Federal Help, Not Washington Politics
text: PATERSON, N.J. — President Obama, surveying some of the most crippling flood damage from Tropical Storm Irene, vowed on Sunday that budgetary wrangling in Washington would not delay federal aid to stricken communities.

headline: ‘The Help’ Holds No. 1 at the Box Office
text: “The Help” officially achieved blockbuster status over the weekend by holding onto the No. 1 spot at North American multiplexes for a third consecutive week. That DreamWorks Studios movie, based on the best-selling novel about black maids in the 1960s and their white employers, took in an estimated $14.2 million for a new total of $122 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data. Second place went to “The Debt,” a Focus Features espionage drama that sold a surprisingly robust $9.7 million in tickets for a total of about $14 million since opening on Wednesday; solid reviews and the potential thrill of seeing Helen Mirren as a retired but still derrière-kicking Mossad agent probably drove interest. The weekend’s other two new releases came in neck and neck: “Apollo 18,” a thriller from the Weinstein Company, was a limp third with an estimated $8.7 million in ticket sales, and “Shark Night 3-D” (Relativity Media) took in about $8.6 million for fourth place. Rounding out the top five was 20th Century Fox’s “Rise of the Planet of the Apes,” which sold $7.8 million in tickets for a five-week total of about $160 million.

headline: TNT Ends Jada Pinkett Smith’s Show
text: As TNT approached the end of a summer that gave it two new hit shows, “Falling Skies” and “Franklin & Bash,” the cable channel pulled the plug on an older show, “HawthoRNe.” The channel said on Friday that it had elected not to order a fourth season of the show, which featured Jada Pinkett Smith as chief nursing officer at a hospital. “TNT truly appreciates the tremendous dedication of everyone involved,” it said in a statement. TNT recently ordered a second season of “Falling Skies,” which was the most popular new cable show of the summer with an average of 6.9 million viewers, and “Franklin & Bash,” which averaged 3.9 million. The third season of “HawthoRNe” typically had about 3.3 million viewers. The cancellation may also make room for one of the shows that TNT is developing, like its remake of “Dallas” or its spin-off of “The Closer,” “Major Crimes.”

headline: Nadal Dispatches Nalbandian
text: If you’ve ever noticed that Rafael Nadal looks fresh and ready for action when he arrives on court for a match, the secret is out. He takes a cold shower.

headline: Kerber of Germany Strolls Into Women’s Quarterfinals
text: The random nature of tennis draws rarely makes for an even, linear progression in difficulty through a tournament.

headline: Bloomberg and Goldsmith Make First Comments on Deputy Mayor’s Arrest
text: On Sunday, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg made his first public comments responding to the firestorm of criticism over misleading information that he gave to the public regarding the resignation of former Deputy Mayor Stephen Goldsmith. Also on Sunday, Mr. Goldsmith emailed The Times with a statement. Here’s a transcript of Mayor Bloomberg’s remarks, given outside the Christian Cultural Center in Brooklyn, followed by the text of Mr. Goldsmith’s email.

headline: Looking for a Game
text: Martin Emmrich of Germany and his doubles partner, Andreas Siljeström, from Sweden, flew to New York with the hope that someone would withdraw from the United States Open and give them a chance to play in their first Grand Slam event.

headline: Jets Put McElroy on Injured Reserve; Juggle Roster
text: Greg McElroy’s rookie season ended Sunday when the Jets placed him on injured reserve as part of a series of roster-sculpturing moves.

headline: A Survivor in Libya
text: Salem al-Madhoun, a Libyan Navy officer who defected to the rebels, was imprisoned and tortured by Qaddafi's forces. He's recently been set free and tells his story.

headline: Rare Power From Jeter, Standard Quality From Sabathia
text: Derek Jeter did two things Sunday that he does not usually do. He pulled a three-run homer into the left-field bleachers, and he knocked in five runs.

headline: When the Mayor’s Management Style Becomes a Study in Arrested Development
text: Now 10 years into his mayoralty, Michael R. Bloomberg still tends to view the office of the mayor as akin to a hallway at Bloomberg L.P.

headline: What Is Naturalism?
text: Many contemporary philosophers describe themselves as naturalists. They mean that they believe something like this: there is only the natural world, and the best way to find out about it is by the scientific method. I am sometimes described as a naturalist. Why do I resist the description? Not for any religious scruple: I am an atheist of the most straightforward kind. But accepting the naturalist slogan without looking beneath the slick packaging is an unscientific way to form one’s beliefs about the world, not something naturalists should recommend.

headline: Close Out the Summer With 2-For-1 Broadway Tickets
text: Interested in two tickets for the price of one to “Wicked?” How about seeing either “The Lion King” or Martin Luther King Jr. (subject of the new play “The Mountaintop”)? A promotion from the marketing and tourism organization NYC & Company will say farewell to summer with a discount deal that includes these shows and several more as part of Broadway Week, which runs Sept. 18-30.

headline: For Satin, a Mets Farmhand, 1 Hit, 1 Run, Plenty of Thrills
text: WASHINGTON — Josh Satin strolled into Nationals Park just after 10 a.m. on Sunday and quickly fell into step with a reporter, who asked him about being in the Mets’ lineup for their game that afternoon.

headline: When the Camera Takes Over
text: Amateur photographers become a part of the art at the Venice Biennale.

headline: When the Camera Takes Over for the Eye
text: SCIENTISTS have yet to determine what percentage of art-viewing these days is done through the viewfinder of a camera or a cellphone, but clearly the figure is on the rise. That’s why Ruth Fremson, the intrepid photographer for The New York Times who covered the Venice Biennale this summer, returned with so many images of people doing more or less what she was doing: taking pictures of works of art or people looking at works of art. More or less.

headline: Tennis Channel Pulled From Cablevision and Verizon Systems
text: Cablevision and Verizon FiOS customers abruptly lost their access to Tennis Channel on Sunday midway through the United States Open.

headline: Roddick Shows Another Side in Latest Victory
text: There just might be something left to Andy Roddick at this year’s U.S. Open after all. Roddick roared back to life with a convincing 6-1, 6-4, 7-6 win over Julien Benneteau, mixing power with patience, serving with authority but also playing with a high shot tolerance. Compared with his first two rounds, in which he looked tentative and defensive, Roddick worked the point until he got a short ball then approached with a knifing backhand slice. His ground game and movement were visibly improved from his awkward win over Jack Sock on Friday night.

headline: Monday: Feels Great!
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Well, hello there! I hope you all had a good week, and before we tear into another week’s worth of crossword puzzles, I’d like to sincerely thank Thomas Gaffney for stepping up to the plate and batting them out of the park while I was off mopping my brow. Tom did an excellent job, as did the wonderful players in the dugout who helped support him, and they all deserve a round of applause from the fans in the stands. I’d throw some more baseball metaphors in there, but that’s pretty much all I’ve got. My point is, he did a great job and I had a wonderful vacation, so thanks again, Tom.

headline: Postal Service Is Nearing Default as Losses Mount
text: The United States Postal Service has long lived on the financial edge, but it has never been as close to the precipice as it is today: the agency is so low on cash that it will not be able to make a $5.5 billion payment due this month and may have to shut down entirely this winter unless Congress takes emergency action to stabilize its finances.

headline: China Challenges U.S. Supremacy in Shale Gas
text: China has a chance of challenging the United States for shale supremacy. So far, only the United States has significantly exploited domestic reserves of shale gas. But Sinopec, China’s major state-run oil company, is now taking shale seriously and lacks many of the roadblocks that have held back developers in other countries.

headline: Counterstrike
text: KNOW THINE ENEMY

headline: What We Kept
text: A selection of items kept by Times readers who were living in New York City on Sept. 11.

headline: Townsend Advances in Juniors
text: The first round of the U.S. Open junior girls’ singles draw got underway on Sunday and the 15-year-old Taylor Townsend just needed 60 minutes to advance. Townsend, who lost in the third round of the women’s qualifying tournament a week and a half ago, defeated No. 15 Jesika Maleckova with ease, 6-1, 6-4.

headline: The Power of Bill
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.

headline: Palin Is Running, but in a Half-Marathon
text: DES MOINES – Sarah Palin decided on Sunday that she was running – a half-marathon, that is.

headline: Deterring Enemies in a Shaken World
text: In an audacious operation that unfolded like a Hollywood thriller, the Navy Seals executed a daring raid deep into Pakistan to kill Osama bin Laden. The departing members of the Seals took not only the body of bin Laden but also a cache of invaluable intelligence on his organization, Al Qaeda. It is fitting that Eric Schmitt and Thom Shanker, veteran security correspondents for The New York Times, begin and end their insightful new book about United States counterterrorism efforts with this triumph. The United States, they argue, could not have pulled off the same raid 10 years ago. The bin Laden strike was the “logical culmination of nearly a decade of missteps, mistakes, trial and error under fire, and ultimately lessons not only learned but taken to heart.”

headline: Film Is Skeptical About Domestic Efforts on Terrorism
text: LOS ANGELES — The film “Better This World” introduces itself with the frightening sounds of television anchors filtering the news of a terrorist plot against the Republican National Convention in 2008. “Disturbing news tonight about homegrown terror,” one of the anchors says, not for the first time and not for the last.

headline: In California, Amazon Pushes Hard to Kill a Tax
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The struggling state of California thinks it has found gold in taxing e-commerce. But that money is proving much more elusive than it seemed just a few months ago.

headline: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include the I.S.M. nonmanufacturing index for August (Tuesday); the Federal Reserve’s beige book (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims and the July trade deficit and consumer credit figures (Thursday), and wholesale trade for July (Friday).

headline: Chunks of Memory, Reassembled Onstage
text: Last year Rock the Bells, the touring hip-hop bonanza, picked up on the voguish festival concept in which an artist performs an old record from beginning to end. It went well, and this year’s edition bought in twice as hard. On Saturday on Governors Island, amid other, more ordinary sets, 11 albums were performed in their entirety.

headline: An Island Sways to Dance Moves and Disco Balls
text: Clean or dirty? Uplifting or brutal? Those were choices dance-music fans could make on Saturday, the second day of the weekend-long Electric Zoo 2011 on Randalls Island. They could go for the polished tones, warm chords and step-by-step buildups of trance and house, the overlapping styles that have long dominated dance clubs worldwide and that gave Electric Zoo its headliners: Tiesto on Friday, David Guetta on Saturday and Armin van Buuren on Sunday. The unsubtle four-on-the-floor beat of trance has been a longtime staple of European pop hits, and in recent years American acts like Black Eyed Peas, Lady Gaga and Rihanna have also embraced it.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: A Nuclear Bunker Comes In From the Cold as an Art Gallery
text: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina — The Yugoslav Army would have been hard pressed to find a more scenic spot to build a nuclear bunker.

headline: Standard Fare Upended, to Reinvent and Explore
text: Among the numerous innovations instituted at Bargemusic by the violinist Mark Peskanov since he became its president and executive and artistic director in 2006, the least likely wrinkle has proved the most durable. Here and Now, an irregularly scheduled but consistently active series devoted to contemporary music, has enlivened the offerings at this longtime bastion for conventional fare.

headline: Nadal Wins; Then Comes the Hard Part
text: In his recently published autobiography, Rafael Nadal paints an unvarnished picture of professional tennis, one that exposes unsightly wrinkles like the friction between him and the loved one who is his coach, and the pain and insecurities and loneliness of the gilded life.

headline: With or Without an AT&T Deal for T-Mobile, Sprint Faces Daunting Challenges
text: If the Justice Department succeeds in blocking the $39 billion merger of AT&T and T-Mobile, the deepest sighs of relief may well come from the executives at Sprint Nextel, the country’s third-largest wireless carrier.

headline: Delaying Diamonds at Youth Congress
text: As I have mentioned, the American performances at the second World Youth Congress in Croatia last month were disappointing, However, Roger Lee of Monrovia, Calif., would have won the award for the best-played deal had there been one. It is in the diagramed deal and occurred during the Knockout Teams.

headline: A Squeaky-Clean Shot at Pop Stardom
text: The musical children’s television series “The Wannabes,” a synthetic but inoffensive piece of international entertainment product, won’t add much to the Starz channels’ reputation as sources of original content. Its virtues lie more in the area of brand extension.

headline: World Track and Field Championships
text: The nine-day meet in Daegu, South Korea, ended with excitement in the 4x100-meter relays.

headline: Rosel Zech, a Movie Actress Favored by Fassbinder, Dies at 69
text: Rosel Zech, a German actress best known to American audiences for playing the title role in Rainer Werner Fassbinder’s grim 1982 satire, “Veronika Voss,” died on Wednesday in Berlin. She was 69.

headline: Vermont Turns Out for Its Dairies as They Take Stock and Dig Out
text: SOUTH ROYALTON, Vt. — As soon as the news of the disaster at the Perley Farm began to spread — how the fast-rising waters of the White River had washed away nearly 200 bales of hay, flooded the farmhouse and then swept some of the cows down the river to their deaths — neighbors and strangers alike began arriving at the muddy barn here to offer help.

headline: Facebook Page for Jesus, With Highly Active Fans
text: A North Carolina diet doctor has come up with a formula to create the most highly engaged audience on Facebook in the world, far surpassing marketing efforts by celebrities and sports teams. He draws on the words of Jesus and posts them four or five times a day.

headline: Ways to Use The Learning Network
text: For school year 2011-12.

headline: Neither Smurf Nor Wizard Could Save Summer Movie Attendance
text: LOS ANGELES — It was the summer that North American movie attendance continued to slide, Hollywood’s reliance on overseas ticket sales intensified, the Smurfs flexed their minimuscles and a cadre of A-list stars flopped — again.

headline: Ex-Premier Faces Charges for Iceland’s Fiscal Woes
text: REYKJAVIK, Iceland — The dust from Iceland’s spectacular financial disaster — the failure of its three biggest banks and then the collapse of its economy in the fall of 2008 — had barely begun to settle when the country set about finding someone to blame.

headline: Partisan Fighting Carries Risks at Election Time
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s renewed engagement with Congressional Republicans this week may seem all too familiar, but it comes with a darkly unpredictable component.

headline: For Some Eagles, a Dream Situation
text: In his first news conference with Philadelphia, Vince Young set the tone for the team and the city when he was asked to characterize the Eagles’ collection of high-profile talent.

headline: Lee Loses Strength, but Still Poses a Flooding Threat
text: NEW ORLEANS — The remnants of what was once Tropical Storm Lee, a slow-moving but extremely wet system that lumbered its way onto the Louisiana coast on Sunday, were still bringing high winds and rains to the Gulf Coast on Monday morning, leaving a wet Labor Day but less damage than had been feared.

headline: Amid a Large City, a Noisy Racing Village
text: BALTIMORE — For the inaugural Baltimore Grand Prix, a three-day event featuring major IndyCar and Le Mans-style street races, downtown Baltimore was transformed into a festive street fair, with just a dash of disaster-movie quarantine zone.

headline: Anger After a Raid Kills a Wealthy Afghan With a Murky Past
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — In life and death, Sabar Lal’s story was riddled with conflicting narratives.

headline: Discharged for Being Gay, Veterans Seek to Re-enlist
text: They lived shadow lives in the military, afraid that disclosure of their sexuality would ruin carefully plotted careers. Many were deeply humiliated by drawn-out investigations and unceremonious discharges.

headline: Tough Times in the Second City
text: Chicago

headline: China’s Challenge at Sea
text: Princeton, N.J.

headline: Inmate Visits Now Carry Added Cost in Arizona
text: For the Arizona Department of Corrections, crime has finally started to pay.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Romney Draws Sparse Protest at Tea Party Event
text: Mitt Romney’s keynote speech Sunday night at a Tea Party Express rally in Concord, N.H., was perhaps more notable for what did not happen — there were no fiery clashes with Tea Party protesters, or angry hecklers — than for what did — Mr. Romney delivered a lively version of his standard stump speech.

headline: Leaving Detroit for Tulsa, the Shock Lost Their Way
text: TULSA, Okla. — Once, it seemed an intriguing idea for prefab success, dismantling a three-time W.N.B.A. championship team in Detroit and relocating it brick by brick to this regional hotbed for women’s basketball.

headline: Radio D.J. in the Catskills Offered a Lifeline During the Storm
text: WINDHAM, N.Y. — In these days of smartphones and social media, a small-town radio D.J. like Big Jay Fink may seem like an improbable source of emergency information.

headline: Libyans Turn Wrath on Dark-Skinned Migrants
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — As rebel leaders pleaded with their fighters to avoid taking revenge against “brother Libyans,” many rebels were turning their wrath against migrants from sub-Saharan Africa, imprisoning hundreds for the crime of fighting as “mercenaries” for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi without any evidence except the color of their skin.

headline: Injury Sidelines Bud Collins and His Pants
text: Bud Collins had picked out a gaudy purple pair of slacks, with appropriate floral patterns, but he never got to wear them to the United States Open on Sunday.

headline: Migrants Face the Suspicions and Wrath of Libyan Rebels
text: Libyan rebels have imprisoned hundreds of migrants from sub-Saharan Africa, accusing them of being mercenaries for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: A Tech Blogger Who Leaps Over the Line
text: When Michael Arrington, the editor of the popular Web site TechCrunch, told his bosses at AOL that he was forming a venture capital company to finance some of the technology start-ups that his site wrote about, they did not fire him or ask for his resignation. Instead, last week, they invested about $10 million in his fund.

headline: The Fatal Distraction
text: Friday brought two numbers that should have everyone in Washington saying, “My God, what have we done?”

headline: Migrants Face the Suspicions and Wrath of Libyan Rebels
text: Libyan rebels have imprisoned hundreds of migrants from sub-Saharan Africa, accusing them of being mercenaries for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: Samsung Removes Tablet From Trade Show After Injunction
text: Samsung Electronics will not showcase the Galaxy Tab 7.7, its latest tablet computer, at one of the largest electronics shows after Apple won a second injunction blocking sales of the computer in Germany.

headline: Hopes Rising, G.O.P. Voters Seek a Winner
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Roy Barbuto is on the hunt. For the past few months, he has been searching for the perfect Republican candidate, and he shows no signs of flagging.

headline: Home-Court Edge? Roddick Takes It, Happily
text: Late in the match, Andy Roddick heard a team-sport cheer, the kind the Yankees hear from their Bleacher Creatures, the kind the Rangers hear from the upper rows of the Garden.

headline: It’s Still the 9/11 Era
text: Osama bin Laden is dead. So is Saddam Hussein, and Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, and too many Qaeda No. 3’s to count. Khalid Shaikh Mohammed is awaiting his military tribunal. George W. Bush is home on the ranch, Dick Cheney is on book tour, and even Gen. David Petraeus is a general no more, having traded in his stars for a civilian position atop the Central Intelligence Agency.

headline: A Debate Arises on Job Creation and Environment
text: Do environmental regulations kill jobs?

headline: L.S.U.’s Coach Makes People Chuckle, but His Team Usually Has the Last Laugh
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — With his stiff-brimmed hat, penchant for straight-to-YouTube sound bites and a legacy of play calls as daring as his clock management is baffling, Louisiana State’s Les Miles is equal parts cult figure and football coach. Miles eats grass, kissed a pig at a charity event this off-season and can rival Yogi Berra for his meandering turns of phrase.

headline: On Flood Plain, Pondering Wisdom of Rebuilding Anew
text: PHOENICIA, N.Y. — For all the destruction and heartache left by Tropical Storm Irene in the Catskill Mountains, the storm was only the latest to cause catastrophic flooding in the region in recent years. With each one, residents have cleaned up, rebuilt and moved on, as resolutely as ever. Now, though, some are asking a once-unthinkable question: Should the rebuilding come to a halt?

headline: Lessons on Health Care
text: Rick Perry and Mitt Romney, two of the leading candidates right now for the Republican presidential nomination, have declared themselves fiercely opposed to President Obama’s health care reform.

headline: With One Day to Go, Leader Board Shows a Throng at the Top
text: NORTON, Mass. — It is a fairly safe bet that cars heading north on Route 95 out of Cape Cod on Monday will not be packed any tighter than golfers on the leader board after three rounds of the Deutsche Bank Championship.

headline: State Election Adds to Gains by Social Democrats in Germany
text: BERLIN — Parties on the German left prevailed in a regional election in the northeastern state of Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania on Sunday, with the center-left Social Democrats swept back to power and the Greens elected to the regional parliament for the first time, according to preliminary results.

headline: Once-Rising Star Finds Closer View of the Top
text: Donald Young, once a teenage prodigy with the future of American tennis on his shoulders, entered the United States Open as an afterthought.

headline: All-American, Floor to Roof? Not So Simple
text: BOZEMAN, Mont. — Anders Lewendal, a general contractor who managed to survive the housing collapse, has hit upon a plan that he thinks will revive the construction industry and help lead the nation out of the economic wilderness: build houses using only American-made materials.

headline: A Tiny New Stage for High-Energy Tennis
text: The latest attraction in Flushing Meadows resides eight feet below ground level, in a virtually private corner of the National Tennis Center, past the chaos of the food court and beyond the shadow of Arthur Ashe Stadium.

headline: Media Strive to Cover 9/11 Without Seeming to Exploit a Tragedy
text: Anniversaries are hard to resist for most media outlets. The stories are evergreen, the advertising potential plentiful.

headline: Suspect Is Sought After 8 Are Wounded in Bronx Shooting
text: Eight people, including three children, were shot at a crowded backyard party in the Bronx early Sunday, and the police said they were looking for a 17-year-old in connection with the shooting.

headline: Japan’s Latest Prime Minister
text: Little remains of the bright promises of reform that swept Japan’s Democratic Party to power two years ago. The ruling Democrats’ choice of Finance Minister Yoshihiko Noda to become prime minister — the party’s third since that historic election — is uninspired and unlikely to provide the strong and creative leadership Japan needs to recover from the earthquake, tsunami and nuclear disaster or its longer-term economic malaise.

headline: Catholic School Teachers Wrestle With Faith and Obedience in Negotiating a Contract
text: Wednesday morning, on the first day of the new school year at St. Paul’s Roman Catholic School in East Harlem, Gertrude Zagarella expects to arrive, as always, at 7:05. By 7:45, the children — mostly Hispanic, black and poor — will be done with breakfast, and then it is Ms. Zagarella’s responsibility to lead all the students, from kindergartners to eighth graders, into the gym for morning prayers.

headline: For Civil Court: Manhattan and Brooklyn
text: New York’s system of electing the city’s Civil Court judges makes no sense. Candidates run in a particular district or borough, but they can end up sitting anywhere in the city, and not even on the court for which they were chosen. Right now, most new Civil Court judges are reassigned for a year or more to relieve pressures on the city’s Criminal and Family Courts, a situation that, in turn, puts strains on the workings of Civil Court.

headline: City Learns Lessons From the Storm, Many of Them the Hard Way
text: Changes both large and small will be made to the way New York City responds to hurricane emergencies in the future, including how evacuations will be publicized and executed, after officials learned valuable lessons from the unprecedented emptying of the waterfront as Tropical Storm Irene bore down on the five boroughs.

headline: To Celebrate Holy Month’s End, Libya Rebels Open Government Offices to Public
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — After the Muslim holy month of Ramadan ends with the Id al-Fitr holiday, Libyan employers traditionally throw a reception for their workers. On Sunday, the interim rebel government decided to make its reception a little different and declared an open house.

headline: This Labor Day
text: There is something a little puzzling about Labor Day. On Thanksgiving we do give thanks, but on Labor Day we do not labor. To the proverbial visitor from outer space, the name of the holiday might suggest 24 hours of national housekeeping, a communal exertion of effort toward some unspecified end.

headline: Corrections: September 5
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: As Sports Medicine Surges, Hope and Hype Outpace Proven Treatments
text: Until she tore her hamstring a year and a half ago, Tina Basle ran marathons. Since then, she has been on a desperate search for a cure.

headline: As Murray Manhandles López Again, Only the Score Is Ugly
text: Feliciano López sauntered on court at Arthur Ashe Stadium late Sunday, his long brown hair pulled back in a ponytail, his beard trimmed just so, his shirt very tight and very bright and very blue. He received an ovation appropriate for a tennis heartthrob.

headline: Lottery Numbers
A Record-Breaking Tie Breaker
text: On Sunday night at the United States Open, with a quarterfinal berth in women’s singles on the line, Samantha Stosur of Australia and Maria Kirilenko of Russia began a second-set tie break. It was not decided for 32 points, which, according to tournament officials, made it the longest tie breaker in women’s Grand Slam history.

headline: The Key Player in the Pac-12’s Expansion Outlook: It’s Texas, Again
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — The eyes of college sports are again on Texas, where the next move in the seismic shift of the major conference landscape is expected to begin.

headline: Frank C. Arricale, Youth Board Leader Who Calmed Race Tensions, Dies at 81
text: The summer of 1966 was long and hot, and racial tension crackled on the streets of Brooklyn. Frank C. Arricale, as the director of New York City’s Youth Board, reached out to people from different ethnic groups to keep unrest from erupting into violence.

headline: Julio Casas Regueiro, Cuba’s Defense Chief, Dies at 75
text: HAVANA — Gen. Julio Casas Regueiro, the Cuban defense minister, who spent two decades at the helm of the military’s powerful complex of businesses and was a close associate of President Raúl Castro, died Saturday in Havana. He was 75.

headline: Fantasy Tournament Reaches Semifinals
text: Stunning upsets, close and gritty battles and a few routs marked the first round of The Times’s fantasy United States Open Tournament, with the thoughts of modern technology and big serves resonating with voters.

headline: ‘The Tennis Channel Has Been Removed’
text: 2:58 p.m. | Updated Tennis fans are used to going to great lengths to follow their sport. We endure tape delays, mid-match channel switches, pre-empted matches, and, in some cases, having to buy pricey top-tier cable packages in order to get the Tennis Channel. Nothing surprises me any more when it comes to tennis coverage, but the subject line of an e-mail I received from my cable provider, Verizon Fios, on Sunday managed to catch my attention.

headline: Complaint Box | Labor Daze
text: Every morning, I sweep the 30 feet of sidewalk in front of my store in Chelsea, and often several more times a day, to keep the area attractive and to avoid getting the nasty fines the city loves to hand out. While I wish that there weren’t so many New Yorkers who just blindly drop their garbage wherever they are walking or standing (there is a trash can only 20 feet from my shop), I know that is too much to expect.

headline: Monday Reading: Airlines Offer V.I.P. Treatment for a Fee
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

Between Friday’s US job report and today’s economic news from the rest of the world, it’s hard to avoid the sense that things are going bust all over. Austerity is really biting, and the global economy is sputtering.

headline: Syria Allows Red Cross Officials to Visit Prison
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syria opened its main prison in Damascus on Monday to a delegation from the International Committee of the Red Cross for the first time since the uprising started in mid-March, amid hopes that the move could begin to reveal the fate of thousands of political detainees.

headline: Tech Support
text: Tim Coppens’s first complete men’s collection is a wonder not just of technical proficiency — Coppens was formerly the design director of Ralph Lauren’s futuristic sportswear line, RLX — but also of economy. Coppens, a Belgian-born Royal Academy of Fine Arts grad, has no office, no employees and he’s financing his 45-piece collection by himself. The design references are varied. They include a spit and polish riff on the leather jackets and baggy sweats of the Paris banlieues and also a curious repurposing of a Persian Farahan rug, which Coppens chopped up to form the back of a leather-sleeved varsity jacket. Characteristically, that jacket is assembled with almost clinical precision, but the carpet segment is left frayed on the bottom — an inspired touch. “I don’t want to be brand-marked as a technical designer,” Coppens says. “I want to make beautiful collections with classic fabrics. But the technical aspect gives me a good starting point.”

headline: On the Inadequacy of the Stimulus
text: Hmm. I don’t think I’ve ever put up a simple explanation of why the stimulus was so clearly inadequate to the task. By the way, my point here is not what Obama shoulda-coulda done; I just want to look at the straight economics.

headline: Can Obama Escape the Alberta Tar Pit?
text: President Obama is in a situation right now somewhat akin to that facing the creatures that once prowled the edges of the La Brea tar pits — a sticky trap that caught and consumed the least wary or agile members of many species.

headline: Even in Victory, Roddick Loses the Spotlight
text: After a wobbly performance against journeyman Michael Russell in the first round and an adequate performance over young Jack Sock in the second, Andy Roddick finally seemed to come into his own in his third-round match Sunday at the 2011 U.S. Open, defeating Julien Benneteau 6-1, 6-4, 7-6(5).

headline: The TV Watch: No Jerry Lewis, but Telethon Still Offers Suspense
text: Jerry Lewis wasn’t there.

headline: European Bankers Urge Leaders to Move Quickly on Debt Crisis
text: PARIS — As the stock and bond markets seem eerily similar to the dark days of 2008, Jean-Claude Trichet and Mario Draghi, the current and incoming chiefs of the European Central Bank, pointedly urged European leaders to move quickly to ensure that the euro zone’s debt crisis does not become seriously worse.

headline: Imps of the Perverse
text: Two guys meet in a bar. It’s an awful place. The music is terrible, and they are the only people in it with any sense of style. One is 6-foot-2, dark and dazzling. The other is just as tall and good-looking, but with yellow hair and a droll expression. They blow out of the bar and discover they both live not only on the same street but also in the same building.

headline: British Panel to Examine Libya Rendition Reports
text: LONDON — A British panel investigating the behavior of the country’s intelligence agencies toward terrorism suspects will examine new accusations of close cooperation between British spies and Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s government, Prime Minister David Cameron said Monday.

headline: For Monaco, It’s All in the Details
text: Juan Monaco has advanced to the fourth round with three convincing wins, besting Andreas Seppi, Radek Stepanek, and Tommy Haas with a relentless, passionate style that has impressed me. I watched him beat Stepanek and Haas, and his ability to play high-percentage, patient backcourt tennis, coupled with his back-arching, athletic serve, makes him an atypical claycourter.

headline: Pakistan Points to Help From U.S. in Qaeda Arrests
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — American and Pakistani officials celebrated their cooperation on Monday as Pakistan announced the arrests of three men they identified as senior operatives of Al Qaeda who had been planning attacks on American and other Western targets.

headline: Perry Skips Forum to Focus on Texas Fires
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Rick Perry, the governor of Texas, will skip a forum for Republican presidential candidates here on Monday afternoon so he can deal with wildfires raging across his state, a spokesman confirmed.

headline: Strike at La Scala Forces Cancellation of Vienna Staatsoper Performance
text: Citing “the extremes of an anti-union attitude,’’ workers at La Scala opera house in Milan have announced a strike that will cause the cancellation of a performance of Beethoven’s “Fidelio” by the Vienna Staatsoper this week, Agence France-Presse reported.

headline: Europeans Talk of Sharp Change in Fiscal Affairs
text: As leaders in Europe try to contain a deepening financial crisis, they are also increasingly talking about making fundamental changes to the way their 17-nation economic union works.

headline: Romney Plays Down G.O.P.-Tea Party Strife
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. – Mitt Romney, the former Massachusetts governor, tried to bridge the gap between himself and the Tea Party on Monday morning, telling a gathering of supporters that the differences between the Tea Party and traditional Republicans were not as wide as many people seem to believe.

headline: One Sperm Donor, 150 Offspring
text: Cynthia Daily and her partner used a sperm donor to conceive a baby seven years ago, and they hoped that one day their son would get to know some of his half siblings — an extended family of sorts for modern times.

text: Researchers in the Himalayas have uncovered a woolly rhinoceros fully a million years older than the ones that roamed Europe and Asia in the ice age.

headline: Lawyers for Michael Jackson’s Doctor Fight to Have Jurors Sequestered
text: Lawyers for Michael Jackson’s doctor are trying to overturn a judge’s refusal to sequester jurors for the doctor’s manslaughter trial, saying they will be “poisoned” by the media frenzy surrounding the trial unless they are kept in isolation.

headline: Newly Found Star Puzzles Scientists
text: A newly discovered star in the constellation Leo — too faint to be seen through any but the most powerful amateur telescopes — has so little mass and such a low level of metal elements that scientists were previously unaware that such a star could exist.

headline: Perry Stirs Supporters, Then Heads Home
text: CONWAY, S.C. — Gov. Rick Perry of Texas ended his South Carolina schedule early on Monday to oversee the emergency response to wildfires spreading in his state, but not before giving a large and friendly audience here a significant spoonful of his latest campaign theme: fiscally focused and folksy.

headline: U.N. Officials Say Famine Is Widening in Somalia
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The United Nations announced Monday that Somalia’s famine had spread to a sixth area within the country, with officials warning that 750,000 people could die in the next few months unless aid efforts were scaled up.

text: PARIS — The trial of former President Jacques Chirac of France on corruption charges will proceed without Mr. Chirac having to be present, a court decided Monday, citing the poor state of Mr. Chirac’s mental health.

headline: Like Former Mayors, a Statue Fades From View
text: He donated a plot from his backyard garden for New York’s original City Hall, where George Washington would be inaugurated as president. He presided as mayor over a government that assumed responsibility for paupers and banned slaughterhouses within the city limits. He even covered municipal deficits out of his own pocket.

headline: Madonna in Venice: From the Director’s Chair to the Red Carpet
text: The Venice Film Festival has kicked off the fall red carpet season with a bang, one that the Emmys on Sept. 18th will have a hard time topping. Among the standouts: Madonna, there to promote her debut as a film director, “W.E.,” (a film loosely based on the affair between Wallis Simpson and the Prince of Wales), and who showed up last Friday in a scene-stealing, floor-length, dove-grey gown adorned with red butterflies, a dress reportedly created for her by the French designer Vionnet (corrected from an earlier post). You can get a look at it from almost angle here.

headline: Nutrition: A Low-Calorie Meal Is Shown to Pay Off
text: Some dieters say that eating less at one meal is ineffective, because people compensate by eating more at other meals.

headline: Childbirth: Neonatal Deaths Slow, but U.S. Still Lags
text: According to a new analysis, the United States now ranks 41st in the world in terms of neonatal mortality, the death rate of infants less than one month old. The rate is higher in the United States than in, among others, Cuba, Slovakia, Croatia and all of Western Europe and Scandinavia.

headline: Judge Allows Suit Against Hungary Over  Artworks to Proceed

headline: Abbas Affirms Palestinian Bid for U.N. Membership

His goal, he said, was for a Palestinian state and Israel to live in peace and security next to one another.

headline: Diplomatic Strains Intensify Between Turkey and Israel

Turkish officials said that Turkish tourists were treated the same way at the Tel Aviv airport last week.

headline: Bike Crash Wiped Details; GPS Data Filled Them In
text: WOODSIDE, Calif. — After racing and biking back roads on the San Francisco Peninsula for almost half a century without serious incident, on July 3 I crashed while riding downhill at more than 30 miles an hour. I knocked myself out, broke my nose and was left with lots of road rash and stitches on my face, as well as a deep gash above my knee that went all the way to the patella.

headline: Bloomberg Again Defends Handling of Deputy’s Arrest

headline: 9/11 Books Released Into a Sea of Others

But the question remains whether people will want to read more about Sept. 11, especially after weeks of magazine covers, newspaper articles and wall-to-wall cable news coverage.

headline: When Lapses Are Not Just Signs of Aging
text: Who hasn’t struggled occasionally to come up with a desired word or the name of someone near and dear? I was still in my 40s when one day the first name of my stepmother of 30-odd years suddenly escaped me. I had to introduce her to a friend as “Mrs. Brody.”

headline: When a Chomp or a Slurp Is a Trigger for Outrage
text: For people with a condition that some scientists call misophonia, mealtime can be torture. The sounds of other people eating — chewing, chomping, slurping, gurgling — can send them into an instantaneous, blood-boiling rage.

headline: When Normal Sounds Are Excruciating
text: People with misophonia have an extreme reaction to certain sounds, often becoming enraged or anxious at the sound of chewing or someone clearing his throat, reports today’s Science Times.

headline: Salvatore Licitra, Operatic Tenor at Met, Is Dead at 43
text: Salvatore Licitra, a tenor with a ringing, powerful voice who rode a sensational surprise Metropolitan Opera debut to dozens of performances with the company, died on Monday in Catania, Sicily, nine days after being severely injured in a motor-scooter accident. He was 43. His death was reported on his Web site, salvatorelicitra.com.

headline: Illness Won’t Keep Buddy Ryan From Watching Sons’ Game
text: 3:05 p.m. | Updated Buddy Ryan will not miss the latest edition of his twin sons’ football rivalry – not even after being diagnosed with cancer for a fourth time. Rob Ryan, the Cowboys’ new defensive coordinator, said Monday in Irving, Tex., that his father plans to delay surgery until after Dallas faces the Jets, coached by Rex, on Sunday night at MetLife Stadium. Rob Ryan said his father learned last week that he had cancer in his glands. It also spread to his neck, Rob said.

Pence had hit a drive to the top of the right-field wall, where a couple of fans helped prevent the Marlins’ Bryan Petersen from catching it (video via MLB.com). The Phillies went on to lose, 5-4, in 14 innings.

headline: Bond Fund’s Gains Help Buoy Support for Money Manager

headline: Palin Praises Influence of the Tea Party

headline: Minor Changes for U.S.

headline: Russian Away

text: We had still not found the perfect duvet cover for my daughter Emma’s college dorm room when she went for a routine dental checkup and was told that her wisdom teeth had to come out, A.S.A.P.

headline: My Chemical Romance Fires Drummer
text: The New Jersey-based band My Chemical Romance has fired its drummer, Michael Pedicone, just a year after he joined the group and replaced him with Jarrod Alexander of Dead Country. According to a statement posted on the band’s Web site by the guitarist Frank Iero on Friday, Mr. Pedicone “was caught red handed stealing from the band and confessed to the police after our show last night in Auburn, Washington.” (Neither the Web site nor reports that followed have said what Mr. Pedicone is accused of having stolen.)

headline: Critics’ Picks: ‘Black Girl’
text: A. O. Scott looks at Ousmane Sembene’s film about a Senegalese maid working in a French home.

headline: Summer Journey to an Isle of Many Musical Languages
text: Governors Island is a bit off the beaten path, as concert sites go. But the idea of staging a summer music festival there, devoted mostly to contemporary works, is inspired. The island has already been transformed into a hybrid sculpture park and playground, and the flat open field at Colonels’ Row, bounded by elegant 19th-century houses, is as comfortable a setting for concerts as any park in Manhattan. What’s more, given the brevity of the offerings at the Rite of Summer Music Festival — the free concerts last an hour, without intermission — listeners have every reason to explore the island’s other artistic lures.

headline: It’s Not a Breeze, but Serena Williams Advances
text: In a blustery Arthur Ashe Stadium, Serena Williams blew hot and cold with the wind, beating No. 16 seed Ana Ivanovic 6-3, 6-4 in a streaky 75-minute fourth-round match.

headline: Sound, the Way the Brain Prefers to Hear It
text: LOS ANGELES — There is, perhaps, no more uplifting musical experience than hearing the “Hallelujah” chorus from Handel’s “Messiah” performed in a perfect space. Many critics regard Symphony Hall in Boston — 70 feet wide, 120 feet long and 65 feet high — as just that space.

headline: Montero Hits First Major League Homer, Then His Second
text: Yankees designated hitter Jesus Montero hit his first major league home run Monday afternoon, leading off the fifth inning with a blast into the right-field seats against Jim Johnson, a right-handed Orioles reliever. The hit gave the Yankees a 9-8 lead.

headline: Memory Process Takes Years to Fully Develop
text: Children have memories, but the ability to remember the origin of memories develops slowly. A new study reports that this ability matures during adolescence and fully develops only in adulthood.

headline: Beware of September
text: Investors who spent August on the beach were fortunate to miss a bout of roller-coaster trading. And they will be rested for the next round, a taste of which came on Friday. The concerns behind the last volatile patch still have not been addressed.

headline: Optimism in Libya on Talks With Remaining Loyalists
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Rebel negotiators have resumed talks with loyalist holdouts in the desert town of Bani Walid in an effort to persuade them to surrender peacefully before a Sept. 10 deadline set by the interim government, Libyan officials said Monday.

headline: Yankees’ Top Prospect Fits In Quickly
text: The Yankees unleashed another onslaught on Monday afternoon as the stars of their relentless offense pounded the overmatched Baltimore Orioles. There was Mark Teixeira hitting another home run. There was Robinson Cano blasting his third grand slam of the season. There was Curtis Granderson smacking a two-run double. There were all three adding to their triple-digit runs-batted-in statistics.

headline: U.S. Open Replay: Day 8
text: Images from Day 8 of the United States Open in Flushing Meadows, Queens.

headline: Day the Colts Dreaded Is Finally Here
text: During the 208 consecutive regular-season games and 19 playoff games Peyton Manning has started since he was a rookie in 1998, no player in the N.F.L. has been more intrinsic to his team’s success than he has. The Indianapolis Colts have gone to the playoffs in all but two of Manning’s 13 seasons, including the last nine, and his brilliance has covered a multitude of holes on their roster.

headline: A Constant Traveler, and Impromptu Nanny
text: I ALWAYS have to laugh when people say they’re Zen about flying. I have no clue what that means. There’s nothing really calming about it.

headline: Tressel Will Wait to Work for Colts Until Week 7
text: When the N.F.L. suspended the former Ohio State quarterback Terrelle Pryor for the first five games of the season — a punishment that mirrors a suspension he would have served for rules infractions had he stayed in college — it angered players and created a sticky situation. Had the league created a precedent it would be willing to follow for coaches who get in trouble with the N.C.A.A. but then jump to the N.F.L.?

headline: A Bounty of Documentaries at Toronto Festival
text: LOS ANGELES — “When I talk to you, it does not necessarily mean that I have to like you,” Werner Herzog, off-camera, can be heard telling the death-row inmate Michael Perry in the opening minutes of “Into the Abyss,” a new documentary about Mr. Perry’s execution in Texas last year for the murder of a 50-year-old nurse, Sandra Stotler.

headline: Retailers Summon Optimism as They Enter a Critical Season

headline: Numberplay: A Flutter on the High Seas
text: Hi folks, I’m back from one of the most relaxing vacations of my life – on a cruise ship to the Caribbean. It’s an experience I’d heartily recommend for everyone, with activities suitable for people of all temperaments. You would imagine there was no scope for Numberplay to intrude on my blissful relaxation, but on the contrary, I had to construct and solve several Numberplay-type puzzles while on the cruise – and I’d like nothing better than to share them with you.

headline: Glamour in the Skies
text: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — Judging from the popularity of the Broadway show “Boeing Boeing” and plans for a television series based on the world of Pam Am stewardesses, the public seems to long for the days when airlines prided themselves on their flight attendants and the pampering they provided.

headline: Hiding Up in Telluride, Silver on Screens
text: TELLURIDE, Colo. — In the local vernacular, the Telluride Film Festival is known as The Show. Each screening — of an Oscar aspirant, a restored classic, a provocative documentary, a slow and quiet piece of cinematic art — is its own show, but so is this town itself, a silver-mining outpost high in the San Juan Mountains long ago converted to an oasis of western-bohemian chic. The Show, which occurs every Labor Day weekend (this is the 38th edition), evokes the eager, collective do-it-yourself spirit of Mickey Rooney and Judy Garland musicals, as a school gymnasium, a restored opera house and a pocket-size park on the main street are converted into movie theaters. There is also plenty of the business of show, manifested in the names of sponsors read out before every screening, and in the presence of renowned filmmakers and big movie stars on the streets.

headline: Police Detain Brooklyn Councilman at West Indian Parade
text: A city councilman from Brooklyn was handcuffed and briefly detained by the police on Monday afternoon during the West Indian Day Parade after an argument with officers over whether he was allowed to use a closed sidewalk, said Public Advocate Bill de Blasio, whose aide was also detained in the dispute.

headline: Ireland: Diplomatic Tensions With Vatican Grow

The Irish foreign minister, Eamon Gilmore, left, said the government was holding firm to its claims that the Vatican had attempted to frustrate an inquiry into abuse in the Diocese of Cloyne as recently as three years ago. The Vatican, in a strongly worded report on Saturday, said there was “no evidence” to support such an accusation.

headline: How Many Leaves on the Tree of Life?
text: How many species are there on this planet? In 1691, the scientist John Ray estimated that there were 20,000 species of insects. His numbers were significantly off — at least a million insect species have been described so far. But he reached it the way most scientists still do, by extrapolating from the number of already known species. Three centuries later, there is still no scientific consensus on the total number of species.

headline: Grant Goes to War
text: Since settlers arrived in the early 19th century, Southern Illinois has been referred to as “Little Egypt,” a reference to the supposed similarity between the Nile Delta and the fertile soil found at the confluence of the Mississippi, Ohio and Tennessee rivers. Fittingly, this delta region was also home to that great Sphinx of the Civil War, Ulysses S. Grant. He had lived in all the surrounding states, often uncomfortably, before moving away in search of work. Residents of all these states would find things even more uncomfortable after his wartime return.

headline: What a Surprise: Rain at the U.S. Open

headline: A Labor Leader Turns 90 on the Ideal Day
text: For Victor Gotbaum, what better date for his 90th birthday to fall on than Labor Day. Well over a hundred supporters of the former municipal labor leader — many of them fellow veterans of the city’s fiscal crisis during the 1970s — jammed Bistro Citron on Columbus Avenue Sunday night to toast Mr. Gotbaum, who was resplendent in a Hawaiian short-sleeve shirt.

headline: Drawing Dance: More From Mexico City
text: The Brooklyn artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting their two-year Legacy Tour through a series of drawings and paintings. After 58 years, the company is scheduled to disband on New Year’s Day 2012. This is the 11th in a series of graphite drawings he plans to create from the road, providing a front-row seat to the final weeks of the company’s journey. This week’s entry is from an extended stay in Mexico City.

headline: Shaw Sells Westinghouse Stake
text: The Shaw Group announced plans to sell its stake in Westinghouse to Toshiba in a deal that would allow Shaw to bolster its balance sheet.

headline: Dale DeGroff, From the Bar to the Stage
text: Dale DeGroff, the man called by many the father of the craft cocktail movement, began his career as many a bartender has — slinging drinks while waiting for his acting career to take off.

headline: For Bachmann, Shake-Up Comes at Challenging Time

headline: Coping With a Natural Disaster
text: Last September, we published a How I Saved My Company video created by Vince Morvillo, who owns Sea Lake Yacht Sales, a dealership in Houston, that had been hit by a one-two punch. First, Hurricane Ike, a Category 4 storm, struck Texas in 2008, doing terrible damage. And then came the recession. In that video, Mr. Morvillo talked about how his company survived a period when many of his customers had higher priorities than buying a yacht.

headline: Restaurant Bottles From the Bottom Up
text: IT’S a challenge for restaurants to offer exciting lists of expensive or even moderately expensive wines. It’s a far greater challenge for restaurants to offer a wide selection of captivating, inexpensive wines. It requires creativity, thoughtfulness and dedication to gather wines that may not return as big a profit as the more expensive choices on the list.

headline: Tsonga, Fish and Getting to the Net

headline: Philbin’s Last ‘Live’ To Be Nov. 18

headline: Knitting Factory
text: Nubby yarns aren’t the most obvious springtime players. But Lindsay Degen, the Brooklyn-based 23-year-old behind the new hand-knit sock and lingerie line Degen, is a different sort of designer. Growing up in the suburban Midwest, she dabbled in cheerleading and Girl Scouting before going on to study fine art at the Rhode Island School of Design, where she joined a performance group called Knitting Nation that practiced endurance-building marathon stitch training. Soon, Degen says, “a hobby turned into a job,” and she started collaborating with brands like VPL, Cooperative Designs and Mischa Lampert. “Knitting for people who see fashion and art as equals bent my previous view that they had to be separate worlds,” she says. Indeed, Degen the line, which makes its debut during Fashion Week, is a clever blend of the two; the stripy, woven lingerie and cheerful one-off socks featured are just conceptual enough. “I’ve never wanted to buy a matching pair of anything,” Degen says about offering singles instead of matching socks. “Plus, when I spend eight hours knitting one, it’s dreadful to think that I’d have to spend another eight hours making the exact same thing.” Restless and inspired, she confesses she’s already in need of a new hobby. Let’s hope it’s sweaters.

headline: Honda Recalls 2006 CR-V for Fire Hazard and 2011 CR-Z to Fix Faulty Hybrid Drive Software
text: In a statement on Sunday, Honda said it would recall about 80,000 of its 2006 CR-Vs to address a potential fire hazard traced to the vehicles’ power window master switch. The automaker is also recalling 5,600 CR-Z hybrids from 2011 with manual transmissions because a flaw in the software governing the hybrid drive system could cause a vehicle to unexpectedly move backward or forward.

headline: Amateur Video Shot on 9/11 Shows Smoke From Plane Crash in Pennsylvania
text: Updated | Wednesday | 8:49 a.m. On Sept. 11, 2001, minutes after United Flight 93 crashed in a field near Shanksville, Pa., a man who lived two and half miles away reached for his video camera and recorded smoke billowing into the sky.

headline: Wind Industry Lobbies for Tax-Credit Extension
text: So far 2011 has been a good year f0or wind energy projects. Installations in the first six months of 2011 were almost double what they were in the comparable period in 2010 in terms of total megawatts (2,151 versus 1,250), according to the American Wind Energy Association. But a bipartisan coalition of 24 state governors, fretting that the industry could lose momentum, has already begun lobbying the Obama administration to improve business conditions for wind energy developers.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
text: Augme Technologies, New York, completed the acquisition of substantially all the assets and business of Hipcricket, Kirkland, Wash., a mobile marketing agency. The purchase price was $44.5 million with a 12-month earn-out payment to shareholders and employees that is valued at up to an additional $27.5 million. Augme said it expected to keep all Hipcricket employees. Ivan Braiker, chief executive of Hipcricket, becomes president of Augme and Eric Harber, president and chief operating officer of Hipcricket, becomes chief operating officer of Augme. The deal came a month after Augme bought Jagtag, which specializes in bar codes and Q.R. codes.

headline: James Levine Withdraws From Met Fall Season
text: James Levine, the Metropolitan Opera’s music director, has withdrawn from all performances at the Met for the rest of the year after falling while on vacation in Vermont and damaging a vertebra, the house said on Tuesday. Mr. Levine had emergency surgery on Thursday. The injury comes after a series of health problems, including back operations and periods of rehabilitation to correct a painful spinal condition called stenosis, have curtailed Mr. Levine’s activities.

headline: Sentence of the Week, Life-Precepts Edition
text: It’s time to crown our August Sentence of the Month. The choice, as always, will be hard. (Have you watched Google’s Freddie Mercury tribute yet, by the way? It’s amazing. After that, definitely watch the official nonanimated video for “Don’t Stop Me Now” to see awkwardly sustained close-ups of Mercury’s amazing mouth.) Here are our winners from August:

headline: A Banker Explains Why Some Small Businesses Have Trouble Getting Credit
text: After a recent post about the bad news embedded in the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation’s second-quarter good news — business lending broadly was up for the first time in three years, but small-business lending continued to fall — The Agenda heard from a representative of Sterling National Bank, a small institution based in New York City that lends exclusively to small and medium-sized businesses. Contrary to what I had reported, loans were way up at Sterling, the representative said. Did I want to find out why?

headline: Study Finds State Unionized at Twice National Rate

headline: Food Links for Your Pleasure

And then there’s this afterschool program in Philadelphia that uses food and gardening to inspire kids to write. (My Philly column from last spring.) headline: Letter From Copenhagen | Feeding Frenzy
text: For two rainy days last week, some 250 chefs, scientists, foragers and farmers gathered beneath a blue and red circus tent in Copenhagen’s Harbor for the first annual MAD Food Camp Symposium. Entitled “Planting Thoughts,” the symposium was organized by Claus Meyer and Rene Redzepi, the founders of the current “world’s best restaurant,” Noma, along with the newly formed Food Organisation of Denmark (FOOD). The mission was to ask the big questions about the role of chefs in society, touching on issues of urban farming, food microbiology and social responsibility. At the podium was a parade of acclaimed chefs, among them Inaki Aizpitarte, David Chang, Andoni Aduriz and Alex Atala.

headline: Univision Reigns on Labor Day

headline: A Jets Rookie From the Roads of Hutto, Tex.

It is small enough for grandparents, both sets of them, to sit on their front porches and mind children tossing a football or playing Red Rover. But it is big enough, about two acres, for boys with lively legs to run and run and run, to high school stardom, to a decorated career at Texas Christian, to the N.F.L.

headline: Steve Martin Honors Another Banjo Player

headline: Reviewing Craft

William Grimes, one of my predecessors in the titanium-and-velvet chair issued to the chief restaurant critic of The New York Times, awarded the place three stars a few months later. It was not reviewed again, until now. (Though Bill Clinton had a rock summit there not so long ago, with Keith Richards.)

headline: Craft
text: LIKE drawing a circle or walking a high wire, the act of cooking simple food well requires years of training and experience, and a self-confidence that must sail close to arrogance. Above all, it requires mastery of the intersection of culinary talent and acquired knowledge.

headline: Elusive Line Defines Lives in Israel and the West Bank

headline: Soft Spot | With & Wessel
text: Growing up in Norway, Stian Tolnaes and Cathrine Wessel had plenty of opportunities to wear wool — and lots of it. “It’s a Norwegian tradition,” Tolnaes says. “If you see Norwegian fishermen, who are exposed to cold weather all the time, they wear layers of wool because it keeps them warm even when it’s wet. Wool is incredibly insulating.” After observing that Greek fishermen toiling in the balmy Aegean also favored wool but for entirely the opposite reason — its insulating qualities keep warm air out, too — the couple had a light-bulb moment. “We wanted to develop a clothing line that was completely natural and eco-friendly,” Tolnaes says. “And we wanted to take the layering tradition of our childhoods and make it fashionable.”

headline: Afghan Army Attracts Few Where Fear Reigns
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — Every morning, jobless young men gather by the hundreds at the busy central square here in this southern city, desperate for whatever work they can find. In other places, this would be an army recruiter’s dream. Not so in Kandahar.

headline: Chandler Arnold, Amir Katz
text: Chandler Frank Arnold and Amir Daniel Katz are to be married Sunday evening at the Pilgrim Monument in Provincetown, Mass. The Rev. David Johnson, a Unitarian Universalist minister, is to officiate.

headline: Now Playing | ManiaMania’s ‘The Third Mind’
text: The Australian designers Melanie Kamsler and Tamila Purvis of the cult-status jewelry line ManiaMania are announcing their new spring collection with three trippy, gem-laden films. “The beautifully uncontrolled manifestoes of André Breton put us both in a surrealist spirit,” says Kamsler of the inspiration behind the starring wooden pendants, crystal balls and cubes cut from things like pyrite and labradorite (a feldspar mineral). Here, the headlining short, “The Third Mind,” directed by Elle Muliarchyk and featuring Abbey Lee Kershaw, pays homage to Brion Gysin and William Burroughs and their “smoky, bohemian lifestyle.”

headline: Polls Show Declining Support for Obama on Economy
text: Two new polls have found low levels of support for President Obama and his economic stewardship of the country, with an increasing number of Americans saying that Mr. Obama’s policies are making the economy worse. The surveys show that Americans have a pessimistic outlook for economic recovery and raise the stakes for the president’s speech on Thursday before a joint session of Congress in which he is expected to offer plans for creating jobs and stimulating the economy.

headline: Classic Score by Bernstein Is Remade
text: When it came time to make a movie of his “West Side Story,” a busy Leonard Bernstein entrusted the score to Hollywood and his loyal arrangers.

headline: An Afghanistan Gallery
text: A portfolio of civilians and troops by Kuni Takahashi.

headline: ‘Sleep No More,’ but Move Nonstop
text: In “Sleep No More,” a roving retelling of “Macbeth” by the English theater company Punchdrunk, the masked audience is in constant motion as it chases the action from room to room at the fictional McKittrick Hotel. But in the end, no one is more breathless than the cast, which is largely made up of some of the most fearless dancers around.

headline: A Reality Check on Clouds and Climate
text: I am often in awe of clouds, as was the case when I shot this video of a remarkable thunderhead somewhere over the Midwest. But I’m tired of the recent burst of over-interpretation of a couple of papers examining aspects of clouds in the context of a changing climate.

headline: Romney Lays Out His Economic Plan
text: NORTH LAS VEGAS, Nev. — Mitt Romney unveiled his plan to rejuvenate the American economy here Tuesday, offering a detailed outline that includes repealing President Obama’s health care law, cutting the corporate tax rate, placing sanctions on China as a currency manipulator and immediately reducing taxes on savings and investment by the middle class — and promised to push many of these policies on his first day in the Oval Office.

headline: China’s New Cultural Revolution: A Surge in Art Collecting
text: As auction houses prepare for their fall sales, Chinese collectors are expected to be a major boost for the market, raising their paddles for big-ticket artworks despite a backdrop of global economic turmoil.

headline: Borders and Barriers: An Overview

headline: Christopher Shinn

headline: Thank Goodness | Elettra Wiedemann Feeds Fashion Week
text: Convenience is key when it comes to refueling during Fashion Week, and more often than not, quick, carry-in-your-pocketbook processed foods are what many models and editors resort to between shows. The model and activist Elettra Wiedemann has set forth to change that by opening Goodness, a pop-up restaurant installed at Ed’s Chowder House just across Columbus Avenue from Lincoln Center. From Sunday through next Wednesday, Goodness will offer a healthy, locally sourced menu, with daily specials designed by some of the city’s best-loved chefs, including Christopher Rendell, an “Iron Chef” winner; Nicholas Wilber from the Fat Radish; and Robert Newton of Seersucker restaurant in Brooklyn. “I wanted to be eco-conscious without forcing it too much and create a place where people can go to escape,” says Wiedemann, who teamed with Ed Brown, the Chowder House’s Michelin star-rated chef, to design an especially soothing atmosphere in which to enjoy things like duck confit salad, pan-seared bream mash with a truffle vinaigrette and a fried chicken that Wiedemann calls “goodness (with a little bit of badness).” Check, please!

headline: More Children Living in Poverty
text: A fifth of children in the United States are living below the federal poverty limit.

text: Jeremy Kerley has risen from the small Texas town of Hutto to a spot on the Jets’ roster.

headline: Introducing David Paterson, Drive-Time Radio Host

headline: Things That Go Bump in the Night Don’t Even Budge on TV
text: Criminals robbing convenience stores have not been able to escape them. Fathers taking a soccer ball to the groin à la “America’s Funniest Home Videos” have not been able to escape them. Couples having sex on a supposedly secluded beach have not been able to escape them. And yet ghosts and other paranormal entities so far have proved amazingly adept at avoiding the millions of security cameras, cellphone cameras and video cameras that now seem to record virtually every moment of life on earth.

headline: In Dispute With Verizon, Union Invokes Members’ 9/11 Work

headline: Enlisted in the World of Airborne Spying
text: For four years, a doctor commuted between his clinics in Texas in a $5 million turboprop with jazzy metallic stripes and ruby stones embedded on the drink cabinet inside. The plane featured exotic wood veneers and polished chrome, and his daughter’s initials were in the tail number.

headline: Bachmann’s Steep Path to the Nomination
text: Following the departure of two of her key advisers over the holiday weekend, you’re likely to see a lot of speculation about whether Michele Bachmann’s campaign is headed for the political graveyard.

headline: P.J. Harvey Nabs a Second Mercury Prize
text: P.J. Harvey became the first singer on Tuesday to win the prestigious Mercury Prize twice, when she accepted the award for her album “Let England Shake.” Adele, the young soul-singer who had dominated the charts for much of the summer with her hit record “21,” was left in the also-ran category. It was the second time that Ms. Harvey, the 41-year-old singer-songwriter from Yeovil, England, had taken home the prize, which is given every year to the best album from an English or Irish act. She first won in 2001, when the ceremony was held on Sept. 11. She was on tour in the United States at the time and got caught up in the chaotic day of the terror attack.

headline: Rain Washes Out Play at U.S. Open
text: Rain again paid an unwelcome visit to the United States Open on Tuesday, washing out the day and night sessions and postponing the men’s and women’s fourth-round singles matches until Wednesday. Weather has created such regular chaos with the Open schedule — it has delayed the men’s final from Sunday to Monday each of the last three years — that cancelations and delays have become as much a part of the scene at the National Tennis Center as overpriced sandwiches.

headline: State Reveals Official Sept. 11 Memorial Flag
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Tuesday unveiled the official New York State Sept. 11 Memorial Flag, which was raised at the State Capitol and will be flown at the entrance to the memorial at the World Trade Center site.

The greatest may be an epically popular television mini-series: imagine a Korean Rachael Ray starring in a combination of “Downton Abbey” and “C.S.I.”

headline: Alison Returns, but Not to Dominick Street
text: THERE were deep-blue banquettes, black-and-white photographs of France and a SoHo address by the Holland Tunnel that cabdrivers could never find. There was hushed jazz, a famous lamb shank and proposals of marriage, sometimes several in one night.

headline: The Season’s New Restaurants
text: ALONG with the imported chefs and restaurateurs bringing Danish open-faced sandwiches, avant-garde Korean and Spanish fare, specialties from Beirut and Moscow, and even the flavors of Portland, Ore., to New York, some familiar faces on the local restaurant scene will try something new. A pizza master is opening a diner, and a high-end chef is doing a sports bar. We’ll see the latest from Danny Meyer, Jeffrey Chodorow and that former downtown dining star, Alison Price Becker.

headline: Foreign Restaurateurs Arrive in New York
text: This season, Manhattan is witnessing a surprisingly robust invasion of new restaurants from abroad.

headline: The Melting Pot Just Got a Whole Lot Richer
text: AS business-news alerts warn of credit downgrades, jobless recoveries and double-dip recessions, New York City is witnessing a surprisingly robust invasion of new restaurants from abroad, and it seems to have everything to do with Frank Sinatra.

headline: A Transformed Bernardin Is Set to Reopen
text: IN the 25 years since Maguy Le Coze and her brother, the chef Gilbert Le Coze, opened the Midtown Manhattan version of Le Bernardin, their high-end Parisian seafood restaurant, the menu has changed more than the dining room. Flavors from Asia and Spain were added, along with new techniques and new ingredients, particularly after Eric Ripert took charge of the kitchen and became a partner after the death of Mr. Le Coze, in 1994.

headline: Firefighters’ Names Endure in St. Patrick’s Twin Towers
text: Among the hundreds of graffiti left by firefighters over the years during their inspections of the cathedral, four names have been found of men who were killed on 9/11.

headline: The Year’s New Markets
text: PANE PANELLE, opening Wednesday, is takeout, mostly Sicilian, from a tiny storefront at Stuzzicheria in TriBeCa. It sells arancini, meat pies, muffulettas and the cheese sandwiches cum chickpea fritters known as pane e panelle ($5 to $10). All are prepared by Paul DiBari, pictured, the restaurant’s new chef: 305 1/2 Church Street (Walker Street), TriBeCa, (212) 219-2357.

headline: Razing a Neighborhood and a Social Engineering Idea
text: LA COURNEUVE, France — At the foot of the dilapidated Balzac housing tower, an 11-year-old boy bled to death here on a summer afternoon in 2005, stray bullets in his heart and neck. Nicolas Sarkozy, who was interior minister at the time and is now president, arrived the next day in this hard-luck Paris suburb, famously pledging to “clean” the area with a Kärcher, a brand of high-pressure hose.

headline: Boats Banned From Dumping Sewage in Long Island Sound
text: Boats will be prohibited from dumping sewage in New York State waters in Long Island Sound under a ban announced on Tuesday by the Environmental Protection Agency.

headline: Injury-Plagued Giants Turn to Rookies
text: When the Giants cut their roster to the 53-player maximum Saturday, they opted to keep four rookie linebackers, a decision that highlighted, once again, the team’s commitment to building organizational depth.

headline: Beyond Refugee Camps, a Better Way
text: In Friday’s Fixes column, I wrote about alternatives to keeping refugees in camps for years. The hundreds of thousands of Somalis streaming today into the camps in Dadaab, Kenya, are getting lifesaving food, medical care and shelter.  Camps like Dadaab are designed for emergency care and do it well — but most refugee situations are long-term.   Camps condemn refugees to years, maybe decades, of dependency.  There are people in Dadaab who have not stepped outside the camp since it opened in 1991.

headline: Living With Loss
text: INTERACTIVE: Portraits of Grief »

headline: Consumer Pick Vows to Streamline Regulations
text: WASHINGTON — The nominee to lead the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau told a Senate committee on Tuesday that he would make it a priority “to streamline and cut back” a mountain of regulations that has grown up over the last 30 years, which he said excessively burdened some banks and discourages them from lending money to consumers.

headline: Amid Tensions With Israel, Turkey Threatens Increased Naval Presence
text: ISTANBUL — Turkey is prepared to fortify sanctions against Israel and increase its naval presence in the eastern Mediterranean Sea, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey said Tuesday, as relations between the countries continued to fray over an Israeli raid on a Turkish-flagged ship last year.

headline: In Miami, Long and Bitter Feud With Mayor Pushes Police Chief Close to Dismissal
text: MIAMI — Police Chief Miguel A. Exposito, whose nearly two-year tenure has been marked by numerous clashes with the mayor and a series of police shootings of unarmed black men, was suspended from his job on Tuesday in a move that could be the prelude to his dismissal.

text: SAN FRANCISCO — Carol A. Bartz, Yahoo’s chief executive, was fired Tuesday, ending a rocky two-year tenure in which she tried to revitalize the online media company.

text: Wildfires cut a path of destruction across Texas. Hardest hit was the town of Bastrop in Central Texas.

headline: In a Game of Physical Prowess, It’s the Mind That Matters
text: Jo-Wilfried Tsonga was talking about how a tennis match is won between the ears as much as between the lines. “My game, you know, is very good when I have nothing in my head, when I just play my game,” he said Monday after defeating Mardy Fish in five sets at the United States Open.
