text: 5:26 p.m. | Updated

headline: Courtside: Great Tennis, Weather Permitting
text: Roger Federer is scheduled for what should be an intriguing matchup with Jo-Wilfried Tsonga, but rain continues to complicate the schedule of play at the Open. Lynn Zinser reports.

headline: K Is for Clothes
text: You know it’s going to be a swinging Fashion Week when, two days out, you’ve already attended three parties, mingled with Karl Lagerfeld and Kim Kardashian, lost an umbrella and spent an ungodly sum on taxis. And this was just on Tuesday.

headline: The Emerging Face Behind the Faces of Fashion Week
text: “ONCE upon a time nobody gave a hoot about makeup,” said Gordon Espinet, the senior vice president of makeup artistry of MAC Cosmetics. A runway show was all about the clothes. “It was all about names like Calvin, Donna, Ralph, Giorgio and Gianni.”

headline: White House Stresses Both Vigilance and 9/11 Remembrance
text: WASHINGTON — For President Obama, the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks is a rare opportunity to change the subject from the embattled economy to his formidable record in capturing and killing terrorists.

headline: Down the Stretch in the Race to Replace Weiner
text: With the special election to fill former Congressman Anthony D. Weiner’s seat just six days away, Nate Silver takes a close look at the conflicting poll numbers, the evolving partisan whims of the people of the Ninth Congressional District and the almighty intangibles over on FiveThirtyEight and declares the Democratic candidate, Assemblyman David I. Weprin, a “modest favorite” over the Republican, Bob Turner, a retired cable television executive. Read the post on FiveThirtyEight »

headline: A Name for the Montreal Symphony Orchestra’s New Hall
text: MONTREAL — Just in time for the inaugural concert on Wednesday night for the new home of the Montreal Symphony Orchestra, the place has an official name. Until now there had been only a tentative name, L’Adresse Symphonique, for this hall, which sits on a corner of Place des Arts, this lively city’s equivalent of Lincoln Center. But the government of the Province of Quebec announced Wednesday morning that the hall will be called La Maison Symphonique de Montréal.

headline: Military Rulers Called to Testify in Mubarak Trial
text: CAIRO — The judge presiding over the criminal trial of former President Hosni Mubarak on Wednesday ordered testimony from the top two officers in the ruling military council, sharpening doubts about whether the court is acting independently or is cooperating with the president’s former allies.

headline: Facebook Adds Bowles to Its Board
text: Facebook announced on Wednesday that it had named Erskine B. Bowles, former co-chairman of the Obama administration’s deficit-reduction commission, to its board.

headline: A Comedic Springboard to Riff and Experiment
text: THE basement of the East Village bar Ella was packed on a recent, simmering Tuesday night. The 90 or so people in attendance stood watching the comedian Tim Heidecker sweat.

headline: Close Encounters With Deep-Sea Samples
text: Jeffrey Marlow, a graduate student at the California Institute of Technology, writes from a workstation off the coast of Oregon, where he is studying life around deep-ocean vents.

headline: In Antigua, a Hillside Retreat
text: A three-bedroom house with two guest cottages on the southern coast of Antigua is on the market for $2.5 million.

headline: Print That!
text: The unofficial mascot for Alexa Chung’s second collection for Madewell has to be the palm tree print, a black-and-gold repeat that shows up mostly on pajama-inspired pieces and looks like a polka dot from a distance. Chung, who wears the print in the line’s new ad and will effectively motivate girls all over the world to go online and buy bits of it — pants, shirt or jersey ice skater dress — by doing so, drew the palm by hand. “I sketch so much in meetings,” she says. “The Madewell team insisted.” In fact, Madewell loves Chung’s scribbles so much that they published a zine called Magaxine full of them. (Copies will be given to the first who buy pieces from the collection, which lands in stores and online on September 22.) “You know me, I’m obsessed with polka dots and Peter pan collars — British things like that — so they’re all in there, too,” Chung says.

headline: F.D.A. Staff: 5 Years May Be Enough for Bone Drugs
text: Most women who take bone-building drugs like Fosamax can safely stop taking them after five years, the Food and Drug Administration said Wednesday in a staff report leading up to a broad safety review scheduled Friday by two scientific advisory committees.

headline: More Rain Worries Areas Hit Hard by Tropical Storm Irene
text: The people of Prattsville, N.Y., have probably grown accustomed to the exercise: check the forecast, glance up at the skies and hope.

headline: ‘Rest in Peace,’ in a Suitcase in the Bronx
text: Monique Exum loaded the suitcase on a dolly and wheeled it around the corner, she told the authorities. She put it behind an abandoned building in the Bronx where she used to live.

headline: Wet Courts Are an Issue for Players
text: 3:43 p.m. | Updated In a closed door meeting with Brian Earley, the United States Open tournament referee, two former champions, Rafael Nadal and Andy Roddick, and the 2008 runner-up, Andy Murray, expressed concerns about the playing conditions being dangerous when they were asked to start their fourth-round matches Wednesday.

headline: ‘The Language of Flowers’
text: Chapter 1

headline: Papermaker Owned by Cerberus Files for Bankruptcy
text: 8:40 p.m. | Updated

headline: An Irishman in New York
text: WHEN he was 16, Dean Quinn of Enniskillen, Ireland, spent a summer in London working as an intern for the eccentric designer Zandra Rhodes. Ms. Rhodes, who is famous for her flamingo-pink hair, asked him if he would be interested in attending Central Saint Martins, the prestigious fashion school based there.

headline: A Bouquet of Petals and Thorns, All Defined With Meticulous Precision
text: Vanessa Diffenbaugh has used adoption, foster homes, emancipation, homelessness, single motherhood and attachment disorder as talking points for “The Language of Flowers,” her virtually self-marketing debut book. She has set up an advocacy group to support young people making the transition from foster care to independence. And she has compiled her own flower dictionary, modeled on one from 1885.

headline: ‘One Little Girl Hid Behind Her Mother’s Leg, Thinking They Were Sea Monsters’
text: A note for the uninitiated: noodlers are people who use their arms for bait, fishing around in the underwater lairs of giant catfish. The Look feature in last week’s magazine showed several veteran noodlers and their gummy catches at the 12th annual Okie Noodling Tournament. Unbeknownst to our photographer, Matt Rainwaters, his shoot was captured by an unrelated YouTube video (check out the adorable family around 7:30).

headline: New Way to Count Afghan Army Recruits Reveals Old Problem
text: KABUL, Afghanistan – Army recruiting in southern Afghanistan – the spiritual homeland of the Taliban — is tricky at best, deadly at worst.

headline: Is Earthquake Insurance Worth the Cost?
text: Like many homeowners, we pretty much ignored the option of earthquake coverage when we bought an insurance policy for our home. After all, we reasoned, it’s not as if we live in California.

headline: Success of ‘Sons of Anarchy’ Season 4 Premiere Puts Creator  on the Hook
text: Fans of the FX drama “Sons of Anarchy” rose up in record numbers on Tuesday, giving the show its highest ratings ever, with 4.9 million total viewers and 3.2 million in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic. Last week, the show’s creator and executive producer, Kurt Sutter, announced on his blog that if the Season 4 premiere was up more than 10 percent in both major ratings categories over last season’s premiere, he would award one of his more than 54,000  Twitter followers and one reader of his blog with a trip to Los Angeles, where the two lucky scion anarchists will be invited to a viewing party at Mr. Sutter’s home. With a gain of 19 percent in total viewers and 17 percent in the 18-to-49 category compared to the Season 3 debut episode, Mr. Sutter will have to make good on his offer. FX also expects that when the final numbers are in, it will be the most watched original series episode in the cable channel’s history.

headline: The Tragic Legacy of Irene
text: This report, from Deborah Kavakos of Stoneledge Farm — a CSA in the Greene County, N.Y., town of Cairo — is a harsh reminder that farming is a risky business. (I’ll be posting other reports from farmers in New York and Vermont — (here’s another, from the Intervale Center in Burlington, VT) — as they come in; submissions welcome via mark@markbittman.com.) Visit Stoneledge’s Web site for more (heartbreaking) photos and information.

headline: Over Time, Tantrums Become Tamer
text: During his second-set meltdown Sunday against Rafael Nadal, the Argentine veteran David Nalbandian raised his racket in disgust and despair, brandishing it above his head at Arthur Ashe Stadium.

headline: Appeals Courts Split on Creditors’ Right to Bid in Auction Sales
text: The Supreme Court probably will not agree to hear the appeal in RadLAX Gateway Hotel, LLC v. Amalgamated Bank, but it should. And not for the reasons the debtors argue in their petition to the court.

headline: As Financial Gloom Deepens, Reform of British Bank Rules May Wait
text: LONDON — Seesaw markets, growing concerns about the stability of Europe’s banks and a faltering economic recovery are dimming prospects that Britain will enact stricter banking regulation anytime soon.

headline: An Elevated Sense of Imagination
text: IF you were to stumble midweek into the Alejandro Ingelmo boutique in SoHo, you might wonder about the salesman manning the store.

headline: Vain Glorious | R&R for the Gambling Man
text: What: Arnica Muscle Repair Massage.

headline: Schedule Adjustments Begin Anew
text: United States Open officials have acknowledged the obvious, that they will not get full sessions in today because of a lingering, pesky rain. They have announced that the match between No. 1 Novak Djokovic and Janko Tipsarevic and the one between No. 3 Roger Federer and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga have been postponed for the day and will be played Thursday at the earliest.

headline: Assertive and Soulful Piano, With a Slow Backbeat and a Spirit of Flow
text: If every great jazz pianist needs a “Live at the Village Vanguard” album, made with a fine trio, the time is ripe for Geri Allen. True, she already released such an album, for a Japanese label, with two of the best possible partners — the bassist Charlie Haden and the drummer Paul Motian — but that was 20 years ago, and it’s no longer in print. (Look to iTunes for your copy.) A lot can happen to a determined and introspective artist since then.

headline: The Endless Runway
text: THIS summer, one of the hottest attractions in Paris was the Madame Grès exhibition at the Musée Bourdelle. Grès was an inscrutable genie of haute couture whose weird demise in 1993 (her only child kept the news of her death secret for more than a year) capped one of the strangest, most productive lives in fashion. I know of several American designers who went out of their way to catch the show before it closed in late July.

headline: Why I’m (Still) Reluctant to Hire
text: The August jobs report that came out last week showed no job growth, and now President Obama and lots of other politicians are talking about how to create jobs. But I’m not sure they fully understand what prompts a business owner to hire someone — and why so many owners are still reluctant to hire, even if they think business might be improving.

headline: The Only America They’ve Ever Known
text: When I joined the Army almost 10 years ago, I was already an old man — by the measure of my fellow recruits anyway, most of them only 18 or 19. I was all of 25, but it was enough to make a difference. Even though I got used to how my sergeants and lieutenants were often younger than me, I never got used to how young some of my fellow privates and Pfc.’s seemed. They were hardly more than boys, some of them, with bright ruddy cheeks, and bright eyes that grew hard during our year in Iraq.

headline: Nadal Reveals the Toll of Being a Top-Tier Athlete in ‘Rafa’
text: After advancing to the fourth round of the U.S. Open on Sunday afternoon, Rafael Nadal gave the fans a scare during a post-match press conference when he abruptly stopped speaking and leaned back in his seat, his face twisted in pain.

headline: House Hunting in ... Antigua
text: A THREE-BEDROOM HOUSE OFF THE SOUTHERN COAST OF ANTIGUA

headline: Photo Replay: Sept. 7
text: The day in sports brought tragedy to international hockey and more rain to the United States Open tennis tournament.

headline: Consumer Bureau Reaches Out to Military Families
text: After the financial crisis of 2008, regulators found that military families were proving to be particularly vulnerable to financial rip-offs. Abusive mortgage practices, deceptive car loans, unscrupulous lenders and sellers of all kinds of financial products have caused headaches for many military families, particularly those with service members abroad.

headline: TimesCast | September 07, 2011
text: A terrorist bomb rips through a courthouse in New Delhi; the Op-Ed columnist Ross Douthat previews the Republican debate; and a major surfing tournament in, of all places, New York.

headline: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from India, Pakistan, Egypt and Gaza.

headline: Bloomberg Responds to Weekend of Shootings
text: Mayor Bloomberg on Wednesday blamed last weekend’s spate of violence on what he said was a national scourge of “young, disaffected people with guns.” He said there were remedies, however, including stricter gun regulation and social programs like his new initiative to help black and Hispanic young men.

headline: Qaddafi Family Video Shows Despot as Doting Grandfather
text: As the search for Libya’s deposed leader continues, a family video obtained by Reuters in Tripoli on Wednesday appears to show that while Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi may have ruled Libya with an iron fist, he was, among many other things, a doting grandfather.

headline: Afraid to Quit Work, Even if You Hate the Job
text: With so much uncertainty about the economy, Americans appear reluctant to quit their jobs, a new Labor Department report shows.

headline: For Champions Series, a Charity Partner
text: The expanded and reformatted 2011 Champions Series announced a partnership with the United States Tennis Association’s national charitable foundation U.S.T.A. Serves on Wednesday.

headline: Water Works
text: To kick off Fashion Week and celebrate the Quiksilver Pro New York Surf Competition, an 11-day surf extravaganza on Long Island with a $1 million prize purse, Rogan’s Bowery Street store is showing a collaborative installation called Rogan vs. LOOMSTATE-SRF CTY. On display starting today: cool surf clothes and the artist Maria Moyer’s exclusive “Blue” collection, which consists of a delightful, ocean-inspired mix of jewelry and homeware, all handcrafted and cautiously sanded to simulate the effects of spending years under the sea. Limited-edition ultramarine discs and unglazed porcelain objects evoke the work of the Austrian sculptor Carl Aubock and are gratifyingly minimal and calming. The collection is available at Rogan through late October, and 10 percent of all proceeds from the capsule will go to Waves for Water, a nonprofit that helps bring clean water to impoverished communities.

headline: Introducing SchoolBook
text: Our colleagues on the Education desk have launched a new site that features news, data and conversation about schools in New York City.

headline: My Futuristic Family’s Closet
text: WHEN it comes to clothes, I am my mother’s son. My mother, her mother’s daughter. My grandmother, her mother’s daughter, too. Different styles, each, but committed to their choices.

headline: Officials See Nevada Shootings as Random Attack
text: CARSON CITY, Nev. — Officials here offered new details Wednesday about a shooting rampage in an IHOP restaurant, a seemingly random attack on Tuesday morning that left five people — including three National Guard members — dead and several others clinging to life.

headline: Tents, but No Circus
text: ELEPHANTS used to walk through the streets every year when the circus came to New York City, trunks swinging, leg chains scraping, lumbering through Midtown as mist rose off their leathery flanks. Anachronistic and enchanting, the vision of these exotic beasts being herded through the concrete canyons never failed to produce a shiver of excitement in even the most jaded bystander. It made you feel part of the circus, the great urban one, even if you never made it to the Big Top.

headline: Mitt Romney’s Tightrope Walk
text: Mitt Romney’s 159-page jobs plan, which his campaign released in advance of tonight’s Republican debate, is getting dismissed as “standard Republican fare,” but its contents are more interesting than that. Romney spent most of his 2008 campaign for the presidency in full-on pander mode, but this time around he’s trying a more difficult two-step. With the exception of a semi-backpedaled comment on global warming, he’s refraining from challenging any conservative shibboleths directly, and his rhetorical flourishes can still sound like the “let’s double Gitmo!” Romney of 2008 infamy. But at the same time, he’s going to great to lengths to leave himself more room to maneuver on policy than the current right-wing line would normally allow — more room for the general election, and presumably for his hoped-for presidency as well.

headline: Speed and Mideast Echoes Add to a Pianist’s Palette
text: Soheil Nasseri’s piano recitals in New York over the last decade have shown him to be a thoughtful, if assertive, interpreter, given to surprises. A Californian of Iranian descent who now splits his time between New York and Berlin, Mr. Nasseri takes a cosmopolitan view of the repertory and has been known to devote concerts mostly to new music by Iranian, Israeli and American composers, music he plays with passion and discernment. He has also shown a fondness for the core Romantic repertory, for which his big sound and iron-clad technique are well suited.

headline: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from India, Pakistan, Egypt and Gaza.

headline: TimesCast | Deadly Bombing In India
text: September 7, 2011 — A New Delhi courthouse gets hit by the second terrorist bombing in less than four months, raising questions about India’s ability to provide security.

headline: Way Off the Runway: Live Streaming of Fashion Week
text: THE first time I saw the "Mona Lisa," it was in the glossy pages of an art book. Years later, I finally saw the real thing in the Louvre, and like many people, I was disappointed: the real "Mona Lisa" was smaller than my art book facsimile, obscured behind thick glass. It was surrounded by so many people, I could barely make out her smile. As scholars like Walter Benjamin and Jean Baudrillard would put it: the virtual "Mona Lisa" seemed better than the actual one.

headline: Oh, to Be Fashion Week’s ‘In’ Spot
text: FASHION WEEK is more than willowy models traipsing runways in a seizure-inducing flurry of flashbulbs. It’s also an opportunity to shake up the city’s night life and anoint a new A-list pecking order.

headline: The Buzz
text: ECCENTRIC socialites, chain-smoking models, dancing till dawn. It must be Fashion Week again. Here, a preview of the buzzing party each night (invitation only).

headline: In Race for Weiner’s Seat, $75,000 From Foes of Same-Sex Marriage
text: After the New York State Legislature voted in June to allow gay couples to wed, opposition groups vowed that they would make trouble for lawmakers who supported the marriage bill the next time they had to face the voters.

headline: NBC Universal Hires Top Morgan Stanley Media Banker
text: NBC Universal said on Wednesday that it had hired Stuart J. Epstein, the head of Morgan Stanley‘s media and communications banking group, as its chief financial officer.

headline: In ‘Rafa,’ a Personal Look at the Game
text: “Rafa,” the new memoir by Rafael Nadal written with John Carlin, is a revealing look at the toll tennis takes on players–and the joy the game gives them. Our colleague Des Shoe has a report on the book, a bestseller, on ArtsBeat.

headline: A House Built Out of Boulders in Uruguay
text: Pilar Acevedo and Enrique Saulle, a New York City couple looking for a change, built a home in a remote part of Uruguay.

headline: Short on Product, but Not Ambition, at Frankfurt Auto Show
text: More than 50 automakers will introduce new vehicles during the press preview at the Frankfurt auto show on Sept. 13. Among them will be the world’s largest manufacturers — BMW, Mercedes-Benz, Audi, Volkswagen, Ford and so on — but so will a few hopeful start-ups. Here is a roundup of what some of these auto industry Davids are offering, in the shadows of the Goliaths:

headline: Undaunted by Past Setbacks, Hands Resumes EMI Fight
text: 8:08 p.m. | Updated

headline: John Romita Jr.
text: The illustrator John Romita Jr. talks about Sept. 11.

headline: Recapturing the Spirit of a City as It Reeled From Its Wounds
text: After 10 years the devil is still in the details. And we see them, again and again, in the modest exhibition opening at the New-York Historical Society on Thursday, “Remembering 9/11.”

headline: A Closer Look at Romney’s Economic Plan
text: Now that we’ve had a day to digest Mitt Romney’s economic plan, Matthew Yglesias looks between the lines and finds what he calls an “agenda on social welfare policy that’s basically every bit as extreme as anyone else’s.”

headline: Compounding the Curves
text: NOT everyone is down with minimalism. Still, it was something of a surprise to see such like-minded modern designers as Lazaro Hernandez and Jack McCollough of Proenza Schouler and Nicolas Ghesquiere of Balenciaga adding baroque-flavored flourishes to their fall runway collections. At Proenza Schouler, fancifully curved matte black and white metal necklaces were shown with stark button-down shirts; at Balenciaga, clutches and shoes in flowery embossed leather were extravagant enough to be at home in Versailles.

headline: Are the ‘RepliKates’ Ready to March?
text: AS he lounged near a pool in Southampton, N.Y., last month, Wes Gordon had an epiphany. A group of young women gathered nearby were poring over an issue of People, its pages teeming with images of Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge. Sheathed in trim-fitting dresses, her slender arms covered almost to the wrist, the duchess impressed them as a model of regal aplomb.

headline: Ross Douthat on Tonight’s Debate
text: The Op-Ed columnist Ross Douthat previews tonight's Republican debate, the first with Gov. Rick Perry.

headline: Homes for $1.25 Million
text: A barnlike contemporary in Upstate New York; a house in Sedona, Ariz., and a Queen Anne in Portland, Ore.

headline: What You Get for ... $1.25 Million
text: SEDONA, ARIZ.

headline: iZon Webcam Sees a Lot, but Misses a Little
text: Consumer tech is filled with enduring mysteries.

headline: Tip of the Week: Retrofitting Internet Explorer 9
text: If that Web page you are looking at in Internet Explorer 9 does not look quite right with menus and other elements out of place, it may be because the site was created before this latest version of Microsoft’s browser was released.

headline: 5 Easy Steps to Stanch the E-Mail Flood
text: Perhaps you have heard of an organizational expert named David Allen. Over the years, Mr. Allen has helped many people organize their time, their tasks and — perhaps most important — their e-mail in-boxes with a method he calls, “Getting Things Done,” or GTD, for short.

headline: Steve Reich
text: The composer Steve Reich talks about Sept. 11.

headline: Lumière | Leg Work
text: September, the month when France makes its post-vacation “rentrée” and social, cultural and political life resumes, is also the month when women dress up again, exchanging loose summer garb and tropéziennes for form-fitting skirts and high heels.

headline: Are Other Commodities Like Gold? (Quick and Wonkish)
text: A number of commenters on my gold post have asked whether the same logic doesn’t apply to all commodities, oil in particular. And the answer is, no, not quite. (I’m reliving my youth here — I really got into economics as an undergraduate, when I took a seminar by Tjalling Koopmans and Bill Nordhaus on exhaustible resources that led to my becoming Nordhaus’s research assistant; and the rest is personal history).

headline: Operator Seeks to Block British Telecom Collaboration
text: The mobile phone provider Three U.K. on Wednesday asked the European Commission to block a joint venture of Britain’s three largest operators to sell a common mobile payment and advertising platform for retailers, arguing that the companies’ influence in the market would result in high fees for consumers.

headline: Day Matches Canceled
text: The United States Tennis Association announced late Wednesday that it had canceled the day session. A handful of matches did start, including Rafael Nadal against Gilles Muller and Donald Young against Andy Murray, but while the tournament dried the courts periodically, match play never resumed.

headline: The Battery-Saving Tips a Family Learned From Irene
text: Maybe the best thing that could be said about a widespread electrical failure is that it brings you closer to your smartphone.

headline: Moseying in Thailand as a Sad, Distant Slacker
text: A not-so-cruel story of youth, the Thai film “Hi-So,” in the ContemporAsian series at the Museum of Modern Art, is a little like its hero: thoughtful but a bit aimless. At ease in two cultures if not quite at home in either, Ananda (Ananda Everingham) has returned to Thailand after college in America. In the first part of the movie, which splits neatly into two, he tries his hand at acting in a film being shot near the sea; in the second, set in high-rise Bangkok, he putters around his apartment building, hangs out with his girlfriend, drinks with pals.

headline: Setback for Plans for Restaurant in Union Square Park
text: Plans to put a restaurant in the historic pavilion on the northern end of revitalized Union Square Park have been set back with the withdrawal of the concessionaire selected by the city’s Department of Parks and Recreation.

headline: The Lifespan of a Link
text: Pop quiz. How long do you think a fresh new link lasts online before people stop clicking on it? The answer: on average, just shy of 3 hours. If you ask the same question about a news-related link, the answer is a measly 5 minutes.

headline: ‘Design Sponge at Home’
text: The daily readership of Grace Bonney’s blog Design Sponge “could fill Madison Square Garden,” she writes in the introduction to her new book, “Design Sponge at Home” (Artisan; $35). It’s a claim that might sound boastful were it not an understatement (actually, it could fill the arena several times over) and immediately followed by “How cool would it be if we could all meet up every day like that?”

headline: No Summer Is Endless
text: Even Mother Nature seemed to send a message: “Get off the beach. Get back to work.”

headline: Summer’s Over; the Game Begins
text: I am being swept along by a tidal surge of densely packed wool, silk and anxiety. I can no longer move to the back or side. My only path is forward, stepping by inches into the cramped silver box full of silent faces.

headline: And Now, a Kardashian of Your Own
text: WHEN you think of Sears (if you think of it at all), what comes to mind?

headline: Digital-media marketing for Hollywood movies; the dark Web; tech news.
text: Jason Yim, the president and executive creative director of the digital-media marketing company Trigger, explains how movie advertising has evolved over the years to include interactive sites, games and mobile apps. Pedro Rafael Rosado takes a peek at the area of the Internet known as “the dark Web.” The week’s tech news includes Sprint filing its own lawsuit over the proposed merger of AT&T and T-Mobile and Google’s recent bit of housekeeping, while the Tip of the Week offers a way for Internet Explorer 9 users to sometimes make sense of scrambled Web sites.

headline: Introducing SchoolBook
text: A new Web site, by The New York Times in association with WNYC, seeks to offer an interactive tool for navigating the farthest reaches of the New York City educational system, public and private.

headline: A Clip From 'Stand In'
text: The “South Park” co-creators Trey Parker and Matt Stone appear in a clip from the mtvU show “Stand In.”

headline: Scene City: A Peek at the Kardashian Kollection
text: The sisters unveil their line of clothing and accessories.

headline: Week 1 in Fantasy Football: Favorable Matchups
text: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Promoting Hollywood
text: Movie marketing has evolved far beyond lobby posters and trailer clips to elaborate campaigns that sometimes start even more the film itself begins shooting. In this week’s Tech Talk podcast Jason Yim, the president and executive creative director of Trigger, a digital-marketing company, discusses some of the sites and apps his company has created for different Hollywood movies.

headline: A Romanian Passes Happily on the Road to a Team Victory
text: There were 12 players representing the United States at the second World Youth Congress in Croatia two weeks ago.

headline: Heat-Seeking Missiles Are Missing From Libyan Arms Stockpile
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — The sign on the wall reads “Schoolbook Printing and Storage Warehouse,” but the fact that the double gates in the wall have been crudely ripped off suggests that something more interesting might be inside.

headline: Uprooting Their Lives for a View of the Hills
text: PILAR ACEVEDO and Enrique Saulle were living in a loft in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and working as translators and editors four years ago, when they decided they wanted to change their lives.

headline: Seaport Museum Takeover Planned
text: The Museum of the City of New York will take over the beleaguered Seaport Museum New York using a $2 million grant from the corporation in charge of developing Lower Manhattan, according to state, city and museum officials who made the deal public on Wednesday.

headline: Eve Brent, Played Jane in Tarzan Movies, Dies at 81
text: Eve Brent, a longtime character actress whose most recognizable role was Jane to Gordon Scott’s Tarzan, died on Aug. 27 in Sun Valley, Calif. She was 81.

headline: Times Names Joe Kahn Its New Foreign Editor
text: The New York Times named a new foreign editor on Wednesday, the latest in a series of high-level appointments by Jill Abramson, who became executive editor this week.

headline: No Beginner Discounts at Lincoln Center
text: FOR industry insiders (and those who desperately yearn to be), there is nothing quite like Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week at Lincoln Center. Editors clutching their BlackBerrys lead gaggles of well-coiffed assistants, p.r. women in headsets and stilettos vibrate on cocktails of Red Bull and agitation, celebrities don free outfits by designers, and camera flashes illuminate rehearsed poses everywhere.

headline: Shopping for Rocking Chairs With Brady Wilcox
text: The designer and chief creative officer of ducduc, which makes modern children’s furniture, went shopping for urbane rocking chairs.

headline: Rocking Chairs
text: ROCKING chairs are often not that high on the shopping lists of city dwellers looking for furniture, simply because interiors evoking “Little House on the Prairie” do not have a lot of urban appeal. Yet this age-old design has had a number of modern makeovers, from the likes of Jacques Adnet and Charles and Ray Eames to more-recent versions from companies like James UK and Iglooplay, which have appeared in the last few months.

headline: Museum of Natural History, 4:08 p.m.
text: Jake Adams, exhibit maintenance supervisor, cleaning the 94-foot-long blue whale model in the Milstein Hall of Ocean Life at the Museum of Natural History.

headline: Crosby Says His Concussion Symptoms Continue
text: Sidney Crosby, the N.H.L.’s marquee player, said Wednesday he still had not recovered from the concussion that sidelined him last January. But he said he expected to return to hockey. .

headline: When it Comes to Fixing the Roof, Look Before You Leap
text: LAST year’s severe winter was a costly beatdown for homeowners who don’t understand ice dams, those frozen chunks that block their roof gutters and allow snow and ice to pile up.

headline: Textured Wallpaper, Inspired by Lace
text: Lace, Beaded Black, a new wallpaper from Jocelyn Warner, a British textile and wallpaper designer, is the highly tactile result of Ms. Warner’s longstanding interest in lace.

headline: Murray Moss on Putting Sex Back Into the Bed of Ware
text: With pricey designer objects displayed in glass cases and on pristine white risers, the SoHo design store Moss has often been compared to a museum. Later this month, Murray Moss, the store’s founder and an owner, will have his way with a real museum: the Victoria and Albert Museum, in London. From Sept. 17 to 25, during the annual London Design Festival, Mr. Moss will present “Industrial Revolution 2.0: How the Material World Will Newly Materialise,” with eight installations throughout the museum.

headline: On 1stdibs, Dreams, at Least, Are Free
text: WHY aren’t country songs written about being unable to afford a luxury item you really want? In my experience, the heartache and longing can be equal to that of any busted love affair Willie Nelson has sung about.

headline: Axor’s First U.S. Showroom to Open in Manhattan
text: Axor, a division of the German kitchen and bath company Hansgrohe, has made a name for itself by commissioning high-profile designers like Philippe Starck and Patricia Urquiola to design fixtures. But while its products have been available in this country for some time, the retailers that carried them often sold only part of the collection.

headline: Sales at Green Depot and Others
text: All items in the Westin Hotels and Resorts Retail Collection are 20 percent off, through Sept. 15 (the Westin Heavenly bed, originally $2,670 to $3,420, is $2,136 to $2,736); (877) 777-5418 or westin.com/store.

headline: Tableware With Something on Its Mind
text: “I keep a kind of mental notebook of phrases that resonate in my mind,” said Rob Wynne, an artist who lives in Manhattan. “Some are made up, some come from reading or from being overheard.”

headline: Creating Instant Old-Money Patina
text: The Charleston, S.C., home-stagers Sheila and Peter Potter have packed and unpacked their prized possessions 14 times in as many years.

headline: The Art of Living Well
text: Charleston, S.C.

headline: Beloved Brooklyn Cow Dies of Natural Causes
text: Aggie, the Dexter cow who spent her days beside the alpacas, sheep and miniature horses in the stable and barnyard at the Prospect Park Zoo in Brooklyn, has died of old age, zoo officials said. She was 18.

headline: Curfew Is Lifted, Shoppers!
text: LIGHTS, camera, fashion! Fashion’s Night Out, the annual retail bacchanal, is back tonight. The city’s fanciest retail corridors will teem with celebrities, designers and the tipsy shoppers who love them until long after posted store hours say they should. This year, the most exciting events offer a first peek at something new: Missoni for Target, the fashion photographer Bruce Weber’s unmentionables line “for the guys who don’t wear underwear” and a range of clothing at Opening Ceremony inspired by the Muppets. For real. So put on a reasonably comfortable pair of shoes (or, if you dare, hop aboard the double-decker Barbie bus that will be making the rounds) and shop your heart out.

headline: Obama’s Courtesy Call to Perry
text: Gov. Rick Perry was no doubt getting his game face on for the debate tonight when the phone rang.

headline: Live Blog: Perry Makes His Debate Debut
text: 10:21 P.M. | That’s a Wrap

headline: Don’t Call Them ‘Losers’
text: On cable news these days Republicans are warring for attention, as the presidential primary season reaches a boiling point, and Democrats are wondering how to win despite a wretched economy. Meanwhile the C-SPAN staff is doing what almost no one else on television does: reaching back into history for campaign lessons.

headline: Harvard Researcher Chosen as New Dean of Weill Cornell Medical College
text: A Harvard University researcher and professor with strong ties to the pharmaceutical industry has been selected as the new dean of Weill Cornell Medical College in Manhattan, as Cornell University seeks to greatly expand its research programs and obtain more federal and private financing, college officials said Wednesday.

headline: Presidential Debate at the Reagan Library
text: The candidates for the 2012 Republican presidential nomination face off in Simi Valley, Calif.

headline: Yemen’s Leaders Fail for Second Time to Resolve Stalemate
text: SANA, Yemen — Hampered by internal divisions, leaders in Yemen’s governing party on Wednesday appeared to fail for a second time to reach an agreement on how to move the country out of its prolonged political deadlock.

headline: Bill Cunningham’s 9/11, Fashion Week Photos
text: Where was Bill Cunningham during 9/11? At New York Fashion Week. Here are a few images that he captured amid the chaos.

headline: Quinn Backs Israel at Ceremony for Kidnapped Soldier
text: Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, told a group of Jewish leaders on Wednesday that the Council supported Israel’s right to defend itself and to respond to attacks.

headline: Vietnam Accused of Abusing Drug Addicts
text: BANGKOK — The Vietnamese government calls it labor therapy, a program to move drug addicts off the streets and into treatment centers, where they process cashew nuts, sew garments, weave baskets — any work that might help them get back on their feet.

headline: Breaking Up Could Be Good for Goldman Sachs
text: Goldman Sachs often helps chief executives increase the stock prices of their companies by carving them up. The bank, run by Lloyd Blankfein, is currently advising Kraft Foods on how it should split its operations and is counseling McGraw-Hill on whether it should do the same.

headline: Where Showmanship Meets One-Upmanship, Singers Seek a Partnership
text: The millennial Steve and Eydie: that was Michael Feinstein’s half-joking description of his sometime musical partnership with Linda Eder on Tuesday evening at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency, where they appeared with a small swing band. This odd musical couple has sung together here and there over the last several years but not at the club that bears Mr. Feinstein’s name: until now.

headline: Drugs in Stimulants Banned for a Year
text: The Drug Enforcement Administration will temporarily ban three synthetic chemicals found in recreational drugs known as bath salts. The stimulants have been linked to episodes of violence and extreme paranoia. The three chemicals, mephedrone, methylenedioxypyrovalerone and methylone, will be banned for at least a year while the government studies whether to ban them permanently.

headline: $265 Million Promised to Carnegie Mellon
text: William S. Dietrich II, 73, has pledged $265 million to Carnegie Mellon University, to take effect at his death. The gift — the largest in the history of the Pittsburgh-based university, and one of the 10 largest individual gifts to a university — is not yet designated for a particular purpose. Mr. Dietrich, who never attended Carnegie Mellon, is former chairman of Dietrich Industries Inc., a leading supplier of steel building materials. He has served as a trustee of Carnegie Mellon, on and off, since 1997.

headline: Serbian Boom Defies an Easy Explanation
text: Up in the mountains in Serbia, Janko Tipsarevic spied a boy, maybe 10 years old, with ground strokes so clean it seemed a robot was delivering them. Tipsarevic, older by three years, had never heard of the boy. But he did hear the boy’s father, who kept going on about how “my Novak is going to be No. 1 in the world.”

headline: Does Tenure Work?
text: Benjamin Ginsberg, left, of Johns Hopkins University and Naomi Schaefer Riley, author of "The Faculty Lounges," debate tenure for professors.

headline: All Fashion, All the Time
text: Thursday marks the official start of Fashion Week, with more than 250 designers showing their spring 2012 collections at dozens of locations around the city, including Lincoln Center, now in its third season as home of Mercedes-Benz New York Fashion Week.

headline: Patent Bill Viewed as Bailout for a Law Firm
text: A bill to overhaul the patent system that is before the Senate contains a provision that could get an influential law firm off the hook for a possible $214 million malpractice payment.

headline: As Some Syrian Soldiers Record Trophy Videos, Others Join the Protesters
text: Updated | Thursday | 1:08 p.m. While video of Syrian soldiers taking part in the crackdown on dissent with enthusiasm continues to appear online — one new clip shows snipers laughing as they fire from rooftops, another the casual way troops record the beating of a prisoner on their phones — Syrian activists are also drawing attention to clips said to show soldiers who have decided to defy their orders and join the protesters.

headline: The Art Of Summer
text: Since July critics for The New York Times have reviewed the inadvertent artistry of everyday life. Photographer Chang W. Lee put images to their words.

headline: Wardell Quezergue, R&B Hitmaker, Dies at 81
text: Wardell Quezergue, a prime mover in New Orleans rhythm and blues since the early 1950s as a producer, arranger and bandleader for a long list of artists including the Dixie Cups, Professor Longhair, the Neville Brothers and Dr. John, died on Tuesday in Metairie, La. He was 81.

headline: Obama Is President, but Football Is King
text: Like a coverage team racing downfield for a kickoff, here comes King Football. This day was always going to happen, come hell or high water or labor issues.

headline: Britain: Police Question Reporter Over Leaks From Hacking Case
text: The newspaper The Guardian said Wednesday that one of its reporters, Amelia Hill, was questioned in recent days by police officers investigating leaks from the phone hacking inquiry that has enveloped Rupert Murdoch’s newspaper group in Britain. That followed the arrest last month of a Scotland Yard detective assigned to the phone hacking investigation, a step that British news reports linked to Guardian reports on the scandal. In a statement confirming that Ms. Hill had been questioned in connection with “alleged leaks,” The Guardian raised concerns about the implications for reporters’ relations with their sources. “Journalists would no doubt be concerned if the police sought to criminalize conversations between off-record sources and reporters,” the newspaper said.

headline: Some Hedge Funds, to Stay Nimble, Reject New Investors
text: Since the financial crisis, big hedge funds like Paulson & Company, Millennium Management and Och-Ziff Capital Management Group have not turned away money, eagerly collecting billions of dollars from investors who have tended to stick with the industry’s marquee firms.

headline: With Unfamiliar Names, Mets Close Out the Marlins
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — One night after Bobby Parnell failed to close out a game with a two-run lead in the ninth inning, the Mets handed a dicier situation to a pair of unheralded pitchers.

headline: In Immigrant Areas, a Culture Clash Over Gay Marriage
text: Molly Blooms, a Victorian-accented Irish bar in Sunnyside, Queens, recently raffled off a free same-sex wedding reception, with a three-hour open bar, a D.J., a photographer and a horse-drawn gilded carriage to deliver the winning couple to the festivities. The bar’s owner thought the idea would be good for business and for the largely working-class and immigrant neighborhood.

headline: Ex-White House Scientist Pleads Guilty in Spy Case Tied to Israel
text: WASHINGTON — A former senior government scientist who held the highest security clearances pleaded guilty to espionage on Wednesday and agreed to a 13-year prison term for selling top-secret information on military satellites and other technology to an F.B.I. agent posing as an Israeli spy.

headline: China’s Rise Isn’t Our Demise
text: WASHINGTON

headline: In a New Libya, Ex-Loyalists Race to Shed Ties to Qaddafi
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Khalid Saad worked for years as a loyal cog in Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s propaganda machine, arranging transportation to ferry foreign journalists to staged rallies, ensuring that they never left their hotels without official escorts and raising his own voice to cheer the Libyan leader.

headline: Texas A&M’s Move to SEC Hits a Snag
text: The only holdup for Texas A&M to leave the Big 12 for the Southeastern Conference has been the potential for legal action. And with the Aggies on the cusp of changing leagues Wednesday, enough legal roadblocks have arisen to at least delay the move.

headline: Aiming Economic Plans at Elusive Independents
text: WASHINGTON — By proposing a jobs package filled with items that Republicans have supported in the past, President Obama is betting that moderate and independent voters he so desperately needs in next year’s elections will flock to his camp.

headline: Inspecting a Virginia Plant for Quake-Resistance
text: The North Anna nuclear plant in Mineral, Va. is serving as a test case on earthquake safety for Northeast designs.

headline: Lessons Maybe Learned
text: The Council on Foreign Relations asked its fellows for a page’s worth of thoughts on lessons learned since 9/11. The result was a series of 10 posts on the Council’s Web site late last month on such topics as immigration policy, counterterrorism, intelligence reform, unconventional warfare. There was nothing about the courts.

headline: The Challenge of Creating Good Jobs
text: In their new book, “Good Jobs America: Making Work Better for Everyone,” Paul Osterman and Beth Shulman argue that the United States needs to worry about not just creating millions more jobs but also ensuring that the jobs are good ones.

headline: Peacekeepers’ Sex Scandals Linger, On Screen and Off
text: UNITED NATIONS — On screen, two senior United Nations officials in Bosnia are arguing about firing Kathy Bolkovac, an American police officer battling to stop peacekeepers from both trafficking in young women and frequenting the brothels where they became indentured prostitutes.

headline: Mogul Plans Another Run, to Succeed Lieberman
text: WASHINGTON — Linda E. McMahon, the wrestling mogul who spent $50 million of her own money in an aggressive but failed Senate run in Connecticut last year, will announce in the coming week that she will try again, according to two Republicans who are close to her.

headline: After a Late Win, a Long and Sloppy Loss
text: The low line drive zipped into the glove of Baltimore shortstop Robert Andino. Keeping in the spirit of 10 errors in 20 often torturous innings over 18 waterlogged hours, Andino dropped the ball. Curtis Granderson sprinted hard to second base, then dived.

headline: Romney and Perry Clash, Drawing Lines in G.O.P. Sand
text: SIMI VALLEY, Calif. — The fight for the Republican presidential nomination began narrowing into an intense and ideological battle at a debate here Wednesday night, with Gov. Rick Perry of Texas and Mitt Romney sharply clashing over Social Security, health care and each other’s long-term prospect against President Obama.

headline: Talks Resume but N.B.A. Keeps Quiet
text: If progress can be measured in hours spent in conference rooms, then the N.B.A. lockout would appear to be moving — slowly, methodically — toward some sort of conclusion. But no one sitting in those conference rooms is willing to confirm or refute that premise, at least publicly.

headline: Once a Leader, Yahoo Now Struggles to Find Its Way
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Yahoo has been one of the most-visited sites on the Internet since its glory days as a Web portal. Yet as the rest of the Internet moved on to social networks and mobile devices, Yahoo has failed to keep up.

headline: Blunt E-Mail Raises Issues Over Firing at Yahoo
text: SAN FRANCISCO — “I’ve just been fired.”

headline: Speed Bumps on a Hardcourt
text: After barely sidestepping Hurricane Irene and then waiting out a deluge that caused the postponement of Tuesday’s matches and weather delays Wednesday, the players who remain in the United States Open  have much riding on the condition of the playing surfaces at the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center. But rain-slickened show courts are only part of their concerns. Some say they have noticed a difference this year in the hardcourts that are beneath the puddles.

headline: A Gentler Touch Atop the Schools, After Years of a Hard Push for Reform
text: As he begins his first full year leading the city’s public school system, Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott is trying to move away from the place that a predecessor, Joel I. Klein, so comfortably occupied: the spotlight.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Why I Needed a Doorman
text: I was 21 when I moved to New York City, and I couldn’t tie my own shoes.

headline: The Iron Horse at War
text: Among many other things, the Civil War marked the first significant use of the railroad as a military tool. Between the opening of the first European and American railroads in 1830 and the outbreak of the war in 1861, there had been a few short wars in which railways had played a supporting role in moving troops and supplying armies with ammunition. Never before, however, did it play such a central role in the strategic and tactical planning of both sides.

headline: After Quake, Virginia Nuclear Plant Takes Stock
text: MINERAL, Va. — After weathering the East Coast’s recent quake, the North Anna nuclear plant finds itself in a situation that no American reactor has ever faced before.

headline: Rising Fears of Recession
text: If history is a guide, the odds that the American economy is falling into a double-dip recession have risen sharply in recent weeks and may even have reached 50 percent.

headline: Waiting for a New Blueprint From Bank of America
text: Brian T. Moynihan takes the stage at a Midtown Manhattan hotel on Monday to tell investors what is in store for Bank of America, but already the chief executive’s plans are generating the kind of buzz reserved for the opening of a Broadway show down the street.

headline: Man Shot in Upper Manhattan Scuffle With Officer Dies
text: A man who was critically wounded in a police-involved shooting in Upper Manhattan died in the hospital from his injuries, the police said Wednesday.

headline: Fatal Shot on a Stoop May Be Tied to the Police
text: A bystander who was fatally shot on a Brooklyn stoop may have been killed by a police officer’s errant round, ballistics testing indicated on Wednesday.

headline: Challenges Would Come With Building a Roof
text: If the Romans could put a roof on the ancient Colosseum, why can’t the United States Tennis Association add a roof to one of its show courts at the United States Open? The question has, well, hung over the premier domestic tennis event for 20 years, since the U.S.T.A. opted for the sensational over the sensible in constructing Arthur Ashe Stadium, the tournament’s marquee court.

headline: Delivered Just in Time for Kickoff
text: IF professional football did not exist, Madison Avenue would probably try to invent it. The sport delivers large audiences for the important fall and Christmas shopping seasons. Those audiences almost all watch the games live, meaning there is no fast-forwarding through commercials during DVR playbacks. And each season culminates with a mid-winter event during which viewers are known to focus on the ads as much as the action.

headline: FedEx Commercial
text: A FedEx commercial uses humor to make the company’s customers aware of all of its offerings.

headline: Going Green but Getting Nowhere
text: YOU reduce, reuse and recycle. You turn down plastic and paper. You avoid out-of-season grapes. You do all the right things.

headline: Finding Hope in Libya
text: When I was entering Libya last week from Tunisia, a rebel soldier named Ayman objected that I didn’t have a visa.

headline: Debating With the Stars
text: It was a dark and stormy night.

headline: Thursday: Man of Tomorrow
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — This is a very groovy puzzle, man. You might or might not agree with the philosophy behind the book it pays tribute to, but the grid rocks. Give yourself a chance to swing with it, daddy-o. Don’t be a square.

headline: Bloody Weekend Shows Intractable Gun Problem
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s efforts to stamp out gun violence in New York were challenged over the Labor Day weekend by a spate of shootings: Bullets flew at house parties, along parade routes and across stoops and street corners.

headline: Job Program for the Supercommittee
text: Just in time to be irrelevant to the nation’s most pressing task, the Congressional “supercommittee” officially starts work on Thursday to come up with a plan to cut $1.5 trillion from the deficit. Fortunately, a few Democrats are trying to steer the committee toward the far more practical goal of creating jobs and stimulating the down-bound economy. If they succeed, there may still be a chance for the group to play a useful role.

headline: Fair Lending and Accountability
text: The banking industry is complaining loudly in Washington about the growing number of fair-lending investigations started by the Obama administration. Given the discriminatory policies used by lenders before the housing meltdown, the banks and mortgage companies deserve the scrutiny. Borrowers need more protection.

headline: A Family’s Wishes
text: Four years ago, the Bush administration issued a regulation to protect families of veterans distressed by the intrusion of volunteer honor guards offering unsolicited prayers and recitations at national cemetery funeral rites. The administration chose the only sensible course, directing that the family of the deceased — “and only they” — would identify any text to be read, not outside groups, however much they invoked God and country.

headline: Defense Team for Clemens Is Criticized by Judge
text: A federal judge said Wednesday that Roger Clemens’s defense team had violated court rules by contacting jurors after Clemens’s mistrial in July.

headline: Intervening in Libya
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Signal From Koch
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Progress’ in Vietnam? Concerns About Human Rights
text: To the Editor:

headline: Super Bowl Winners Give Warm Welcome to Rookies
text: GREEN BAY, Wis. — It’s a cute little story, though the background runs deeper.

headline: Doctor Fees Major Factor in Health Costs, Study Says
text: WASHINGTON — Doctors are paid higher fees in the United States than in several other countries, and this is a major factor in the nation’s higher overall cost of health care, says a new study by two Columbia University professors, one of whom is now a top health official in the Obama administration.

headline: Obama Blocks an Air Pollution Rule
text: To the Editor:

headline: Report Outlines Rewards and Risks of Upstate Natural Gas Drilling
text: Natural gas drilling using a controversial technique known as hydraulic fracturing could create up to 37,000 jobs and generate from $31 million to $185 million a year in added state income taxes for New York at the peak level of well development, according to analyses in a report commissioned by the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation that was released on Wednesday.

headline: Bad News Is Now Official for Scorched Texas Town
text: BASTROP, Tex. — It was one simple line of text, one out of 243: 112 South Buckhorn Drive. Bettye Porterfield found it on Wednesday as she ran her finger over a piece of paper taped to a window. She and her husband, Ken, had lived at that address for nearly nine years — they called it their little cottage in the pines — but now her home was gone. The list made it official.

headline: Humanitarian Aid for Rape Victims
text: On his third day in office, President Obama issued an executive order lifting the odious “global gag rule” that denied federal money for family planning work abroad to any group that performed abortions or counseled about the procedure, even with its own money. But he left standing another policy that imposes similar speech restrictions and bans using foreign aid money for abortions — even to save a woman’s life or in cases of rape in war zones like Congo, Sudan and Burma.

headline: The Matches Pile Up as Rain Wins Again
text: The United States Open continued Wednesday under both a cloud of controversy and actual clouds. The latter dumped, sprayed and misted rain throughout the afternoon and into the night, which left frazzled tournament officials rearranging a gridlocked schedule, players angered by an early afternoon false start and fans in dire need of umbrellas, ponchos or hooded sweatshirts.

headline: From a Summer Focused on the Debt, Congress Now Pivots to Jobs
text: WASHINGTON — A mere six weeks ago, the animating word on Capitol Hill was debt. Republicans and Democrats obsessed about it, campaigned against it, fought over how to tame it and deployed it as a tool of mutual embarrassment. This fall, same template, new word: Jobs.

headline: TV Executive Behind ‘Springer’ Tries to Win House Seat for G.O.P.
text: Robert L. Turner has seen his share of tawdry sex scandals.

headline: Intensity Increases in Republican Debate
text: Eight candidates gathered at the Reagan Library in Simi Valley, Calif., at a moment of increasing intensity in the fight for the party’s presidential nomination.

headline: Mets’ Patience Tested by Parnell
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — The Mets have been exceedingly patient with Bobby Parnell this season. A losing season has afforded them that small indulgence.

headline: Newly Published Audio Provides Real-Time View of 9/11 Attacks
text: For one instant on the morning of Sept. 11, an airliner that had vanished from all the tracking tools of modern aviation suddenly became visible in its final seconds to the people who had been trying to find it.

headline: The 9/11 Tapes: The Story in the Air
text: A selection of audio recordings from the morning of September 11, 2001.

headline: Big Hole to Repair on Giants’ Defense
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The scene in the Giants’ locker room Wednesday provided a snapshot of the reality of their decimated defense. In the stall next to Jonathan Goff’s vacant locker, the rookie Greg Jones sat on a stool with an open playbook at his feet.

headline: In Congress, Storm Relief Is Grist for Dispute
text: WASHINGTON — Disaster relief proposals touched off a political storm on Capitol Hill on Wednesday as Senate Democrats moved to provide immediate assistance to victims of Hurricane Irene without cutting other programs to offset the cost.

headline: Video of Russian Plane Wreckage
text: As my colleagues Ellen Barry and Andrew E. Kramer report, a plane carrying a popular Russian hockey team crashed during take-off on Wednesday near the Russian city of Yaroslavl, killing 43 of the 45 people on board.

headline: Stoudemire Touts the Benefits of School
text: In front of about 70 people at the Polo Grounds Community Center in Harlem, Amar’e Stoudemire of the Knicks on Wednesday entertained rapt school children and inquisitive adults at a Department of Youth program.

headline: 2 More Solar Companies Get U.S. Loan Backing
text: Undeterred by the bankruptcy filing of a California solar company that got $535 million in federal loan guarantees, the Energy Department is issuing two more large loan guarantees, albeit to companies that look like safer bets.

headline: From the Archives: The First Day of School

headline: When Dogs Tangle With Snakes
text: One reason I like having a dog is to see how much she enjoys being in the outdoors. This summer my dog, Betsy, a shepherd mix I rescued five years ago, and I joined my friend George for a hike in the Sandia Mountains, which rise dramatically on the edge of Albuquerque. As we laced up our boots at the trailhead, with Betsy already checking out the smells of the forest, we were told by a ranger to look out for bears, which had been bothering picnickers in the area.

headline: The Lexicon
text: Unlike some other momentous events in our history — World War II, say, or the Vietnam War — the attacks that took place on Sept. 11, 2001, have not particularly changed or enriched our vocabulary. Sometimes these things take a while. It wasn’t until the 1960s, for example, that the term “holocaust,” which used to mean any large-scale massacre, took on the specific connotations it has today. For now, though, you could argue that the events of 9/11 still seem so unfathomable that they have actually impoverished the language a little, leaving us with a vacuous phrase like war on terror, which manages to empty both “war” and “terror” of much their meaning, or the creepy, Nazi-sounding homeland, which seems a far less pleasant place to live than just plain America.

headline: Thursday Reading: The Ins and Outs of Fixing Your Roof
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: His Highnesses
text: “I love brands that have a niche, something that they do incredibly well time and time again,” says the designer Wes Gordon. For Gordon, few fit this description better than Manolo Blahnik. “What I love about Manolo is that they’ve been making the same consistently beautiful shoes for as long as they’ve been in business,” says Gordon. “No one nails the timeless, forever-feminine aesthetic quite like them. This praise explains his excitement about collaborating with the Italian shoe company for his spring presentation, taking place on Thursday at the Hosfelt Gallery in Chelsea. Using elements of Manolo’s existing vocabulary  — a heel here, a strap there — Gordon designed two different shoes for the show, an updated Mary Jane for day and a streamlined, stacked-heel sandal for night. “It was something of Manolo Legos,” the designer says of the process. “The look is very Gwyneth from ‘Great Expectations.’ Clean ’90s minimalism done in a very luxe way.” Expect timeless silhouettes done in surprising fabrications, like Lurex and stretch tulle. “So many shoes out there are very aggressive or very cool, and make a statement. But I think at the end of the day what a woman wants is something really sexy, beautiful and clean.”

headline: George Carlin Street? He’d Have Something to Say About That

headline: Hello! Matt Stone and Trey Parker Crash a Class at N.Y.U.
text: It turns out a Tony Award really can get you in anywhere. Having run the table at the Tonys in June with their hit musical, “The Book of Mormon,” the “South Park” co-creators Matt Stone and Trey Parker were back in New York on Tuesday, where they showed up as instructors at New York University’s Tisch School of the Arts. Approximately 25 freshmen who perhaps expected to doze their way through the first day of a “Storytelling Strategies” course were instead treated to a surprise visit by Mr. Stone and Mr. Parker, who discussed the creation of projects including “South Park,” “Team America: World Police” and “The Book of Mormon.” (Among the nuggets of wisdom offered by Mr. Parker, a self-confessed addict of the Food Network, was to not use too many ingredients in your writing: “Get one piece of salmon and cook it just right,” he said. “Boil it down to one thing.”)
