headline: The Rick Perry Experiment
text: Under the traditional rules of American politics, last night was a very bad night for Texas Governor Rick Perry. In his debut debate, his first introduction to a national audience, he found himself first explaining and then doubling down on his description of  Social Security as a “Ponzi scheme,” with a few references to the “monstrous lie” of its long-term promises thrown in for good measure. It was precisely the kind of moment that the Romney campaign must have been hoping for, and thanks to the moderators’ questions and Perry’s answers, it fell into Romney’s lap without him having to even raise the issue. As soon as the exchange happened, a Romney adviser e-mailed Politico’s Ben Smith: “[Perry] has lost. No federal candidate has ever won on the Perry program to kill Social Security. Never has. never will.” That’s spin, yes, but I’m sure the Romney people believe the basic premise. As well they should. Everything we know about American voters — and yes, Republican primary voters very much included — suggests that Perry’s comments will eventually be deadly to his electoral prospects.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: Morning T: Rag & Bone
text: Jane Herman, online editor at T Magazine, talks with the designers behind the clothing line Rag & Bone.

headline: At the Open, Bagels for the Men
text: Despite the well-publicized trend of top A.T.P. players such as Novak Djokovic and Andy Murray turning to gluten-free diets, male players at the 2011 U.S. Open have shown a voracious appetite for bagels.

headline: Kids in the 9/11 Decade
text: How children coming of age in the 9/11 decade respond to the events of Sept. 11.

headline: DuPont Offers Compensation for Dead Trees
text: The chemical manufacturer DuPont has set up a process through which people can make monetary claims for trees that have been damaged or killed by its product Imprelis, a new-generation herbicide that was used by commercial applicators on lawns across the country this spring for the first time.

headline: In the Morning, Optimism at the Open
text: Shortly after 9 a.m. on Thursday, subway workers opened the gates below the tracks for the 7 train, and workers for the United States Open made their way onto the boardwalk. One woman wore rainbow striped galoshes. A man carried an oversized umbrella.

headline: Art on Your Sleeve | Amy Yao for JF & Son
text: Not many fashion labels can boast an in-house art curator, but for Jesse Finkelstein and Katie King, the designers behind the New York label JF & Son, Travis Boyer is an accessory they can’t live without. Through my “My Favorite Things,” JF & Son works on at least four collaborative collections per year as well as various one-off collaborations. Last year, for example, the artist Ulrike Müller translated her 8.5-by-11-inch pencil drawings into quilts; a version of this project was part of the 2010 Cairo Biennial. “We’re trying to be a little more spontaneous,” Finkelstein explains. “It’s not about creating a lifestyle for our customer. Adds King: “It’s more about creating a vision that appeals to the community.”

headline: Knopf Speeds U.S. Publication of Julian Barnes Novel
text: Trying to capitalize on Booker buzz, Knopf has moved up the publication date of “The Sense of an Ending,” a novel by Julian Barnes that was one of six books chosen for the shortlist of the 2011 Man Booker Prize for Fiction. Mr. Barnes has been widely cited as a favorite for the prize, which is the most celebrated literary award in Britain. “The Sense of an Ending,” a slim volume of only 176 pages, will be released by Knopf, part of Random House, on Oct. 11, three months ahead of its scheduled U.S. publication date. Four of the other shortlisted books have already been published in the United States, and the remaining book, “Half Blood Blues” by Esi Edugyan, is not yet available in the United States, said a spokeswoman for its London-based publisher, Serpent’s Tail. The winner of the Booker will be announced on Oct. 18.

headline: Welcome to India Ink
text: Welcome to India Ink, The New York Times’ first-ever country-specific site for news, information, culture and conversation.

headline: Ironworkers of the Sky
text: To get to the top of 1 World Trade Center as it stands in mid-August, just shy of 1,000 feet above Lower Manhattan, higher than anything else on the island’s southern end, first you walk to the middle of the blast-resistant concrete cathedral that will become the building’s lobby. From there, a hoist takes you to the 39th floor, whose perimeter has already been glassed in. A sign spray-painted in screaming construction orange — “EXPRESS ALL DAY” — directs you to a second hoist, inside which Don McLean is singing, “Bye, bye, Miss American Pie . . .” and men in hard hats decoupaged with flag decals are bobbing their heads to the beat.

headline: Ford Focus ST: An Already Familiar Face Turns Toward Frankfurt
text: The series production version of the Ford Focus ST will show its face formally — and finally — next week at the Frankfurt motor show. The hot hatch will be sold in the United States later in 2012.

headline: Some Channels Are Forgoing 9/11 Shows
text: By the time the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks has passed, American television networks will have presented more than 75 hours of new programming — documentaries, memorials, dramas, live broadcasts — connected to the event. That tide will continue into the night of the anniversary on Sunday, when ABC, CBS, PBS and several cable channels are devoting some or all of their prime-time schedules to shows related to the attacks.

headline: Plane or Train? Sites to Help You Decide
text: Some travelers would take the train rather than plane if the price was right, but entering an itinerary at multiple travel sites is inconvenient. Two search engines, Hipmunk and TripAdvisor Flights, are fixing this problem by allowing users to do one-stop shopping for airplane and intercity rail tickets.

headline: Play Resumes at the Open
text: The United States Open resumed play Thursday morning. But for Andy Roddick, the No. 21 seed, and fifth-seeded David Ferrer, the resumption did not last long at Louis Armstrong Stadium. Roddick was part of a group of players who visited Brian Earley, the tournament referee, on Wednesday, after three matches were started briefly in the afternoon, then eventually canceled. Roddick said that officials “may have jumped the gun a little bit,” in trying to force the players on the court. Other matches were being played on other courts.

headline: Yankees Playing Orioles Under Overcast Skies
text: 1:51 p.m. | Updated With Game Under Way

headline: Exhibition of Bob Dylan Paintings Will Be Shown at Gagosian Gallery in New York
text: From the rubble-filled streets of Rome to the sunny, aqua-blue skies of Mozambique, Bob Dylan has traveled the world in his music and his real-life exploits. Now a series of his drawings and paintings that chronicle his journeys in Asia will be coming to the Gagosian Gallery, the first time that Mr. Dylan’s art will be exhibited in New York City, the gallery said. The exhibition, “The Asia Series,” will run at the Gagosian on the Upper East Side from Sept. 20 through Oct. 22, and will include works that Mr. Dylan created on trips to Japan, China, Vietnam and South Korea. (Dylanologists will recall that the singer-songwriter played his first shows in China and in Vietnam last spring.)

headline: Monza:  A Weekend of Anniversaries, Good and Bad
text: MONZA, Italy – It feel likes a typical, warm, sunny Thursday of the Italian Grand Prix weekend here in Monza. But as I think about the themes of the weekend, one thing comes through predominantly: The number of anniversaries, good and bad. They are coming in from all sides.

headline: Monza:  A Weekend of Anniversaries, Good and Bad
text: MONZA, Italy – It feel likes a typical, warm, sunny Thursday of the Italian Grand Prix weekend here in Monza. But as I think about the themes of the weekend, one thing comes through predominantly: The number of anniversaries, good and bad. They are coming in from all sides.

headline: Leading M.&A. Lawyer to Join Greenberg Traurig
text: Big news in Big Law: Dennis Block, one of the country’s leading mergers and acquistions lawyers, is joining Greenberg Traurig. He is leaving Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft.

headline: Fall Trends | Feet First
text: Walk softly and wear a big trend. Go to  interactive feature >>

headline: Google Details, and Defends, Its Use of Electricity
text: Google disclosed Thursday that it continuously uses enough electricity to power 200,000 homes, but it says that in doing so, it also makes the planet greener.

headline: The Price We Pay for Medical Care
text: Americans seem to be paying the price for the unrelenting rise in health care costs in this country, according to several studies being published on Thursday in Health Affairs, an academic journal.

headline: In a Twist, Google Reviews Zagat, and Decides to Bite
text: 8:45 p.m. | Updated

headline: Mourners Gather at Arena of Russian Hockey Team
text: YAROSLAVL, Russia — Toward evening on Thursday, a column of government officials in dark suits filed out of the hockey arena and began their journey back to Moscow. They were watched from a distance by a crowd made up largely of teenagers, many in hockey jerseys, their eyes swollen from crying.

headline: A Tale of Jacob, Esau and Muscles
text: At one point in “Warrior” we see Brendan Conlon, a high school science teacher, laying down the law — the law of physics that is — for his students. “Force equals mass times acceleration,” he writes on the board. That formula might be of use in thinking this new film from Gavin O’Connor, which grasps the Newtonian principles at the heart of pugilistic melodrama.

headline: Regulator Further Delays Derivatives Rules
text: A top federal regulator will further delay a flood of new rules for the $600 trillion derivatives market, another setback for the sweeping overhaul passed in the aftermath of the financial crisis.

headline: Spotting a Few Sharks and Jets at New York Philharmonic’s ‘West Side Story’
text: When they stood up, several looked like New York Philharmonic patrons: older men in suits.

headline: Tips for Negotiating the Cost of Medical Care
text: Readers of Bucks know that we usually advocate negotiating discounts on all sorts of things, on the theory that it never hurts to ask. But what about medical care? Is there room to discuss the cost of, say, your annual checkup?

headline: Guess Where This Is
text: It’s time again for our weekly contest: guess the location of the photograph above.

headline: Just One Look | Organic by John Patrick
text: A collection dominated by khakis and white cotton linen has safari written all over it, even with the offbeat addition of Belgian loafers and silk pajama pants. Here, a very American white shirt, wide-leg jeans and a cape-shaped parka in a look full of basics that should be the easiest to shop for, but often aren’t. Bookmark it. You’ll be happy you did.

headline: No Search for Profits, but Troupe Finds Hits
text: LONDON

headline: Google Buys the Zagat Guides
text: Our colleagues at DealBook are reporting that Google has purchased the Zagat Survey company for an as-yet undisclosed sum.

headline: Subversive Tongue and a Sharp Focus on Identity Politics
text: IF Caryl Churchill, Franz Kafka and Ali G were to goof around one night and play their music too loud until the Department of Homeland Security came knocking on their door, they might emerge (eventually) the next morning holding something like the script to “Invasion!” In that play — Jonas Hassen Khemiri’s blistering dark comedy, which opens at the Flea Theater on Tuesday — one character’s harmless memories of his Lebanese uncle, Abulkasem, morph into a genre- and language-scrambling fantasia on fear, confusion and the Other. Along the way the evasive Abulkasem re-emerges as everyone from a world-renowned terrorist to a female avant-garde theater director to a “super pro pimp” at a singles bar.

headline: Intelligentsia Coffee and Tea Asks a Friend to Help It Grow
text: Doug Zell, the founder of Intelligentsia Coffee and Tea, announced that he will share his duties as chief executive with the philanthropist and former real estate developer Robert Buono. Mr. Zell and Mr. Buono will both have the title of Co-C.E.O. in a professional association that Mr. Buono characterizes as a “partnership.”

headline: Man Pleads Guilty in 4 Killings at Long Island Pharmacy
text: RIVERHEAD, N.Y. — The man accused in the shooting deaths of four people in a pharmacy in Medford, N.Y., pleaded guilty on Thursday to five counts of first-degree murder and faces the likelihood of spending the rest of his life in prison.

headline: Japan Official Ordered Nuclear E-Mails, Inquiry Finds
text: KYOTO, Japan — Investigators concluded Thursday that a nuclear plant operator that tried to manipulate public opinion with fake e-mails was acting under instructions from a high-ranking local government official, adding a new twist to a scandal that has hampered Japan’s efforts to restart idled nuclear reactors after the Fukushima disaster.

headline: Court Blocks Suit Against Health Law
text: A federal appellate court in Richmond, Va., on Thursday threw out a pair of cases challenging the constitutionality of President Obama’s 2010 health care law, ruling for varying reasons that the plaintiffs did not have legal standing to sue.

headline: ‘[title of show]’ Team Will Return to Vineyard With Newest Show
text: The creators of the critically acclaimed but short-lived Broadway musical “[title of show]” will mount their new project “Now. Here. This.” — once more, a blend of autobiographical stories and songs — at the Vineyard Theater in March and April 2012, the Off Broadway theater company announced on Thursday.

headline: Mississippi Lures ‘Green’ Manufacturing Jobs
text: Calisolar, a Sunnyvale, Calif.-based manufacturer of silicon for solar cells, has decided to build its next factory in a faraway locale known for generous government subsidies, low taxes and relatively inexpensive labor rates: Mississippi.

headline: Lazard Hires a Greenhill Founding Partner
text: Lazard, the independent investment bank, said on Thursday that it had hired Timothy M. George, a founding partner of the boutique investment bank Greenhill & Company, to expand its consumer and food advisory practice.

headline: Hedge Fund Takes Big Yahoo Stake, Calls for Board Shake-Up
text: Daniel S. Loeb’s hedge fund, Third Point Management, disclosed in a filing on Thursday that it had acquired a 5.15 percent stake in Yahoo and hinted at a proxy challenge if changes were not made on the Internet company’s board.

headline: Roddick-Ferrer Match Moved to Court 13
text: 1:48 p.m. | Updated Andy Roddick seemed to take his anger over the botched drying of Armstrong Stadium out on David Ferrer. After play resumed on Court 13, Roddick quickly grabbed the first set 6-3 and then the second set 6-4.

headline: Miles Davis, Live at the Apogee
text: AROUND this time last year it became hard not to see the Miles Davis reissue juggernaut as a snake swallowing its own tail. What cinched the impression was the arrival of “The Genius of Miles Davis,” encompassing all of Davis’s output for Columbia. It wasn’t a bricklike compendium of albums — that had been done, with great fanfare, the previous year — but rather a stockpile of the eight multidisc sets released by Columbia/Legacy over the last 15 years. A boxed set of boxed sets. It came housed in a reproduction of Davis’s trumpet case, along with a reproduction of his mouthpiece, a lithograph of one of his paintings, and a T-shirt. Original retail: $1,199. (It’s a well-fed snake.)

headline: Ironworkers in the New York Times Lobby
text: We invite all of our local readers to check out an amazing exhibit of New York Times photography in honor of 9/11. Come to the New York Times lobby, at 620 8th Avenue, between 40th and 41st Streets. It’s free and open to the public from 8 a.m. to 7 p.m. between Sept. 8 and 12.

headline: Patient Data Posted Online in Major Breach of Privacy
text: A medical privacy breach led to the public posting on a commercial Web site of data for 20,000 emergency room patients at Stanford Hospital in Palo Alto, Calif., including names and diagnosis codes, the hospital has confirmed. The information stayed online for nearly a year.

headline: How Much Information Do You Share With Employees?
text: Do you tell your employees everything that’s going on? Or only what you think they need to know? I have grappled with this question since I started managing a business.

headline: A Boa, an Autopsy and More About Goldsmith
text: As Tropical Storm Irene was making landfall in the city on Aug. 28, flooding erupted in an apartment at a public housing complex in Brooklyn, and officers from the department’s elite Emergency Service Unit answered the call for help.

headline: Sex, and Kids, and Rock ‘n’ Roll
text: Each generation’s definition of good music seems to include the fact that it offends, or at least baffles, the generation before.

headline: Library of Congress Acquires John Raitt Collection
text: The Broadway and personal memorabilia of John Raitt, the dynamic baritone and Broadway leading man who played Billy Bigelow in the original 1945 production of “Carousel” and Sid Sorkin in “The Pajama Game” a decade later, has gone to the music division of the Library of Congress. The extensive collection is a peek into six decades of Mr. Raitt’s life and includes scrapbooks, publicity photos, recordings, annotated scripts, musical scores, tapes he made of himself, and correspondence, said Denise Gallo, the head of acquisitions and processing at the library’s music division.

headline: Hertz on Demand Enters Car-Sharing Race
text: With a Kermit-green ethos and paperwork-free, right-around-the-corner rentals, car-sharing schemes like Zipcar  have built a loyal following among auto-less urbanites and college students, customers that Zipcar refers to as Zipsters. Now one of the biggest names in car rentals is rolling out some new competition.

headline: Divining Perry’s Meaning on Galileo Remark
text: In one of the more curious moments in the Republican debate on Wednesday night, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas invoked 17th-century science in discussing his doubts about climate change. He cited the astronomer and mathematician Galileo Galilei — often called the father of modern science — in suggesting that the current thinking that climate change is a result of human activity could be overturned. “Galileo got outvoted for a spell,” he said.

headline: Phillies’ Protest Is Denied
text: The Phillies’ protest regarding fan interference and the umpires’ use of video replay in their game with the Florida Marlins on Sunday was denied on Wednesday by Major League Baseball.

headline: Firefighters’ Names Endure in St. Patrick’s Towers
text: You and I can think of many words to describe the ceiling of St. Patrick’s Cathedral: Intricate. Fussy. Medieval. Gloomy. Mysterious. Celestial. Uplifting. Inspirational. Awesome.

headline: Nadal Defeats Muller
text: In a battle of powerful left-handers, Rafael Nadal of Spain took top billing over unseeded Gilles Muller of Luxembourg and rushed into the quarterfinals of the United States Open on Thursday with a 7-6 (1), 6-1, 6-2 victory on a dried-out Arthur Ashe Stadium court.

headline: Lost & Found | Hanna Liden at Karma
text: A couple of weeks ago, the artist Hanna Liden forgot her backpack on a bench in the East Village. When she went back to look for it some 20 minutes later, it was still there. “That’s scary!” Liden exclaimed the other morning, sitting at a table at Karma, Brendan Dugan’s bookshop and design studio on Downing Street in the West Village. The New York Liden lays bare in her new book, “Out of My Mind … Back in 5 Minutes,” is not the sort of place you’d want to leave your personal belongings unattended. Trash bags pile up in the streets like body bags, a slick of dark liquid might be oil or it might be blood, even a rock in central park has the menacing look of a giant, gaunt-eyed skull. This is, of course, all a lot funnier than it sounds. The book is compiled from images swiped from the Internet, photos taken with a BlackBerry and installation shots from Liden’s recent shows at Maccarone and Salon 94 including a series of self-portraits in which she wore various plastic deli shopping bags. A recurring chorus of slogans appropriated from souvenir T-shirts delivers the punchline. “Of all the things I’ve lost, I miss my mind the most.”

headline: At La Scala, the Show Will Go On as Workers Cancel Strike Plans
text: Workers at La Scala opera house in Milan have rescinded a strike threat, meaning a concert performance of Beethoven’s “Fidelio” there on Friday by the Vienna Staatsoper will go on, a spokesman for the company said on Thursday.

headline: Obama Challenges Congress on Job Plan
text: WASHINGTON — Mixing politically moderate proposals with a punchy tone, President Obama challenged lawmakers on Thursday to “pass this jobs bill” — a blunt call on Congress to enact his $447 billion package of tax cuts and new government spending, designed to revive a stalling economy and his own political standing.

headline: Richard Chai: Back to School
text: At New York Fashion Week, particularly with the September shows, there is always a slight back-to-school feeling whenever all the editors and retailers reconvene, as they did this morning in Lincoln Center, in all their latest finery. This morning also happened to be the first day of school for most New York City students, and at least in my neighborhood in Brooklyn, the students were better dressed than the fashionistas. I was particularly taken with a young woman who was wearing an oversize white dress shirt backwards and belted. (It’s also Fashion’s Night Out, so that may explain why so many people look done-up today.)

headline: The Cycle of Revenge
text: I’ve never understood the proverbial wisdom that revenge is a dish best served cold. Some seem to like it hot. Better is the Chinese proverb, attributed to Confucius, “Before you embark on a journey of revenge, dig two graves.” Osama bin Laden’s grave was watery, but the other still appears empty. Is it intended for us?

headline: Romney Hits Perry Again on Social Security
text: If there was any doubt about what Mitt Romney thought was the most significant moment of Wednesday night’s debate, an e-mail from his campaign should clear that right up.

headline: Opel-Vauxhall Concept Joins Suddenly Crowded E.V. Runabout Segment
text: Add another contestant to the city-car sweepstakes kicking off next week in Frankfurt: the battery-operated Opel-Vauxhall runabout concept.

headline: New York Fashion Week Diary | Tom Bull
text: Isaac Hindin Miller of Isaac Likes follows the breakout Aussie model Tom Bull as he navigates New York Fashion Week. In this clip, the duo attends a Perry Ellis casting. “I’m already an option for the campaign, so hopefully the show’s a given,” Bull says. Our fingers are crossed for you, Tom!

headline: New York Fashion Week | Tom Bull
text: The Moment follows Tom Bull on a casting call for Fashion Week.

headline: Divining Perry’s Meaning in ‘Galileo’ Remark
text: In one of the more curious moments in the Republican debate on Wednesday night, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas invoked 17th-century science in discussing his doubts about climate change. He cited the astronomer and philosopher Galileo Galilei — often called the father of modern science — in suggesting that the current thinking that climate change is a result of human activity could be overturned. “Galileo got outvoted for a spell,” he said.

headline: A performance by the English singer-songwriter Nick Lowe; a flood of Miles Davis live releases; and new albums from Terius Nash, George Strait and Cymbals Eat Guitars.
text: This week: a chat with and performance by the English singer-songwriter Nick Lowe; a deep dive into a new Miles Davis live set; and a look at new releases by Terius Nash, George Strait and Cymbals Eat Guitars. Ben Ratliff is the host.

headline: Poetry Pairing | Images of Transit Riders
text: What images strike you and linger in your mind when you’re on a subway platform awaiting an arrival or leaving the station? Do you notice the faces and expressions of your fellow riders when you’re on a train?

headline: Wal-Mart to Bring Back Layaway for Holidays
text: Wal-Mart said on Thursday that it planned to bring back its layaway payment plan for the holidays, an indication that shoppers at the nation’s largest retailer were feeling more and more strapped.

headline: Brian Dennehy stars in two productions at the Stratford Shakespeare Festival.
text: Brian Dennehy portrays two contrasting miscreants in productions of Shakespeare’s “Twelfth Night” and Harold Pinter’s “Homecoming” at the Stratford Shakespeare Festival.

headline: Memory in the Making
text: MILAN

headline: Fed Chief Describes Consumers as Too Bleak
text: WASHINGTON — Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, offered a new twist on a familiar subject Thursday, revisiting the question of why growth continues to fall short of hopes and expectations.

headline: Dodging Raindrops and Seeking a Title, Federer Moves On
text: That man trying to sell New Yorkers a Rolex by the side of the road? That would be Roger Federer, whose image graces a billboard along the route from Manhattan to the National Tennis Center in Queens.

headline: A Hummingbird’s Musical Tail
text: David Rothenberg, a musician, author and environmental philosopher (and friend and neighbor last seen here covered in cicadas), has contributed a “Your Dot” reflection on some fascinating research published in the Sept. 9 edition of Science. The work reveals how the males of certain hummingbird species go beyond the usual avian song-making methods, exploiting the turbulence around tail feathers to add to their conventional vocalizations when trying to attract a mate.

headline: ArtsBeat: Sept. 8, 2011
text: Excerpts from interviews with artists reflecting on the Sept. 11 attacks ten years later. For the full interviews, please go to nytimes.com/arts.

headline: Many Views on a Greek Bond’s Value
text: Is there one set of international accounting standards, or can each country choose its own when the going gets tough?

headline: HBO Picks Up Aaron Sorkin Series About Cable TV News
text: Aaron Sorkin is a man who likes getting deep inside high-pressure work environments – see his résumé, which includes the television series “Sports Night” and “The West Wing,” and his Academy Award-winning screenplay for “The Social Network.” And his latest project should offer plenty of opportunities for the verbal fireworks and walk-and-talk tracking shots he favors. HBO said on Thursday that it had picked up a new series from Mr. Sorkin set in the competitive world of cable-television news.

headline: For the Mets, Injuries Never End
text: Jay Horwitz, the longtime spokesman for the Mets, fractured his ankle Thursday morning while walking to work and will undergo surgery Monday.

headline: F.B.I. Raids Solar Firm That Got U.S. Loans
text: The F.B.I. on Thursday raided the office of a California solar company that borrowed $528 million from the federal government before filing for bankruptcy, as House Republicans announced that they would call two top Obama administration officials to testify about the case next week.

headline: Head Injuries on the Football Field
text: College football players beware: Linebackers and linemen suffer more head impacts during a game than players in other positions, but running backs and quarterbacks endure the hardest and most severe blows to the head, a new study reports.

headline: Discussing the Opening Sequence of ‘3’
text: Tom Tykwer, the director of ‘3,’ discusses the collage-focused opening credit sequence of his film.

headline: Popcast: Nick Lowe, an Interview, Performance and Album Preview
text: This week the English singer-songwriter Nick Lowe stopped by to talk about his career and perform a song from his new album, “The Old Magic.” An exclusive stream of the record is below.

headline: Canada Extends Trading Ban on Sino-Forest
text: OTTAWA — The Ontario Securities Commission on Thursday extended until next year its trading ban of shares of Sino-Forest, a controversial Chinese forestry company listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

headline: Cloudy, With A Chance Of Tennis
text: After two days of washouts, tennis matches have resumed with Roger Federer facing Jo-Wilfried Tsonga in the Quarterfinals of the US Open at Arthur Ashe Stadium tonight.

headline: Profile in Style | Scott Sternberg
text: Ask him about his childhood troll collection, his penchant for old Time Life tomes or his worship of baked goods — but please don’t ask the Band of Outsiders designer to expound on his personal style. “That’s such a magazine question,” he says with a groan. Like the cool subversions of men’s and women’s preppy classics his fast-growing label is known for (the first BOO store opens in Tokyo this winter), Sternberg’s L.A. home is a playful amalgam of vintage references and bright color combinations with a winsome splash of naïveté. Go to  interactive feature >>

headline: Courtside: Cloudy, With a Chance of Tennis
text: After two days of washouts, tennis matches have resumed, with Roger Federer facing Jo-Wilfried Tsonga in the Quarterfinals of the U.S. Open at Arthur Ashe Stadium tonight.

headline: Boys in Briefs
text: Go figure. The combination of an open bar and the promise of young, attractive men in skimpy underwear is quite the crowd-pleaser. At least that was the conclusion to be drawn from the 2(X)ist 201fashion show at the Hiro Ballroom in Chelsea last night.

headline: Pictures of the Day: New Jersey and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from the United States, Libya, Russia and Britain.

headline: Report Details British Abuses in Iraq
text: LONDON — A major inquiry into the most notorious case of detainee abuse by British soldiers in Iraq described “a very great stain on the reputation of the army” in its report issued Thursday, detailing a series of gruesome abuses by servicemen in a regiment with a 300-year history of battle honors abroad.

headline: Internet Memes 101: A Guide to Online Wackiness
text: In the olden days, it was simple to keep up with pop culture. There were only three channels on TV, and everybody saw the same shows at the same time.

headline: Fall Hacking Season Underway!
text: General Assembly, on Broadway, between 20th and 21st streets, will host noteworthy hackfests the next two weekends.

headline: Saab, Denied Court Protection, Faces Bankruptcy
text: On Thursday, a Swedish district court rejected Saab’s bid for protection from its creditors, leaving the automaker with few options other than filing for bankruptcy. The company reportedly owes its suppliers 150 million euros ($210 million).

headline: At the Toronto Film Festival, the Publicists Invade
text: TORONTO— American Airlines Flight 1586, nonstop from Los Angeles to Toronto on Wednesday, was packed to the bulkheads with what looked very much like Geoffrey Rush, a journalist or two (this one included), and publicists, of every size, shape and function. Ryan Gosling’s publicist. International publicists. Sony Pictures publicists. The whole gamut.

headline: Serena Williams Wins in Straight Sets
text: Serena Williams of the United States won an error-plagued encounter with Anastasia Pavlyuchenko of Russia on Thursday to advance to the semifinals of the U.S. Open, 7-5, 6-1.

headline: The Vote That Delayed Obama’s Speech
text: WASHINGTON – Last week there was a small hoo-ha over choosing a day for President Obama to address a joint session of Congress. Mr. Obama wanted to give his jobs speech on Wednesday, the same night as a Republican presidential debate. But he was rebuffed by John A. Boehner, the House speaker, who said late votes on Wednesday would prohibit an ample security sweep.

headline: Fete Accompli | The Couture Council Honors Valentino
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#892", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);What: The annual benefit luncheon for the Couture Council of the Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology. This year’s event was in honor of Valentino, who was presented with the Artistry of Fashion Award. In attendance were many of the retired designer’s friends and fans — many in Valentino red to brighten up a dreary, gray day.

headline: Does the Return of Lost Items Require a Reward?
text: Many of you have probably experienced that sinking feeling when you realize that you’ve lost your wallet, a phone, or perhaps even worse, a laptop.

headline: Rating the No. 1’s: ‘Batgirl’ and More
text: Two Times staffers and comic-book fans, George Gene Gustines and Adam W. Kepler, will review all of the 52 DC Comics titles that have been rebooted as part of a companywide effort to revive the brand. In the second of five weekly installments they discuss Batgirl, Animal Man, Action Comics and others that came out on Wednesday. Next week they’ll look at Batwoman, Green Lantern and more.

headline: Plan’s Focus on Social Security Taxes Reflects Its Modest Ambitions
text: WASHINGTON — The centerpiece of President Obama’s job-creation plan, a proposal to further reduce Social Security taxes, is emblematic of a package of modest measures that some economists describe as helpful but not sufficient to lift the economy from its malaise.

headline: A Big Risk in the Health Care Handoff
text: Care transitions — those times when someone enters a hospital, transfers from one department to another, gets discharged to a rehabilitation center or goes home — are risky times. Health care professionals have long known that these handoffs provide prime opportunities for mistakes, most often because of communication lapses.

headline: 36 Hours in Bern
text: In Bern, you can dance till dawn or rise early and take a walk under the gaze of the Alps and be back in time for lunch.

headline: 36 Hours in Bern, Switzerland
text: ASK a Swiss to describe Bern and you may hear a joke about how the people move so slowly that even their souls take centuries to reach heaven. While it is true that this city of about 130,000 people in western Switzerland must be counted among the most relaxed of Europe’s capitals, Bern is also one of the most beautiful, a pocket-size Prague of arcades and whimsical fountains, all framed by leafy hills and the glacial-green currents of the Aare River. The urban and rural mingle closely here. Forests of ash and oak push up against a clutch of embassies off a city square. You can dance till dawn or rise early and take a walk under the gaze of the Alps and be back in time for lunch. Why rush through that?

headline: Best Sellers Weekly Graphic: Inside the Bush White House
text: Former Vice President Dick Cheney’s memoir debuts at No. 1 on the hardcover nonfiction list this week. How some other books written by authors with ties to the Bush administration fared.

headline: Brothers in, and Beyond, Arms
text: Last fall, as a new student at Columbia University, I endured the hallowed tradition of new student orientation, picking classes, and trying to fit in. The only difference being that I was not a 17-year-old leaving his parents’ nest for the first time, but a 24-year-old soldier who had spent a large majority of his early 20s training for war and deploying to war.

headline: The Different Audiences for Obama’s Speech
text: President Obama’s jobs speech on Thursday evening will take place in front of a joint session of Congress, underlining the coming legislative clash over how best to jump-start the nation’s flagging economy.

headline: Faculty Strike Delays Classes at L.I.U.
text: Classes at Long Island University were supposed to start Wednesday, but the new school year has been delayed for thousands of students at the main campuses in Brooklyn and Long Island, where the faculty is on strike.

headline: Stosur Defeats Zvonareva
text: Samantha Stosur of Australia, a finalist a year ago at the French Open, upset Vera Zvonareva of Russia, 6-3, 6-3, on Thursday to catapult into the women’s semifinals of the U.S. Open.

headline: ‘Talent’ Lifts NBC
text: Riding on the back of “America’s Got Talent,” NBC finished first in average total viewership and tied CBS for the top spot in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic on Wednesday night. “Talent” definitely has some momentum heading into its season finale next week, rising 11 percent in total viewers to 11.8 million compared to last week’s episode.

headline: TimesCast | Obama's Jobs Speech Preview
text: President Obama presents his jobs and economic growth plan tonight amid a darkening economic forecast.

headline: Backstage at BCBG
text: Wet, slicked-back hair and minimal makeup at the BCBG show.

headline: Morgan Stanley Names 3 to Head Media and Telecom Group
text: Morgan Stanley has named three new heads of its media and communications banking group, after the team’s current head left the firm for NBC Universal, according to an internal memorandum obtained by DealBook.

headline: A Push-Button Hemingway Soundtrack
text: IN a game of Six Degrees of Ernest Hemingway it might take a while to get to David Lee Roth, the founding frontman for the rock band Van Halen. But Papa Hemingway and Diamond Dave are united in virility at the New York Theater Workshop, where Mr. Roth’s arena-size yelps are among the atmospheric audio effects in “The Select (The Sun Also Rises),” a show based on Hemingway’s 1926 novel.

headline: TimesCast | Potential New Human Ancestor
text: Paleontologists in South Africa may have discovered a new species of hominid, potentially redrawing the tree of human evolution.

headline: When Computers Come Between Doctors and Patients
text: Despite being considered by some as a hospital of last resort, the sprawling city hospital where I’ve spent 20 years is at the forefront of electronic trends. Although some hospitals are computerized, most do not have fully functional electronic medical records, as promoted by the health care reform law of 2010. And more than half of all outpatient practices still use paper charts, making health care the only major industry that is not fully computerized.

headline: Just One Look | BCBG MaxAzria
text: New York City’s public schools resumed classes just hours before the 10 a.m. BCBG MaxAzria show, the first to take place under fashion’s big top at the Theater at Lincoln Center. Indeed, the distinctive back-to-school buzz was a good one to ride during the show, which starred piece-y silk chiffon dresses and colors called “clover,” “saffron” and “jade.” On Jacquelyn (above): a striking “layered” look with a pleated side panel and the collection’s defining diamond embroidery up top.

headline: Figuring Out How Children Learn With Technology
text: Schools are stocking classrooms with computers. And outside of school, children are increasingly glued to screens, be they on phones, personal computers or TVs hooked to gaming consoles.

headline: Imagining a Blur of Fracking Activity
text: As I reported in Thursday’s Times, the complete environmental document detailing how horizontal hydraulic fracturing could affect the communities in upstate New York where most of this gas drilling would take place is out for public review. It may take days for state residents to sift through it.

headline: Amazon and California in Deal on Tax
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The pitched battle between Amazon.com and the state of California over taxes is threatening to turn into a draw.

headline: Backstage Beauty at BCBG
text: The hair and makeup at the BCBG Max Azria show today were pretty basic. Well, it looked basic — fresh-faced, barely there. But for someone who has been trying to achieve the minimal makeup look all summer, I will be the first to say it’s harder than it looks.

headline: U.S. Open Replay: Sept. 8
text: Images from Day 11 of the United States Open in Flushing Meadows, Queens.

headline: Rating the Designers
text: Just when you thought stylists and editors were the only ones passing judgment during New York Fashion Week, Klout — the company that scores people on their so-called digital influence — has ranked the top 10 Fashion Week designers.

headline: Isner Wins in Four Sets
text: While there was chaos and confusion on other parts of the grounds, No. 28 seed John Isner quietly blasted his way into his first career Grand Slam quarterfinal on Court 17, defeating No. 12 Gilles Simon 7-6(2), 3-6, 7-6(2), 7-6(4).

headline: Jerry Swartz
text: Mr. Swartz, 72, is a partner in HKS Capital Partners, a boutique real estate capital advisory and financial brokerage firm that he helped start in April.

headline: When Real Estate Agents Make Referrals
text: A REAL estate agent recommends two mortgage brokers whom she describes as experienced in closing loans. You go to the first one, and don’t bother shopping around on rates or fees.

text: An artist’s supply shop in SoHo provides sculptors everything they need — instruction and supplies — except talent.

headline: Millennium Attracts $4 Billion in New Money
text: As Millennium Management, the New York hedge fund run by the industry titan Israel A. Englander, looks to grow and diversify, it has been on a fund-raising tear, with more than $4 billion in new commitments this year from sovereign wealth funds, pensions and other big investors, according to people with knowledge the fund.

headline: A Front-Seat View of a Back-Seat Robbery
text: Here is a brief tale told in two surveillance photos. On Monday night, the police say, the man pictured above got into a livery cab at Waterbury and East Tremont Avenues in Schuylerville in the Bronx and directed the driver to go to Faile Street and Lafayette Avenue in Hunts Point, about four miles away.

text: The Securities and Exchange Commission is involved in an increasingly heated battle with Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu, the Shanghai-based accounting firm that discovered bookkeeping fraud at Longtop Financial Technologies of China, over access to the financial software company’s records.

text: Among the Republican presidential candidates proposing economic and energy solutions in their debate on Wednesday night, Newt Gingrich cast one of his ideas as particularly bold.

headline: Blame the iPad for Slow PC Sales
text: Shipments of personal computers are expected to grow only 3.8 percent this year, according Gartner, far slower than the 9.3 percent gain it previously forecast.

headline: The Education Bonus and the Gender Gap
text: We at Economix have been fairly persistent in demonstrating why college is worth it. Say it together, now: you are overwhelmingly likely to earn more.

text: PARIS — With markets still volatile, and politicians only marginally closer to a solution of the euro’s troubles than they were two years ago, the future for the euro zone remains uncertain at best.

text: Movies

headline: TimesCast | September 08, 2011
text: David Leonhardt previews President Obama's jobs speech; questions arise about Gov. Rick Perry's electability; and a potential new human ancestor is discovered in South Africa.

headline: Theater Talkback: When a Bare Stage Fills The Theater
text: Theatergoers, especially the kind who regard Broadway as Mecca, expect their seats to come with a breathtaking view. I mean of scenic scenery that gives its own spectacular performance, regardless of what’s happening in front of it. Not for nothing is the longest-running musical ever on Broadway, “The Phantom of the Opera,” a major eye-filler, replete with fat Belle Époque designs, the occasional falling chandelier and a stage-crossing gondola.

headline: Pop and Rock Listings for Sept. 9-15
text: Pop

headline: Smoke and Mirrors
text: We asked the Paris-based designer Rick Owens, a native Californian, to make the T for our fall men’s issue because he’s our favorite independent American abroad. And indeed, he went straight to his home state for inspiration, recalling “rapturous moments at stadium concerts in Fresno and at basement discos in Bakersfield” to create the fog-filled installation that was then captured in this photograph by Fernando Stangelo. We knew that Owens would give us something arresting, original and distinctly American. His reference to the band Kiss and tips on what a man can do to make his masculinity “pop,” below, are just brilliant bonuses.

headline: Fresh Off Debate Debut, Perry Turns Down the Heat
text: CORONA DEL MAR, Calif. — Gov. Rick Perry’s first debate was a hot and unapologetic barbfest with his fellow Republican candidates in which he did not back down from his remarks that Social Security was a “Ponzi scheme.” But Thursday, speaking to the Orange County G.O.P. here, Mr. Perry was more muted in his attacks, never mentioning the entitlement program and offering his own assessment of the debate.

headline: Clip: ‘Lost Tribes and Promised Lands’
text: An excerpt from a silent video installation by Elisabeth Subrin. (Courtesy of Sue Scott Gallery and the artist)

headline: A Database of Names to Trace Slave Ancestry
text: Scholars at the Virginia Historical Society in Richmond have set out to leaf through eight million documents dating back to the 17th century, seeking the names of slaves. The preliminary results, listing about 1,400 enslaved people and 180 owners, will start appearing on Wednesday in a database posted at vahistorical.org.

headline: Elisabeth Subrin
text: An artist and filmmaker’s video installation “Lost Tribes and Promised Lands” deals with 9/11.

headline: Twitter Reaches 100 Million Active Users
text: When Jack Dorsey, co-founder of Twitter, sent the very first tweet five years ago, he most likely didn’t expect that the site would soon be home to tens of millions of people doing the exact same thing. On Thursday, Twitter said that it now has 100 million active users.

headline: Clap Clap, Here Comes Beetle
text: Two years after a children’s game called punch buggy provided the basis for a popular Volkswagen commercial, VW is turning to another children’s game for a commercial to help introduce the 2012 Beetle.

headline: The 9/11 Decade: Colum McCann
text: Colum McCann, the author of five novels and two collections of short stories, won the 2009 National Book Award for “Let the Great World Spin.”

headline: Pictures of the Day: New Jersey and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from New Jersey, Libya, Afghanistan and England.

headline: Redskins Owner Dan Snyder on Being a Marked Man
text: You created a billion-dollar business, which made a mint in direct marketing, but since buying the Redskins in 1999, you have been losing a major P.R. war. There has been this constant drumbeat of negative stories about you.  You mean overkill? I think the media overblows most things. My father was a University of Missouri journalism grad, and when he was alive, he’d say, “At U.P.I., we weren’t allowed to do what they’re doing on the Internet, putting stuff out whether it’s true or not.”

headline: Where Stone Waits to Become Works of Art
text: THE snide “No Rock Climbing” sign in the basement of the Compleat Sculptor makes it clear that the 300 tons of marble, alabaster, granite and soapstone there are not meant for rappelling; they await a finer destiny wrought by human hands wielding sharp tools. The same goes for the slabs of 80-year-old ebony, their resemblance to old telephone poles purely coincidental. Someday they will be works of art in the eye of the beholder who buys and transforms them.

headline: On Court 13, Roddick Prevails
text: As water continued to gurgle up onto the court of Louis Armstrong Stadium, 2003 U.S. Open champion Andy Roddick took control. He forcefully convinced both tournament referee Brian Earley and opponent David Ferrer to move their match to tiny Court 13, which seats fewer than 600 spectators. “Follow me,” he said to Ferrer as he charged out of Armstrong and toward their new venue.

headline: Testimony Implicates a Mubarak Co-Defendant
text: CAIRO — Testimony on Thursday in the criminal case against former President Hosni Mubarak implicated top officials for the first time in ordering the use of force against demonstrators. The evidence added to a patchwork of contradictory accounts that have cast a shadow over the first days of the proceedings.

headline: Jazz Listings for Sept. 9-15
text: Jazz

headline: Kurt Cobain’s Sweet, Sweet Ax
text: Is it appalling, or is it perfectly logical that Fender Guitars is manufacturing a limited-edition Kurt Cobain Jaguar? The sunburst Jaguar is an exact replica of the original that Cobain used on ‘‘Nevermind,’’ from its nonstandard humbucker pickups to the glamorous scar on the back, where Kurt’s belt buckle wore away the finish. It retails for $1,849, and I think it’s axiomatic that if you can afford it, you’re not the next Kurt Cobain.

headline: More on Tar, Oil, Pipelines and Presidents
text: I sought reactions to my post on President Obama and the “Alberta tar pit” from a variety of analysts and campaigners examining the economics and environmental impacts of a proposed pipeline linking that Canadian source of oil with American refiners.

headline: Lorna Williams: ‘brown baby’
text: Dodge Gallery

headline: Empty Seats and Defeat for Yanks
text: BALTIMORE — The crowd at Camden Yards was sparse on Thursday afternoon. It was one of those days when a fan’s yell could reach the field, and it seemed as if beer vendors were speaking into microphones.

headline: A Vanished Row of Unusual Grace in the West Village
text: THE back-and-forth preservation controversy over the odd, saw-toothed National Maritime Union building, on Seventh Avenue and 12th Street, appears to be at an end, with city approval in August of its restoration and renovation as a health care center. A white monolith, it is a peculiar presence in the toy-scale West Village, just as unusual as the strange little string of 1840s houses it succeeded, the charming Rhinelander Row.

headline: Waxing Brazilian
text: Brazil’s most famous assets usually end up prancing down a Victoria’s Secret runway, but with the publication of “Brazilian Style” ($65 at assouline.com), the country’s more obscure offerings — pink dolphins, anyone? — join Carmen Miranda and the caipirinha in a colorful look at Brazil’s cultural legacy. Armand Limnander, the book’s author and a former T editor, says the tome grew out of a 10-year love affair with the country. “It’s a very personal take on the people, places and things that resonate with me,” he says (like the idyllic island of Fernando de Noronha, shown here.) He adds, “Brazil is already an economic superpower — it’s hosting both the Olympics and the World Cup in the next few years — so the next logical step is for it to begin exporting its culture, which is rich, varied and above all, fun.”

headline: Picking Your Slice of New York
text: The digital carrier pigeon flew into Mr. Critic’s window this week with questions about bringing Vermonters south for memorable eating, about the sense and sensibility of brunch and about a rising tide of chefs’ tasting menus. My answers follow. As always, you may send questions about dining out in New York restaurants to dinejournal@nytimes.com. And follow me on Twitter: @SamSifton.

headline: Battle for Libya | Sept. 8, 2011
text: Rebel fighters found a grave containing four dead men in Tripoli, and searched through a rest house belonging to the Qaddafi family in Sadaada.

headline: Men’s U.S. Open Final Headed for Monday, Again
text: The United States Tennis Association announced the revised schedule for the rest of the United States Open, which pushes the men’s final to Monday for the fourth straight year.

headline: TimesCast | Rick Perry's Electability
text: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas laid out several positions in the Republican debate that veered far from many of his competitors.

headline: How Republicans Plan to Respond to Obama
text: President Obama has not started his speech yet, but House Republicans have talking points ready to go.

headline: Working Stiffs
text: Political correctness has rarely been a consideration for the designers Daniel Silver and Steven Cox of Duckie Brown, who often take inspiration from elements of London subcultures that are not always savory. It is from them, years ago, that I first heard the term “chav” used to describe a group of binge-drinking, disaffected underclass teenagers who once embraced the brand Burberry to such a degree that they began to undermine the company’s brand image.

headline: Who’s Sitting With the First Lady
text: A sushi chef, a third-grade teacher facing a layoff and an Iraq war veteran are among the two dozen guests who will be seated with Michelle Obama on Thursday night when President Obama lays out his jobs plan before a joint session of Congress.

headline: Excerpts From 'Cymbeline'
text: Scenes from the Fiasco Theater's production of "Cymbeline." (Video courtesy of the Fiasco.)

headline: Deficit Panel Member Already Talks of Quitting
text: Generally in this town, people serve on a committee at least a few days before threatening to quit. But underscoring the incredibly difficult task before the 12-member bipartisan Congressional committee charged with finding $1.5 trillion in deficit reductions, Senator Jon Kyl of Arizona, one of the six Republicans on the panel, told a conservative group on Thursday that he was already pondering his potential exit.

headline: Kerber Defeats Pennetta
text: Unseeded Angelique Kerber of Germany defeated Flavia Pennetta of Italy, 6-4, 4-6, 6-3, in a tense, hard-fought match that sent the German into the U.S. Open women’s semifinal, where she will face another surprise victor, Samatha Stosur of Australia.

headline: Showcasing Sound in a New Space
text: MONTREAL — When a major new orchestra hall is opened, welcoming speeches from public officials and board members are almost inevitable. So it was here on Wednesday night for the inaugural program of the Montreal Symphony Orchestra at its handsome new home: more than 30 minutes of speeches, including remarks from Jean Charest, the premier of Quebec, and a ceremonial ribbon cutting onstage, with four charming children holding the ribbon and the orchestra’s popular music director, Kent Nagano, conducting the official cutters.

headline: A Nightmare Pox on Your Civilized World
text: “Contagion,” Steven Soderbergh’s smart, spooky thriller about a thicket of contemporary plagues — a killer virus, rampaging fear, an unscrupulous blogger — is as ruthlessly effective as the malady at its cool, cool center. Set in the world-is-flat now, the movie tracks a mystery pathogen after it catches a ride on a flight from Hong Kong to Chicago, an early hop for a globe-sprinting pandemic that cuts across borders and through bodies as effortlessly as Mr. Soderbergh moves among genres, styles and eras, this time by updating 1970s paranoia freakouts like “All the President’s Men” for the anti-government, Tea Party age.

headline: Once a Fast Track, Now a Real Hike to the Top
text: Beacon, N.Y.

headline: Simplest Roast Chicken
text: Mark Bittman reveals the secret to roasting the perfect whole chicken.

headline: The Minimalist: Simplest Roast Chicken
text: I did five recipes for whole roast chicken over the 13-year history of the Minimalist column, and, modesty aside (what does that mean, actually? Get ready for me to be immodest?), there’s no need for me to apologize for the redundancy.

headline: Revving Up
text: Coveralls, quilting, army surplus and collegiate classics as spotted at the fall men’s shows make their way onto the men who wear them best. Go to interactive feature >>

headline: Feasting on Paperwork
text: The amount billed by Debevoise & Plimpton to write a 17-page letter on a new rule intended to rein in risky banking — around $100,000 — would make most authors jealous.

headline: As Concert Halls Open, Programs Follow a Blueprint
text: Concert halls continue to open around North America, and each one is a big deal for classical music lovers and performers, even if orchestras are increasingly falling into serious financial trouble. The inaugural concert program has become a ritual, almost as codified as haiku.

headline: Q&A: Taking the Upgrade Leap From Windows XP to Windows 7
text: Q.

headline: Pretty Girls, Seemingly Pursued by an Evil Eye
text: I have a mistake to admit. Four years ago I reviewed Lucette Lagnado’s book “The Man in the White Sharkskin Suit” and called it, as her publisher did, a memoir. But after reading what is being billed as its sequel, I’ve come to realize that her earlier book was, in fact, a biography.

headline: A Beloved Film Gains a Live Sound
text: Orchestras have discovered in the last few years that film nights — concerts that present live accompaniments to movies — are huge audience draws. Often they involve excerpts, usually without dialogue, and sometimes edited for the occasion, though silent films with newly composed scores have been popular too, as have quirky productions like the Godfrey Reggio dialogue-free “Qatsi” trilogy, with its through-composed scores by Philip Glass.

headline: Fighting Backlog in Patents, Senate Approves Overhaul
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate approved a sweeping reform of the nation’s patent laws on Thursday, sending to President Obama a bill that changes the system for determining priority for inventions at the patent office and provides more financing for an agency beset by application backlogs and outdated computer systems.

headline: From a Gaffe, Some Good for Little Sisters of the Poor
text: OREGON, Ohio — For at least a half-century, “Little Sisters of the Poor” has been used as a euphemism in college sports to describe a weak opponent. Its roots trace back to an emphatic victory by Senator Robert Taft of Ohio in his 1950 re-election, which the mayor of Cleveland compared to the “Notre Dame football team beating the Little Sisters of the Poor.”

headline: At Clinic for Young Players, Graf Emphasizes the Fun
text: At the Harlem Tennis Center, the Hall of Fame tennis player Steffi Graf was trading shots Thursday morning with a scrawny boy using a scaled-down racket. They were playing on the backcourt of a regulation-size court, with a net stretched from the service line to the baseline, and using oversize foam balls.

headline: Part of a Whole, but Still Me
text: I BECAME a feminist the day my sixth-grade math teacher dismembered and spit on a white rose, telling us, “This is you after you have sex.” Other girls had other interests; horseback riding and ballet were two trendy ones in the Mississippi neighborhood where I attended elementary school. I did try ballet, and stuck with it for a while, but I barely had room in my duffel bag for pointe shoes and feminist texts.

headline: A Tumultuous Time, Captured by Outsiders
text: “The Black Power Mixtape 1967-1975,” among other things an extraordinary feat of editing and archival research, takes up a familiar period in American history from a fresh and fascinating angle. In the late 1960s and early ’70s, Swedish television journalists traveled to the United States with the intention of “showing the country as it really is.” Some of the images and interviews they collected have been assembled by Goran Hugo Olsson into a roughly chronological collage that restores a complex human dimension to the racial history of the era.

headline: Tracking the Global Food Situation
text: The latest numbers suggest that the situation with the global food supply continues to be deeply worrisome.

headline: A Master’s Thin Skin, Etched for Posterity
text: The artist Jean Auguste Dominique Ingres was famous for reacting, and overreacting, to criticism. As a young student in Rome, he broke off an engagement to his longtime love in Paris because he couldn’t stomach a return to the salons there, “the scene of my disgrace,” he said. And later, in midcareer, the bad press from another salon outing prompted a second extended stay in Rome.

headline: John Jay’s New Building
text: The enormous new building of the John Jay College of Criminal Justice was opened for the first time on Sept. 8 for a 9/11 memorial service.

headline: ‘The Arrogant Years’
text: The Avenger of Sixty-Sixth Street

headline: At Obama Jobs Speech, Small Business Is in Audience
text: Whenever a president addresses Congress, the White House invites a panel of Americans, distinguished and not, to watch the speech with the first lady from prime seats in the gallery above. The guests tend to be demographically diverse, but they also tend to be united in representing priorities the president intends to emphasize in the speech.

headline: G.I. Killed Afghan Journalist, NATO Says
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — NATO acknowledged Thursday that an American soldier killed an Afghan journalist working for the BBC after mistaking him for a suicide bomber during a complex attack in southern Afghanistan in July.

headline: F.D.A. Panel Endorses New Blood Thinner Drug
text: A Food and Drug Administration advisory panel voted 9 to 2 on Thursday to endorse a new anticoagulant drug, Xarelto, to help prevent strokes in people with atrial fibrillation.

headline: Poll: Now vs. 5 Years Ago
text: New York Times/CBS News polls describe a city and a nation that have not fully recovered.

headline: Feeling Safer but Wary
text: GRAPHIC: New York and America: Now vs. 5 Years Ago »

headline: How the Three Surveys Were Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News polling project consists of three telephone surveys: of the United States, of New York City, and of friends and relatives of 9/11 victims.

headline: After Conquest, Subtle Emblems of Protest
text: It’s hard to see, when you walk into the Chinese painting galleries at the Met these days, that you’re entering a scene of catastrophe, with lives about to be lost right before your eyes. All seems calm in the show called “The Art of Dissent in 17th-Century China: Masterpieces of Ming Loyalist Art from the Chih Lo Lou Collection.” There are no smoking ruins among the bamboo groves in a 17th-century handscroll painting, no anguished cries emerging from columns of calligraphic script.

headline: City Campaign Finance Board Seeks Greater Disclosure From Donors
text: In a move that could affect the 2013 municipal elections, the New York City Campaign Finance Board on Thursday released proposed rules requiring more disclosure of campaign spending by independent groups like unions.

headline: Where Every Second Counts
text: COLUMBIA, Pa. — “What exists everywhere in the universe but occupies no space?” a wall panel asks. “What can be measured — but not seen, heard, smelled, tasted, nor held in our hands? What can be spent, saved, frittered away or killed — but never destroyed?”

headline: Day 1: Off the Runway
text: Scenes from New York Fashion Week on Sept. 8.

headline: Social Media Gears Up for Obama Address
text: While the Republican Party will not deliver a formal response to President Obama’s job speech on Thursday, some members of Congress and Republican presidential candidates will be turning to Twitter to get their message across.

headline: Democrats Seek to Impose Tougher Supreme Court Ethics
text: House Democrats, seeking to capitalize on recent questions about the political leanings of several Supreme Court justices, are pushing for toughened ethics standards that would hold the justices on the high court to the same judicial requirements as federal judges.
