headline: Weekend Miser
text: They say you don’t get many second chances in this life, but not so, according to the  FringeNYC Encore Series. Beginning on Friday, you can catch some of the most popular shows that were performed at this summer’s New York International Fringe Festival. These include the Telly Savalas-inspired lounge act, “Who Loves You Baby?,” starring Tom DiMenna as a ranting Savalas who is disappointed by this decade’s leading men; “facebook me,” the Arts Effect Theater Company’s look at what status really means to the six million adolescent girls trolling Facebook these days; and “Jersey Shoresical,” a musical based on the reality television show “Jersey Shore” and a FringeNYC Excellence Award winner for best ensemble. Those and other productions will play in repertory at the SoHo Playhouse and the Players Theater through Sept. 26. ($18; 866-468-7619, FringeNYC-EncoreSeries.com.)

headline: Georgia’s Voter Law: The Election Chief’s Rebuttal
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Clybourne Park’ Eyes Broadway
text: “Clybourne Park,” Bruce Norris’s Pulitzer Prize-winning play about race relations and neighborhood gentrification, is looking for its own real estate on Broadway.

headline: Three Times the Effort, but Not the Cost
text: SEVEN years ago Lucy Danziger, the editor in chief of Self magazine, was looking for a way to get excited about exercise again. She had been running almost daily for years, but a marathon had left her with painful shin splints, and she was tiring of her routine.

headline: Wozniacki Defeats Petkovic
text: W.T.A. No. 1 Caroline Wozniacki made her third consecutive U.S. Open semifinal with an impressive 6-1, 7-6(5) win over No. 10 Andrea Petkovic.

headline: Popular Ascendance to Grim Downfall
text: It’s impossible that “The Autobiography of Nicolae Ceausescu” is the monument that the former Romanian dictator would have produced in his own honor. Among other things, it has an unhappy ending, at least for him and his wife, Elena, who were executed on Christmas Day, 1989. Yet in many respects Ceausescu turns out to be as much the author of this brilliant documentary as the director, Andrei Ujica, who waded through more than 1,000 hours of filmed state propaganda, official news reports and home movies to create a cinematic tour de force that tracks the rise, reign and grim fall of its subject.

headline: Transcript: Obama’s Speech to Congress on Jobs
text: The following is a transcript of President Obama’s speech to a joint session of Congress about jobs and the economy, as provided by the White House.

headline: F.C.C. Chairman Counsels Students to Be Moderate With Digital Media
text: Julius Genachowski, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, welcomed students back to school on Thursday by asking them to walk a line: use technology to learn, but don’t get distracted by it.

headline: Pants on Fire
text: Fifteen years ago, “Primary Colors” meant politics, in the form of the novel written anonymously by Joe Klein.

headline: Bloggingheads: Monogamy and Morals
text: Dan Savage, left, of Savage Love and Ross Douthat, Op-Ed columnist for The New York Times, debate the morality of non-monogamous marriages.

headline: U.S. Ambassador to Syria Responds to Critics on Facebook
text: Two days after he attacked the Syrian government’s violent response to peaceful protests in a blunt note posted on Facebook, Robert Ford, the American ambassador in Damascus, returned to the social network on Thursday to spar with some of his critics.

headline: Fear and Loathing at Parker Prep
text: “Beware the Gonzo” is “Revenge of the Nerds” redux, but instead of a college, its setting is Parker Prep, a private New York City high school celebrating its 150th anniversary. Leading the student uprising against a vile clique of alpha teenagers and their smug enabler, Principal Roy (James Urbaniak), is Eddie Gilman (Ezra Miller), a self-righteous hotshot reporter for the school newspaper who is waiting to hear if he has been accepted to Columbia.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 1’s Toughest Picks
text: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

headline: Palestinian Leader Says U.S. Is ‘Too Late’ on U.N. Bid
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, said Thursday that last-ditch American and international efforts to prevent the Palestinians from applying for membership in the United Nations this month were “too late.”

headline: Senator Introduces Online Security Bill
text: Senator Richard Blumenthal, Democrat of Connecticut, introduced a new bill Thursday that aims to protect citizens’ personal information from online data breaches. The bill would also punish companies that are careless with customers’ information.

headline: Merrill Lynch Cuts Several Hundred Jobs
text: Following a pattern that is expected to be repeated across Wall Street in the coming months, Bank of America Merrill Lynch began handing out pink slips to several hundred employees on Thursday. The job cuts are expected to fall across the entire organization, including sales and trading operations as well as investment banking.

headline: Bloomberg’s ‘Beer Summit’ Idea Antagonizes Many in Council
text: Perhaps it seemed like a conciliatory idea at the time.

headline: With Rainouts, Fans Have to Scramble
text: The decision by the U.S.T.A. to rework the schedule and finish the U.S. Open on Monday has created all sorts of headaches for fans.

headline: Obama’s Speech to Congress
text: The president spoke to a joint session of Congress.

headline: When Quoting Verse, One Must Be Terse
text: COPYRIGHT law is so often a matter of guesswork and loopholes, small print and obscure provisions. One such provision, dating from the ’70s, has recently come to the music industry’s attention. “Termination rights” allow musicians to reclaim the copyrights on their songs after 35 years — meaning songs from albums like Funkadelic’s “One Nation Under a Groove” may soon be back in the hands of George Clinton and his funkified compatriots. Late last month, Representative John Conyers Jr. of Michigan, the senior Democrat on the House Judiciary Committee, called on Congress to clarify the statute in question in order to protect artists’ rights.

headline: Does America Have a Future?
text: Failure after failure after failure. Bubbles that end in busts. Wars that aren’t won. Stimuli that don’t stimulate. All together plunging the United States into the worst economic slump since the 1930s. Meanwhile, across the Pacific, America faces a geopolitical rival that is also an effective economic competitor — a combination not seen since the kaiser’s Germany.

headline: When He Was Good, He Was Very, Very Good
text: One evening in the summer of 1972, John Chancellor of NBC began his newscast with a rundown of the day’s reports. War, economic turmoil, the growing Watergate scandal — all of that would be dealt with in due course. “But first,” Chancellor said, “Bobby Fischer.”

headline: Manning Sidelined by Another Operation
text: Peyton Manning had his second neck operation since late May on Thursday, casting his availability for the season in considerable doubt.

headline: Where Stone Waits to Become Works of Art
text: The snide “No Rock Climbing” sign in the basement of the Compleat Sculptor makes it clear that the 300 tons of marble, alabaster, granite and soapstone there are not meant for rappelling; they await a finer destiny wrought by human hands wielding sharp tools.

headline: In a City’s Plague Years, Caring for Their Own
text: “There was nothing extraordinary about the fact that you lose the people you love because it’s going to happen to all of us,” observes Ed Wolf, a gentle, gay San Franciscan in his mid-50s who devoted years to counseling dying AIDS patients during the peak of the epidemic. “It’s just that it happened in this targeted community of people who were disenfranchised and separated from their families. And a whole group of other people stepped up and became their family.”

headline: A Christie’s Loss Is the Kimbell’s Gain
text: By all accounts, Nicolas Poussin’s “Sacrament of Ordination (Christ Presenting the Keys to Saint Peter)” should have been a winner. Executed between 1636 and 1642, the painting is part of the artist’s groundbreaking series depicting the seven sacraments. It is in perfect condition and has a pristine provenance. So why was there not a single bidder interested in the painting at a Christie’s auction in London last December?

headline: Getting a Little ‘Lost’ in a Secluded Spot on the Coastline
text: The day was turning golden at El Matador State Beach here on the Pacific as the end of the afternoon approached. Matador is a secluded stretch of rock formations, beach and tide pools, with views miles down the coast. It’s not easy to reach: take the steep and rutted path off a dirt parking lot along the Pacific Coast Highway that leads to 80 precarious steps finally spilling out onto soft sand.

headline: U.S. Is Urged to Plan to Aid Cuba in Case of an Oil Spill
text: HAVANA — The United States should urgently make plans for helping Cuba in the event of an offshore oil spill as it prepares to begin exploring fields opposite Florida this year, William Reilly, the co-chairman of a commission that examined the Deepwater Horizon spill, said during a visit here.

headline: The Lingering Injustice of Attica
text: Philadelphia

headline: For Mets, Few Fans and a Pair of Losses
text: The Atlanta Braves’ one-day, two-game visit to Citi Field on Thursday had a distinct coulda-woulda-shoulda aspect to it. Maybe, just maybe, these games could have had legitimate implications for the National League wild-card race.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,466 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,744 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Russian President Warns Against Xenophobia
text: YAROSLAVL, Russia — In one of the last major addresses of his presidential term, President Dmitri A. Medvedev on warned Thursday against allowing xenophobia into Russia’s political mainstream.

headline: Open Skies, Bouncing Balls, Tough Critiques
text: Don’t let the obstacles beat you. It’s always been that way at the United States Open, from the stench of burning meat wafting across the court to the rumble of garbage bins to the rattle of the railroad train, to say nothing of the weather.

headline: U.S. Is Investigating Wages Among Residential Builders
text: The federal government’s top wage enforcement official said on Thursday that the Labor Department had begun a far-reaching investigation into possible minimum wage and overtime violations in the residential construction industry.

headline: The Now-or-Never Apartment
text: AT last, Lee Zegar was ready to upgrade to a one-bedroom.

headline: A Persistent Puddle, a Determined Roddick
text: It was the perfect metaphor for the sodden 2011 United States Open.

headline: Romney and Perry Assume Contrasting Republican Brands
text: The full-throated sparring between Mitt Romney and Rick Perry during the Republican debate on Wednesday night provided an early glimpse of the very different strategies that will propel their presidential campaigns forward in the next several months.

headline: Q & A
text: A Regulated Tenant Can’t Find the Lease

headline: Investigators Assess Threat of Bombing Tied to 9/11
text: WASHINGTON — Counterterrorism officials on Thursday were assessing a report about the threat of an attack in New York City or Washington using a car or truck bomb and timed to the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, according to several officials briefed on the matter.

headline: Stall in Realignment Process Gives Big 12 Hope
text: Conference realignment, which once appeared to be an inevitability, has reached a holding pattern. The threat of legal action by Baylor and other Big 12 universities has stymied Texas A&M’s move to the Southeastern Conference, reviving the chance that the Big 12 can save itself.

headline: New-Form Press Release, in Blog, Tweet and Haiku
text: Press releases were created to break news, not make it.

headline: How Flooding Hurts Home Values
text: AFTER the shrewd and wary real estate blogger known as Grim (real name: James A. Bednar of njrereport.com) bought his first house in Wayne last spring, he quickly announced where he would start with renovations: the damp basement.

headline: The Even Longer Road to ‘Sold’
text: ERIC FRIEDLANDER of Oyster Bay, the owner of the Windemere Development Corporation, used to build subdivisions and single-family homes from Southampton to Smithtown and Bellmore, sometimes on speculation.

headline: College Football Live Blog: Join the Conversation
text: Paul Myerberg of The Times will be hosting his own college football watch party all day Saturday, right here at The Quad. He will bring you highlights and analysis from games around the country and spend some time answering your questions.

headline: N.B.A. Talks Show Hints of Progress
text: When N.B.A. labor talks resumed Wednesday, for an extended session in Midtown Manhattan, officials from the players union opened with a broad premise: Tell us what it will take to end the lockout and save the 2011-12 season.

headline: Renting Is All the Rage
text: BROKERS these days, wrestling with dwindling sales, would have their clients believe that there is no better time than the present to buy a home. Prices are down, they say, and mortgage rates are at all-time lows.

headline: In Italy, the Old Lady Opens a New Stadium
text: 12:37 p.m. |Update

headline: Iraq: Radio Host Is Killed Before Protest
text: A radio talk show host who had been a prominent government critic was killed by gunmen in his home on Thursday, a security official said. The host, Hadi al-Mahdi, had organized protests, including one planned for Friday,  to call for more government accountability and better services. In a posting on Facebook just three hours before he was killed, he said that he had received threatening messages from people trying to deter him from holding the protest. He said the demonstration would go on. “I firmly believe the political process is a trash can of economic and political failure and we deserve to have it changed and we deserve a better government,” he wrote.

headline: Quinn Hires Pollster Tied to President for 2013 Race
text: Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, has added a big political name to her campaign team as she prepares for an expected mayoral bid in 2013: Joel Benenson, the pollster for President Obama and, until recently, for Anthony D. Weiner.

headline: Omitting Clergy at 9/11 Ceremony Prompts Protest
text: The second Sunday after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, New York clergy members of many faiths joined elected officials at Yankee Stadium in a city-sponsored memorial ceremony that melded the sacred and the secular, replete with flags, prayers and tears.

headline: Deciding What’s Next After Deadly Crash
text: Russian hockey officials said Thursday that they were struggling to deal with a contingency they had yet to develop a plan for, if a plan could ever really be developed to replace an entire team wiped out in a tragedy.

headline: Barbour Joins Rove-Affiliated Super PAC
text: Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi is joining American Crossroads, the influential Republican Super PAC, to help the group raise money during the 2012 election, the group announced on Thursday.

headline: A Story as Old as Gentrification
text: This film has been designated as a Critics' Pick.

headline: Lawmaker Offers Plan to Lure Migrant Farm Workers
text: A leading Republican lawmaker has proposed creating a program to bring 500,000 foreign migrant farm workers to the United States each year, responding to an outcry this summer from American farmers who said shortages of legally authorized labor were imperiling their crops.

headline: Beyond Baby Mozart, Students Who Rock
text: With school underway, I asked my eight-year-old son this week if he had any interest in learning guitar. He said he’d prefer the piano. I was pleased, but hesitant. I had my own stint with after-school piano lessons at age eight — plinking out notes from classical pieces that were foreign to me. My progress was agonizingly slow and I gave up within months.

headline: Union Dispute, Turning Violent, Spreads and Idles Ports
text: The busy ports of Seattle and Tacoma, Wash., were shut down on Thursday as an increasingly violent dispute between unionized port workers and the owner of a grain export terminal in Longview, Wash., spilled over to the other facilities.

headline: The Jobs Speech
text: With more than 14 million people out of work and all Americans fearing a double-dip recession, President Obama stood face to face Thursday night with a Congress that has perversely resisted lifting a finger to help. Some Republicans refused to even sit and listen. But those Americans who did heard him unveil an ambitious proposal — more robust and far-reaching than expected — that may be the first crucial step in reigniting the economy.

headline: For Obama, a ‘Moment’ Speech at a Time of Great Obstacles to Change
text: Enshrined in the mythology of the American presidency, there is something called a moment speech, an address to the nation so forceful and eloquent that it changes the way the country feels about its leadership and even itself.

headline: There’s Something Odd About This Hospital
text: “This is not a movie,” a bogus producer insists at the beginning of the mockumentary “Grave Encounters,” the latest found-footage scam and the directing debut of Colin Minihan and Stuart Ortiz, otherwise known as the Vicious Brothers. By the time this derivative clunker sputters to a close, many in the audience may find themselves agreeing with him.

headline: China’s Flawed Inflation Figures
text: When China reports this week that the consumer price index rose at an annualized rate of about 6 percent in August, economists may say inflation has peaked. They said the same last year, when the C.P.I. was running half as fast. The problem isn’t bad forecasting: China’s headline inflation measure is flawed.

headline: Setting Their Hair on Fire
text: First things first: I was favorably surprised by the new Obama jobs plan, which is significantly bolder and better than I expected. It’s not nearly as bold as the plan I’d want in an ideal world. But if it actually became law, it would probably make a significant dent in unemployment.

headline: Obama Presents Jobs Plan
text: President Obama challenged lawmakers in a blunt address Thursday evening to enact a sweeping package of tax cuts and new spending designed to revive the stagnant job market.

headline: Somali Terrorism Suspect Appears in Civilian Court
text: A Somali accused of supporting Al Qaeda made his first public court appearance in New York on Thursday, a prelude to a highly anticipated international terrorism trial in civilian court.

headline: On the First Day of School, a Million Students Finding Their Seats
text: The rain cleared, and the sidewalks of New York filled with all the familiar sights and sounds: the Cinderella backpacks, the complaints about school uniforms, the comparing of schedules, the shrieks and giggles. As 1.1 million students and 77,000 teachers returned to school Thursday, Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott made the traditional five-borough tour, saying his “goal is to set a high bar for our parents, our teachers, to aspire to.”

headline: Clouds Part, Revealing Close Quarters and Short Fuses
text: On Thursday, the sun returned to Flushing Meadows, and the beleaguered United States Open resumed play. The chaos, though, continued, even worsened, as this tournament, marred by delays and marked by player discontent, plowed forward through the muck, eventually shifting the schedule into a third week. Again.

headline: Judge Widens Antitrust Suit Against Private Equity Firms
text: A federal judge has greatly expanded the scope of an antitrust lawsuit against the world’s largest private equity firms, broadening the case to include some of the largest leveraged buyouts in history.

headline: No Plot, No Story, No Kicks: Want to Back My Movie?
text: The career of the actor Dax Shepard hasn’t skyrocketed, but neither has it sputtered: a regular on the NBC sitcom “Parenthood,” he supported Jessica Simpson and Dane Cook in “Employee of the Month“ and probably enjoyed his finest hour as Amy Poehler’s clueless boyfriend in “Baby Mama.” “Brother’s Justice,” his flailing, ultralow-budget directorial debut, will not accelerate his professional trajectory.

headline: General Frémont’s ‘She-Merrimac’
Lottery Numbers
From Prison to Pickles
text: If Paul Levesque, the professional wrestler better known as Triple H, hopes to follow the career path of, say, Dwayne Johnson, who is now a credible action-adventure leading man, he’s going to need movies a lot better than “Inside Out” to do it.

headline: Despite Talk of Taming Partisanship, a Show of It for President’s Remarks
text: WASHINGTON — It was, for a moment, Bizzaro World, with Republicans giving the president of the United States a standing ovation, while Democrats, in large part, remained firmly fixed in their seats as he expressed his desire for new trade agreements.

headline: A Diamond Maker Joins Hearst to Show Power of Print and Dazzle
text: IN the current economy, some can afford to buy diamonds and some might need a little help to do so. A new advertising campaign by Hearts On Fire, the Boston-based diamond company, hopes to have something for all types of buyers.

headline: For Abkhazia, Recognition Is Coming Piece by Piece
text: SUKHUMI, Georgia — After nearly two decades of searching mostly in vain for international acceptance, Abkhazia, a tiny rebel region in the former Soviet republic of Georgia, has found an unusual ally.

headline: Rich Girls Have All Kind of Drama
text: “Tanner Hall,” an uneven drama set at a girls’ boarding school, rarely rises above the generic, though its atmosphere of coddled young people indulging themselves in opulent surroundings is palpably authentic. Fernanda (Rooney Mara), an otherwise sensible senior, pursues the older Gio (Tom Everett Scott), a family friend who has impregnated his sometime girlfriend (Tara Subkoff); the British Victoria (Georgia King), a neglected daughter, seeks to thwart Fernanda’s fortunes; the tomboyish Lucasta (Amy Ferguson) is ambivalent toward a boy’s overtures; and Kate (Brie Larson) flirts with a teacher (Chris Kattan), disregarding potential consequences.

headline: President Obama Addresses Congress
text: The President challenged lawmakers in a blunt address Thursday evening to enact a sweeping package of tax cuts and new spending designed to revive the stagnant job market. (Video: NBC)

headline: Stimulus for Skeptics
text: A few years ago, Kenneth Rogoff and Carmen M. Reinhart wrote the definitive guide to the current economic downturn, a book called “This Time Is Different.” Rogoff and Reinhart studied data from eight centuries of financial crises. They found that banking-crisis recessions are worse than normal recessions. They last longer.

headline: In Shift, Iran’s President Calls for End to Syrian Crackdown
text: For years, posters celebrating the decades-old alliance joining Syria and Iran festooned the streets and automobiles of the Syrian capital — the images of Presidents Bashar al-Assad and Mahmoud Ahmadinejad embroidered with roses and daffodils.

headline: Welcome, Madamji
text: She’s back. At least, we think she is.

headline: In Last Push, Rivals in House Race Try to Provoke a Blunder
text: With just days remaining before the special election on Tuesday to replace former Representative Anthony D. Weiner, the two major-party nominees on Thursday sought to trip each other up at their only widely televised debate, while national Democratic groups bought expensive television time in a last-ditch effort to buoy their candidate.

headline: Settlement Said to Be Near for Fannie and Freddie
text: Regulators are nearing a settlement with Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac over whether the mortgage finance giants adequately disclosed their exposure to risky subprime loans, bringing to a close a three-year investigation.

headline: Friday: Be Unable to Get the Rest
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Joe Krozel seems to be on a quest to set crossword-constructing records and he nearly makes it today. With a wide open grid and eleven 15-letter entries, Mr. Krozel misses the record set by David Levinson Wilk in 2009 with his twelve 15s (Across Lite, Solution, blog) by a square. See what I did there? Mr. Krozel’s grid also has one more black square than Mr. Wilk’s does. Don’t try this at home.

headline: A Bipartisan Move to Tackle Benefits Programs
text: WASHINGTON — In a significant shift driven by bipartisan concern about the looming long-term debt, Republicans and Democrats are no longer fighting over whether to tackle the popular entitlement programs — Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security — but over how to do it.

headline: Lost in the Fog
text: As they debated at the Reagan library Wednesday night, the Republican presidential candidates seemed lost in a separate, frivolous galaxy from the sobering economic reality that President Obama was trying to confront. A public desperate for ideas about economic revival heard an astonishing argument about whether Social Security is a hoax, along with a fight about which states were more effective in luring low-wage jobs from other states.

headline: A Scion of Queens Democrats Vies for a House Seat
text: David I. Weprin still remembers the moment he realized his family was just a little different from other families in Queens.

headline: Finding Romance in All Kinds of Places
text: Just when America’s trade balance needs all the help it can get from Hollywood’s global entertainment dominance comes the latest challenge to its supremacy: a China that can make chick flicks.

headline: Shifting the Schedule, Paying a Price
text: When Rafael Nadal muttered on Wednesday that “it’s always about money,” he mostly had it right.

headline: Damage From Brain Stents
text: Americans eager to try the newest cures and willing to trust their doctors’ judgment might have second thoughts about seeking experimental treatments given the disturbing results of a clinical trial of a new brain procedure. The trial involved inserting wire mesh stents into the brain arteries of patients at high risk of a second stroke. The stents were supposed to keep the arteries open, but the patients suffered strokes and died at such an alarming rate that the trial had to be stopped.

headline: Search for the Searchers
text: This summer, a team of Canadian archaeologists went searching for the remains of the Arctic expedition led by Sir John Franklin, which vanished somewhere northwest of Baffin Island in 1845. People have been looking for Franklin, on and off, ever since. This time the scientists were scouring the sea bottom for Franklin’s ships, the Erebus and the Terror. Last year, the same team discovered the sunken remains of a ship that was searching for Franklin in 1854.

headline: Michael Hart, a Pioneer of E-Books, Dies at 64
text: Michael Hart, who was widely credited with creating the first e-book when he typed the Declaration of Independence into a computer on July 4, 1971, and in so doing laid the foundations for Project Gutenberg, the oldest and largest digital library, was found dead on Tuesday at his home in Urbana, Ill. He was 64.

headline: Killer of Denise Gay, an Innocent Bystander, Is Still a Mystery
text: It was barely four hours after the gunfire stopped on Park Place in Brooklyn when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg appeared at a hospital to announce what officials believed had happened: one of two criminals involved in a gun battle killed an innocent woman as she sat on her stoop; one of those men exchanged shots with the police; one of the gunmen died at the scene, and the other died shortly afterward.

headline: Tom Brokaw: ‘Unknowable Future’
text: A decade after 9/11, Tom Brokaw reflects on his Op-Ed from Sept. 28, 2001, and the need for the whole country to share some of the sacrifices made by military families.

headline: Kevin Hart Is On the Road
text: Some of Kevin Hart’s fans may be disappointed that “Laugh at My Pain,” a film version of his recent stand-up tour, offers less than an hour of Mr. Hart onstage. But a couple of adornments — one before the concert footage, one after — flesh out this funny, profanity-heavy movie nicely.

headline: Court Rejects Restitution for Victim in Porn Case
text: A victim of child pornography seeking restitution should not receive court-ordered payments from those who possessed the images but had no hand in creating them, a federal appeals panel ruled Thursday. The young woman, referred to in court papers as Amy, was known as “Misty” in pornographic images created by her uncle. The uncle was convicted and imprisoned on child pornography charges, but the images continue to be widely circulated and downloaded.

headline: Before a First Start, a Football for a Friend in Iraq
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Jake Ballard cornered Justin Tuck outside a meeting room at the Giants’ training center here earlier this week. Ballard had a football with one panel whited out, the kind designed for autographs, and he asked if Tuck wouldn’t mind giving a signature. Tuck took the ball and uncapped his pen, but hesitated when he saw that the only other signature on the ball was Eli Manning’s.

headline: Easy Money From Body Parts
text: When an American director uses a bunch of well-known English actors to tell a Scottish tale centered on two Irish immigrants, you might expect some inconsistencies of tone and accent, and you get them in “Burke & Hare,” so nitpickers beware. But those who care less about such stuff than about being entertained will find plenty to like in this ghoulish comedy, a droll take on one of the most notorious mass-murder cases of the 19th century.

headline: Illinois: Students Lose E-Mails to Prosecutors
text: Hundreds of e-mails between Northwestern University students and a former journalism professor must be turned over to prosecutors in a closely watched case, a Chicago judge ruled Wednesday. The students, working with the college’s Medill Innocence Project, were investigating the case of Anthony McKinney, a man convicted of the 1978 murder of a security guard. The state’s attorney subpoenaed the students’ notes, e-mails and other materials in 2009, but the university argued that many of the materials were protected by the state reporter’s privilege law. Judge Diane Cannon ruled that the students actually acted as investigators for Mr. McKinney’s lawyers and not as journalists. The professor, David Protess, who has left Northwestern, said he was disappointed with the decision.

headline: Vegetable Gardens Are Booming in a Fallow Economy
text: WEST LIBERTY, Ky. — As the economy continues to stagnate in towns and cities across the country, here in eastern Kentucky it is causing things to sprout.

headline: 1.4 Million Lose Electricity in Area Around San Diego
text: LOS ANGELES — A power failure swept through Southern California on Thursday afternoon, leaving more than a million people without electricity in an area that extended from the coast east to Arizona and south into Mexico.

headline: Green Shoots in Eastern Kentucky
text: As the economy continues to stagnate in towns and cities across the country, in eastern Kentucky garden plots are dug into the green hills.

headline: Fashion Week: @whatdidIjustsee
text: Maybe a year ago — or was it longer? — Prabal Gurung answered Demi Moore’s Twitter post with his own. Until then, Mr. Gurung, an up-and-coming designer who started his company two years ago, had been on the Twitter fence. He really didn’t know what it was and, as he said, “it seemed too much about yourself.” But after replying to Ms. Moore, he quickly got 500 followers. Today he has 32,604 followers, and as he calculated the payoff from the social media network, says, “It’s a business.” It has helped him build his brand.

headline: A Tax Deal in California Is Bipartisan
text: LOS ANGELES — Gov. Jerry Brown of California announced a rare bipartisan agreement with legislative leaders Thursday, eliminating a tax loophole for out-of-state businesses that opponents said encouraged moving jobs out of the state. The deal will allow the state to lower personal income taxes and provide more incentives to small companies based in the state.

headline: Life’s Intersections, Random Twists of Fate
text: “The High Cost of Living,” a somber morality tale set in Quebec, bears all the hallmarks of an uncompromising indie drama: a downbeat scenario, flawed protagonists, a strongly regional inflection. This debut feature by the Canadian director Deborah Chow is so artistically well-intentioned and earnest in its ambitions that you can almost forgive the banality of its every scene.

headline: S.E.C. Asks Court to Force a Release of Papers From China
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission asked a federal court on Thursday to force a Chinese affiliate of Deloitte, the accounting giant, to produce documents related to an investigation into one of its former auditing clients, Longtop Financial Technologies.

headline: Buddha Stars in a Kung-Fu Flick
text: Sadistic warlords square off against noble monks in “Shaolin,” Benny Chan’s satisfying kung-fu action-and-redemption film starring Andy Lau. If the movie feels old-school (with new-school production values), consider its pedigree. It’s no wonder: “Shaolin” is a reimagining of the 1982 “Shaolin Temple,” in which Jet Li made his debut.

headline: Taking Up Swords and Arias in Prenationalist China
text: The North-South power divide of prenationalist China provides the hazy historical backdrop for “My Kingdom,” an intermittently kinetic epic about rival “opera warrior” clans. Though its reverence for Peking Opera gives the film a thinly heritage sheen, its generic mix of backstage musical and swordplay spectacular is vintage discount bin.

headline: For High School Team, a Loss That Goes Beyond Any Game
text: LINWOOD, N.J. — The pursuit of normalcy was momentarily derailed by a simple, understandable mistake.

headline: The Bachmann Response
text: Apparently Representative Michele Bachmann did not get the memo from House Republican leaders advising them to seek some common ground in responding to President Obama’s proposed $447 billion package of new spending and tax cuts.

headline: Grist for Left and Right in Perry Immigration Record
text: Ann Coulter, the conservative pundit, has called Gov. Rick Perry “a little bit too much like George Bush” on immigration — and she does not mean it as a compliment. Tea Party loyalists have decried Mr. Perry’s opposition to a border fence and Arizona-style enforcement laws. And Mitt Romney has taken not-so-veiled jabs at Mr. Perry, criticizing officials who provide “incentives that promote illegal immigration.”

headline: For María and José, All Work and No Play
text: No one eats free, but children eat least of all in “The Inheritors,” Eugenio Polgovsky’s unvarnished portrait of the rural poor in modern-day Mexico.

headline: Stoudemire and Designer Team Up on Fashion Line

headline: A Hockey Enforcer Has His (Dark) Day
text: TORONTO — Hockey fans, and you know who you are, you will not be the first to see “The Last Gladiators,” Alex Gibney’s latest documentary, about the busted-up world of hockey “enforcers.” Some 100 movie fans beat you to it, at a Thursday-afternoon press and industry screening here at the Toronto International Film Festival.

headline: Strung Together
text: The one rivalry that I thought you missed was Big Bill (Tilden) versus Little Bill (Johnston). After losing the finals of the U.S. Championships in 1919 to Johnston, Tilden realized that he would never beat him until he found an answer to Johnston’s forehand drive to his own slice backhand. Tilden took the entire winter off to develop a backhand that he could hit flat, with top spin or with slice. Many consider it the finest stroke in tennis history. In 1920 he defeated Johnston in five sets in the U.S. Championships and never lost another important match to him. I often wonder why today’s pros don’t do the same thing. It’s pretty clear that Djokovic has come up with a stylistic advantage over Nadal (similar to what Nadal has over Federer). It is a cliché to say that the mental part of the game determines rivalries when style of play is significantly more important. Looking back over the past 10 years of men’s tennis, you have to wonder: if Andy Roddick had been willing to make the changes to his game to beat Federer, would we be talking about the great Roddick-Federer rivalry?

headline: Manufacturing
text: Reading Jon Gertner’s article reminded me of industrial-policy talks I participated in as a State Department official in the mid-’80s between U.S. and Japanese officials. We aired our complaints about their aid to business; the Japanese responded that we also backed industry with R&D tax credits and Darpa subsidies, among many programs. At the conclusion of our meetings, the head of the Japanese delegation aptly summed up as follows: “We in Japan have an industrial policy and won’t admit it; you have an industrial policy and don’t know it.”

headline: The Losing Ticket
text: Many state lotteries (some of which have hired me as a consultant) continue to sell scratch-off lottery tickets regardless of whether the winning tickets have already been claimed. Some states print a disclaimer stating that some prizes may not be available sometime after the tickets have been issued. But even so, is a state within its ethical purview to continue selling those tickets on the false premise that a $1 million payout is attainable? STANLEY I. COHEN, GLEN ROCK, N.J.

headline: Untying the Knot in Japan
text: On a Saturday night in Tokyo’s Asakusa district, a woman in a floral kimono and a man in a boxy dark suit silently waited side by side. First, one black rickshaw pulled up to them. Moments later, another cart arrived. With a small nod to each other, the couple moved to board their separate chariots en route to the night’s main event: their divorce ceremony.

headline: Asking Candidates About Their Faith
text: I agree with Bill Keller that we must overcome our squeamishness about asking candidates how spiritual beliefs would inform their governance. I too remember the controversy surrounding John Kennedy, then a candidate, and his Catholicism. Today this attitude seems antiquated, ridiculous. But had he sought the pope’s endorsement or sponsored a prayer rally hosted by Catholic bishops, it would have been a different matter. Who knows whether Rick Perry believes the radical ideas of the leaders featured in the Response rally. The fact that he chose representatives from movements that are antigay, anti-Muslim, anti-Buddhist, antichoice, who believe that foreign policy toward Israel and the Middle East should be determined by religious beliefs, is troubling. Would these ideas affect his political decisions? Would he appoint people with such beliefs to his administration? Voters need to know before they cast ballots.

headline: In New Sitcoms, Parents Need the Growing Up
text: When I was 33 and single, I moved in next door to a family who threw big parties throughout the summer. There seemed to be an inflatable jumpy castle in their front yard almost every weekend: an enormous, unsightly purple or red or orange blob that would quiver and wobble as little kids and big kids shrieked and giggled and barely missed injuring one another inside. I tried to ignore it, but the thing was just a few feet from my bedroom window, and the racket would go on way past a reasonable hour. Screaming, laughter, sobbing; the jumpy castle boiled life down to its essential elements. And every now and then, one of the smaller kids would roll right out onto the grass, like a baby tumbling out of a gigantic, shaking womb.

headline: A Failure of Happiness
text: We met one cold day on Columbia University’s indoor track, weeks before the 1992 New York Marathon. My workout called for 10 miles, or 100 laps, a lonely affair until a lean, chipper young grad student pulled alongside me. With his booming voice, he announced that he was studying philosophy because philosophers were the only people who could change the world.

headline: Chances Are Good for a Tangent

His best-known characters — the sidewalk-pounding heroine of “Run Lola Run,” the globe-trotting Interpol agent of “The International” — are perpetual-motion machines. His pinballing plots take shape as intricate series of actions and reactions: stories as demonstrations of chaos theory.

text: AMERICAN filmgoers may not know what a “granito” is, but Pamela Yates’s new documentary of that name comes with a subtitle whose meaning could not be clearer: “How to Nail a Dictator.” The tyrant in question is Gen. Efraín Ríos Montt, who for 17 bloody months in the early 1980s led a military junta in Guatemala, and the “granitos” are the many human-rights advocates, metaphorical grains of sand who, by working together, have now managed to bring him up on genocide charges in a Spanish court.

headline: The ‘Shut Up’ Guys Find Their Boswell
text: IN the late 1980s, two University of Wisconsin grads living in a run-down building in San Francisco taped the interminable drunken tirades of two next door neighbors, Peter Haskett and Raymond Huffman, initially without the men’s knowledge. The profane poetry of abuse — “I can kill you from a sitting position!”; “You always giggle falsely” — was shared with friends on cassettes, heralded by fanzines, sampled on a radio show, adapted by comic-book artists and distributed on CD under the title “Shut Up, Little Man!,” a reference to Mr. Haskett’s favorite put-down. Artists like Kurt Cobain expressed their appreciation; movie producers plotted deals; and a play about the bickering roommates was produced. But, while their private conflicts were played and replayed, first Mr. Huffman and then Mr. Haskett died, with only Mr. Haskett learning about the fuss near the end.

headline: A Master of Impossible Camera Angles
text: IN Leonard Retel Helmrich’s “Shape of the Moon” (2004) a barefoot man crosses a railroad trestle a thousand feet above an Indonesian valley, stepping briskly along a beam barely wider than his feet. We see him from behind. We see him from above. Most alarming, we see him from the side, by means of a camera that seems mounted in midair. It’s breathtaking, what the subject is doing. But a man with a camera is doing it too.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Kevork Kiledjian
text: “If you look good, you don’t have to try so hard,” said Kevin Ryan backstage at Kevork Kiledjian, a funny declaration from a hairstylist surrounded by assistants and assorted Rsession Tools curling irons and dryers. Still, this was the idea behind the loose, mussed hair for the show. It takes work to look like you’re not trying too hard.

headline: Hearing Rumors of a Plot, Cities Make Their Security Forces Seen
text: WASHINGTON — Bomb-sniffing dogs were deployed in the Washington subway, and the police searched vehicles at the Brooklyn Bridge on Friday as counterterrorism officials with frustratingly imprecise clues hunted for at least two men reportedly dispatched by Al Qaeda to set off a car or truck bomb in New York or Washington.

headline: Directors Adapt to Shooting 3-D With Depth
text: EVEN as Hollywood prepares for an autumn onslaught of 3-D movies from big-name directors (including “Hugo” from Martin Scorsese and “The Adventures of Tintin” from Steven Spielberg), the future of the format remains uncertain. Resentful of premium ticket prices and burned by too many films hastily and unconvincingly converted from 2-D to 3-D, audiences aren’t flocking to stereoscopic films the way they did a year ago. The novelty is fading.

headline: Getting Medieval
text: Emilia Clarke is the nice English girl who plays Daenerys Targaryen in HBO’s hugely successful pork-sword-and-sorcery drama series, “Game of Thrones.” In the show, which is adapted from George R. R. Martin’s equally huge series of cod-medieval fantasy books, “A Song of Ice and Fire,” Daenerys is one of the two remaining children of the ousted Targaryen dynasty, forcibly married, aged 15, to Khal Drogo, another huge thing (played by the 6-foot-4 Hawaiian-born actor Jason Momoa), a warlord of the horse-mad Dothraki people who live beyond the Narrow Sea.

headline: Channel Surfing: ‘Mel Brooks and Dick Cavett Together Again’
text: With a combined total of 159 years on the planet, Mel Brooks and Dick Cavett still have a ways to go to catch the 2,000-Year-Old Man. But they have managed to accumulate some amusing stories nonetheless, which they share in “Mel Brooks and Dick Cavett Together Again,” a pleasant hourlong special Friday night on HBO.

headline: Gonzo Fishing
text: Last weekend’s Look, and a related video in Rachel Nolan’s post below, furnish the perfect occasion to revisit — and recommend strongly — an article that appeared 15 years ago in The Atlantic Monthly: “In the Monster’s Maw,” by Burkhard Bilger. Where we only had room enough to skim over what goes into noodling, or catching catfish barehanded, Bilger was able to dive deep into the thoroughly American (it goes back to the Indians) subculture of using your fingers as fishing lures.

headline: How to Ask a Proper Question at a Public Event
text: You have probably heard it said that there is no such thing as a bad question. That’s not true; of course there is such a thing as a bad question. But the upside of that is that there is such a thing as a good question.

headline: Europe Is Urged to Take Bolder Action on Debt

headline: Op-Ed columnist Thomas L. Friedman, co-author of “That Used to Be Us,” talks about America’s decline; Bill Keller on Christopher Hitchens; best-seller news.
text: This week, Times Op-Ed columnist Thomas L. Friedman, co-author of “That Used to Be Us,” talks about America’s decline and possible recovery; Bill Keller surveys the career of Christopher Hitchens; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: China: Drought Leaves 14 Million Chinese and Farmland Parched
text: A persistent drought in China has left more than 14 million people short of drinking water and damaged large tracts of farmland, according to a report on Friday by Xinhua, the state news agency. The drought is concentrated in the southwest, where 12.6 million people are short of water. The drought began in early July and has caused reservoirs and rivers to dry up. The areas hardest hit are Yunnan and Guizhou Provinces, the Guangxi Autonomous Region and the dense municipality of Chongqing. About 14 million acres of farmland across China have been affected, Xinhua reported. This drought and others that have devastated southern China this year have raised questions about the wisdom of a giant and expensive government project to transfer water from rivers in the south, in particular the Yangtze, to the parched north.

headline: Creating Spaces for Tweens and Teens
text: IT may seem improbable to suburban tweens, whiling away the after-school hours in front of a video-game console in a friend’s basement, but even in Manhattan, people in their age group get bored.

headline: Christopher Hitchens, a Man of His Words
text: Anyone who occasionally opens one of our more serious periodicals has learned that the byline of Christopher Hitchens is an opportunity to be delighted or maddened — possibly both — but in any case not to be missed. He is our intellectual omnivore, exhilarating and infuriating, if not in equal parts at least with equal wit. He has been rather famously an aggressive critic of God and his followers, after cutting his sacrilegious teeth on Mother Teresa. He wrote a deadpan argument for trying Henry Kissinger as a war criminal, then was branded an apostate by former friends on the left for vigorously supporting the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq. (He memorably — a lot of what Hitchens has written merits the adverb — shot back that his antiwar critics were “the sort who, discovering a viper in the bed of their child, would place the first call to People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals.”) And he is dying of esophageal cancer, a fact he has faced with exceptional aplomb.

headline: Big League Anxiety on the Baseball Diamond
text: To defenders of baseball and literary fiction, the charges against each are familiar, and overlapping: too slow, too precious, not enough action. The only realistic response is a resigned shrug. Guilty, and so what? You may as well complain that lemons are too yellow. The indictment amounts to a kind of category error; detractors went looking for entertainment, and found art instead.

headline: Up Front: Robert F. Worth
text: When this year’s momentous upheavals in the Middle East began, Robert F. Worth had just returned from lengthy stints in Baghdad and in Beirut, where he’d run the New York Times bureau. Soon, he was on his way back to the area to report on the revolts in Egypt, Libya and Yemen for The Times Magazine, where he is now a staff writer. “Covering the Arab uprisings,” he told us, “has been a transforming experience. By the end of last year, after more than seven years in the region, I had become a dour cynic about the potential for change in the Arab world. I had covered far too many bombings and fraudulent elections, and heard Arabs themselves complain too often about their own inability to transcend the morass of corruption and thuggery. Seeing all that explode has been a welcome challenge to my own assumptions about this place and its people.”

headline: A Libyan Author Writes of Exile and a Vanished Father
text: Ever since a Tunisian street vendor named Mohamed Bouazizi set himself on fire last December, people around the world have been asking how a new generation of Arab rebels learned to do what their parents could not: resist and even defeat a brutal police state. But a darker corollary soon arose. Why did it take so long? Why did the earlier rebellions fail? And how much damage has been done to the fabric of the societies that are now struggling, at the cost of so much blood, to reinvent themselves? For Western readers, what often seemed lacking — as in Iraq in years past — was an authentic interpreter and witness, someone who could speak across cultures and make us feel the abundant miseries that fueled the revolt.

headline: Welcome to the Counter-Jihad
text: The Arab world is poised for an era of political and cultural renewal. In dramatic succession, popular uprisings have toppled long-reigning dictators even as others cling to power. Amid these momentous events, scholars, journalists and politicians are scrambling to explain how these revolutions came about after years of political stagnation and dashed attempts at reform.

headline: The Waning Appeal of Radical Sheik
text: In “The Missing Martyrs,” Charles Kurzman suggests that even before Osama bin Laden was killed, his movement had failed utterly. Al Qaeda’s ideological trademark is to exhort ordinary Muslims to engage in individual acts of violence against those deemed enemies of Islam, specifically Americans, Jews and the infidel rulers of Muslim-­majority states. And yet very few such attacks have occurred in the United States since Sept. 11, and certainly none comparable to the devastating events of that day. To emphasize just how surprising this is, Kurzman cites a 2006 online manual for aspiring jihadists that lists 14 “simple tools” that “are easy to use and available for anyone who wants to fight the occupying enemy” — they include “running over someone with a car” and “setting fire to homes or rooms at sleep time.” Kurzman, a sociologist who has written widely about Islamic reform movements, asks: “If terrorist methods are as widely available as automobiles, why are there so few Islamist terrorists? In light of the death and devastation that terrorists have wrought, the question may seem absurd. But if there are more than a billion Muslims in the world, many of whom supposedly hate the West and desire martyrdom, why don’t we see terrorist attacks everywhere, every day?”

headline: What Do Egypt’s Writers Do Now?
text: The Egyptian revolution is over, the army wields power and the new government is in disarray. Tensions between Christians and Muslims are ascendant and members of the elite are leaving the country in droves while those who remain bemoan the masses as ignorant ideologues. This is the Egypt of Waguih Ghali’s “Beer in the Snooker Club,” a coming-of-age novel set in 1952 that, much like “The Catcher in the Rye” in America, articulated the identity crisis of a generation. Ghali’s characters — young, precocious, cosmopolitan — are lost in the bewildering aftermath of the military coup that overthrew the pliant boy-king Farouk. They pine for the easeful gambling, womanizing and drinking of the past even as they scorn both the ancien régime’s sordid pretensions and the new regime’s inability to deliver on its vaulted promises; “We have the worst of both systems,” one of them declares, exasperated. Ghali, who published his novel in 1964 and committed suicide five years later in the bathtub of his British editor’s Primrose Hill apartment, took the fall of the monarchy as his subject. Still, his tale presents uncanny parallels to today’s Egypt, where artists, intellectuals and youth at large are beginning to fashion a new cultural republic of sorts even as they also struggle to find their bearings.

headline: Brooklyn by the Book
text: Late in “Literary Brooklyn,” Evan Hughes quotes the opening words of a Paul Auster novel: “The address is unimportant. But let’s say Brooklyn Heights, for the sake of argument.” For Hughes, the address is terrifically important, as he charts New York’s most-­populated but (his description) “less exceptional” borough. We learn which writers lived where, which were neighbors or enemies; which houses no longer stand and which are now worth $18 million. Meanwhile, the argument that emerges, recedes, rallies and falters throughout is that Brooklyn, because more human in scale, is more American than Manhattan and has particular stories to tell about the rest of the land.

headline: A Novel of Pirates, Zealots and the Somalia Crisis
text: Some in the media may paint Somali pirates as womanizers with lavish tastes and an eye for Nairobi real estate, but Nuruddin Farah exposes the shallowness of such depictions in his 11th novel, “Crossbones.” This timely book, which can be read as a stand-alone work or as the final volume in the author’s acclaimed Past Imperfect trilogy, is politically courageous and often gripping.

headline: A Story of Sun, Sand and Street Smarts
text: Miami comes alive in “Birds of Paradise,” a lush new novel by Diana Abu-Jaber, the author of a culinary memoir (“The Language of Baklava”) and three previous novels (“Arabian Jazz,” “Crescent” and “Origin”). From the verdant streets of Coral Gables to the back lots of Little Haiti and the seedy under­belly of Miami Beach, the metropolis is floridly, meticulously detailed. Its every breath and scent, its hallucinations, its beckoning torpor, the ambitions and accents of its inhabitants become as impossible to resist as a postprandial siesta in the tropics. (“Hurricane season. The trees have grown dense as rooftops; the plumerias hold their flower-tipped branches up like brides with golden corsages.”)

headline: Jane Fonda, Constantly Evolving
text: There’s often a moment in a biographer’s life when the subject, once nonchalantly inaccessible or perhaps even hostile, decides that he must satisfy his curiosity about the project at the price of tossing scraps to this desperate soul. For Patricia Bosworth, a biographer of Montgomery Clift, this moment came in 2003, when she was invited to a weeklong respite at the 2,500-acre ranch in New Mexico that Ted Turner had bestowed on Jane Fonda as “a divorce present.” Fonda, with her breast implants newly removed and her shapely legs encased in terrific bluejeans (“I have 50 pairs,” she explained), plied Bosworth, a friend from the Actors Studio in the 1960s who had profiled her for magazines over the years, with red wine in enormous goblets, showed off her man-made lake stocked with fish, and introduced her to her six horses, including a white stallion purchased from Mike Nichols, and a golden retriever, a gift from Larry David.

headline: Tyler and ‘Odd Future’ Join Adult Swim
text: Tyler, the Creator, and his group of irreverent young rappers known as Odd Future, have landed a television show on Adult Swim, the nighttime incarnation of the Cartoon Network, which has become a showcase for underground pop-music genres in recent years.

headline: Why Vasco da Gama Went to India
text: The Portuguese navigator Vasco da Gama set sail from Belém, a village at the mouth of the Tagus River now part of greater Lisbon, on July 8, 1497. An obscure but well-­connected courtier, he had been chosen, much to everyone’s surprise, by King Manuel I to head the ambitious expedition to chart a new route to India. The king was not moved chiefly by a desire for plunder. He possessed a visionary cast of mind bordering on derangement; he saw himself spearheading a holy war to topple Islam, recover Jerusalem from “the infidels” and establish himself as the “King of Jerusalem.”

headline: Leaving Egypt, Finding Brooklyn
text: The coming-of-age memoir is centered on a premise that anyone would grant: growing up is hard. The genre’s challenges lie in how to articulate memory and the passage of time, how to express what’s forgotten as well as what’s recalled, how to capture the shifting self — challenges to which we have a short history of solutions. Memoir writers are enticingly free to forge innovations.

headline: Can Darwinism Improve Binghamton?
text: My undergraduate students, especially those bound for medical school, often ask why they have to study evolution. It won’t cure disease, and really, how useful is evolution to the average person? My response is that while evolutionary biology can explain, for example, the origin of antibiotic-resistant bacteria, we shouldn’t see evolution as a cure for human woes. Its value is explanatory: to tell us how, when and why we got here (by “we,” I mean “every organism”) and to show us how all species are related. In the end, evolution is the greatest tale of all, for it’s true.

headline: Beryl Bainbridge’s Bobby Kennedy Novel
text: On May 30, 1888, Anton Chekhov wrote exasperatedly to a friend, the newspaper editor A. S. Suvorin, complaining about the state of contemporary Russian literature, filled with its moral injunctions and its pious prescriptions for human behavior. The writer, he insisted “should not be a judge of his characters or what they say, but an impartial witness. . . . It’s time for writers, especially writers of real artistic worth, to realize . . . that in fact nothing can be understood in this world.” In a real sense, these phrases encapsulate the Chekhovian credo: nothing makes sense, mediocrity is the true demonic force, life is weird and vulgar, judgment is irrelevant. And to many writers, post-Chekhov, this point of view has appeared very attractive. In English literature since World War II, two writers in particular have made this take on life and the human predicament their personal forte — Muriel Spark and Beryl Bainbridge. Bainbridge, who died last year, of cancer, at the age of 77, pushed this attitude of amused, quietistic indifference to its ultimate level. Her succession of short novels (17 in all) demonstrates a beguiling relish in people’s fundamental opacity, eccentricity and inability to conform, however hard they may happen to be trying.

headline: Carol Bartz Has a Few More Words for Yahoo
text: After being fired on Tuesday, Carol A. Bartz, Yahoo’s former chief executive, still has a close tie with her old employer: she remains a board member.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: BELIEVING IS SEEING: Observations on the Mysteries of Photography,  by Errol Morris (Penguin Press, $40.) The filmmaker is chiefly interested here in the nature of knowledge, in figuring out where the truth lies — in photos, yes, but not exclusively so.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE TWILIGHT OF THE BOMBS: Recent Challenges, New Dangers, and the Prospects for a World Without Nuclear Weapons,  by Richard Rhodes (Vintage, $17.) In “The Making of the Atomic Bomb” (1986), Rhodes explained how the United States came to build atomic weapons. His next volume, “Dark Sun” (1995), traced the early years of the cold war. “Arsenals of Folly” (2007) told the story of its end. “The Twilight of the Bombs,” the absorbing fourth and final volume of the series, describes the fate of nuclear weapons since the collapse of the Soviet Union.

headline: Inside the List
text: BEHIND THE WHEEL: One of the goofier, more endearing features to appear each week in The Globe and Mail newspaper in Toronto is the column My Car, in which Canadian celebrities discuss what they drive and why. (Sample headline: “Curler Likes an S.U.V. With Room for the Brooms.”) Last year, the column included an interview with the Québécois crime writer Louise Penny, who enters the hardcover fiction list this week at No. 4 with “A Trick of the Light,” the seventh novel in her Chief Inspector Armand Gamache series. (Marilyn Stasio reviews it in the Sept. 18 issue of the Book Review.) Penny, a former CBC radio host who turned to writing as a second career, said she gets most of her ideas as she drives around in her 2006 powder blue Volkswagen Beetle convertible. The best thing about the car, she said, is the color. “The salesman was going on and on — it has this feature, it has that feature, and all I’m trying to say is, ‘What color is it? Powder blue?’ ” she said. “I put a down payment on it over the telephone. There was no sort of second thought here. He could have said it was double the price and I would have said, ‘Is it powder blue?’”

headline: As Auto Show Opens, an Industry’s Balance Shifts
text: WHEN the 64th Frankfurt Motor Show opens on Tuesday for two days of press previews, some 50 automakers and specialty builders will begin unwrapping upwards of 100 new models for journalists.

headline: House of Strings and Feathers

headline: Apps and Sites for Restaurant Hunters
text: The news on Thursday that Google is buying Zagat, the longtime publisher of restaurant reviews, got us thinking over here at Gadgetwise, mostly about the fact that we haven’t really used Zagat all that much in the last few years. There are times where it can be useful (if you’re going to a city with limited restaurant-review options, Zagat can steer you to a place that will probably be just fine, and possibly great), but what Zagat used to have to itself has become its own industry with plenty of competitors. Here’s a look at some of the bigger and better players in the restaurant search world.

headline: Another Ryan Awaits His Star Turn
text: IRVING, Tex. — Not 10 months after saying he would be “shocked” if he were not an N.F.L. head coach this season, Rob Ryan stood outside his team’s locker room Monday, surrounded by television cameras and microphones and recorders, and praised the man who had hired him: Jason Garrett, the head coach of the Dallas Cowboys. So, is Ryan, imported to resuscitate one of the league’s worst defenses of last season, shocked again that his prediction has gone unfulfilled?

headline: European-Specification Honda Civic Gets a Mugen Special Edition

headline: Questions for a Father Lost on 9/11
text: I was going to write about what we have learned in 10 years. About how love, family and community were all that mattered on that awful day, and how we should use each anniversary of Sept. 11 to try to reclaim the sliver of good that was forged in the flames. About how all our lives are measured not by what happens to us, but by what we do in response. And about how we must use this day to honor what was clear as the September sky that morning. We must cherish the sheer luxury of normal.

headline: In Spain, Hiking Along the Volcanoes of Catalonia
text: A BLACK-AND-WHITE bird, perhaps a magpie, looking not unlike a soaring penguin, floated above my wife, Jessie, and me as we walked out of Olot, deep in the foothills of the Pyrenees in Spanish Catalonia. We weren’t exactly lost, but an old lady’s directions, in rambling Catalan, seemed somewhat improbable: go until you see a path that looks like it used to be a railroad, she said. Then follow it for about 35 miles until you reach Girona.

headline: Peter Som Smells the Roses

Mr. Hilfiger himself is scheduled to show his men’s wear at 5:30 this afternoon. Neither one looked especially stressed when they sat down in the front row of the show of Peter Som, who is also a consultant on Mr. Hilfiger’s women’s collection.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: Governors Island becomes a pig fest Saturday from 11:30 a.m. to 5 p.m. during the Pig Island event, which benefits Food Systems Network NYC. A team of 20 chefs will cook 80 hogs raised by local farmers. Craft beers and New York wines will be poured, and cooking demonstrations will take place throughout the day. There will be options for vegetarians, too. Tickets range from $43.19 to $74.84.

headline: Democrats Plan Briefings on Jewish Outreach
text: It’s no surprise that the Democratic National Committee meeting in Chicago on Friday will include briefings on jobs and health care, issues critical to President Obama’s re-election. headline: An Immigration Lottery Won, Then Dreams Lost
text: Earlier this year, the United States State Department notified some 22,000 applicants from around the world that they were among the winners of its lottery drawing for a permanent resident visa, known as a green card. A few days later, however, the State Department changed course, saying the winners were not winners after all because the required random-selection process had been done improperly. The dreams of applicants from Venezuela to Egypt and Uzbekistan to Fiji were dashed. Months later, that disappointment continues. Two would-be winners, each from Russia, talk about what it was like to have won — and then lost.

headline: House Freshmen Emerge as G.O.P. Power Brokers
text: CONWAY, S.C. — Voters here were showing Representative Tim Scott the love, and Gov. Rick Perry of Texas looked as if he might jump across the stage and give Mr. Scott, a Republican freshman, a kiss himself.

headline: The Lowdown | Erik Foss
text: The founder and owner of Lit Lounge, a singular source of some of the most embarrassing “I blacked out” moments in New York, the almost legendary Erik Foss also devotes a fair amount of his time and energy to supporting and creating art. His gallery, Fuse, has given an invaluable vote of confidence to countless young New York artists (including me a year ago), by showing their work before anyone else would so much as bat an eyelash at them. Over the last few years, Foss’s own cheeky (and often pornographic) paintings have appeared in numerous group shows internationally, and he’s had two solo gigs at White Walls Gallery in San Francisco. I caught up with Foss on the eve of his first solo show in New York, the town he has called home for almost two decades. Catch the artist’s reception for “Avarice” at Malick Williams and Co. (150 11th Avenue), on Sept. 11 from 6 p.m. to 9 p.m.

headline: Obama and Abbas: From Speed Dial to Not Talking

The last time the two men spoke was in February, when Mr. Obama failed, in an awkward, 55-minute phone conversation, to persuade Mr. Abbas not to go to the United Nations to condemn Israel for building Jewish settlements.

text: Andy Roddick’s stirring win over David Ferrer surprised many tennis analysts, who thought the indefatigable Spaniard would return well enough to neutralize Roddick’s cannon of a serve. But Roddick showed signs of returning to the form he displayed at Wimbledon in 2009. He also played superbly from the backcourt, committing fewer unforced errors than the notoriously stingy Ferrer.

headline: Party Leaders Appeal to Yemen’s President to Help End Stalemate
text: SANA, Yemen — Having failed so far to bring an end to the nation’s political crisis, a delegation of governing party officials traveled to Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, on Friday, hoping to persuade the absentee president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, to help break a stalemate that has paralyzed the country for months.

headline: Lady Gaga to Ring in the New Year With Dick Clark
text: Lady Gaga will be the featured guest performing at Times Square during the annual New Year’s Eve celebration on ABC hosted by Dick Clark and Ryan Seacrest, The Associated Press said. The show is in its 40th year and Mr. Clark has been hosting it much longer than Lady Gaga, the pop diva given to euro-dance grooves and wacky costumes, has been alive. (She was born in 1986.) Fergie, of the Black Eyed Peas, will host the Los Angeles portion of the show, which will go for three hours in prime time, break for the local news, then return for two and a half hours.

headline: Employers Say Jobs Plan Won’t Lead to Hiring Spur
text: The dismal state of the economy is the main reason many companies are reluctant to hire workers, and few executives are saying that President Obama’s jobs plan — while welcome — will change their minds any time soon.

headline: Red Bulls Re-Engage
text: The Red Bulls — remember them? — will be back on the field for a game in Major League Soccer for the first time since Aug. 20 when they face the bottom team in the entire league, the Vancouver Whitecaps, at Red Bull Arena in Harrison, N.J., Saturday night.

headline: Seeking Universal Life Lessons in Story of Baseball Nerdery
text: TORONTO — It’s a safe bet that nobody’s picture got a green light on Sony Pictures’ Culver City lot on Friday. The company’s top brass — including the studio chief, Amy Pascal, and the president of the Columbia Pictures unit, Doug Belgrad — were crammed into the front row of a news conference at the Toronto International Film Festival here, watching Brad Pitt introduce their sports-and-business drama, “Moneyball.”

headline: Fashion’s Night Out in New York City
text: Fashionistas celebrated the start of New York Fashion Week during Fashion’s Night Out, a shopping event held at various venues in New York City.

headline: What’s in the Obama Jobs Plan for Small Businesses
text: In his speech to the joint session of Congress on Thursday night, President Obama proposed a jobs bill, the American Jobs Act, with several specific, if not yet particularly detailed, tax initiatives that would benefit small businesses — though most in fact would bring the same relief to all companies, large or small. The initiatives can be sorted into two flavors, incentives to promote investment broadly and incentives to promote hiring in particular.

headline: Embracing the Positive
text: “My sister and I both had a positive lookout for life,” said Marisa Berenson, now in her 60s and still an arresting beauty, at a Fashion’s Night Out event held in Donna Karan’s Madison Avenue store on Thursday to celebrate “Marisa Berenson: A Life in Pictures,” due out in October from Rizzoli books.

headline: Strapping
text: For the Bulgarian-born shoe designer Gio Metodiev of Gio Diev, seven-inch heels aren’t always a prerequisite for seductive footwear. “It’s really not about height anymore,” he says. “You can make a statement without having to be sky high.” The 30-piece offering, which Metodiev will introduce at Premiere Classe in Paris later this month, includes color-blocked heels with ankle cuffs inspired by armor and flats strapped with leather “wire.” Diev’s meticulous construction — he shares a factory in northern Italy with Manolo Blahnik; he has his mother wear and test every new style — and intuitive sense of what strong women want have already made him a favorite of actresses like Emmy Rossum and Rose Byrne. His dream feet, though? Gwyneth Paltrow’s. “She’s so beautiful and she does it all,” Metodiev says, going on to explain that at the end of the day it’s all about taking chances. “Who wants to wear the same old safe thing?” Not we, says T.

headline: Combo Platter, Ethical Dilemma on the Side
text: We buy it, we prepare it, we order it, we think about it, we worry about it, we talk about it, we read about it, we watch TV about it, and if there’s any time left over, we actually eat and digest it. Whatever your relationship to food, practically every aspect of contemporary existence is influenced by food culture. So how does it affect your ethical life? Probably more than most of us realize.

headline: Threat by Turkish Premier Raises Tensions With Israel
text: JERUSALEM — Israel was wrestling on Friday with growing tensions with Turkey after the Turkish prime minister threatened to use his navy to accompany aid flotillas to Gaza and to challenge Israel’s plans for gas exploration and export in the Eastern Mediterranean.

headline: Letting Vegetables Inspire a Stir-Fry
text: Few dishes are as simple as the stir-fry, which just requires some basic chopping, a few seasonings and a hot pan. As Martha Rose Shulman explains in this week’s Recipes for Health, the vegetables on sale at the farmers’ market can inspire variations on the recipes offered here.

headline: A Chicago Market of Food and Fashion
text: EVERY summer in Chicago, most neighborhoods put on their own street fair, with generally the same mix of homogeneous items: cheap sunglasses, tacky art, deep-fried food and music by local bands. But recently, a new concept — let’s call it the curated flea market — has caught on, thanks to the introduction this year of Dose Market by a group of young and intrepid media and style experts.

headline: A Bit of Switzerland in Wisconsin

headline: Snooki Slept Here. So Did I.
text: THE Jersey Shore did not get the worst of Hurricane Irene, though the storm left its mark. Boarded-up shops and houses, battered dunes, broken trees and buckled hunks of boardwalk provided a jarring tableau of pleasure aborted.

headline: Letters: Elite in Coach, for a Fee
text: To the Editor: Regarding “Elite for a Day, in Coach, for a Fee” (Practical Traveler, Sept. 4), I have no desire to be fawned over, or need to impress. How about a flat fee of $100 for a civil flying experience? Reasonable legroom, checked bags, no being bounced, short security lines — basically, all the services we used to take for granted. Joshua P. Hill

headline: Digging in Colorado (but Not for Gold)
text: ON a sunny Saturday morning in July, a group of nearly two dozen gathered at the foothills of the Arapaho National Forest in Colorado, in one of the many scenic areas between Denver and Vail. They might have easily been mistaken for typical hikers if not for their accouterments: baskets filled with small waxed bags, pocket knives and paintbrushes of varying sizes. Soon, the group dispersed into the woods alongside the rocky trail, on a hunt for fungi. These were people interested in mycology, the study of mushrooms.

headline: The World (or Some Interesting Parts) Under One Scottish Roof
text: The National Museum of Scotland recently reopened in Edinburgh after a £46.4 million (about $75 million) refurbishment, with 16 new galleries. This multidisciplinary museum, with four million objects in its collection, was founded in 1866 with the goal of showing all the world under one roof.

headline: State Heeds Minor Parties on Voting-Machine Complaint

headline: N.F.L. Season Opener Kicks Off NBC’s Ratings
text: While the final outcome of the National Football League season opener on Thursday between the Green Bay Packers and the New Orleans Saints was in doubt until the end, what was never in doubt was the ratings dominance the N.F.L. would give NBC. (The Packers ultimately won the game, 42-34.) According to Nielsen estimates, an average of 27.2 million total viewers tuned in for the game. It was the second-most-watched N.F.L. opener of all time, trailing only last season’s Brett Favre-enhanced contest between the Minnesota Vikings and The Saints.  CBS, which was led by “Big Brother” at 9 p.m. with 6.5 million viewers, came in far behind NBC for second place among the broadcast networks.

headline: Replacing Panic With a Sense of Pride
text: Robert Moir, 42, joined Merrill Lynch in 1997. On Sept. 11, 2001, he was a business manager for NASDAQ Trading. He is now a managing director and chief operating officer of the Americas cash equity sales and trading at Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Really Big Bands
text: If you’re gonna play music, play it big — in size, sound or influence — and dress big in the fall’s loudest pieces. That was the lesson learned at Bonnaroo, the festival in remote Tennessee, where our team at T Magazine photographed Deerhunter, Florence & The Machine, Gogol Bordello and the Scissor Sisters to name a few.

headline: Your Head Belongs to You
text: I’ve been going to the same hairstylist for seven years. When she took her vacation this summer, I tried another stylist in the salon. My hair has never looked better! The cut, the color, even the little massage at the end were vastly superior with the new girl. Is it possible to make a permanent switch, or would that be too disloyal to my original stylist? How do I maneuver it? And why do I feel like I’m cheating?

headline: Keeping Score: Lee’s Value to Phillies Can Be Measured in Zeros
text: Cliff Lee, the left-handed Philadelphia Phillies starter, is on quite a tear. In August he was 5-0 with a 0.45 earned run average in 39 2/3 innings. And it was not even his best month this season: in June he was also 5-0, with three shutouts and a 0.21 E.R.A. in 42 innings.

headline: On 9/11, the Seeds of the Infinite Grapevine
text: One of the last times I remember actually waiting for film to be developed was in mid-September 2001. I was a college student living in downtown Manhattan, and had taken dozens of photographs from the roof of my dorm, where I watched the World Trade Center collapse, and then from ground zero and Union Square, where I spent most of the next day. When I ran out of film, I dropped it off at a storefront on Waverly Street and waited.

headline: Russia Identifies Defect in Rocket That Crashed

headline: A Boy’s Bar Mitzvah Lessons Bridge a Cultural Chasm

There he stood at a makeshift lectern in his baggy shorts and floppy shirt and mop-top hair, a boy of 13, and began to read from a speech about the Jewish martyrs of Masada.

headline: Hot Times in Monza as Vettel and Hamilton Battle
text: MONZA, Italy  — There is a microclimate here in Monza, it seems, as the weather feels as if we’re still in the midst of a summer heat wave. But things don’t change at the front of the grid all that much. Again, the  battle lines at the Italian Grand Prix appear to be drawn between Sebastian Vettel of Red Bull and Lewis Hamilton at McLaren Mercedes. Vettel was fastest in the afternoon practice session on Sunday; Hamilton was fastest in the morning.
