text: Eliza Lipnack Stamps, a daughter of Jessica Lipnack of West Newton, Mass., and the late Jeffrey Stamps, was married Saturday evening to Ethan Hopkins Covey, a son of Marcy Smith Covey and Laird P. Covey of Poland, Me. Ion Sokhos, a friend of the couple who received a one-day solemnization certificate from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, officiated at the home of the bride’s mother.

Kevin Madden of Purchase, N.Y. Cynthia Kilburn, a Vermont justice of the peace, officiated at the Equinox Resort in Manchester, Vt.

headline: Julia Kidder, Charles Kulwin
text: Julia Malone Kidder, a daughter of Judith Malone and Stephen W. Kidder of Belmont, Mass., was married Saturday evening in Cambridge, Mass., to Dr. Charles Glen Kulwin, a son of Dr. Elizabeth H. Brown and Dr. Dwight R. Kulwin of Cincinnati. The Rev. Victor H. Kazanjian Jr., an Episcopal priest and the dean of intercultural education and religious and spiritual life at Wellesley College in Wellesley, Mass., performed the ceremony at the Memorial Church at Harvard.

headline: Sara Levine, Zack Rosenblum
text: Sara Block Levine, a daughter of Shelley Block and Lee Levine of Chevy Chase, Md., was married Saturday evening to Alvin Isaac Rosenblum, the son of Candice Sutton Rosenblum and Howard Walder Rosenblum of Mandeville, La. Rabbi Peter Hyman officiated at the Hyatt Regency Chesapeake Bay in Cambridge, Md.

headline: Genílson Brandão and Mark Lenhart
text: Genílson Brandão and Mark Sibley Lenhart were married Saturday at their summer home in Provincetown, Mass. Joseph T. DeMartino, a minister of the Universal Life Church, officiated.

text: Chen Zhang, a daughter of Yini Zhu and Huiming Zhang of Livingston, N.J., was married in New York Saturday evening to Kent Yee Cheng, a son of Nina Cheng and Bill Cheng, also of Livingston. Gerald Fierst, a Universal Brotherhood minister, officiated at Cipriani Wall Street, an event space in New York.

headline: Judith Andiman, James Pagnam
text: Judith Aliza Andiman and James Thomas Pagnam were married Saturday at Sankaty Head Golf and Beach Club in Nantucket, Mass. John Downey, a retired judge of the Connecticut Superior Court in New Haven, officiated with the assistance of Rabbi William Cutter.

headline: Lauren Lefton, Paul Resnek
text: Lauren Meredith Lefton, a daughter of Rochelle S. Lefton and David Lefton of San Antonio, was married Saturday evening to Paul Benjamin Resnek, the son of Barbara Resnek and Frank M. Resnek of Newton, Mass. Rabbi Samuel M. Stahl officiated at Temple Beth-El in San Antonio.

headline: Allison Kupfer and Daniel Poteet
text: Allison Macy Kupfer and Daniel Charles Poteet were married Saturday afternoon at the Claremont Hotel in Southwest Harbor, Me. Linda Martin, a Maine notary public, officiated.

headline: Ali Rosof, Andrew Fedder
text: Ali Renee Rosof, the daughter of Patricia J. F. Rosof and Alan H. Rosof of Manhattan, was married Monday to Andrew Scott Fedder, a son of Linda S. Fedder and Dr. Marc F. Fedder of Lexington, N.C. Rabbi Laurence A. Sebert officiated at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

headline: Laura Weidman, Michael Powers
text: Laura Elizabeth Weidman and Michael Parker Powers were married Saturday. Judge Jody Adams of the Family Court of New York officiated at the Wölffer Estate Vineyard in Sagaponack, N.Y.

headline: Robin Steinberg, David Feige
text: Robin Gail Steinberg and David Lawrence Feige were married Saturday evening at the Bronx Borough Courthouse. Rabbi Marc Margolius officiated.

headline: Theodore Kaplan, Henry Tobin
text: Theodore Nalitt Kaplan and Henry David Tobin were married Friday afternoon in their garden in Northport, N.Y. George J. Doll Jr., the mayor of the Village of Northport, officiated.

headline: Lauren Hill, Jonathan Patrick
text: Dr. Lauren Marie Hill, a daughter of Catherine R. Hill and Dr. Robert B. Hill of Hockessin, Del., was married Saturday to Dr. Jonathan Edward Patrick, a son of Joan Patrick and Robert A. Patrick of Tampa, Fla. The Rev. Richard G. Malloy, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Old St. Joseph’s Catholic Church in Philadelphia.

headline: Emily Janney, Nicholas Elliot
text: Emily Phipps Janney, the daughter of Lynn B. Janney and Stuart S. Janney III of Butler, Md., was married Saturday to Nicholas Thomas Elliot, the son of Martine Aubin of Knysna, South Africa, and Dr. Michael S. Elliot of Cape Town. The Rev. Dr. James L. Haddix, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated at the Pot and Kettle Club, a private club in Bar Harbor, Me.

headline: Michelle Guest, Peter Carter
text: Michelle Rachel Guest and Peter Smathers Carter were married Saturday at the Golden Gate Club in San Francisco. Alan F. Neckritz, a friend of the bride’s family who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Susan Resley, David Shalleck
text: Susan Diane Resley and David Shalleck were married Saturday afternoon at Old St. Hilary’s, an event space and former church in Tiburon, Calif. Irene Kane, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Heather Miles, David Lombino
text: Heather Elizabeth Miles and David Albert Lombino were married Friday at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church in Washington Depot, Conn. The Rev. Matthew Kappalumakkel officiated. On Saturday afternoon, the Rev. Edward J. Hanrahan, another Roman Catholic priest, performed a wedding mass at the home of Jill F. Lloyd and Michael A. Lloyd, who are friends of the bridegroom’s family, also in Washington Depot.

headline: Amanda Talbott, Joshua Schuler
text: Amanda Danielle Talbott and Joshua Benjamin Schuler were married Saturday aboard Fireball, a Fire Island ferry. James Mallot, the mayor of Ocean Beach, N.Y., officiated.

headline: Colleen Newman, David Silk
text: Colleen Patricia Newman and David Robertson Silk were married Saturday afternoon in Hoboken, N.J. Msgr. Robert S. Meyer, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at SS. Peter and Paul Church, where he is pastor.

headline: Michelle Bright, Devin Lyons-Quirk
text: Michelle Ashley Bright and Devin Lyons-Quirk were married Saturday at the San Diego Zoo Safari Park in Escondido, Calif. Officiating was Patricia A. Labosky, an aunt of the bride, who was designated a deputy marriage commissioner by San Diego County.

headline: Kate Barbera, Bryan McShane
text: Kate Lindsay Barbera and Bryan Patrick McShane were married Saturday at St. Bernard’s Episcopal Church in Bernardsville, N.J. The Rev. William F. Feus, the church’s rector, performed the ceremony, with the Rev. James C. L. Arimond, a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.

headline: Robin Rosenbloom, Darin Goldman
text: Robin Gail Rosenbloom and Dr. Darin Ryan Goldman were married Saturday evening at the Harmonie Club in Manhattan. Rabbi Dennis G. Shulman officiated.

headline: Starting New York Cool, Ending Atlanta Hot
text: “The hottest artist in the world!” DJ Esco shouted from the S.O.B.’s stage Wednesday night, teasing the impending arrival of the Atlanta rapper Future. He repeated it a couple of times for emphasis, but maybe also because not everyone in the room was paying attention. They were milling about, probably wondering why they were so alone.

headline: Laura Quist, Daniel Ponickly
text: Laura Zoe Quist and Daniel Joseph Ponickly were married Saturday evening at a farm in Fairbanks, Alaska, that is owned by the bride’s family. Christopher L. Quist, the brother of the bride, who was appointed a marriage commissioner for the day by the State of Alaska, officiated

headline: Women With Wrenches
text: ON most days, Katlyn Hershman can be found smeared with grease, plying her skills as a mechanic at Bike Works NYC, a shop on the Lower East Side. When she answers the store phone, though, all that toil and expertise can suddenly seem invisible.

headline: The Limits of Medicine
text: To the Editor:

headline: Reviewing the BMW 1 Series M
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich reviews the BMW 1 Series M Coupe, which had its formal debut at the Detroit auto show in January.

headline: Obama’s Message to Congress on Jobs
text: To the Editor:

headline: This Sunday: What Does Alec Baldwin Have to Do With 9/11?
text: A friend who saw a copy of this week’s issue shortly after it arrived in our office remarked that it was a “relief” not to see another 9/11 image. I understood what she meant, but that was not our intention, nor was it a reflection of how I personally feel. In fact, I’ve been surprised by how absorbed I’ve been in the coverage of the 10th anniversary, particularly some of the excellent stories I’ve listened to in the morning on WNYC radio.

headline: In Indochine, a New York Mainstay for the Fashion Elite
text: Drawing a fashionable, artsy, loyal crowd since the 1980s, the buzz surrounding the restaurant Indochine is not about the food.

headline: Florida Museum to Hold On to Disputed Painting
text: Federal officials have ordered a museum in Tallahassee, Florida, not to return a painting on loan from Italy because it may have been stolen by the Nazis during World War II, the head of the museum said.

headline: Atlanta Cheating Scandal
text: To the Editor:

headline: Cuban Coffee and ‘True Blood’
text: The designer Narciso Rodriguez says that preparing his runway show for fall fashion week is “like taking a stress test on a treadmill.” It even ruins a few of his Sundays, otherwise languorous, unstructured days dedicated to things like eating Cuban food and sipping red wine. Mr. Rodriguez, 50, has a minimalist aesthetic and a lengthy list of celebrity clients that includes Michelle Obama, Julianna Margulies and Kate Winslet. He lives in a penthouse in Chelsea with his partner, Thomas Tolan, an advertising executive, and their three dogs, a Chihuahua and two Yorkies. They also have a country house in Westchester County.

headline: Police Investigating Finances of Man Left in Suitcase
text: After she was charged with improper burial for stuffing her dead roommate into a suitcase and leaving his body behind an abandoned building in the Bronx — topped by a handwritten sign saying “Rest in Peace” – Monique Exum told detectives in the Bronx that she did not report his death for fear of being punished for it.

headline: Obama Jobs Plan Would Boost the City, Comptroller Says
text: President Obama’s plan to temporarily cut payroll taxes in half would yield big benefits in New York City, if Congress passed it as proposed, the city comptroller’s office said on Friday.

headline: Magazine Covers on a Topic Known All Too Well
text: Choosing the right magazine cover is a challenge in any ordinary week. But capturing the right sentiments surrounding the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks presented questions more fraught and delicate than most.

headline: Remembering P.S. 2
text: To the Editor:

headline: Three Ways to Look Back, None Easy
text: Many people assured us that we would never forget, and they were right. The attacks of Sept. 11 were the most extensively witnessed and recorded events in history, a spectacle, as the hijackers intended. The towers exploding against the crystalline blue sky, the white dust cascading, the panicked office workers — these are all seared in collective memory.

headline: Cold Hands, Warm Planet
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Tighter, Lighter, Smaller Mahler
text: The Orchestra of St. Luke’s, now comfortably settled in its new home at the DiMenna Center for Classical Music, is understandably intent on showing off the building’s flexible, freshly renovated performance spaces. For its first offering of the season, on Thursday evening at the center’s Jerome Robbins Theater, the orchestra fielded its core musicians — the St. Luke’s Chamber Ensemble, 14 players strong — for a centenary commemoration of the premiere of Mahler’s hefty orchestral song cycle, “Das Lied von der Erde.”

headline: Podcast: The Economy, Manufacturing and Commercialized College Life
text: The economy has been slowing and unemployment in the United States is stuck at 9.1 percent. President Obama has come up with a program that he says will help.

headline: Using a Side Suit to Control Trumps
text: If you asked bridge aficionados to name the three greatest players of all time, Benito Garozzo would be on almost everyone’s list. Born in Italy but a United States resident for many years, Garozzo had his 84th birthday on Monday.

headline: Flooding Brings New Wrinkle to Fracking Report
text: The floods in upstate New York are raising new concern about plans for natural gas drilling in New York.

headline: For Banks, Unfortunate Echoes of 2008
text: THREE years ago, financial stocks tumbled as worries about the health of the banking system grew. By Sept. 12, indexes of financial stocks were down 28 percent from the end of 2007 in both the United States and Europe.

headline: Day 2: Off the Runway
text: Scenes from New York Fashion Week on Sept. 9.

headline: Protest of Thousands in Cairo Turns Violent
text: CAIRO — A demonstration that brought tens of thousands to this city’s central Tahrir Square turned violent on Friday, when thousands of people — led by a heavy contingent of soccer fans — tore down a protective wall around the Israeli Embassy, while others defaced the headquarters of the Egyptian Interior Ministry.

headline: ‘Super Fly’ Musical Struts a Step Closer To the New York Stage
text: Could blaxploitation meet Broadway? It’s an obvious question that comes up with news that Bill T. Jones, the director and choreographer, will spend three weeks next month developing “Super Fly: The Musical” in New York.

headline: #trendingnyc: The Week on Twitter
text: What do a councilman, a comedian and a catcher named Jesus have in common?

headline: U.S. Open Point/Counterpoint: Steffi Graf vs. Justine Henin
text: Fantasy U.S. Open Tournament: Who are the two greatest U.S. Open champions from the past 30 years? It’s up to you to decide, with a little help from The Times’s tennis experts. Watch our video debates, vote on the winner and then explain your position in the comments section. The winner from this match will be the champion of our virtual tournament. View the bracket.

headline: They Messed With Texas
text: A funny thing happened at the Republican debate at the Reagan Library in California on Wednesday night, when the evening’s co-moderator Brian Williams asked a question of Gov. Rick Perry of Texas. (Not funny ha-ha, funny peculiar.) Let’s go right to the video.

headline: An iPhone Case for Tiny Hands
text: Most toddlers, being the intelligent creatures they are, like to mimic adults. Give them a toy cellphone to play with, and they demand yours instead. But who wants to put their mobile device in the hands of a 2-year-old?

headline: Some Crazy Colors
text: As she made the rounds of shows today wearing purple and scarlet, Linda Fargo, the fashion director for Bergdorf Goodman, seemed to signal her commitment to a crazily colorful spring. Some designers parading their collections this Fashion Week were just as dedicated to a brash new palette: Peter Som offering exuberant mashups of pink and teal: BCBG splicing bright tones into otherwise subdued silks; and Jason Wu unveiling a party frock in raucous caution yellow. Complementing those hues, or clashing with them outright, were hairstyles streaked, in some cases, with fuchsia or aquatic green. Can full-on psychedelia be far behind?

headline: Killed on Sept. 11, 2001, but Destined to Be Mourned Only Quietly, Only by a Few
text: Three deadly weapons struck down their victims in New York City on Sept. 11, 2001. Two were hijacked jets. The third was a .40-caliber pistol on a dark corner of Brooklyn, with just 18 minutes remaining in that day.

headline: Teenage Immigrant Dreams in the City
text: “EVERYBODY has The Outfit — the outfit they bought for America,” Brooke Hauser writes in “The New Kids: Big Dreams and Brave Journeys at a High School for Immigrant Teens” (Free Press).

headline: Smoke Signals
text: I.

headline: A Play That Will Not Come to Dust While It’s a Troupe’s Lucky Charm
text: “Cymbeline,” which opened at the New Victory Theater in January, reopened on Thursday night at the Barrow Street Theater, 27 Barrow Street, at Seventh Avenue South, West Village; (212) 868-4444, smarttix.com. Following are excerpts from Ben Brantley’s review, which appeared in The New York Times on Jan. 18; the full text is available here.

headline: Netherlands: Lebanon Tribunal Will Weigh Trial in Absentia
text: The United Nations-backed tribunal investigating the killing of Lebanon’s former prime minister, Rafiq Hariri, and 22 others, has formed its first trial chamber, even though the four Hezbollah members indicted in the case remain at large. A panel of three judges, from Switzerland, Lebanon and Australia, are to decide whether to go ahead with a trial in absentia anyway. The court, which follows Lebanese law, is based near The Hague.

headline: Trinity Church Calls; Composers Respond
text: In the days leading up to the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, on Sunday, Bach, Brahms, Mahler and their ilk have once again been pressed to serve, their historically distant, emotively durable works lending voice to public expressions of grief in manners broad enough to enfold diverse beliefs and perspectives.

headline: Making the Most of the Very Least, and Other Lessons
text: “Bucky Larson: Born to Be a Star” is the tale of a small-town boy from Iowa, with a Prince Valiant haircut, a bad overbite and big dreams, who comes, like so many other small-town dreamers, to the San Fernando Valley to become a pornographic film star. There he meets a bunch of other performers who seem to be desperate for work and willing to submit to unimaginable degradation for a chance to appear on the big screen.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Sept. 9
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include treasure hunting on the beach, flooding in New York and New Jersey, and the first day of school.

headline: Deal May Be Near in L.I.U. Strike
text: A faculty strike that disrupted the first week of school at Long Island University could come to an end on Monday, both sides said Friday after a new round of negotiations produced the outlines of a deal.

headline: Chock-Full of Gator Bait, Most of It Human
text: On television the backwoods are a trendy place to hang out lately, what with shows like “Swamp People” on History and “Hillbilly Handfishin’ ” on Animal Planet. At the movies, though, the boggy undergrowth is apparently still where young people go to be eaten by strange beasts, as we learn from “Creature,” a long-on-gore, short-on-brains horror film that opened on Friday.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Photos
text: The man who rebuilt Cantor Fitzgerald after 9/11, continuing economic turmoil in Europe, doctors who add an M.B.A. to their credentials and more.

headline: A Movie About Scandalously Familiar Politicians
text: TORONTO — “It’s probably not our best moment in politics,” offered George Clooney, who was on a stage at the Toronto International Film Festival on Friday being asked about the message of his movie, “The Ides of March.” The film’s take on American democracy left some viewers here feeling stunned, if not disillusioned.

headline: A Jam Band Plays, and Occasionally a Song Even Breaks Out
text: Every now and again during its energetically sprawling two-part show at Brooklyn Bowl on Thursday night, Umphrey’s McGee outlined the clear parameters of a song. Typically this involved Brendan Bayliss, the band’s lead singer, delivering gauzy lyrics in his thin, nearly featureless voice. Often it felt faintly dutiful, in stark contrast to the urgency and unpredictability of the band’s instrumental outflow.

headline: Hackers Take Over NBC Twitter Account
text: A Twitter account belonging to NBC News was hacked on Friday evening by an entity that claimed, falsely, that an airplane had crashed at the site of ground zero in New York.

headline: Deal Reached on Dialysis for Immigrants
text: ATLANTA — Twenty-one illegal immigrants will continue to receive regular dialysis at no cost for three years under an agreement disclosed Friday by Atlanta’s public hospital, Grady Memorial, and the world’s largest dialysis provider, Fresenius Medical Care.

headline: Ethiopia Calls for Aid Corridors to Protect Food for Somalia
text: Prime Minister Meles Zenawi of Ethiopia called on Friday for the creation of “corridors of humanitarian assistance” in neighboring Somalia to ease the delivery of life-saving aid. A famine is steadily spreading across southern Somalia but the Shabab, a militant Islamist group, has been blocking many aid groups from reaching starving people. United Nations officials seemed cool to the idea of establishing humanitarian corridors, which can be a pretext for military intervention.

headline: Wordless Vocals and a Complex Whisper
text: Wild Flag

headline: Women’s Scheduling Draws Criticism
text: Vocal complaints lodged by several top men’s players about scheduling at the 2011 U.S. Open resulted in dramatic schedule changes, giving the men more rest between matches that might have otherwise been closer together due to rain interruption earlier in the week. But while the men were appeased, the four women who had advanced to the semifinals were done few favors by the revised schedule.

headline: Antitrust Suit Is Simple Calculus
text: Have you looked at your cellphone bill lately?

headline: Teamwork on the Hudson
text: The Army football team practices and trains together.

headline: Annals of Conference Planning
text: Two impressions:

headline: The Optimism Is as Blinding as the Colors
text: The first days of Fashion Week are sort of the children’s hour, when a lot of young designers show. But don’t expect bratty behavior from these kids. They’re so nice it’s sickening.

headline: Another Shift in Late Night?
text: Late night is undergoing what may be a long-term shift thanks to changing viewing habits, the rise of social media and the high cost of production.

headline: No More Desk Potatoes?
text: JIMMY FALLON had them crying in the aisles on July 14 — and he couldn’t have been happier.

headline: Tough Assignment for an Accidental Conductor
text: WELL before “Nine Rivers,” a major work by the Scottish avant-garde composer James Dillon, was given its premiere by the BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra in Glasgow last November it had acquired a singular reputation. Interviewed in The Telegraph, a London newspaper, Mr. Dillon referred to his nine-part cycle as “the most canceled premiere ever.” Five previous attempts to mount it had been called off, casualties of its elaborate technical requirements, daunting difficulty and four-hour duration.

headline: Obama Asks for $5.1 Billion in Disaster Aid
text: President Obama formally asked Congress on Friday for $5.1 billion to cover the federal cost of the response to recent natural disasters, including the tornadoes in the Midwest and Hurricane Irene. In a letter to Speaker John A. Boehner, the president wrote that the added money would help bolster the Disaster Relief Fund, which is down to less than $900 million, according to W. Craig Fugate, administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency. The House majority leader, Eric Cantor, Republican of Virginia, has said that added money for relief should be matched by budget cuts elsewhere. The administration argues that under the debt-ceiling measure enacted last month, Congress can provide the money without offsets.

headline: An Efficient Move Is No Longer Saved for Clay
text: In the fourth set of his United States Open quarterfinal, Novak Djokovic sprinted forward. His opponent, Janko Tipsarevic, had placed a drop shot low, short, wide and across the court.

headline: 30 Seconds With Desmond Howard
text: Desmond Howard, who was inducted to the College Football Hall of Fame in July, is one of four Heisman Trophy winners who were also named most valuable player in a Super Bowl. Howard, 41, played for five teams in 11 N.F.L. seasons, winning the Super Bowl with the 1996 Green Bay Packers. He holds the N.F.L. record for most punt return yards in a season (875) and the longest kickoff return in Super Bowl history (99 yards). Now a college football analyst for ESPN, Howard has chronicled his Michigan career in the book “I Wore 21: The Legend of Desmond Howard,” which will be released Saturday.

headline: Stronger Cautions Backed on Bone Drugs for Women
text: Two advisory panels to the Food and Drug Administration on Friday recommended increasing the cautionary language on the product labels of bone-building drugs taken by more than five million women in the United States.

headline: In July Data, Inventories Rose More as Sales Fell
text: Inventories at wholesalers rose more in July than a month earlier, bolstered by automobiles and computer equipment, as sales stagnated, the Commerce Department said on Friday.

headline: Charles Dubin, Television Director, Is Dead at 92
text: Charles S. Dubin, whose career as a daring director in television’s early years stalled after he refused to answer questions before Congress about Communist involvement, then robustly rebounded as he went on to direct more episodes of “M*A*S*H” than anyone else, died on Monday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 92.

headline: Perry and Social Security
text: To the Editor:

headline: On Coach’s Long Road to Michigan, His Marriage Provides a Compass
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — Every night when either Brady or Laura Hoke finishes with tooth brushing, one makes sure to put toothpaste on the other’s toothbrush. It is a small sign of the bond between a couple that met in seventh grade, married in college and have thrived while hopscotching through places like Yorktown, Ind.; Kalamazoo, Mich.; and Corvallis, Ore., where life’s consistency came from the soundtrack of marching bands.

headline: Life Is a Game of Doubles
text: Fort Collins, Colo.

headline: Clans Battle for Control as Shabab Loses Ground
text: In Somalia, a weak transitional government is struggling to fill the vacuum left by the Shabab militant group, leaving clans and Islamist militias to battle it out.

headline: The Great Melvino, or Our Mr. Brooks
text: Have you, perchance, decided — as I have — not to spend the weekend re-wallowing in 9/11 with the media? Aside from allowing Saint Rudolph, former tenant of Gracie Mansion, to trumpet once again his self-inflated heroism on that nightmare day, the worst feature of this relentlessly repeated carnival of bitter sights and memories is that it glamorizes the terrorists.

headline: On Anniversary of Attack, Many New Yorkers Will Try Not to Dwell on It
text: Laurel Wells is not going to the official Sept. 11 ceremony on Sunday morning at ground zero.

headline: As an Enemy Retreats, Clans Carve Up Somalia
text: DHOBLEY, Somalia — Adan Dahir Hassan sits in a bald office, wires dangling from the ceiling, handing out death sentences. Recently installed by an Islamist warlord, Mr. Hassan recalled how he had ordered a soldier who had killed a civilian, possibly by accident, to be delivered to the victim’s family, which promptly shot him in the head.

headline: Bloggingheads: Regulating the Regulators
text: Glenn Loury, left, and Ross Levine, both of Brown University, debate the failure of financial regulators.

headline: With Studio Space, Musicians Get Sneakers
text: IF it were not meant to flog sneakers, it could be a sociology experiment. In July, Converse opened a recording studio in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and invited musicians to use it free. Who would come? With the recording industry on life support, who in New York still wants to be a musician?

headline: Lottery Numbers
Artistic Tributes on a Solemn Day
text: DUSK over “The Rising,” the memorial to the Westchester residents who perished during the attacks of Sept. 11, will be ushered in on Sunday evening by the plaintive strains of Samuel Barber’s “Adagio for Strings.” The composition, considered a musical embodiment of grief, will be performed by the Westchester Philharmonic as part of the county’s candlelight ceremony at Kensico Dam Plaza, in Valhalla, commemorating the 10th anniversary of the attacks.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Pipeline Spills Put Safeguards Under Scrutiny
text: DENVER — This summer, an Exxon Mobil pipeline carrying oil across Montana burst suddenly, soiling the swollen Yellowstone River with an estimated 42,000 gallons of crude just weeks after a company inspection and federal review had found nothing seriously wrong.

headline: Two Decades of Spills
text: Since 1990, more than 110 million gallons of crude and petroleum products have spilled from America’s pipeline network.

headline: City Hall to Give Council Role in Bike-Share Program
text: The Bloomberg administration, facing unexpected resistance from the City Council over its plan to bring a large-scale public bike-sharing network to New York, agreed on Friday to hold hearings with politicians and community leaders before the program is up and running.

headline: Re-envisioning Pollock, Paint-Spattered Cowboy
text: Jackson Pollock, the American painter who became famous for pouring and dripping paint on canvases in the mid-20th century, has become a tourist attraction. In Springs, up the road from East Hampton Village, you can visit the house he shared with his wife, the painter Lee Krasner, which also served as the location for the 2000 film “Pollock,” and buy a mouse pad or coffee mug decorated with Pollockesque drips. Nearby is Green River Cemetery, where the grave of Pollock, who died in an alcohol-related car accident in 1956, is marked by a huge boulder. And currently the Pollock experience can be enhanced with “Richard Prince: Covering Pollock” at Guild Hall Museum in East Hampton.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Open Dominated by News of the Weird
text: This United States Open keeps getting weirder and weirder.

headline: And the Good News Is ...
text: Finally, we’re coming to a consensus about what’s wrong with the economy. It’s us. And our bad attitude.

headline: The Delicate Task of Reshaping Remnants of 9/11
text: THE three long, narrow pieces of aluminum being hosed down outside David Boyajian’s  studio in New Fairfield were instantly recognizable — they were about eight feet long, with the distinct corrugations of the exterior cladding that once formed the multistory gothic arches of the World Trade Center towers.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: A Burial for Victims of Flight 93
text: The families of 40 passengers and crew members who lost their lives on Flight 93 have struggled to purchase the land and raise the money to memorialize their loved ones in Shanksville, Pa.

headline: Battle for Libya | Sept. 9, 2011
text: Libyan rebels began what they called full-scale attacks to subdue the loyalist holdouts of Bani Walid and Surt on Friday night.

headline: Mr. Banker, Can You Spare a Dime?
text: Not long ago, I received an e-mail from David Rynecki, an old friend and former colleague who left journalism a half-dozen years ago to become a small businessman. David’s firm, Blue Heron Research Partners, does research for investment professionals; he was writing to share his frustration in trying to build a business in the aftermath of the recession.

headline: G.O.P. Is Cautious in Jobs Response
text: WASHINGTON — Armed with worrisome poll data and seeking to maintain the legislative upper hand, Congressional Republicans who have spent the balance of the year pouring buckets of criticism on the Obama administration are shifting to a more restrained approach as they ponder how to respond to the president’s jobs plan.

headline: Get Me Rewrite: It’s a Fresh ‘Newsies’
text: THE 1992 Disney movie “Newsies,” inspired by the 1899 newsboy strike against the publishing tycoons Joseph Pulitzer and William Randolph Hearst, was hardly a box-office smash.

headline: Heroism and Resistance Amid the March of the Nazis
text: Hannah Senesh was a remarkable young woman whose short life (1921-1944) exemplified selfless bravery and idealism in the midst of the Holocaust.

headline: A New Start for Libya
text: After 42 years of erratic dictatorship, it would be unrealistic to expect a smooth transition in the early days of Libya’s post-Qaddafi era. There have been water and fuel shortages, episodes of vigilante justice, and power struggles among the victorious rebel forces. There are also signs of progress on military, diplomatic, economic and political fronts.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Devoted to Keeping Lobster Divers of Honduras Alive
text: La Ceiba, Honduras AT a modest clinic down a dirt road, there are rocking chairs on the front porch and a hyperbaric chamber in the front room where Dr. Elmer Mejía treats deep-sea lobster divers who arrive paralyzed but walk out days later.

headline: The Enlightened Rich Want to Be Taxed
text: Some of the world’s wealthiest people are calling for higher taxes on the rich. They seem to recognize that the burden of the economic downturn cannot be borne entirely by the poor and middle class.

headline: Saturday: Man of Steel
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Oh boy. I like David Quarfoot puzzles. They don’t come up nearly enough for my taste, but when they do, you can definitely see the youth in the entries. Fresh. Crunchy. Scrabbly. Good.

headline: Violent Protest in Cairo
text: A demonstration that brought tens of thousands to this city’s central Tahrir Square turned violent on Friday.

headline: They Want to Re-up
text: The end of discrimination against openly gay men, lesbians and bisexuals in the military takes effect officially on Sept. 20. As historic as that good news is, it is further burnished by word that hundreds of veterans ousted by the “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy want to rejoin military service.

headline: At a 9/11 Site, a ‘Last Funeral’
text: SHANKSVILLE, Pa. — Jerry Bingham, whose 31-year-old son was a passenger on United Airlines Flight 93 when it crashed near here a decade ago, has participated in so many memorial services for his son Mark that he can barely remember them all.

headline: September on a Patio: Bring a Sweater and Enjoy
text: I LOVE to eat dinner outside in September, when mosquitoes call a general cease-fire and the sun gives way in a hurry to dusk, leaving a nip in the air. You can pull a sweater around your shoulders and linger at the table, extending the day, and the season, just a bit longer.

headline: For an American in Paris, a Stern Lecture by Police and an Exploded Suitcase
text: PARIS — When the stern policeman finished his lecture, I turned to my sister, Paula, whose command of French puts mine to shame, and said, “You know, it’s funny, for a second there, I thought he said they exploded my suitcase.”

headline: Syrian Protesters Call for International Protection From President Assad’s Crackdown
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Tens of thousands of Syrians took to the streets on Friday to call for international protection from President Bashar al-Assad’s crackdown on pro-democracy activists who have been trying to topple his government for more than five months.

headline: Somalia: A Country Broken Into Pieces
text: Warlords and clan-based militias are creating ministates in Somalia.

headline: In the Tasting Room, the Cheese Plate Evolves
text: CUTCHOGUE, N.Y.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Fashion's Night Out
text: Fashion’s Night Out marked its third year on Thursday with an extensive turnout. Fifth Avenue suggested Times Square on New Year’s Eve.

headline: The Goal Standard
text: This weekend’s issue of T: The New York Times Style Magazine includes something for soccer fans, as Tim Adams looks at Alex Ferguson, the man who built the team by which most of the rest are measured, and the photographer Max Vadukul makes him and some of his current and former players look like the sexiest team on earth. Online, Rob Hughes offers a peek inside the club’s Carrington training ground, where all those trophies were cultivated. The Arsenal and Chelsea fans among you should probably skip the articles — too painful — but T has something for you, too. Like the chance to chuckle at a photo of Wayne Rooney in a $5,000 Tom Ford overcoat. What’s more likely to be in the breast pocket: a cellphone, a Twix bar or a fancy new tortoise shell hairbrush?

headline: Catching a Wave and Some Cash Off Long Island
text: LONG BEACH, N.Y. — In crisp, overhead barrels, the Quiksilver Pro New York competition concluded Friday with a display of performance surfing that highlighted both the past and the immediate future of the sport.

headline: White House Plans Effort to Refinance Mortgages
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is seeking to broaden access to a two-year-old refinancing program that has helped far fewer homeowners take advantage of low interest rates than initially expected.

headline: Hooky-Playing Crowds and Strong Waves Energize Competition
text: LONG BEACH, N.Y. — There were plenty of reasons to be skeptical of Quiksilver Pro’s inaugural surfing contest in New York, among them the quality of the waves and the effects of Tropical Storm Irene, which had damaged the community and threatened to dampen the enthusiasm for the event. Indeed, the festival that accompanied the event, including skateboard, motocross and music events, was canceled.

headline: Strong Waves and Crowds Energize Competition
text: Images from the Quiksilver Pro New York surfing event in Long Beach, N.Y.

headline: Instead of a Runway, a Half-Pipe Ramp
text: Oil and water. Cats and dogs. Stilettos and subway grates.

headline: The Fields of Our Youth
text: Sullivan Farm has been a part of Litchfield County’s fertile landscape for 170 years. Its undulating fields are dotted with corn, tomatoes, pumpkins, squash and more; the retail shop, a red barn with windows and doors trimmed in white, is the very model of a Connecticut farm store.

headline: Array of Greek Dishes, Best Served Outdoors
text: GREEK restaurants in Fairfield County exist, but they are not ubiquitous. In New Canaan, Kouzina is actually a first. The name means “kitchen” in Greek, which implies a casual setting — an apt description of this luncheonette-style cafe, although “plain” would be a more accurate assessment of its interior. Weather permitting, it is much more pleasant to sit outside and enjoy the pedestrian traffic.

headline: Barking Dogs and Other Threats to Backyard Diplomacy
text: AS the old saying goes, good fences make good neighbors, but as I’ve found out, it’s more complicated than that. Is the fence on the right side of the property line? Are there any overhanging branches or roots sneaking under the fence? Is there a really annoying dog barking behind that fence?

headline: From Wall Street to a Bakery
text: After working for three years as a credit underwriter on Wall Street, Tracy Silverman left the world of finance behind in 2008 and threw herself into her second career and true love: baking. She graduated in 2009 from the Institute of Culinary Education in Manhattan, apprenticed at Brownie Points Bakery in Summit, then opened her own shop, Sweet Lucy’s, in March in a former bank.

headline: Quad Q&A: Michigan Coach Brady Hoke
text: When Brady Hoke was hired as Michigan’s coach, his first three congratulatory phone calls were from Tom Brady, Charles Woodson and Steve Hutchinson. Hoke has returned some swagger and bravado to the Wolverines after Rich Rodriguez’s inglorious three-year stay in Ann Arbor. Hoke has talked big in promising that in Year 132 of Michigan football that everyone will be accountable, right down to the managers and grounds crew. “There’s consequences for losing,” he said, flatly. So who is Brady Hoke? He sat down for an extended interview during training camp about everything from his desire to work in the Secret Service, to marrying his junior high sweetheart and whether he would make Denard Robinson tie his shoes.

headline: With a Bite of Fish, the Sound of the Surf
text: TWO visits in August produced two different experiences at the Dauphin Grille in Asbury Park. The first, on a patio within earshot of the surf on a busy Saturday night, earned a solid A for effort and a low C for execution. The second, in a nearly deserted dining room on a Thursday night, again earned an A for effort. But that time, execution was a solid B, sometimes rising to an A.

headline: Rise of the Fallen?
text: The man was on fire!

headline: Corrections: September 10
text: NEW YORK

headline: Recent Pipeline Ruptures in the U.S.
text: An analysis shows that the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration is chronically short of inspectors and struggling to safeguard a transport network laced with risks.

headline: For Museum and Memorial, Issues of Money and Fence-Mending Lie Ahead
text: On Sunday, 3,652 days after it was reduced to a smoldering pyre, an eight-acre patch of Lower Manhattan will finally be prepared for its ultimate purpose: remembering 2,983 people who were murdered by terrorists.

headline: Titan of Tennis vs. Next Big Thing
text: The United States Open semifinal between Caroline Wozniacki and Serena Williams is a study in contrasts.

headline: Setting Sail to the Barn
text: This is the time of year when projects pile up at the farm. I realize about now that most of the projects I started when the snow melted last spring either need finishing before the snow falls or can never really be completed, like cleaning the barn. Let me not depress you with a list of them. All I know is that instead of pounding posts for a new fence or cleaning up the garden, I’ve been gazing idly at small sailboats for sale on the Web.

headline: Turner Delivers Win for Mets, While Santana Offers Bit of Hope
text: Justin Turner’s arrival with the Mets this season came quickly. Although his defense has been questioned, he reaffirmed his strength at the plate, quickly setting a franchise record for consecutive games with runs batted in.

headline: Bill Kunkel, an Early Chronicler of Video Games, Dies at 61
text: Bill Kunkel, who helped invent video game journalism and create the first video game magazine in the United States, died on Sunday at his home in White Lake, Mich. He was 61.

headline: Crime Is Focus of Guatemala Election
text: As Guatemalans prepare to go to the polls in a presidential election, the dominant issue has been organized crime, by drug cartels and gangs, that has increasingly gripped the country.

headline: Desperate Guatemalans Embrace an ‘Iron Fist’
text: COBÁN, Guatemala — They burned villages, killed children and, just a winding road away from here in 1982, the Guatemalan military also massacred hundreds of Mayan peasants, after torturing old men and raping young women.

headline: Disney Reorganizes Its Retail Sales System
text: The Walt Disney Company said that it would reorganize its approach to mass-market retailers and named a movie distribution executive to lead the effort. The executive, Robert Chapek, formerly president of distribution for Walt Disney Studios, will take over as president of Disney Consumer Products, succeeding Andrew P. Mooney, who resigned as chairman of that division on Tuesday. Mr. Chapek’s first assignment will involve working with Disney’s various units to create a more consolidated way of interacting with retailers like Wal-Mart. Disney currently handles merchandising in a decentralized fashion. The company’s movie studio controls DVD sales. Disney Consumer Products manages apparel, toys and publishing. Another group oversees packaged video games. That means three different Disney teams typically interface with Wal-Mart and other big-box retailers. Disney’s goal is to increase efficiency by having one point of contact.

headline: The American Jobs Act
text: President Obama’s cost outline for spurring job growth.

headline: Joseph S. Nye: ‘Protect the Homeland’
text: Joseph S. Nye reflects on his Op-Ed from Sept. 25, 2001, about the strategies needed to defeat terrorism.

headline: Third City in Three Days Brings Break in Clouds
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — After three of the wettest, craziest and longest days and nights that the Yankees have endured in years, the team had to travel 2,800 miles to see something they had not seen in days.

headline: Embracing the Game, Preparing for Reality
text: WEST POINT, N.Y. — They were gathered here on the banks of the Hudson at Trophy Point among captured artillery, a one-of-a-kind setting for a one-of-a-kind college football moment. The speaker was First Lt. Tyson Quink, and he was here to remind the Army Black Knights of why each of them had chosen to come to the United States Military Academy, of what the Long Gray Line really meant.

headline: Editorials: The Aftermath of 9/11
text: A collection of editorials traces the Times editorial board’s observations and policy proposals for a shaken country and a shifting world.

headline: Fearing Loss of Weiner’s Seat, Democrats Make a Late Push
text: Panicked Democrats are releasing a barrage of negative television advertising, turning to the national party for a cash infusion and pleading with President Obama’s network of supporters for help as they confront what seemed impossible two months ago: defeat in the heavily Democratic House district last represented by Anthony D. Weiner.

headline: Suns’ Chief Executive Quits, Calling Decision Personal
text: Rick Welts is resigning as the president and chief executive of the Phoenix Suns, only four months after becoming the most prominent sports executive to publicly say that he is gay.

headline: Off the Track in Honor of an Ill Friend
text: Lukas Verzbicas is one of only five Americans to run a mile in less than four minutes in high school, but he is more than a track star. Now an 18-year-old freshman at Oregon, he will be a medal favorite Sunday in the junior world championships — in the triathlon — in Beijing. He did not plan on riding and swimming this summer, but he made an impulsive decision on March 8.

headline: Jordan Belson, Experimental Filmmaker, Dies at 85
text: Jordan Belson, an experimental filmmaker whose work — abstract, mutable and hypnotic — is a series of studies of color, movement and light, died on Tuesday at his home in San Francisco. He was 85.

headline: Sidney H. Asch, a Judge and a Scholar, Is Dead at 92
text: Sidney H. Asch, a New York judge with a Ph.D. in sociology who wrote scholarly works about civil liberties and made notable decisions about landlord-tenant law, employment of gay people and a man’s right to get his hair cut in a women’s beauty salon, died on Sept. 1 in a nursing home in North Carolina. He was 92.

headline: Belgian Prevails in Quebec
text: Philippe Gilbert of Belgium, who has won 23 races this year, passed Cadel Evans, the winner of this year’s Tour de France, as the leader of the World Tour points ranking with a victory in the Grand Prix of Quebec. Robert Gesink made several attempts to catch Gilbert but finished three seconds behind. Levi Leipheimer was the first American, finishing fifth.

headline: Quiet Bats Doom Yankees to a Loss in the Ninth
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Jet-lagged and water-logged, a weary group of Yankees finally played baseball under perfectly dry conditions Friday night. For the first time in four days, there was nary a hint of moisture in the air, but there was also scant offense.

text: A selection of news from around the country.

headline: Q&A: Security Expert Faults India’s Counter-Terrorism Preparations
text: Ajai Sahni is a founding member and executive director of the Institute for Conflict Management, a New Delhi-based think tank focused on counter-terrorism, as well as a member of the Council for Security Cooperation in the Asia Pacific, a pan-Asian academic group that advises governments.

headline: Japan Investigates Online Posting of Obama Flight Plans
text: TOKYO — Japanese officials moved to control diplomatic damage after an air traffic controller was questioned here for posting secret American flight information on his blog, including the detailed flight plans of Air Force One last November.

headline: In Afghanistan, ‘Unbelievable Force of Life’
text: Zalmai Ahad, known professionally as Zalmai, is an Afghan photographer. Now 47, he moved to Switzerland when he was 15. He was featured on Lens in September 2009, when his work on Afghanistan was a highlight of the Visa Pour l’Image photojournalism festival in Perpignan, France. He has been photographing Afghanistan for almost 10 years.

headline: After Attack on Embassy, Egypt Vows a Tougher Stance on Protests
text: CAIRO — Acknowledging a credibility crisis after it allowed a mob to invade the Israeli Embassy here, the military-led transitional government said Saturday night that it would exploit a reviled “emergency law” allowing extra-judicial detentions as part of a new crackdown on disruptive protests.

headline: Will Jets’ Offense Regress in 2011?
text: Chase Stuart of Pro-Football-Reference.com is weighing in on the 2011 Jets.

headline: In Radio Address, Obama Says, ‘We’ve Taken the Fight to Al Qaeda’
text: WASHINGTON — On the eve of the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, President Obama called for continued vigilance against terrorist threats, but declared that Al Qaeda and other groups “are no match for the character of our people, the resilience of our nation or the endurance of our values.”

text: NEAR BANI WALID, Libya — A rebel push to take control of the loyalist holdout Bani Walid stalled Saturday after encountering resistance, with rebel spokesmen giving varying accounts of the fighting there and NATO carrying out airstrikes against the defenders.

headline: Urban Forager | That Gasoline Smell? Time for Guacamole
text: I was walking recently with a friend near Stuyvesant Town, on the East Side of Manhattan, when we spied a low-lying plant, about knee-high, growing just outside an apartment building. The leaves gave off the unmistakable scent of gasoline that is characteristic of epazote. I immediately considered the culinary possibilities: guacamole, quesadillas or black-bean dip?

headline: Germany Recommends Asmussen for Central Bank Post
text: MARSEILLE, France (AP) — Germany’s finance minister said Saturday that he wanted his long-serving deputy to succeed Jürgen Stark, who resigned unexpectedly, on the executive board of the European Central Bank.

headline: Ristretto | The Coffee Collective in Torvehallerne
text: I was recently in Copenhagen, where I took a sneak peek at the Coffee Collective’s new coffee bar in Torvehallerne, a gastro-complex of modernist glass sheds that opened last week. Copenhagen’s amenities might be the envy of the civilized world — that airport, those parks, a network of bike paths so comprehensive and easy to use that cars are almost pointless — but until Torvehallerne, the city didn’t have a central food hall.

headline: A Burial for Victims of Flight 93

headline: Small-Business Owners Respond to Obama Plan
text: President Obama, in his speech on Thursday before a joint session of Congress, promised to deploy the power of the federal government to induce small businesses to hire out-of-work Americans. But even some of the small-business owners who watched the speech live in the House chamber at the White House’s invitation said they would not be swayed by the carrots the president proposed to dangle.

headline: Starkness Falls
text: Update: Via Mark Thoma, similar sentiments from Barry Eichengreen; see addendum at the end.

headline: Are These Men the Best Ever? Making the Case
text: In the U.S. Open’s men’s semi-finals’ matches being played in Arthur Ashe today, the four best men’s players will be on the court — not simply the four best of this moment, which they surely are, and by no small measure: Andy Murray, the tour’s fourth-ranked player, is 2,300 points ahead of fifth-ranked David Ferrer, 2,300 being more than half the points Ferrer has accumulated in the past twelve months.

headline: With Vettel on Pole,  the First Female Racer Reflects
text: Every country in which Formula One has a race attracts a certain number of local residents who are not seen at other races. Phil Hill would often come all the way from the United States to visit the race at Monza, where he won the world title – as I mention in today’s F1 preview. Monza also tends to attract Luca di Montezemolo, the Ferrari president who occasionally visits other races.

headline: For the Poet Laureate, the Joy of Tennis Is in the Effort
text: After a summer of dispiriting headlines, one piece of news made me yelp with joy: Philip Levine was named poet laureate of the United States. I was happy because I have loved his sublime, subversive poems for years; now, more people would read his work. And I was happy because the new poet laureate loves tennis, and was a pretty good player.

headline: In K.C., Nice House, but Yard Needs Work
text: KANSAS CITY, Kan. — It has been lauded as perhaps the best soccer stadium in the country, but Sporting Kansas City’s Livestrong Sporting Park has received some negative attention recently for one of its most integral parts: the grass playing surface.

headline: California Lawmakers Give Amazon Tax Reprieve
text: SAN FRANCISCO — California lawmakers overwhelmingly approved a compromise bill Friday night giving Amazon.com a one-year reprieve from having to collect a sales tax from its customers in the state.

headline: For Federer, It’s All About Court Position

You can also follow Paul on Twitter for additional updates throughout the afternoon and evening.

headline: In Seeking Statehood, Palestinians Stir Concern
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — Less than two weeks before Palestinians plan to defy the Obama administration by requesting membership and statehood recognition at the United Nations, there is a growing fear that the Arab-Israeli conflict is entering an explosive new phase.

headline: Ties of Tennis
text: Rich Lynch of Queens was one of the best young tennis players on the East Coast in the early 1980s. Years after his tennis career was over, on Sept. 11, 2001, Lynch found himself on the 84th floor of the World Trade Center’s south tower.

headline: German Nominated to Central Bank Post

headline: A Snapshot of the World, Hours Before It Changed Forever
text: The front page of The New York Times from Sept. 12, 2001, with its “U.S. ATTACKED” headline, has become one of the more widely seen images of Sept. 11 attacks.

headline: The Trouble With Homework
text: Annie Murphy Paul is the author of “Origins" and is at work on a new book about the science of learning.

headline: Golden Spikes
text: As some readers may have guessed, I’m having some fun thinking about gold price economics — nothing like a good intellectual puzzle to keep you occupied while the world collapses. Anyway, some people have asked about previous gold price fluctuations, and in particular whether my low-interest-rate story can fit with the last time gold soared.

headline: A Time When Anything Was Possible
text: He was a tennis prodigy from an Irish Catholic family in Douglaston Manor, a leafy neighborhood in Queens. A gifted athlete, he swayed back and forth at the baseline before attacking the net behind a wicked left-handed serve. He played with a wooden Dunlop racket, wore Sergio Tacchini clothes and gracefully moved around the court in Nike shoes.

headline: Tournament Has Suffered in This Year of the Plague
text: In this year of the deluge, the symbol of the United States Open remains the water oozing in the surface of Louis Armstrong Stadium, alongside the soggy estuary of Flushing Bay.

headline: Djokovic Defeats Federer to Advance to Open Final
text: Following a script eerily similar to that of the U.S. Open semifinal the two played last year, Novak Djokovic saved two set points to defeat Roger Federer, 6-7(7), 4-6, 6-3, 6-2, 7-5, booking a spot in his second consecutive Open final.

headline: Want to Inspire? Don’t Sugarcoat Your Feedback
text: This interview with  Tiffany Cooper Gueye, chief executive of BELL, a nonprofit organization that assists urban children, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Florida Forces Towns to Pull Local Laws Limiting Guns
text: MIAMI — The signs — “No Guns Allowed” — are being stripped from many Florida government buildings, libraries and airports. And local ordinances that bar people from shooting weapons in their yards, firing up into the air (think New Year’s Eve) or taking guns into parks are coming off the books.

headline: Let’s Twist Again, Like We Did in ’61
text: “COME on baby, let’s do the Twist.”

headline: In Shanksville, Thousands Gather to Honor Flight 93 Victims
text: SHANKSVILLE, Pa. — The dedication of a memorial here on Saturday to the 40 passengers and crew members who died on United Airlines Flight 93 on Sept. 11, 2001, provided an opportunity for two former presidents to appeal for unity.

headline: In Mixed Doubles, a Title for the Americans
text: In the category of unexpected Grand Slam champions, it would be hard to top the fresh-faced pair that captured the 2011 mixed doubles trophy at the U.S. Open. Nineteen-year-old Melanie Oudin and 18-year-old Jack Sock, a wild card entry playing together for the first time, beat No. 8 seeds Gisela Dulko and Eduardo Schwank of Argentina 7-6(4), 4-6, 10-8 Friday evening to give the United States its first championship of the tournament.

headline: New York Fashion Week Diary | Tom Bull
text: Isaac Hindin Miller of Isaac Likes follows the breakout Aussie model Tom Bull as he navigates New York Fashion Week. In this clip, Bull tells T about the struggles of staying in shape during Fashion Week. “I really do try my hardest to eat as healthily aspossible,” Bull says. “It gets really hard when you’re flying two nights a week and staying in hotels.” Sigh.

headline: Google Warns Users in Iran About Security Issue
text: Google took the unusual step of warning Gmail users in Iran to “secure their accounts,” a week after an unidentified hacker generated fake Web site verification certificates that may have allowed the Iranian state to monitor communications by its citizens, including dissidents.

headline: Making Headway in the Movement to Protect the World’s Sharks
text: For sharks, life at the top of the ocean food chain is becoming safer — at least from human predators.

headline: Yemen Forces Are Said to Be at Taken City
text: SANA, Yemen — Yemeni armed forces freed a cornered military brigade and appear to be preparing to enter the city of Zinjibar, which has been under the control of Islamic militants for months, according to the official Saba news agency.

headline: In Case You Wondered, a Real Human Wrote This Column
text: “WISCONSIN appears to be in the driver’s seat en route to a win, as it leads 51-10 after the third quarter. Wisconsin added to its lead when Russell Wilson found Jacob Pedersen for an eight-yard touchdown to make the score 44-3 ... . ”

headline: Japanese Official Resigns Over Radiation Joke
text: TOKYO — Just over a week after he took office, Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda of Japan suffered his first political setback on Saturday when the new minister of trade and industry resigned after a joke about radiation caused a public uproar.

headline: Remote Control, With a Wave of a Hand
text: PLAYING a computer game once meant sitting on the couch and pushing buttons on a controller, but those buttons have been disappearing of late, replaced by human gestures that guide the action.

headline: For Sanchez, a Season to Become a Presence, Not Merely Present
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — If a quarterback’s rookie year is roughly equivalent to an endless first day of school, learning playbooks and defenses instead of locker combinations and classroom assignments, then his third season is akin to his going away to college. No more pampering, no more coddling, no more excuses. For Mark Sanchez, MetLife Stadium will double as his freshman dormitory — if more than 80,000 people were paying to watch him study.

headline: Uptown/Downtown
text: Friday night, after checking out a cheeky and borderline shameful Parke & Ronen runway show that suggested the male modeling industry may soon be facing its own steroid scandal, I popped over to Jason Wu’s afterparty at Adour in the St. Regis Hotel. After muscle-bound mutants in skimpy swimwear, it was a pleasure to see some grown-ups in evening attire. Nacho Figueras and Delfina Blaquier looked smashing, he in a sharp black suit, she in a one-shouldered black dress, standing next to a D.J. booth that was covered over with hydrangea blossoms. I almost had my appetite back when I picked up what appeared to be a mint-colored petit four, only to bite into a watercress-wrapped piece of salmon.

headline: Battery Park, 8:45 A.M.
text: A gathering to mark the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Rag & Bone
text: “It was really embarrassing,” said Revlon’s Global Artistic Director, Gucci Westman, dressed in a tweed aqua blazer, baggy white pants and leopard slippers backstage at Rag & Bone. “My husband (Rag & Bone designer David Neville) called and said, ‘Where are you? We need the turquoise trousers for the show.'” By accident, Westman had selected a look that made it into the final collection, instead of an edit, to wear today, a mistake that was quickly corrected. “It’s the strongest Spring, yet,” she said explaining her excitement at the ’70s surf vacation and 90s rave culture-inspired pieces. She chose a minimal makeup look, so as not to compete with the bright colors of the clothes. Eyes were simply taupe Revlon 16H shadow in Addictive with a touch of Sueded Brow liner. Cheeks were tinted with a light bronzer and blush in Tawny Peach while lips were pale pink, coated with shine and patted with powder. “Personally, I don’t think lip gloss is cool.” What is cool– and consistently Rag & Bone– appears to be grey nails. Jin Soon Choi took last season’s slate to a lighter shade of concrete- Revlon’s Smoky Canvas or Hazy. As for hair, Guido Palau admitted the idea was “effortless,” though the process was anything but. “Eighty percent of the New York designers want ease. It always looks glamorous,” he said. To achieve this, Palau tightly braided the underside of the models’ hair and then added extensions for length to create the illusion of fineness. He then used Redken Satinwear all over damp hair which he dried with a Mason Pearson brush and Sultra tools. The hair was then clamped at the neck with a Velcro strap to create a bob-like effect. Ah, this explains the rave reference.

headline: How to Make Business Want to Invest Again
text: DURING the last week, the nation has witnessed much partisan wrangling over the economy. So it might be worth stepping back and assessing what we know and what we don’t. Let’s start with five propositions about which there is little doubt:

headline: Getting Back to a Grand Bargain
text: THIS is not an easy time to be president or minority leader. Our cupboard is bare, and the only thing we have in surplus is political venom. Indeed, if political venom could be turned into a transportation fuel, we’d be energy independent today.

headline: We’re Rich! (In Nature.)
text: AT a time when Americans fret about terrorism and war and are afflicted by the worst economic downturn in 70 years, let’s embrace a remarkable treasure possessed by every citizen of our country.

headline: Loss and Hope
text: It is painful and puzzling to look back to that day, to the chasm after the second tower fell, when we knew nothing except that fires were burning, an untold number of lives had been lost, and Lower Manhattan was gasping in a cloud of what looked like Pompeian ash. That morning’s terrible events marked a border between one realm and another, a boundary none of us would ever wish to have crossed. Everything had changed — that was how it seemed.

headline: Bicycle Visionary

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Mandy Coon
text: “We usually have a strong beauty concept,” said the stylist Natasha Royt backstage at Mandy Coon. “This time it’s modern, approachable, realistic, low maintenance– cool. We want to let the graphic, modern clothes speak for themselves.” Last season’s wig-wrapped hair and black, fringed, pastel falls turned into “effortless glamour” this season, according to Rolando Beauchamp. Loose waves came by way of Bumble + Bumble Gel, a blow dry, and then a one-inch curling iron wrapped at the shaft of the hair, all set with Bumble + Bumble Grooming Creme and roughed up with BB Texture for a messy, matte finish. The last step ensured that nothing was “too pretty or too shiny.” Coon’s color-blocked looks were translated into Mark Rothko-inspired, multi-step eyes at the hands of the makeup artist Francelle Daly for NARS. Lavender-grey Lhasa was the primary shadow. “I’m obsessed with this shade,” Daly said. “It’s rarely used for spring/summer collections.” She also added a trio of pinks with an icy tone at both corners of the eye. The Rue Bonaparte Larger Than Life Eyeliner pencil, a natural beige, was used to neutralize under the eye while white Santa Monica Boulevard lined inside. Madison Avenue grey was drawn as triangles on the outer edge of the lid. Without mascara on the bottom lashes, this all contributed to a “special effect” accompanied by a raspberry lip. An effect that caused one model to comment, “I look like I’ve been crying.” Her friend countered, “No, you look beautiful.”

headline: In Season’s Long March, Every Step Can Be Painful
text: They are young and rich, world travelers who play a gentleman’s game. Hours of training outdoors have given them, men and women alike, bodies that are taut and tanned. Often exceedingly photogenic, they are the smiling faces for some of the world’s most exquisite consumer products.

headline: The Flashy Side of Prabal Gurung
text: Here is something you do not expect to see at a Prabal Gurung fashion show: Nicki Minaj, the colorful hip-hop star who gives Lady Gaga a run for her money in the outrageous attire department, making a slow entrance with John Demsey, the carefully groomed, straight-faced Estée Lauder executive, and followed by an entourage of men wearing black T-shirts that said “$WAG.” Ms. Minaj, who will appear in a new MAC Viva Glam campaign, wore a bikini top that was half hot pink and half purple, some crazy graffiti-covered tights, a silver ballerina skirt and, in her big curly blonde hair, an iridescent pink bow that matched the chain of her necklace that had attached to it a hot pink pendant in the shape of a pretzel.

headline: The New Guy at Lacoste
text: Felipe Oliveira Baptista had a nice debut at Lacoste this morning with a collection that featured women’s looks largely based on rugby shirts, some cool outerwear pieces and, for men, a larger-than-usual piqué used on blazers and polo shirts that looked nice and breathable. Mr. Baptista, who is Portuguese by birth, shows his own line in Paris and took over Lacoste this season from Chistophe Lemaire, who scooted over to Hermès.

headline: Giants’ First Line of Defense Becomes Main Line of Defense
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — On a recent day in the Giants’ locker room, a crowd of reporters lingered near the wall that is defensive-line territory, and the scene was like happy hour at a bar. One segment of the horde surrounded defensive end Justin Tuck, while another hovered near the locker of Osi Umenyiora, the injured All-Pro enigma, hoping for a glimpse of him. A smattering chatted up Jason Pierre-Paul, and at the end of the row, even Chris Canty could not escape without offering a few platitudes.

headline: Quietly, Rivera Nears an Underrated Record
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — With surprisingly little hype and fanfare given the magnitude of the achievement, Mariano Rivera is on the verge of another milestone. After he earns just a few more saves, he will take his place as the career leader in that category, a fitting honor for the man widely considered the greatest closer ever.

headline: On 10th Anniversary of 9/11, Social Media Is a Forum for Reflection
text: To mark the 10th anniversary of the 9/11 attacks, people are using social networks to reflect and to share their memories, thoughts and prayers.

headline: Beyond Cairo, Israel Sensing a Wider Siege
text: JERUSALEM — With its Cairo embassy ransacked, its ambassador to Turkey expelled and the Palestinians seeking statehood recognition at the United Nations, Israel found itself on Saturday increasingly isolated and grappling with a radically transformed Middle East where it believes its options are limited and poor.

headline: Streaks Built on Preparation, Day After Day
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — When Archie and Olivia Manning took their family on vacations, each of their three sons would pack cleats. The boys played catch in Hawaii and ran the beach in Destin, Fla. Days off did not exist.

headline: Susquehanna Floodwaters Recede, but the Threat Remains
text: WILKES-BARRE, Pa. — As the Susquehanna River began a rapid retreat toward its banks Saturday after days of record flooding here and in parts of New York, tens of thousands of evacuated residents began a gut-wrenching return home, some finding little more than mud-caked chaos where their lives used to be.

headline: Surprise Semifinalists, from Evert to Kerber
text: Because its equitable playing surface and place in the calendar present most top players with ample opportunity to succeed, the U.S. Open historically has had fewer unknowns scuttling through the draw than the other three Grand Slams.

headline: So How Do We Best Experience Wilderness?
text: My favorite vacation involves backpacking in the mountains with my family – unplugged, out of contact and engaging with the most beautiful scenery in America. And that’s what inspired my Sunday column: If America’s “best idea” is its public lands, then it’s an idea under assault. But while environmentalists focus on Republican efforts to reduce protections of those lands, it seems to me that an equal challenge is the way the public is withdrawing from nature. Conservation should be about preserving nature, yes, but also about giving people a chance to experience it.

headline: Runway Grooming Report | Antonio Azzuolo
text: Unlike some creatives who choke under pressure, the menswear designer Antonio Azzuolo, a finalist for this year’s CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund, gracefully eased the reins and took a more relaxed approach to his Spring/Summer collection. Mr. Azzuolo explained backstage, “My first collection was very formal, all about suits. This season I designed more liberally, drawing inspiration from Les Minets, a French/British hybrid movement of mod culture. These young men shunned bourgeois culture, but still dressed up. They were rough and rebellious, but chic and sophisticated as well.” Noting the designer’s departure from his norm of neat, the hairstylist Andre Rodman casually styled models’ hair with his hands and a healthy dollop of Shu Uemura Shape Paste, to enhance each guy’s individual hair texture. Mr. Rodman completed looks with a brisk shake of the dryer, along with “lots of Oribe Dry Texturizing Spray, for a subtly messy, matte look.” The makeup artist Gregory Arlt paired hair and clothes with M.A.C. products that conveyed, “Healthy tired. It might sound strange, but we imagined the guys looking warm and attractive, despite their penchant for partying.” Using just moisturizer (as opposed to foundation) for a base, Arlt slathered onto the models’ faces a yet to be released product from M.A.C.- Mineralize Charged Water Moisture Gel (hitting shelves this December). Brows were then defined and filled in with Kid eyeshadow, while lips were smoothed with lip conditioner. Lastly, he dotted on Select Moisturecover Concealer as necessary, so models looked “handsome, even after that long night out.”

headline: Tilda Swinton Talks About ‘Kevin’
text: TORONTO — Parenting has rarely looked as painful and difficult onscreen as it does in Lynne Ramsay‘s drama “We Need to Talk About Kevin,” which screened last night at the Toronto International Film Festival. The film focuses on the experience one woman (Tilda Swinton) has raising a son (Ezra Miller) who turns out to be a very, very bad seed.

headline: At the Open, a Different Role for Women’s Coaches (and the Players)
text: The obstacles male players face when transitioning from A.T.P. Tour events to the Grand Slams are well-documented. Best-of-three matches are traded in for best-of-five, increasing the physical and mental difficulty of winning significantly.

text: After the N.C.A.A.’s meeting last month to discuss the state of college sports, the organization’s president, Mark Emmert, sounded offended when a reporter asked whether the university presidents had addressed having separate commissioners for football and men’s basketball to tackle problems in a timely manner.

headline: The 181st Draft Pick Becomes a Superstar
text: WASHINGTON — The O’Malley family sold the Los Angeles Dodgers in 1998, but artifacts from decades of stewardship remained. One was a brochure for Dodgertown, the lavish spring training campus in Vero Beach, Fla., where Jackie, Pee Wee, Campy and the Duke once roamed. Mike Leuzinger, a longtime team scout, kept the pamphlets after the O’Malleys left. He liked to show his draft picks where they would go to carry on the tradition.

headline: A Breakthrough for Italy by a Player of the World
text: In the 1950s, Domenico Liddi emigrated from Italy to Southern California and found work as a tailor. He took his 2-year-old son, Agostino, and raised him in the United States.

text: Dung Mai, a student at the University of Texas at Arlington, had a hard time taking tests. He would know the material, but once he walked into class, his mind would go blank.

headline: Europe’s Fiscal Fantasies
text: Europe’s leaders believe they can stave off economic disaster without taking real action. They keep pretending that they will not have to ask taxpayers to help shore up fragile banks, that ever larger doses of austerity will let weak economies like Greece pay off their debts, and that Europe can continue to reap the benefits of monetary union without the shared responsibilities of greater fiscal union.

headline: No Job, No Insurance, No Health Care
text: Workers who lose their jobs in the economic downturn typically suffer a double whammy: they lose not only their incomes but their employer-based health insurance as well. Millions are forced to forgo the medical care that they cannot pay for.

headline: Separating the Moment From What Came After
text: A few days after Sept. 11, 2001, I received a stack of drawings and poems in the mail. They were by schoolchildren whose teacher had given them the lead article from The New York Times about the attacks and told them to write and illustrate a poem. Because I wrote the piece, she sent them to me. Many of the children picked up on my description of the planes as “gorged” with fuel, and their jets were huge and red, dwarfing the doomed black towers before them. Some of the drawings also had disproportionately huge stick figures falling from the towers.

headline: Housing for the Truly Vulnerable
text: The recession has made it increasingly difficult for low-income people to afford decent housing. Federal statistics show that record numbers of people now pay more than half their incomes in rent, causing them to skimp on essentials like food, medical care and other basics, and increasing the chances that they will end up homeless.

headline: Mayor in Mexico Rejects Calls to Step Down
text: MEXICO CITY — The mayor of Mexico’s third-largest city, where a fire set in a casino last month left 52 dead, on Saturday rejected a call days earlier from leaders of President Felipe Calderón’s governing party to step down amid questions over his brother’s ties to the gambling industry.

headline: In India, 11-Year Hunger Strike Is Waged in Shadows
text: IMPHAL, India — She arrived in an ambulance, thin and ghostly pale, a tube dangling from her nostril. Flanked by police officers, she was ushered into the judge’s chambers for a fortnightly ritual she has repeated hundreds of times. Was she ready to end her fast?

headline: Legend of a Commander Flourishes, but Can’t Bridge an Afghan Chasm
text: JANGALAK, Afghanistan — Each September, thousands of people flock to this tiny village along the rushing waters of the Panjshir River like pilgrims to a holy shrine, coming to commemorate the death of Ahmed Shah Massoud, the most celebrated hero of the Afghan resistance.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Alexander Wang
text: Backstage at Alexander Wang, 3:30 pm: Liya Kebede, in black jeans and Doc Martens, is having her hair examined by Guido Palau’s team. Nearby, Frankie Rayder is pulling on a black and red plaid lumberjack shirt over the plastic-bag poncho she’s wearing around her neck. It’s a makeshift protective cover for hair damp with product and oil. Like the look at Helmut Lang earlier today, the mandate is “wet,” but Alexander Wang-style, which translates into Palau using Redken’s Full Frame 07 All Over Volume Mousse to coat the head and then finishing off with Argan-6 oil right before the girls go out. “To get a glint in the hair,” is how Mr. Palau explained the addition of the multipurpose product. He is also adding extensions where needed and uses his Sultra curling iron for a little movement. With prints hitting the collection this season, Mr. Palau wanted to be sure the hair was edgy. “Pulled back can look too pretty,” he said, explaining the switch from last season’s low ponytail. “Today she’s let her hair down.” Both Mr. Palau and Diane Kendal agree that Mr. Wang has a very specific vision for his woman. She’s cool, downtown, beautiful and raw, as Ms. Kendal sees it. For makeup, this means M.A.C.’s black kohl pencil blended out around the eye and then removed with M.A.C. studio moisturizer and a cotton swab, only to be reapplied thereafter. There’s nothing on the face or lip. Nails are painted with Sally Hansen’s natural Parchment. Ms. Kendal has done this look before circa 1990. “Calvin went there,” she said before also calling out Helmut Lang. No doubt Mr. Wang remembers this girl and is now making her his own.
