headline: Stosur Reaches First U.S. Open Final With Three-Set Win
text: No. 9 seed Samantha Stosur toughed out a 6-3, 2-6, 6-2 over 92nd-ranked German Angelique Kerber, becoming the first Australian woman to reach the U.S. Open final since Wendy Turnbull in 1977. It will be Stosur’s first career U.S. Open final and second career Grand Slam final.

headline: Mets Pitch to Ramirez and Pay a Price
text: First base was open when Chicago Cubs third baseman Aramis Ramirez, a .300 hitter, walked to the plate with runners at second and third and two outs in the ninth inning Saturday. The Mets were hanging on to a one-run lead in a game that turned from a snooze to a thriller in an instant.

headline: The Ryan Boys: Loud and Clear, Mostly Loud
text: As young coaches, Rex Ryan and Rob Ryan were known as Buddy Ryan’s twins but now, with Rex the Jets’ coach and Rob the Dallas Cowboys’ defensive coordinator, Buddy is better known as their father. With a thud heard round the world of pro football, each of these swaggering apples fell not far from the tree.

text: The commemoration of the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks began in earnest on Saturday, with major ceremonies not only in Shanksville, Pa., but also New Jersey, Lower Manhattan and Midtown Manhattan. Most, if not all, were somber events.

headline: Kemp May Be Most Valuable, but Will Dodgers Pay?
text: As the agent for Matt Kemp, Dave Stewart has an obvious bias in the National League Most Valuable Player Award discussion. But Stewart, the former star pitcher, looks at the recent trend in awards voting and feels good about the chances of his client, who is profiled in the Sunday New York Times.

headline: Getting There Is Just a Piece of the Puzzle
text: ABOARD THE M/V HYAK, Wash. — Washington State Ferries is the largest such system in the United States, but it is small, too. Amid all the comings and goings, the getting theres and leaving heres, there is the middle part — people making their way.

headline: Iraqi Cleric Tells Followers to Halt Attacks
text: BAGHDAD — The anti-American cleric Moktada al-Sadr called on his followers on Saturday to cease their attacks on United States military forces in Iraq, saying that he did not want the Americans to have an excuse to remain in the country, according to a statement posted on a Web site of his political party.

headline: Betty Skelton, Air and Land Daredevil, Dies at 85
text: The “inverted ribbon cut” was one of Betty Skelton’s most daring maneuvers, in which she flew her single-seat, open-cockpit biplane upside down at about 150 miles per hour, maybe 10 feet above the ground, and sliced through a ribbon stretched between two poles.

headline: Battle for Libya | September 10, 2011
text: A rebel push to take the loyalist holdout of Bani Walid stalled after encountering resistance from the defenders.

headline: Christopher Small, Cultural Musicologist, Is Dead at 84
text: Christopher Small, a New Zealand-born writer and musicologist who argued that music is above all an active ritual involving those who play and listen to it and only secondarily a matter of “black dots,” as he once called written music, died on Wednesday in Sitges, Spain. He was 84.

headline: Rodriguez Is Out Again
text: ANAHEIM — With his sprained left thumb not completely healed, Alex Rodriguez was kept out of the lineup for Saturday night’s game against the Los Angeles Angels. Yankees Manager Joe Girardi said Rodriguez would be shelved for the next three to four days.

headline: Close Loss Raises Pressure on Georgia’s Coach
text: ATHENS, Ga. — There is little vitriol in sports, both in pitch and emotion, that compares with a Southeastern Conference fan base fed up with its coach.

headline: A Nation Remembers
text: Americans took part in ceremonies and other events commemorating the 10th anniversary of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: In a Show of Power, a Joyful Williams Storms Into the Final
text: Serena Williams screamed, but it was nothing like the cry that pierced Arthur Ashe Stadium the last time she had appeared in a United States Open semifinal.

headline: Utilitarian Streetwear by Alexander Wang
text: Mesh was a strong look at Alexander Wang’s show this afternoon, held in his usual space on a pier on the West Side Highway, seen in the loose-fitting parkas, bombers and anoraks that opened the collection in an inky color he called “petrol.” They were shown over bright blue and orange polo shirts in technical fabrics that constituted Mr. Wang’s nod to the color trend of the season. It’s nice to see several designers continuing to show sporty jackets for spring, reprising a dominant look from the fall collections. Fashion has been moving so fast these days, I was half afraid they would have already moved on to something else.

headline: Display of Sportsmanship Makes News at World Cup
text: Cheating and temper tantrums get a lot of attention at chess tournaments, but two players at the World Cup are making news for all the right reasons.

headline: Bruce Dan, Who Helped Link Toxic Shock and Tampons, Is Dead at 64
text: Dr. Bruce Dan, who as a leading federal researcher helped establish a link between the life-threatening disease toxic shock syndrome and the use of tampons, prompting a major shift in the way tampons are produced, died Tuesday in Baltimore. He was 64.

headline: Employee Lawsuit Exacerbates Issues at Livermore Lab
text: Marian Barraza, like many who have worked at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, considered Livermore more than just an employer. Mrs. Barraza, a soft-spoken administrator, worked at Livermore, the federal weapons research lab, for 38 years. She met her husband there. One of the couple’s two daughters and many of Mrs. Barraza’s friends still work there.

headline: Arranging the Music for Austin’s Influential Festival
text: Amy Corbin has been pursuing Stevie Wonder for years. He’s been on a shortlist, alongside Bruce Springsteen and Radiohead, of acts Ms. Corbin has long hoped would agree to headline the Austin City Limits Music Festival. This year she got her man. Mr. Wonder, Coldplay and Arcade Fire are among the 130 acts that will draw 75,000 people each day next weekend to Zilker Park in Austin for the three-day festival’s 10th anniversary.

headline: Caldecott Tunnel Edges Forward, Tribute to Stimulus Bill
text: On Thursday morning, miners deep in the fourth bore of the Caldecott Tunnel spent 10 grueling hours drilling six feet farther into the bedrock.

headline: Wanting the Hard to Get Simply Because It Is
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Alderman Narrows Her Chicken Ban and Tries Again
text: Alderman Lona Lane is hard boiled when it comes to her vendetta against live chickens raised in the city.

headline: Homer Lane
text: A tiny street near Palo Alto in an unincorporated part of San Mateo County is one of the few relics of the days when the area was a hotbed of anti-Vietnam War sentiment, groovy rock music and experimental drugs. Currently, 10 families live in a string of cottages at the end of the road. JAMIE HANSEN

headline: Williams Overpowers Wozniacki and Advances to Final
text: Shrugging off the effect of a bandaged right foot layered with adhesive, Serena Williams of the United States bounded into the U.S. Open women’s final with a 6-2, 6-4 victory over Caroline Wozniacki of Denmark, the world’s top ranked and top seeded player.

headline: Lottery Numbers
U.S. Open Point/Counterpoint: Roger Federer vs. Pete Sampras
text: Fantasy U.S. Open Tournament: Who are the two greatest U.S. Open champions from the past 30 years? It’s up to you to decide, with a little help from The Times’s tennis experts. Watch our video debates, vote on the winner and then explain your position in the comments section. The winner from this match will advance to the finals of our virtual tournament. View the bracket.

headline: State Challenging Hospitals’ Tax Exemptions
text: Facing a budget deficit exceeding $11 billion, the State of Illinois in recent weeks has begun challenging the property tax exemptions of some of its best-known hospitals, saying they should pay more because they are not providing enough charity care.

headline: Who’s That Guy Behind the Plate?
text: ANAHEIM, Calf. — For the first time all season, Jorge Posada is behind the plate catching for the Yankees.

headline: United Flight Attendants Gather to Mourn 5 Colleagues
text: SHANKSVILLE, Pa. — As dusk settled over the Flight 93 National Memorial here Saturday night, a group of 70 United flight attendants in their crisp blue uniforms came to stand vigil for their five colleagues who went down with the plane on Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: Leppert Runs a Campaign of Ideas, on an Uphill Track
text: Like other Texas politicians before him — Republican Tom Luce and Democrat John Odam come to mind — Tom Leppert, a former mayor of Dallas, is trying to attract support for his Senate campaign with a detailed jobs program that combines his business experience with his public-policy vision. His seven-second sound bite? “You just can’t put this in a seven-second sound bite.”

headline: Teachers Must Clean Up Mess Left by Budget Cuts
text: DRIPPING SPRINGS, Tex. — Just as Judy Gardner answered the phone on Wednesday afternoon, a coach stuck his head into her empty classroom.

headline: A Very Festive Weekend for Sony Classics
text: TORONTO— It was a big night Saturday for Sony Pictures Classics at the Toronto International Film Festival, but that seems to be true of the entire weekend. Sony’s arthouse unit and its two co-presidents, Michael Barker and Tom Bernard, have been celebrating the company’s 20th anniversary with a series of parties that just keeps getting longer.

text: The second week of the season saw Georgia struggle again and U.S.C. escape with a win.

headline: Cliff Robertson, Oscar-Winning Rebel, Dies at 88
text: Cliff Robertson, the ruggedly handsome actor who won an Oscar for “Charly” but found himself frozen out of jobs for almost four years after he exposed a prominent Hollywood studio boss as a forger and embezzler, died Saturday on Long Island. He was 88 and lived in Water Mill, N.Y.

headline: Parts of Dulles International Airport Temporarily Evacuated

headline: Downtown’s Rebirth, 10 Years and $24 Billion Later
text: A DECADE after the Sept. 11 attack, downtown Manhattan is resurgent. The residential population has doubled. Two skyscrapers — 1 and 4 World Trade Center — are rising at ground zero, due to open in 2013. The next year, the exuberant PATH transit hub is scheduled to come online. The national memorial is open; two streets have been built. A far more diverse array of businesses call downtown home today, including a large cluster of media companies, law firms and nonprofit organizations. And just last week, both the northbound and southbound platforms of the Cortlandt Street subway station were open.

headline: Suit Up
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#713", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);“This is our life!!” e-mails Maayan Zilberman when asked if she and her design partner, Nikki Dekker, of the Lake and Stars ever wear swimsuits as bodysuits. “”We were both wearing bikini tops as bras, with the straps poking out at the tops of our tanks when we met,” says Dekker days later, in their TriBeCa studio. True to form, the Lake and Stars label is all about intimates that can be purposefully layered to wear with outerwear. “Our lingerie lives in the world of fashion,” says Zilberman about their four-year-old line. In anticipation of their presentation today, which includes swimwear for the first time, the Lake and Stars gives T a lesson in wearing bathing suits as bodysuits.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
text: A look at some of the long form Indian journalism India Ink has been reading this week:The much-discussed profile of Arvind Kejriwal, the man who is in many ways the brains behind the Anna Hazare anti-corruption movement, gives some fascinating details of the careful planning and execution of Mr. Hazare’s high-profile fasts. One nugget: when Mr. Hazare and Mr. Kejriwal were planning the first fast in April, “they deliberately selected a date that would fall between the end of the Cricket World Cup and the start of the Indian Premier League.” (The Caravan)

headline: Photos by Pirkle Jones, 1914-2009
text: Pirkle Jones’s images of threatened California towns and valleys and the Black Panthers at the peak of their power made him one of the most admired photographers of his generation.

headline: The Reach of Mexico's Drug Cartels
text: Mexican drug trafficking cartels “represent the greatest organized crime threat to the United States,” according to a recent Justice Department report. The cartels have waged increasingly violent battles with one another, as well as with the Mexican government, which began an aggressive crackdown in 2006.

headline: Drug Violence Invades Tucson
text: Tucson is coping with a wave of drug crime the police suspect is tied to the bloody battles between Mexico’s drug cartels.

headline: West Side Story
text: Okay, I didn’t see Valentino do his karaoke number at the Carine Roitfeld party tonight and maybe I’ll sleep better without that memory. Barneys gave the party, at a former strip club near the West Side Highway, across from Alexander Wang’s even bigger party at Pier 40. I got to the club right after the Joseph Altuzarra show and ran into Max Osterweis and Erin Beatty, the Suno designers. I knew Saturday would be a long day, and it was, starting at 9 a.m. with a tour of the hat exhibit that Stephen Jones has organized at the Bard Graduate Center on the Upper West Side. I saw a bunch of shows, had a good lunch with my friend Simon Ungless, dropped by to see Oscar de la Renta, who was watching the tennis match and casting models, and got locked out of the Christian Siriano show, though I managed to see the clothes backstage. That was around 5 p.m.

headline: What to Watch on Sunday
text: Samantha Stosur is an exciting player who breaks the mold of the typical baseliner. She’s got a big serve, and one of the best forehands going. Where many of her peers will be content to stand back and wait for errors, Stosur prefers to take the offensive — even sneaking into net occasionally.

headline: Yemeni Forces Are Said to Enter Coastal City
text: SANA, Yemen — Yemeni armed forces have entered the city of Zinjibar for the first time since armed Islamic militants seized the southern coastal city in May, according to state-run media.

headline: Historic Madrid Theater Celebrates Spanish Directors
text: Film buffs may recognize Madrid’s Cine Doré from the silent film sequence in Pedro Almódovar’s film “Talk to Her.” But the Art Nouveau movie theater (Calle Santa Isabel, 3; 34-91-369-1125), which is also the public face of Filmoteca Española, a Spanish film preservation association, is very much alive. This month, the theater, which dates to 1923, is screening films from two prominent Spanish directors, Luis García Berlanga and Carlos Saura.

headline: 9/11 Recalled — Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD — September 11. Although it was 10 years ago it was just like yesterday. I was 21 years old when I went home from college, and when I first went into the house my eyes fell on the TV with a live broadcast of the second airplane hitting the tower.

headline: Bush and Obama, Shoulder to Shoulder
text: On Sunday, for the first time, President Obama and former President George W. Bush stood together at the site of the Sept. 11 attacks, listening as family members read the names of lost love ones and bowing their heads in silence to mark the moments the planes hit.

headline: On 9/11, Vows of Remembrance
text: They played the bagpipes again and recited the names of the dead like poetry. Bells tolled, and requiems by President Obama and other dignitaries filled the amphitheater of ground zero on Sunday as America looked back upon a contagion of terrorism and war and renewed its vows of remembrance.

headline: The City Remembers
text: The Tenth Anniversary of the 9/11 Attacks

headline: The Day’s Best in College Football
text: JAMES WHITE The Iowa State running back ran for two touchdowns in overtime to help the Cyclones beat their rival Iowa, 44-41, in three overtimes and give his teammate Stephen Ruempolhamer, right, a chance to hoist the Cy-Hawk Trophy, which is given to the winner.

headline: Ten Years On, Remembering a Day of Grief and Horror
text: A decade later, in a city and a nation transformed, Sept. 11 dawned in the year 2011 and the loved ones of the dead gathered beside where the Twin Towers stood to repeat a memory lesson that harnessed still-raw emotion to factual accounting: the reciting of the names of the 2,983 victims of the terror attacks of 2001.

headline: 4 Suspects Arrested in Swedish Terror Plot
text: LUND, Sweden — Four people were arrested in Goteborg on Saturday night on suspicion of planning acts of terrorism there, the police said. The authorities also evacuated an arts center in the city.

headline: Blast Hits NATO Outpost in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A cargo truck packed with explosives struck a NATO outpost south of the capital late Saturday, killing at least 5 people and wounding dozens more, including 77 members of coalition troops, NATO and Afghan officials said Sunday.

headline: Marking the 9/11 Anniversary
text: Visitors gathered at ground zero for the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks.

headline: The Years of Shame
text: Is it just me, or are the 9/11 commemorations oddly subdued?

headline: At Pentagon, No Words Will Fill Void
text: WASHINGTON — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Sunday told the families of the 184 men, women and children killed at the Pentagon a decade ago that “I know what it’s like to receive that call out of the blue that the dearest thing in your life is gone.”

headline: Tennis Video Games Have a History But Not Yet a Big Hit
text: Tennis has had a historically important, if sometimes forgotten, role in the history of video games. As the U.S. Open concludes at Flushing Meadows, it’s worth looking roughly 60 miles east of the U.S.T.A. Billie Jean King National Tennis Center, where one of the first video games ever made was a tennis game, created more than 50 years ago on Long Island.

headline: The Spanish Prisoner
text: One of the good ideas in Paul De Grauwe’s now-essential paper (pdf) was to do a head-to-head comparison of Spain and the UK to illustrate the problems the euro faces. Here’s an update.

headline: In Pennsylvania, a Wall of Names
text: SHANKSVILLE, Pa. — The sun rose brightly here on Sunday morning, burning off the mist that hovered over the field where United Airlines Flight 93, hurtling through the sky at more than 575 miles per hour, crashed on Sept. 11, 2001. At the moment of impact, 10:03 a.m., the field was empty.

headline: 9/11 Recalled — Fort Benning
text: Under a blue, cloudless sky I waddled along the flight line toward a waiting C-130 Hercules. This was going to be my second jump, and the first with combat equipment. The day prior I had taken my first jump, and with four more I would earn my Airborne wings. I was nervous about getting injured.

headline: Vettel Cruises to Victory, and Nearly Almost a Second World Title
text: MONZA, Italy — Sebastian Vettel drove to an easy victory in his Red Bull at the Italian Grand Prix on Sunday, winning his eighth race of the season and extending his grip on the championship lead. With six races left in the series, he is in an unassailable position.

headline: What to Watch Sunday: Junior Finals
text: Caroline Garcia versus Grace Min, Court 7, noon — Garcia, the No. 1 seed, has powered her way to a final of a junior slam after having reached the semifinals in the other three this year. The 17-year-old from France, who has lost only one set in her five victories this week, is a big favorite over the unseeded Grace Min of the United States. But an upset is certainly possible if Min can sustain the level of play she displayed in her semifinal victory over Nicole Gibbs, who was also a semifinalist for the N.C.A.A. singles title.

headline: At Toronto Film Festival, Los Angeles Has Some Screen Time
text: TORONTO — Aficionados of the Los Angeles street film — “Colors,” “Collateral,” “To Live and Die in L.A.,” the list is endless — might be a little surprised by “Rampart,” Oren Moverman’s latest contribution to the genre. Mr. Moverman’s movie, which stars Woody Harrelson as a cop who makes all the wrong turns, has been screening at the Toronto International Film Festival here.

headline: Somali Gunmen Attack British Tourists in Kenya
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — A boatload of Somali gunmen attacked an exclusive beach resort in Kenya on Sunday, killing a British tourist and kidnapping his wife before racing back into Somalia, Western diplomats said.

headline: How Are You Marking the 9/11 Anniversary?
text: As the official Sept. 11 commemorations take place at ground zero, in Shanksville, Pa., and at the Pentagon, millions of people around the world are reflecting on the 10-year anniversary in their own private ways. We asked our readers on Facebook to tell us how they are spending the day. Below, a selection of their responses. Use the comments box below to tell us what you’re doing today, or post a comment on our Facebook page.

headline: Victoria Beckham: Fashion Goes On
text: The atmosphere before Victoria Beckham’s runway show at Astor Hall in the New York Public Library Sunday morning was somber, with the lights dimmed and some guests noting the queasiness of getting on with the business of Fashion Week, even as the 9/11 memorial services were taking place downtown. Ms. Beckham did away with her customary routine of narrating each look during the show, though you could still hear her say, “I’d like to start by thanking everyone,” just before the music cut her off.

headline: Stosur vs. Williams: Keys to the Final
text: Most people have already engraved Serena Williams’ name on the U.S. Open women’s singles trophy for 2011 following her dominating semi-final victory over world No. 1, Caroline Wozniacki, Saturday night.

headline: A Journey of Heroism That Led to the Towers
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Halfway through James B. Stewart’s nonfiction book “Heart of a Soldier,” which has been adapted into an opera that had its premiere on Saturday evening at the San Francisco Opera, Rick Rescorla tries to write a novel.

headline: ‘Contagion’ Is No. 1 at Weekend Box Office
text: North American moviegoers, jumping at the chance to see Gwyneth Paltrow and a host of other stars die of a horrible disease, drove “Contagion” to No. 1 at the weekend box office with an estimated $23 million in ticket sales. That Warner Brothers film, directed by Steven Soderbergh and made in conjunction with Participant Media, cost about $60 million to produce; an all-star cast (Kate Winslet, Matt Damon, Laurence Fishburne and Jude Law in addition to Ms. Paltrow) and strong reviews contributed to audience interest. “The Help” (DreamWorks Studios) was second, taking in about $8.7 million for a five-week total of $137 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office statistics. “Warrior,” a mixed martial arts drama from Lionsgate, was a disappointing third with about $5.6 million in ticket sales. “The Debt” (Focus Features) took in roughly $5 million for fourth place, lifting its two-week total to $22 million. “Colombiana” (Sony Pictures Entertainment) was fifth with about $4 million in ticket sales and a new three-week total of $29.8 million. On the gloomy side, “Bucky Larson: Born to be a Star,” a Sony comedy produced by Adam Sandler’s company, took in just $1.5 million and placed far outside the top 10.

headline: Where Do We Go From Here?
text: Today, a large share of the Sept. 11 reflection in this country and worldwide has been focused on the attacks themselves and the events of the decade that followed. We were curious to hear from you about what goals the U.S. should set for itself in the next 10 years, taking into consideration where we are now, and where we have been ever since that Tuesday morning in 2001.  We asked our Twitter followers on @NYTimes for ideas and suggestions and we are featuring a selection of their responses here. Post your own comment in the box below, or tweet to us at @NYTimes with the hashtag #911plus20.

headline: Another Rain Delay at the Open

headline: New York Top 5 | Siki Im
text: Siki Im’s first runway show here in New York City, titled “The Topography of Globalization,” was the perfect combination of concept and clothing. Bespectacled models walked the runway in stark multiculti clothing that was a combination of American sportswear staples like denim jeans and tailored sport jackets and Middle East style scarfs and wrapped coats. Smart military style cargo pockets and oversize flaps provided the fine finishing touches in this highly styled yet utterly wearable collection.

headline: Trendspotting: Athletic Wear

headline: Stosur Defeats Serena Williams for 2011 Open Title
text: Live Coverage of Women’s Open Final: On Saturday, The New York Times brought you live analysis, photos and chat from the women’s championship match of the United States Open between Serena Williams and Samantha Stosur.

headline: ‘Boardwalk Empire’ Wins Creative Arts Emmys
text: “Boardwalk Empire,” the Prohibition-era drama set in Atlantic City, picked up seven awards at the creative arts Emmys on Saturday, making it the Academy of Television Arts & Sciences’ most-honored television program a week ahead of the prime-time awards. “Boardwalk Empire,” shown by HBO, won for art direction, editing, sound editing and visual effects, among other categories. HBO also received awards for the mini-series “Mildred Pierce,” a Lady Gaga tour special and a children’s program called “A Child’s Garden of Poetry.” The annual creative arts ceremony also recognized Justin Timberlake twice — once for guest-hosting “Saturday Night Live” and once for co-writing the lyrics to his “SNL” monologue song. Other stars who were recognized on Saturday include Gwyneth Paltrow, for her guest-star turn on “Glee”; Jay Leno, for his car Web site JayLenosGarage.com; and Jeff Probst, for his hosting of “Survivor.” The ceremony will be shown on the ReelzChannel on Saturday, a day before the prime-time awards are shown live on Fox.

headline: Team Players
text: Designers casting about for a credibly American fashion identity could do worse than to mine the sports arena. An influential cohort did just that, drawing inspiration from the locker room, the racetrack, sand and surf.

headline: Global Memorials, Tinged With Weariness

headline: I.S.S. Comes Out Against Transatlantic’s Deal With Allied
text: The proposed merger of Transatlantic Holdings with Allied World Assurance experienced a fresh setback on Friday, as a major shareholder advisory firm recommended that investors vote against the $2.86 billion deal.

headline: The Truth? Europe Can’t Handle The Truth!
text: I’m a big fan of the FT’s Alphaville blog — although I have to say that their explanation of my views on gold left me feeling a bit confused.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Victoria Beckham
text: It’s not every morning that starts with someone referencing Catherine Deneuve and drugstores in the same sentence. It happened backstage at Victoria Beckham where Guido Palau explained that he was using “quite a lot of product” and Goody hair barrettes to channel Deneuve-like elegance with a masculine bent. This meant Redken Thickening Lotion spread throughout the hair for texture, with Hardwear at the center to make a wet-looking panel at the crown, which was pulled back with a classic silver clip (here’s where we get drugstore). Then loads of Hairspray 23 on the loose hair, “for texture, not hold,” Palau said. “Wet and dry, shine and matte,” is how he described the contrasts within the style. As the girls walked out, Palau added a little Glass Panel to heighten this effect.

headline: Tuck Inactive for Giants Opener
text: LANDOVER, Md. — The Giants opened their season Sunday afternoon against the Washington Redskins without their defensive leader, Justin Tuck, who was declared inactive just before the game because of a lingering neck injury.

headline: Hacker Rattles Security Circles
text: He claims to be 21 years old, a student of software engineering in Tehran who reveres Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and despises dissidents in his country.

headline: Qaddafi Son Found in Niger
text: NIAMEY, Niger — A son of the deposed Libyan leader Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi has entered Niger, crossing the desert from Libya, the Niger government said Sunday.

headline: Fashion’s Experienced Hands, a Long Walk From SoHo
text: Jean Salvemini wrapped her arms around a pair of headless mannequins — one in a wedding dress, the other in a suit and tie — and made a fashion statement: “You know, we really don’t have a glamorous address,” she said, “but we do glamorous work.”

headline: Backstage Grooming Report | Robert Geller
text: At a cozy table mere yards away from the pre-show shuffle, the men’s wear designer Robert Geller quietly shared, “This season I thought a lot about proportions, and how to play with them. If a guy wears a slim pant, I’d think about juxtaposing it with a rounded sleeve or shoulder. In this collection, I emphasized how men really need to loosen up, but still be masculine, with a certain coolness.”

headline: Underground Musicians Lose a Haven
text: Man Forever, a five-piece band, was making some decidedly unmarketable noise. Two drummers sat on either side of a snare drum, rolling out an undercurrent of cadences, while an organist with wild hair played endlessly sustained dissonant chords, and the bass and guitar thrummed muddy harmonies that fed back on themselves. The effect was of a primordial drone in which overtones clashed and warbled, phasing in and out in waves, chaos seeking order.

headline: Bartz Departs Yahoo’s Board
text: Days after she was fired as Yahoo‘s chief executive, Carol A. Bartz resigned her seat on the Internet company’s board, according to a spokesman for the directors.

headline: Remembering September 11 With Music
text: Like a solo Bach line, music wove its way through Sept. 11 remembering on Sunday. Pockets of people formed in halls and churches around New York to hear musicians form the consorts of consolation.

headline: Biggest Carry for Greene: The Jets’ Offensive Load
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Shonn Greene, the 226-pound running back whom the Jets plan to lean on harder this season, does not talk much, even to his teammates. But he will say he likes to think of himself as the kind of player who becomes stronger as games wear on.

headline: New Seasons: N.F.L., Serie A
text: O.K., it is only a coincidence … the N.F.L. regular season turned over into gear and the Serie A season in Italy began, finally.

headline: Big Names Join Cast of ‘Les Misérables’ Movie
text: Russell Crowe has been cast as Inspector Javert opposite Hugh Jackman as Jean Valjean in the coming film adaptation of the musical “Les Misérables,” according to deadline.com. The film will be directed by Tom Hooper (“The King’s Speech”) and is scheduled for release in December 2012. The most recent theatrical adaptation based on that 1862 Victor Hugo novel — released in 1998 and starring Liam Neeson and Geoffrey Rush — earned less than $14 million at the domestic box office despite generally positive reviews.

headline: You Look Familiar Somehow
text: Technically speaking, there was nothing groundbreaking in the T-shirts and utility jackets printed with big eyeballs, or a buttoned-up black polo shirt slashed with white stripes, that Daisuke Obana created for his N. Hoolywood collection. And yet, Mr. Obana’s show, in a pitch-black theater at the Tribeca Performing Arts Center on Friday night, was utterly engrossing.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Altuzarra
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#576", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);Matthew Kristall’s New York fashion week photo diary.

headline: The Meaningfulness of Lives
text: Who among us has not asked whether his or her life is a meaningful one?  Who has not wondered — on a sleepless night, during a long stretch of dull or taxing work, or when a troubled child seems a greater burden than one can bear — whether in the end it all adds up to anything? On this day, too, when many are steeped in painful reminders of personal loss, it is natural to wonder about the answers.

headline: Never Seeking the Presidency, Yet Swept Into Office Nonetheless
text: In both of the books she has written about American presidents, Candice Millard has zeroed in on events that other historians largely overlook. Her first book, “The River of Doubt,” followed Theodore Roosevelt’s strenuous efforts to regain his confidence after his failed 1912 third-party bid for re-election and described his near-disastrous journey down the Amazon tributary of the title. The details of this trip were hardly unknown, but they were easily overshadowed by other aspects of Roosevelt’s hugely eventful life. Ms. Millard turned a relative footnote into a newly mesmerizing story.

headline: Shuffling and Mirroring in a Sort of Simon Says
text: Noémie Lafrance is a site-specific choreographer, which means that in her works, place is paramount. She’s staged dances in a 50,000-square-foot drained swimming pool and on the swooping rooftop of a Frank Gehry building. Her new installation, “The White Box Project,” is set at the Black & White Gallery in Williamsburg, Brooklyn — or, rather, behind it. A door at the back of the gallery opens onto a concrete courtyard, enclosed by whitish brick walls and exposed to the sky. It’s like a handball court that’s seen better days, a space small enough that when the cast of 20 dancers start running, everyone else better get out of the way. Unfortunately Ms. Lafrance’s guiding idea is even smaller.

headline: You Can See Spring Coming
text: Self regard has been a cultural driver for some time, so the intersecting mirrors at the center of Alexander Wang’s show made perfect sense. The audience of editors and star photographers could regard themselves while regarding the clothes.

headline: Capturing a Yearning Fit for a Prince
text: It might seem a stretch to ask audience members at Bargemusic, the floating concert hall on the East River with an expansive view of the Manhattan skyline, to imagine themselves next to the Rhine in 1475, as the tenor and lutenist Eric Redlinger did before a concert on Thursday evening.

headline: Monday: Popular Bar Game
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — In another lifetime, I earned my living as a canine behaviorist. This means that I spent a lot of time explaining to people who hired me that their dogs would be much more well-behaved once the dog clearly understood what the people wanted from the dog. For example, if you train your dog to eliminate outside on the command “Hurry up!”, you should not be surprised if, the moment you yell “Hurry up!” to your spouse when you’re late to a social engagement, the dog eliminates as directed, most likely on your Persian rug. It’s all about communication, people.

headline: A Bollywood Bride, but Who’s the Groom?
text: Free spirit or spoiled brat? Dimple, the heroine of the Bollywood romantic comedy “Mere Brother Ki Dulhan” (“My Brother’s Bride”), is a bit of both, though as portrayed by Katrina Kaif the brat often has the upper hand. Still, Dimple, the London-raised daughter of a diplomat, barely resembles the demure Hindi-film heroines of yore. She knows what she wants, likes to have fun and enjoys being a bad girl. She even stages an unauthorized rock concert at the Agra fort, where — with the Taj Mahal for a backdrop — she wails on a shiny electric guitar in ripped pink jeans. (You’ve come a long way, Bollywood baby.)

headline: A Modern Update on Musical Tradition
text: Before conducting the inaugural concert of the West Side Chamber Orchestra at St. Peter’s Church in Chelsea on Saturday evening Kevin Mallon said he had been amazed — given the struggles of many orchestras to survive — to receive a call from the oboist Kathy Halvorson about founding a new ensemble.

headline: A Celebration of Bach, as a Counterpoise to Painful Memories
text: What does Bach, or any classical composer, have to do with Sept. 11? For most people nothing, but for some of us everything.

headline: New York Exhales With Mahler’s ‘Resurrection,’ Symphonic Salve
text: The terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, 2001, came as the classical music season in New York was about to begin. In the aftermath the city’s stunned performing arts organizations were not sure how to respond, or even whether to begin performances at all.

headline: Where The Big Girls Are | Alexander Wang
text: The photographer JD Ferguson gets close up on the biggest faces in fashion.

headline: A 92-Year-Old Former Champ Who Doesn’t Play by the Book
text: Wednesday is the 92nd birthday of one of the former stars of the game: Leonard Harmon of East Hampton, N.Y.

headline: Monster Island
text: A haven for struggling artists and musicians in Brooklyn is headed for redevelopment.

headline: Mass Grave in Iraqi Town Held Bodies of 40 Cabbies
text: BAGHDAD — Iraq has been so inured by years of war, terrorism and sectarian strife that what would be a horrific crime of shocking proportions in most countries has gone barely noticed here.

headline: PBS’s ‘Need to Know’ Turns to Roster of Guest Hosts
text: PBS’s Friday newsmagazine “Need to Know” is turning to a rotating group of well-known guest hosts for the next several months, as it seeks a new permanent anchor in the wake of Alison Stewart’s departure on Friday.

headline: ‘The Lion King’ Has a New Life
text: Theater owners are furious with movie studios for speeding up the release of movies on DVD and video-on-demand services. Except when they’re not upset about it at all.

headline: Critics See Drop in Talent as U.S.T.A. Grapples With Player Development
text: A deluge forced the United States Open junior tournament to be moved Thursday from Flushing Meadows to indoor courts in Port Chester, N.Y. To the young players, it was a reminder of how far they have to go in tennis, a sport to which many have dedicated much of their lives.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Duro Olowu
text: “Chic with a beautiful, sensual quality showcasing an elongation of the neck and the profile of the face,” said Johnnie Sapong backstage at Duro Olowu of the style he created to channel the photographer Jacques Henri Lartigue’s women, who were among the inspirations for both the beauty look and the clothes in the collection. Sapong molded an undone chignon using TIGI Catwalk Session Series Work It hair spray, the loose ends of the upswept hairdo dusted with Transforming Dry Shampoo. “Like a piece of raveled rope,” is how he described the bun. As for makeup, Luc Bochard kept it modern and feminine, as well, with M.A.C. Metal X Crème Shadow in Gold Carbon over the eye and Russian Red and Film Noir on the lips. Among the hair and makeup team was Olowu’s wife, Thelma Golden, watching the crew prep for the presentation. “Beautifully combined, broad influences,” is how she described the cumulative effect of her husband’s sensibilities. Spoken like a true art aficionada.

headline: A Shrub Back From Oblivion and in Need of Care
text: The extinction-defying shrub is informally called Franciscan manzanita, for its home near San Francisco Bay, but maybe someone should rename it the Lazarus manzanita. It was given up for extinct some 60 years ago, then rediscovered in a traffic island in 2009 by a botanist driving home from a climate-change conference.

headline: Campaign Trains Viewers for ‘TV Everywhere’
text: PUTTING in place TV Everywhere, a long-promised system for online television, calls for new contracts between channels and distributors and for new technology to check that viewers have paid their cable bills. And it takes something else: training. Viewers, after all, are not accustomed to being able to go online and see a library’s worth of television on demand.

headline: Ceremonies Mark 10th Anniversary of Sept. 11
text: In Washington, New York and Pennsylvania, officials and victims’ families gathered to commemorate the attacks.

headline: Huber and Raymond Win Women’s Doubles Title
text: The last time Liezel Huber and Lisa Raymond were on the same court at a United States Open doubles final, it was as opponents. That was in 2008, when Huber teamed with Cara Black to defeat Raymond and Samantha Stosur to win the doubles title.

headline: The Real Threat of ‘Contagion’
text: I ADMIT I was wary when I was approached, late in 2008, about working on a movie with the director Steven Soderbergh about a flulike pandemic. It seemed that every few years a filmmaker imagined a world in which a virus transformed humans into flesh-eating zombies, or scientists discovered and delivered the cure for a lethal infectious disease in an impossibly short period of time.

headline: Reports See Fiscal Woes Undermining Palestinians
text: JERUSALEM — With the Palestinian Authority seeking United Nations membership and statehood recognition this month, two new reports say Palestinian public institutions are gaining traction, but there is trouble on the economic front — growth has slowed amid a fiscal crisis.

headline: News Trends Tilt Toward Niche Sites
text: It was a rough week for the big guys on the Web. Yahoo unceremoniously dumped its chief executive, Carol Bartz, and AOL faced a mutiny from TechCrunch, the Silicon Valley news site it bought last year.

headline: YouTube Founders Revamping a Site for Link Sharing
text: SAN MATEO, Calif. — Chad Hurley and Steve Chen have some experience with turning a small Web site into Internet gold. In 2006 they sold their scrappy start-up YouTube to Google for $1.65 billion.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Derek Lam
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Giants, Needing Some Early Wins, Stumble in Opener
text: LANDOVER, Md. — After a training camp filled with injuries ranging from torn chest muscles to shredded knees, the Giants began their season Sunday by absorbing perhaps the most painful blow of all: the stomach punch.

headline: Yankees’ Offense Stirs to Life With Assist From the Angels
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — It had been five days and three cities since the Yankees last won a game. Their offense was sagging, their bullpen was depleted, and the injuries were stacking up so high that by the weekend they had used three catchers they never thought would squat behind the plate this season.

headline: Anderson Cooper Seeks to Show His Daytime Side
text: This year, Anderson Cooper spent 10 days in Japan covering the aftermath of the devastating earthquake; he spent nine days in Egypt and was roughed up by supporters of Hosni Mubarak during the uprising there.

headline: Changing the Rules
text: Some south Louisiana business owners say new regulations on guest workers could put many of them out of business.

headline: In Russian Leadership Battle, Medvedev Hints He Lacks Fire
text: YAROSLAVL, Russia — When President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia took the lectern here at his annual political forum last week, the circles under his eyes suggested he had barely slept.

headline: On the Field, All Is Well
text: ATHENS, Ga. — After an off-season in which college football fans could barely stand to watch, the star-kissed fans at Michigan Stadium did not want to leave. After an off-season with seemingly endless descriptions of the ills of college football, Iowa State Coach Paul Rhoads was reduced to tears when his team’s triple-overtime victory ended. After an off-season of relentless controversy, fans saw an abundance of thrills, almost like the sport’s version of an N.C.A.A. basketball tournament’s opening Thursday.

headline: In Tapes, Candid Talk by Young Kennedy Widow
text: In the early days of the Cuban missile crisis, before the world knew that the cold war seemed to be sliding toward nuclear conflict, President John F. Kennedy telephoned his wife, Jacqueline, at their weekend house in Virginia. From his voice, she would say later, she could tell that something was wrong. Why don’t you come back to Washington? he asked, without explanation.

headline: Men’s Final Could Punctuate, or Puncture, the Year’s Narrative
text: A defeat on Monday will hardly ruin Novak Djokovic’s greatest season. He has already won 9 tournaments and 63 matches, beating up on the best repeatedly, on everything from the cushioned acrylic of Melbourne to the red clay of Madrid and Rome to the deep-rooted grass of Wimbledon.

headline: Look of the Moment | Sofía Sanchez Barrenechea
text: The Look: Ravishing––a most dramatic metal collar and black ankle boots sharpen a showstopping red halter dress.

headline: Returning Greece to the Drachma
text: The standard of living reached in Greece since it joined the European Union means austerity will be inadequate to rebalance the economy. Returning Greece’s currency to the drachma, on the other hand, would allow market forces to set the country’s wage levels, induce other indebted European Union members to reform without Continental prodding and thus solidify the euro.

headline: Stosur Captures the Title After a Williams Outburst
text: Samantha Stosur endured the longest women’s match in tournament history in one round and the longest tie breaker in another on her way to the United States Open final. When the rain came in the second week, she endured being moved like a pawn around the National Tennis Center.

headline: In Guatemalan Election, a Focus on Security Issues
text: MEXICO CITY — Guatemalans streamed to the polls on Sunday to elect a new president, Parliament and local leaders in an election defined by rising concerns about gangs and drug cartels. Voters waiting to cast ballots from the countryside to the capital said they were motivated mostly by the fear of violent crime, and demands for a stronger government response.

headline: The President’s Do-Over
text: A week after President Obama took the oath of office, Alice Rivlin, budget chief to President Bill Clinton, testified before a Congress that was about to consider sweeping stimulus legislation. In her remarks, Rivlin voiced her support for a swift and substantial federal intervention to prop up the sagging economy. But she offered lawmakers three warnings as well.

headline: Sony Slate a Big Bet on Dramas
text: TORONTO — “This was not by design,” said Michael Lynton, the chairman of Sony Pictures Entertainment.

headline: G.O.P. Senators in Albany Block Federal Aid to Fulfill Part of Health Law
text: With 2.6 million uninsured residents, a popular Democratic governor and tens of millions of federal dollars at stake, New York would seem to be one of the least likely states to join a growing revolt in the nation’s capitals against facilitating a federal overhaul of health care.

headline: Raid on Egyptian Al Jazeera Affiliate Seen as Part of a Broader Crackdown
text: CAIRO — Egyptian security forces raided the offices of an Egyptian affiliate of the Al Jazeera news network known for attentive coverage of street protests, eliciting allegations on Sunday of a crackdown on the news media as the military-led transitional government seeks to ensure law and order after allowing an angry mob to invade the Israeli Embassy over the weekend.

headline: A Day to Take Stock of What Really Matters
text: Landover, Md.

headline: An Impeccable Disaster
text: On Thursday Jean-Claude Trichet, the president of the European Central Bank or E.C.B. — Europe’s equivalent to Ben Bernanke — lost his sang-froid. In response to a question about whether the E.C.B. is becoming a “bad bank” thanks to its purchases of troubled nations’ debt, Mr. Trichet, his voice rising, insisted that his institution has performed “impeccably, impeccably!” as a guardian of price stability.

headline: Report Details Rise of Social Media
text: 11:20 a.m. | Updated As social media like blogs, Facebook, Twitter and YouTube grow increasingly popular among consumers, marketers are seeking more data about the changing behavior of their customers.

headline: Julia Marcum’s Civil War
text: At around two in the morning on Sept. 7, 1861, Confederate soldiers burst into the home of Julia Marcum, intent on killing her father. They “broke the door open with bayonets on their guns and said there was 36 men around who had come to kill” him, she later wrote. The 16-year-old girl lived with her parents and five siblings on a farm in Scott County, Tenn., northwest of Knoxville near the Kentucky border. Like most of their neighbors, the Marcums were strong Unionists. Early in the war Julia’s father, Hiram, made his farm available as a way station for the thousands of Southern men traveling north to join Lincoln’s army, guiding many of them to the border himself.

headline: Joe Torre
text: The manager Joe Torre talks about Sept. 11.

headline: A 9/11 Gesture Curtailed
text: On Sunday night, as Mets players and coaches observed a ceremony commemorating the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, they donned caps representing the police and fire departments of New York City.

headline: Palestinian Statehood
text: A United Nations vote on Palestinian membership would be ruinous. Yet with little time left before the U.N. General Assembly meets, the United States, Israel and Europe have shown insufficient urgency or boldness in trying to find a compromise solution.  The need for action is even more acute after alarming tensions flared in recent days between Israel and two critical regional players — Egypt and Turkey.

headline: Video: Joe Torre Talks About Sept. 11
text: Former Yankees manager Joe Torre shares his memories.

headline: Ex-F.B.I. Agent Cites High-Level Dysfunction Over 9/11
text: WASHINGTON — In a new memoir, a former F.B.I. agent who tracked Al Qaeda before and after the Sept. 11 attacks paints a devastating picture of rivalry and dysfunction inside the government’s counterterrorism agencies. The book describes missed opportunities to defuse the 2001 plot, and argues that other attacks overseas might have been prevented, and Osama bin Laden found earlier, if interrogations had not been mismanaged.

headline: Closing a Nursing Home, and a Chapter of New York History
text: Her 98-year-old father lies under white sheets, frail and incoherent, attached to a feeding tube and a catheter. But Rose Lauria visits him nearly every day, taking a 10-minute bus ride to the historic block where the Bialystoker Center for Nursing and Rehabilitation has towered over the Lower East Side’s tenements for 80 years, then greeting her father with a “Hey, cutie pie!”

headline: Cheering On the Death Machine
text: Even supporters of the death penalty used to consider execution a solemn state responsibility, not an occasion for celebration. But the crowd of Republicans who gathered at the Reagan Library last week to watch their presidential candidates debate actually applauded and cheered when a moderator noted that Texas had executed 234 inmates under Gov. Rick Perry, by far the most under any governor in modern times.

headline: Lottery Numbers
First Downer: Colts and Others Begin Season With Clunkers
text: Late last week, Kerry Collins was musing about the odd turns his career had taken, the latest being the head-spinning journey from retiree to rescuer of the Indianapolis Colts less than three weeks before Sunday’s season opener.

headline: Secret Bid to Arm Qaddafi Sheds Light on Tensions in China Government
text: BEIJING — At a United Nations conference in Indonesia this summer, an official of the agency that oversees China’s weapons industry ticked off the hurdles that any proposal to sell Chinese weapons abroad must clear. Among them: arms sales must not alter another nation’s internal security. They must not violate United Nations arms embargoes. And they must win government approval.

headline: Justice for Women Veterans
text: Women in the military who are sexually assaulted or harassed face obstacles not seen in the civilian workplace. They can’t decide to take time off or quit, often have no way to avoid a predatory colleague or supervisor, and certainly in combat zones, no way to visit the human resources department. They often work in a culture that has long tolerated misogynistic behavior. And they can be further traumatized by the indifference or hostility of the bureaucracy that is supposed to help them.

headline: Heralded Girls Basketball Star Is Shot to Death in Manhattan
text: A star player in high school girls basketball was shot dead early Sunday in a building stairwell in Morningside Heights in Manhattan, the police said.

headline: A Choice Made Decades Ago Comes Back to Haunt a Town
text: WEST PITTSTON, Pa. — On a flood-ravaged street on the west bank of the Susquehanna River, a pointed question is literally writ large now in white spray paint on the side of a building: “Levee or view?”

headline: Bank Chief Has Big Job to Reassure Stockholders
text: Like a magician facing a weary audience, Bank of America faces pressure to pull another rabbit out of its hat.

headline: From a Voice to a Roar, Again
text: Serena Williams was not going to win that match, anyway. Even shouting “Come on!” in the middle of the point was not going to lift her out of her morass.

headline: Too Fast on Drilling
text: Gov. Andrew Cuomo has long vowed that extraction of natural gas reserves with hydraulic fracturing in New York State will not “come at the expense of human health or have adverse environmental impacts.” It will be hard to keep that promise if his administration moves too fast in permitting such drilling into deep shale formations. It must not rush the process of creating detailed regulations that will be crucial to reducing risks to the environment.

headline: After the Match, Federer vs. Djokovic Continues
text: For all the thrills the Djokovic-Federer semifinal offered, and there were many—the fifth set alone was enough to satisfy the most rabid fan—there were additional ones to be found in the two men’s post-match interviews, which exposed the chasms that separate them as competitors.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Proxy Firm Opposes Allied Bid
text: The proposed merger of Transatlantic Holdings and Allied World Assurance suffered another major blow late on Friday, as a major shareholder advisory firm recommended that investors vote against the $2.86 billion deal.

headline: About These Proposals
text: The baseline figure for the total Gaza/West Bank area is 6,195 square kilometers (about 2,392 square miles), which is the relevant area won by Israel in the 1967 war. It includes the northwest portion of the Dead Sea, one-half of No Man’s Land, and all of East Jerusalem, except Mount Scopus.

headline: Cam Newton Appears to Be Ready for the N.F.L.
text: The only problem with Cam Newton’s passing for 422 yards in his N.F.L. debut was that his Carolina Panthers needed 423.

text: David Makovsky proposes three land-swap scenarios that could lead to an Israeli-Palestinian peace deal.

headline: Connecting With Lost Loved Ones, if Only by the Tips of Fingers
text: They clutched slips of paper bearing letters and numbers, trying to navigate a strange new map created by computer algorithm that was designed to place people next to other people whom, in life, they had cared about. The visitors looked hopeful, dazed, afraid.

headline: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include import prices for August (Tuesday); retail sales for August, business inventories for July and the Producer Price Index for August (Wednesday); the Consumer Price Index for August, the current account deficit for the second quarter, industrial production and capacity utilization for August, the Philadelphia Fed manufacturing index for September and weekly jobless claims (Thursday); and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for September (Friday).

headline: Cobo Victorious in Vuelta a España
text: Juan José Cobo won the Vuelta a España, protecting his 13-second lead over Christopher Froome during the traditional finish in Madrid. Peter Sagan edged the pack in a sprint to win the 21st stage, a 59-mile ride from the Circuito del Jarama race track to the city center in 2 hours 20 minutes 59 seconds. It was Sagan’s third stage win of the event.

headline: Jacqueline Kennedy Speaks
text: In 1964, just months after the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, his widow spoke about his presidency for an oral history project.

headline: On Wikipedia, Echoes of 9/11 ‘Edit Wars’
text: AS the nation marked this terrible anniversary, people invariably turned to Wikipedia to learn about the events of Sept. 11, 2001. Nearly two million page views were registered last September for the article “September 11 Attacks,” a typically Wikipedian effort with exhaustive, even picayune, details of the events, bolstered by nearly 289 footnotes. This September, the total page view number could be something like six million.

headline: Traveling Different Paths to Get the Job Done
text: The owner of Riceland Crawfish and the company’s workers speak on the state of employment at the plant and in the community.

headline: Seeking Citizenship and Civics
text: “Do you have any title of nobility in any foreign country?” If so, have I got a show for you.

headline: A Lost Generation Drinks Up, Always on Jake Barnes’s Tab
text: It takes great discipline to stay sloppy drunk for three hours and still be smart and engaging. I bet you’ve never achieved that. (If you think you have, your memory is lying.) So raise a brimming glass to Elevator Repair Service, which exists in what appears to be a state of perpetual and severe intoxication for the entirety of “The Select (The Sun Also Rises),” which opened Sunday night at the New York Theater Workshop.

headline: Angels Include Yankees in Pregame Ceremony
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Before the Yankees’ game against the Los Angeles Angels on Sunday three first responders and survivors who took part in rescue efforts at ground zero and the Pentagon, and three Navy Seals threw out ceremonial first pitches to Derek Jeter, Mariano Rivera and Jorge Posada of the Yankees, and Torii Hunter, Jered Weaver and Manager Mike Scioscia of the Angels. Joe Torre, who was the Yankees’ manager in 2001, joined the Yankees as they lined up along the first-base line for the pregame ceremony.

headline: Market Swings Are Becoming New Standard
text: The stock market just can’t seem to make up its mind.

headline: La. Business Owners Sue Over New Rules for Guest Workers
text: EUNICE, La. — The workers have been in fine spirits this summer in the small plant where Dexter Guillory cuts up alligator meat to feed the growing demand from Southern restaurants for the swamp creatures’ steaks.

headline: Elections Tuesday in New York State
text: Voters in New York State on Tuesday will elect a new representative from Brooklyn and Queens, as well as six members of the Assembly from around the state. Voters in some areas will also elect party nominees for a variety of local offices.

headline: Battle for Libya | September 11, 2011
text: Rebel fighters advanced toward Surt and headed to the front line in Bani Walid, Libya.

headline: Prosecution Seeks to Focus Trial on Election Aide, Not the Mayor
text: While John F. Haggerty Jr., a Republican political operative, will be the only defendant sitting at the defense table when his trial begins this week, the proceeding could prove damaging for another person: the mayor of New York.

headline: Wall Street Recovers After Fresh Worries Shake European Markets
text: Shares on Wall Street closed mostly higher on Monday despite fears of a deepening debt crisis in Europe that battered European markets and financial institutions suspected of being vulnerable to a possible Greek default.

headline: One of Qaddafi’s Sons Flees to Niger as New Leaders Focus on Next Steps
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Leading figures of the deposed government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi continued to flee from Libya or surface in rebel custody on Sunday, including one of Colonel Qaddafi’s sons, as the de facto government announced new steps toward restarting the economy and bringing the country under its full control.

headline: For the Mets, a Tribute in Prime Time

headline: ‘Plane People’ From 9/11 Return to Newfoundland to Give Thanks

headline: Civic Paralysis Seizes Tsunami-Stricken Town Still in Shambles

People come from near and far to pray before the three-story structure, turning it into a shrine of sorts for the town officials who died here.

headline: Slow Start but Fast Finish as Jets Beat Cowboys

Maybe their coronation begins on an overcast night, in front of a boisterous crowd, when all good sense says that they should have lost. What emerged instead after 60 how-did-that-happen minutes was yet another victory in the final seconds, a 27-24 season-opening win against the Dallas Cowboys on Sunday that added texture and resonance to their favorite catchphrase of last season.

headline: Daniel Snyder, Owner of the Redskins, Keeps on Talking
text: Here are a few extras from my interview with the billionaire owner of the Washington Redskins, Daniel Snyder. We spoke on the afternoon of Aug. 22, just after he came off the field from watching his team practice at their Ashburn, Va., headquarters. Snyder was very eager to talk about the initiative he’d embarked upon to install solar panels atop FedEx field. He sent assistants scurrying about to bring in renderings of what the field will look like after NRG, the energy company, installs them. (NRG gets some very prominent signage at FedEx  for its efforts.) He seemed less eager to discuss the general antipathy that has greeted his ownership from the media, fans and even a beloved Redskins Hall of Fame Running back. Throughout the interview, he kept glancing uncomfortably at Tony Wyllie, the Redskins’ head of communications, who was sitting in. I honestly couldn’t tell whether he was shocked that I was pursuing that particular line of questioning, or if he was so insulated that he didn’t understand the depth and breadth of the criticism of the decisions he’s made as owner.

headline: Now Listening | Stillspotting
text: Sometimes all a New Yorker wants is a little peace and quiet. And on the extended weekends of Sept. 15-18 and Sept. 22-25, it will be available, in a very carefully fashioned version, at various locations around Lower Manhattan, as part of “To a Great City,” the second installment of “Stillspotting Nyc,” a two-year multidisciplinary program by the Guggenheim Museum. Organized by David van der Leer, the museum’s associate curator in architecture and urban studies, and Sarah Malaika, a project associate, “To a Great City” is a collaboration between the Estonian composer Arvo Part and the Norwegian architecture firm Snohetta. It creates urban soundscapes in five downtown locations that, according to the museum’s press release, “quietly celebrate the city, 10 years after the Sept. 11 attacks.” The locations include a green labyrinth created by the Battery Conservancy, an underground chamber at the Governors Island National Monument, and spaces in landmark skyscrapers that are normally inaccessible to the public. For a $10 admission fee, visitors will be given a map, directions and a one-day pass to each of the “stillspots” for a self-guided tour, which takes about three hours; reservations are recommended. In conjunction with the project, visitors can identify and map their own favorite quiet spots as part of “Create Your Own Stillspot” at stillspotting.guggenheim.org.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Diane von Furstenberg
text: “Am I done?” Joan Smalls asked Orlando Pita backstage at Diane von Furstenberg as he fixed her teased out beehive. “Done,” he said as she coyly examined his curly hair. “Done done?” Smalls asked knowing there may be yet another round of Orlando Pita hair spray to keep the look in place. Surprisingly, it wasn’t the ’60s that inspired the up-do that Pita referred to as “Kim Novak-y,” rather Von Furstenberg’s starting point for the collection: “New Beginnings.” For makeup, this meant James Kaliardos used M.A.C. products for a face inspired by the land where it all began: Africa. The idea was to highlight the planes and tones of the face using an earthy (literally) palette of eight Crème Color Base shades, including Ochre, Pale Peach and Dark Brown. The inner and outer corner of the eye was highlighted with a khaki variation, while the middle of the lid was done in white or yellow. There was no lip, just as nails were kept clean, coated with only Sally Hansen’s Hard as Nails. Kaliardos described the ingenuity of the woman who inspired him, “No matter her economic situation, she finds a way to look beautiful— regal even.”

headline: From Sikhs and Cheese to Patels and Motels

headline: The Arctic Ice Watch

(We were drifting around 400 yards an hour at the time; all the sound is the crunching and huffing of the ice.)

headline: Dustin Hoffman Graduates to Film Director
text: Hey, I’m directin’ here! I’m directin’ here! He’s an excellent driver, a two-time Academy Award winner for “Kramer Vs. Kramer” and “Rain Man,” a magnet for New York taxis (at least in the guise of Ratso Rizzo from “Midnight Cowboy”) and now, finally, Dustin Hoffman has become a film director. On Monday, production began on “Quartet,” Mr. Hoffman’s feature-directing debut, its press representatives announced. The film, which is expected to shoot for nine weeks in Buckinghamshire, England, stars Tom Courtenay (whose previous films include “Doctor Zhivago” in 1965), Billy Connolly (“Mrs. Brown”) and Pauline Collins (“Shirley Valentine”) as residents of a home for retired opera singers. Their annual plans for a fund-raising concert, held on Verdi’s birthday, are disrupted by the arrival of a down-on-her-luck grande dame (played by Maggie Smith, the “Downton Abbey,” “Gosford Park” and “Harry Potter” star). The screenplay for “Quartet” is by Ronald Harwood, the Academy Award-winning screenwriter of “The Pianist” and “The Diving Bell and the Butterfly,” and adapted from his play of the same title. Mr. Hoffman is also a producer on the film, which is financed by BBC Films, DCM Productions and Decca. An American distributor and release date for “Quartet” were not immediately announced.

text: I  DECIDED at a young age to become an architect after watching my father, who had a small construction company. I wanted to learn the business, but he said that he didn’t want me to have calluses on my hands, and that I should go to college.

headline: Lasker Honors for a Lifesaver
text: The Lasker Awards, announced on Monday by the Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation, carry a $250,000 prize per category and are widely considered the nation’s most prestigious medical awards.

headline: Horwich Wins Lasker Award by Straddling Science and Medicine
text: NEW HAVEN — Medicine is a divided world. On one side are the doctors, who come face to face with illness each day and try to heal their patients with whatever tools they can get their hands on. On the other are the researchers, who explore the body’s microscopic complexity, never sure whether their discoveries will ever end up in the hands of the doctors.

headline: Forsaken Fisher
text: Another nice piece from Sylvia Nasar, this time about Irving Fisher and the foundations of macroeconomics. Fisher remains hugely relevant to this day, and in particular to my own thinking about the mess we’re in.

headline: Now Screening | Co, in Mysterious Company
text: To celebrate their spring/summer 2012 collection, the Co designers Stephanie Danan and Justin Kern collaborated with Daft Punk’s Thomas Bangalter and the actress Élodie Bouchez on a short film.

headline: A.N.C. Official Convicted of Hate Speech
text: In a ruling that tugged at South Africa’s racial wounds, a judge said Monday that a firebrand youth leader was guilty of hate speech for singing an apartheid-era freedom song that includes lyrics calling on people to shoot white farmers.

headline: ‘No Makeup’ Makeup at Diane Von Furstenberg
text: James Kaliardos, the makeup artist who led the MAC Pro team for Diane Von Furstenberg’s spring 2012 collection, took a few minutes backstage at the designer’s show on Sunday to talk about trends, and to explain the look he created. One of his inspirations, he said, was “an African face,” because “African women have found this way to look absolutely stunning no matter what the situation is.” So he wanted to use makeup strategically to give the models’ natural features more impact.

headline: Romo Admits It Was His Fault
text: Sometimes a quarterback points the finger at himself to shield a teammate from criticism. It can be part of leadership.

headline: The Numbers Behind an Urgent Fight
text: If the trend that, since the 1970s, has led to striking increases in the proportion of Americans who are overweight or obese is not halted, about three of every four Americans will be overweight or obese by 2020.

headline: Nadal vs. Djokovic: Keys to the Final
text: Rafael Nadal must significantly update his game plan if he has any hope of beating Novak Djokovic in today’s U.S. Open men’s singles final.

headline: New Song From Winehouse and Comments From Her Father
text: On the same day it was announced that Amy Winehouse’s last recording – a duet with Tony Bennett — would be released on Wednesday, her father said she had been experiencing seizures related to alcohol withdrawal in the weeks before her death.

headline: Runway In Review
text: Derek LamDesigner: Derek LamDate and Location: Sunday, Lincoln Center, StagePhotos: slide show

headline: Bourdain to Have His Own Line of Books
text: Anthony Bourdain, the celebrity chef, author and reality TV star, will acquire books for Ecco, an imprint of HarperCollins, the publisher said on Monday. Mr. Bourdain has been given a line of books that is expected to release three to five titles each year, which Ecco said in a statement would “reflect his remarkably eclectic tastes.” Daniel Halpern, the president and publisher of Ecco, said that Mr. Bourdain has been an informal adviser to him for about 10 years, a period during which Mr. Bourdain’s own books were published by Ecco. “His intuition has been unerring – suggesting such authors as Ferran Adria and Fergus Henderson,” Mr. Halpern said in an e-mail. “Now he’s becoming one of us, sort of.”

headline: ‘It Was Raining Glass and Metal’
text: Ronald Carletta has spent nearly 20 years at the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. In September 2001, he was a supervisory auditor at the agency’s New York office in the World Trade Center. Ten years after terrorist attacks destroyed that office, Mr. Carletta has become a branch chief for the Division of Clearing and Intermediary Oversight. He remains in the New York office, which has relocated a few blocks from its former home.

headline: Shark-Fin Vote Adds to Pressure on Hong Kong
text: As Elisabeth Rosenthal reported in Sunday’s Times, the battle to protect the world’s endangered shark population has passed another major milestone with a California Senate vote that bans the possession, sale and distribution of shark fins.

headline: Chemotherapy for Dogs
text: When a beloved pet is found to have cancer, many owners aren’t sure whether they should pursue aggressive treatments. John Rennie, the former editor of Scientific American, faced this decision when brain and lung tumors were diagnosed in his dog. He chose to give his dog chemotherapy treatment, an issue he wrote about recently in the online magazine Txchnologist. One of the surprises he encountered: Chemotherapy, while it creates many challenges for dogs, is often less grueling than it is for humans.

headline: Martha Plimpton in 'Raising Hope'
text: The actress was nominated for an Emmy for her performance in the Fox sitcom "Raising Hope."

headline: Rare Birds at Carolina Herrera
text: A sociologist looking to understand the vast diversity of species that cohabitate the fashion kingdom would do well to observe the audience at a Carolina Herrera show.

headline: Giffords to Appear With Diane Sawyer
text: 5:59 p.m. | Updated | ABC News said Monday that its top anchor, Diane Sawyer, had booked the first “sit down” interview with Representative Gabrielle Giffords, the Arizona Democrat, since she was critically injured in a shooting spree in Tucson eight months ago.

headline: Finding the Next NetLogic
text: Broadcom is opening its wallet wide — to the tune of $3.7 billion — to acquire NetLogic, a maker of advanced chips for routers.

headline: At a Bronx Hospital, a Teenage Milestone
text: Jessica Earnshaw recalls feeling somewhat overwhelmed while she photographed the children’s prom at Montefiore Medical Center, talking and laughing with the participants as she worked.

headline: Arrington Is Out at AOL and TechCrunch
text: Michael Arrington, the TechCrunch blogger turned venture capitalist, is no longer an employee of AOL.

text: The Moment follows model Tom Bull during New York Fashion Week. Directed by Isaac Hindin Miller of the blog isaaclikes.com.

headline: Just One Look | The Row Spring 2012 Collection
text: At Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen’s presentation Friday morning, spring was heralded not with a bang but a whisper. The predominantly all-white collection was almost Zen-like in its restraint (among the few accessories was a strand of oversize prayer beads), but moments of breathtaking embellishment, like a kimono-inspired gown with a silver beaded bodice or this look with its mother-of-pearl-button cuffs, sent the spirits soaring.

headline: Attacking the Obesity Epidemic by First Figuring Out Its Cause
text: If you have gained a lot of unwanted pounds at any time during the last 30-odd years, you may be relieved to know that you are probably not to blame. At least not entirely.

headline: Social Status and How the Elected Vote
text: FiveThirtyEight extends a hearty welcome to John Sides, a political scientist at George Washington University, who will be writing a series of posts for this site over the next month.

headline: Statistics, M.L.S. and the Castrol Index
text: Soccer will never make it in the United States, or so goes the conventional wisdom. It was once called the sport of the ’80s. The ’90s brought the World Cup and the start of Major League Soccer. A new century began with a run to the quarterfinals of the World Cup.

headline: Anthony Bourdain to Acquire Books for Ecco
text: Over at the culture desk’s ArtsBeat blog, Julie Bosman has a post announcing a new job for Anthony Bourdain. In addition to his work on television, Mr. Bourdain is set to acquire a number of books each year for Ecco, a subsidiary of HarperCollins run by the polymath epicure and poet Daniel Halpern.

headline: Madonna Finds Friends in Toronto
text: TORONTO — Madonna showed up on Monday to fight for her new film, “W.E.,” at the Toronto International Film Festival. But nobody called her out.
