headline: Detroit Sets Its Future on a Foundation of Two-Tier Wages
text: DETROIT — They are a cornerstone of Chrysler’s unlikely comeback: 900 employees turning out a Jeep Grand Cherokee sport utility vehicle every 48 seconds of the working day at an assembly plant here.

headline: On Eve of 9/11, Celebratory Fireworks Rattle Nerves
text: On Saturday evening, many New York and New Jersey residents were preparing for the somber ceremonies of the next day when they heard noises from a different kind of ceremony.

headline: For Many Older Gays, a Toll of Time and Isolation
text: Long after I had asked the paramedics to stop chest compressions, I was more dejected and frustrated by this patient’s death than by almost any I had experienced as a physician.

headline: Sleeping Sickness: Blood Test Could Be a Breakthrough in Field Diagnosis of Tropical Diseases
text: A new blood test for sleeping sickness that may prove to be the first major breakthrough in the field diagnosis of tropical diseases is to be unveiled in Mali this week by a Geneva-based foundation working with a Japanese chemical company.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Derek Lam
text: It was the architect Richard Neutra’s rigorous West Coast houses that inspired the beauty look at Derek Lam — that and the color yellow. Both may be odd inspirations for hair and makeup, but that’s what makes them so welcome. Better yellow and geometry than another repeat reference, though the look wasn’t totally different from last time around. “This collection’s an evolution from last season, not a complete change,” Orlando Pita said. “The hair has that feeling too.” This meant a low side-parted ponytail instead of hair pulled back at the crown without a visible barrette. “Clean, simple lines,” is how Pita described the look he created using Phyto Volume Active Mousse, blow drying with a T3 featherweight Luxe, then sealing the ends with Phyto 7 and a T3 Single Pass iron. The hair was then scraped back into a ponytail with a part over the right eye. Pita used Phyto Finishing Spray and a little Shine Defining Wax to ”make it perfectly done.” Nails were painted Estée Lauder’s Nude Attitude, but it was the eyes that went a little wild. Tom Pecheux (Estée Lauder’s creative makeup director) explained the Neutra connection by making references to large windows that “let the outdoor weather into the house,” which became a ray of yellow from Estée Lauder Rain Boots shadow on the lid highlighted with Cyber Copper brown shimmer all the way to the brow bone. Citron Kiss lip gloss was the final step. Canary colored in the vial, it’s the perfect way to warm up another lip color or let the light in for spring.

headline: Interview: Guy Maddin
text: The director Guy Maddin discusses the varied elements of his film "Keyhole," which tells a gangster ghost story.

headline: A Child’s Nap Is More Complicated Than It Looks
text: What makes a child nap? Most parents cherish toddlers’ naps as moments of respite and recharging, for parent and child alike; we are all familiar with the increased crankiness that comes when a nap is unduly delayed or evaded. But napping behavior has been somewhat taken for granted, even by sleep scientists, and napping problems have often been treated by pediatricians as parents’ “limit-setting” problems.

headline: White House Videographer Writes Book
text: Arun Chaudhary, the first official White House videographer, has written a book about the experience, to be published by Times Books, a division of Henry Holt and Company. Mr. Chaudhary, who was hired in 2007 to work on the Obama campaign, followed Mr. Obama to the White House and recently left the staff. His book will tell the story of what it means “to follow the president and be available 24/7 to record history; to be a video Boswell, as it were; how to use art, media and politics as a prism to capture history and record the quotidian moments even of the president,” a statement from the publisher said. The book is scheduled for publication in summer 2012.

headline: Trendspotting: Ophelia
text: Looks from Helmut Lang, The Row, Band of Outsiders and more.

headline: Drifting Away from Hard Edged
text: As the has week progressed, a handful of designers turned their backs on hard-edged urbanity in favor of a style as pale and wraithlike as Ophelia. Their fabrics, which sometimes drifted in sheer panels to the floor, lent their collections an air of fragile dishabille.

headline: New Knorr Ad
text: A new ad for Knorr stock features a chef, Marco Pierre White.

headline: Macro Photography 101: Extreme Close-Ups
text: If, as poetess Ella Wheeler Wilcox is right, “a weed is but an unloved flower,” then there are no weeds in the work of Tony Sweet. Mr. Sweet is a macro photographer whose close-up pictures practically caress the petals of the flowers that are his primary subject.

headline: The Caucus | Tea Party Debate Preview
text: Sept. 12, 2011 - A look ahead to Monday's Republican debate focused on the Tea Party. Also, the White House photographer on covering President Obama during the 10-year anniversary of 9/11.

headline: Bug Labs and Ford Team Up on Geeky Gear for Cars
text: Get ready to start hacking your own car.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
text: Arnold Worldwide, Boston, opened an office in Shanghai. The office has 10 employees and there are plans to hire about 20 more by the end of the year. Arnold Worldwide is part of the Havas Worldwide division of Havas.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Q: (Reader)

headline: Unilever Tries to Corner ‘Stock’ Market
text: Once, it was fashionable for marketers of packaged foods to center their campaigns on brand characters like Betty Crocker, Martha White and Aunt Jemima. Today, Madison Avenue is following a new recipe.

headline: Union Square Pedestrian Plaza Is Declared a Success
text: The city’s Department of Transportation has declared its pedestrian plaza on the north side of Union Square, the fourth such major street revamping along Broadway, an out-and-out success, despite some early qualms from residents.

headline: Ban on E. Coli in Ground Beef Is to Extend to 6 More Strains
text: The federal government will ban the sale of ground beef tainted with six toxic strains of E. coli bacteria that are increasingly showing up as the cause of severe illness from food. Officials have been under pressure from food safety advocates and some elected officials to do more to keep the potentially deadly bacteria out of meat, but the beef industry said the move was not needed and could force the price of ground beef to rise.

headline: BMG Rights Buys Music Publisher for $300 Million
text: BMG Rights Management, a new music company backed by the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, is buying Bug Music, a midsize publisher of songs like “What a Wonderful World” and “I Walk the Line,” the company announced on Monday.

headline: Ristretto | Some Coffee in Your Milk
text: This Fashion Week, Blue Bottle Coffee set up shop on the ground floor of Milk Studios in a converted loading dock with a view of the sidewalk paparazzi snapping the editors and bloggers heading to the shows upstairs. Blue Bottle shares the space with Bleach London, Butter London Nails and Creatures of Comfort as a part of the Aldo Salon pop-up. Shoes, hair, nails, printed matter, coffee — it’s a concentrated little scene, a lot of taste and style distilled into a tiny storefront.

headline: Caucus Video: Tea Party Debate Preview; A Photojournalist on the 9/11 Anniversary
text: A look ahead to tonight’s Republican debate, focusing on the Tea Party. Also, Doug Mills, The Times’s White House photographer, on covering President Obama and former President George W. Bush on Sunday at the ceremony at ground zero for the 10th anniversary of 9/11.

headline: Emmys Watch: Martha Plimpton
text: We will be talking to Emmy nominees leading up to the awards telecast on Sept. 18.

headline: In Crisis Mode, and Focused on a Return to Normalcy
text: Jonathan Doyle is a managing principal of Sandler O’Neill, an investment banking and brokerage firm, and member of the firm’s executive committee. On Sept. 11, 2001, he was a senior executive in the firm’s fixed-income unit.

headline: Strauss-Kahn Questioned on Accusations of 2003 Sexual Assault
text: PARIS — Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former head of the International Monetary Fund who returned to Paris last week after New York prosecutors dropped rape charges against him, was questioned for three hours on Monday about a sexual assault complaint dating to 2003, his lawyers said.

headline: The Cough That Launched a Hit Movie
text: When Hollywood turns to medicine, accuracy generally heads for the hills. But the creators of the new action thriller “Contagion” went to unprecedented lengths to fact-check their story of a destructive viral pandemic, retaining a panel of nationally renowned virologists and epidemiologists as consultants. The intent was to infuse the usual hyperbole with an extra frisson: This is the way it could really happen. Be very afraid.

headline: More About the 9/11 Anniversary
text: It looks as if I should say a bit more about yesterday’s anniversary. So:

headline: A Squirt of Insulin May Delay Alzheimer’s
text: A small pilot study has found preliminary evidence that squirting insulin deep into the nose where it travels to the brain might hold early Alzheimer’s disease at bay, researchers said on Monday.

headline: The New American Muslim
text: Though Peter Casey was raised by a Christian dad and a Jewish mom, he converted to Islam as a young teenager. Now, he uses social media to find out what it means to be Muslim in America.

headline: In Frankfurt, Ford Won’t Wait for Tuesday
text: The press previews for the Frankfurt auto show won’t begin until 8:30 Tuesday morning. That won’t stop some automakers, including Ford, from showing their most important production vehicles and concept cars on Monday evening around the city.

headline: Savoring That Djokovic Shot
text: Down double match point, with Roger Federer serving at 5-3 in the fifth set, Novak Djokovic looked like a beaten man. The crowd stood ready to explode at Federer’s triumph, clearly rooting for the upset. But Djokovic decided to gamble, to double down on his bet and give the wheel one more spin. He guessed right on Federer’s choice of a wide slice to the forehand, unleashed a huge forehand crosscourt winner on the return, then seemed to laugh at the absurdity of the moment.

headline: Drawing Dance: The Cunningham Company at Bard
text: The Brooklyn artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting, through a series of drawings and paintings, their two-year Legacy Tour. After 58 years the company is scheduled to disband on New Year’s Day 2012. This is the 12th in a series of graphite drawings Mr. Parris plans to create from the road, providing a front-row seat to the final weeks of the company’s journey. This week’s entry is from Bard College.

headline: Learning to Love Okra
text: Until lately, I hadn’t been a fan of okra. But then I learned how cooks in the eastern and southern Mediterranean treat this popular vegetable: they cook it whole, after tossing it with salt and vinegar and marinating it for an hour to make it less, well, slimy. Some regional cooks dry okra in the sun after salting it.

headline: Serena Williams Is Fined $2,000
text: One day after her latest outburst at the United States Open, Serena Williams received a $2,000 fine for a code violation of verbal abuse during Sunday’s women’s singles final.

headline: Susan and David
text: Susan and David discuss their first encounter and travel plans for the future.

headline: Maxim Healthcare Pays $150 Million in Fraud Case
text: Maxim Healthcare Services, a privately held company with 360 offices nationwide offering home health care services, has agreed to pay about $150 million to settle civil and criminal charges over claims of false billings to Medicaid and the Department of Veterans Affairs, the Department of Justice announced Monday.

headline: ‘The Black Banners’ Excerpts
text: The Central Intelligence Agency redacted what it considered to be classified information from a memoir by Ali H. Soufan, a former F.B.I. counterterrorism expert, including references to “I,” “me” and “my.”

text: Isaac Hindin Miller of Isaac Likes follows the breakout Aussie model Tom Bull as he navigates New York Fashion Week. text: A. O. Scott looks back at Martin Scorsese’s ultra-violent mob film from 1990.

text: Jim and Jamie describe bonding over good food and a shared love of sea glass.

text: Jeanette Schwarz Young is the director of the Chartered Market Technician program for the Market Technicians Association and the president of the American Association of Professional Technical Analysts. On Sept. 11, 2001, she was working as a broker at the New York Board of Trade.

headline: Rajaratnam’s Defiant Approach to Sentencing
text: Raj Rajaratnam and Zvi Goffer both went to trial to fight insider trading charges, and both were convicted largely on the strength of wiretap evidence. As their sentencing dates approach later this month, they are taking almost diametrically opposed approaches in asking for sentences well below the prison terms called for by the advisory federal sentencing guidelines.

headline: Replacing Schwab’s Late, Great Rewards Card
text: Holders of Charles Schwab’s Invest First Visa credit card, which paid 2 percent cash back on all purchases, are learning this month about their replacement options for the card, which, sadly, was discontinued by Schwab. Bucks has written previously about the demise of the card, which was one of the best deals out there in the world of rewards plastic.

headline: Photo Replay: Sept. 12
text: The day in sports included the world wrestling championships in Istanbul and volleyball championships in Europe.

headline: At Frankfurt Show, German Auto Firms Hope to Rise Above the Gloom
text: FRANKFURT — There may be no better cure for a banker suffering the sovereign debt blues than a new Porsche, and few cities with more bankers in need of solace than Frankfurt.

headline: Fears Rattle Big Banks in France
text: PARIS — French banks moved toward the center of the European debt storm Monday as investor concern about their ability to handle a potential Greek default raised the possibility that France’s government might need to shore up the banks’ financial positions.

headline: A new experiment in gene therapy for cancer, tracking a tree-killing insect and comparing the movie “Contagion” to real-life epidemics.

headline: Guy Maddin Looks Through the ‘Keyhole’
text: TORONTO — Not even the director Guy Maddin is certain how to classify a Guy Maddin movie. The Winnipeg-born filmmaker is known for his experimental, black-and-white, sometimes silent, often strange films that tackle issues in a surreal way. He delivers another puzzler with “Keyhole,” a film starring Jason Patric that could be described as a gangster ghost drama, although it is loosely based on Homer’s “Odyssey.” Mr. Maddin offers an explanation of the film and gives some insight into his creative process.

headline: Attacking a Tumor
text: An annotated video showing how cells have been engineered to attack tumor cells.

headline: Axa Equitable Pitches in an Online Game
text: 3:55 p.m. | Updated Playing games online, known as online gaming or casual gaming, is becoming increasingly popular with marketers because it is becoming increasingly popular with consumers. Even companies in categories that have not been taking part in the trend are starting to, well, play.

headline: Where They Were: Using Maps Across the Curriculum
text: Because The New York Times features multimedia every day, and because we believe that being literate means being able to read images and graphics as well as text, each Monday this school year we’ll present a short lesson plan using Times multimedia.

headline: Fortunate to Survive, but Left Wondering, ‘Why Me?’
text: On Sept. 11, 2001, Britt Newhouse was the president of the Americas operations of Guy Carpenter & Company, a reinsurance intermediary and a subsidiary of Marsh & McLennan. Of the 295 Marsh employees who died in the attacks on Sept. 11, 29 were Guy Carpenter employees. Today, Mr. Newhouse is Guy Carpenter’s chairman.

headline: Rome Opera Not Happy About Losing Conductor to the Met
text: The Rome Opera has leveled unusually harsh criticism for the outwardly genteel world of opera houses at the conductor Fabio Luisi, who canceled performances there and elsewhere to fill in for James Levine at the Metropolitan Opera. Mr. Luisi has long been on standby for the ailing Mr. Levine and was elevated from principal guest conductor to principal conductor, the Met said last week in announcing his last-minute substitute role.

headline: Bernadette Peters: Ghosts of ‘Follies’
text: The actress talks about playing Sally in the Broadway revival of the musical "Follies."

headline: Is SpongeBob SquarePants Bad for Children?
text: New research on children and television has put SpongeBob Squarepants on the hot seat.

headline: Videos Depicting Beating of Protesters in Syria Spread Online
text: The United Nations high commissioner for human rights, Navi Pillay, gave a staggering death toll from the violence in Syria as she addressed the opening session of the human rights council in Geneva on Monday. “With regard to Syria, let me note that, according to reliable sources on the ground, the number of those killed since the onset of the unrest in mid-March 2011 in that country, has now reached at least 2,600,” she said.

headline: With Ruling, Mayor’s Spending May Enter Trial of Former Aide
text: A Manhattan judge on Monday refused to bar defense lawyers from exploring Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s campaign spending habits in the trial of one of his former political consultants.

headline: Passes in the Air, and Points in Bunches
text: The groundwork was laid Thursday night at Green Bay. Seventy-six points, 731 passing yards, no interceptions, defensive coordinators reaching for the antacid. It’s a quaint idea that defenses are ahead of offenses early in the N.F.L. season because offenses require more precise timing that takes longer to hone. But it probably hasn’t been true for a while, not since football tilted so heavily to the pass. And it certainly isn’t true this season.

headline: On Carrie Bradshaw’s Block, Romance Over 6 Decades
text: The house where Carrie Bradshaw lived, supposedly on the Upper East Side but actually at 66 Perry Street in the West Village, still draws a steady stream of “Sex and the City” fans. They snap photos of the row house, which was built in 1866, as if to partake in the fictional life of a New York writer and the foibles of her quest for lasting romance.

headline: Blue-Eyed Muslim Convert Challenges Stereotypes
text: Peter Casey, or AbdulMalik as he is known online, often rides a skateboard to the mosque and rarely thinks twice about performing his prostrations at a Starbucks. Mr. Casey, a 23-year-old recent Queens College graduate, does not do it out of a rebellious impulse to defy Muslim orthodoxy. Rather, he says he seeks to “challenge stereotypes and misconceptions” others have about his faith.

headline: Rwandan Leader, in Paris, Seeks to Ease Tensions
text: PARIS — President Paul Kagame of Rwanda met President Nicolas Sarkozy on Monday in a fence-mending exercise on the Rwandan’s first official bilateral visit to France since the genocide in his country in 1994.

headline: TimesCast | September 12, 2011
text: Fresh European economic fears lead to historic market volatility; a study shows that fathering children can lower testosterone; and a Times presidential photographer reflects on the 9/11 anniversary.

headline: Self-Regulatory Group May Gain Power in House Plan
text: Lawmakers on Capitol Hill are weighing plans to outsource the government’s authority over Wall Street, aiming to shift some power from the Securities and Exchange Commission to groups backed by the financial industry.

headline: Donna Karan, to a Tribal Beat
text: Just a quick dispatch about Donna Karan on a busy Monday afternoon of back-to-back shows. Ms. Karan held her  show in a gallery in far-off Chelsea, where Wyclef Jean showed up in a cute straw ball cap and rhinestone studded jeans. Ms. Karan said she has been traveling to Haiti over the last year and plans to have a party tonight celebrating a group of Haitian artists.

headline: Callahan Fills Drury’s Role as Captain of Rangers
text: Ryan Callahan was named the captain of the Rangers on Monday, succeeding Chris Drury, who retired in August after agreeing to a buyout from the team in June.

headline: Understanding a Child’s Nap Time
text: In this week’s 18 and Under column, Dr. Perri Klass focuses on every parent’s favorite subject, the childhood nap. She writes:

text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#857", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

headline: Jindal to Endorse Perry
text: Bobby Jindal, the Republican governor of Louisiana, has decided to endorse Gov. Rick Perry’s presidential bid, according to a source familiar with the discussions between the two men.

headline: ‘Keys to the White House’ Historian Responds
text: Allan J. Lichtman, the presidential historian at American University whose “Keys to the White House” system we posted a critique of here last week, has kindly prepared a response. (Mr. Lichtman’s system forecasts that President Obama is a heavy favorite to be re-elected in 2012.)

headline: Buildings in 2 Southeastern Cities Are Evacuated as 9/11 Security Concerns Linger
text: The 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks passed without major incident, but jitters about terrorism that led to alerts across the country on the ground and in the skies were still being felt on Monday.

headline: Back to School | Tatiana von Furstenberg’s ‘Tanner Hall’
text: When Hurricane Irene rained all over the planned Southampton screening of Tatiana von Furstenberg and Francesca Gregorini’s coming-of-age boarding school drama, “Tanner Hall,” the duo — best friends since their own teenage years at Brown — decided to move the festivities to Los Angeles. Pulled together in three days by Von Furstenberg, last Tuesday’s low-key premiere at the Vista Theater in Los Feliz (followed by food-truck fare at picnic tables instead of dinner at Nobu) nonetheless boasted the star wattage of the cast members Brie Larson, Amy Ferguson, Chris Kattan and “The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo”’s Rooney Mara, in one of her first lead roles as the film‘s protagonist, Fernanda.

headline: Scientists Pursue an Unusual Tactic Against Alzheimer’s
text: A small experimental pilot study has found preliminary evidence that aerosolized insulin, squirted deep into the nose, might hold early Alzheimer’s disease at bay, The Times reported on Monday. Read the full article, “Squirts of Insulin May Delay Alzheimer’s,” and share your thoughts in the comments section.

headline: A Jekyll-and-Hyde Act for the Feathered Set

headline: Post-Labor Day Slump, and Security, Hit Broadway Box Office
text: Ticket sales for most Broadway shows fell sharply last week, marking the traditional start of the post-Labor Day slump for musicals and plays when the tourist season is over and families are focused on the start of school. Some Broadway producers also said the 9/11 anniversary ceremonies and the heavy security in Times Square were factors in relatively weak sales for Sunday performances.

headline: Perry’s Tone on Social Security Takes a Turn
text: The language Rick Perry used to describe Social Security in a USA Today opinion article on Monday was anything but inflammatory — and strikingly different in tone than his recent book and statements on the campaign trail.

headline: Cavefish Keep Time Without the Sun
text: Cavefish are ancient, scaleless, live in total darkness and lack any pigment. Now researchers have discovered that they have another unusual feature: a circadian rhythm, or body clock, of 47 hours, about twice the length of most animals, including humans.

headline: The Tricks and Tech Keeping Charlie Kimball, Diabetic IndyCar Driver, on the Track
text: BALTIMORE — Charlie Kimball has spoken often about how he learned at age 22 to manage the disease that threatened to end his career. Less has been said, however, about the technology and trial-and-error engineering that enabled him to race at the highest level of motorsports.

headline: Surface Matters for Tennis
text: So, for the fourth year in a row, the men’s final at the U.S. Open is taking place on a weekday. At least it will be easier to watch online at work this afternoon than this season’s midweek Champions League soccer games, which start tomorrow. For the latter, you’re stuck with match ‘‘trackers’’ and minute-by-minute commentary (admittedly, a kind of keyboard art form in the fingers of the Guardian writers) — or maybe pirate video feeds from the likes of Vietnam — whereas the U.S. Open live-streams the match.

text: European astronomers said Monday that they had found what might be the best candidate for a Goldilocks planet yet: a lump of something about 3.6 times as massive as the Earth, circling its star at the right distance for liquid water to exist on its surface — and thus, perhaps, to host life, as we narrowly imagine it.

headline: For Family, 9/11 Is Uninvited Guest
text: Richard Nelson knows what you were thinking on Sunday. Oh, not everything, of course. But if you see (and you need to) his soul-stirring new play, “Sweet and Sad,” at the Public Theater, the odds are that you’ll experience the kind of shivery moments that come when someone articulates ideas that have been lurking in your head, unexpressed and perhaps even unrecognized.

headline: NFL Puts NBC on Top of Ratings
text: Another nail-biting National Football League game provided NBC with record-breaking numbers on Sunday, soundly beating the other broadcast networks in overall viewers and among the advertiser-coveted demographic of 18- to 49-year-olds. After the New York Jets completed their comeback against the Dallas Cowboys with a 50-yard field goal, winning the game 27-24, preliminary overnight Nielsen estimates revealed that it was the highest rated “Sunday Night Football” game since the program moved to NBC in 2006. Final audience figures were not available on Monday.

headline: Suzuki Seeks to Dissolve Volkswagen Partnership
text: TOKYO — In a sharp rebuff to its partner of nearly two years, Suzuki Motor announced Monday that it would seek to end its alliance with Volkswagen, saying no progress had been made on joint projects. It is also asking Volkswagen to sell back its 19.9 percent stake in Suzuki.

headline: Europe Extends Copyright on Music
text: In a victory for the financially troubled recording industry, the European Union on Monday extended the term of copyright on sound recordings to 70 years from 50, while declining to include provisions that would allow artists in Britain and elsewhere in Europe to recoup ownership of their music easily. Had the Council of the European Union not acted, many of the most famous and popular recordings of the British Invasion of the 1960s, including albums by the Beatles, the Rolling Stones, the Who and the Yardbirds, would have fallen into the public domain in the coming years. For example, the Beatles’ first hit record, “Love Me Do,” which was released in 1962, could have been treated next year in much the same way as works by classical composers whose exclusive ownership of their music has expired. With multiple versions available at cheaper prices, the four major record labels would be deprived of one of their biggest sources of income.

headline: TimesCast | Testosterone Lower in Dads
text: A new study shows that fatherhood leads to lower testosterone.

headline: Rental Car Roulette

In fact, this method could have been made for campfires, where the closed packages may be partly buried in the embers to steam-cook.

headline: Young Attention Spans Impaired by SpongeBob and Rapid Games, Study Says
text: Studies have found that children who watch television and play fast-paced interactive games can, in the long run, experience challenges with focus and attention. A study published today in the Journal of Pediatrics suggests that such activity can also have immediate impact on a child’s neurological functions.

headline: Inspiring Young Minds and Holding Some Secrets
text: Surely you’ve heard this story before. It’s about a charismatic high school teacher named Will. He’s in his 30s, and he’s comfortable around his students, so he doesn’t mind when some call him “dude” or “Mr. S.” He challenges their religious beliefs, politicizes the apolitical among them, helps the meek to find their voices; at one time or another, nearly everyone in his class develops a crush on him. But no matter what the school administrators say, he understands and respects the boundaries between teacher and pupil. Or at least that’s true most of the time.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Tommy Hilfiger
text: “I’m not reinventing the wheel,” was how Eugene Souleiman introduced the sleek, simple ponytail at Tommy Hilfiger, before adding, “But for Tommy, I am. Because Tommy does that healthy, American girl with bouncy hair, and I’m doing something very clean, very sharp, and very chic.” This shift from previous seasons (it was Souleiman who was behind those healthy, bouncy heads of hair at the fall 2011 show) was implemented through flat ironing strands with the help of Wella’s Shine Finish, which he called “liquid gold,” then tucking hair back behind the ears before pulling it into a low ponytail tied with a thin black elastic. To achieve a graphic but not hard, product-y look, Souleiman squirted a bit of Wella Professionals Stay Essential Finishing Spray on a brush blush before running it over the surface of the hair to smooth down flyaways. As it turns out, it takes almost as much work to not reinvent the wheel as it does to invent it; as he noted, “It’s so easy to do something really wacky — I could do that with my eyes shut. But to think of something that has a subtlety and beauty to it, it’s so much harder.”

headline: Gay-Marriage Plays Headed to New York
text: “Standing on Ceremony: The Gay Marriage Plays,” a compilation of one-acts focusing on marital equality, will begin an Off Broadway run next month, the producers announced. Directed by Stuart Ross, the production includes original works from Neil LaBute, Moisés Kaufman and Doug Wright, among others, with a portion of ticket sales to be donated to marriage-equality groups. Conceived by Brian Shnipper as a series of benefit events, a Los Angeles run included performances by Matthew Broderick, Judd Hirsch and Debra Messing. A rotating cast for the New York incarnation has yet to be announced. Previews are scheduled to begin at the Minetta Lane Theater on Oct. 18 with an Oct. 24 opening.

headline: Sawyer Lands Giffords Interview
text: ABC News said on Monday that Diane Sawyer, its top anchor, has booked the “first sit-down” interview with Representative Gabrielle Giffords, below, Democrat of Arizona, since she was critically wounded in a shooting spree in Tucson eight months ago. The hourlong special would be broadcast on Nov. 14, one day before the publication of a memoir, “Gabby: A Story of Courage and Hope,” written by Ms. Giffords and her husband, Mark Kelly. An ABC spokesman said Ms. Giffords’s “exact participation” will hinge on her medical condition; in other words, the interview may not be shown on TV, but video clips of her recovery would be shown.

headline: Smoking a Cigarette, Making a Film
text: TORONTO — “Don’t be fooled by the smoke,” James Benning told a sold-out audience at the Toronto International Film Festival screening of his latest film “Twenty Cigarettes.” A collection of living portraits, in which 20 smokers, all friends of his, face the camera for the time it takes to consume a cigarette, it is both an homage to Andy Warhol’s fabled screen tests and a quintessential film for Mr. Benning, 68, a giant of American experimental cinema whose conceptually minimalist works tend to open up vast spaces for reflection.

She, more than any other European politician, will have to either summon the leadership to rescue the euro or concede that the political will is not there.

text: A former hospital chief executive was convicted on Monday in a far-reaching scheme to pay bribes to three New York State legislators in return for beneficial treatment toward his health care organization.

headline: Wary Investors Start to Shun European Banks
text: When a $225 million loan to BNP Paribas comes due Thursday at Legg Mason’s Western Asset management unit, managers at its money market funds will be exercising caution. Instead of renewing the loan as they would have as recently as two months ago, they are looking to park investors’ money elsewhere, avoiding BNP and other Continental banks in favor of institutions in Scandinavia, Canada and Britain.

headline: Dominant Victory in Dominant Year
text: Forecasting nobility in sports is tougher than predicting the weather, which mercifully held Monday at the sodden United States Open for the final between Novak Djokovic and Rafael Nadal.

headline: Gentlemen, Start Conserving
text: Is green Nascar an oxymoron? After all, the sport is all about watching gas guzzlers drive at high speeds in circles for hours. Until 2007, race cars used leaded fuel. Tens of thousands of fans still drive to races in recreational vehicles and other gas hogs.

headline: The Misuse of Life Without Parole
text: The Supreme Court ruled last year that it is cruel and unusual punishment to sentence a juvenile to life without parole when the crime is short of homicide. In the majority opinion, Justice Anthony Kennedy noted that life without parole shares “some characteristics with death sentences that are shared by no other sentences” in altering “the offender’s life by a forfeiture that is irrevocable.”

headline: Government Pays More in Contracts, Study Finds
text: WASHINGTON — Despite a widespread belief that contracting out services to the private sector saves the federal government money, a new study suggests just the opposite — that the government actually pays more when it farms out work.

headline: Somalia’s Worsening Famine
text: Famine has pummeled the Horn of Africa generally, but Somalia has been the hardest hit — and the situation is getting worse. Severe drought-induced scarcities of food and water would pose a daunting challenge for any nation. It is even more daunting for Somalia, where a barely functioning central government and ruthless militant groups are undermining international efforts to respond to the most devastating famine in 60 years.

headline: With Many Holes to Fill, Giants’ Secondary Regroups
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Deon Grant heard the hysteria on the airwaves Monday. Driving in his car, listening to sports talk radio, Grant, a safety, heard callers screeching about how the Giants’ secondary had been exposed by the Washington Redskins a day earlier. The Redskins are an inferior offense, the callers said, but they still dominated the Giants’ defensive backs.

headline: Libya’s War-Tested Women Hope to Keep New Power
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Aisha Gdour, a school psychologist, smuggled bullets in her brown leather handbag. Fatima Bredan, a hairdresser, tended wounded rebels. Hweida Shibadi, a family lawyer, helped NATO find airstrike targets. And Amal Bashir, an art teacher, used a secret code to collect orders for munitions: Small-caliber rounds were called “pins,” larger rounds were “nails.” A “bottle of milk” meant a Kalashnikov.

headline: I.M.F. Chief’s Change of Tune on Bank Capital
text: Over the weekend, Christine Lagarde, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, was desperately trying to back-pedal. A report had surfaced citing an internal I.M.F. document estimating that Europe’s banks were woefully short of capital — by a whopping $273.2 billion.

headline: Bad Grades on Long-Term Care
text: New York has a surprisingly poor record in providing long-term care for its residents, according to a new score card comparing all 50 states and the District of Columbia on the availability and quality of services. New York ranked a dismal 41st. Minnesota, Washington and Oregon were at the top of the list, while Mississippi, Alabama and West Virginia brought up the rear.

headline: Name Misspelled on 9/11 Memorial

headline: Exploding Kansas
text: By late summer 1861, most Americans, North and South, were just coming to grips with the prospect of a long and bloody civil war. Not so the people of western Missouri and eastern Kansas — they had already been fighting over slavery for over five years. Although Kansas’ admission to the Union as a free state in January 1861 had effectively settled the slavery question and calmed the partisan violence in most of that territory, bloody guerrilla warfare still roiled the border with Missouri, a slave state, especially the region south of Kansas City and the Missouri River.

headline: Lottery Numbers

headline: Ryan Watches Film but Hopes There’s No Sequel

headline: A Woman on Libya’s Front Lines
text: NEAR BANI WALID, Libya — The rebel fighter, in a billowing white “Free Libya” T-shirt, jeans, scarf and camouflage cap, was leaning against a car, talking in a businesslike manner with other rebels.

headline: Her Bank Got Enough Help When It Was in Trouble. She Didn’t.
text: For those who live in the alternate universe that is New York outside of Manhattan, brownstone Brooklyn and assorted upper-income offshoots, Mimi Pierre Johnson’s story is depressingly familiar.

headline: Numberplay: Phi – The Magic and the Myth
text: Last week I attended a wonderful presentation given by Keith Devlin, a Stanford University mathematician and NPR’s “Math Guy,” on “Fibonacci & the Golden Ratio: Exposed Common Myths and Fascinating Truths” as part of the public lecture series “Math Encounters” organized by the Museum of Mathematics. The golden ratio or phi (1.61803…) is a fascinating number that we have explored before in the puzzles, Moonlighting Triangles and The Golden Ratio Treasure. The ratio, which is approached to greater and greater precision by two adjacent numbers of the related Fibonacci sequence (1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 13…), has become part of popular culture, attaining almost mystical status. Images and video clips like the one above abound on the Internet, connecting the golden ratio and the Fibonacci sequence with art, architecture, cosmology, biology, aesthetics, poetry, music and many other fields. But how much of all this is true and how much is myth? Professor Devlin, who recently published a scholarly book titled The Man of Numbers: Fibonacci’s Arithmetic Revolution, examined the evidence with a scientific eye and separated the wheat from the chaff. I present some of his findings below – in the form of questions to you, of course.

headline: Uniformity Sought in Sept. 11 Sentiments
text: Major League Baseball told the Mets not to wear caps honoring the first responders of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks during their game Sunday night because it is trying to streamline the way that various causes and tragedies are commemorated.

headline: Protect Our Right to Anonymity
text: Washington

headline: If It Feels Right ...
text: During the summer of 2008, the eminent Notre Dame sociologist Christian Smith led a research team that conducted in-depth interviews with 230 young adults from across America. The interviews were part of a larger study that Smith, Kari Christoffersen, Hilary Davidson, Patricia Snell Herzog and others have been conducting on the state of America’s youth.

headline: MSG Varsity Nears Deal to Show High School Games
text: For years, television stations around the country have shined a light on high school sports, including hockey in Boston and Friday night football in Texas. Yet, New York City’s high school teams received little TV time despite producing scores of players who went on to college and even professional fame, and despite staging tournaments in all sports.

headline: Unheralded Mets Relievers Trying to Make Their Mark
text: As far as athletic archetypes go, these two pitchers, at first glance, would be polar opposites.

headline: Mets and Montero Share a Brief and Scary History
text: SEATTLE — Five years later, Omar Minaya can still recall the sound of a bone-crushing thwack and the scream of pain that followed from 16-year-old Jesus Montero.

headline: Tuesday: Of Base 8
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — You might not appreciate the cleverness of today’s theme until you get to 37 Across. I know I didn’t, but once I filled in CON GAME, the sun came out. Sometimes a good payoff can really take a common homophone theme and turn it into something elegant.

headline: Long Day’s Journey Into Laughter
text: Stage directions, those humble, practical and occasionally ignored players in the art of dramatic composition, are the stars of the show at the Kraine Theater in the East Village, where the New York Neo-Futurists are presenting a handful of early Eugene O’Neill plays, shorn of all dialogue. “The Complete & Condensed Stage Directions of Eugene O’Neill Volume 1: Early Plays/Lost Plays” sounds like the title of an exceptionally dreary doctoral thesis, but the show, adapted and directed by Christopher Loar, is something far more enjoyable, an impish illustration of how lively entertainment can be created from theatrical spare parts.

headline: Darkness Around the Spotlight
text: Somewhere along the road from Washington to Broadway, the Kennedy Center production of “Follies” picked up a pulse. A vigorous heart now beats at the center of this revitalized revival of James Goldman and Stephen Sondheim’s 1971 musical, which opened on Monday night at the Marquis Theater. And though the subject is the ghosts of show business past, don’t expect gentle nostalgia. This “Follies” looks back as much in anger as in fondness. That’s what makes it so vibrant.

headline: On 9/11, the View From the Train
text: I’d been away for a few days, just me and my dog, but Sunday morning I rose early and drove the 100 miles to New York City. On the 10th anniversary of 9/11, I felt a deep need to be with my family. As I began to cross the Triborough Bridge into Manhattan, I could hear the whoosh of police helicopters overhead. I looked up. There were five of them.

headline: Amid Cheating Complaints, Regents Move to Improve Test Security
text: ALBANY — Acknowledging that New York lags behind the best practices for detecting and deterring cheating by educators on high-stakes standardized tests, a Board of Regents committee on Monday authorized an independent investigator to look at how the State Education Department handles complaints of cheating.

headline: In Deal, Hundreds of Mentally Ill People Will Leave Confinement of Nursing Home
text: Hundreds of mentally ill people who have been confined to nursing homes, sometimes in prisonlike conditions, would move to apartments or other housing within three years under a legal settlement with New York State.

headline: Battle for Libya | September 12, 2011
text: Photographs from the front lines as Libya’s rebels fight to take complete control of the country from Col. Qaddafi’s loyalists.

headline: U.N. Count of Syria Dead Now at 2,600
text: The United Nations on Monday raised its estimate of the number of protesters killed in the Syrian uprising to 2,600, as it announced the appointment of three investigators to look into human rights abuses in the country, where President Bashar al-Assad has defied international condemnation of the crackdown, even among his dwindling allies.

headline: Out of Prison, Ex-Procurers for Client 9 Get New Jobs
text: An untold number of customers were willing to pay $5,000 an hour for an escort from Emperor’s Club VIP, the Internet prostitution ring run by a 62-year-old former Israeli tax official and his bubbly 20-something girlfriend that in 2008 helped end the political career of Eliot Spitzer, also known then as Client No. 9.

headline: Perry Is Target as Republican Candidates Take Aim
text: TAMPA, Fla. — The Republican presidential candidates aggressively confronted Gov. Rick Perry at a debate here on Monday night, and pressed him to explain his views on Social Security and his decade-long record in Texas, including an effort to require the vaccination of schoolgirls and granting children of illegal immigrants a college tuition break.

headline: Terms Met, Payout Rises for Workers at 9/11 Site
text: More than 10,000 ground zero rescue and cleanup workers who settled lawsuits with New York City over damage to their health will share an extra $55 million in bonus payments but will not have to pay lawyers’ fees on the increase, a federal judge has ruled.

headline: Jailed 5 Years Without Trial, Prisoner Issues Airborne Plea
text: He has been blogging about his case from jail, pleading his side in lengthy writings. He says he has cut his hand and written on the wall of his cell with blood. And he has hired a pilot to fly a banner along the New York skyline proclaiming what he sees as an injustice.

headline: Premier of Turkey Takes Role in Region
text: CAIRO — Seeking to capitalize on Turkey’s growing stature and influence across the Arab world at a time of regional upheaval, its prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, appeared on Egyptian television late Monday once again calling Israel “the West’s spoiled child.”

text: SEATTLE — Francisco Cervelli was found to have a concussion Monday after visiting Dr. Kirk Roberts, a neurologist at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital specializing in concussion syndromes, the Yankees said.

headline: Marc Jacobs: Secondary Line in Prime Time
text: Marc Jacobs, citing production delays caused by Hurricane Irene, decided a couple of weeks ago to move his main collection show from its usual perch on Monday night to Thursday, at the end of Fashion Week. He instead showed his diffusion line, Marc by Marc Jacobs, in the usual Monday time slot. And that turned out to be a good move, for more reasons than the extra design time he was able to buy.

headline: U.S. Spending Billions on Rural Jobs, but Impact Is Uncertain
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is investing billions of dollars to promote economic development in rural areas by bringing broadband service and small-business financing to regions with chronic poverty and high unemployment.

headline: What’s a Presidential Library to Do?
text: SIMI VALLEY, Calif. — When Republicans gathered at the Ronald Reagan Library and Museum here for the presidential debate last week, the backdrop was an overhauled exhibition on the Reagan presidency, done under the watchful eye of Nancy Reagan. It is intended, in part, to be a more complete depiction of the Reagan presidency, replacing one that many had seen as a bit too worshipful and airbrushed.

headline: As Perry Rises, G.O.P. Elite Look Toward Romney
text: TAMPA, Fla. — The rising presidential candidacy of Gov. Rick Perry of Texas is stirring excitement for many Republican voters but is creating unease in some quarters of the party’s establishment, particularly over his views of Social Security, which are at the root of an intensifying competition with Mitt Romney.

headline: Your Femininity Is Showing

headline: Newswallah: In the National English-Language Press Today
text: The 2002 Gujarat riots dominated the day’s headlines after the Supreme Court ruled that a lower court should look into a massacre at Gulberg Housing Society that left 69 people dead, including a former member of Parliament.  Calling the riots “abominable and woeful”, (Indian Express) the court said it would cease to directly monitor the case. The court directed the court-appointed (Hindustan Times) special investigation team to submit its final report before an Ahmedabad trial court. Leaders of the Bharatiya Janata Party issued statements celebrating the ruling as proof that there was no evidence (Times of India) to link the Gujarat chief minister, Narendra Modi, to the riots.

headline: Seattle Council Votes for Paid Sick Time
text: The Seattle City Council voted Monday to require employers with five or more workers to provide paid sick days. Supporters said they expected Mayor Mike McGinn to approve the legislation, which would make Seattle one of three major cities, along with San Francisco and Washington, to require paid sick days. Connecticut is the only state to enact paid sick days for private employers. The Seattle vote was 8 to 1, with the City Council president, Richard Conlin, opposing. Companies with 5 to 49 workers would have to offer full-time workers at least five paid sick days yearly, while the largest companies would have to provide at least nine. Supporters said it was important for public health that food-service and health-care workers have paid sick days, but business opponents said the legislation was an expensive mandate.

headline: A Conversation With Archie Panjabi
text: Immediately after warmly greeting me on the Greenpoint, Brooklyn set of the popular CBS drama “The Good Wife”, British actress Archie Panjabi started apologizing.

headline: Yankees Batter Mariners’ Hernandez for an Easy Victory
text: SEATTLE — The Yankees, whose offense awoke Sunday from a two-day slumber, demonstrated in convincing fashion Monday that the previous game was no fluke. The postseason creeping into view, this team has started to amass hits and score runs again, even against one of the best pitchers in baseball.

headline: At Monk Competition, a Sound Worth Returning To
text: WASHINGTON — Hod Moshonov, a 22-year-old pianist from Israel, had already loosened his tie by 1 p.m. on Sunday, and his wine-colored dress shirt was coming loose from his waist. Super-revved, he seemed to dump his whole conception of jazz on his instrument.

headline: A Plea to Bring the ‘Sexy Back’ Back

headline: The India Growth Story: Glass Half Full or Half Empty?
text: Reading the foreign and domestic newspapers these days, it is hard to avoid the conclusion that the bloom has come off the rose of the India growth story. For instance, a leading Indian business daily, Mint, recently ran a series questioning India’s future growth prospects, and pointing to the unfinished economic reform agenda.

headline: Can  Jets Make ‘Hurry Up’ Their 12th Man on Offense?
text: With just over three minutes to go in the first half against the Cowboys on Sunday, the Jets were looking for a spark. After four offensive possessions, the numbers were dismal: 3 first downs, 3 three-and-outs and a 10-point deficit on the scoreboard.

headline: How to Raise Revenue Without Violating the Tax Pledge
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul.

headline: Lewis Hine Spotlighted in Paris Photo Show
text: The photographs of Lewis Hine (1874-1940) fuse humanism, artistic vision and remarkable anthropological insight about the early 20th century. A new exhibition on Hine, running through Dec. 18, the Fondation Henri Cartier-Bresson (2 Impasse Lebouis; 33-156-802-700; henricartierbresson.org) in Paris has assembled 150 original black-and-white prints.

headline: American Hikers to Be Freed in 2 Days, Ahmadinejad Says
text: LONDON — Iran’s president said Tuesday that two Americans arrested two years ago while hiking the Iran-Iraq frontier and imprisoned on espionage charges would be freed within two days as a humanitarian gesture. The move seemed timed to portray him more favorably before he attends the United Nations General Assembly meeting next week.

headline: U.S. Embassy and NATO Headquarters Attacked in Kabul
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Heavily armed insurgents wearing suicide vests struck Tuesday at two of the most prominent symbols of the American diplomatic and military presence in Kabul, the United States Embassy and the nearby NATO headquarters, demonstrating the Taliban’s ability to infiltrate even the most heavily fortified districts of the capital.

headline: Abuse Victims Ask Court to Prosecute the Vatican
text: Human rights lawyers and victims of clergy sexual abuse filed a complaint on Tuesday urging the International Criminal Court in The Hague to investigate and prosecute Pope Benedict XVI and three top Vatican officials for crimes against humanity for what they described as abetting and covering up the rape and sexual assault of children by priests.

headline: Maybe Someone Should Make a Documentary About Documentarians and the Press?
text: TORONTO — Any honest, independent, critically minded journalist had to get a little nervous at Monday’s documentary conference here, part of the Toronto International Film Festival, on hearing that some documentarians consider the press to be a willing adjunct to their advocacy. The subject came up several times in the first 30 minutes or so of an afternoon panel that was titled “How Films Can Change the World.”

headline: A Wilderness Ranger, Age 21
text: I’m a senior in college, which means that everyone I meet feels entitled to ask me, “So, what are you planning to do after you graduate?” But I’m at a liberal arts school, so I always respond with an “I’m not sure yet” or an “I’m going to take what comes my way.”

headline: A Keen Use of the Wind Aided Djokovic
text: Novak Djokovic won his first U.S. Open and his fourth Grand Slam title, defeating Rafael Nadal in four grueling sets. The match had many twists and turns, as conditions varied from blustery to calm. As night fell over Arthur Ashe Stadium, the points became brutally physical, with both players delivering forcing body blows in an attempt to knock the other out.

headline: Deluxe Apartment, Village Town House or Staten Island Manse?
text: This week’s Appraisal tells the tale of one of the town houses that stood in for Carrie Bradshaw’s Upper East Side pad on “Sex and the City” and the real-life couple, Harold Eliot Leeds, an architect and Pratt professor, and Wheaton Galentine, a filmmaker, who lived there for 50 years.

headline: Seth Rogen’s Answers to Your Questions
text: TORONTO — You asked, he answered! We had some time with the actor Seth Rogen at the Toronto International Film Festival, where he is representing the movies “50/50″ and “Take This Waltz, and we picked some of the best questions submitted by our readers and posed them to Seth. Here are his responses.

headline: What the President’s Job Plan Means to Me
text: I am trying to decide when exactly small businesses became the official poster child of the latest economic disaster. This is a relatively new phenomenon, but it’s been building for a few years. Sometimes, the attention feels good. I didn’t know everyone cared! Sometimes it feels like pandering. I have a suspicion that some of the people who are always arguing that we will destroy small businesses if we raise income taxes on the wealthy don’t really care that much about small businesses, but it sounds noble.

text: Hewlett-Packard has extended its offer for the Autonomy Corporation, as it tries to win over shareholders.

headline: From Europe, Mounting Pressure Over Greece’s Debt
text: PARIS — Facing market pressure to resolve the Greek debt crisis once and for all, President Nicolas Sarkozy of France and Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany will hold a video conference call Wednesday evening with the embattled Greek prime minister, George Papandreou, French officials announced on Tuesday.

headline: British Hacking Inquiry to Recall James Murdoch
text: LONDON — A parliamentary panel investigating the phone hacking scandal in the British outpost of Rupert Murdoch’s media empire said on Tuesday that it would recall his son James Murdoch to answer more questions about the case.

headline: A Contrarian Since Childhood
text: In 2001 Christopher Hitchens published a slim, engaging how-to book titled “Letters to a Young Contrarian.” Among its most consequential advice was this: “The noble title of ‘dissident’ must be earned rather than claimed; it connotes sacrifice and risk rather than mere disagreement.”

headline: Special Election! So What’s So Special?
text: Whatever his flaws — and where to begin counting them? — the self-destructive Anthony D. Weiner was not yawn-inducing. Too bad the same can’t be said about the two men running in a special election on Tuesday for the Congressional seat that Mr. Weiner forfeited after he sexted himself into political oblivion as the Twit of Tweets.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Attacking the Causes of the Obesity Epidemic
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: How Much Hoc to Add? (Wonkish and Methodological)
text: Mark Thoma objects to Tyler Cowen’s attempt to pigeonhole some of us as “Old New Keynesians”, and makes the case for flexibility in use of models. Indeed. But there’s something more systematic to the macro story – something that very much informs my work. Namely, “old Keynesian” and “new Keynesian” models represent two intelligent but imperfect responses to the problem of thinking about an economy in which people must make future-oriented decisions. Neither is fully convincing, but there are no better alternatives at this point. So what I do, and I hope others do as well, is to think about policy issues both ways, and try to “bracket” things in a way that leads to reasonably secure conclusions.

headline: Vain Glorious | Barbershop Quartet
text: We’ve discovered a quartet of Portland barbershops to get your mop and mug tidied up — in perfect harmony. All four establishments, much like the city’s famed eateries and wineries, are exceptional in skill and gentle in pricing.

headline: Know Your Enemies
text: I took it personally the first time I saw a Barney trap hanging from a tree in Delaware County where my family has a cottage. It brought to mind the time, about 20 years ago, when I transplanted a sapling that I found growing behind a shed to a spot near the stump of a century-old butternut tree that had fallen victim to wind and rot.

headline: Wall Street Self-Regulator Makes Case for More Power

headline: Republicans Are Clear Favorites in New York and Nevada Special Elections
text: Voters will go to the polls in opposite corners of the country on Tuesday. In New York’s Ninth Congressional District in Brooklyn and Queens, they will be picking a replacement for Democratic Representative Anthony D. Weiner. And in Nevada’s Second Congressional District, which encompasses nearly all of the state outside Las Vegas, they will be choosing someone to replace Dean Heller, a Republican, who was appointed to the Senate in May after John Ensign resigned.

headline: Fears Ease in France, and Shares Edge Higher
text: Stocks rose on Tuesday, sending the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index higher for a second day, as French banks eased concerns over their access to funding and investors watched for signs of progress in solving Europe’s debt crisis.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | The Lake & Stars
text: “It’s like they just came out of the ocean. They’ve been hanging out on holiday,” said Emiko Kaneko of the makeup backstage at the Lake & Stars. A recent trip to Mexico City prompted the designers Maayan Zilberman and Nikki Dekker to create this season’s presentation of pieces in red, gold, passion fruit, peach and mint. “We thought of a girl gang that was strongest as a unit. Together they emote this heat,” Zilberman said of the lineup of 16 bronzed models wearing lingerie, red socks and sandals. Kaneko used minimal makeup on the face, simply M.A.C.’s tawny brown Photo lipstick with a touch of gloss, and focused instead on creating glowing skin with Studio Sculpt in a variety of shades. The center-parted pulled back hair was more labor intensive. Andre Gunn channeled Frida Kahlo and Apache Native Americans with tight fishtail braids coiled in single or double loops and fastened with black or blond ribbon.

headline: Bill Would Provide Federal Funds for 9/11 Memorial
text: Under a plan proposed to Congress last week, the federal government would assume ownership of the National September 11 Memorial and Museum and would provide $20 million in annual financing.

headline: Vincent Reinhart Joins Morgan Stanley
text: Vincent R. Reinhart, an economist and former head of the Federal Reserve‘s monetary division, is joining Morgan Stanley as its chief United States economist in New York.

headline: See You in the Next Life: ‘Point Break’ Is Hollywood’s Latest Planned Remake
text: In the 1991 thriller “Point Break,” a squad of surfers-cum-bank robbers commit their crimes while wearing masks of Presidents Lyndon B. Johnson, Richard Nixon, Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan, so we’ll assume that in a newly announced remake of this film, they’ll disguise themselves as Bill Clinton, George W. Bush, Barack Obama and Hu Jintao of China. That’s just a guess, but we can tell you for certain that the original “Point Break” was directed by Kathryn Bigelow, the future Academy Award-winning director of “The Hurt Locker,” and starred Keanu Reeves as a young F.B.I. agent on the trail of the “Ex-Presidents” gang, whose philosophical leader is played by Patrick Swayze. The new version was announced late Monday by Alcon Entertainment, a production and finance company based at Warner Brothers, which has been on a rebooting binge; last month the company announced that it was producing a new “Blade Runner” film that could serve as a sequel or prequel to Ridley Scott’s original movie.

headline: Volkswagen Group Brings the Pomp and Power on Eve of Frankfurt Motor Show
text: FRANKFURT — On Monday night, the Volkswagen Group rang every bell, blew every whistle, trotted out a troupe of dogs and ponies and, quite literally, nearly set the stage on fire.

headline: General Motors Europe Chief Says Opel Is (Still) Not for Sale
text: FRANKFURT– Nick Reilly, the president of General Motors Europe, has said numerous times that the company’s Opel unit was not for sale, but that didn’t prevent the question from arising again when he sat down with a small group of reporters at the Frankfurt auto show Tuesday.

headline: Rick Perry as Howard Dean
text: Last week, I compared Rick Perry in 2012 to Barack Obama in 2008: Like Obama four years ago, Perry doesn’t have the profile of an ideal general election candidate, but he’s the kind of figure that an influential portion of his party’s primary electorate is eager to find a reason to support. As Perry fumbled his way through last night’s Republican primary debate, though, the Texas governor seemed a lot more like Howard Dean in 2004 — a candidate, again, who many Democratic primary voters wanted to support, because he was speaking their language and gleefully throwing insults in the teeth of a president they hated, but also a candidate whose weaknesses were obvious enough that he couldn’t finally make the sale.

headline: Turkish Leader Urges Vote for Palestinian Statehood
text: CAIRO — Capitalizing on Turkey’s growing stature and influence across the Middle East at a time of regional upheaval, its prime minister ramped up the pressure on Israel and the United States on Tuesday, telling the Arab League ministers they must vote for Palestinian statehood at the United Nations this month.

headline: Are Bills That Good, and Chiefs That Bad?
text: This time last year, I wrote that an opening day loss wasn’t necessarily a harbinger of things to come. But Week 1 isn’t meaningless, and no team knows that better than the Chiefs. Last season, Kansas City pulled off the biggest upset in Week 1 and rode a hot start directly into a division championship.

headline: Soaring Poverty Casts Spotlight on ‘Lost Decade’
text: WASHINGTON — Another 2.6 million people slipped into poverty in the United States last year, the Census Bureau reported Tuesday, and the number of Americans living below the official poverty line, 46.2 million people, was the highest number in the 52 years the bureau has been publishing figures on it.

headline: At Rodarte, a Van Gogh Exhibition
text: Before the Rodarte show, one of the photographers made a crack about the “teenage front row.” Elle and Dakota Fanning, next to Tavi Gevinson, were facing Taylor Swift (who is an adult), next to Anna Wintour. While it is true that Kate and Laura Mulleavy, the Rodarte designers, skew young in their fan base, I think that is part of what fuels the appeal of their collections, at least among a fashion set that is eternally nostalgic for that moment in high school when anything seemed possible. (See Rookie.) Beyoncé and Solange Knowles made a late entrance, so maybe the appeal is even broader.

headline: Guineans in New York Push for Justice in Homeland

In a corner of the office sit stacks of hand-lettered placards that were made for a rally to protest violence against Guinean women.

headline: New Take on Chekhov to Highlight Soho Rep Season

headline: South Korean Family Conglomerates Pressured
text: SEOUL — In Parliament, lawmakers call them “beasts.” Newspaper editorials liken them to unfettered predators robbing ordinary people of their livelihood. President Lee Myung-bak, once an ally, has withdrawn his promise to cut taxes for them, instead urging them to win “respect from the people” by doing more to help the poor.

headline: The Death of the Confidence Fairy
text: In the first half of last year a strange delusion swept much of the policy elite on both sides of the Atlantic — the belief that cutting spending in the face of high unemployment would actually create jobs. I went after this stuff early and hard (I suspect that the confidence fairy will be one of my lasting contributions to economic discourse); still, it’s good to have a steadily mounting weight of evidence about just how wrong that view was.

The production version of the coupe is expected to be shown at the Tokyo auto show later this year.

text: New York State’s poverty rate climbed to 16 percent last year, the third consecutive annual increase and the highest rate since 1998, according to census figures released Tuesday. Nearly 3.1 million New Yorkers were living below the official poverty rate in 2010, also the highest total in 12 years.

headline: North Korean Defectors Rescued Off Japan Coast
text: TOKYO — Nine North Korean defectors, including three children, were rescued off the coast of Japan after drifting some 500 miles in a small wooden boat, the Japanese Coast Guard said Tuesday.

headline: Bursting the ‘Nutty Bubble’
text: People who spend a lot of time around the luxury-goods trade live in what Linda Fargo, the fashion director of Bergdorf Goodman, termed the other day “a nutty bubble.’’ While the world outside the Fashion Week tents teeters on the economic brink, the people inside them teeter around on shoes, she said, for which they think nothing of spending $1,500 a pair.

headline: Backstage Grooming Report | Timo Weiland
text: “We imagined a New Yorker going coastal, or heading to the beach,” explained Alan Eckstein, Timo Weiland’s design partner, minutes before the label’s first runway show. “He is resourceful, youthful in spirit and loves an adventure.” James Boehmer, the Nars makeup artist, let clothes take center stage by keeping male models’ faces bare. “When guys are wearing bright colors and bold patterns, even a little bit of makeup can borderline on precious,” Boehmer said. “Instead, I prepped the guys’ faces with massage, and applied Nars Hydrating Freshening Lotion and Hydrating Moisture Cream to mildly exfoliate and minimize dryness. That’s it.”

headline: New Director for Nederlands Dans Theater

Mr. Vincent, who took over in the post in the 2009-2010 season, will stay on as co-artistic director until the end of the year, the company added in a statement on its Web site.

headline: Student Loan Defaults Rise Again
text: As Tamar Lewin reports in today’s Times, defaults on student loans rose again last year, and sharply. Of all borrowers, 8.8 percent – the highest rate since 1997 – were unable to pay their loans, while 15 percent of borrowers at for-profit institutions defaulted on their payments. headline: Still Unearthing Discoveries in de Kooning’s Brush Strokes
text: The first thing visitors will see at the entrance to the Museum of Modern Art’s sprawling Willem de Kooning retrospective, which opens on Sunday, is a wall of photographs that chronicle six stages in the creation of the legendary painting “Woman I” (1950-52). John Elderfield, MoMA’s chief curator emeritus of painting and sculpture, said he chose these images as a starting point because they illustrate “that de Kooning was an artist about process.”

This spring, Ms. Moore introduced a breakfast panel of children’s book authors — Brian Selznick, Kevin Henkes and Sarah Dessen — at Book Expo America, the publishing industry’s annual convention, and demonstrated a long-standing interest in and firm grasp of children’s literature. Her enthusiasm was infectious.

headline: One Quick Thought About Newspapers and Grief
text: Sometimes a story in the newspaper arrests your attention not because you want to read it but because you want to show it to someone who is dead. For a moment that you wish would last longer, your impulse to share the article overrides your conscious understanding that the person who would have liked it, in this case my mother, is beyond reach. Then you do remember.

headline: Forget Your Umbrella

headline: Glenn Close Explores Gender in ‘Albert Nobbs’
text: TORONTO — In “Albert Nobbs,” Glenn Close plays a 19th-century woman who, having fallen on hard times, poses as a man to get work as a butler. The character lives for over 20 years in that guise with nobody knowing her secret, until she comes in contact with a painter at the hotel where she works who might have a secret of his own.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Marc by Marc Jacobs
text: You know you’re a beauty industry rock star when a designer makes references to your past work in his preshow brief. “Nineties Guido,” was what Marc Jacobs wanted for Marc by Marc Jacobs according to Guido Palau backstage before the show. “They got out all my old pictures,” he said of the stack of images unearthed by Jacobs’s team. In the end, Palau came up with a half pulled-through ponytail created by first blow-drying the hair with Redken Satinwear, then pulling it back with an elastic. The next step was attaching the tail to the back of the head with a silver Goody clip and coating the hair with Shine Enrich and Forceful 23 Spray. “A little bit spiky — aerodynamic,” is how Palau described the finished look. Nails were painted Zoya’s Olivia with a custom matte top coat to make a nude velvet effect. For makeup, Dick Page conceived what he referred to as the appropriately collegiate “Pretty 101, just a healthy face.” This was done using Shiseido gold blush dusted just above the cheek bones with a rosy tone below. Eyelids were spread with Shiseido Maquillage Lip Gloss and brows were colored with Shimmering Cream eyeshadow in one of four shades: Sable, Gold Meadow, Caviar or Leather, a reddish brown for those with auburn hair. Roseate was dabbed onto the bare mouth with the finger. Said Page, “Nothing too complicated, no tricks.”

headline: Look of the Moment | Solange Knowles
text: The Look: Divine Disco – Super ’70s long sleeves, a groovy watercolor print and mylar-metallic heels.

headline: ‘Bachelor Pad’ Finale Delivers for ABC
text: Blanketing prime time with three hours of the “Bachelor Pad” paid off on Monday, as the season finale of that show averaged just over seven million total viewers while lifting ABC to first place in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic for the night among the broadcast networks. On the CW, the French designer Jean Paul Gaultier’s interview of Lady Gaga, “Gaga By Gaultier,” averaged 1.4 million viewers, a small figure to be sure, but it was still the network’s largest audience since the season finale of “Supernatural” in May. The 2011 Miss Universe Pageant, meanwhile, produced diminishing returns for NBC: the event was down 16 percent in the 18-to-49 demographic when compared with last year, its lowest rating ever.

headline: Regulators Fear Legal Challenges to Derivatives Rules
text: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission is moving to safeguard dozens of derivatives regulations from legal challenges after a federal appeals court recently struck down a new rule for corporate America, an agency official said Tuesday.

headline: 14 Gun Seizures, 16 Arrests and a Bit of Dirty Dancing
text: The police at the West Indian Day Parade last week were extremely busy. There were three shooting episodes, and the police seized 14 firearms and made 16 arrests. But along the peaceful stretches of the parade some officers apparently found time to enjoy themselves, perhaps with a little too much abandon.

headline: Peter King in the Hot Seat — in London
text: Representative Peter T. King testified about terrorism on Tuesday before a legislative committee, but the committee was in London, not Washington, and the New York Republican found himself the uncomfortable object of tough questioning. In a hearing on “Roots of Violent Radicalization,” Mr. King was asked about his own past support for the Irish Republican Army.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Hiccups Solved!

headline: A Hell’s Kitchem Mural in Distress
text: Arnold Belkin’s 1972 mural, “Against Domestic Colonialism,” is in dire need of restoration. A team of expert conservators inspected it on Tuesday.

text: FRANKFURT — Norbert Reithofer, the chief executive of BMW, correctly called the last big auto industry crisis in 2008. So if the sage of Munich was predicting another sharp downturn, that would be cause for concern.
