headline: In Ohio, Obama Emphasizes School Upgrades as Part of Jobs Proposal
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — President Obama took his jobs sales pitch to a high school in this politically crucial swing state on Tuesday, challenging Congress to act swiftly on his $447 billion proposal of tax cuts and stimulus projects to buck up the economy.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Rodarte
text: Backstage at Rodarte, James Kaliardos was touching up Kate Mulleavy’s makeup while one of his assistants prepped the model Samantha Gradoville (wearing her own webby, iridescent knit) nearby. Odile Gilbert was on the other side of the space getting girls ready for what she calls the “Sweet 16,” an off-center part with a natural wave and one side twisted up and tucked in with a comb. “Soft, innocent — not pretentious,” she said of the style created with Kérastase Volume Active Mousse and Double Force hairspray. “It looks easy, but it’s not easy.” Deborah Lippman painted toes Fashion, her opaque beige, and fingers a custom variation of Lady Sings the Blues. The Mulleavy sisters asked her to up the amount of large graphite glitter in the polish rather than the standard mix of paillettes. Like Lippman, Kaliardos channeled Van Gogh’s “Starry Night” with dark navy, shimmering eyes. Using Nars products, he drew all over lids with the shadow pencil in Dark Night and then added Night Flight and Tropic, a turquoise glitter. “Looks a bit like Edvard Munch’s ‘The Scream,'” Kaliardos said laughing as he moved on from Van Gogh. Penny Lane cream blush was used high on the cheeks and to cover the lips, which were then coated with Pearl Beach eyeshadow and Na Na gloss. “Dreamy and aggressive at the same time,” he said. “A cool, ethereal girl.”

headline: Reviewing Hospoda
text: This week’s restaurant review takes us to the Bohemian National Hall on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, for a look at the Central European cuisine of Hospoda, on the building’s ground floor.

headline: Big Flavors in Delicate Portions
text: THERE is something charmingly Old World about Hospoda, the sleek new restaurant on the ground floor of the Bohemian National Hall on the Upper East Side. With its plain bare tables, elegant inlaid wood floors, high ceilings, whimsically engraved wood walls and soaring glasswork, the dining room suggests a beautifully renovated Prague apartment.

headline: In the Belly of the East
text: TORONTO — The glass case in the lobby of the Toronto Blue Jays’ executive office holds World Series trophies from 1992 and 1993. Between them is a small stand, just a few inches high, with a $1 coin. Cito Gaston, the manager of those teams, gave the coin to the receptionist for good luck when he retired two years ago. She displays it as a placeholder for the next trophy, because the coin is dated 1993.

headline: Return of the Man Who Used to Rock
text: The 40-year career of the English singer-songwriter Nick Lowe constitutes a paradox: the songs he has written are better known than he is. He cheerfully acknowledges that many people think that Elvis Costello is the author of the Lowe song “(What’s So Funny ’Bout) Peace, Love and Understanding” and that the Johnny Cash version of “The Beast in Me” has come to overshadow his own, which was used on the soundtrack of the HBO series “The Sopranos.”

headline: The Daily Shoe | Rodarte
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Self-Driving Audi A2 Concept, for the Reluctant Motorist
text: FRANKFURT — When conceiving the A2 concept, Audi engineers might have been thinking about the 405.

headline: Just Name That Tune: He’ll Sing It
text: A performer of boundless confidence, charm and good humor but with a less-than-photographic musical memory singing karaoke without a teleprompter: that would describe Gregory Charles, the 43-year-old Canadian singer and pianist who gave two shows at the Café Carlyle on Saturday.

headline: Excerpt: 'Completeness'
text: A scene from the new Itamar Moses play at Playwrights Horizons. (Video courtesy of the production.)

headline: U.S. Embassy in Kabul Under Attack
text: Insurgents launched a complex assault against the United States Embassy and the nearby NATO headquarters.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Afghanistan, Libya, Pakistan and Yemen.

headline: Militants Attack U.S. Embassy in Kabul
text: Insurgents launched a complex assault against the United States Embassy and a nearby NATO base in Kabul on Tuesday, raising new questions about security in Afghanistan’s capital.

headline: American Military Team Visits Libya to Assess Risks of Reopening U.S. Embassy
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — American forces are back on the shores of Tripoli — albeit in a small way.

headline: Pessimism and Little Progress After Day of Negotiations Ends
text: Negotiators for the N.B.A. and its players union departed Manhattan under a cloud of frustration Tuesday, a labor deal still out of reach, and the season appearing increasingly in doubt.

headline: Warren Jumping Into Race for Brown’s Senate Seat
text: BOSTON – Elizabeth Warren, the Harvard law professor who has battled the financial industry as a consumer advocate, will announce her candidacy Wednesday for what will probably be a high-profile race against Senator Scott P. Brown.

headline: After His Open Victory, Djokovic Is ‘the Happiest Guy’
text: Fresh off a convincing and thrilling United States Open final victory over Rafael Nadal, Novak Djokovic admitted he was feeling anything but fresh Tuesday morning.

headline: TimesCast | September 13, 2011
text: Militants attack United States and NATO targets in Kabul; Iran agrees to free jailed American hikers; and a heated Congressional race to replace Anthony D. Weiner.

headline: Pairings: Braised Spiced Veal Brisket
text: Autumn approaches. Say hello to braising. It’s just right for an esoteric cut of veal, the brisket, actually the meatier, less fatty part of a boned breast. Spices, a touch of smoked paprika, and onions and mushrooms in a sauce with real depth give the meat what it needs alongside a graceful red wine with a piquant, smoky bite. I used free-range veal. Like most braises, this was best with patience. When done, refrigerating it overnight and reheating it only improves it. And for Rosh Hashana, consider potato pancakes alongside.

headline: A Complex Red With an Austrian Accent
text: EVERYBODY knows that wine is intimidating. The terminology and the connoisseurship can set even the most confident person atremble. But nothing scares wine consumers so much as an umlaut.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Afghanistan, Libya, Pakistan and Yemen.

headline: When Empty Seats Just Won’t Do
text: THEY are monkeying with the 75-year-old Monkey Bar again, and an urgent reason suggests itself.

headline: Elmhurst College Asks Applicants About Sexual Orientation
text: The Common Application may have opted earlier this year not to ask students about their sexual orientation, but Elmhurst College in Illinois has recently announced that it will do so on its admission application.

headline: Happy Birthday, Roald and James
text: Today would have been Roald Dahl’s 95th birthday had he not died at the age of 74 in 1990. This year also marks the birthday of one of his most beloved books, “James and the Giant Peach,” which was published in the United States 50 years ago. (Interestingly, it wasn’t published in Britain, Mr. Dahl’s home until six years later.)

headline: A Guide to Cutting Through Special-Election Spin
text: I used to take the view — and I think I’ve been pretty consistent about this — that special elections to Congress, while interesting on their own merits, should more or less be ignored in terms of their national implications.

headline: Macedonia Is Wild Card of EuroBasket Quarterfinals
text: Most of the quarterfinalists at EuroBasket 2011 do not come as a surprise. Greece, Slovenia and Russia are no strangers to this stage of the competition. And Spain, France, Serbia and host Lithuania were touted as pretournament favorites. But Macedonia? It is bound to turn some heads when the quarterfinals begin Wednesday.

headline: G.M. Looks to Shepherd U.A.W. Pact
text: DETROIT — General Motors is aiming to set the framework of a new labor agreement with the United Automobile Workers union that would increase entry-level wages and establish a new profit-sharing formula for workers at all three Detroit car companies.

headline: Mercedes-Benz B-Class Is Coming to America
text: FRANKFURT — Mercedes has long hesitated to export its A-Class and B-Class models to America, fearing that the compact cars’ prosaic, minivan looks did not fit with the super-premium image that the company cultivated in the United States.

headline: A Reporter Shields His Identity and an Iranian Exile Group’s Viewpoint Goes Missing
text: Reporting on the People’s Mujahedeen of Iran and their complicated plight at Camp Ashraf in Iraq has proved challenging for The New York Times. So when reporter Tim Arango had the opportunity to visit the camp with Ambassador Lawrence E. Butler, an American diplomat negotiating with the group, he took it.

headline: Thelonious Monk International Jazz Piano Competition
text: Polish, understatement and breadth were what the judges were looking for in this jazz competition.

headline: Okra, Avocado and Tomato Salad With Chili and Lime Juice
text: This lively combination is inspired by one of my favorite Mexican salads, which is made with diced cooked cactus paddles (nopales), onion, tomato and avocado. Cactus paddles are gooey, like okra, so I figured okra could stand in for nopales in this salad. The result is prettier and, I think, tastier -- and certainly easier to work with than cactus.

headline: The Toll From Tree-Boring Pests
text: As Anthony DePalma explained here this morning, the Forest Service went to great lengths to get inside the mind of the emerald ash borer, a vivid-green, bug-eyed invasive insect that is wreaking havoc on trees in 15 states.

headline: A Flight to Newark, Later Than the Usual Late
text: It was a flight predisposed, if not predestined, to being late.

headline: G.E. Will Pay Back $3 Billion to Buffett
text: Mario Anzuoni/ReutersWarren E. Buffett will get back $3 billion that he invested in General Electric during the financial crisis, plus a $300 million bonus.

headline: Tory Burch on Fantasy Island
text: There’s always been a sense, when walking into a Tory Burch store or into her Fashion Week presentations, that you are arriving at the “Fantasy Island” of fashion. You half sense that Mr. Roarke will tap you on the shoulder at any moment and turn you into an Upper East Side blonde with a car and driver, at least for the day.

headline: Vieira Named Special Correspondent for NBC News
text: Three months after she tearfully signed off the “Today” show, Meredith Vieira confirmed on Tuesday that she was sticking with NBC News as a special correspondent.

headline: Web Show Booted From CBS After Bogus Tweet About Steve Jobs
text: Live by the tweet, die by the tweet. That was the lesson for the weekly online news and chat show “What’s Trending,” which up until Friday appeared on the Web site of the old-media behemoth CBS News. The events that led to the end of the relationship between the show, independently produced by Disrupt Group, and CBS were recounted by its host and executive producer, Shira Lazar, in a long and fairly excruciating on-camera mea culpa at the beginning of Tuesday afternoon’s episode:

headline: The Making of “Grit” Tape Installation
text: The artist Stephen Doyle taped, across multiple surfaces, the words for the traits being taught at KIPP Infinity middle school in Manhattan. Watch the word “grit” being made.

headline: Tipping the Balance for Kitchen Scales
text: CONSIDER the Parmesan problem: Imagine that you’re making lasagna with a recipe that calls for topping it with “a cup of grated cheese.”

headline: N. Carolina Puts Same-Sex Marriage Ban on Ballot
text: North Carolina may soon lose its status as the last state in the Southeast without a Constitutional amendment making marriage legal only when there is a bride and a groom.

headline: Trummer Pleads to a Violation in Bar Fire and Avoids Jail
text: Albert Trummer, the celebrity mixologist who was charged last year with illegally setting alcohol aflame on the bartop of his haute cocktail haunt Apothéke in Manhattan, pleaded guilty to disorderly conduct, a violation, on Tuesday in Manhattan Criminal Court.

headline: Debates Continue to Attract Viewers
text: The Republican presidential primary debate on Monday night attracted 3.6 million viewers to CNN, far fewer than the summer’s earlier debates on Fox News and MSNBC. But the audience was still big enough for CNN to claim a rare ratings victory over its rivals.

headline: I’ll Drink What the Monkey’s Drinking
text: Back in the 1920s, when a well-heeled gentleman’s vim and vigor were flagging, he would visit a Paris surgeon for an implant of monkey testicle tissue.

headline: Tradition, Stripped Down and Set to a New Tune
text: Pity the poor Irish dancer. Before “Riverdance” took the world by surprise in 1994, there were practically no performance opportunities outside of a closed circle of competitions. Since that blockbuster made its debut there has seemed to be only “Riverdance” and its progeny of lucrative spectacles, mostly assaultive and inane. Presenting Irish dance any differently has proved a daunting challenge.

headline: Designers Shop the Cultural Bazaar
text: Some designers this week released their inner gypsies, unveiling collections that brimmed with violently colorful, multicultural references.

headline: Day 6: Off the Runway
text: Scenes from New York Fashion Week on Sept. 13.

headline: Humans and Their Planet – One Big ‘Design Space’
text: Brad Allenby is at it again, and thank goodness for him and for his ability to prod people out of their cognitive comfort zones in a time of astonishing change.

headline: Designers Shop the Cultural Bazaar
text: Some designers this week released their inner gypsies, unveiling collections that brimmed with violently colorful, multicultural references. Some shows carried a whiff of Haiti or Hawaii, while others mined the landscapes and cultures of India and North Africa. Embracing a vagabond spirit,Thakoon Panichgul married the exoticism of Bollywood with broad hints of the American West; Donna Karan combined Haitian-inspired geometry with a dusky African palette, Duro Olowu offered an homage to his Jamaican-born mum, and Joseph Altuzarra showed a smattering of hothouse florals redolent of the South Pacific. It’s a global marketplace, they say, in more ways than one.

headline: Hugh Jackman Will Sing and Dance Again on Broadway
text: Hugh Jackman is 2-for-2 at turning a profit on Broadway, with his 2003 musical “The Boy from Oz” and his 2009 play with Daniel Craig, “A Steady Rain” — a golden track record in a business where only 25 to 30 percent of shows even recoup their investment each year. Now Mr. Jackman has a chance at a hat trick: He will return to Broadway this fall with an 18-piece orchestra for his one-man show, “Hugh Jackman, Back on Broadway,” featuring a selection of his favorite musical numbers, the producers announced on Tuesday.

headline: Order Moves in on Chaos, as Rappers Go Legit
text: Early Das Racist shows were chaos. Not organized chaos (a term of forgiveness), but actual chaos: a thrilling unreliability perpetrated by a duo — notionally a hip-hop outfit but more interested in being provocateurs — who seemed to know exactly what the audience would tolerate. It had to be believed to be seen.

headline: Over Objections, New Brooklyn Historic District Is Created
text: Brooklyn’s latest historic district – a cluster of 21 skyscrapers and office buildings surrounding Borough Hall downtown – was created on Tuesday over the objections of some of its landowners and inhabitants.

headline: Excerpt: 'Up All Night'
text: Christina Applegate and Will Arnett play new parents in this new NBC sitcom.

headline: So, Like, You Hate Me, You Really Hate Me
text: All you philosophers and physicists can stop speculating because it’s now official: there is more than one reality.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Glorious Corn

headline: I’ll Have the Absurd, Please
text: THE smoked salmon pâté arrived in an ashtray. “Breadblunt?” a waiter murmured, proffering breadsticks from a battered Dutch Masters cigar box.

headline: Pork Jowl With a Backwoods Whiff
text: In Italy, the bacon called guanciale is made of pork cheeks. Down South, that’s hog jowls, honey. S. Wallace Edwards & Sons of Surry, Va., has introduced Surry Farms-brand Jowciale, made of Berkshire pork. It is suitably fatty, just streaked with meat and easy to slice or dice so it renders nicely. Unlike guanciale, it is smoked and gives a backwoods whiff to bucatini all’amatriciana or other sauce, stew or braise.

headline: For Once, the Guys Go First
text: Wherever there has been a men’s wear show this week, there has been a women’s collection not far behind it. We’re not talking just about man-skirts and rose prints, but actual men’s designers trying their hand, with mixed results, at women’s wear.

headline: New Spud on the Block
text: The new Peter Wilcox is a potato for New York Fashion Week, cloaked in deep purple and lined in gold. It’s as appealing to the palate as it is on the plate, beautifully textured, firm but not waxy, whether roasted, boiled or sliced into wedges and fried, with a full, earthy flavor that hints of hazelnuts. It was developed by researchers in Maryland and Maine and named for a professor at Loyola University in Baltimore. Cooking fades the inside color a bit. For best effect, use these potatoes with the skin on.

headline: The Volume Stays Up
text: There seems to be no escape from the orgy of prints and color consuming the runways.

headline: Governor Sandoval of Nevada Endorses Perry
text: Rick Perry, the governor of Texas, on Tuesday picked up the support of Brian Sandoval, the governor of Nevada and a fellow Republican.

headline: Marchesa: Under the Sea
text: Making the switch from a presentation, with models standing on platforms, to a formal runway show this season allowed Georgina Chapman and Keren Craig of Marchesa to do a lot of things differently. They could hire supermodels like Karen Elson and Karolina Kurkova. They could seat their guests, including Tinsley Mortimer and Courtney Love. They could show in a beautiful space, the Palm Court of the Plaza Hotel.

headline: Wall Street Journal Adds to Live Video Programming
text: Operating a bit like a stealth business news network, The Wall Street Journal on Tuesday announced a major expansion of its video unit, which is now producing three and a half hours of live programming each weekday and will soon produce even more.

headline: CNN-Tea Party Republican Debate in Tampa, Fla.
text: The following is a transcript of the CNN-Tea Party Republican presidential debate in Tampa, Fla., as provided by Federal News Service:

headline: 2011 Frankfurt Motor Show
text: Dozens of new models were introduced as automakers vowed to shed some weight from their vehicles.

headline: Creating a Cinematic Picture of a Flemish Masterpiece
text: Even before the opening credits run, “The Mill & the Cross” casts a transfixing spell, as Pieter Bruegel the Elder, the great 16th-century Flemish artist, chats with his patron Nicholas Jonghelinck while he sketches studies for a large work he is preparing. Then the camera pulls back, blending scores of actors and animals with computer-generated effects, painted backdrops and location shots to restage Bruegel’s 1564 masterpiece, “The Way to Calvary.”

headline: Stocking Up on Warehouse Properties
text: Developers and investors are starting to make big bets on industrial real estate, following signs that consumers may be starting to spend again. Sales of such properties have jumped nearly threefold from last year, according to figures from commercial real estate companies, and the vacancy rate has fallen for three consecutive quarters.

headline: Theater Producers’ Fraud Convictions Are Upheld
text: OTTAWA — An appeals court on Tuesday upheld the fraud convictions of the Canadian impresario Garth H. Drabinsky and his former business partner, Myron I. Gottlieb.

headline: Mets’ Announcer Weighs In on Cap Controversy
text: In the bottom of the third inning Monday night during the Mets-Nationals game, the SNY announcer Gary Cohen took on Major League Baseball for refusing to let the Mets commemorate the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks by wearing New York Fire Department caps when they played the Cubs on Sunday night.

headline: Hearing on Solyndra Won’t Include Executives
text: Two weeks after the bankruptcy of a solar company that got $527 million in government loans, the House Energy and Commerce Committee will hold a hearing on Wednesday to explore what went wrong.

headline: Schrager Makes Over a Legendary Chicago Hotel
text: CHICAGO — Ian Schrager, whose indefatigable pursuit of buzz over the last 30 years has produced memorable hotels like the Royalton and the Gramercy Park in New York, the Mondrian in Los Angeles and the Delano in Miami Beach, is about to open his first new project as an independent hotelier since the 2008 financial crash.

headline: A Return to Guatemala’s Civil War, in Black and White
text: The cold war may be over, but Washington’s history of intervention in Latin America remains a hotly contested legacy. Its involvement is also, in its sprawling historical detail and far-reaching ideological implications, a necessarily complex inheritance, a fact nowhere suggested by Pamela Yates’s new documentary, “Granito: How to Nail a Dictator,” a follow-up to her first feature-length film, “When the Mountains Tremble” (1984).

headline: Regulators Aim to End ‘Too Big To Fail’
text: Nearly three years to the day that Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy and Wall Street teetered on the brink, federal regulators are seeking to wipe out the infamous phenomenon that Wall Street is too big to fail.

headline: ConAgra Gives Ralcorp a Deadline to Accept Its Offer
text: After months of unsuccessfully trying to persuade Ralcorp to accept several takeover proposals, ConAgra on Tuesday set a Monday deadline  for the food company to accept its $5.2 billion merger bid.

headline: Looking Up in the Standings, With Hope
text: When I was growing up, there was a children’s book called “Nothing Ever Happens On My Block.” A gloomy kid sits on a curbside, so convinced that there’s nothing worth seeing behind him that he never even turns around. Meanwhile, all sorts of stuff is going on in the background, and he misses it all.

headline: The Battle of the Barrier
text: The West Bank security barrier is a source of contention in establishing a border between Israel and a future Palestinian state.

headline: Kucinich Is Likely to Stay Put
text: Representative Dennis Kucinich, the very liberal Ohio Democrat, evidently won’t be heading West in an unusual effort to remain a member of Congress.

headline: For Some, Confusing Finish to U.S. Open
text: Television viewers in the Albany, Buffalo and New Orleans markets were entitled to feel a bit confused by Monday’s coverage of the United States Open men’s final: it was not initially carried on local CBS stations.

headline: Rock Is Not the Enemy
text: On Friday, I wrote about an organization called Little Kids Rock, which has helped to revitalize and broaden music education in more than a thousand schools by encouraging children to learn to play popular music, form bands and compose their own songs. The column sparked a little bit of a culture war: some readers were aggrieved by the idea that children should learn popular music in schools, others suggested that classical composers would love rock ‘n roll. Some feared that teaching pop would “dumb down” music education, others felt it was vital to make music education more relevant to children. I’d like to clarify some misconceptions and explain why I think the program is a valuable addition, rather than a threat to the classical tradition.

headline: At TechCrunch Conference, Talk of a Bubble
text: This year’s TechCrunch Disrupt conference in San Francisco sometimes felt more like an episode of “E! True Hollywood Story” than a high-priced technology gathering.

headline: For a Few Weeks, Horse Shows Alter a River Town
text: Every year, the elite competitive equestrian circuit makes its way around the country, from Ocala, Fla., to Culpeper, Va., to Thermal, Calif. These traveling troupes of privilege and skill also take with them small armies — of trainers, grooms, farriers, veterinarians, even equine acupuncturists and masseuses.

headline: How Google-Motorola Deal Came Together
text: It took less than seven weeks, but it became more expensive quickly.

headline: The Merrill Lynch and Lehman Deals, 3 Years Later
text: This is a tale of two deals.

headline: Banks Brace for a Season of Fall-Offs
text: The worries of Wall Street banks keep growing.

headline: Scientists Hint at Why Laughter Feels So Good
text: Laughter is regularly promoted as a source of health and well being, but it has been hard to pin down exactly why laughing until it hurts feels so good.

headline: In Republican Race, a Heated Battle Over the HPV Vaccine
text: An unlikely issue — whether to vaccinate preadolescent girls against a sexually transmitted virus — has become the latest flashpoint among Republican presidential candidates as they vie for the support of social conservatives and Tea Party members.

headline: C.I.A. Examining Legality of Work With Police Dept.
text: WASHINGTON — The Central Intelligence Agency has opened an internal inquiry into whether its close cooperation with the New York Police Department in the decade since the Sept. 11 attacks has broken any laws prohibiting the agency from collecting intelligence in the United States.

headline: For ‘King Pimp,’ a Name-Dropping Defense Only a Panic Attack Can Slow Down
text: By now, a fair number of people are familiar with the modus operandi of Jason Itzler, proud promoter of female companionship and champion of hyperbole.

headline: Baying at the Bard, Appropriately and Otherwise
text: Hundreds of people had come to Griffith Park for a night of Shakespeare, carrying blankets and picnic baskets filled with wine, artisanal cheeses and heirloom tomato salads (dressing packed separately in Tupperware, of course).

headline: Amid the Deluge and the Drama, Dazzling Play
text: A little more than two weeks ago, the United States Open started under the threat of Hurricane Irene, a harbinger, perhaps, of the tumult that lay ahead.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Mideast Prospects
text: To the Editor:

headline: Orient Express Trailer
text: A new campaign for Orient-Express luxury hotels includes commercials like this one.

headline: Luxury Hotels Market the Memories They Can Make
text: SINCE the financial crisis began, millions of wealthy consumers have decided to play down the joy of accumulating things in favor of the pleasure of accumulating experiences. As a result, purveyors of premium-priced products and services are embracing the notion that they provide customers with moments to remember rather than with more stuff that needs dusting (by the help, most likely).

headline: In Woodstock, Values Collide Over Housing
text: WOODSTOCK, N.Y. — If they had decided to pave paradise and put up a parking lot, the issues might have seemed simpler.

headline: The Glass-Half-Full Department
text: Maybe it’s back-to-school fever, but everyone I know seems besieged by pessimism. I’m distressed by water shortages, the state of the labor movement and the Somalian famine, which may needlessly kill 700,000 people this year. Friends are overwhelmed by their memories of 9/11 and of the horribly blown opportunities to use an excruciatingly painful event to move us towards a better place.

headline: The Season of Djokovic Challenges All Others
text: If prize money is the measuring stick, Novak Djokovic’s magnificent season is already the best in men’s tennis history — $10.6 million earned and more than two months of paydays still to come.

headline: Seeking a Fiscal Plan That Will Work
text: To the Editor:

headline: I.R.S. Extends Estate Taxes Deadline
text: The Internal Revenue Service said on Tuesday that tax returns for estates that are worth more than $5 million for people who died in 2010 will be due on Jan. 17, instead of Nov. 15.

headline: Tax Plan for Jobs Bill Has Familiar Ring
text: To pay for his $447 billion jobs bill, President Obama is once again proposing an assortment of tax increases on wealthy individuals and corporations.

headline: Our Wealth in Lands
text: To the Editor:

headline: North Korea's First Cruise
text: Edward Wong travels on a trial run of the first-ever tourist cruise to the secretive authoritarian nation of North Korea.

headline: Jobs in a Green Economy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Import Prices Fall for Second Time in 3 Months
text: Prices of goods imported into the United States fell in August for the second time in three months as the cost of oil and food dropped, while autos stabilized, the Labor Department said Tuesday.

headline: Fees for Inmate Visits
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Name to Beat in the FedEx Cup Is a Long One
text: LEMONT, Ill. — Surely it isn’t his face that gets Webb Simpson noticed in airport security lines — a preposterously smooth, sunburned visage set off by a pair of steely blue eyes that fairly screams tennis player, surfer, golfer or skier.

headline: North Korean Cruise Seeks Tourists, 8 to a Room
text: ABOARD THE MANGYONGBONG, off North Korea — It was billed as a cruise ship, but the creaking, nearly-40-year-old vessel that set sail from the remote North Korean town of Rajin had more of the trappings of a tramp steamer. With its cramped cabins, cut-rate cuisine and foul, water-deprived bathrooms, it was not about to compete anytime soon with Cunard or Carnival in the leisure industry.

headline: Demand at Target for Fashion Line Crashes Web Site
text: Target’s Web site came crashing down on Tuesday as Missoni-loving fashion devotées invaded, scrambling to buy the high-end Italian designer’s clothes for a song.

headline: Toyota Restores North American Pace
text: Toyota on Tuesday said that it had resumed full production at its North American plants for the first time since it began experiencing parts shortages after the earthquake and tsunami that struck Japan in March.

headline: Lottery Numbers
North Carolina Voters to Decide on Same-Sex Marriage
text: ATLANTA — North Carolina on Tuesday took a big step toward losing its status as the last state in the Southeast without a constitutional amendment making it clear that marriage is legal only when there is a bride and bridegroom.

headline: EBay Discloses Inquiry Over Craigslist
text: EBay, the online auction site, said on Tuesday that it was cooperating with a Justice Department investigation into Craigslist’s disputes with the company.

headline: Some People Like Citi Field’s Size. They’re Called Pitchers.
text: Amid growing speculation that the Mets will shrink the daunting dimensions of Citi Field this off-season, the issue has become an open topic of discussion among players in the clubhouse. After a recent game, David Wright lamented that he had hit “800 feet worth of doubles” and added, perhaps only half-jokingly, that he hoped such an effort would yield a couple of home runs next season.

headline: The Terrifying Tigers
text: Lt. Col. Charles de Choiseul was not a happy man. It was September 1861, and de Choiseul, a well-educated French Creole, had been ordered to take temporary command of Maj. Chatham Roberdeau Wheat’s First Special Battalion of Louisiana Infantry while Wheat recovered from a serious wound suffered at the First Battle of Bull Run. It was no routine assignment: a Virginia officer had been given the position previously, but he was unable to control the rowdy men and quit after only a few days. Now it was de Choiseul’s turn to try to rein in what was known as the Tiger Battalion. He wrote a friend, “I am a victim of circumstances, not of my own will. … Whether the Tigers will devour me, or whether I will succeed in taming them, remains to be seen.”

headline: Photo Replay: Saugerties Horse Shows
text: More than 2,200 equestrians and their entourages descend on Saugerties, N.Y., every summer, and the influx of cash has played a part in transforming the village.

headline: A Well-Regulated Wilderness
text: Vienna, Va.

headline: Airport Security Officers Charged in Drug Case
text: STAMFORD, Conn. — Three Transportation Security Administration officers have been charged with accepting bribes to let couriers smuggle painkillers and cash undetected through security checkpoints at airports in New York and Florida, federal prosecutors said Tuesday.

headline: Tuck Hopes to Play Against the Rams
text: Defensive end Justin Tuck said the neck injury that kept him out of the Giants’ Week 1 defeat at Washington had improved, and he hopes to play in the Giants’ game against the St. Louis Rams.

headline: A Good Jobs Program
text: President Obama has often trimmed his ideas to what he thinks he might possibly get from an opposition that intends to give him nothing. So it is a relief to see him demanding that Congress do what the country really needs.

headline: The Cost of Inaction
text: The latest figures from the Census Bureau show the devastating cost of the recession and why putting Americans back to work must be Washington’s top priority.

headline: Retired Players Sue Players Union
text: A group of retired N.F.L. players, led by the Hall of Famer Carl Eller, filed a class-action lawsuit in federal court against the N.F.L. Players Association seeking damages and asking that the terms of the new collective bargaining agreement that relate to retiree benefits be renegotiated between the retired players involved in the lawsuit and the N.F.L.

headline: U.S. Scrambles to Avert Palestinian Vote at U.N.
text: WASHINGTON — The United States is facing increasing pressure as the Palestinian quest for statehood gained support from Turkey and other countries, even as the Obama administration sought an 11th-hour compromise that would avoid a confrontation at the United Nations next week.

headline: U.S. Inquiry Traces Foreigners With Visas
text: A vast investigation by the Department of Homeland Security of 1.6 million cases of foreigners suspected of remaining in the United States after their visas expired has shown that more than half of them have already left the country or obtained legal immigration status, officials told Congress on Tuesday.

headline: No Justice for Anna Politkovskaya
text: Five years after the Russian journalist Anna Politkovskaya was brutally shot in her Moscow apartment building, there have been no convictions for her murder.

text: Actions by states to require vaccination against HPV.

text: Comparing Internet speeds across the nation.

headline: Champions League: Sky Blue Over Manchester
text: The UEFA Champions League on Wednesday brings the second series of matches in the form of six group-stage games, with Manchester City hosting Napoli and Bayern Munich traveling to Villarreal in Spain in Group A, which has been nominated as the tournament’s group of death. The schedule (all games start at 2:45 p.m. Eastern):

headline: Young Science Geeks Try to Make Love Add Up to Something
text: If Mary can shuck three ears of corn in a minute, and John can shuck four ears of corn in a minute, and there are 150 ears of corn in a bushel, how many bushels of corn can Mary and John shuck in an hour? Aarrgh! Remember word problems on math quizzes? The rebellious young mind, faced with such vexing questions, would be hard pressed to resist the desire to tear up the test paper and shout out, “Who cares how many bushels of corn Mary and John can shuck?”

headline: Evicted for Manhattan Starbucks No. 188, but Defying the Coffee Octopus
text: One day about three weeks ago, the morning rush in the Bean coffee shop in the East Village was reaching its crest when one of the baristas dashed downstairs to get the boss.

headline: 4 Council Members, Each With $1 Million, Will Let Public Decide How It’s Spent
text: Four City Council members, intrigued by experiments begun in Brazil to let ordinary citizens determine how government uses tax dollars, say they plan to allow their constituents to decide how $4 million is spent next year.

headline: The Spirit of the Game
text: Gracious losers, and winners, are, sadly, rare in professional sports. Rafael Nadal’s performance Monday night, after losing this year’s United States Open, was the very essence of graciousness and a reminder of what good sportsmanship really means.

headline: Photo Replay: Sept 13
text: A look back at the day in sports, from soccer in Jordan to Usain Bolt in Croatia.

headline: Is It Weird Enough Yet?
text: Every time I listen to Gov. Rick Perry of Texas and Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota talk about how climate change is some fraud perpetrated by scientists trying to gin up money for research, I’m always reminded of one of my favorite movie lines that Jack Nicholson delivers to his needy neighbor who knocks on his door in the film “As Good As It Gets.” “Where do they teach you to talk like this?” asks Nicholson. “Sell crazy someplace else. We’re all stocked up here.”

headline: Looking to Raise Revenue
text: The Obama administration has proposed to pay for its jobs bill by eliminating tax breaks in four areas.

headline: Bystanders Lift Flaming Car to Save a Man
text: On a stretch of road by the crest of a hill in Logan, Utah, on Monday, a motorcycle and a BMW collided, throwing the cyclist under the car and causing the bike to burst into flames, which quickly spread to the sedan. Rather than fleeing those two flaming vehicles, a dozen bystanders rushed toward the blaze, lifted the car and pulled the injured man out by his ankle.

headline: In City of Cyclists, Pedestrians Feel the Squeeze
text: COPENHAGEN — Mikael le Dous has it in for bikers.

headline: Vacation Cut Short by Chance to Help Yanks in the Stretch
text: SEATTLE — Austin Romine was walking out of a Wal-Mart in Kentucky last Saturday night, carrying supplies for his girlfriend’s new apartment there, when his phone rang.

headline: Memoirs of a Geisha
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Richard Hamilton, British Painter and a Creator of Pop Art, Dies at 89
text: Richard Hamilton, a British painter and printmaker whose sly, trenchant take on consumer culture and advertising made him a pioneering figure in Pop Art, and who designed the cover of the Beatles’ “White Album,” died on Tuesday at his home near Oxford. He was 89.

headline: Board Urges Cellphone Ban for All Commercial Drivers
text: WASHINGTON —After a Kentucky truck crash that killed 11 people, top federal safety investigators vastly broadened their recommendations on cellphones on Tuesday and said all commercial drivers should be forbidden to use them, whether hand-held or not, except in emergencies.

headline: Auditors Find Chaos in U.S. Marshal’s Asset Sales Record-Keeping
text: The unit of the United States Marshals Service that manages complex assets seized in criminal cases, including that of Bernard L. Madoff, kept such shoddy records that it could not say who bought assets or how much was paid for them in 8 of the 55 sales it handled from 2005 to 2010, according to an audit released on Tuesday.

headline: Baghdad Assailed Over Attack in Anbar
text: BAGHDAD — Just a few hours after the bodies of 22 executed Shiite pilgrims were found in western Anbar Province, Sunni leaders there erupted in anger on Tuesday at Iraq’s Shiite-led government, exposing yet another fault line in the country’s sectarian tensions.

headline: For Idaho and the Internet, Life in the Slow Lane
text: POTLATCH, Idaho — Barry Ramsay, who owns a small manufacturing company here between two mountains, remembers the day his Internet connection crashed for several hours. Work crews had to ride up in snowmobiles to discover the problem.

headline: A Night for Everyone but the Mets
text: It was Star Wars Night at Citi Field on Tuesday.

headline: A ‘Go To’ Accountant Is Accused of Fraud
text: LOS ANGELES — For almost 15 years, Kinde Durkee has been one of the go-to accountants for Democratic candidates in California. She and her firm kept track of expenditures and contributions and made sure that candidates and party committees’ campaigns complied with California’s tangled election finance laws.

headline: With Bipartisan Support, Law on Expansion of Charter Schools Passes the House
text: In a rare display of bipartisanship, the House approved a bill on Tuesday supporting the expansion of charter schools, the first part of a legislative package planned by Republicans to carry out a piecemeal rewrite of the main federal law on public education, No Child Left Behind.

headline: In Milestone Victory for Wakefield, Red Sox Ease a Collective Panic
text: BOSTON — The panic and fear that had gripped all New England, that the Red Sox would throw away what looked like an insurmountable lead in the wild-card race, has tempered. At least for one night.

headline: Bigger Economic Role for Washington
text: WASHINGTON — Just weeks ago, economists and financial analysts were dismissing Washington as largely irrelevant to the economy’s course in coming months, if only because it chose to be. They are not dismissing it anymore.

headline: ‘Serious’ Error Found in Carbon Savings for Biofuels
text: The European Union is overestimating the reductions in greenhouse gas emissions achieved through reliance on biofuels as a result of a “serious accounting error,” according to a draft opinion by an influential committee of 19 scientists and academics.

headline: Wal-Mart to Announce Women-Friendly Plans
text: Wal-Mart planned to announce on Wednesday new programs aimed at helping women-owned businesses and women workers, as the company continues to deal with the possibility of individual claims of sex discrimination after the Supreme Court threw out a class-action suit by women workers this summer.

headline: U.N. Accuses Yemen of Using Deadly Force in Protests
text: GENEVA — A United Nations report published Tuesday says the Yemeni government has used excessive and deadly force against peaceful demonstrators, killing hundreds and wounding thousands since the beginning of the year.

headline: Abuse of Xanax Leads a Clinic to Halt Supply
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Gayle Mink, a nurse practitioner at a community mental health center here, had tired of the constant stream of patients seeking Xanax, an anti-anxiety drug coveted for its swift calming effect.

headline: Israeli Company Taken Off Iran Trade Blacklist
text: JERUSALEM — The State Department on Tuesday removed Ofer Holdings Group Ltd., a leading Israeli company, from a sanctions blacklist for trade with Iran, reversing a step taken four months ago that dealt a blow to the reputation and businesses of the Ofer family, one of the richest in Israel.

headline: Spending Inequity in Colleges Has Risen
text: As income inequality has increased in the United States over the last decade, so too has the gap between rich and poor colleges and universities.

headline: Word of the Day | deflect
text: deflect •\di-ˈflekt, de-\• verb

headline: Lapses by American Leaders Seen in Syphilis Tests
text: The highest medical and legal officials of the American government and experts at Harvard and other top medical schools approved venereal disease experiments on people in the 1940s, which led to the deliberate infection of Guatemalan prisoners and mental patients with syphilis to test penicillin, a White House bioethics panel reported Tuesday.

headline: Kashmir: Top Militant Is Killed
text: The authorities in Indian-administered Kashmir said they killed a top officer of Lashkar-e-Taiba, a Pakistan-based militant group that was responsible for the 2008 attacks in Mumbai, in a gun battle on Tuesday. The officer, Azhar Malik, was shot after the police surrounded a house where he had been hiding in the town of Sopore, the district police chief, Imtiaj Hussain, said in a telephone interview. Mr. Malik was involved in at least 20 cases of terrorist activities, the police chief said, the latest being the bombing in April that killed a moderate separatist religious leader in the Kashmir Valley.

headline: Arab League Asked to Act on Syria
text: Scores of Arab and international human rights organizations have submitted a petition to the Arab League demanding that it suspend Syria as a member until that nation halts its crackdown on demonstrators who are demanding democratic change. The petition, signed by more than 175 organizations, also said Arab League members should support United Nations actions including a travel ban and the freezing of assets and should go even beyond those measures with an arms embargo. The lack of a unified Arab position against the Syrian government, unlike the reaction to the uprising in Libya, has helped block international action against Damascus.

headline: Carl Oglesby, Antiwar Leader in 1960s, Dies at 76
text: Carl Oglesby, who led Students for a Democratic Society as it publicly opposed the Vietnam War but who was later expelled by a radical faction that became the Weather Underground, died on Tuesday at his home in Montclair, N.J. He was 76.

headline: Obama Campaign Launches AttackWatch.com
text: President Obama’s re-election campaign launched a Web site on Tuesday called AttackWatch.com that encourages supporters to help dismiss false accusations made about the president’s record and to report what they believe is misinformation about his policies.

headline: John Calley, Hollywood Chief, Dies at 81
text: LOS ANGELES — John Calley, who was known for his unusually artistic approach in running three major Hollywood studios and overseeing some of the most successful movies of the last 50 years, died Tuesday at his home here. He was 81.

headline: Democratic Party Pick Wins Brooklyn Race
text: The Democratic machine whirred and then roared in northern Brooklyn on Tuesday, churning out a significant victory for Rafael L. Espinal in a fiercely contested three-way race for the 54th State Assembly District seat.

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Today
text: A train collision in the southern Indian state of Tamil Nadu last night killed at least 10 people (The Hindu) and injured more than 70 when a passenger trained rammed into a stationary one near Arrakonam, which is about 50 miles from the state capital, Chennai. This is the third major train accident (The Times of India) in the country in the past two months.Is Gujarat Chief Minister Narendra Modi on the “fast track to center stage” (Hindustan Times), after announcing a three-day fast starting September 17? While fasting is most recently associated with the Anna Hazare anti-corruption movement, Modi said in an open letter that his fast will “strengthen the state’s environment of “peace, unity and harmony” (Gujarat government Web site) after Monday’s Supreme Court decision ended an “unhealthy environment” created by the “unfounded and false allegations” against him and his government.

headline: Battle for Libya | September 13, 2011
text: Residents continued to flee Bani Walid.

headline: Rivera Notches Save No. 600 in Seattle as Yankees Win
text: SEATTLE — In the end, Mariano Rivera did what millions of baseball fans have been doing for 15 years. He watched as the final out was recorded in one of his saves.

headline: Indian Police Say Terror Chief Killed In Kashmir
text: Police in Indian-administered Kashmir said they killed a top officer of a Pakistan-based terrorist group in a gun battle yesterday.

headline: For Democrats, It’s 2010 All Over Again
text: The outcome of any individual election to the United States House, even in a highly partisan era where Congressional elections have a relatively strong correlation with presidential voting and national trends, is going to be determined based on a combination of local and national factors. One congressional district’s outcome may diverge significantly from another’s – even if they seem similar on the surface — based on the quality of the candidates, the demographics of the region and issues highly pertinent to the district but not to the nation at large. Any one race may or may not be representative.

headline: TimesCast | Iran to Free Prisoners
text: September 13, 2011 - Iran agrees to release two American hikers it suspected of being spies.

headline: Ms. India: The Women’s Printing Press
text: Ms. India, a regular feature by Nilanjana S. Roy, offers snapshots of the changing lives of women in the country, from the perspective of the “Bharatiya Naari”, or ideal Indian woman, whether she lives in urban, small-town or village India.Everyone in Karaikal knows the Women’s Press, whose colorful pink sign advertises the press and its stationery shop just outside the Old Bus Stand, on a dusty street perfumed by the scent of jasmine sold everywhere. The Karaikal Women Society Co-operative Printing Society Ltd., to give the press its full name, was started in 1979 in this thriving port town in the Union Territory of Puducherry, making it the oldest — and perhaps the only — printing press in India run by women.

headline: Sept. 14, 1959 | Soviet Space Probe Is First Human-Made Object to Reach Moon
text: On Sept. 14, 1959, the Luna 2 space probe crashed onto the surface of the moon. Though Luna 2 was shattered on impact, the mission was a major success, as it represented an important first in the history of space exploration.

headline: News Quiz | Sept. 14, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Raiders Put Trust in Janikowski
text: When Sebastian Janikowski tied the N.F.L. record by making a 63-yard field goal to end the first half against the Broncos on Monday night, few on the Oakland side of the field were surprised. Janikowski routinely kicks 65-yarders in practice, and made one from 70 in pregame warm-ups Monday.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Sept. 14, 2011
text: Test your math skills with today’s question, created by Bobson Wong at Math for America from the article “Atop TV Sets, a Power Drain That Runs Nonstop.”

headline: In Rebuke to Iran’s President, Courts Void Release of Hikers
text: CAIRO — To pave the way for his annual visit to the United Nations, Iran’s president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, announced with great fanfare this week the imminent release of two American hikers sentenced to eight years for espionage.

headline: An Antigay Bullying Battle
text: WHO has brought a lawsuit against a suburban school district contending that school officials have failed to stop relentless antigay bullying?WHO has demanded that the schools there avoid any descriptions of homosexuality or same-sex marriage as normal?WHO is the Congressional representative for most of this school district?

headline: Does Your Homework Help You Learn?
text: New research suggests that a lot of assigned homework amounts to pointless busy work that doesn’t help students learn, while more thoughtful assignments can help them develop skills and acquire knowledge. How would you characterize the homework you get?

headline: Terrorists Kill More Than 20 Across Iraq
text: BAGHDAD — Terrorist attacks across Iraq killed more than 20 people on Wednesday, including in Anbar Province, where an increase in violence has heightened sectarian tensions.

headline: How Payroll Tax Cuts Can Create Jobs
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: At London Show, Comic Book Heroes Combined to Create Real-Life Ones
text: To commemorate the 10-year anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, one London gallery is honoring the real-life heroes — the firemen and policemen who protect us every day — by imbuing them with the invincible spirit of fictional superheroes.

headline: At Frankfurt Motor Show, the Future Toys of the Very Rich
text: FRANKFURT — At every auto show, a certain number of impossibly exotic vehicles are introduced. The brands that manufacture these pieces of the unattainable don’t usually make a point of discussing how only ultra-high-net-worth individuals can afford their creations, and nobody seems particularly surprised or perturbed if these playthings of the very rich wind up in the garages of oil barons, drug lords, Far Eastern nouveau capitalists or various Third World despots.

headline: Tebow Becomes the Broncos’ Burden
text: Tim Tebow’s critics can’t blame him for this.

headline: Part 3: Answers to Your Back-to-School Admissions Questions
text: The Choice has lined up the authors of a new book — which bills itself as “the ultimate user’s manual” for college applicants, and loosely follows, as its model, the “What to Expect When You’re Expecting” series — to field questions about what high school seniors and juniors (and their parents) should be doing now on the college admissions front.

headline: Austere Italy? Check the Traffic
text: COMITINI, Italy — With only 960 residents and a handful of roads, this tiny hilltop village in the arid, sulfurous hills of southern Sicily does not appear to have major traffic problems. But that does not prevent it from having one full-time traffic officer — and eight auxiliaries.

headline: The Early Word: Piecemeal?
text: Today’s Times

headline: They Didn’t Win, but They Deserve Some Applause
text: More than the physical and mental battles that playing an elite-level match necessitate, the true brutality of a tennis tournament is the near-inevitability of leaving as a loser. One hundred and twenty eight men entered the singles competition at the 2011 United States Open, and all but one–Novak Djokovic–leave New York as a loser.

headline: Codecademy Offers Free Coding Classes for Aspiring Entrepreneurs
text: When Zach Sims, a political science student at Columbia, and Ryan Bubinski, a developer and former classmate, were batting around ideas for their start-up pitch to present at Y-Combinator, a well-known start-up incubator based in Silicon Valley, they had more than a few stumbles while settling on an idea.

headline: When Rockefeller Criticized Lindsay, He Was Wrong
text: Defending his decision not to go to the Attica Correctional Facility in September 1971 where inmates were holding guards hostage and where a siege by the state police ended in 39 deaths, Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller made a disparaging assertion about New York’s John V. Lindsay. Except, Rockefeller was wrong.

headline: Can This Web Site Match Employers and Employees?
text: After Helen Rosen was laid off in 2008, she found herself frustrated by the job search process. Ms. Rosen, who had worked in the financial industry for 15 years, didn’t get the results she was hoping for from online job boards. In fact, she found the process of matching jobs to job seekers terribly inefficient.

headline: Replacing Coal With Gas Is No Panacea, Study Says
text: Although power plants fired by natural gas emit about half the carbon dioxide that conventional coal plants do, shifting from coal to natural gas to generate electricity will do little to slow climate change, according to a new study from the National Center for Atmospheric Research.

headline: U.S. Blames Pakistan-Based Group for Attack on Embassy in Kabul
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Raising the death toll sharply, American and Afghan officials said Wednesday that the complexity and execution of the siege of the American Embassy and NATO’s headquarters in Kabul bore the hallmarks of a militant group based in Pakistan that has become one of the American military’s most implacable foes.

headline: Elizabeth Warren Announces Senate Run
text: Elizabeth Warren officially announced her candidacy for the United States Senate in Massachusetts on Wednesday morning in a short video posted to her new campaign Web site, www.elizabethwarren.com.

headline: Turning the Mind Into a Joystick
text: How we’ll able to direct a computer with our thoughts using an ECoG (electrocorticographic) implant.

headline: The Cyborg in Us All
text: “Fingers!” Gerwin Schalk sputtered, waving his hands around in the air. “Fingers are made to pick up a hammer.” He prodded the table, mimicking the way we poke at computer keyboards. “It’s totally ridiculous,” he said.

headline: The Name Might Escape, Not the Work
text: THE golden age of Hollywood may have passed, but these are boom times for great character actors. On the big screen and the small, in movies and in television, beautiful sad sacks like Paul Giamatti, Bryan Cranston and Steve Buscemi are running away with some of the best roles and lines going, and Viola Davis is suddenly on the verge of stardom.

headline: A Heartthrob Finds His Tough-Guy Side
text: THE not uncommon view that Ryan Gosling is among the most disarming of young actors took on another meaning last month with the emergence of a viral video of a New York City street fight. In a scene that could be out of Laurel and Hardy, two men are going at it in an East Village crosswalk while bystanders, to no avail, try to pull them apart. A young man in a tank top and a baseball cap strolls into the melee. In the time it takes for the excited voices behind the cellphone camera to realize that this movie starlike good Samaritan is in fact “the guy from the movie — ‘The Notebook’ ” he has somehow orchestrated a cease-fire.

headline: The Perils of Chasing Buffett

headline: Is the Republican Victory in New York a Sign?
text: Republicans wasted no time late Tuesday night trying to nationalize their victories in special elections in New York and Nevada, seizing on them as evidence of dark days ahead for President Obama.

headline: What if the Secret to Success Is Failure?
text: Dominic Randolph can seem a little out of place at Riverdale Country School — which is odd, because he’s the headmaster. Riverdale is one of New York City’s most prestigious private schools, with a 104-year-old campus that looks down grandly on Van Cortlandt Park from the top of a steep hill in the richest part of the Bronx. On the discussion boards of UrbanBaby.com, worked-up moms from the Upper East Side argue over whether Riverdale sends enough seniors to Harvard, Yale and Princeton to be considered truly “TT” (top-tier, in UrbanBabyese), or whether it is more accurately labeled “2T” (second-tier), but it is, certainly, part of the city’s private-school elite, a place members of the establishment send their kids to learn to be members of the establishment. Tuition starts at $38,500 a year, and that’s for prekindergarten.

headline: MF Global Holdings to Eliminate Jobs
text: MF Global Holdings, the giant commodities and derivatives brokerage firm, said on Wednesday that it would reduce equity sales, trading and research jobs in Europe and Asia by more than 30 percent.

headline: Election Reflects New Dynamic in Brooklyn and Queens
text: The Democratic Party in Queens ended Tuesday night exposed as a tottering old dame, her inability to push a loyal — if severely charisma-challenged — son into Congress testament to her infirmities.

headline: A Next-Generation Cooking App by Dorie Greenspan
text: Dorie Greenspan, whose books on baking have launched a thousand sables, has a new app for the iPad dropping today. Baking With Dorie ($12.99) has several nifty and useful features that we didn’t see in the first generation of cooking apps, including step-by-step video for every recipe, like tarte tatin; crisp, airy visuals; and a choice among several recipe layouts, all of them designed for the needs of the cook, not the programmer.

headline: New Route to Sundance: Follow the Bunny
text: Playboy on Wednesday is announcing a competition intended to give budding film directors a new spotlight at the Sundance Film Festival – along, of course, with the bunny itself. The adult entertainment and publishing company will operate its contest, called the Playboy Shorts Series, viaTalenthouse.com, a social networking site that aims to foster artistic collaboration.

headline: The Somber Shadows of Attica
text: There was talk of crucifixion and resurrection Tuesday night at Union Theological Seminary, not a surprising topic for that setting. The context was unusual, though. The speakers weren’t referring to Calvary. They had in mind a muddy cellblock yard at Attica state prison where the blood had flowed freely 40 years earlier to the day.

headline: Germany and France Back Greece on Austerity Effort
text: PARIS — The Greek prime minister vowed Wednesday to persevere with austere cuts in the struggling country’s budget, while the leaders of France and Germany promised to support Greece’s continued membership in the euro zone.

headline: Baryshnikov Breaks Out His Russian For ‘In Paris’
text: PARIS — In 1978, the first time Mikhail Baryshnikov performed in Paris, he was booed. Loudly. He was dancing the role of the doomed Herman in Roland Petit’s interpretation of “Queen of Spades,” and the audience hated it.

headline: Another Day, Another Odd Literary Collectible for Sale: J. K. Rowling’s Boots
text: Finally, something for the J. K. Rowling fan who has everything, including some extra space in his or her shoe closet. Arriving on the heels, so to speak, of Tuesday’s announcement that a one-sentence letter from J. D. Salinger to his maid was being offered for $50,000, a company in Omaha is putting up for auction a pair of boots that Ms. Rowling wore while she wrote the first book in her best-selling “Harry Potter” series. The boots, which are being sold by Blue Earth Benefit Auctions in an online auction that starts Friday at proxibid.com, were given to a fifth-grade class at Harrison Elementary School in Omaha in 1999. At that time, the class was conducting a project called “Operation Shoe Tree,” in which celebrities or other people the pupils admired were asked to write about their lives from the perspective of their footwear.

headline: Istanbul Reimagined
text: “Design is not about objects anymore; it’s more pervasive,” says Vasif Kortun, a director of Istanbul’s new arts center Salt (Istiklal Caddesi 136; saltonline.org). “Turkey is picking it up belatedly.” And quickly. Since the opening of Adnan Kazmaoglu’s austerely geometric Yesil Vadi Mosque in Istanbul last year, a design and architecture movement is sweeping through the city. Salt’s Beyoglu building, a columned space by the local architect Han Tumertekin on the boulevard Istiklal, features the work of a different Turkish designer in each room — there’s a cinema by Hakan Demirel, a bookstore by Omer Unal and a cafe by Ali Selcuk and the chef Murat Bozok. Regular symposiums cover everything from urban planning to electronic music, and later this fall a second outpost will open nearby in Galata.

headline: Europe Won’t Allow a Lehman-Like Collapse, Geithner Says

headline: Senior American Diplomat in Tripoli Says Islamists Are Not a Threat
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — America’s top diplomat for the Middle East said on Wednesday that he was monitoring the growing influence of Islamists on the interim government that has replaced Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in Libya, but does not consider that influence a significant threat.

headline: Hard Times for a Hell’s Kitchen Mural
text: For nearly 40 years, several much-larger-than-life neighborhood advocates have been battling the establishment from a wall overlooking a West 46th Street playground. Turning against the ravages of drug abuse and the juggernaut of slum clearance, they carry blueprints, flowers and a manifesto — “We the people demand control of our communities” — into a rainbow-anointed future.

headline: Google Flight Search vs. Kayak

headline: Where the Bargains Are
text: LOOKING for five-star service at three-star prices? Try Latin America for your next vacation. Whether it’s due to a good exchange rate (as in Argentina) or simply because a destination is just coming into its own (Colombia), travelers will find that they will often pay less for a boutique hotel experience and that meals are more reasonable, if not downright cheap, compared with Europe or the United States.

headline: Boys at Play

Three new picture books capture the singularity, stubbornness and, yes, sweetness in the ways young boys find to amuse themselves.

headline: For Rivera, Save No. 600 Comes With an Assist

headline: Waste Not, Biden Tells Cabinet

Biden Jr. on Wednesday convened the first Cabinet meeting dedicated solely to looking at how to reduce waste at federal agencies.

headline: Watch Out for Lethal Branches. Bats, Too.
text: For my job at the Nature Conservancy, I spend a lot of time planning fieldwork in remote places where I study how conservation benefits people in poor communities. So I approached my family’s year in the woods as if it were fieldwork in a new country. I read all I could before going and talked to people who were already living off the grid in the woods of Maine to understand the local risks.

headline: Interview: Matthew Goode

headline: Can an Applebee’s Franchisee Be a Real Entrepreneur?
text: We’ve just published a lively small-business conversation with Zane Tankel, who bought into the established Applebee’s business model but who has also challenged that model in many ways, including what his employees wear, how they are hired and rewarded, where he builds his restaurants, and what food those restaurants serve. Based on revenue numbers confirmed by Applebee’s, the results have been impressive. “Maybe this kind of thing isn’t for the average franchisee,” Mr. Tankel told Eilene Zimmerman, “but we pushed the envelope right from the start, took those protocols to the next level, and I think that’s entrepreneurship.”

headline: Michael Kors: Poor Man’s Safari

headline: Matthew Goode Becomes ‘Burning Man’
text: TORONTO — The English actor Matthew Goode has appeared in a wide range of movies during his relatively brief film career, including a Woody Allen movie (“Match Point”), one inspired by a comic book (“Watchmen”) and  a Hollywood romantic comedy (“Leap Year”). In the Australian drama “Burning Man,” he takes on one of his toughest acting challenges, as a chef who has experienced an event that would change his life permanently.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Michael Kors
text: “Michael loves a bronze girl or boy,” said Dick Page backstage at Michael Kors. “This is a sort of rough glamor.” Page used Shiseido Creme Shadow in Caviar, Leather and Sable to create strong eyebrows with Meadow gold spread on the lid and Caramel Perfect Rouge on the lips. Luminize Satin Face Color in BE 206 was mixed with Bronzer 1 and 2 all over the face to make sure the models “didn’t look like they had to get up at 6 a.m. to do a show.” No one did. “It’s pretty,” Hanne Gaby said of her tousled hair braided with black leather. “I don’t think I’d be able to do it, though.” Luckily, Orlando Pita was there to help create the look that came about based on one of Kors’s fantasy stories. (“He embellished it more than I do,” said Pita of the designer’s storytelling prowess.) The tales goes: These girls are on a trip in Africa with only shoelaces to tie back their hair. “They groom themselves,” said Pita. “The front is all they can see.” This explains why the hair around the face was more tidy, parted in the middle, while the back was wild and messy. Orlando’s own Dry Shampoo was used with Bumble and Bumble Surf Spray to coat the hair before braiding. The tail was then teased up between the lacing and Pita’s Elevate Texture Spray added. The model Magdalena Frackowiak offered a way to translate the look to her own routine: “braid it loosely and then pull bits out.”

headline: A Congressman-Elect Wakes Up to His New Role
text: Bob Turner, who won a special election on Tuesday to replace Anthony D. Weiner in the Ninth Congressional district, emerged onto his porch in Rockaway Point, Queens, at 9:45 Wednesday morning in shorts and T-shirt and with bare feet, still somewhat groggy from his late-night victory party and surprised to find a reporter and photographer waiting in his yard.

headline: BP Shortcuts Led to Gulf Oil Spill, Report Says

headline: In Brussels, American vs. Belgian Beers
text: In Brussels, Moeder Lambic (8 Place Fontainas; 32-2-503-60-68) is among the most traditional of Belgian beer cafes, specializing in the obscure sour brews known as lambic and gueuze. By contrast, California’s Stone Brewing Company is among the most innovative of American brewers, turning out broad-shouldered double I.P.A.’s and other highly hopped, high-octane ales with names like Sublimely Self-Righteous and Ruination.

headline: Russia Again at Odds With West Over Election Monitors

(A House committee held a hearing on the company and the administration this morning.)

headline: Uninstalling ‘Curiosity,’ the Video

Educators at KIPP Infinity, a charter school in Harlem, and Riverdale, a prestigious private school in the Bronx, are using special lesson plans to improve the character of their students. To illustrate the piece, we wanted to show the two school environments as well as express the idea of teaching traits like optimism, grit and curiosity.

Here, Mr. Refn discusses a chase scene that happens early in the film and is primarily shot within the car’s interior.

headline: Sluggish Start for CW’s ‘Ringer’

An identical twin premise on the CW’s “Ringer” meant a double dose of Sarah Michelle Gellar, but the return of that former vampire slayer to television was mostly met with a ratings shrug. The show averaged 2.7 million total viewers and matched the rating in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic of last season’s “Hellcats” opener on the CW, which was ultimately canceled. NBC was the No. 1 broadcast network in the 18-to-49 category for the night, helped by the return of “Parenthood” (6.7 million total viewers) and the final performance episode of “America’s Got Talent” (13.2 million).
