text: September 14, 2011 — Elizabeth Warren, a consumer advocate and Harvard University professor, announces a run for U.S. Senate in Massachusetts.

headline: Armed Pirates Hijack a Fuel Tanker Off Benin and Take 23 Crew Members Hostage
text: Armed pirates commandeered a fuel tanker off the West African nation of Benin on Wednesday and took its 23 crew members hostage, an international piracy monitoring group reported.

headline: Homes for $810,000
text: A Queen Anne in Aberdeen, Wash.; a modern house in Austin, Tex.; and a Tudor in Birmingham, Ala.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Theyskens’ Theory
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#552", 592, 430, true, chameleonData);

headline: The Island Birds of Papua New Guinea
text: Jack Dumbacher, curator of ornithology and mammalogy at the California Academy of Sciences, writes from Milne Bay, Papua New Guinea, where he is studying island birds and their diseases.

headline: Trendspotting: Peplums
text: In a season marked by all manner of flounces and frills, the peplum was a standout.

headline: Day 7: Off the Runway
text: Scenes from New York Fashion Week on Sept. 14.

headline: Former Harvard President to Head New York Public Library Board
text: Neil L. Rudenstine, the former president of Harvard University, was elected chairman of the board of the New York Public Library on Wednesday. Mr. Rudenstine, 76, is replacing Catherine Marron who has led the board since 2004. He will assume the post immediately.

headline: Peplum for the People
text: In a season marked by all manner of flounces and frills, the peplum was a standout. Embraced in the 1940s and ’50s by Jacques Fath and Christian Dior, the look, defined by a starchy little overskirt that flares from the waist, reappears every decade or so. It was picked up last season by Marc Jacobs of Louis Vuitton and Christophe Decarnin at Balmain, and revisted once more this week on the runways of Jason Wu, Vera Wang, Badgley Mischka and Rodarte, to name but a handful, lending their collections a shot of vintage Hollywood allure.

headline: TimesCast | Fall TV Lineup
text: In their fall TV lineups, networks bet on big budget shows.

headline: What You Get for ... $810,000
text: Aberdeen, Wash.

headline: Financial Regulators May Get Bigger Budgets
text: Financial regulators clamoring for bigger budgets notched a rare victory on Wednesday, as a Senate subcommittee approved a measure to increase the budgets for cops on the Wall Street beat.

headline: For Android Users, a Cure for iTunes Withdrawal
text: A few weeks ago, I pulled off a major feat for a fortysomething relic in the company of a 15-year-old. I taught him something cool about his phone.

headline: Simon Cowell vs. Everybody Else
text: Bill Carter and Brian Stelter, reporters on The Times’s media desk, take a look at Simon Cowell’s new talent competition, “The X Factor,” among other notable new shows arriving this fall.

headline: Controls Gone Wild
text: Think your car dashboard has gotten tricked out with digital tools? Think twice, says Consumer Reports in its newest issue, with a bit of a sobering video about the amount of effort drivers must exert to deploy some of the dashboard devices.

headline: A Hi-Fi House in Melbourne
text: The exterior of David and Karine O’Donnell’s home in Melbourne, Australia, looks like a striking copy of a vintage hi-fi stereo.

headline: In Good Times and Bum Times, a Trouper With Feisty Resolve
text: Had Elaine Stritch sung “I’m Still Here” at Café Carlyle on Tuesday night, it would have seemed redundant. The mere presence of this lean, glaring lion of a woman in a white shirt and black tights, clenching her fists, said everything about resilience, feisty determination and the will to continue that is voiced in a veteran showgirl’s embattled proclamation from “Follies.”

headline: Verizon’s Prepaid Plan Cut By Nearly Half
text: Tomorrow Verizon Mobile will begin to offer a new unlimited prepaid plan at almost half the price of the current plan.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Narciso Rodriguez
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#69", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);Matthew Kristall’s New York fashion week photo diary.

headline: Sarah Palin Could See This Guy From Her House
text: On May 22, 2010, Joe McGinniss moved into a strategically well-situated house in Wasilla, Alaska. It was next door to the home of former Gov. Sarah Palin and her family, but that understates the highly exploitable proximity of the two places. They were very close together. The Palins could probably hear tweets from the newly hatched birds that Mr. McGinniss excitedly uses as filler for “The Rogue,” his book about his summer-long experiment in homesteading. “The grebe chicks have hatched!” he needlessly exclaims.

headline: Consortium Views Arts as Engines of Recovery
text: In the two years since he became chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, Rocco Landesman has been trying to make the case that art is an effective linchpin to economic development. Now in a broad effort to build on that thesis, he has helped to enlist an unusual consortium of foundations, corporations and federal agencies that will use cultural enterprises to anchor and enliven 34 projects around the country, from a struggling city block in Detroit to a vacant school in East Harlem.

headline: Madison Avenue Says Ho! Ho! Halloween!
text: For several years, it has been the practice of marketers, retailers and media companies to start making their pitches earlier and earlier for the important Christmas shopping season.

headline: A Gentle Nod to Country, With a Streak of Darkness
text: No act in contemporary pop is more careful than the bionic country trio Lady Antebellum, which never leaves a note out of place, which never lets a feeling spill outside the lines. It takes basic components — male-female harmony, sturdy pop arrangements with light brushes of country, an unerring sense of when to shift a song from desperate to redemptive — and arranges them in several different ways, with mostly similar results. These are plain and obvious tricks, shopworn from years of deployment. Lady Antebellum songs don’t try to hide anything. It’s infuriating.

headline: Emotions Swirl Amid the Simple Language
text: Alan Hampton was airing out a new song at the Living Room on Tuesday night, and like the tumblers in a lock, every piece seemed to be clicking into place. “Don’t you stay mad at me,” he sang sweetly, thumb-picking an eight-stringed ukulele. “I’m doing the best that I can with what I’ve got.” There was a faint, ambiguous edge to the line, a puckish mix of apology, self-deprecation and passive-aggression. You could picture Mr. Hampton sighing it, rather than singing it, during the deflated last stretch of an exasperating spat.

headline: Upheaval in a Family That Hopes to Stand Out
text: Rain clouds flow like lava across the Indonesian countryside at the outset of “Position Among the Stars,” the final installment in Leonard Retel Helmrich’s documentary trilogy about three generations of an upwardly striving family. Later, when clouds of chemicals invade the Jakarta slums to combat dengue fever — a toxic mirror of that dreamy opening shot — their deadly billows encapsulate the film’s recurring concern: for some, cities can be poison.

headline: It’s a Close Contest, but One Is Cruder
text: Good news for those who feel as if they hadn’t been getting enough vulgarity and misogyny in their television: the next few days bring the return of two of cable’s raunchiest sitcoms, “It’s Always Sunny in Philadelphia” and “Blue Mountain State.”

headline: Fashion Week Casting | Proenza Schouler
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#91", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

headline: A Battle at the French Box Office: Two Remakes of One Classic Film
text: PARIS — On screen it is a story of a war between two rival bands of schoolboys. In real life it is a war between two producers, neither of whom will surrender.

headline: A Home That Looks Like the Sounds of the ’60s
text: MELBOURNE, Australia

headline: Teenage Driving Laws May Just Delay Deadly Crashes
text: A nationwide study shows that tougher licensing laws for teenage drivers have reduced deadly accidents among 16-year-olds, but with an unintended consequence: increasing the fatal crash rate among 18-year-olds.

headline: There’s an Exciting Clash on the Field. Oh, That’s the Uniform.
text: The right side of the helmet was covered in a black and gold diagonal checkerboard pattern. The left side displayed a red and white cross. The patterns extended from the helmet to the shoulders, and some players accentuated them with similarly styled armbands.

headline: ‘The Rogue’
text: ONE

headline: A Bold and Ferocious Swirl
text: On my first morning in New York, more than 30 years ago, and for most mornings the next three weeks, I stood in line at the New York State Theater to buy, for $2.50, a standing-room spot at the back of the fourth ring to watch New York City Ballet. At some performances we could move down to empty seats, but we could not have afforded them. The performances seen from the fourth ring — including George Balanchine’s classic “Four Temperaments” on my very first night — were among the most revelatory of my life. And my younger eyes loved the view from that eyrie.

headline: ‘Swan Lake’ at City Ballet
text: The company opened its season on Tuesday with Peter Martin’s production of “Swan Lake.”

headline: Tackling Reams of Bank Data Can Take Diligence, and Trust
text: Some people stay sharp in their old age by doing crossword puzzles. Some play memory games or Scrabble or cut back on the heavy drinking.

headline: Making the "Grit" Tape Installation
text: The artist Stephen Doyle taped, across multiple surfaces, the words for the traits being taught at KIPP Infinity middle school in Manhattan. Watch the word “grit” being made.

headline: Automakers Resolve to Drop a Few Pounds
text: FRANKFURT

headline: Athletes Hit the Front Rows at Fashion Week
text: A NEW face was turning heads at fashion shows this week, and it wasn’t Nicki Minaj (the Day-Glo-hued rapper, who sat next to Anna Wintour), Beyoncé (sporting a baby bump) or even another basketball all-star.

headline: Who Suffered the Most
text: A look at changes in median income before and after the recession for different groups of people.

headline: A Bag That Powers Your Gear
text: In these days of always-on devices, there’s nothing worse than a dead gadget. New bags by PowerBag promise portable charging for multiple devices on the go.

headline: New York Top 5 | J. Crew
text: J. Crew staged its highly anticipated, first-ever New York Fashion Week presentation at the tents in Lincoln Center this season. The men’s collection, designed by Frank Muytjens, included some greatest hits of American sportswear (the perfect slender suits and sports jackets, sailor-striped knits and tailored trousers) alongside clever pieces in bright colors, plaids and polka dots, always impeccably styled. The cuffed khakis lined with St. James stripes were absolutely charming, but my favorite look was on the more minimal side. A stone-colored jean jacket, buttoned all the way up and worn with matching jean-style trousers, topped by a navy nylon lightweight parka, was the winner for me. The jacket is from a new capsule collection called Wallace & Barnes that will consist of reinterpretations of favorite vintage pieces that somehow never made it into the main line. Coming soon to a J. Crew near you.

headline: French Compositions, and Even a French Horn
text: The New York Chamber Music Festival, during its nine-day run at Symphony Space (which began on Sunday), is offering an eclectic lineup, including anniversary concerts celebrating Mahler, Liszt and the French composer Pierre de Bréville; 13 premieres; masterpieces, obscurities, tango and jazz.

headline: Susan Orlean on Rin Tin Tin and Her Own Menagerie
text: The New Yorker writer Susan Orlean’s latest book, “Rin Tin Tin: The Life and the Legend,” a biography of the famous German shepherd, is “a California book in so many ways,” she said. In a story that often has the feel of a golden-hued Hollywood dream, the orphaned puppy is found on a French battlefield in World War I and goes on to become a star of silent films, radio and, ultimately, television, in “The Adventures of Rin-Tin-Tin.”

headline: Fashion Week’s Split Personality
text: FOURTEENTH Street was mildly crowded as the couple walked west in the approaching twilight of last Friday. Something about the way they looked suggested that they were headed to Milk Studios, the fashion show site on West 15th Street, and that it might be interesting to follow them.

headline: Live and Let Dance
text: Paul McCartney collaborated with Peter Martins, the New York City Ballet’s ballet master in chief, for “Ocean’s Kingdom,” which has its gala opening next week at Lincoln Center.

headline: Suspended Animation
text: MOSS & LAM, a Toronto art studio, specializes in large-scale installations and creative wall finishes — what amounts to special effects for interiors and architectural projects.

headline: Hanging Mobiles
text: The Toronto artists Deborah Moss and Edward Lam shopped for mobiles that bring beauty and action to a room.

headline: Facebook’s New Friend-Sorting Features
text: This week, Facebook is rolling out two new features designed to make it easier to share posts with small groups of people who belong to the same family, city, workplace or school as you, and to separate your best friends from your so-so friends.

headline: Cathy Horyn's Spring 2012 Report
text: Cathy Horyn discusses themes that have emerged during New York Fashion Week so far.

headline: McGinniss Book on Palin Comes Out
text: Just as Palinologists and politicos are awaiting Sarah Palin’s imminent (or so she says) decision on whether she will run for president, a new biography of her makes lurid accusations that have filtered out to media outlets now that the book has begun circulating.

headline: Back to School, Demurely
text: “IT’S all about grandma chic,” said Chelsea Roberts, who was surveying the clothes in SoHo one Thursday last month while back-to-school shopping. Ms. Roberts, 17, is about to begin her senior year at Roland Park Country School in Baltimore.

headline: Battle for Libya | September 14, 2011
text: Demonstrators protested the prospect of Islamists taking over the revolution in Libya while Qaddafi loyalists remained in Bani Walid and Surt.

headline: A Big Player Puts a Toe in the Pond
text: DOES New York need a Nordstrom? We’ve got our big B’s: Barneys, Bloomie’s, Bergdorf and the sadly diminished Bendel (R.I.P. Bonwit Teller and your violet-festooned shopping bags). Also our profusion of little b’s (boutiques) offering every brand that this Seattle-based department store chain carries, and then some. And yet Nordstrom continues to make advances: slowly, cautiously, like a love-handled suitor not quite sure his embrace will be welcome.

headline: Do Individual Acts Help Save the Planet?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Some Democrats Are Balking at Obama’s Jobs Bill
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama anticipated Republican resistance to his jobs program, but he is now meeting increasing pushback from his own party. Many Congressional Democrats, smarting from the fallout over the 2009 stimulus bill, say there is little chance they will be able to support the bill as a single entity, citing an array of elements they cannot abide.

headline: An interview with Julie Newmar; digital comics; animated GIFs; tech news.
text: The actress and dancer Julie Newmar discusses her new book, perpetual Internet fandom and her approach to playing an android on TV. George Gene Gustines and Adam W. Kepler of The Times offer pros and cons for reading comic books on digital devices — or sticking to good old-fashioned ink and paper. Pedro Rafael Rosado offers a how-to lesson on making your own animated GIFs. The week’s tech news includes Microsoft’s developer’s preview of Windows 8, GameStop’s venture into making its own gaming tablet, and new surveys on both Android adoption in Europe and Americans’ use of social networks. The Tip of the Week highlights a quick way to edit photos right on the Flickr site.

headline: A Political Upset in New York
text: To the Editor:

headline: Seeking Relief Through Arnica
text: BEFORE the C.F.D.A. Fashion Awards in June, the New York-based fashion designer Phillip Lim, who’d been traveling frequently and working hard, was feeling a bit puffy. “I heard of models and other designers taking arnica before big events or photo shoots, so I thought I’d try it out,” he said recently, referring to the homeopathic supplement arnica montana. “It’s supposed to slim you down because it flushes you out. And it clears up your skin.”

headline: Palestinians Say a U.N. Gamble on Statehood Is Worth the Risks
text: KALANDIA, West Bank — It is far from clear what will happen when the Palestinians go to the United Nations next week to seek recognition of statehood. But the initiative is engaging a Palestinian public that had become deeply cynical after 20 years of intermittent Israeli-Palestinian peace talks.

headline: History May Point Toward More Conservative G.O.P. Nominee
text: The Republican presidential nomination is shaping up to be a battle between the party’s moderate and conservative factions, as Jeff Zeleny and Michael Shear reported Tuesday:

headline: TimesCast | Palestinian Statehood
text: September 14, 2011 — U.S. officials make a last minute effort to avert a United Nations vote on Palestinian statehood.

headline: Six Actresses Not in Search of TV Work
text: BURBANK, Calif.

headline: Head of Goldman’s Computer-Trading Shop to Step Down
text: Katinka Domotorffy, the head of Goldman Sachs‘s quantitative investment strategies group, will retire from the firm at the end of the year, according to a letter the bank’s asset management division sent to investors on Wednesday.

headline: Wait, Wait, I Think She Changed
text: THE e-mails started coming in June, as many as four a day, announcing what Rosie Huntington-Whiteley wore. It was a Ferragamo dress at a photo call in Rio de Janeiro, a Vhernier ring in Moscow, a Stella McCartney dress in Berlin.

headline: New Bedding From Area
text: For some time now, the dark-to-light gradation of color known as ombré has been a trend in fashion and hair, and recently, it’s made an appearance in home furnishings as well. At the New York International Gift Fair last month, Area introduced a collection of bed linens called Ines that looked like ombré. But Anki Spets, the company’s owner and designer, insisted that it is technically a gradient stripe.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Catwoman and an Animated Internet
text: Julie Newmar has appeared on many TV shows that entranced young baby boomers — “Star Trek,” “The Twilight Zone,” “Get Smart” and “Batman,” in which she was Catwoman. One of her earliest roles was playing an android on the 1964 science-fiction sit-com “My Living Doll.” Miss Newmar discusses her new book “The Conscious Catwoman Explains Life on Earth” and reflects on her career and her continued fame on the Internet.

headline: The Food Was Great, the Groveling Wasn’t
text: LAST year, when my girlfriend accepted a job in Mumbai, we had to find an apartment on short notice, a daunting task in that city’s drastically oversubscribed housing market. But we were lucky, finding a cheap sublet at one of the city’s most desirable addresses, in the Churchgate neighborhood of south Mumbai’s Art Deco precinct. The spacious three-bedroom apartment overlooked one of the rare open spaces in the city, the Oval Maidan, an oblong park where dozens of cricket matches intertwine each evening, and beyond which sit the august Gothic buildings of the British period.

headline: Dyson Hot, a Fan That Heats and Cools
text: If you like the looks of the Dyson Tower Fan, you will be pleased to learn of the Dyson Hot, a strikingly similar heater that hits the market today. With a remote-control thermostat that can be set between 32 and 99 degrees, the Dyson Hot, which sells for about $400, can do double duty as a cooling fan.

headline: A Pop-Up Shop Previews a Cecil Beaton Show
text: In anticipation of “Cecil Beaton: The New York Years,” a show opening next month at the Museum of the City of New York, the New York Design Center and 1stdibs will host a pop-up preview, “Cecil Beaton and the 1930s,” on the center’s 10th floor, starting on Friday.

headline: ‘300 Years of Glassware’ at Jasper Morrison
text: For the last two years, the Jasper Morrison shop in London has presented exhibitions coinciding with the London Design Festival that have focused on the design of a specific object: the first year, “Jugs, Jars and Pitchers”; the second, “Trays From Around the World.”

headline: Sales at George Smith and Others
text: Floor models, prototypes and in-stock furnishings are up to 70 percent off during the annual sample sale at Desiron, through Sept. 25 (the Bedford Club Chair, originally $4,015, is $1,205; the Chrysler Cocktail Table, regularly $5,600, is $2,800); 151 Wooster Street (Houston Street); (212) 353-2600 or desiron.com.

headline: A Texas Sanctuary for Waterlilies
text: Ken Landon, a renowned waterlily hybridizer and plant explorer, has assembled a collection in San Angelo, Tex., that contains 90 percent of the world’s known wild species of waterlilies and more than 4,000 hybrids.

headline: Lights Out, Game On
text: LAST night I slept on athletic shorts. Or more accurately, I slept on the stuff athletic shorts are made of: high-tech performance fabric, the sort of super-Lycra that goes into the uniforms of, say, basketball players.

headline: For Waterlilies, an Odd Refuge in Texas
text: SAN ANGELO, Tex.

headline: Pay for Only 4 Years of College. Guaranteed.
text: ASHLAND, Va. — Each incoming freshman at Randolph-Macon College this year was eligible to take part in a brief signing ceremony.

headline: Beauty Spots
text: LET THEM SMELL GREAT  When Marie Antoinette was sent to prison during the French Revolution, she took with her a dark jade flask containing a floral scent that apparently reminded her of her gardens at Versailles. Right before she was executed, the story goes, she entrusted the flask to her loyal friend, Madame de Tourzel, whose descendants still have it. Lubin Paris is resurrecting the scent with Black Jade: a mix of rose, jasmine and bergamot, with hints of cardamom and cinnamon (from $130, at Henri Bendel in New York and Luckyscent.com).

headline: A Flowering of a Family Legacy
text: DIAMONDS glinted like tiny asteroids on Tatiana Von Furstenberg’s fingers, every one of them a talisman of sorts. There was the domelike gem she inherited from her father, the faceted stone that was a gift from her former husband and another that belonged to her maternal grandmother.

headline: The A.M.A., on Doctor Fees
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lauding Columbia’s Leader
text: To the Editor:

headline: Chinese Team Takes Top Prize at a Tournament in Beijing
text: The Hua Yuan Cup world women’s elite tournament was held in Beijing from Sept. 5 to 9 with total prize money of $200,000. Eight teams were invited: Canada, England, France, the Netherlands, Sweden, the United States and two from China.

headline: Vaughn and Carson Help Give the Liberty a Shot
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The five-on-five session was playing out on the Madison Square Garden Training Center court, a rehearsal before the W.N.B.A. playoffs for Kia Vaughn, working up a sweat in the low post, and Essence Carson, showing off her energy a bit farther from the basket.

headline: Trendspotting at TechCrunch Disrupt
text: Entrepreneurial zeal is the inevitable theme at technology conferences like TechCrunch Disrupt, which ends its three-day run in San Francisco on Wednesday. Start-up founders and those who wanted to be overdosed on self-promotion, salesmanship and name-dropping while Silicon Valley celebrities pontificated on stage.

headline: To Wit and Long Memories, Anna Sui
text: Anna Sui rarely fails to put a smile on your face with her whimsical prints and girly dresses, and her show Wednesday night was no exception. Her soundtrack transformed the big tent at Lincoln Center into a scene from Club Sept in Paris in the 1970s, and the models lined up at the back of the runway as if they were waiting to get in. One by one, they took the catwalk wearing chiffon trousers and tops in dark vintage prints, many of them with matching turbans, or long lace gowns with floppy hats. Her prints were especially witty, one with stripes that, if you looked closely, were made of toothbrushes.

headline: Beyond ‘New Atheism’
text: The Stone is featuring occasional posts by Gary Gutting, a professor of philosophy at the University of Notre Dame, that apply critical thinking to information and events that have appeared in the news.

headline: NoBar
text: WITH its reclaimed church pews and Edison bulbs, NoBar aims to be something that this strip of fried-chicken outlets and dollar stores in Bedford-Stuyvesant lacks: a stylish but unpretentious bar.

headline: Minority Groups and Gay Marriage
text: To the Editor:

headline: Near the 5-Inch Heels, Guerrillas on Four Wheels
text: EVERYONE was expecting New York Fashion Week to embrace mobile this fall. They just didn’t mean vehicles.

headline: The Buzz
text: A PREVIEW of the must-attend parties, talked-about openings and fashionable night spots for the week ahead.

headline: Rick Perry Tackles Faith — and Bad Grades
text: Speaking at Liberty University in Lynchburg, Va., the candidate for the Republican presidential nomination told students about his poor college performance, but spoke little about politics.

headline: Bloggingheads: Is Perry Lying?
text: David Corn, left, of Mother Jones and James Pinkerton of Fox News debate Rick Perry's claims about Obama's record.

headline: As Fighting in Kabul Wanes, Sniping on Twitter Begins
text: As the firefight in Kabul, Afghanistan, simmered down early on Wednesday, the battle on Twitter began heating up, with representatives of the NATO-led coalition and the Taliban trading barbs in a burst of virtual conversation.

headline: Win May Not Be Needed to Take the FedEx Cup
text: LEMONT, Ill. — With the PGA Tour’s playoffs for the FedEx Cup coming down to the final two weeks, some startling possibilities could emerge from the field of 70 that begins play Thursday at the BMW Championship at Cog Hill Golf and Country Club.

headline: Barely Time for the Shows
text: FASHION insiders were exhausted before the shows even started. The twice-a-year bacchanal known as New York Fashion Week started two days early this year, with a flurry of parties for models (One Management), store openings (Surface to Air) and birthdays (Rachel Zoe).

headline: House Is Expected to Pass Bill Aiding New Boeing Plant
text: Leading House Republicans on Thursday will take up the contentious debate over the National Labor Relations Board’s efforts to block Boeing from operating a $750 million aircraft assembly line in South Carolina instead of Washington State.

headline: After a Long March, Chinese Surrender to Capitalist Shrines
text: PARIS — It was once the Americans, then the Japanese, then the Russians. Now it’s the Chinese.

headline: Ready for Next Round, Sanchez Bounces Up Off the Canvas
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Mark Sanchez spent Monday being tested for a concussion, resting, sitting in a cold tub and getting a massage. He said the pummeling he received Sunday at the hands of the Dallas Cowboys was really not a big deal.

headline: AOL, Yahoo and Microsoft Reportedly in Ad Deal
text: Yahoo, AOL and Microsoft, three major technology companies that have traditionally competed for digital advertising revenue, have created an unusual partnership in which they will sell ads for one another.

headline: Steps Can Be Painful as Giants’ Line Masters a Difficult Dance
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Offensive linemen are the Goliaths of the N.F.L., and for most fans they are probably interchangeable. One 300-pounder gets injured? Just get another. Any ogre will do.

headline: Three Terrorist Groups in Africa Pose Threat to U.S., American Commander Says
text: WASHINGTON — The senior American military commander for Africa warned Wednesday that three violent extremist organizations on the continent were trying to forge an alliance to coordinate attacks on the United States and Western interests.

headline: Vice Media to Expand Offerings of Video Entertainment on Its Site
text: Vice Media, a company that produces things like documentary films profiling Liberian war lords and albums by the Black Lips, has decided to go old-school media.

headline: Arthur Evans, Leader in Gay Rights Fight, Dies at 68
text: Arthur Evans, who helped form and lead the movement that coalesced after gay people and their supporters protested a 1969 police raid on the Stonewall Inn, a Greenwich Village gay bar, died on Sunday at his home in San Francisco. He was 68.

headline: Syrian TV Station Accuses Al Jazeera of Fabricating Uprising
text: A YouTube channel called the Syrian Interpreter has posted a subtitled recording of the Syrian television station Addounia TV claiming in a Sept. 9 broadcast that the news station Al Jazeera has built enormous “cinematic replicas” of Syrian cities and squares in the Gulf state of Qatar in order to fabricate the uprising in Syria.

headline: Yanks’ Closer Also Serves as Mentor and Counselor
text: SEATTLE — One afternoon earlier this season, when Alex Rodriguez was searching for his swing, Mariano Rivera took him into the trainer’s room for a quiet but emphatic conversation.

headline: A City of Glass Towers, and a Hazard for Migratory Birds
text: Most bird-watching enthusiasts spend their days looking up in the hope of seeing the flash of a yellow warbler or a scarlet tanager. Deborah A. Laurel looks at the ground.

headline: Showing Their Colors
text: College football teams across the country are wearing new, and sometimes garish, uniforms to increase the visibility of both the university and the apparel manufacturer.

headline: Ex-Spy Chief of Colombia Is Sentenced to Prison
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Jorge Noguera, Colombia’s former spymaster, was convicted on Wednesday of collaborating with paramilitary assassination squads and sentenced to 25 years in prison for his involvement in the 2004 murder of a prominent sociologist.

headline: Mog, the Music Streaming Service, Will Offer a Free Version
text: Music, it seems, wants to be free.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Forecast Comes True: No Playoffs for the Mets
text: Minutes after being formally eliminated from playoff contention on Wednesday afternoon, the Mets did their best to escape the present and dwell on the past.

headline: Manufacturing Expectations and Belief at Mississippi State
text: STARKVILLE, Miss. — The president of Mississippi State, Mark E. Keenum, canceled Thursday’s classes months ago in anticipation of a night game against No. 3 Louisiana State. Early Wednesday morning, fans began lining a grassy area known as the Junction, waiting for a chapel bell to ring at 5 p.m. so they could officially begin tailgating more than 24 hours before kickoff. Before the game, and not far from the all-day revelry, construction workers will break ground on a $25 million football training facility.

headline: Judge Says Hedge Funds May Have Used Inside Information
text: There have long been whispers on Wall Street that hedge funds have hijacked the bankruptcy process, using their influence as debt holders to obtain and trade on insider information about when and how a company will restructure.

headline: After Choosing a Candidate Who Lost, a Democrat Stands in an Unfavorable Light
text: New York Democrats woke up on Wednesday morning to an unwelcome new reality — the voters of Queens and Brooklyn had elected a Republican to represent the Ninth Congressional District — and an uncomfortable new question: What went wrong?

headline: Frank Quattrone’s Golden Touch
text: When Frank Quattrone comes calling, buyers should beware. The latest coup for the former Credit Suisse First Boston ace is persuading Google to bid against itself for Motorola Mobility. Since starting Qatalyst Partners, his boutique investment bank, Mr. Quattrone has extracted a much higher premium for clients than rival tech bankers. Silicon Valley has now been given fair warning.

headline: Bradley to Coach Egypt
text: Bob Bradley, the former coach of the United States national team, who was fired over the summer and replaced by Jurgen Klinsmann, will become the next coach of Egypt, said a spokesman for Egypt’s federation.

headline: Islamists’ Growing Sway Raises Questions for Libya
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — In the emerging post-Qaddafi Libya, the most influential politician may well be Ali Sallabi, who has no formal title but commands broad respect as an Islamic scholar and populist orator who was instrumental in leading the mass uprising.

headline: Walking Out on China
text: YUNNAN PROVINCE, in southwestern China, has long been the exit point for Chinese who yearn for a new life outside the country. There, one can sneak out of China by land, passing through pristine forests, or one can go by water, floating all the way down the Lancang River until it becomes the Mekong, which meanders into Myanmar, Laos, Thailand, Cambodia and Vietnam.

headline: Just Elected to Congress, and Already Talking of Staying

headline: Seeing Ripple in Jewish Vote
text: WASHINGTON — Not since Jimmy Carter in 1980 has a Democrat running for president failed to win a lopsided majority of the Jewish vote. This has been true during times of peace or war, and even when there has been deep acrimony between the White House and the Israeli government.

Muammar el-Qaddafi, Libyan officials said.

text: SEATTLE — Mariano Rivera has done many things in baseball, from recording 600 saves to starting games and even batting. But he has never played center field.

headline: Israel and New York’s Ninth District
text: There has already been a lot of theorizing about why a little-known Republican businessman, Bob Turner, won Tuesday’s special Congressional election in a traditionally Democratic New York City district. The grim economy appears to have been a big factor in his victory over Assemblyman David Weprin, and some voters also complained about Mr. Weprin’s principled vote in Albany to legalize gay marriage, which was anathema to many ultra-Orthodox Jewish voters.

headline: Can Old Dresses Help a Kenyan Dressmaker?
text: My Thursday column tells the story of Jane Ngoiri, a woman in Nairobi who has managed to transform her life – and her children’s – with some outside help. Originally, I thought I would write this column about microfinance, but as I followed Jane it became increasingly obvious that while her access to credit helped her start a business, the biggest help was the psychological push to save and start thinking about the future.

headline: Unconstitutional Policing
text: The Justice Department has issued a devastating report on the rampant corruption and constitutional violations committed by the Puerto Rico Police Department, the second-largest police force in the United States. It concluded that “lasting reform will require nothing less than federal judicial intervention.” And the sooner, the better.

headline: Bleak News on Health Insurance
text: Nearly one million more Americans went without health insurance in 2010 than in 2009. This distressing news is further evidence of the need for government safety net programs and the national health care reforms that will take effect mostly in 2014.

headline: Groupon Back on Track for Its I.P.O.

headline: In India, Online Retailers Take a New Tack
text: BANGALORE, India — Several months ago, when Prabhu Kumar could not find a book he wanted in bookstores here, he found it online at Amazon.com for $10. But he had to pay more than $9 in fees to have Amazon ship it to him.

headline: Help Needed for Student Debtors
text: New federal data showing a spike in student loan defaults does not simply reflect the bad economy, although that is a factor. A substantial part of the problem also lies in the fast-growing for-profit college industry, which accounts for only about 10 percent of students but nearly half of student loan defaults.

headline: Vatican Gives Group Reconciliation Path
text: The Vatican on Wednesday told a breakaway traditionalist group with which Pope Benedict XVI has taken pains to reconcile that it must accept certain church teachings before being fully brought back into the Roman Catholic Church. The Vatican’s chief doctrinal officer, Cardinal William J. Levada, met with Bishop Bernard Fellay of the Society of St. Pius X, which split with Rome to protest the liberalizing reforms of the Second Vatican Council. In 1988, Pope John Paul II excommunicated the group's founder, Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre, as well as four bishops he consecrated without the approval of the Vatican, including Bishop Fellay. In 2009, Benedict lifted the excommunications of the four bishops, even though one of them, Richard Williamson, had denied the scope of the Holocaust.

In addition to designing his own marvelous hats, he has provided headgear to a bunch of designers: Marc Jacobs, Rei Kawakubo, L’Wren Scott. When asked to organize a hat exhibition at the Victoria & Albert Museum in London, from its archives, even Mr. Jones was a little awed. “There were 4,000 hats in the drawers,” he said.

text: In the latest advance for health care accountability, the country’s leading hospital accreditation board, the Joint Commission, released a list on Tuesday of 405 medical centers that have been the most diligent in following protocols to treat conditions like heart attack and pneumonia. Almost without exception, most highly regarded hospitals in the United States, from Johns Hopkins in Baltimore to the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., did not make the list.

headline: The Bulgogi Slider Is a Delicious Curveball
text: There are three ways to make the recipe that follows here; three pathways to dinnertime nirvana. The dish is the Korean barbecue standard known as bulgogi — “fire meat,” is the literal translation — transformed into a sandwich filling, a sloppy Joe for a more perfect union. (File under “Blessings of Liberty.”) Fed to children with a tall glass of milk, the sandwiches may inspire smiles and licked plates, rapt attention and the request that the meal be served at least monthly — they are not at all too spicy for younger palates. Given to adults accompanied by cold lager, cucumber kimchi and a pot of the fermented Korean hot-pepper paste known as gochujang, they can rise to higher planes.

text: In advance of his yearly United Nations visit and media blitz, Iran’s president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, announced that two American hikers imprisoned in Iran since 2009 and sentenced to eight years for espionage, would be released imminently, my colleagues Alan Cowell and Rick Gladstone reported. But a day later, as David D. Kirkpatrick reported, Iranian courts rebuked Mr. Ahmadinejad, saying he did not have the authority to free the prisoners.

headline: Turkey: New Site for Missile Shield Plan
text: Turkey will locate an early-warning radar system, part of a new NATO shield against a missile attack in Europe, at a military base in the southeast, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said. The base lies about 375 miles west of Turkey’s border with Iran; American and NATO military officials have said the missile shield plan was designed to deter Iran. Iran has already expressed its opposition to Turkey’s decision to join the system.

headline: Sept. 15, 1963 | Birmingham Church Is Bombed by Klansmen
text: On Sept. 15, 1963, a bomb exploded before a Sunday morning sermon in the predominantly black 16th Street Baptist Church in Birmingham, Ala., killing four girls and injuring more than 20 others. The bombing incited violence in the city, which led to the killing of two black boys, one by a police officer.

headline: Unfurling a Life of Creative Exuberance
text: The Museum of Modern Art has never known quite what to do with Willem de Kooning. You can package Jackson Pollock as drips and Barnett Newman as zips, but de Kooning, who painted both opulent abstractions and big, blowsy dames, resists easy branding. So, apart from a show of late work in 1997, the museum has neglected him, until now.

headline: My Family’s Experiment in Extreme Schooling
text: The phone rang, and my stomach clenched when I heard her voice. “Daddy? I want to go home,” said my 8-year-old daughter, Arden. Two hours earlier, I dropped Arden and her two siblings off at their new school in a squat building in a forest of Soviet-era apartment blocks on Krasnoarmeyskaya (Red Army) Street in Moscow. They hugged me goodbye, clinging a little too long, and as I rode the metro to my office, I said a kind of silent prayer to myself that they would get through the day without falling apart.

headline: New Layers Amid the Song and Dance
text: THE theater director Michael Mayer faced deep skepticism in 1997 when he first proposed a radical plan to the literary executors for “On a Clear Day You Can See Forever,” a 1965 musical admired for its lush score but undercut by loopy story lines about ESP and reincarnation. Mr. Mayer wanted to rewrite the book and to transform its muddled romantic subplot into a love triangle full of dramatic and comic tension. His boldest idea: turning one of the central characters, a flighty woman named Daisy, into a gay florist named David. The gender switch was meant to throw impediments into the main narrative, about a male psychiatrist who hypnotizes Daisy/David and then falls in love with her/his past self, a woman named Melinda Wells.

headline: Bike Sharing vs. Sidewalk Sharing

Innovations tend to originate elsewhere, whether in education, mass transit, homelessness, health — or bicycles.

headline: Take Two: Polanski Plans Another Trip to Zurich Film Festival
text: Two years after his attempt to travel to the Zurich Film Festival resulted in his arrest in connection with a decades-old sex crime Roman Polanski will return to that festival to receive the lifetime achievement award he was to have received in 2009, Reuters reported. Mr. Polanski, the director of films including “Rosemary’s Baby,” “Chinatown” and “The Pianist” was arrested at the request of the United States when he arrived in 2009 at the Zurich airport en route to the festival. Prosecutors in Los Angeles and Washington were seeking to extradite the filmmaker, who fled the United States in 1978 to avoid facing punishment after he pleaded guilty one year earlier to having sex with a 13-year-old girl. Mr. Polanski spent several months under house arrest in Gstaad before Swiss prosecutors said they would not extradite him.

headline: Grandson Disputes New Play Attributed to Oscar Wilde
text: Perhaps there is something worse than being talked about, and that is having words attributed to you that you never wrote. At least, that’s the case being made by Merlin Holland, the grandson of Oscar Wilde, who says that a coming play promoted as a rediscovered Wilde text is not the handiwork of his illustrious grandfather, The Guardian reported.

headline: Just a Little Moonlighting on Broadway

On Broadway, where Mr. Jordan will soon spend his days rehearsing for the new musical “Bonnie & Clyde,” he is one of the outlaw lovers who terrorized and seduced East Texas during the hungry years of the Depression.

headline: Also Waiting in the Wings
text: There’s busy, and then there’s Theresa Rebeck busy. Besides being writer and executive producer of “Smash,” an NBC series about the making of a Broadway musical, Ms. Rebeck has three plays having premieres this season: “Poor Behavior,” a comedy about adultery now in previews at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles; “Seminar,” starring Alan Rickman and Lily Rabe, to open on Broadway in November; and “Dead Accounts,” which begins in January at the Cincinnati Playhouse in the Park. (Another play, “What We’re Up Against,” had its premiere in February and will be at Alley Theater in Houston in the spring.)

headline: ‘Z Is the First Letter of the Alphabet’
text: What goes on behind the walls of your children’s school is usually something of a mystery. You drop them off in the morning, they disappear inside, and perhaps at night you glean a few details from them about their day. But imagine receiving a trove of videos, hundreds of hours’ worth, that documented your children’s other life at school. And not just any school, but one in a foreign country, where they seemed miserable at first, then managed to cope and finally began to thrive.

headline: Familiar Faces Wear Classic Roles

New Yorkers may feel that this demented curser of the gods has been hanging out a lot in their neighborhood recently. You could even say he’s become sort of a cautionary fixture in this town, like that homeless guy on the corner who talks to space aliens and throws rotten fruit at passers-by.

Names of stars more familiarly splashed on movie trailers are glowing from marquees around the district. The London-to-Broadway express delivers its usual cargo of prestige attractions. New musicals based on popular movies cause devotees to lament the days when Broadway was not a recycling plant but a hotbed of cultural creativity.

headline: My Three Favorite Journeyman-Athlete Memoirs
text: The barrier for entry into the jock memoir genre is, unsurprisingly, pretty low. For every “Open” — Andre Agassi’s much-acclaimed, lovely autobiography — there are a dozen or so books like “Outrageous!,” the decidedly less literary reminiscences of Charles Barkley, in which the author famously claimed he was misquoted. Sure, ghostwriters have something to do with this, but at least “Outrageous!” was about Charles Barkley — a controversial N.B.A. Hall of Famer who played with and against some of the league’s all-time greats. What has always confounded me is the sheer number of ordinary, even journeyman athletes who cash in by documenting their rise to midlevel greatness between hard covers. But since so many of them do it, here are my favorites. (Intentionally missing is Jim Bouton’s totally awesome, gossip-laden “Ball Four.” Though Bouton was the definition of a mediocre player, he remains the Homer of the genre he created. Simply put, it’s not fair to compare him to anyone.)

headline: In Praise (Mostly) of Bike Trails
text: BARABOO, Wisc. — Cyclists revere bike trails; we don’t get too many signs from the world that we have a place in it, and bike trails, those routes on which you can get from one place to another on two wheels without the interference of motorized traffic, well, they tell us we belong on the great transportation grid that caters to the natural restlessness of humankind.

headline: Ralph Lauren: Everything in Its Place
text: Walking into Ralph Lauren’s runway shows in the Skylight Soho studios, where he has held them for the last several years, is like entering the set of a theater, where every detail is precisely placed. Actually, the industry veterans Stan Herman and Ellin Saltzman, on their way out of the show, were saying it was just like seeing a movie.

headline: Should You Automatically Reinvest Dividends?
text: As a long-term investor, I tend to automatically reinvest any dividends that my investments throw off: it allows you to put that money to work as soon as you can, without having to think about it. And as an added bonus, since you’re reinvesting those small drips of money over time, it would seem to help improve the odds that you’re not buying too heavily at market peaks.

headline: Seeing Things | Getting Hubbied
text: Her last name means partner or husband, and her parents have married and divorced each other more than once. So it’s no surprise that the Los Angeles artist Bettina Hubby is fascinated with the institution of matrimony. “Marriage is a big topic for me,” she said. “I was married and so were my parents, several times, and I wondered why marriage hasn’t changed or evolved the way other things have changed.” In 2009 she initiated Get Hubbied, a multitiered art project to investigate the idea of marriage, which she describes as both fragile and resilient. Hubby and the artist and musician Tif Sigfrids, who have been working together for the last four years, conducted intensive research into all aspects of marriage and the rituals surrounding the wedding ceremony.

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills 26 Funeral Mourners in Pakistan

A hospital official said he expected the death toll to rise.

headline: Famine Ravages Somalia in a World Less Likely to Intervene
text: DOLO, Somalia — Is the world about to watch 750,000 Somalis starve to death? The United Nations’ warnings could not be clearer. A drought-induced famine is steadily creeping across Somalia and tens of thousands of people have already died. The Islamist militant group the Shabab is blocking most aid agencies from accessing the areas it controls, and in the next few months three-quarters of a million people could run out of food, United Nations officials say.

headline: Watchlist: Alloy, Media Purveyor to Teenage Girls, Tries a Web Series
text: The continuing efforts of Alloy Entertainment to capture the attention of teenage girls, examined recently in Arts & Leisure, do not end with book series (“Sweet Valley High”), television shows (“The Vampire Diaries,” “Pretty Little Liars”) and movies (“Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants”). Its tentacles extend online, where a new Web series, “Wendy,” went up Thursday, an effort to distill the brand’s dreamy-schemey, supernaturally tinged formula into five-minute episodes. (The series is scheduled for six episodes; No. 2 goes up Tuesday.)

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Phillip Lim
text: On what’s supposed to be the last day of summer weather, a cool breeze was appropriately the inspiration for Odile Gilbert’s hair backstage at Phillip Lim. After coating strands with Kérastase Fibre Architecte, a yet to be released product that’s both a texturizer and a treatment conditioner, she parted straightened hair on the side and separated it into two low ponytails. These were then knotted at the neck and four little strands were pinned to the head as if blown back by a gust of wind. Perhaps in an allusion to the raincoats in the collection, nails were painted a custom blend of CND Raspberry Parfait, Guava and Speedy top coat. Francelle Daly for Nars created what she described as “dewy, fresh, skin” with Radiant Tinted Moisturizer intended to contrast “a edgy, heavy metallic eye.” Night Life shadow was applied in the crease to make a demi lune; underneath it, a hollow of bare skin. The silver Paris Duo was used along the eyebrow and Rue Bonaparte neutral liner in the duct. Not one but six coats of mascara were applied to lashes. “Romantic and rebel,” is how Daly explained this juxtaposition. Lips were covered in concealer and topped with Gaiete blush to create color in a fresh way. You know, these things change with the wind.

headline: Deportation Program Sows Mistrust, U.S. Is Told

headline: In Honduras, Land Struggles Highlight Post-Coup Polarization
text: TOCOA, Honduras — The settlement on the giant Marañones plantation looks like a refugee camp, where children play between rows of huts and chickens peck at garbage heaps. But the farmworkers living here plan to stay, laying claim to land owned by one of the country’s richest men.

headline: Percentage of New Yorkers Lighting Up Is Down, to 14%
text: The number of New Yorkers who smoke has declined 35 percent since 2002, bringing the adult smoking rate to what city officials said was an all-time low of 14 percent, the lowest level since they started tracking the habit, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced Thursday.

headline: Video of Medal of Honor Presentation
text: President Obama is awarding Marine Cpl. Dakota Meyer the U.S. Medal of Honor for his valor during a 2009 battle in Afghanistan’s Kunar Province. Corporal Meyer, 23, is credited with saving the lives of 36 Marines and soldiers — 13 Americans and 23 Afghans, when he charged repeatedly into a Taliban-held area after learning that four American military personnel — three fellow Marines and a Navy corpsman — were missing. Corporal Meyer came under heavy fire, but located and retrieved his fallen comrades from the battlefield with the help of a Afghan troops. He is only the third living veteran to receive the award for service in Afghanistan or Iraq and the first living Marine to receive the award since 1973.

headline: Nick Broomfield’s Alaska
text: TORONTO —The documentary style of the English director Nick Broomfield often puts him at the center of the action, making films that focus on the process of creating a documentary as well as the films’ subjects. In his new film, “Sarah Palin: You Betcha!”, he sets his sights on Ms. Palin, the former governor of Alaska, and travels to her hometown of Wasilla to interview her friends and family. Mr. Broomfield spoke about why he chose Ms. Palin as a subject and elaborates on his technique.

headline: 36 Hours in Quito, Ecuador
text: NESTLED amid snowcapped Andean peaks, Ecuador’s capital has long been overlooked by travelers on their way to the country’s most famous destination, the Galápagos Islands. But visitors who bypass this lively historic city of some two million people are missing out. At 9,350 feet above sea level, on the eastern slopes of the Pichincha Volcano, Quito offers breathtaking vistas around nearly every corner. Its historic center, a Unesco World Heritage site, is one of the largest in South America, with 40 colonial churches and chapels, 16 convents and monasteries and picturesque plazas. In recent years, museums have been opened; mansions restored; hotels, restaurants and cafes opened and safety improved. And this year, in recognition of Quito’s rich mix of architectural heritage and cultural traditions, the International Cultural Capitals Bureau chose the city as its 2011 American Capital of Culture.

headline: Clorox Puts Focus on ‘Bleachable Moments’

headline: Steel Tycoon With Links to a Mubarak Is Sentenced
text: CAIRO — An Egyptian criminal court sentenced the steel tycoon and former political power broker Ahmed Ezz to 10 years in prison and fined him the equivalent of about $11 million for corruption on Thursday, satisfying one of the most visceral demands of the revolution that toppled President Hosni Mubarak.

headline: Will Obama ‘QuickPay’ Policy Mean Billions to Small Businesses?
text: On Wednesday, the White House made good on President Obama’s pledge, in his jobs speech to Congress last week, to speed up government payments to small-business contractors. The new policy, which has its own product-like branding, QuickPay, reduces the government’s payment time from 30 days after receiving an invoice to 15 days. In a statement, Karen Mills, Small Business Administration administrator, lauded the new policy: “QuickPay is a smart and powerful boost that effectively delivers billions more dollars into the hands of small contractors so that they can do what they do best — create jobs.”

headline: Brooklyn Becomes Book Country Again

Pete Hamill and Jennifer Egan, both of Brooklyn, talked about their literary inspirations. Dramatic readings from the work of legendary Brooklyn writers were staged in a plaza outside Borough Hall. This year, the festival’s sixth, it remains centered in the same pocket of downtown Brooklyn. But its borders have spread far beyond.

In the third of five weekly installments they discuss Batwoman, Green Lantern, Red Lanterns and others that were published on Wednesday. Next week they’ll look at Wonder Woman, Batman and more.

headline: Steuben Glass Factory and Store to Close
text: For decades, they have solved the riddle of what to give those who seem to have everything. Pieces of Steuben glass, those quintessential samples of American artisanship, have proved suitable for queens and presidents, brides and retiring executives.

headline: Metro-North’s Port Jervis Line Slowly Returns
text: Metro-North Railroad is restoring parts of the Port Jervis train line faster than expected after 14 miles of tracks were uprooted and wiped out by Tropical Storm Irene.

headline: An Escape to the ‘Tropics’ in the City
text: THE Lower East Side has more than its share of cross-cultural mash-ups, but few surpass Tropical 128, a combination pool hall and tiki bar. A first visit can be a little disorienting, with or without one of its potent cocktails, as Chinese lanterns compete for attention with the clack of billiard balls. Watch your step or you might fall into the koi pond.

headline: Frederick Hammersley: ‘Organic and Geometric’
text: Ameringer McEnery Yohe

headline: ‘Driving Home’
text: In the spring of 1990 I packed up as much of my life in London as would ﬁt into a suitcase and four large plywood boxes and ﬂew to Seattle to set up house. It was a selﬁsh and irregular move. I had “met someone” and liked what I’d seen of the Paciﬁc Northwest during a two-month stay there the previous autumn. I liked the aquarium lighting, the sawtooth alps forested with black ﬁrs, the compact cities encrusted in dirty Roman esque stucco. Most of all, I liked the place’s wateriness. At forty-seven I felt cracked and dry. My new home territory was as rainy as Ireland, puddled with lakes and veined with big rivers. Seattle was built out on pilings over the sea, and at high tide the whole city seemed to come aﬂoat like a ship lifting free from a mud berth and swaying in its chains.

headline: Some for the Road: The Odds and Ends From a Traveler’s Tales
text: Given its title, some readers will pick up Jonathan Raban’s new book, “Driving Home: An American Journey,” and assume that it’s among his excellent travel volumes, like “Bad Land” and “Passage to Juneau.” They may be distressed to find instead that it’s a collection of B sides, odds and ends, acoustic versions and rarities: book reviews, leftish political essays, introductions to reissued classics and meditations on seafaring and on Seattle, where this British writer has lived since 1990. It’s prose mostly cooked to order.

headline: Thinking Pink at Milly
text: While some designers went for soft beauty looks this season — including BCBG, Diane Von Furstenberg and Reed Krakoff — Michelle Smith, the designer for Milly, chose color. In an interview backstage, she described her collection as young and fresh (as well as other marketable keywords). Romy Soleimani of the MAC Pro Team created a bright pink lipstick to accompany the geometric prints in the collection. She mixed MAC’s white and fuchsia lip color. From a distance, the pink looks very similar to the popular matte summer pink that a lot of women, especially young women, have been wearing the last few seasons. But close up, the pink has more of an opaque base and looks like a mix of Pepto-Bismol and neon pinks.

text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#538", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);Kava Gorna’s New York fashion week photo diary.

text: The Twitter universe was alive on Thursday with words, news, whispers … no, a tweet that the German-American defender Timmy Chandler could be about to slip through the fingers of Jurgen Klinsmann and the U.S. national team.

text: Scrooge and the Grinch would come across as hopelessly mushy about holiday traditions compared with the debunking exhibition catalog for “American Christmas Cards, 1900-1960,” which opens on Wednesday at the Bard Graduate Center: Decorative Arts, Design History, Material Culture in Manhattan.

headline: Backstage Beauty at Milly Spring 2012
text: Hot pink lips and orange nails hit the spring 2012 Milly runway.

headline: Calvin Klein: X-Ray Vision
text: The celebrities on the front row at Calvin Klein wore dresses in solid colors that looked covered up. Uma Thurman (in blue), Lara Stone (in red) and Naomi Watts (in gray) were three of a kind.

headline: Creamy Curried Celery Root Soup
text: Mark Bittman uses an unusual root vegetable in a delicious creamy soup.

headline: The Minimalist: Creamy Curried Celery Root Soup
text: Hulking, bristly, bulgy, khaki-colored celery root (also known as celeriac) isn’t going to win any beauty contests. When you see one, you instantly understand why the stalks are more popular.

headline: City Unemployment Rate Ticks Up to 8.7%
text: The two-week strike by unionized employees of Verizon offset all of the hiring that occurred last month in New York City and pushed the city’s unemployment rate up slightly, according to figures released Thursday by the State Department of Labor.

headline: ‘Berlin 36’
text: Tasteful to a fault, “Berlin 36” turns real-life controversy into disappointingly tepid drama.

headline: Obama Administration Removes Doctor Disciplinary Files From the Web
text: Three journalism organizations on Thursday protested to the Obama administration a decision to pull a database of physician discipline and malpractice actions off the Web.

headline: ‘Prince of Swine’
text: Unpleasant in every way imaginable, Mark Toma’s “Prince of Swine,” a repulsive farce about sexual harassment in the double-D-movie industry, opens, hilariously, with a quotation from “The Odyssey.” But not even Homer can elevate this ugly ode to our basest instincts, a film so drenched in bile and profanity there is little room for anything else.

headline: Mosaics of the East From the Met to San Francisco
text: THE big institutional news in New York City this fall is the reopening, after eight years of renovation and rethinking, of the Metropolitan Museum’s Islamic collection, in what are now being called the Galleries for the Art of the Arab Lands, Turkey, Iran, Central Asia and Later South Asia. The wrap-around suite of 15 spaces, which opens on Nov. 1, will hold some 1,200 works (out of a collection of 12,000) from dozens of cultures that have, during 13 centuries, shared Islam as a religious faith.

headline: For Spectacle’s Sake, Museums Get Specific
text: THE offerings from New York museums this fall vary widely, from the much-heralded de Kooning retrospective opening Sunday at the Museum of Modern Art to “Hide/Seek: Difference and Desire in American Portraiture,” a survey of the role of sexual identity in a century’s worth of American art that will arrive at the Brooklyn Museum after its controversial run at the National Portrait Gallery in Washington. But right down the center some of New York’s major museums promise a fair amount of high-production-value Conceptual-art spectacle.

headline: ‘Shut Up Little Man!’
text: Matthew Bate’s “Shut Up Little Man!” is a dandy little documentary whether you view the story it captures as a precursor to the flash fame of the Internet age or as one of the last genuine underground phenomena before the Internet made that whole concept obsolete.

headline: Spare Times for Sept. 16-22
text: Around Town

headline: Mockery, Alive and Well Through the Ages
text: It is not nice to make fun of other people, but it is hard to resist. There is even a genre of art devoted to this often uncharitable impulse of human nature: caricature. Fine and popular artists have been producing comical, grotesque and weird images of people at least since the days of Leonardo da Vinci.

headline: ‘The Weird World of Blowfly’
text: Outside of the recording industry or a convention of pop-music connoisseurs, you’re not likely to hear anyone name-check Clarence Reid, a 66-year-old songwriter whose funk-and-R&B-heavy back catalog has been sampled by the likes of Beyoncé, Puff Daddy and the Jurassic 5.

headline: Spare Times: For Children, for Sept. 16-22

headline: ‘Jane’s Journey’
text: This breezy biographical profile of Jane Goodall, the primatologist and “rock star” of conservationism, as one environmentalist introduces her, skimps on intellectual substance but skirts by on the lightly likable charm of its subject, who appears throughout.

headline: Home Prices Are Down, but Rentals Are Rising
text: The housing market is gasping for air, and home prices are down to 2003 levels, according to the S&P/Case-Shiller Home Price Indices.

headline: ‘Silent Souls’
text: Sex and death are inextricably entwined in “Silent Souls,” a melancholy poem to love, loss and the tug of tradition.

headline: Bedrooms for 2, Dinner for 6 Guests
text: AFTER three years of sharing a two-bedroom rental on West 99th Street, Tamar Fox and her two roommates were fed up with their building’s bad maintenance. They decided to go their separate ways.

headline: ‘My Afternoons With Margueritte’
text: Drearily sentimental, Jean Becker’s “My Afternoons With Margueritte” is the chaste love story between a genial, unlettered lug of a working man (Gérard Depardieu in unflattering blue overalls) and an older woman he meets on a park bench in a town in the Charente-Maritime region of France. She reads to him (Camus, Romain Gary). He blossoms.

headline: ‘One Fall’
text: “One Fall,” a star vehicle Marcus Dean Fuller created for himself, starts out with an intriguing premise but grows muddier as it grows more mystical.

headline: Roughed Up by Horses
text: WEST 83rd Street between Columbus and Amsterdam is a “Sesame Street” kind of block, with stoops, horses’ heads, brownstones, apartment houses by McKim, Mead & White, rent-a-car places, and Jerry Seinfeld’s garage. Everybody seems to be in a hurry here, and that means it is just the place for a leisurely late-summer saunter.

headline: New Evidence for an Apple a Day
text: The old adage promoting an apple a day for better health just got a boost from science. A large Dutch study has found that eating apples and pears is associated with a lower risk of stroke.

headline: A Stormy Housewarming
text: JENNIFER TAUBER and her husband, Hayes, closed on their new home in New Canaan on Aug. 24 — just in time for Tropical Storm Irene.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Yigal Azrouël
text: “While I was inspired by architecture and the idea of uniforms, I designed these clothes to feel more relaxed, almost effortless,” Yigal Azrouël said of his collection backstage. “Think sophistication in structure.” This translated into a look the hairstylist Anthony Campbell called “a reverse mohawk.” After dampening hair with Cutler Specialist Protectant Treatment Spray, Campbell gathered a healthy “horseshoe section” from the top and pulled it forward, using a flat brush and dryer. The sides were then pressed down with fingers. Campbell finished styles by showering hair with Redken Shine Flash 02 Glistening Mist and Cutler Shine Tattoo for an extreme, wet-looking finish. The makeup artist Yadim kept things aglow by moisturizing with Sisleÿum Global Revitalizer for Men, then tapping Sisley Radiant Immediate Lift on the high planes of the face to highlight. Phyto-Ombre Eclat Eye Shadow in Quartz was smudged on upper and lower lash lines “to enhance tone, like the boys have been out all night.” Yadim said. And just minutes before the show, Yadim slicked Confort Creme Lip Balm on lips and eyelids to complete “a face that looks as it’s been flooded in light.”

headline: The cultural impact and staying power of Nirvana’s “Nevermind” 20 years after its release; and new records by Daniela Mercury and Gilad Hekselman.
text: This week: Jon Pareles and Ben Ratliff assess the cultural impact and staying power of Nirvana’s “Nevermind” 20 years after its release; and we take a listen to new records by Daniela Mercury and Gilad Hekselman. Ben Ratliff is the host.

headline: Storm Left Some Buyers in the Dark
text: JENNY GRAHAM BRUGO stayed up all night when Tropical Storm Irene swooshed across Long Island a few weeks ago, hoping the two giant pine trees in front of the four-bedroom Cape she was about to buy for $380,000 in Locust Valley would not fall.

text: HOMEOWNERS looking to refinance their mortgage will need to compare interest rates, loan terms and fees, but some who live in New York may also want to arrange for what’s known as a mortgage assignment, when the balance on the loan is transferred to the new lender from the old.

headline: ‘Back Door Channels: The Price of Peace’
text: Having just commemorated the 10th anniversary of the terrorist attacks, another, more hopeful, September anniversary on Saturday is likely to draw no comment. On Sept. 17, 1978, after 13 days of negotiations at Camp David, President Jimmy Carter brought President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt and Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel to the White House to sign an accord to end the state of war between their two countries.

Customers of the store, Sound It Out, would all feel quite at home at Championship Vinyl.
