headline: App Smart Extra: More Kids Apps
text: Last week’s App Smart column offers a few strategies for overcoming a week without power in a house full of children.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Proenza Schouler
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.The shoes at Proenza Schouler were like an ode to midcentury furniture design — a glossy, painted-stripe platform with clean, curvy lines and a rubbery stopper for a heel. Alternate versions of the theme came in colors (red and turquoise) and with platforms carved to look like oak, then lacquered black most modernly.

headline: Trendspotting: Hemlines
text: Longer hemlines are making a comeback at spring 2012 show.

headline: A Stable Hemline
text: After vacillating for several seasons, an influential band of Seventh Avenue taste makers settled on a length for day that was fresh, youthful and, at times, even disarmingly sexy. Forsaking the fashion schizophrenia that led in past seasons to thigh-high skirts that alternated randomly with versions that plunged to the floor, designers like Derek Lam, Ralph Lauren and Francisco Costa of Calvin Klein put their money on hemlines ending just below the knees. Loosely cut and flattering, they showed off the models’ calves and offered flirty glimpses of the area just behind their knees.

headline: Mets Conclude a Humiliating Homestand
text: As the Mets played out the last innings of an abysmal homestand on Thursday, the stands were virtually empty, the players seemed to be going through the motions and Manager Terry Collins was just getting started.

headline: A Short Life and Its Consequences
text: Leah Hager Cohen is one of our foremost chroniclers of the mundane complexities, nuanced tragedies and unexpected tendernesses of human connection. She earned her reputation with heralded books of nonfiction like “Train Go Sorry” and the novel “House Lights.” Impressively, her fourth novel, “The Grief of Others,” is her best work yet. Six complex but fundamentally decent characters hurt one another and are hurt by forces greater than themselves, whether those forces be the impersonal cruelty of nature’s accidents or the very personal torments of marriage and middle school. The overarching question is whether the members of the Ryrie family will piece themselves together and re-find who they all were during a halcyon vacation eight years past, or whether they will let sorrow, secrets and shame drive them irreparably apart.

headline: Real World Quileutes Lobby for Their Land
text: Twilight fans, take heart. Jacob Black’s cousins finally got their day before Congress on Thursday.

headline: The TV Watch: An ‘A’ for Effort on Emmy Night
text: Emmy Awards don’t factor in the degree of difficulty, but they should. It’s at least one way to choose between equally good performances.

headline: Seeking Reality on Climate
text: 7:02 p.m. | Updated Former Vice President Al Gore and organizers of the Climate Reality Project should be commended for building a worldwide forum on human-driven climate change over the past 24 hours. I’ve had a chance to dip in a few times and there were some useful discussions amid more predictable efforts to cast the climate challenge as an us-versus-them problem (to my mind it’s much more an us-versus-us problem). The organizers reported more than 6 million views as of late afternoon.

headline: Papa’s Damn Good Pictures
text: ERNEST HEMINGWAY the hunter, Hemingway the fisherman, Hemingway the drinker — they’re all part of the legend. Among the motifs in “The Select,” the Elevator Repair Service staging of “The Sun Also Rises,” currently at the New York Theater Workshop, is an inside joke about how much imbibing takes place in that book.

headline: N.Y.U. Relents a Bit on Acquiring Parkland Near Planned Housing
text: New York University, trying to placate critics of it plans to build more dormitories and offices in Greenwich Village, announced on Thursday that it would not seek to purchase two park-like strips of land bordering two giant housing complexes.

headline: Fasten Your Seat Belts, the Chevy Is Taking Off
text: A long time ago, as a young filmmaker besotted with the hard-boiled pleasures of classic Hollywood, Jean-Luc Godard claimed that all anyone needed to make a film was a girl and a gun. In his new movie, “Drive,” Nicolas Winding Refn, in thrall to a later Hollywood tradition, tests out a slightly different formula. In this case all you need is a guy and a car.

headline: A Painting That Begat a Whole Show
text: Kehinde Wiley, 34, is an artist preoccupied with global culture. He is also a history painter whose multicultural images of primarily good-looking men recall the work of old masters like Rubens and Jacques-Louis David. The lush and intricately painted backgrounds make them more interesting still.

headline: Apple Brings Back Final Cut 7
text: When Apple replaced its movie-editing software Final Cut 7 with Final Cut Pro X, the pros were outraged.

headline: Photos of the Moment | L’Wren Scott
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#938", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);Skye Parrott’s New York fashion week photo diary.

headline: His Credit Cards and Fancy Words Can’t Help Him Here
text: “Straw Dogs” — Rod Lurie’s odd and interesting remake of Sam Peckinpah’s venerable and violent button pusher — begins with a clash of cultural stereotypes. David Sumner (James Marsden) is a Hollywood screenwriter with an Ivy League education (or at least a Harvard T-shirt and fond memories of the Harvard-Yale game), newly arrived in his wife’s hometown, Blackwater, Miss. He is an effete coastal liberal, the kind of person who orders light beer at the local bar and grill, disdains its celebrated fried pickles and tries to pay with a credit card. He listens to classical music, uses big words like “acutely” and stays in shape by jumping rope. He can’t fix a roof or change a tire.

headline: Top Medal for Marine Who Saved Many Lives
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama awarded the Medal of Honor on Thursday to a young former Marine who ignored orders to stay put and fought his way five times into an ambush in an Afghan ravine, helping to rescue three dozen Afghan and American troops and to recover the remains of four dead American servicemen.

headline: This Cheating Couple Have a Lot in Common
text: Tom Tykwer’s “3,” a forbiddingly sober and sophisticated comedy of adultery and sexual experimentation, is unburdened by the usual emotional markers found in films whose characters push conventional boundaries. Hanna (Sophie Rois) and Simon (Sebastian Schipper), who have lived together for 20 years and who separately embark on an affair with the same man, are childless hard-working Berliners in their 40s.

headline: Goldman Sachs to Shut Its Global Alpha Hedge Fund
text: Goldman Sachs is closing Global Alpha, one of its best-known hedge funds, after it rung up big losses this year.

headline: A Founder’s at Home
text: When you look at Alexander Hamilton’s home comfortably nestled on the sloping hillside of St. Nicholas Park in an area of northern Manhattan that has long been known as Hamilton Heights, it almost seems to be ... well ... at home.

headline: Reputation and Monolith, Both Stand Tall
text: GARDENA, Calif.

headline: Showing It All in Toronto
text: TORONTO — Having muscled its way forward with ambition and mountains of money, the Toronto International Film Festival stands supreme as the leading cinema event after Cannes. This year’s event was the first time that the Bell Lightbox, the festival’s permanent home here, was fully operational. For much of the festival’s 11 days (it ends on Sunday), the five public theaters of the Lightbox are a home away from home for locals and globe-trotting professionals who also make camp in adjacent theaters, including a 14-screen multiplex with its own Burger King. They do things big here: more than 300 movies on 33 screens for admissions that, last year, topped a quarter-million.

headline: The Future, Retrenched
text: WHAT may be the biggest architecture event of the year ahead has not yet been scheduled. But when it happens, it’ll be a doozy: MGM Resorts International recently announced its intention to demolish the Harmon, a tower by Norman Foster that is a prominent component of the new CityCenter development in Las Vegas. Construction flaws were found years ago, and the building was never completed or occupied. Still, the spectacle of a boom-time project by one of the world’s most celebrated designers razed by a controlled implosion is sure to spark talk about the state of architecture today.

headline: Altering Landscapes for Art
text: ON paper it resembles a subplot from David Foster Wallace’s deliriously satiric novel “Infinite Jest”: a billionaire heiress builds a spectacular art museum on family property somewhere in the Deep South and gives it the suspiciously New-Agey name Crystal Bridges. But this is nonfiction. On Nov. 11 Alice Walton, daughter of Wal-Mart founder Sam Walton, will unveil the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art in the small city of Bentonville, Ark.

headline: RIM Suffers as Profit Falls 58.7%
text: OTTAWA — The BlackBerry maker Research in Motion delivered more grim financial news on Thursday that caused some analysts to question the future of RIM, the company that created and once dominated the smartphone market.

headline: Theater Listings: Sept. 16 — 22
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information: nytimes.com/theater.

headline: An Escape to the ‘Tropics’ in the City
text: The Lower East Side has more than its share of cross-cultural mash-ups, but few surpass Tropical 128, a combination pool hall and tiki bar. A first visit can be a little disorienting, with or without one of its potent cocktails, as Chinese lanterns compete for attention with the clack of billiard balls. Watch your step or you might fall into the koi pond.

headline: She’s Dying Gracefully, and It’s Killing Him
text: The story of a dying girl and the morbid young man who loves her, “Restless” rolls Elisabeth Kübler-Ross’s five stages of dying into a single, dreamy state of feeling. It is hard to say, though, if this film, directed by Gus Van Sant from a script by Jason Lew, is an argument for denial or a treatise on acceptance. Curiously, and in a way that is sometimes touching and sometimes icky, it does not seem to perceive much of a difference.

headline: Rick Ludwin to Leave Late Night Post at NBC
text: One of the longest-serving network television executives, Rick Ludwin, is leaving his job as the top overseer of all NBC’s late-night programs.

headline: The Schumacher Debate Considered
text: Since the Italian Grand Prix in Monza on Sunday, Michael Schumacher has been at the center of a debate about his driving tactics. As I wrote in my final race report, I thought the Schumacher/Lewis Hamilton battle made the race worth watching.

headline: The Schumacher Debate Considered
text: Since the Italian Grand Prix in Monza on Sunday, Michael Schumacher has been at the center of a debate about his driving tactics. As I wrote in my final race report, I thought the Schumacher/Lewis Hamilton battle made the race worth watching.

headline: Even a Things-to-Do List Seems to Be Multitasking
text: The curse of Carrie Bradshaw infects “I Don’t Know How She Does It” with a severe case of what might be called post-Carrie Parkeritis. Parkeritis, if you haven’t heard, is the term given to a new ailment named after Sarah Jessica Parker, in which a star finds herself condemned to eke out the last drops of freshness from the role (in this case in “Sex and the City”) that made her world famous eons ago. In its chemical structure it closely resembles the Roberts Syndrome (as in Julia), first identified in “Pretty Woman” and last seen in “Larry Crowne.”

headline: Plenty of Chatter About a New iPhone
text: We’re just weeks away from the announcement of the new Apple iPhone 5, according to an Apple employee who asked not to be named because he was not allowed to speak publicly for the company.

headline: Six-Year Extension for Isles’ Tavares
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — John Tavares said Thursday that he had signed a six-year contract extension with the Islanders, ending speculation that he would return to his native Toronto in the next couple of seasons.

headline: Hemingway the Museumgoer
text: When in New York, Ernest Hemingway was as likely to visit the Metropolitan Museum as Toots Shor’s.

headline: Ruling May Jeopardize ‘Dolphin Safe’ Label
text: A ruling on Thursday by the World Trade Organization could imperil “dolphin safe” labeling on tuna in the United States.

headline: Where Banks Proliferate, So Do Rules
text: The more banks a country has, the less political power they have.

headline: A Veneer to Hide Crumbling Poise
text: The title of “Happy, Happy,” the debut feature of the Norwegian director Anne Sewitsky, presumably refers to the facade of garrulous cheer thrown up by its obsequious central character, Kaja (Agnes Kittelsen). A schoolteacher who lives in the snowy countryside with her glowering husband, Eirik (Joachim Rafaelsen), and young son, Theodor (Oskar Hernaes Brandso), Kaja is compulsively chipper until the moment her composure crumbles, and she collapses in tears.

headline: Requiem’s Premiere Is Conductor’s Farewell
text: Kent Tritle devoted the opening of the 23rd season of the Sacred Music in a Sacred Space series at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola to the New York premiere of Juraj Filas’s grandly scaled requiem “Oratio Spei” (“Prayer of Hope”) on Wednesday evening. Technically, the work is not a response to the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, but it has a connection that makes it a fitting commemoration.

headline: Long-Term Stock Plans Help to Avoid Impulsive Moves
text: JUST as you caught your breath after the stock market mayhem of 2008 and 2009, it has become increasingly clear that this ride isn’t over just yet.

headline: British Dubstep Singer Crosses the Pond, Leaving the D.J. for a Band
text: “I haven’t played a little venue in a while,” Katy B said from the little stage in the little room that is the Studio at Webster Hall on Tuesday night. “I’ve just been playing muddy fields in England.”

headline: Who Should Win Emmy Awards
text: Alessandra Stanley’s picks.

headline: The World Maker Faire in Queens Draws Inventors
text: As a Brooklyn resident in my 30s, I am required, by local social standards, to be able to hold my own with do-it-yourself projects. At the very least, I can brew a little craft beer and cross-stitch heavy-metal lyrics onto throw pillows. But soldering a 70-foot steel dragon onto the frame of a 1963 Dodge dump truck and turning it into an interactive kinetic playground? I’ll leave that to the do-or-die DIY-ers gathering in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens this weekend for  the World Maker Faire.

headline: Moody’s May Downgrade UBS After Trading Loss
text: Moody’s Investors Service said late Thursday that it might downgrade UBS‘s credit rating, after the Swiss bank disclosed that a London-based trader lost about $2 billion in a series of unauthorized trades.

headline: Perry Repeats Socialist Charge Against Obama Policies
text: In an interview with Time magazine, Gov. Rick Perry showed that he had no intention of softening the cactus-thorned rhetoric he developed during his decades in Texas politics, notably repeating his characterization of President Obama’s policies as “socialist.”

headline: U.S. Hails Deal With Turkey on Missile Shield
text: WASHINGTON — The final legal and diplomatic building blocks fell into place this week for the Obama administration’s rejiggered defense of Europe against a potential Iranian missile attack. Romania signed a deal for 24 interceptor missiles to be based there, and Turkey officially agreed to have in its territory a sophisticated American radar system that could be on the watch by the end of the year.

headline: For a Day, It’s All Good
text: Wednesday was a double-bonus day with outstanding shows from Ralph Rucci and Proenza Schouler. The next morning, Ralph Lauren concocted one of his romances out of straw picnic purses and robin’s egg blue, ending it with a gown as triumphant as the Chrysler Building.

headline: With Stakes for Bachmann Higher Now, Her Words Get in the Way
text: In the pugilism of this week’s Republican presidential debate, Representative Michele Bachmann seemed to have landed a clean blow against Gov. Rick Perry over an order he issued requiring Texas schoolgirls to be vaccinated against a sexually transmitted virus.

headline: New York Fashion Week
text: Eric Wilson highlights the season's emerging trends.

headline: Teaching as a Second, or Even Third, Career
text: AT 65, Walt Patteson has two careers behind him and is relishing his third as a high school chemistry teacher. He is one of the retirement-age Americans who are finding new uses for their skills by deciding to teach.

headline: Walter Bonatti, Daring Italian Mountaineer, Dies at 81
text: Walter Bonatti, one of the world’s greatest mountaineers, who pioneered some of the most difficult and breathtaking climbs on the earth’s tallest mountains, often alone, died Tuesday in Rome. He was 81.

headline: The Moral Values of America’s Youth
text: To the Editor:

headline: TimesCast | Cameron & Sarkozy in Tripoli
text: September 15, 2011 - British and French leaders visit Tripoli to meet with the new Libyan leaders.

headline: China Consolidates Grip on Rare Earths
text: BEIJING — In the name of fighting pollution, China has sent the price of compact fluorescent light bulbs soaring in the United States.

headline: Keeping Themselves Fit for Going to the Rescue
text: THIS weekend, the last of the lifeguards still on duty at two of Long Island’s largest public beaches — Jones Beach and Robert Moses State Park — will climb down from the stands and lock up their shacks for the winter.

headline: A Two-Step Plan That Strengthens Your Nest Egg
text: BY now, you may have accepted, with grim reluctance, that you must delay taking your retirement benefits.

headline: Fine-Tune a 401(k) or I.R.A., and Cut Costs
text: YOU have to dig deep into your retirement accounts to find out how to optimize their performance and bolster your nest egg.

headline: In Annuities, Better Rates Come With Complexity
text: IF you’re unhappy with the wretchedly low rates that many savings vehicles offer today, imagine how you would feel earning meager income until the day you die. If you recently began collecting on a fixed-rate annuity, you don’t need much imagination.

headline: The Risks of Investing Like the Big Pension Funds
text: OVER the last several years, the managers of many big, traditional pension plans have become increasingly cautious. Instead of viewing high returns as their top priority, these managers have focused on avoiding risk. Some have shifted assets from stocks to bonds, while others have changed the way they analyze their investments or hired special risk officers. An old investment strategy called liability-driven investing has been revived, in which pension plans buy a series of bonds with maturity dates timed to match the years when cohorts of employees are expected to retire.

headline: The Dividend as a Bulwark Against Global Economic Uncertainty
text: DESPITE the gyrations in the stock market this year, one sweet spot has been dividends. These cash payments from mature, profitable companies have been a welcome addition to retirement portfolios.

headline: The Company You Keep
text: ONE of the biggest challenges of relocating after retirement is making new acquaintances.

headline: Staying Fit to Stay on the Job
text: Older people in need of inspiration to stay fit as they age might consider the example of lifeguards. Facing a tough physical test each spring, they train hard in the off-season — and keep their jobs well past the age of 50.

headline: Coming Together to Make Aging a Little Easier
text: LAST summer, Shoya Zichy was about to drop off a prescription at a friend’s house when she tripped and dislocated her elbow in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: ‘Contagion’ Puts a Focus on Infectious Diseases
text: To the Editor:

headline: City Hands Off Part of Teacher Evaluation Effort to the State
text: New York City education officials announced Thursday that they would end their effort to rank teachers based on their students’ standardized test scores, adding a surprise twist to one of the most contentious issues facing the city’s teaching force.

headline: The Israeli Embassy View: Don’t Blame Netanyahu
text: To the Editor:

headline: Beneath the Hoodie, the Many Layers of Belichick
text: The public personality that Bill Belichick presents is a shield of his own making. That grim coach in the hoodie, that somber football genius, that unrevealing news conference speaker — all of it is what he wants outsiders to see. Those who know him are aware of a man with a depth of emotion and a sense of humor, but he has kept those in reserve as if revealing them would cause him to lose his soul.

headline: Brain Stent Trial: The Investigators’ View
text: To the Editor:

headline: France: Time Limits on Begging
text: In an enhanced campaign against petty crime and criminality, the government of President Nicolas Sarkozy has banned begging for the next six months on the famous Avenue des Champs-Élysées from 10 a.m. to 10 p.m., as well as prayers in the streets outside crowded mosques, according to Interior Minister Claude Guéant. Mr. Guéant has offered Muslims a large, unused barracks for a prayer space. He also announced a renewed crackdown on non-French Roma who overstay their visas, saying that delinquent minors will be deported.

headline: Bipartisanship of the Wrong Kind
text: As soon as he proposed to pay for his $447 billion jobs plan with tax increases, President Obama knew he was going to do battle with Republicans. But he is also being challenged by Democrats because they cannot face another big pre-election fight or are thinking more about campaign contributors than the country’s best interests.

headline: Negotiations Continue Over U.S. Hikers
text: The Iraqi president has been negotiating with Iranian officials in an attempt to gain the release of two American hikers held in Iran on espionage and trespassing convictions, according to Kurdish officials in Iraq. The president, Jalal Talabani, has been told by Iranian officials that the hikers will probably be released, the officials said. Iran’s president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, had said that the hikers, Shane M. Bauer and Joshua F. Fattal, would be freed by Thursday, but Iran’s judiciary ruled otherwise. The conflicting messages are believed to reflect a power struggle between Mr. Ahmadinejad and Iran’s conservative establishment. Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said Thursday the United States had “received word through a number of sources” that the men would be released, despite the apparent confusion in Iran.

headline: Good Time for Yanks’ Very Rare Day Off
text: The Yankees spent their last off day of the regular season resting in Toronto for the final push toward the playoffs. The precious day of rest was their first since Aug. 22, not counting the 24 hours they spent closeted in their Baltimore hotel rooms five days later because of Hurricane Irene.

headline: Spagnuolo, Giants’ Monday Night Foe, Is Still a Friend
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Steve Spagnuolo has had more important things to worry about than crossing paths again with Tom Coughlin, his old boss, on “Monday Night Football.” Spagnuolo’s St. Louis Rams are pretty banged up, too.

headline: Yemen: Fear as Fighting Resumes
text: Violence escalated across the country on Thursday as the government shelled a volatile neighborhood in the capital, Sana, and security forces fired on antigovernment protesters in Taiz, killing a 21-year-old man. Three civilians were killed early Thursday morning by mortar fire after fighting broke out in northern Sana, according to an employee inside a compound that had come under attack. The clashes brought fears that despite a cease-fire brokered in June, war has ignited again between the government and the Ahmars, tribal leaders who are accused of fomenting protests by Yemen’s government.

headline: Customers Angry Over Revamped Pricing Are Deserting Netflix
text: Some of Netflix’s popularity lies in its simplicity — in its ability to serve up films and TV shows and renew subscriptions automatically, without any thinking on the part of the customer.

headline: Morgan Executive Fits a Choir Robe Beneath Her Pinstripes
text: Wall Street banks are not known as particularly religious workplaces. But Carla A. Harris, a managing director at Morgan Stanley and a part-time gospel singer, has found a way to blend profits with piety.

headline: Where All Work Is Created Equal
text: School went badly last year for José, Angel and Estefani.   The 8-year-old twins and their 7-year-old sister are recent immigrants to the Washington Heights neighborhood of Manhattan.   In part because they didn’t speak much English, late in 2010 all three were notified they were in danger of failing.

headline: Metal Hips Failing Fast, Report Says
text: In a troubling development for people with all-metal artificial hips, a registry that tracks orthopedic implants in Britain reported on Thursday that the failure rate of the devices was increasing.

headline: China: Recycled Cooking Oil Poses Risk
text: At least two million tons of cooking oil are recycled illegally every year and used by restaurants in China, posing a serious health hazard to diners, according to a report on Thursday on the Web site of Xinhua, the state news agency. Recycled oil has become an increasing concern as the country tries to grapple with food safety issues. On Wednesday, Chinese news organizations reported the police had detained 32 people who are part of a ring spanning 14 provinces that collected recycled oil and peddled it at a discount to restaurants.

headline: Hedge Fund Chief Takes Major Role in Philanthropy
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Until last year, Tom Steyer was just another billionaire hedge fund manager intent on keeping a low profile.

headline: Amnesty Program Yields Millions More in Back Taxes
text: More than 12,000 American taxpayers have voluntarily revealed their secret offshore bank accounts to the Internal Revenue Service as part of the government’s latest tax amnesty program, agency officials said on Thursday. The move will allow the United States Treasury to collect at least half a billion dollars in unpaid taxes.

headline: Racial Bias Seen in Study of Lead Dust and Children
text: A class-action lawsuit was filed Thursday against a prominent Baltimore medical institute, accusing it of knowingly exposing black children as young as a year old to lead poisoning in the 1990s as part of a study exploring the hazards of lead paint.

headline: The Planning Fallacy
text: When the Nobel Prize-winning psychologist Daniel Kahneman was a young man, he led a committee to write a new part of the curriculum for Israeli high schools. The committee worked for a year, and Kahneman asked his colleagues how long they thought the rest of the project would take. Their estimates were around two years.

headline: Uncertainty on Wall Street, Big Deals on Madison Avenue
text: THREE years after the collapse of Lehman Brothers produced worldwide financial disruption, advertising agencies continue to face significant challenges. But Madison Avenue is, by and large, in better shape than many of the industries for which it creates ads.

headline: Judge Sets Schedule in Case Over Google’s Digital Library
text: Google’s plan to build a huge digital library remained stalled on Thursday when a federal judge set a proposed schedule for a lawsuit against the giant search company that could take the case to trial next year.

headline: Free to Die
text: Back in 1980, just as America was making its political turn to the right, Milton Friedman lent his voice to the change with the famous TV series “Free to Choose.” In episode after episode, the genial economist identified laissez-faire economics with personal choice and empowerment, an upbeat vision that would be echoed and amplified by Ronald Reagan.

headline: New Ranger Joins Call for Safer Hockey
text: Brad Richards, the prize of the off-season free-agent market and the N.H.L.’s highest-paid player, skates for the first time as a Ranger on Friday, when the team opens training camp. He says he is ready for the challenge and the pressure of trying to win in New York.

headline: Book Details Dissension in Obama Economic Team
text: WASHINGTON — A new book claims that President Obama’s response to the economic crisis was hampered by a White House economic staff plagued by internal rivalries, a domineering chief adviser and a Treasury secretary who dragged his feet on enforcing decisions with which he disagreed.

headline: Belly Up to the Bistro
text: PARIS — You’re reminded hourly, even while walking along the slow-moving Seine or staring at sculpted marble bodies under the Louvre’s high ceilings, that the old continent is crumbling. They’re slouching toward a gerontocracy, these Europeans. Their banks are teetering. They can’t handle immigration. Greece is broke, and three other nations are not far behind. In a half-dozen languages, the papers shout: crisis!

headline: TimesCast | Police Apartheid in Bahrain
text: September 15, 2011 - Six months after Bahrain's brutal crackdown on democratic protests, sectarian tension is brewing.

headline: By Car or by Paw? Trying to Retrace a Cat’s Travels
text: Maybe she came on foot, charming strangers along the nation’s plains like a character out of Mark Twain.

headline: Exploits, Now Not So Daring
text: Watertown, Mass.

headline: House Republicans Push Stopgap Spending Bill
text: WASHINGTON — In last year’s campaigns, Republicans ripped into Democrats for failing to perform one of Congress’s most basic duties: providing money in a timely way for the operations of government.

headline: ‘The Point Is That You Don’t Have to Spend a Lot of Money to Do What You Love’
text: Just two words on the back of a motorcycle, and half of Midtown Manhattan was stopping — well, let’s say slowing — to gawk:

headline: Marinovich Breaks Family Mold
text: LOS ANGELES — With little fanfare, the last of Marv Marinovich’s football-playing sons is coming home.

headline: Making Tyrants Do Time
text: Minneapolis

headline: Koch May Test His Political Voice on National Stage
text: Former Mayor Edward I. Koch’s strategy seemed almost nutty at first: ask Jewish residents in Brooklyn and Queens to vote against an Israel-loving observant Jew for Congress to send a message to President Obama.

headline: Rumors of Revolt
text: Ever since Abraham Lincoln’s election in November 1860, rumors of a slave insurrection had been growing along the plantations in the lower Mississippi River Valley. By September 1861, with battles breaking out from Missouri to Virginia and a Union blockade stretching across the Gulf Coast, those rumblings had reached a fever pitch.

headline: For Lundqvist, a Summer of Joy and Sorrow
text: For Rangers goalie Henrik Lundqvist it was a busy summer, highlighted by his marriage in his hometown, Gothenburg, Sweden. But it was also a sad summer, marked by the death by overdose of his Rangers teammate Derek Boogaard, the apparent suicides of two other N.H.L. enforcers and the plane crash in Russia that killed the players and coaches of Lokomotiv Yaroslavl. Last week in a conversation with Jeff Z. Klein of The Times and Jeff Blair of The Globe and Mail, Lundqvist talked about his career, his hopes for the Rangers, and the shock of a sobering off season.

headline: Aid for Baffled Weekend Subway Riders
text: Have trouble figuring out the subways on weekends? Get ready for a little help from an old friend.

headline: Stand or Fall Together
text: European leaders have at last begun edging, haltingly and reluctantly, toward the only realistic solution to the continent’s debt and banking crises: refinancing unpayable government debts and reinforcing weakened banks. If their monetary and political union is to survive, all members must start acting more like a union and less like a collection of jealous sovereign states.

headline: Arrest of UBS Trader Rattles Banks in Europe
text: Kweku Adoboli traveled from Ghana to Israel to a Quaker boarding school before attending a leading university in Nottingham, England. With his education pedigree, he landed a coveted job at UBS, the giant Swiss bank, right after graduation.

headline: Pandering to the Gun Lobby
text: How low can the Florida Legislature go in pandering to the gun lobby?

headline: Lottery Numbers
In Kansas City, an Arts Center Makes a Debut
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — As arts organizations from one coast to the other wrestle with cuts in grants and declines in ticket sales, an ambitious new performing arts center in the middle of the country is defying the trend.

headline: Pitching-Rich Rays Continue Late Charge
text: Boston

headline: New F.A.A. Shutdown Is Averted
text: WASHINGTON (Bloomberg News) — The Senate passed legislation on Thursday to avert a second partial shutdown of the Federal Aviation Administration, extending the agency’s financing for four months.

headline: Humane Housing for the Mentally Ill
text: Gov. Andrew Cuomo brought an end to a shameful chapter in New York’s history last week when he agreed to settle a suit over the mistreatment of mentally ill people who have been unnecessarily confined in nursing homes.

headline: At White House, Weighing Limits of Terror Fight
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration’s legal team is split over how much latitude the United States has to kill Islamist militants in Yemen and Somalia, a question that could define the limits of the war against Al Qaeda and its allies, according to administration and Congressional officials.

headline: Delta One Desks Are Big Moneymakers
text: The $2 billion trading loss that has rocked the Swiss banking giant UBS has also cast a spotlight on a relatively unknown but increasingly profitable corner of Wall Street — Delta One desks.

headline: Advantage, Tight Ends, Against the Jets
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — By Rex Ryan’s count, the Jets made seven glaring defensive mistakes in their victory over Dallas, and one of them seemed more than a bit familiar. Like many tight ends before him, Jason Witten burned the Jets over the middle, exploiting a mismatch in coverage to rumble for a 64-yard gain in the fourth quarter.

headline: Potential Buyers Renew Their Interest in Yahoo
text: With potential buyers circling above, Yahoo, the once-mighty online empire, is preparing to sell.

headline: Friday: Generally Speaking
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Some weeks are like this. I begin on a buoyant note, solving smoothly and confidently, which carries me through the themed puzzles for the week, and just as I’m hitting my stride I get derailed by a tough themeless, like today’s grid by Joe DiPietro.

headline: The Dance of the City on a Day in June
text: From the very first moments of “Septimus and Clarissa,” Ellen McLaughlin’s relentlessly, almost nerve-rackingly ambitious adaptation of Virginia Woolf’s “Mrs. Dalloway,” a bold visual gauntlet is thrown down.

headline: Some Cabbies Given Right to Say No to Racy Ads
text: For Mohan Singh, the breaking point came last year when his granddaughter, who was 6 at the time, saw a seductive woman in an advertisement affixed to the roof of his taxicab. She proudly announced that she suddenly knew what she wanted to be when she grew up.

headline: Withdrawal of Database on Doctors Is Protested
text: Three journalism organizations on Thursday protested a decision by the Obama administration to remove a database of physician discipline and malpractice actions from the Web.

headline: Lawmaker Takes Office and Learns Some Rules
text: WASHINGTON — Thursday was a day of firsts for Bob Turner, who is New York’s newest congressman and the Republican Party’s newest hero.

headline: Malcolm Wallop, Senator From Wyoming, Dies at 78
text: Malcolm Wallop, a three-term Republican senator from Wyoming who was a leading conservative light in Washington, pressing for a strong national defense, tax reform, states’ rights and other elements of the political sea change swept in by the Reagan administration, died on Wednesday at his home near Big Horn, Wyo. He was 78.

headline: Newark Is Betting on a Wave of New Principals
text: NEWARK — There is Sonn Sam, a Rhode Island transplant who could be mistaken for one of the students at his alternative high school, with his shaven head, sneakers and tattooed left arm.

headline: Mets Pitchers Not Helping Themselves
text: Mets pitcher Mike Pelfrey has adjusted his view on the Mendoza Line to suit his performance at the plate. He is simply hoping to improve his batting average 4 points, to .100, by the end of the year. That is 100 points below the actual Mendoza Line.

headline: UBS Has Some Explaining to Do
Sam DeLuca, a Former Jet and Broadcaster, Is Dead at 75
text: Sam DeLuca, a scrappy guard for the Jets in the 1960s who became a broadcaster after sustaining a career-ending injury, died on Tuesday at his home in Pelham, N.Y. He was 75.

headline: In Syrian Town, Uprising Turns Into Grim Standoff
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Daraya, a town on the outskirts of Damascus famous for its carpentry and fertile fields, has emerged as an example that illustrates the dichotomy of the Syrian uprising: a revolt that seems too resilient to fail and too vulnerable to endure.

headline: Aiming to Become the Best, Against Some of the Worst
text: There is nothing glamorous about the 5-year-old gelding named Rapid Redux. He will never make the Hall of Fame, win an Eclipse Award or race on national television. He just shows up, usually at small tracks with empty grandstands, usually against one-time claimers, and does his job.

headline: Denmark to Be Led by Its First Female Premier as Leftists Win
text: LONDON — A closely contested election in Denmark resulted in victory on Thursday for a center-left coalition led by the Social Democratic Party, ending a 10-year run in power for a center-right coalition that adopted some of Europe’s toughest immigration controls.

headline: Bahrain Boils Under the Lid of Repression
text: MANAMA, Bahrain — The battle began soon after sundown. And for the next six hours, in air heavy with heat and tear gas, phalanxes of police officers in helmets battled scores of youths in ski masks, as customers at a Costa Coffee not far away sat like spectators.

headline: Survey Finds Decline in New Yorkers Who Smoke to 14%
text: Just 14 percent of New York City adults said they were smokers in 2010, the lowest level since the city began tracking the smoking rate nearly two decades ago, according to a survey released on Thursday.

headline: Players Show Their Unity at Key Juncture of Talks
text: LAS VEGAS — On an afternoon of showy symbolism and strident commentary, Derek Fisher took the podium, flanked by 33 constituents in matching shirts, and flipped the script on the N.B.A.’s festering labor drama.

headline: Boehner, in Washington Speech, Reaffirms No-Tax-Increase Position
text: WASHINGTON — Speaker John A. Boehner on Thursday rejected tax increases as part of a sweeping effort to reduce the nation’s debt, delivering his prescription for a Congressional deficit-cutting committee ahead of a competing presentation by President Obama early next week.

headline: Brazilian Couple Traverses the Americas
text: At midlife, Sinomar Godois Tavares met Edivania Marques and bought a motorcycle. Then they took off to see the world.

headline: Market Risks Are Seen in Energy Innovations
text: WASHINGTON — The same market forces that doomed Solyndra, the solar cell manufacturer that received $528 million in government loans and then went bankrupt, could imperil other manufacturing ventures that have received loan guarantees from the Energy Department, energy experts warned this week.

headline: Giants’ Chief Executive Is Stepping Down
text: Winning the World Series last year did not create longtime harmony atop the San Francisco Giants’ hierarchy. On Wednesday night, the team said that Bill Neukom, its bow-tied managing general partner and chief executive, would retire at the end of the year.

headline: Virginia Health Board Tightens Rules on Abortion Clinics
text: WASHINGTON — The Virginia Board of Health on Thursday approved a set of regulations for abortion clinics that abortion rights advocates say could result in the closing of a number of the state’s more than 20 clinics. Supporters of the measures say they will make the clinics safer.

headline: Rose Leads the Attack on One Tough Course
text: LEMONT, Ill. — Whether it is called “going low” or “posting a number” or “shooting nothing” or simply “shooting a good score,” it is axiomatic wherever touring pros gather to play for money: someone always seems to do it.

headline: Americans and Cubans Still Mired in Distrust
text: MEXICO CITY — Bill Richardson had chits to offer Cuban officials in Havana this week if they released Alan Gross, the American contractor serving a 15-year sentence for distributing satellite telephone equipment.

headline: Ex-Basketball Prodigy Dies on Streets Where He Lived
text: LOS ANGELES — Lewis Brown, a high school and college basketball prodigy who spent the past 10 years living on a sidewalk in Hollywood, seemed on the verge of a second chance. He had scraped enough money together to get a California identification card so he could fly to visit a sister in New York who had thought him dead. Friends said that he would finally get off the street.

headline: Repressing the Religious Majority
text: Five months after the start of a ferocious crackdown against a popular uprising — so sweeping it smacks of apartheidlike repression of Bahrain’s religious majority — many fear that no one can win.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Palestinians Resist Appeals to Halt U.N. Statehood Bid
text: JERUSALEM — Senior American and European diplomats tried without success on Thursday to persuade the Palestinian leaders to skip or modify their planned United Nations membership bid, officials involved said.

headline: Import Helps Macedonia Find Unity
text: A look at the scoring leader board at the European championships reveals some familiar names — Deng, Bargnani, Parker and Gasol, to name a few. But sitting fourth, averaging 20.9 points a game, is a previously obscure player from New Orleans playing for Macedonia — population two million — which earned a highly improbable berth Wednesday in the tournament’s semifinals with a 67-65 win over host Lithuania.

headline: The Voices of Sjogren’s Syndrome
text: When the tennis great Venus Williams announced she was withdrawing from the United States Open this month because of health reasons, she put the spotlight on a common yet little-known disorder called Sjogren’s syndrome.

headline: More Schools Choose to Teach Abstinence-Plus
text: In the spring, public school students in Midland will touch what until recently was the political third rail of sex education. For the first time they will be taught about contraception — and how to practice safe sex.

headline: The Dewhurst Profile: Unexciting but Atop Polls
text: David Dewhurst is the Mitt Romney of the United States Senate race in Texas.

headline: Budget Cuts Threaten Underenrolled Physics Departments
text: The physicist Carlos Handy moved from Georgia to Texas in 2005, excited about building a physics program at Texas Southern University. But after serving as chairman of the department for six years, he may soon have to oversee its dismantling.

headline: Skeptics Cast Wary Eyes on Plan to Finance Cal Stadium Upgrade
text: Are there buyers for $225,000 college football tickets?

headline: Syrian Opposition Council Forms in Istanbul
text: ISTANBUL — Syrian opposition leaders announced on Thursday the formation of a national council to support the revolution against President Bashar al-Assad’s government and communicate with other nations in a unified voice.

headline: Homelessness Live on a Tenderloin Stage
text: The first sign that “Hunter’s Point,” a new play by Elizabeth Gjelten of San Francisco, is not a typical theatergoing experience is at the door.

headline: Abalone and a Rite Fall Victim to Red Tide
text: Since he was a child, Matt Mattison has taken part in an enduring summer ritual of the spectacular and rugged Sonoma Coast: donning fins and a mask, and diving to the ocean floor in search of abalone.

headline: Living at the Intersection of Public Need and Housing Pride
text: Valencia Gardens, located in San Francisco’s Mission neighborhood, is considered by many to be the Eden of public housing.

headline: Just Children, but Training for the Center Ring
text: Regina Meirmanov is 8. She likes pizza, hula hoops, the TV show “iCarly” and the singer Katy Perry. When she grows up, she wants to be a contortionist, or maybe a trapeze artist.

headline: Battle for Libya | September 15, 2011
text: The leaders of Britain and France visited Libya on Thursday and anti-Qaddafi fighters advanced southwest of Surt.

headline: Three St. John’s Recruits Fail to Qualify
text: The revamping of the St. John’s basketball program hit a significant roadblock Thursday when three top recruits failed to qualify academically, leaving the team with just eight scholarship players to start the season. Amir Garrett, Norvel Pelle and JaKarr Sampson, each considered one of the country’s top 100 players, failed to make it through the N.C.A.A. Clearinghouse.

headline: Glib Announcements on Job Creation Can’t Hide a Grim Reality
text: If Mayor Rahm Emanuel can generate jobs as well as he creates solicitous publicity, work-hungry citizens will be hitchhiking to Chicago from San Diego. If only it were that easy.

headline: Aftermarket Groupon Sites Eat Into Revenues
text: As skepticism mounts over Groupon’s long-term business prospects, this Chicago-based daily-deal giant, already facing a possible delay in its initial public stock offering, could be facing a new challenge in the form of the $1.2 billion market for resale of the company’s signature deep-discount coupons.

headline: NYT Front Page for 09/16/11
text: NYT Front Page for 09/16/11

headline: Community Is Torn Over Expansion of Oil Refinery
text: Steve Kozel was 7 in August 1955 when the Standard Oil refinery near his family’s Whiting, Ind., home was badly damaged by a huge explosion and fire. His father, who worked at the nearby Sinclair oil refinery, had been planning to buy a house in Whiting. “My mother said no way,” Mr. Kozel said, and they moved farther away.

headline: No Stranger to Suspense, L.S.U. Outduels Mississippi State
text: STARKVILLE, Miss. — When Louisiana State bumbled its way to the national title in 2007, it raised the crystal football despite two losses, six overtime periods and six games decided by one touchdown or less. The season is remembered for a flurry of close calls, head-shaking finishes and fourth-quarter gambles by Coach Les Miles that fluctuated from daring to baffling.

headline: Pennsylvania Electoral College Plan Could Backfire on G.O.P.
text: Republicans in Pennsylvania are considering a proposal that would award 18 of the state’s 20 electoral votes to the winner of each of its congressional districts, leaving the remaining 2 to the winner of the state at large.

headline: Rays Gain Ground (Again) on the Red Sox
text: BOSTON – It was the kind of freakish play that happens to teams in a free fall. With two out and two on in the third inning of a scoreless game Thursday, Tampa Bay’s B.J. Upton broke his bat on a ground ball to shortstop. Major league infielders — incredibly, when you think about it — almost always find a way to ignore bouncing shards of wood in their vicinity. But this one skipped too quickly to Boston shortstop Marco Scutaro.

headline: ‘West Side Story’
text: Photos from the new Broadway revival, which opened at the Palace Theater.

headline: Telling a New ‘Story’
text: A look at the many lives of the musical “West Side Story.”

headline: Playing It Cool
text: “West Side Story,” the 1957 musical that changed the way we think about how dance can tell a story, is reopening at the Palace Theater.

headline: Word of the Day | supplant
text: supplant •\sə-ˈplant\• verb

headline: Fashion Week Finale: Marc Jacobs
text: Sometime between Calvin Klein, at 3 p.m. Thursday, and Marc Jacobs that evening, the weather changed, and suddenly Fashion Week seemed over before it actually was. We saw Ralph Lauren, L’Wren Scott (who served her guests salade Niçoise and French fries), Calvin Klein and Mr. Jacobs. It was a pretty good day, with good fashion — Ms. Scott’s tart colors and then a sharp, finishing slap of glamorous black; Francisco Costa’s languid minimalism, and Mr. Jacobs’s very personal ode to dance halls and Bob Fosse.

headline: Post-Grunge, Seattle Rocks On
text: SEATTLE — Three months before he killed himself, Kurt Cobain spoke of his band’s breakthrough single at a concert here that turned out to be one of Nirvana’s final performances in the United States.

headline: 20 Years of Seattle Sound
text: Twenty years ago, Nirvana’s “Nevermind” album introduced the world to the Seattle sound of grunge. Now a new exhibit and documentary are celebrating the antiestablishment music.

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Today
text: Government oil companies raised the price of petrol (Times of India) by 3.14 Indian rupees per liter yesterday in a move that is expected to stoke inflation and upset household budgets. This is the third substantial increase since January. Oil companies argue that a fall in the rupee against the American dollar increased their cost of crude, forcing them to raise the price. There’s more bad news for households. A group of ministers is likely to consider limiting the supply (Hindustan Times) of subsidized liquefied petroleum gas cylinders today in an effort to cut the government’s overwhelming fuel subsidy bill.Less than 24 hours after the arrest of two high school students, police nabbed two more students (Indian Express) in connection with the bombing of the Delhi High Court last week, which killed 14 people and injured dozens more. Apart from these four young men, police are questioning a cybercafé owner and his manager in relation to the e-mail sent to the media soon after the blast.

headline: Quiz: Test Your Grunge Knowledge
text: Grunge music helped define Seattle in the early 1990s and has left its mark on rock ’n’ roll in the 20 years since. How well do you know the genre? Test your knowledge.

headline: Seattle, Post Grunge
text: Twenty years after Nirvana soared from obscurity to superstardom, a new exhibition, a film and a tribute concert make clear how different things really are here now.

headline: North Korean Accused of Plotting Against Fellow Defector
text: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea’s top government spy agency said on Friday that it had arrested a North Korean defector on suspicion of plotting an attack on a fellow defector who is a vocal critic of the North.

headline: Questioning of Reggae Artist Led Police to 300 Pounds of Marijuana

headline: Lille Entertains, but Then Spoils the Ending

headline: The Grammar of Anarchy
text: As Western democracies contemplate the ravages of debt and recession, in India the global economic crisis has manifested itself this summer as a burning debate about corruption. Led by a 74-year old farmer from Maharashtra, Baburao “Anna” Hazare, the popular outcry against this scourge of the Indian polity has consumed the months of summer and monsoon from April to September. While the Indian media have read Anna’s appearance in public life as a historic moment, in fact it is an old tension within India’s founding principles that has once again come to the fore.

headline: Malaysian Premier Proposes Replacing Laws on Detention
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — Prime Minister Najib Razak of Malaysia has promised to abolish two contentious security laws that allow for detention without trial and to relax a law governing the media in what analysts say is an attempt to revive his public support before elections that could be called by early next year.

headline: Sept. 16, 1974 | Conditional Amnesty for Vietnam Draft Dodgers and Military Deserters
text: On Sept. 16, 1974, President Gerald R. Ford issued a proclamation that offered amnesty to those who evaded the draft during the Vietnam War. Mr. Ford also granted amnesty to those in the military who deserted their duty while serving. However, the amnesty came with certain conditions, namely that those involved agreed to reaffirm their allegiance to the United States and serve two years working in a public service job.

headline: Approval of Congress Matches Record Low
text: Congress faces historically low approval ratings as it wades into the debate over the $447 billion jobs package proposed by President Obama, with just 12 percent of Americans now approving of the way Congress is handling its job, matching its all-time low, recorded in October 2008 at the height of the economic crisis, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: Site Specific
text: When she traveled, Pavia Rosati used to scour “90 Web sites for hours, then narrow down the information into a 40-page mega-Word document.” To save the rest of us the trouble, Rosati started Fathom (fathomaway.com): guides, postcards and resources by journalists, tuned-in travelers and readers eager to share. “It’s crowd sourcing with an editorial filter,” says Rosati (above right, in Capri with Fathom’s editorial director, Jeralyn Gerba, left). “Everyone loves the voice of the people, but can you trust them?”

headline: Going Behind the Scenes With Four Owners
text: What happens when women who own businesses get together to talk openly about their challenges, strategies and goals? Beginning next week, we’ll find out when I start to meet regularly with the owners of four businesses. Our continuing conversation will become an important feature of She Owns It. This post introduces the women and the companies we will get to know.

headline: Fill-In | The 1,800-Mile Cat

headline: Ahead of Its Time | An Icon Goes Digital
text: In 1972, Massimo Vignelli designed a diagrammatic map for the New York City subway. It was a radical departure. He replaced the serpentine maze of geographically accurate train routes with simple, bold bands of color that turned at 45- and 90-degree angles. Each route was color-coded, its stops indicated by black dots. Its abstract representation of the routes was elegant but flawed. To make the map function effectively, a few geographic liberties were taken, something that didn’t sit well with New Yorkers.

headline: Friday Reading: How to Avoid Impulse Moves in Retirement Investments

headline: Week 2 N.F.L. Matchups
text: Eagles (1-0) at Falcons (0-1)Sunday, 8:20 p.m.Line: Eagles by 2 1/2In honor of Michael Vick’s return to Atlanta, the Eagles have starting using their 1989 throwback offense. The scheme pays homage to Randall Cunningham’s glory days. The Eagles do not really drive down the field; they just string together amazing highlights, interspersing the occasional punt or baffling mistake. A typical play begins with two defenders knifing untouched through Philadelphia’s porous, inexperienced offensive line. Vick either gets flattened or performs some Matrix-style escape, scrambling for a big gain or tossing to a receiver who used the confusion to get wide open. Andy Reid calls for a timeout four or five times per half to impose order (teams only get three timeouts per half, but a 5-yard penalty is a small price to pay for the chance to install a precisely designed sequence of plays for Vick to scrap).

headline: Russian Drama
text: After closing its doors in 2005 for a rafters-to-orchestra-pit renovation, Moscow’s Bolshoi Theater still kicked up controversy — embezzlement, corruption, sex scandal. Now, three years past due and way over budget, the hall, which dates to 1825, will reopen next month with a gala performance of the ballet and opera companies’ greatest hits. In attendance will be President Dmitri Medvedev and other heads of state, who will finally see what $760 million restores. It took more than 3,500 workers to restore the Apollo and the Muses ceiling piece, replicate the missing Villeroy & Boch tiles and hang 617 pounds of crystal from the main chandelier. Much of the work was supervised by the president’s office itself, which stepped in when construction faltered in 2009, after a contractor was paid three times for the same work. Now the acoustics are fixed, subterranean hydraulic stages are built, and, for the finishing touch, the Romanov coat of arms has been reinstated above the lintels, in place of the hammer and sickle.

headline: Advice on Debt? Europe Suggests U.S. Can Keep It

But at least in this case his latest adventure is being written by an author with the sense and sensibility to preserve the voice and spirit of Potter’s original stories.

One of the first of these, which also promises to be one of the most interesting, is an exhibition of Faye Toogood’s third furniture collection, “Delicate Interference: Assemblage 3,” at Phillips de Pury & Company’s Brook Street space at Claridge’s in Mayfair (until Oct. 4).

headline: New York Top 5 | Michael Kors
text: The vacation destinations of Michael Kors have often served as rich fodder for his collections, and his latest locale is one more for that enviable list. The African Bush of Peter Beard and “Brad and Angie” (see video) set the scene for a safari most of us can just dream about. Utility jackets in actual mudcloth and ombred leather were worn with colorfully dyed linen scarves and loose pants. My favorite look was a multipocketed khaki jacket with treated seams worn with voluminous knee-length olive cargo pocketed shorts, with a natural linen scarf dip dyed to match. Book my plane ticket now.

headline: Taking Manhattan by Bike (the Russian Way)

Velonight’s creator, Sergey Nikitin, is an associate professor of Russian art, architecture and “sociourbanistics” at the People’s Friendship University of Russia in Moscow.
