headline: Backstage Beauty Report | L’Wren Scott
text: “Rock ‘n’ roll on the Riviera” is the beauty catchphrase backstage at L’Wren Scott. “A contessa from wherever,” is how Serge Normant described the woman that inspired the undone French twists he created using his own line of products. He coated hair with Meta Lush Volumizer and Meta Revive Dry Shampoo before blow-drying and using a small barrel curling iron to create the base for finger waves. Then, the back was swept to the side and tucked into a twist secured with pins. “Sophistication becomes disheveled,” Normant said, using his fingers to pull apart the up do. Nails went the way of the lady, as well. “She wanted something sexy, nothing dark or overpowering of the clothes,” Yuna Park said of Blush, the custom mauve polish she created for Scott to replace last season’s black varnish. “It’s less Gothic, more feminine — not so harsh.” For makeup, Aaron De May translated Scott’s directive with a dense shiny eye, bronzed skin and a subtle lip. “Normally, L’Wren always likes strong, smoky, colorful, this was also about decadence, the duchesses, princesses arriving on boat in the ’40s and ’50s,” he said. De May used Lancôme Star Bronzer  in Solaire to make each girl’s skin color “two tones darker.” He then applied Le Crayon Kohl in Black Coffee all around the eye and in the crease. This was blended with Mochaccino shadow on the top and Vintage Brown on the bottom. He painted the inner corners of the eye gold from the 5 Pan Palette in Gold Frenzy and spread Juicy Tubes Pure clear lip gloss on the lid. “It can look dull or muddy with all that brown,” De May said. “This brings life to the face in need of a little bit of sparkle.”

headline: Jerry O’Connell Coming to Broadway in Theresa Rebeck Comedy
text: The television and film actor Jerry O’Connell (“Sliders,” “Jerry Maguire”) will make his Broadway debut this fall as a self-satisfied young writer in Theresa Rebeck’s new comedy, “Seminar,” which stars Alan Rickman as a no-holds-barred writing teacher.

headline: Robertson Stirs Passions With Suggestion to Divorce an Alzheimer’s Patient
text: With his suggestion this week that a man whose wife was far “gone” with Alzheimer’s should divorce her if he wanted a new companion, the television evangelist Pat Robertson stumbled into treacherous moral terrain, setting off storms of criticism and questions about a disease that shatters lives and families.

headline: Strange Case of Willow the Cat Is Solved, to a Point
text: It is looking as if the mystery of how Willow the calico cat crossed the country may have the most prosaic possible solution. No death-defying four-paw trek out of “The Incredible Journey“; no stowing away on Amtrak or Greyhound; no Toonces-like turn at the wheel of a careering car.

headline: Can Antioch College Return From the Dead Again?
text: The long corridors of Antioch Hall are dark. The fluorescent lights, perhaps 50 years old and never updated, do not work. The vinyl floor tiles are loose. There are cobwebs and puddles on the floor, and the whole place smells of mold. You have to squint, almost, to picture this four-story brick building as the birthplace of one of the most vaunted experiments in American higher education.

headline: Why We Need For-Profit Colleges
text: Last month, a company called Education Management Corporation was sued by the Department of Justice. Education Management is a for-profit education company; in fact, it is the country’s second-largest such company, with more than 150,000 students attending classes on more than 100 campuses, where it offers degrees in business, accounting and nursing, among other subjects.

headline: There Is No Escaping Whitney Cummings
text: This fall, you’re coming out of relative obscurity to have two shows on network TV: “Whitney,” which you star in, and “Two Broke Girls,” which you co-created. What do you remember about being broke?  There was a time in L.A. when I drove to 7-Eleven to go grocery shopping, and I locked my keys in my car, which wasn’t insured. My wallet was in there, and I couldn’t call AAA, because I only had $7 in my bank account. It was one of those moments where I was like, “O.K., I literally have nothing right now.”

headline: The 83-Year-Old Money Tree
text: Earlier this summer, I found myself in the passenger seat of 83-year-old Mary Donnelly’s Ford Escape as she darted around Block Island, dodging dozens of half-drunk tourists spilling into the street.

headline: ‘Stolen’ Property?
text: I bought a house that a previous owner had nearly destroyed. He knocked holes in walls and doors, trucked away the deck and trashed the aboveground pool, etc. I assumed he was angry at his wife, but it turned out that he was angry at the bank, which had foreclosed, taking everything the couple had put into the property. When a mutual friend invited the former owners to visit, the wife wept and said she could never bear to see our improvements on a house that had been “stolen.” I know we didn’t steal her home, but I resolved never to buy a foreclosed house again. It seems to be an evil thing to do, to profit from another family’s misfortune. Is it? ELIZABETH MURPHY, NORFOLK, VA.

headline: College Football Live Blog: Join the Conversation
text: Paul Myerberg and Karen Crouse of The Times will be hosting their own college football watch party all day Saturday, right here at The Quad. They’ll bring you highlights and analysis from games around the country and spend some time answering your questions.

headline: Dear Important Novelists: Be Less Like Moses and More Like Howard Cosell
text: “To start with, look at all the books.” That’s the promising first sentence of Jeffrey Eugenides’s new novel, “The Marriage Plot,” due in bookstores this fall. The book is about three college friends from Brown University, and at first taste — I’ve been toting around an advance copy — it appears to be luscious: humane, recondite and funny. Part of the heavy anticipation for “The Marriage Plot,” though, is a simple emotional response: We’ve missed this man. It has been nine years since Eugenides’s last novel, the Pulitzer Prize-winning “Middlesex.” It has been a long, lonely vigil. We’d nearly forgotten he was out there.

headline: The Re-Education of an Amnesiac
text: I’m not your typical undergraduate. I am a 46-year-old wife and mother with three adult children. Depending on how you count, I may be twice as old as the traditional students or essentially the same age as they are. After all, my life as I know it began 23 years ago, when, in a freakish accident, I was hit in the head by a ceiling fan in our home in Fort Worth, Tex. At that moment, everything and everyone I ever knew, and all I had ever learned, was erased completely from my mind.

headline: What Would Hillary Clinton Have Done?
text: Every week, several letters rail against Republicans. I find the claim in last week’s letter about Hillary Clinton that Republicans don’t play fair particularly delicious, because the Clintons are hardly known for playing political softball. To all of you paranoid folks, however: Republicans are not the cause of all of the problems of the Western world. We genuinely believe that government needs to live within its means, that it is not the government’s role to try to socially engineer every problem and especially that the government is not the solution to our jobs problem. The Democrats controlled the House and the Senate since 2006, and Obama certainly got his health care program through. So what is it exactly that the Republicans have kept Obama, Pelosi, Reid and Co., from doing?

headline: Beatles on the Beach
text: Every Beatles fan knows that the iconic images of them starts, and arguably ends, with Astrid Kirchherr’s work. Her incredible influence on their tastes, interests, appearance, clothes and even music is as legendary as she is. She is a fabulous icon of that era, an accomplished artist in her own right and really a sixth member of the band in so many ways in the early days. And her tragic link to Stu Sutcliffe is another reminder of her rightful place in Beatles history.

headline: Hugh Laurie Sings the Blues
text: Here’s my favorite Laurie story: Before “House,” the producers were auditioning actors for the lead role. Laurie was on location in the Sahara or someplace equally remote, filming “Flight of the Phoenix,” so he sent in a video audition. They hired him on the basis of that video. I read a comment the producer made that they were not familiar with Laurie and had no idea that he was British; his American accent is that good. I’ve watched a lot of BBC, and I can attest that Britons often do appalling American accents (I can only presume the reverse also holds true). Watching every episode of “House,” I think I’ve caught only one accent mishap.

headline: Where Steel Meets Sky
text: I used to build scaffolding for ironworkers some years ago, and I never met a tougher or tighter-knit group of guys, their silver hats distinguishing them as the aristocrats of blue-collar workers. Much of their banter recalled “fliers,” fellow workers who had “gone down” on past jobs. Rather than braggadocio, I took this as their way of reminding themselves to avoid making a fatal misstep. No one ever took more pride in their job than those guys.

headline: What the Left Doesn’t Understand About Obama
text: Jonathan Chait fundamentally misunderstands the left’s disapproval of President Obama. Yes, dissatisfaction with his handling of the stimulus and recession factors into it, but more important, the left finds him politically feckless and to have abandoned principles without having won political battles. His desire to create comity is admirable in theory, but compromise for its own sake is neither effective nor politically desirable. Perhaps we on the left misjudged Candidate Obama, but his campaign rhetoric was far more progressive than his presidency has been. We know he’s constrained by the Republican House, though there are areas in which he could achieve change, like closing Guantánamo, protecting whistle-blowers or, most important, withdrawing forces from Afghanistan. He could use ye olde Bully Pulpit to advocate progressive ideals vocally. That’s what “the left” wanted to see from Obama and why we are dissatisfied with him now.

headline: Questions For Carine Roitfeld
text: Is Carine Roitfeld’s antimules screed a shoe jab at Anna Wintour? Is it a coincidence that Wintour, editor of Roitfeld’s once-frenemy magazine, American Vogue, spends half the year wearing Manolo Blahnik slides — which, for all intents and purposes, are open-toe mules?

headline: Syria’s Sons of No One
text: Terrific reporting and a rare insight into the why of the revolution. This reporter risked his life for this article. Thank you for that.

headline: The Old Fish Market Cleans Up Good
text: The South Street Seaport is emerging as a residential neighborhood.

headline: How Parenting Has Changed in 10 Years
text: “I Don’t Know How She Does It,” the movie, opens today, a decade after Allison Pearson wrote “I Don’t Know How She Does It,” the book. They are both about a mother of two, Kate Reddy, who works in finance and frantically juggles home and office. But it’s the differences between them that I want to talk about on Motherlode today.

headline: Children’s Bookshelf: Fairy and Folk Tales
text: Pamela Paul reviews new children’s books about fairy and folk tales.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Marc Jacobs
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#319", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);Kava Gorna’s New York Fashion Week photo diary.

headline: Palestinians Set Bid for U.N. Seat, Clashing With U.S.
text: JERUSALEM — The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, announced Friday that he would seek membership for a state of Palestine from the United Nations Security Council next week, putting him on a collision course with Israel and the United States as both face an Arab world in turmoil.

headline: Steps Away but Worlds Apart in New York
text: For decades, the intersection of Park Avenue and 96th Street has remained one of the city’s most obvious and despairing emblems of disparity, with East Harlem and its challenges spreading out to the north, and a vast gridlock of extraordinary privilege colonizing the acreage below. It is worth debating whether a visit to this corner ought to be mandated for tourists; few spots so profoundly render the truths of New York’s economic extremism. Liberal parents hoping to foster their own political values in their children might consider pilgrimages. When I stood there, as a teenager, for the first time in the early 1980s, I felt a call to fierce and equalizing justice, ready, suddenly, for Latin American guerrilla work and the Red Brigades.

headline: The Fish Market Cleans Up Good
text: WHEN Gary Fagin began renting in a dilapidated former sausage factory in the South Street Seaport area 25 years ago, fishmongers plied the cobblestone streets, carcasses of mackerel and cod were often underfoot, and the bar at Jeremy’s Ale House was packed at 8 o’clock in the morning.

headline: Maglen & Louis
text: In this video, Maglen Kaiser says she first noticed Louis Epstein’s eyes and Louis says he noticed Maggie’s dry sense of humor.

headline: At San Gennaro, Offerings More Worthy of a Saint
text: O tourists with your plastic bongs brimming with banana daiquiris: pause a moment as you weave down Mulberry Street in the coming week and consider the saint in whose honor  you are blessed with free refills and fried Oreos and sound-activated light-up T-shirts.

headline: An Essayist in Love with Seattle, Sailing and the Open Road
text: For the essayist the past is less a foreign country than a home address, a lodestar or touchstone, in Phillip Lopate's words the “Aladdin’s lamp which he or she never tires of rubbing.” It is more markedly so in a collection assembled over time, or in the case of Jonathan Raban, over the two decades this eloquent Englishman has spent in America. Raban presents his selections humbly, mindful of the gap that separates American from British English. “The longer I stay here,” he writes, “the more conscious I am of nuances to which I must still remain deaf.” It is impossible not to take to the author of a book called “Driving Home” who reveals that on his arrival he made the greatest of idiomatic American mistakes: he bought the wrong car. Less than gently, the woman for whom he had crossed the ocean translates. What message does his black Dodge Daytona communicate? “Midlife crisis,” she answers. “Who drives them?” he asks. “Kids. Black teenagers. Gang members,” she replies, crisply. She sounds very much aware that she is interpreting for a man who previously assumed Oregon to be an invention of Bernard Malamud.

headline: H.G. Wells, the Man Who Invented Tomorrow
text: The stupefyingly prolific H. G. Wells published more than a hundred books and slept with “well over a hundred women in his lifetime.” But who’s counting? David Lodge, that’s who. Some of Wells’s works, including the briskly entertaining science fiction classics “The Time Machine” and “The War of the Worlds,” are as familiar as any in English; others, like the appallingly named novel “The Bulpington of Blup” (you can look it up) have sunk from view.

headline: What Happens When a Mathematician Marries a Painter?
text: The novel opens with a hand growing cold. Nina Hoffman is sitting by the body of her husband, Philip, who has died of heart failure on his bed while she was making supper, boiling new potatoes, taking the chicken out of the oven. In her all-night vigil by his side, her mind moves back over the past, remembering, imagining, wondering.

headline: Famine, the Unnecessary Evil
text: You and I and everyone we know are always living only a few weeks of food away from famine psychosis. Here’s how it goes. Deprived of meals, your body starts to consume itself. It uses up the glucose stored in your liver and body fats. It uses up the proteins in its own muscles and cells. Rapidly, your body starts to mock you: your belly swells as if you are becoming fat, because the breakdown of muscle causes the remaining fat to bunch there.

headline: Blacks, Whites and the Wedding Gap
text: The unmarried black woman is a figure of cultural fascination these days. Cable news specials, popular books by Steve Harvey and T. D. Jakes, the films of Tyler Perry, and newspaper articles about single black women and their children born out of wedlock send waves of dismay through the American public. The explanations offered for this phenomenon tend to be of two sorts: prurient accounts of black male promiscuity and irresponsibility, or caricatures of aggressive and unreasonable black women. It is rare for the popular media to include careful social or historical analyses. Rather, they are often purveyors of a moral panic presented without root or reason.

headline: The Dinner Guest Who Never Left
text: Ali Smith loves words. She loves playing with them, calling attention to them, listening to them as if they were members of a vast extended family, each precious in its own right and she their fair-­minded parent, determined not to play favorites. She can give the word “but” such a star turn that you wonder why you’d ever taken it for granted.

headline: From Gandhi to Gatsby
text: The project of the Indian republic has never been short on ambition. It now cinches 1.2 billion people into a pluralist democracy, and its recent experiments with economic reform have made the project still bolder. Perhaps this is why the moment seems to call for nonfiction about India that must match its subject for ambition. The platonic ideal of this book requires it to be rewarding to both Indians and outsiders; to possess the fluid art of literature but also the sweat-stained craft of journalism; to be encyclopedic and anecdotal; and to seek, within its characters, metaphors for their country at large.

headline: Coming to Terms With the Experience of Combat
text: A  soldier comes home from war. His wife’s welcome is extravagant, fit for a god. Refusing to let his feet touch the ground, she unrolls a new carpet, plush and crimson. She tells him he is “like the sun,” bringing “warmth in winter,” and predicts that he will again be “master . . . of his house, fulfilled.” Then the man takes a bath, an act of literal and symbolic cleansing after a long journey and an even longer, deeply compromising war. And there he dies, stabbed by his wife, in bath water polluted by his own blood.

headline: By the Ayatollah’s Decree
text: On the night of Sept. 17, 1992, two armed men entered the Mykonos restaurant in Berlin and shot dead a visiting Kurdish leader of the Iranian opposition, his two aides and an exiled dissident. The visiting dignitary, Sadegh Sharafkandi, was the chairman of Iran’s Democratic Party of Kurdistan and had come to Berlin to address the International Congress of the Social Democratic Party. The dinner at Mykonos, attended by members of the exiled Iranian community, was to honor his visit. It had been arranged at a moment of optimism for many of the exiles, when the president of Iran, Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, was calling on them to return home, promising moderation and reconciliation.

headline: When Spain Led the World
text: Hugh Thomas’s big new book falls firmly into the genre of Nobody Does This Anymore. “The Golden Empire” is the second installment in a multi­volume history of the rise of the Spanish Empire. The whole enterprise will surely comprise 2,000 pages or more; this present book clocks in at almost 700 pages, including five of intricate genealogical charts. The last historian of imperial Spain to work on this scale published his first volume in 1918, and the fourth and final volume didn’t appear for 26 years. Baron Thomas of Swynnerton, as Thomas is officially known, works much faster. If he keeps up the present rate of production, he might be able to lay down his pen after only 16.

headline: Denis Johnson’s Tragedy-in-the-Woods Novella
text: Sometimes, if you wander long enough out-of-doors, you look up and find yourself in a suddenly devastating place: on a glittering slab of granite, say, hanging a thousand feet above a mountain lake. Your blood quickens, the clouds stretch, the light turns everything to gold and something enters you, shakes you, seizes some root of your soul and pulps it. Maybe you make your way down to the lake for a swim, or just sit beneath the sky for an hour, dazzled, but what lasts is the feeling that you have found something important, something precious, something that would be world-renowned if only it weren’t so hard to find.

headline: Northern Exposure
text: Joe Fresh, the popular Canadian fashion brand, is finally coming stateside. Its first Manhattan location, at 110 Fifth Avenue, opens in early November, and a splashy Midtown flagship will follow in the spring. Joe Mimran, the company’s founder and creative director, knows a thing or two about making covetable but affordable clothing: he founded Club Monaco in 1985. An avid art collector, Mr. Mimran was inspired by the painter Peter Doig’s “magical landscapes” when designing this chunky hand-knitted sweater, which will be available when stores open.

headline: The Unacknowledged Victories of the American Left
text: We might as well call it: The American left is dead. Faced with the greatest crisis of capitalism in almost a century, the left has mounted no effective mass protests, inspired no significant uprisings, spawned no major institutions or policy revolutions. In Wisconsin, labor unions lost their greatest public battle since Ronald Reagan’s showdown with air traffic controllers. In the midterm elections, the Tea Party, not the left, took advantage of economic discontent to upend the status quo. Today, the dream of socialism exists mostly as a far-right phantom, to be conjured up when Democrats dare to imply that Medicare or Social Security might serve the public good.

headline: A Novel of India, Pakistan and How Their Elites Failed
text: Rehan Tabassum is in a bad way. Although, strictly speaking, the trouble isn’t of his making. He’s just got that kind of family — prone to falling in love with the servants, scheming against one another, messing with the wrong fundamentalist and leaving sensitive home videos lying about. The Tabassums, owners of a telecommunications empire in Pakistan, are a brutal, blundering clan grown crooked and strange after years of bending to the will of their autocratic patriarch. Their methods are medieval, but they’re punished for their excesses and brutality in distinctly modern ways: they’re blackmailed via text messages and pilloried in the comments of Internet articles.

headline: The Love for One Orange
text: WHEN asked what they like best about living in South Orange, residents almost invariably cite three attributes: the rich and varied architecture, the demographic diversity, and the easy commute into Manhattan. The latter two have a lot to do with the fact that New York City is the point of origin for a high percentage of South Orange’s residents.

headline: A Hail-Mary Pass as the Clock Runs Down
text: THE phrase “troubled adoptions” brings to mind rescued pit bulls or the neglected children from third-world orphanages. Now there’s an automotive analog to trouble prospective parents: the cars of Sweden’s embattled Saab.

headline: Flexing Some Korean Muscle
text: TESTED 2012 Hyundai Genesis 5.0 R-Spec

headline: A Deaf Boy’s New York Quest
text: Sequels and seconds-in-a-series are as often as not better than the starter volume, and yet it seems incumbent upon us all to doubt them anyway. “Through the Looking Glass” is an incomparably better book than its predecessor — its chess-problem structure more ingenious; its nonsense poems far more inspired — but we still say “Alice in Wonderland” and always shall when we refer to Carroll’s world. Freshness of vision is in all departments of life an aesthetic category not to be sneezed at.

headline: Big Deal | Jehovah’s Witnesses List Prime Properties
text: As the Jehovah’s Witnesses prepare to move their headquarters out of Brooklyn, where their Watchtower sign has long been a fixture of the cityscape, they are selling two town houses, two brownstones and a carriage house on prime Brooklyn Heights blocks.

headline: More Accidental Drug Poisonings of Children
text: The growing use of prescription drugs by adults, from pain relievers to sleep aids and heart medications, has led to an increase in accidental drug poisonings of children, new research shows.

headline: A Decemberist’s Tale of a Fantastical Portland
text: Portland, Ore., is an analog town, a city of bicycles and bookstores and Douglas firs and old pubs with splintery wooden bars and hulking industrial-era bridges. It’s a town where the bookish, bewhiskered, occasionally bowler-hatted band members of the Decemberists can play perfect homegrown rock. Now the band’s singer, Colin Meloy, has written a fantasy adventure set, appropriately, in the green heart of the city.

headline: ‘Car of Tomorrow’ Gets Fuel System of Today
text: WHEN the 2012 Nascar season roars to life in Florida next February, racecars in the Sprint Cup series will have undergone one of their biggest changes in decades. But the difference won’t be visible to spectators in the stands or fans watching on TV.

headline: How to Win at Scrabble in a Parallel Universe
text: Even in a literary cosmos populated by teenage wizards and smart alecks, the characters in Meg Wolitzer’s first young adult novel might seem fantastical bordering on ridiculous. Kids obsessed with Scrabble? Who play in a national championship? With a first prize of $10,000? Come on.

headline: What the Zagabog Knew
text: For this revival of “The Flint Heart,” a wonderful British fantasy by Eden Phillpotts first published in 1910, we can thank Katherine Paterson, the well-known author and current national ambassador for young people’s literature, and her husband, John, who at the request of their publisher “freely abridged” the original.

headline: Bookshelf: Fairy and Folk Tales
text: KING HUGO’S HUGE EGO  Written and illustrated by Chris Van Dusen 36 pp. Candlewick Press. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 6)

headline: Bound by Books
text: To the Editor:

headline: Preferred Pronouns
text: To the Editor:

headline: Concept of Mine
text: To the Editor:

headline: Chanel and the Germans
text: To the Editor:

headline: Voltaire’s Punching Bag
text: To the Editor:

headline: Water Sprites
text: Ryan McGinley captures dancers from New York City Ballet's “Ocean's Kingdom” on the Hudson waterfront.

headline: The Children’s Authors Who Broke the Rules
text: The stylistic eccentricities of Maurice Sendak, Shel Silverstein and Theodor Geisel, a k a Dr. Seuss, are so much a part of the childhood vernacular today that it’s hard to imagine their books were once considered by some to be wholly inappropriate for children.

headline: Art, Poetry, Murder
text: After dispatching Chief Inspector Armand Gamache to Quebec City in her last novel, “Bury Your Dead,” Louise Penny finds good cause to draw the discerning head of the homicide division of the Sûreté du Québec back to Three Pines, a village so tiny and secretive it doesn’t appear on any maps. “It could not be found unless you were lost,” she explains, with the exactitude of language that’s crucial to the psychological subtlety of her characters — and the delight she takes in them.

headline: Up Front: Imani Perry
text: Imani Perry, a distinguished scholar of law, literature, and American culture and history who is currently on the faculty of the Center for African American Studies at Princeton, this week reviews “Is Marriage for White People?” by the Stanford law professor Ralph Richard Banks. Combining academic research with personal interviews, Banks’s book investigates trends in marriage among African-Americans and asks how these may extend to society at large. Perry said via e-mail that she favors Banks’s approach: “It’s wonderful to match up human voices with more abstract analyses. I believe in employing many tools for pursuing an answer to a challenging problem. I’ll read poetry, neuroscience, psychology, media studies, and political, literary and social theory, all for a single project.”

headline: Digital Diary: Becoming an Alarmist
text: I’m in the market for a new gadget. But I’m not shopping for a shiny new tablet or phone, no. Neither of those.

headline: At the Tippler: High-Concept Blender Drinks and Shot Pairings
text: Tad Carducci — one of the founders of the new Chelsea bar the Tippler and half of the cocktail consulting team called the Tippling Bros. — wants his new saloon to be a local bar that appeals to all thirsts, not another haute cocktail emporium.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THAT USED TO BE US: How America Fell Behind in the World It Invented and How We Can Come Back,  by Thomas L. Friedman and Michael Mandelbaum (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $28.) A call for more public-spiritedness on the part of elite Americans.

headline: Paperback Row
text: A JOURNEY: My Political Life,  by Tony Blair (Vintage, $19.) In this engrossing memoir the former British prime minister traces his political ambitions and principles, and assesses his role in shaping recent historical events: the remaking of the Labour Party, the power-sharing agreement in Northern Ireland and the divisive decision to go to war in Iraq.

headline: Leah Cohen on her new novel, “The Grief of Others”; the art of children’s books; and best-seller news.
text: This week, Leah Cohen talks about her new novel, “The Grief of Others”; Adam Gopnik and Pamela Paul discuss the art of children’s books and the art of writing about them; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: Guest No Longer, Conductor Raises His Profile at Met
text: WITH the news this month that James Levine had slipped and injured a vertebra while vacationing in Vermont, necessitating emergency surgery and forcing him to withdraw from all of his commitments at the Metropolitan Opera at least through the rest of the year, Fabio Luisi became the company’s music director in all but name.

headline: Christina Hendricks in 'Mad Men'
text: The actress is nominated for best supporting actress in a drama for her work on the AMC series.

headline: On Common Ground: The Pairing of Piano Men
text: JAZZ pianists spend a lot of time alone with their craft, and often just as much in the context of a rhythm section. It’s less common for them to sit down and make music with each other, though it does happen every now and then. (It happened a lot in the 1930s among Harlem stride masters, behind closed doors, in clubby camaraderie.) The scarcity is enough to make you notice a good piano-duo album when it arrives. This fall, oddly enough, there are a few, two of them due out on Tuesday.

headline: Inside the List
text: LESSONS FROM TWAIN: Next month, the perennial best sellers David Baldacci, John Grisham and Jodi Picoult will appear together at Yale to discuss Mark Twain’s influence on their work. It’s not the most intuitive topic, as Picoult acknowledges: “Most of my Twain was read when I was a student, the same as most American kids,” she said by phone recently from her home in New Hampshire, “and I haven’t had the time to reread him since.” Yet Picoult — who spent nine weeks on the hard­cover fiction list this spring with “Sing You Home,” a novel about gay parenthood and embryonic rights — argues convincingly for Twain as a role model, emphasizing “how he balanced social commentary with a commercial fiction appeal.”

headline: Conjuring Abstraction and Subtlety Onstage
text: I WILL watch Jodi Melnick do pretty much anything. More than watch, I will be transfixed. All she has to do is unfurl one of those marvelously expressive arms of hers or step through a phrase so delicately wrought it might almost not be there, and I’m hooked, sent over the moon by her ability to conjure, just for a moment, those subtle, passing states of mind and emotion that suffuse the human condition.

headline: A Writer of Bodies Delves Into Survival
text: WITH so much turmoil in the world, isn’t it time for some inspiring dance? Something that indicates the delicate line between struggle and hope? Rachid Ouramdane is coming to town, and I’ve never seen anything by him that hasn’t made my jaw drop.

headline: Philip Glass, A Minimalist Maximized
text: WHEN the notion of the Park Avenue Armory’s becoming a temporary home for the New York Philharmonic during a proposed refurbishing of Avery Fisher Hall (still waiting) was raised, listeners were understandably skeptical: could the hangarlike Wade Thompson Drill Hall possibly be configured as an acoustically appropriate space for concert performances? Those doubts began to vanish in 2008, when the Lincoln Center Festival presented Bernd Alois Zimmermann’s opera “Die Soldaten” at the armory. And in February, the armory itself brought in Eighth Blackbird, the adventurous new-music ensemble, to assemble its first Tune-In Festival, which was judged a hit.

headline: Preaching With Gerard Butler
text: TORONTO — The Marc Forster film “Machine Gun Preacher” is based on the true story of Sam Childers, a Pennsylvania biker and former drug dealer who found religion and became an advocate for the children of war-torn Sudan. Mr. Childers is played by Gerard Butler, who also is appearing in another Toronto film: Ralph Fiennes’s version of “Coriolanus.” Mr. Butler spoke about his role in “Machine Gun Preacher” and the techniques he used to embody the character of Mr. Childers.

headline: For This Director, Mozart’s Message Is That Love Hurts
text: CHRISTOPHER ALDEN’S production of Mozart’s “Così Fan Tutte” for New York City Opera will be set in a park as night falls, enveloping the characters in darkness as they play out the plot’s cruel game: two men, egged on by an older friend, disguise themselves to test their fiancées’ fidelity, a test both fail.

headline: Pride at the Piano: Schiff Playing Bartok
text: PIANOPHILES in New York are privileged to hear many first-rate concerts each season by rising stars and established pianists. But only a few of them — including Mitsuko Uchida, Martha Argerich and Andras Schiff — can be counted on for revelatory and transcendent interpretations.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Threeasfour
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#690", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

headline: Perry Sharpens His Attacks on Romney
text: NEWTON, Iowa — On the campaign trial in Iowa, Texas Gov. Rick Perry isn’t answering questions — or even taking questions — on any of the key issues his Republican rivals attacked him on during last Monday’s debate. Instead, he’s sharpening his attacks on Mitt Romney, the former Massachusetts governor.

headline: Romney Tries to Pin Familiar ‘Flip-Flop’ Label on Perry
text: Mitt Romney has struggled for years to shake off a politically damaging reputation as a flip-flopper.

headline: DC Comics Writer Resigns From ‘Static Shock’ Series
text: A few days into a much-publicized shakeup of its superhero titles, DC Comics has experienced a less pleasant tremor with the resignation of the writer of “Static Shock,” one of 52 comic books that the publisher restarted at issue No. 1 this month.

headline: U.A.W. Reaches Tentative Agreement With General Motors
text: DETROIT — The United Automobile Workers and General Motors said late Friday that they had reached a tentative agreement on a new labor contract.

headline: Calls for Shakeup in White House That Prizes Constancy
text: He has probably been quoted more than any pundit on the planet since 1992 (which, by the way, was the last time he actually won an American campaign), but when James Carville opens his mouth, Democrats still tend to listen. And so it got a lot of people talking this week when Mr. Carville, in an open letter for President Obama on CNN’s Web site, urged the struggling president to follow the example of some of his predecessors and just fire a bunch of people.

headline: The Bounty of Solitude
text: LESLIE FEIST, the songwriter who records as Feist, led a visitor up a winding trail to a hilltop with expansive views of treetops and a reservoir. Bounding ahead were her two mongrel dogs: the white Sasha, described by her owner as “hyperemotional, sometimes gets depressed,” and the black Bentley, who’s “just out for a good time.” Feist added, “They’re both like me.”

headline: ‘The Golden Empire’
At Audi Display in Frankfurt, One Ring to Rule Them
text: FRANKFURT — From the company identified by four rings, came one very big ring.

headline: ‘There but for the’
text: There

headline: Korea Envoys to Discuss Resuming Nuclear Talks
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The top nuclear negotiators from North and South Korea plan to meet next week in Beijing to discuss terms of restarting the long-stalled six-nation talks aimed at ending North Korea’s nuclear weapons program, a senior government official here said Friday.

headline: The Caucus | Cooperation Remains Elusive
text: In Washington, developments this week tempered some of the hope for bipartisan cooperation. Meanwhile, a new Times/CBS News poll shows Congressional disapproval at record levels.

headline: This Time It’s Crosswords (Not Cross Words) That Surface From Sondheim
text: For decades they have been an elusive collector’s item sought by puzzle fans and musical theater aficionados alike: The cryptic crosswords that the celebrated composer Stephen Sondheim created for New York magazine in the late 1960s and that were later compiled in a book that has long been out of print. But earlier this week some online chat sites devoted to puzzles began to buzz about a Web site that included scans of 19 crosswords that were apparently the Sondheim mother lode. “These are the gold standard for sure!” one commenter gushed on Facebook.

headline: Gundlach Found Liable in Trade Secret Case, but He Wins Back Pay
text: A bitter trial that rattled the normally quiet world of mutual funds came to an unusual end on Friday, as a jury awarded Jeffrey E. Gundlach, a star bond fund manager, millions of dollars in unpaid compensation even though it found him liable for breaching his fiduciary duty and stealing trade secrets at his former firm, Trust Company of the West.

headline: Runway In Review
text: Calvin Klein CollectionDesigner: Francisco CostaDate and Location: Thursday, 205 West 39th StreetPhotos: slide show

headline: Ameriprise Speaks With a New Voice
text: With Labor Day in the rearview mirror, Madison Avenue is fully engaged in bringing out new advertising campaigns for scores of marketers. The idea is to connect with consumers during the important fall and Christmas shopping seasons.

headline: Caucus Video: Hope Tempered for Cooperation; Voter Disapproval of Congress at Record Levels
text: In Washington, developments this week tempered some of the hope for bipartisan cooperation. Meanwhile, a new New York Times/CBS News poll shows Congressional disapproval at record levels.

headline: Artists Support Global Fund Health Efforts
text: A diverse group of actors and artists has come out in support of a global charity that fights some of the world’s deadliest diseases.

headline: Drop of Opera in a Downpour of Pop
text: Ordinarily it is difficult for officials to estimate the crowd size for a concert in Central Park. But every attendee at Thursday night’s free performance there by the superstar crossover tenor Andrea Bocelli had to have a ticket, obtained in advance. And 60,000 were given out.

headline: Step Away From the Fashion Police
text: I work with a woman who never left 1985: She clips a fake ponytail into her hair (with scrunchies to match her outfits), curls her bangs and wears blue eye shadow. We got along pretty well — until I got drunk at a company party and told her she was one banana clip away from appearing as a “Don’t Do This!” model in a women’s magazine. (I also told her she’s a great person.) The next day, the fake hair was gone, which she made a point of showing me. Now I feel guilty. Who am I to tell her how to look? Should I apologize?

headline: Two Venture Capitalists Exit Twitter Board
text: Twitter confirmed on Friday that two of its board members, Fred Wilson, a principal at the venture capital firm Union Square Ventures, and Bijan Sabet, a general partner at Spark Capital, have left the board.

headline: Retired, Perhaps, but Still on the Case
text: If you were looking to stick up a restaurant on Thursday night, the Battery Gardens restaurant in Lower Manhattan would have been a bad choice.

headline: Faces to Watch
text: Five performers from this season of fall movies find themselves on the verge.

headline: Sept. 18-Sept. 24
text: Theater

headline: How to Rate 401(k) Plans and Investment Advisers
text: In this week’s Your Money column, I chronicle the adventures of the BrightScope brothers, two young men who aim to rate every 401(k) and 403(b) retirement plan and publish a directory of every investment adviser, too.

headline: Spotlighting 401(k) Plans, Thanklessly
text: SAN DIEGO — Up the stairs from the Chicken of the Sea offices in the northern reaches of this city, two brothers and about three dozen of their employees mine databases in a fledgling effort to help Americans retire a little sooner and manage their money a little better.

headline: Multimedia | Rauschenberg’s Photos
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#263", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: There Shall Come a Titan
text: “The New Teen Titans” omnibus, Vol. 1, sits atop the hardcover list this week. It reprints the first 16 issues of the 1980s series that brought together a few sidekick heroes (Robin, Kid Flash and Wonder Girl) and teamed them with some new ones (Cyborg, Raven and Starfire). These Titans, written by Marv Wolfman and illustrated by George Pérez, become one of DC’s most popular books. The stories reprinted in this omnibus edition chronicle the formation of the team, faceoffs with the assassin Deathstroke and the Fearsome Five, a misguided confrontation with the Justice League and a battle royal against Trigon, a demon who is also Raven’s father. About midway in there is a “day in the life” story that focused on the civilian lives of the heroes. That issue cemented this series as doing something different: the creative team was developing three-dimensional characters and exploring new directions.

headline: Unbeaten Boxer Pioneers Ways to Make Money Hand Over Fist
text: LAS VEGAS — On Saturday night, Floyd Mayweather Jr. will make tens of millions of dollars for an hour’s worth of work, if that. He will be paid for what happens inside the ring and outside it, paid far more than any other boxer fighting today, for far more than just his performance in a welterweight title fight against Victor Ortiz.

headline: Cold-Water Detergents Get a Cold Shoulder
text: Newly formulated laundry detergents can wash most clothes perfectly well in cold water, manufacturers say, but customers are stubbornly refusing to turn down the temperature. Although some of these detergents have been available for several years, customers cling to mom’s age-old advice that hot water washes best — squandering energy and contributing to greenhouse gas emissions.

headline: Decoding the Wide Variations in House Appraisals
text: I RECENTLY decided to refinance a condominium my wife and I owned in Florida and quickly got caught up in the frustrating and often baffling world of real estate appraisals.

headline: Alabama County’s Debt Deal Averts Bankruptcy
text: The governing board of Alabama’s most populous county voted Friday to accept an agreement on how to restructure more than $3 billion of debt, avoiding what could have been the biggest municipal bankruptcy filing in American history.

headline: Was Pat Robertson Right?
text: The question from a viewer of “The 700 Club” had likely crossed the minds of hundreds of thousands of people experiencing the slow and inevitable loss of a spouse to Alzheimer’s disease or another dementia. Could a healthy partner justify a relationship with someone else as a demented spouse declined?

headline: Handling Disasters, on Screen or Off, With Aplomb
text: IN the first of two acclaimed performances by Kirsten Dunst at the 64th Cannes Film Festival in May, a rapt audience watched as a dozen emotions — amusement, stoicism, distress, weariness, embarrassment and rue among them — played across her features in a scene in which she was required to maintain her composure at every moment and express an extraordinary range of feeling with almost no dialogue.

headline: Wanting to Get Into the Fight, and Failing
text: Just because you volunteer to serve your country does not mean you will ever be sent into harm’s way, even if you want to. No matter how patriotic or noble your intentions, the needs of the military come first, and that organization is a very focused machine that maintains a combat force structure based on units and their capabilities, not individuals and their desires. That policy has a side effect of leaving some of us bearing a burden of guilt at not having done more.

headline: Love, Divorce and Alzheimer’s
text: The television evangelist Pat Robertson has sparked controversy with his suggestion that a man could divorce his wife with Alzheimer’s once she no longer recognized him.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $23,680,000
text: A penthouse condominium at the Mayfair on Park Avenue was the highest sale of the week, according to city property records.

headline: Defiant Crowds Face Deadly Gunfire in Syria
text: Protesters faced down deadly gunfire from Syrian security forces on Friday as they returned to the streets of several restive cities, as Anthony Shadid reports. Videos captured their marches, as well as some of the violence that left dozens dead, the latest in the six-month crackdown that has left more than 2,600 dead.

headline: Top Offshore Drilling Regulators Named
text: Interior Secretary Ken Salazar on Friday appointed leaders for the two entities that will assume responsibility for offshore oil and gas development.

headline: The Kindly Ones
text: Via Reihan Salam, I see that Virginia Postrel has published a tart response to Harvard College’s attempt to pressure its incoming freshmen into taking a public pledge promising to place “the exercise of kindness … on a par with intellectual attainment” during their undergraduate careers.

headline: Gassing Up Nascar V-8s
text: THE fuel injection systems that will replace four-barrel carburetors on all cars in Nascar’s top-level Sprint Cup series for 2012 will use some components similar to those found on today’s passenger cars and others that are little changed from current racing engines.

headline: Musicals Festival Diary: New Mother, Old Habits
text: Being a new mother hasn’t stopped the actress Donna Lynne Champlin (“Sweeney Todd”) from returning to the stage. She is starring in “Jane Austen’s Pride and Prejudice, a Musical,” part of the eighth New York Musical Theater Festival, which begins Sept. 26.

headline: Games to Watch on Saturday: A Test for Oklahoma
text: No. 1 Oklahoma at No. 5 Florida State 8 p.m., ABC

headline: The Taormina Sisters and the Misuraca Brothers
text: THE back-to-back weddings on a rain-drenched day in Gloucester, Mass., might never have happened if Caterina Taormina’s older sister Patty Hodges did not have a big mouth.

headline: A Park With a Past
text: Coiba National Park in Panama, an isolated marine preserve 14 miles off the Pacific coast, is a paradise for nature lovers.

headline: A Panamanian Marine Preserve With a Past
text: A LOGGERHEAD turtle swiveled its spotted head toward me, then disappeared beneath the waves as I slipped over the side of the boat with my snorkel, mask and fins. Instantly, a Technicolor underwater world revealed itself: pastel-patched parrotfish, tiny purple-fairy maidens, big-eyed red squirrelfish and a school of purple finned sturgeonfish darting in and out of orange stag coral and purple sea fans. I followed a slow-moving grouper into deeper water and suddenly, swimming out of the depths, six white-tip sharks emerged, sending me thrashing in the boat’s direction, calling for a lift out.

headline: Emmys Watch: Christina Hendricks on ‘Mad Men’
text: Christina Hendricks began as a guest star on “Mad Men” — she was in only two scenes in the pilot — but her Joan Holloway (now Joan Harris) quickly became one of the most recognizable characters on AMC’s perpetually praised midcentury drama.

headline: Yanks on the Tube: A Weekend TV Guide
text: You have got to have a plan these days.

headline: Meatloaf Again? Not Exactly
text: MY mother’s meatloaf was correct — moist, well seasoned, part oatmeal, mostly beef, with a band of bottled red chili sauce down the center. It was dependable, but it was not the stuff of dreams. Other mothers’ meatloaf recipes sometimes appeared, like a stuffed, cheesy one I liked, but mostly the house version prevailed throughout my childhood. To my emerging sensibilities, the occasional stuffed cabbage was more interesting, and chafing-dish Swedish meatballs had a certain appeal. I also liked the smell of hamburgers before they were cooked, sprinkled with salt and pepper and resting on wax paper.

headline: In Buenos Aires, Sips From All Over
text: FOR visitors to Argentina, missing out on Mendoza, the country’s main wine region, doesn’t mean missing out on its wines — or, for that matter, those of other Argentine regions. In the last few years, a number of wine-tasting opportunities have opened in Buenos Aires, offering samples of the best the country’s vineyards have to offer.

headline: Hotel Review: Hotel Mio in Buenos Aires
text: THE UPSHOT

headline: Letters: My Kailua
text: My Kailua

headline: Suriname, South America’s Hidden Treasure
text: THE road to Atjoni got more interesting as the wind grew stronger, making the surrounding ceiba trees of the Surinamese jungle murmur with whispers of an impending storm. We were hours into the country’s interior when we came across a solitary hunter. He had a shotgun slung from his shoulder and a machete sheathed at his waist. We stopped to talk. After brief introductions, things became complicated.

headline: In Uruguay, Bohemian-Chic at the Beach
text: WHEN summer arrives in December, La Pedrera’s main street bustles with families dining al fresco, sandy-haired teenagers hanging out in board shorts, jazz musicians entertaining passers-by and artisans selling handmade jewelry on makeshift stands.

headline: In Argentina, Glaciers by Way of Patagonia
text: THE boat slid across the teal waters of Lago Argentino, and soon we were 900 feet from the Perito Moreno Glacier. Through the morning rain, the glacier loomed above us — a jagged wonder glowing with colors: aquamarine, pure white, pale gray and an otherworldly, nearly fluorescent blue. Every few seconds there was a thunderous crack, and a chunk of ice, distant and unseen, went crashing into the ice field.

headline: Street of Art by Buenos Aires
text: In Tigre, outside Buenos Aires, Boulevard Saenz Peña reflects the interests of art lovers.

headline: The Charm of Suriname
text: Suriname proves that there are still corners of the world that can provide surprise and adventure.

headline: Practice Time for Injured Giants
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — There seemed to be promising developments for the banged-up Giants at practice Friday, with defensive end Justin Tuck and receiver Hakeem Nicks participating in individual drills. Even Osi Umenyiora looked good.

headline: New York Fashion Week Diary | Tom Bull
text: Isaac Hindin Miller of Isaac Likes followed the breakout Aussie model Tom Bull as he navigated New York Fashion Week. In this clip, Tom Bull discusses his “edgy” beard: “The amount of commercial clients asking me to get rid of it is crazy. Unless it’s something big, I won’t.”

text: Mercedes-Benz USA is taking another crack at selling Americans on the mini-size Smart car, which has recently been selling in mini-size numbers after a good start.

headline: On ‘Project Runway,’ a Dose of Reality
text: Real women have curves. That simple fact of anatomy seemed to flummox the contestants on “Project Runway” last night as they faced what appeared to be their most challenging task of the season: designing clothes suitable for women who don’t consider a cigarette and a couple of Altoids a satisfying meal.

headline: Video View: ‘Climate Refugees’
text: Anyone tracking global issues these days is flooded with multiple fire hoses of material — books, documentaries, blogs and more. This makes it impossible for any individual to assess what’s out there. One film I missed is “Climate Refugees,” a documentary that’s done well on the film festival circuit and been lauded by environmentalists. You can read about it on the Green Blog.

headline: ‘The Beautiful and the Damned’
text: A phenomenally wealthy Indian who excites hostility and suspicion is an unusual creature, a fish that has managed to muddy the waters it swims in. The glow of admiration lighting up the rich and the successful disperses before it reaches him, hinting that things have gone wrong somewhere. It suggests that beneath the sleek coating of luxury, deep under the sheen of power, there is a failure barely sensed by the man who owns that failure along with his expensive accoutrements. This was Arindam Chaudhuri’s situation when I first met him in 2007. He had achieved great wealth and prominence, partly by projecting an image of himself as wealthy and prominent. Yet somewhere along the way he had also created the opposite effect, which – in spite of his best efforts – had given him a reputation as a fraud, scamster and Johnny-come-lately.

headline: A Brother, Lost and Found
text: MY brother Dario was kidnapped for two years. He was taken when he was 7 and returned when he was 9. During his absence, he grew six inches and lost most of his baby teeth.

headline: Texas Execution Stayed Based on Race Testimony
text: HOUSTON — In May 1997, a psychologist took the stand in a courtroom here during the sentencing hearing of Duane E. Buck, a black man found guilty of killing his former girlfriend and her friend.

But appearances, on this recent Saturday night, were very much deceiving.

But its surpluses with the United States and some major European countries have risen to record levels.

headline: The Problem With Living Wills for Financial Firms
text: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation took an important step this week toward getting big financial institutions, foreign and domestic, to submit resolution plans — also known as living wills or funeral plans — as required by the Dodd-Frank Act. If the new, so-called orderly liquidation authority is going to work, it is going to depend on F.D.I.C.’s ability to understand and plan for financial distress in advance. And thus the living wills are key.

text: In what can be described as a broadcast television calm before the storm of the fall season, CBS won the night over all on Thursday with a slate of repeats. “Wipeout” on ABC was the only original program on the four big networks, and it finished the season rather meekly, down by 19 percent from last year’s two-hour finale in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic according to Nielsen data.

headline: Members Disapprove of Debt Ceiling Increase, No Matter What Their Votes Say
text: Wednesday’s House vote disapproving the recent increase in the nation’s debt limit was unusual in at least one respect: it drew opposition from five Republicans, including a committee chairman, two of whom now say they didn’t mean to oppose the nonbinding resolution.

text: I called George Shultz, the former more-or-less everything, this week to see what he thought of the government now. I discovered that he is rankled by the budget process but impressed by at least one candidate for the Republican presidential nomination.

headline: Q. and A.: The Quest of the Earth Scientist
text: Ralph J. Cicerone, president of the National Academy of Sciences, was back in his old haunt this week, celebrating the 20th anniversary of the University of California, Irvine’s Department of Earth System Science, which he founded. He later served as the university’s chancellor. Dr. Cicerone spoke with The New York Times about scientific research on the campus, the national attitude toward science today and the scientific questions he would most like to see answered. Following are excepts, edited for brevity and clarity.

headline: It All Leads to This: Cunningham’s Final Bow
text: WHEN the impresario Serge Diaghilev died in 1929, the Ballets Russes — the company he had formed in 1909 — folded with him. The sense of loss was so abysslike that in the years that followed several new companies around the Western world (some also bearing the name Ballets Russes) were established to recapture his achievement. Still, much had been lost. Some of his most celebrated dancers retired at once or soon after. Only one of his five choreographers (George Balanchine) went on — eventually — to bigger and better things. Seldom since then has ballet had the same force as a vehicle for the new.

text: In the Styles section this weekend, Alex Williams looks at how men are taking that study out of Northwestern University showing that testosterone, the most male of hormones, decreases substantially after a man becomes a father.

headline: Not Quite Gone, A Punk Band Is Coming Back
text: PROPOSITION: No punk band of the 1990s has been more influential than Blink-182.

headline: A Glimpse Into the World of House Appraisals
text: Paul Sullivan writes about the daunting, frustrating world of real estate appraisals in his Wealth Matters column this week. He writes from personal experience, after getting two different appraisals on his Florida condominium, neither of which made sense to him.

headline: A Father-Son Journey Continues
text: AMERICANS have elected men to the highest office in the land in the hope that they would be tough but fair, regular guys but still presidential. You know, like Josiah Bartlet, who reigned with dignity for seven seasons on “The West Wing” on NBC. During some of the more feckless stretches of the presidency people have even suggested that Martin Sheen, who played Bartlet, should give it a whirl for real. Mr. Sheen has heard the cry of the people and is in the midst of a 55-day cross-country bus campaign. But it’s to persuade his supporters to go out and see “The Way,” his new film, which was directed by his son Emilio Estevez.

headline: The Storyteller Who Returned From the Cold
text: THE Englishman David Cornwell, who writes under the name John le Carré, has been a best-selling novelist for nearly five decades, and he has been, right from the start, an unusually perverse member of that select class: he writes books that practically beg not to be turned into movies. Of his 22 novels nearly all of them about the perennially popular and movie-friendly subject of espionage, a mere 7 have made the perilous border crossing to the big screen. (Three others have been adapted as television mini-series and one more as a stand-alone television movie.)

headline: Myung & Aaron
text: In this homemade video, Myung Joh and Aaron Wesner recall meeting at a rooftop party.

headline: Legal Assistance in Civil Cases Under Growing Threat
text: Both houses of Congress have indicated that they plan to cut back federal financing for the Legal Services Corporation, the nation’s largest provider of money to assist people who cannot afford lawyers in civil cases, according to an article in The National Law Journal.

headline: Shooters Face Off, and the Legend of Zelda Continues
text: THIS fall will be the seventh for the current generation of video game consoles, which began with Microsoft’s introduction of the Xbox 360 in 2005. That means artists, designers and programmers have had a long time to master the intricacies of the 360, as well as two Japanese consoles that arrived in 2006, Sony’s PlayStation 3 and Nintendo’s Wii.

headline: On Top of Country but Also Above It
text: THE 27-year-old country singer Miranda Lambert, whose fourth and latest album, “Four the Record,” comes out Nov. 1, is in the rare position, for any young performer, of having nothing in need of proving. But “Four the Record” tries hard anyway, moving into layers of alternativeness and smeared genre, in country and rock and folk, and sound itself.

headline: Ronaldus Shamask Returns
text: Ronaldus Shamask thinks he was the first designer to show at the New York Public Library, in the Celeste Bartos Forum. He cannot recall the year, but suffice to say the tents and all the hoopla had not yet arrived. “I paid $1 for the library,” Mr. Shamask, 66, said with a grin on Friday morning in his studio on West 38th Street.

headline: TimesCast | Syria's Bloody Uprising
text: Syrian security forces kill at least 29 pro-democracy protesters, as the six-month uprising shows signs of even greater bloodshed to come.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Marc Jacobs
text: There was a little bit of everything on the dance floor at Marc Jacobs last night — the Charleston (fringed, dropped-waist flapper dresses); “A Chorus Line” (models backlit and posed on bentwood chairs); a good old honky-tonk two-step (sharp-heeled cowboy boots). What’s here: a witchy Mary Jane that feels curiously “Dirty Dancing”-esque in its sexiness.

headline: Composer (and Others) Rethinking His Works
text: THROUGHOUT a lengthy, influential career the composer and vocalist Robert Ashley has designed his groundbreaking series of operas — dizzying confluences of spoken and sung words, electronic music, video elements, mystery and charm — to be performed by himself and a tightly knit group of regular collaborators.

headline: Sony Changes Gaming Policy to Thwart Future Lawsuits
text: Sony quietly updated its PlayStation Network terms of service agreement on Thursday, adding a new section that will prevent users from joining future class-action lawsuits against the company.

text: The setting was stunning. The dancers were heavenly. The magical sunset light was exactly what we aimed for. The smell was not so good.

headline: Obama Warns Iceland on Whaling Activity
text: In a move hailed by conservation activists, President Obama initiated potential diplomatic sanctions against Iceland this week for its commercial whaling activity. The sanctions include six measures ranging from possibly limiting cabinet-level visits to Iceland to limiting cooperation with Iceland in the Arctic region.

headline: New AIDS Cases Dropped 25% This Year, City Reports
text: In a sign of progress against one of the great plagues of the last generation, a dwindling number of New Yorkers have been diagnosed with AIDS over the last eight years, according to new statistics released Friday.

headline: United Technologies Said to Pursue Goodrich

headline: This Sunday: Exiting the Comfort Zone
text: I met Cliff Levy for the first time when he was in New York to collect his Pulitzer Prize last spring. He came up to my office and pitched a story about how he put his three Brooklyn-bred kids in a Russian school, even though they didn’t speak the language, when he was sent to Moscow as a correspondent for The Times. I could hardly say yes fast enough to his story, which I knew would fascinate the many people on this earth obsessed with how best to educate their children. But I also privately wondered if maybe Cliff wasn’t a little insane. I have twin daughters who just started kindergarten this week, and though their school could not be a warmer, more welcoming place — they even speak English there! — I still worry about their adjustment to an unfamiliar environment.

headline: No Blood, No Gore, Just Megatons of Steel
text: When I could have been doing something healthy recently, like going to the gym, I was probably sniping with a Panzer IV from the escarpments of a desert called El Halluf. When I should have been doing something responsible, like scrubbing the tub, I was probably barreling around a European town called Himmelsdorf in an “Easy Eight” Sherman. Even when I should have been playing some other game, I was probably playing World of Tanks, a concussively enjoyable, shrewdly designed armored-combat game.

headline: New Fantasy: Viewing Like It’s 1979
text: IN advance of the debt-ceiling debate in Congress this summer, morning-show pundits repeatedly compared the moment with 1979 both in terms of specific economic realities and the bleak, broader cultural mood. In 1979 the country similarly faced the danger of defaulting on its financial obligations; growth lagged; the Iranian revolution sparked turmoil in the Middle East. Catastrophists found validation for their unease in the disaster at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant in Pennsylvania just as bizarre shifts in weather patterns today seem to confirm our darkest worries about global warming.

headline: Beethoven, Messiaen and Background Checks
text: Listeners and performers are often curious about what inspired a particular piece of music. But in the opening program of his engaging Reflections series on Wednesday evening, “Divine Inspiration or Intelligent Design?,” the violinist Gil Morgenstern pondered whether knowing the source of inspiration actually enhances the experience for musician or audience.

headline: Bringing Nascar to Race Fans, One Spray ‘n Wax at a Time
text: For a sport whose founding myth is steeped in Appalachian mud and moonshine, Nascar has a curious preoccupation with cleanliness. Drivers are expected to play nice with the media, talk glowingly of their sponsors and avoid, for the most part, “racing dirty.” Now, stock-car fans can affect the same virtue as their favorite drivers, if only for a few minutes at the car wash.

headline: Kill the Alarm and Rev Up the Vespa
text: David Karp, 25, the founder and chief executive of Tumblr, lives his life out loud on his sleek blogging platform. He and his girlfriend, Rachel Eakley, who is a trained chef and a graduate student in psychology, recently moved to the West Village, where they spend their weekends exploring their new neighborhood and playing with their puppy, Clark, a French-English bulldog mix. Pictures from their meandering Sundays just might end up on Mr. Karp’s Tumblr.

headline: Jane Lynch Finds Herself

headline: Verlander Could Reach Rarefied Air
text: The wins just keep piling up for Justin Verlander, the Detroit Tigers’ ace. On Tuesday, his seven scoreless innings propelled Detroit to a 5-0 victory over the Chicago White Sox, the 23rd time this season that Verlander was the pitcher of record in a Tigers win. If Verlander can win his final two starts of the regular season, he will become the first 25-game winner in more than 20 years.
