text: To the Editor:

headline: A Way Out of the Labor Stalemate
text: Somewhere between the foolish ravings of hard-line owners and the players’ union myopia lies an N.B.A. collective bargaining agreement that is ready to be wrapped and tied — just not too tight.

headline: Bikes in the City: Pleasures and Perils
text: To the Editor:

headline: Striding Confidently Toward the Light
text: By the end of Fashion Week, we had seen many a woman with a “wan, scornful mouth.” We had seen a surplus of blue crepe de Chine, rippling white, and rooms “gaudy with primary colors, and hair shorn in strange new ways.” If any of us had looked, we might even have seen Daisy’s green light.

headline: Fast and Furious for a Designer Week
text: OLIVIA MUNN, 31, is a correspondent for “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart” and a featured actress in the film “I Don’t Know How She Does It.” She is based in Los Angeles but visited New York for Fashion Week.

headline: Even in a Swoony Show, Innocence Stays Intact
text: For how long can one singing actor embody an ingenuous golden boy exempt from the laws of nature? That question occurred to me while watching Howard McGillin’s swoony show “Isn’t It Romantic?” at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel on Wednesday evening.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Sept. 16
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, a special election in the Ninth Congressional District of New York, and new principals for Newark schools.

headline: Where Graffiti Met Old Masters, Under Riverside Park
text: From 1980 to 1996, Chris Pape painted huge murals on the walls of an abandoned underground freight train passageway. Surprisingly, many survived leaks, soot and other vandals.

headline: Words With Strangers
text: MY frequent online Scrabble opponent of the last few days has sent me a message saying he’s sorry, but he can’t play right now. He has a “stomach bug/malaria,” he writes. Such are the considerations when your opponent lives in Ghana.

headline: TimesCast | Palestinian Statehood Vote
text: September 16, 2011 - Palestinian president Mahmoud Abbas says he will seek formal recognition of a Palestinian state at the U.N. Security Council next week.

headline: October Release Schedule
text: OCTOBER

headline: Driving the Saab 9-4X
text: A couple of weeks ago, when I took delivery of a Saab 9-4X test car for a few days, a wistful thought arrived with the keyfob: this could well be the last new Saab I’d ever drive.

headline: November Release Schedule
text: NOVEMBER

headline: Fashion Week Parties, Night 8
text: Scenes from Thursday: The Daphne Guinness show at F.I.T. and Marc Jacobs at the Gallery.

headline: December Release Schedule
text: DECEMBER

headline: Sgt. Brian Keith
text: After a year in Afghanistan, Sgt. Brian Keith talks about seeing his young son for the first time.

headline: Interview with Sgt. Jerry Price
text: Sgt. Jerry Price describes the experience of being trapped in a minefield on Qurghan Tapa hill in Afghanistan.

headline: Staff Sgt. Jonathon Clark Interview
text: About halfway through his deployment, Staff Sgt. Jonathon Clark reflects on what it was like to see his family while on leave.

headline: James Franco and Other Art Stars of the Toronto Film Festival
text: TORONTO — It is increasingly de rigeur for film festivals to encompass much more than film. Many major festivals now supplement screenings with installations and performances, and entire sections are devoted to exploring the intersection of cinema and the other arts. The Rotterdam Film Festival pioneered this kind of cross-disciplinary programming in the ’90s. Berlin has an annual Forum Expanded mini-festival, which spills logically into the museums and galleries of an art-centric city. Sundance has a New Frontier sidebar. And since 2007 the Toronto International Film Festival has made room for film-based art installations in the Future Projections program.

headline: Staff Sgt. Jonathon Clark Interview
text: About halfway through the deployment, Sergeant Clark reflects on how it is going.

headline: Male Models at the Line of Beauty
text: CONSIDER the red-backed fairy wren. The males, one of nature’s dandies, have coal-black plumage, scarlet capes and wings with yellow trim. The females are gray-brown with just a bit of speckling. If a female flew by, you’d think: “wren.” If a male flew by, you’d think: “wow.”

headline: Digital Age Drives Rally to Keep a Georgia Inmate From Execution
text: ATLANTA — As Troy Davis faces his fourth execution date, the effort to save him has come to rival the most celebrated death row campaigns in recent history.

headline: Sgt. Robert Smith Interview on Family
text: About halfway through his deployment, Sgt. Robert Smith talks about changes that have happened in his relationship with his daughter and her mother.

headline: Sgt. Robert Smith Interview
text: About halfway through his deployment, Sgt. Robert Smith reflects on how it is going.

headline: Ride This Bike? Nay. This Beauty’s Made for Framing.
text: STEP into the tight entryway of Noah John Gellner’s compact studio apartment on the Upper West Side, and try to squeeze past the everyday bicycles perched on their hooks. There is his road bike — a titanium rocket from Colorado — and hanging below it, a customized mountain bike, also titanium.

headline: Dodgers’ Biggest Foes Could Be M.L.B. and Fox
text: The Los Angeles Dodgers are seeking a bankruptcy court judge’s approval to auction off the team’s future cable television rights. But in so doing, they might run into stiff opposition from Major League Baseball and Fox.

headline: Sgt. Henry Negron-Diaz on Family
text: About halfway through his deployment, Sgt. Henry Negron-Diaz gives an update on his family.

headline: Sgt. Henry Negron-Diaz Interview
text: About halfway through his deployment, Sgt. Henry Negron-Diaz reflects on life in Afghanistan.

headline: A Man of God and Technology, Trying to Steady Libya
text: Tripoli, Libya

headline: A Big Twist in a Career, but Not Quite a 360
text: “Anderson,” a new syndicated daytime talk show, has been on only a week, and viewers already know more about Anderson Cooper than they’ve learned in the decade he has spent as a CNN anchor and correspondent.

headline: A Site-Specific Work Without the Site
text: Deganit Shemy & Company’s “2 kilos of sea” began life last year as a short, site-specific piece for two men and four women in a concrete churchyard near City Hall. During its move inside to the Baryshnikov Arts Center, the dance has expanded a little, shed a man, swapped two women and acquired a set. Lenore Doxsee has partitioned the stage with bright orange plastic netting and patches of fake grass. The artificial environment plays an important role, particularly the photo backdrop (of an empty pool) behind which the dancers can hide. But the work is now less about architecture and more about story.

headline: A Pacifist College Considers the National Anthem
text: At most American colleges, hearing “The Star-Spangled Banner” before sporting events is a regular feature of campus life, like getting shut out of the psychology lecture you needed or seeing pledges humiliated during fraternity rush. But at Goshen College, a Mennonite school in Indiana with a historical emphasis on pacifism, the tradition was not hearing the national anthem.

headline: Podcast: The European Crisis, the Guggenheim Family and Online Privacy
text: The European financial crisis has already roiled markets around the world, but it’s likely that worse is yet to come.

headline: Moving to a New Borough and Banking on Name Recognition
text: From its founding in 1978, the performance space Roulette has served as a crucial home base for a vast, amorphous mass of activity that could collectively be lumped under the imprecise rubric of avant-garde music. Originally established in the TriBeCa loft space of Jim Staley, a trombonist and composer whose genius for improvisation has run parallel to his skill as an entrepreneurial impresario, Roulette survived the waning of the downtown loft scene during the early 1980s and outlasted storied nightclubs like the original Knitting Factory and Tonic.

headline: Hot Seat for Sheen Promises the Warmth of the Limelight
text: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — Long before television and the Web crystallized our build-celebrities-up-then-knock-them-down culture, there were roasts: smoky, boozy affairs made famous by the Friars Club, where comedians privately traded barbs and pushed boundaries and, above all, bonded. The Friars’ motto: “We only roast the ones we love.”

headline: Magnate Ousted as Party Leader Cites Kremlin Discord
text: MOSCOW — Mikhail D. Prokhorov, the Russian billionaire who this week denounced the entire political system here as a sham, said in an interview on Friday that he had fallen victim to infighting in the Kremlin.

headline: A Scavenger Hunt by Smartphone
text: APP: The Pegleg

headline: ‘Dance in America’ for a New Generation
text: If you came of age in the late 1970s and ’80s, odds are you first encountered Martha Graham and modern dance not in a theater, but via television. Over the years the “Dance in America” program, which made its debut on PBS in 1976, introduced millions of Americans to major dance artists and their greatest works.

headline: Bloggingheads: A Moral Foreign Policy
text: F. Gregory Gause, left, of the University of Vermont and Shadi Hamid of the Brookings Doha Center debate morality in U.S. foreign policy.

headline: Unusual Benefactor Finances Book Tour
text: It is trickier than ever for an author to persuade a publisher to finance a traditional book tour. Brick-and-mortar bookstores are decreasing, travel is expensive, and money for marketing and promotion is increasingly being spent online.

headline: Where Diplomats and Young East Siders Collide
text: When Eduard Frauneder and Wolfgang Ban brought their brand of seasonal Austrian cooking down to a not-entirely-gentrified stretch of Avenue C near Seventh Street last December, many of their fans from the commissary at the German Mission to the United Nations and their high-end restaurant Seäsonal in Midtown followed along. As a result, on any given evening or weekend afternoon, Edi & the Wolf plays host to a mix of funky young Lower East Siders and buttoned-down diplomats. The room and its enclosed garden out back are fashioned after a Viennese wine tavern, with wood reclaimed from church benches, a church bell rope draped over the bar and a confessional bench in one of the bathrooms. On Tuesday night at Table 1, just inside the door, two Austrians and a German discussed travel and the anticipated street snarls when the world’s leaders flood the city for the meeting of the United Nations General Assembly this week. DIANE CARDWELL

headline: A Lost Girl of Ireland, Dealing With Its Lost Boys
text: Brigit, the recovering addict at the heart of Deirdre Kinahan’s “BogBoy,” having its United States premiere as part of the 1st Irish Theater Festival, has the kind of voice that stays with you. Combative and wry, she can make the simplest things sound sadly funny. Not that her life is a laughing matter. It’s too crowded with failure for that. And yet she seems to be doing better than Hughie, her reclusive neighbor in “the bleedin’ wilderness” of Navan, where she’s been sent from Dublin to get herself together.

headline: After Generations of Making Do, Yemenis Take Their New Hardships in Stride
text: SENNA, Yemen — In this stone village perched in the mountains surrounding the capital, Sana, people make do. The state-owned company that normally doles out cooking gas rarely provides these days. Even when it does, the price is prohibitive. Days go by with only a couple of hours of electricity.

headline: Questions Raised Over Letting Another Lender Help a Failing Solar Company
text: WASHINGTON — The political brawl over Solyndra, the solar array manufacturer that received $528 million in government aid and then went bankrupt, shifted focus Friday to a decision by the Energy Department that allowed another lender to step in to help rescue the company.

headline: Hadid to Design a Garage in Miami Beach
text: Miami Beach certainly values its parking. The city announced on Friday that Zaha Hadid, left, has joined the ranks of prominent architects lending their talents and star power to Miami Beach’s garages. Ms. Hadid is to design the garage at Collins Park, a neighborhood shared by the Miami City Ballet, the Bass Museum and the City Library. Among the “starchitects” who have designed garages are Frank Gehry; Herzog & de Meuron, Arquitectonica, Enrique Norten and Perkins & Will. “Even our parking garages are more than a group of parking spaces,” Matti Bower, the Miami Beach mayor, said in a statement. “Some have become destinations within themselves and have attained individual iconic status. Every building can be a work of art.”

headline: Let’s Talk About Death
text: As medical science has proven, death is hard to avoid. But it was especially hard this week.

headline: Where Football and Higher Education Mix
text: CHICAGO — The University of Chicago, well known for Saul Bellow, Milton Friedman and its links to 85 Nobel Prizes, was once famous sea to shining sea for football. It boasted a legendary coach, a Heisman Trophy winner and a national championship.

headline: Happy Illegal Holiday!
text: Newton, Mass.

headline: Americans Give Beijing Team Its Sole Loss at Hua Yuan Cup
text: At the Hua Yuan Cup world women’s elite tournament in Beijing this month, the highlight for the United States team of Lynn Baker, Karen McCallum, Cheri Bjerkan, Rozanne Pollack, Renee Mancuso and Pam Wittes was inflicting the only defeat on the victorious Beijing Hua Yuan team.

headline: Vito Perrone Sr., Who Fought Standardized Tests, Dies at 78
text: Vito Perrone Sr., a leading advocate for humanistic, regimentation-free public education and a mentor to several generations of liberal reformers who fought the tide of standardized testing, died on Aug. 24 in Cambridge, Mass. He was 78.

headline: Tuck Praises Spagnuolo and a System He Built
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Justin Tuck thought for a moment, his head cocked as he walked toward the cafeteria at the Giants’ training center. All week Tuck had been asked about the impact that Steve Spagnuolo, the former Giants’ defensive coordinator, had on the franchise, and minutes earlier, Tuck had praised Spagnuolo’s game-planning acumen to a group of reporters.

headline: Obama Adviser Discusses Using Military on Terrorists
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — John O. Brennan, the top counter-terrorism adviser to President Obama, on Friday defended a broad conception of where the United States can use military force against members of Al Qaeda and its allies.

headline: Jesús Silva, Priest Who Founded Spanish Boys Town, Dies at 78
text: Jesús Silva, a Spanish priest who responded to the problems of poor and neglected children in his native province, Galicia, by founding a self-governing Boys Town, whose children’s circus toured the world to great acclaim in the 1970s, died on Sept. 2 in Ourense, Spain. He was 78.

headline: U.N. Takes Steps to Assist Libya’s Transitional Leaders
text: UNITED NATIONS — The United Nations moved on two fronts on Friday to bolster the nascent Libyan government, with the Security Council lifting some economic sanctions and the General Assembly accepting the credentials of the transitional government to represent Libya in the world body.

headline: Off Radar and Flying Into Share of Lead
text: LEMONT, Ill. — There really was no logical way to predict that Justin Rose of England would follow his opening-round 63 with a 68 on Friday to share the 36-hole lead in the BMW Championship. Especially after his lackluster 2011 season in which he was winless on the PGA Tour and missed the cut at the Memorial and the United States Open.

headline: Learning From Hammarskjold
text: Tyringham, Mass.

headline: For Adoptive Parents, Questions Without Answers
text: IN almost any adoption, the new parents accept that their good fortune arises out of the hardship of the child’s first parents. The equation is usually tempered by the thought that the birth parents either are no longer alive or chose to give the child a better life than they could provide.

headline: Separated in Foster Care, Siblings Reunite in Camp
text: KATTSKILL BAY, N.Y. — The crisp morning swims in Lake George were quite a change of pace for Shakeema, an 8-year-old from Far Rockaway, Queens. But so was spending five days straight with her sisters, Kendra, 10, and Marquia, 7, who live in the Bronx.

headline: Charging $1 to Use the Restroom, and Paying the Price
text: Sure, you could have gotten a haircut at the Phenomenon Barber Shop in Brooklyn in the early morning hours of Labor Day, but that was just one of any number of reasons to have stopped by. It was also a place to dance, to relax, to hang out with friends and — regrettably, in hindsight — to use the restroom after a few drinks.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Gay-Marriage Foes See Message in House Race
text: Bob Turner’s victory over Assemblyman David I. Weprin in Tuesday’s special Congressional election has been chalked up to many factors: unhappiness with President Obama, the sluggish economy and the Middle East peace process, to name three.

headline: Quick as a Cat, a Coach and His Message Find Fame on the Internet
text: Truth be told, the man with the thick-as-grits Southern accent looked a little crazy on a video that went viral last week.

headline: Brothers and Sisters, Reacquainted
text: A camp in upstate New York offers siblings who have been separated in foster care a chance to send precious time together.

headline: ‘No Language Like Song’
text: Frederick Douglass spent much of his life speaking about the hardships of slavery — but even he, at times, realized that words were not enough. Instead, he turned to music: “The mere hearing of [slave] songs,” he said, revealed the “physical cruelties of the slave system; for the heart has no language like song.” Today, spirituals like “Go Down, Moses” and “God’s Going to Trouble the Water” continue to convey American slaves’ anguish, frustration and hope.

headline: Once a Redoubt Against China, Taiwan’s Outpost Evolves
text: KINMEN, Taiwan — Burrowing just a few feet beneath the surface of this island in the Taiwan Strait turns up remnants of what was once the most militarized zone on earth.

headline: Wood-Fired Tribute to Pizzerias of Naples
text: THERE is no doubt that Za’Za’ (erstwhile Rustico) in Scarsdale ranks as one of the more accomplished pizzerias around, and its pizza oven is a structure of wonder, an imported Neapolitan wood-burning beauty that does its job splendidly.

headline: Killing Jobs and Making Us Sick
text: “In January, Mr. Obama signed a food safety law that provides broad new authority to the Food and Drug Administration,” wrote Robert Pear in Friday’s Times, in an article about the Congressional appropriations mess. But House Republicans, he added, had voted “to cut the agency’s budget.”

headline: UBS Faces Questions on Oversight After a Trader Lost $2 Billion
text: Until this week, Kweku M. Adoboli was riding high, a young trader for a big bank, with a stylish apartment in a fashionable London neighborhood and a steady girlfriend.

headline: WikiLeaks Goes on eBay to Raise Cash
text: The opening bid for a steely portrait of Julian Assange — “one of only four photos of Julian in the world” that he signed on his 40th birthday in July, according to the accompanying text — was set at more than $900. It is among 10 pieces of memorabilia and services being auctioned online by WikiLeaks, the group that he founded.

headline: Jets Step Into the Past With Their Uniforms
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Rex Ryan likes to make references to the long-gone American Football League every chance he gets. On Friday, he was asked to compare Maurice Jones-Drew, the stocky and elusive Jacksonville Jaguars running back, to other ball carriers.

headline: Extra Fuel for Students
text: With school back in session, Maurizio Belli, the owner of Gianfranco’s, in Bedford Hills, finds his phones pretty much ringing off the wall. From his sprawling take-out menu of Italian specialties, one item in particular inspires calls: the “boss” wrap ($6.95), a high-calorie, supersize answer to the most extreme craving.

headline: Another Reason to Avoid His Friends
text: THE GIST His sex life suffers when she is too close to his friends.

headline: Let’s Hear It for Aunthood
text: FOR simplicity’s sake, let’s call me a childless spinster. So when my younger brother and his wife announced their first pregnancy, I — then in my mid-30s — listened hopefully for that famous tick-tock, and when it didn’t sound, slunk back to my familiar unknown. My indecision, I was forced to accept, was fast reaching its expiration date. And then on a bright March afternoon I entered a hushed delivery room, and my brother handed me a small white bundle, and I felt something, not maternal exactly, but decidedly formidable: a primal pull, a plummet. It was my niece, Sophie, 2 hours old.

headline: Saturday: Cause For Some Spatial Relationships
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — It is said, within some circles of crossword puzzle construction, that Saturdays are when the heavy lifters like to show off their stacks. Long, crunchy entries abound, foreign and complex words get shined up for their turn in the spotlight. Solvers are asked to ignore the sweat stains left after trying to formulate coherent Down entries all the way across rows of stacked 15s. I won’t even get into the cluing; you know what I’m talking about. Saturday is not for the faint of heart.

headline: Two Directors Leaving Twitter’s Board
text: Twitter said Friday that two of its board members, Fred Wilson, a principal at the venture capital firm Union Square Ventures, and Bijan Sabet, a general partner at Spark Capital, have left the board. Mr. Wilson, who writes a popular blog, is widely seen as an important figure in the company’s development. Union Square Ventures, which made its first investment in Twitter in 2007, and Spark Capital are two of the company’s earliest investors.

headline: Couple Accused of Stealing Millions Intended for Preschoolers’ Meals
text: A Staten Island couple stole at least $2.5 million in federal funds meant for nutritious meals for preschoolers, prosecutors asserted in a criminal complaint unsealed on Friday.

headline: Transatlantic and Allied Cancel Merger Plans
text: Transatlantic Holdings and Allied World Assurance called off their proposed $2.94 billion merger on Friday after the two insurers faced stiff shareholder opposition and two rival bids for Transatlantic. Transatlantic has been fending off a higher $3.01 billion takeover bid by another reinsurer, Validus Holdings, and had been in talks with a unit of Berkshire Hathaway that had offered $3.25 billion.

headline: Borderline Ridiculous
text: The United States is home to 11 million illegal immigrants. The undocumented hold jobs, have children, pay taxes, use government services — and too often live in fear. What is to be done about them? It’s a difficult question, and one the Republican presidential candidates in the last two debates spent a great deal of effort avoiding.

headline: On Day Devoted to Constitution, a Fight Over It
text: In the 100 years since Constitution Day was first established, most Americans have lumped it with holidays like Grandparents’ Day and Administrative Assistants’ day — a noble cause, lightly observed.

headline: Tehran’s Ambitions
text: Five years after the United Nations Security Council ordered it to halt, Iran is still enriching uranium and refusing to come clean about its nuclear program. Tehran is clearly hoping the world will either forget or acquiesce. That would be very dangerous.

headline: Stay of Execution
text: After granting a stay of execution to Duane Buck just hours before he was to be put to death in Texas on Thursday, the Supreme Court must now review the case or, at the very least, order a lower federal court to consider Mr. Buck’s plea for a new sentencing hearing. It cannot allow a terrible injustice to stand.

headline: Just Singing, and Mingling With Trumps, in the Rain
text: Several thousand people ringed Central Park in the rain on Thursday night, lining up for hours for a free concert by Andrea Bocelli. We pitied them as we flounced past the snaking line into the V.I.P. area, we swear. But our smugness was short lived: we were no better off.

headline: Sleek and Snappy, With No Gilded Dragons
text: THE stunningly modern black-and-white interior of China White, in Greenwich, is a far cry from the gilded dragon décor of old-time Chinese restaurants. Coupled with the snappy service of waiters and waitresses in immaculate white jumpsuits — outfits that evoked thoughts of the place’s former life as a Lotus car showroom — the smart look led to hopes of a fresh take on Chinese cuisine. But after three visits, those expectations were only partly fulfilled.

headline: New York’s Benighted
text: Can’t they get anything right? New York City’s hapless Board of Elections finally got new voting machines operating last year, replacing the 60-plus-year-old clunkers with electronic devices that are supposed to register and count votes quickly while retaining a paper trail for any recount. But the board has concocted such an overly complicated counting process that it took an extra day to report 100 percent of preliminary returns for the few races in this week’s primaries and special election. We shudder to think what will happen in the 2012 vote.

headline: Vietnamese Classics
text: With a menu listing largely traditional dishes, Miss Saigon Vietnamese Restaurant is a satisfying alternative to the plethora of Chinese and Pan-Asian eating spots in Connecticut. Its service is predictably efficient, portions are ample, and, most notably, pricing is quite reasonable.

headline: Quarterback’s Impressive Delivery Catches the Eye of Big Ten Coaches
text: EAST LANSING, Mich. — The annual Big Ten news media luncheon is largely a predictable affair. Coaches deliver optimistic clichés. Joe Paterno says something technologically backward that showcases his Internet naïveté. Everyone eats lunch and goes home.

headline: Red Apple Complaint
text: United States of America vs. Joanna Fan and Ziming Shen

headline: Turkish-Persian, in a Multiethnic Setting
text: THERE is a narrow ribbon of storefront restaurants at the top of East Palisade Avenue in Englewood that is an international food court of sorts. One can choose among Mexican, Greek and Lebanese, a kosher deli and a place called Hummus Elite, all squeezed into the same block. All seem inviting in their own way, and most spill out onto the sidewalk when the weather allows. But the most promising-looking may be Levant Grille, dedicated to what the menu calls “authentic Mediterranean cuisine.”

headline: Syracuse and Pitt in Talks With A.C.C.
text: Syracuse University and the University of Pittsburgh, two bedrock members of the Big East Conference, are engaged in talks about joining the Atlantic Coast Conference, according to a person with direct knowledge of the talks.

headline: Venezuela: Victory for a Dissident
text: The Inter-American Court on Human Rights ruled on Friday that Venezuela must allow Leopoldo López, a prominent opposition leader, to run for public office. The decision could shake up a presidential election scheduled for October 2012, opening the way for a strong opponent to run against President Hugo Chávez. Mr. López, a former mayor of Chacao, a municipality in Caracas, was disqualified by Mr. Chávez’s government from running because of legal claims against him from his time as mayor. Mr. López argued that the disqualification, a method used by Venezuela’s government against other opposition figures, amounted to political discrimination. In a statement, the Foreign Ministry called the ruling “politically partial.” Venezuela is believed to be required to respect the decision by the court, a judicial entity of the Organization of American States.

headline: For Jobs, It’s War
text: The American political discussion has finally turned to the right target: jobs.

headline: Officials Eye Role of a Lawyer in Madoff Case
text: Federal ethics officials are expected to recommend that the Justice Department begin a criminal investigation into actions taken by David M. Becker, the former general counsel of the Securities and Exchange Commission, who determined the agency’s proposal for compensating victims of the Bernard Madoff Ponzi scheme when he had a financial interest in the outcome.

headline: Cuban Flavors, Especially Garlic
text: Tony Gonzalez, who runs the Cuban restaurant El Caney (“the hut” in Spanish) in Bergenfield, spent 16 years at Bear Stearns on Wall Street before taking a buyout in 2008.

headline: Battle for Libya | September 16, 2011
text: Forces aligned with the provisional Libyan government fought their way Friday into two cities still held by fighters loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, in a bid to end weeks of standoff around the fugitive former leader’s remaining strongholds.

headline: Court Filing Details Shortcomings of Airport Screeners on 9/11
text: The five terrorists who boarded United Airlines Flight 175 in Boston on the morning of Sept. 11, 2001, passed through a security checkpoint that was staffed by some screeners who could not speak or understand English, did not know who Osama bin Laden or Al Qaeda were, and, in one case, could not identify what Mace was, according to new court documents.

headline: Britain: Law Is Changed On Arrests of Foreign Officials
text: Britain has altered a law to make it more difficult for private citizens and activist groups to seek the arrest of foreign politicians for crimes like torture, genocide and war crimes. The change, which took effect Thursday, means that Israeli officials who had feared traveling to Britain because of threats that they might be arrested will now be able to visit again. Under the old law, people could apply to magistrates to have arrest warrants issued against people suspected of committing crimes against humanity. But now the director of public prosecutions will have to consent before such arrest warrants can be issued. The law has been a bone of contention between Israel and Britain for some time, after former Foreign Minister Tzipi Livni canceled a trip to Britain amid reports that activists would seek to have her arrested in connection with the Gaza offensive in 2008 and 2009.

headline: On a Swing Through Early-Voting Iowa, Perry Finds Kindred Spirits
text: JEFFERSON, Iowa — At several levels, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas seemed a perfect fit for this small Iowa farming community.

headline: A Place for Families With Hungry Teenagers
text: SOME restaurant locations seem to have revolving doors, with occupants rotating through in quick succession. One of them is 4 Berry Hill Road in Syosset. Last year, it was home to Moules et Frites; in June, it became 516 American Kitchen and Bar.

headline: Ice Cream Made to Order
text: At Nitro, a new neon-bright ice cream parlor in Syosset, there is no freezer to store the ice cream and frozen yogurt sold there. Instead, frozen desserts are made to order at the display counter, where employees pour icy pitchers of liquid nitrogen, shrouded in clouds of vapor, into cream-filled stainless steel mixers. At minus 325 degrees, the nitrogen is cold enough to flash-freeze the ice cream as it churns.

headline: Fall Happens Every Year, but Still Gets People Talking
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Suddenly it’s as if it never happened. All those furnace-stoked, sweat-streaked days — a smothering gauntlet of triple digits that strained thermometers, primed wildfires, aggravated droughts and stripped away all the fun of one summer afternoon after another. Gone.

headline: Rangers Remember Boogaard at Camp
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Derek Boogaard’s absence from the Rangers’ first day of training camp was noted by several players Friday, but it seemed especially keen for one in particular: his fellow enforcer, Brandon Prust.

headline: Satellite to Land, Somewhere
text: A defunct, six-ton NASA satellite will plummet out of orbit in about a week — on Sept. 23, give or take a day. But where it will land nobody knows. The orbit of the Upper Atmosphere Research Satellite passes over latitudes as far north as Edinburgh and as far south as Cape Town, and the trail of debris will stretch to about 500 miles long. NASA puts the chances that anything would hit anyone at 1 in 3,200 and notes that there are no known cases of injury by falling satellite, not even when its Skylab space station crashed into western Australia in 1979. The falling satellite, about one-tenth the mass of Skylab, was launched in 1991 from the space shuttle Discovery to study the dynamics and chemistry of the upper atmosphere and was decommissioned in 2005 when its fuel ran out and its batteries failed.

headline: Britain: Seeking a Paper’s Sources
text: The Metropolitan Police Service is seeking a court order to force The Guardian to disclose confidential information about its reporting on the phone hacking scandal, The Guardian reported on Friday. Among the materials being sought are documents that would reveal the sources for articles by the reporters Amelia Hill and Nick Davies, including those that accused The News of the World of illegally intercepting the voicemail of a girl who was kidnapped and then murdered. The police say that Ms. Hill and Mr. Davies may have violated a law that forbids the dissemination of potentially damaging material leaked illegally by government officials.

headline: Corrections: September 17
text: NATIONAL

headline: House G.O.P. Leaders Find Some Things to Like About Obama’s Jobs Plan
text: WASHINGTON — House Republican leaders rejected some main elements of President Obama’s jobs plan on Friday but told their rank-and-file members that they would support other components. Approvals ranged from the well-publicized parts, like an extension of the payroll tax holiday, to the more obscure, like continuing depreciation write-offs for businesses.

headline: Rodriguez Expects to Return Saturday
text: TORONTO — Alex Rodriguez was not in the Yankees’ starting lineup for Friday’s game against the Toronto Blue Jays because he wanted to try out an experimental tape job on his bat first.

headline: Plane Crash in Reno
text: A plane crashed during an air show in Reno, Nev., on Friday.

headline: France: Strauss-Kahn to Speak Out
text: Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former head of the International Monetary Fund who returned to Paris after New York prosecutors dropped charges of attempted rape against him, will be interviewed on Sunday on France’s most-watched news program, a spokesman at the TF1 television channel said. It will be Mr. Strauss-Kahn’s first interview since his arrest in New York in May. Mr. Strauss-Kahn, 62, who had been considered a strong rival to the French president, Nicolas Sarkozy, in the 2012 presidential election, is expected to be asked about his political future, the future of his party and the current crisis of the euro, among other things.

headline: F.B.I. Chided for Training That Was Critical of Islam
text: Arab-American and Muslim groups deplored on Friday the Federal Bureau of Investigation’s use of training material that characterized the prophet Muhammad as a “cult leader” and linked Muslims’ religious devotion to a potential for violence.

headline: Iraq: Seeking Jobs and Electricity
text: Several thousand followers of the anti-American cleric Moktada al-Sadr took to the streets in Iraqi cities on Friday, calling for the government to provide more electricity and jobs. Far fewer people took part in the protests on Friday than in previous demonstrations organized by Mr. Sadr, a Shiite. In the Shiite neighborhood of Sadr City in Baghdad, slightly fewer than 1,000 people protested for about 20 minutes immediately after prayers on Friday. In addition, about 3,000 followers of Mr. Sadr protested in Najaf.

headline: Two Orchestras, Two Approaches to Leadership
text: WHEN Itzhak Perlman resigned as the Westchester Philharmonic’s artistic director halfway through last season, leaving the orchestra without a designated artistic leader for the first time in its 28 years, few thought that, on the eve of a new season, it would neither have a new leader nor actively be seeking one. But that is the case. The orchestra’s administration has warmed to the leaderless approach.

headline: South Side Odyssey
text: The University of Chicago’s football team has had a complicated history.

headline: Bloomberg, on Radio, Raises Specter of Riots by Jobless
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg takes every opportunity these days to mention what he says are two major problems facing the country’s economy: enormous public debt and high unemployment. But on the radio show he appears on with John Gambling on Friday mornings, Mr. Bloomberg took his comments further than usual.

headline: Rivera’s 601st Will Have to Wait as Yanks Fall
text: TORONTO — With Trevor Hoffman’s record of 601 saves just one rung ahead of him on the career list, Mariano Rivera brought his family to Canada in the hope that they could share in the celebration when he tied, and then broke the record.

headline: Seeing the Humor in a Shakespearean Tragedy
text: For a tragedy, “Othello” has always been pretty funny. But not every director has the courage to bring the humor front and center, as Bonnie J. Monte does in the Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey’s top-notch, smoothly executed new production.

headline: Falling Approval Ratings
text: Fewer than a quarter of Americans say the country is on the right track, and approval ratings for President Obama and Congress are at record lows, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: Motivated Mets End Their Slump
text: ATLANTA — Drifting aimlessly through the final weeks of a draining and disappointing season, the Mets have appeared at times to be devoid of purpose.

headline: These Witches Aren’t in Puritan New England Anymore
text: Don’t be alarmed if your eyes start to smart even before the house lights dim at “The Crucible,” Hartford Stage’s industrial-strength production of the classic Arthur Miller play about the Salem witch trials. It’s only the fake smoke fogging your eyeglasses and providing a little screening — very little — for the near-naked ladies who will in a moment be dancing wildly among the boughs above the stage.

headline: Plane Crash in Reno
text: A World War II-era fighter plane plunged into the grandstands Friday during a popular annual air show, killing at least three people and injuring more than 50 spectators.

headline: Superefficient Home With Big Ambitions, Built by Students on a Hoboken Lot
text: HOBOKEN, N.J. — On summer evenings, the running path along the riverfront here is clogged with businessmen on smartphones tripping over dog leashes and joggers weaving through a stream of strollers. It had gotten even more congested recently as curious pedestrians congregated around a fenced-off parking lot on Sinatra Drive to guess the purpose of the structure being built inside.

headline: Shakespeare Can Wait, Till Spring at Least
text: DARKO Tresnjak likes the way his new job has started.

headline: For the Red Sox, a Curative Victory
text: Boston

headline: An Early Setback for St. John’s
text: For almost 18 months, it seemed like a perfect match: a coach overseeing a resurgence and a university that yearned for renewed basketball glory. Now, for Steve Lavin and St. John’s, the honeymoon may be over.

headline: Exploring a Career Before, and Beyond, ‘John and Yoko’
text: IN 1968, Kevin Concannon was a 12-year-old Beatles fan when an avant-garde artist named Yoko Ono started appearing in press stories linking her with John Lennon. “It was my first exposure ever to a real live artist, and especially a real live avant-garde conceptual artist,” recalled Dr. Concannon, who has a doctorate in art history from Virginia Commonwealth University and is now the director of the School of Visual Arts at Virginia Tech.

headline: 2 Are Dead and Dozens Injured in Crash of Vintage Plane at Show
text: A small vintage plane crashed into a crowd at a Nevada air show at the Reno-Stead Airport on Friday, killing at least two people, including the pilot, and injuring more than 50 others, officials said.

headline: Reviving a Rachmaninoff Connection
text: WHEN Ellie Horn, 13, heard the name Sergei Rachmaninoff at a party for Huntington Historical Society volunteers in December, her ears perked up.

text: London

headline: Sure, Obama Can Fire His Staff. So Should He?
text: WASHINGTON — He has probably been quoted more than any pundit on the planet since 1992 (which, by the way, was the last time he actually won an American campaign), but when James Carville opens his mouth, Democrats still tend to listen. And so it got a lot of people talking this week when Mr. Carville, in an open letter to President Obama on CNN’s Web site, urged the struggling president to follow the example of some of his predecessors and just fire a bunch of people.

headline: Detroiters Make the Case for a Lifeline
text: A cross section of Detroiters say they wish they could persuade the country why G.M. and Chrysler, and by extension Detroit, deserve to be saved.

headline: ‘To Sleep, Perchance to Dream’
text: An exhibition at the Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington explores how 17th-century thinkers perceived the mysteries and science of sleep.

text: Designer visions are often quite wonderful, but for most working women, reality is tailored clothing.

headline: Author, 90, Sees Her Essays Brought to Life Onstage

headline: AIDS Cases Drop Again
text: In a sign of progress against one of the great plagues of the last generation, a dwindling number of New York City AIDS cases has been diagnosed over the last eight years, according to new statistics released on Friday.

headline: A Profile of Peter Orszag
text: Forty-year-old Peter R. Orszag, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, is the youngest member of President Obama’s cabinet.

headline: New Center Will Develop Teaching Tools
text: The White House on Friday announced the creation of a national research center that will focus on developing new technologies like software and games for teaching and learning in public schools. The center, called Digital Promise, was created with bipartisan Congressional support and is to be an independent nonprofit organization, overseen by a board of leaders in education and technology appointed by Education Secretary Arne Duncan. It will work with researchers, entrepreneurs and schools. Administration officials said the center builds on the president’s call in a speech this month to create jobs by focusing on new approaches in education. The project evolved from efforts by private foundations and scientists as well as civic and business leaders.

headline: A Circuitous Route to a Celebration
text: Constitution Day was apparently first observed in Iowa in 1911, at the urging of the Sons of the American Revolution, who later reported that “appropriate exercises” were held in every school in the state. It was to be celebrated on Sept. 17, to mark the day in 1787 that the Constitutional Convention signed the document.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: The state government in Jammu and Kashmir has introduced autumn cocoon rearing in the Kashmir Valley for the first time. This silk worm-rearing program is aimed at creating employment opportunities for the unemployed youth in the valley. (Kashmir Times)

headline: Math Is Hard, Euro Edition
text: It’s astonishing how many European officials and unofficial wise men insist, with a great air of wisdom, that the euro crisis was caused by failure to enforce the stability pact — that is, limits on deficits and debt.

headline: Waving the Flag Against Corruption
text: Like other politically correct people, I too shrink away from those who wave or wrap themselves in flags.

headline: Spectators’ Deaths Highlight Risks of Popular Aerial Racing
text: RENO, Nev. — It was, for fans and followers of the high-speed sport of air racing, a sure sign of serious trouble: the vintage P-51 Mustang, the World War II fighter known as the “Cadillac of the skies,” pitching violently skyward in a frantic effort by the pilot to gain altitude — and to buy time.

headline: Emmys Watch: A.D. Miles on ‘Late Night With Jimmy Fallon’
text: A. D. Miles had never worked on a talk show when he was hired as the first head writer for “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon.” But that was kind of the point.

headline: Palestinians See U.N. Bid as Their Most Viable Option
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — The Palestinian decision to apply for full United Nations membership at the Security Council, announced Friday by President Mahmoud Abbas, was the most viable of the only options possible: surrender, return to violence or appeal to the international community, a senior Palestinian official said Saturday.

headline: Bare Market
text: There are cities you love for what they offer in terms of superficial diversion — the joy of hunting down a perfect piece of passementerie in Paris or of locating a wonderfully sinuous leather journal in Milan — and there are cities you love for their significant history and scope, despite their lack of good shopping. Athens is one of those cities, offering up the Parthenon and not much else, as is (so I’m told) St. Petersburg. Jerusalem is one of my favorite cities on the planet; its yellow stone and golden light draw me back time and again, but when I was there this past July as a judge for the Jerusalem Film Festival I was reminded of the serious absence of retail therapy.

headline: Charles Percy, Former Ill. Senator, Is Dead at 91
text: Charles H. Percy, a former United States senator from Illinois and a moderate Republican who clashed with President Richard M. Nixon over Watergate and whose own presidential ambitions were stymied by Nixon’s resignation, died Saturday in Washington. He was 91.

headline: General Motors Is Said to Offer Bonuses and Reopened Plant
text: DETROIT — The United Auto Workers union won $5,000 signing bonuses for its workers and a promise to reopen an assembly plant in Tennessee as part of its tentative new contract with General Motors, according to people briefed on the negotiations.

headline: Variety: The Most Important Diagramless
text: Administrivial Notepad Alert!  There is a Notepad on today’s Diagramless puzzle that says: This diagramless is 17 squares wide by 17 squares deep and has regular crossword symmetry. 1-Across begins in the first square of the first row.

headline: Live Analysis: Third Saturday in September
text: Paul Myerberg and The Times’ Karen Crouse will be reporting on all of the day’s action in college football. Check back throughout the day for updates and analysis, to ask questions or to give us your observations, whether from your couch or from the bleachers. You can also follow Paul on Twitter for additional updates throughout the afternoon and evening.

headline: Eleanor Poling, Daughter of Former Vice President, Dies at 51
text: Eleanor Mondale Poling, a former television and radio personality and the daughter of former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, died early Saturday at her farm in Prior Lake, Minn. She was 51.

headline: If Syracuse and Pitt Exit, Things Could Get Interesting
text: From Walnut Creek, Calif., to Birmingham, Ala., where the offices of the Pacific-12 and Southeastern Conferences are located, the big question for a week has been which commissioner would blink first. It turns out that SEC Commissioner Mike Slive and Pac-12 Commissioner Larry Scott didn’t have to.

headline: Anti-Qaddafi Forces Capture, Then Lose, Last Redoubts
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — In a conflict that has seen more than its share of martial ineptitude, the struggles for the town of Bani Walid and the city of Surt stand out.

headline: Rupture With Vatican Reveals a Changed Ireland
text: DUBLIN — Even as it remains preoccupied with its struggling economy, Ireland is in the midst of a profound transformation, as rapid as it is revolutionary: it is recalibrating its relationship to the Roman Catholic Church, an institution that has permeated almost every aspect of life here for generations.

headline: Ted Williams’s .406 Is More Than a Number
text: Inside his room at Philadelphia’s Ben Franklin Hotel on Saturday, Sept. 27, 1941, Ted Williams was jumpy and impatient. That might have been an apt description of the mercurial Williams at most times, but on this evening he had good cause for his unease.

headline: Kara Kennedy, Daughter of Edward Kennedy, Is Dead at 51
text: Kara Kennedy, the daughter of Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, died Friday after a workout at a Washington-area health club. She was 51. The cause was a heart attack, according to the Edward M. Kennedy Institute for the United States Senate in Boston, which announced the death.

headline: A Jet Who’s Easy to Root for and Hard to Keep Down
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — At 8:13 p.m. last Sunday in Gilbert, Ariz., Kevin Guy stared at his big-screen television and cheered for the smallest player on the MetLife Stadium turf. In Las Vegas, Jim Fassel broke into a wide smile. In Cheney, Wash., Chris Hansen received a two-word text message. It read: “Trufant Scores.”

headline: Meetings on European Debt Crisis End in Debate, but Little Progress
text: WROCLAW, Poland — European finance ministers ended a two-day meeting here Saturday without making substantial progress toward solving the region’s debt crisis, or any pledge to recapitalize Europe’s banks.

headline: Ireland Upsets Australia; South Africa Routs Fiji
text: Ireland upset Australia, 15-6, to move atop its group at the Rugby World Cup in New Zealand, as the defending champion, South Africa, routed Fiji, and Argentina beat Romania for its first win.

headline: After Losing Manning and Game, Colts Try to Keep Perspective
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Peyton Manning’s third neck operation had already been completed, perhaps keeping him out for the season, and before the Indianapolis Colts played their first game of the season, defensive end Dwight Freeney was looking for another kind of diagnosis. How do you measure civic panic? Freeney turned on his radio.

headline: Rodriguez Returns to Third Base and Bats Fifth
text: TORONTO — For the first time Since Sept. 9, Alex Rodriguez is back in the Yankees’ starting lineup. After missing the past six games because of his sprained left thumb, Rodriguez is playing third base and batting fifth in Saturday’s game against the Toronto Blue Jays.

headline: A Mother’s War on Germs at Fast-Food Playlands
text: GILBERT, Ariz. — One of those who kicked off her shoes and slithered her way through the multihued plastic tubes of a fast-food restaurant playground here one recent morning was not enjoying herself in the least. In fact, she had a frown on her face.

headline: Unusual Trade Propels Three Teams Toward Playoffs
text: Max Scherzer was drafted by the Arizona Diamondbacks in the first round in 2006. When they traded him after three years, it changed his outlook on his profession.

headline: Car Is Stolen With Boy Still in the Back Seat
text: When a thief jumped into a car in the Bronx and drove off with it on Saturday morning, he apparently did not realize that a 2-year-old boy was in the backseat.

headline: The Guggenheim Connection
text: LADY CATARINA PIETRA TOUMEI and her benefactor, David B. Guggenheim, late of the New York Guggenheims, will never rank among the great impostors. Victor Lustig sold the Eiffel Tower. Anna Anderson masqueraded as Anastasia. David Hampton posed as the son of Sidney Poitier, snookering high-caste Manhattan.

headline: Vikings’ McNabb Has Something to Prove
text: EDEN PRAIRIE, Minn. — Impressionable and eager to learn, the Minnesota Vikings rookie quarterback Christian Ponder gravitated to the veteran Donovan McNabb almost as soon as McNabb dropped his bags at training camp. A first-round draft choice from Florida State, Ponder said McNabb helped him with everything, from grasping the nuances of a West Coast offense to teaching him how to politely ask autograph seekers for privacy during dinner in a restaurant.

headline: Front-Office Strife Put Rams in a Fix
text: The St. Louis Rams, who face the Giants at MetLife Stadium on Monday night, have not had a winning season in eight years. They finished second to last in the N.F.L. in points allowed four times from 2005 through 2009. They posted a 6-42 record from 2007 through 2009, and although last season’s 7-9 finish offered hope that the franchise was finally headed in the right direction, a season-opening 31-13 loss to Philadelphia proved that the Rams still have a long way to go.

headline: Suddenly, Over There Is Over Here
text: THE debt crisis in Europe has finally, and officially, washed up on American shores. Last week, the mighty Federal Reserve moved to help European banks that have been having trouble finding people who are willing to lend them money.

headline: An Unlikely Contributor to an Unexpected Contender
text: In the heat of a pennant race with Boston on Friday, the Tampa Bay Rays made a curious choice for their cleanup spot. Batting fourth was Casey Kotchman, the journeyman first baseman who was hitting .312 — between Boston’s David Ortiz and Chicago’s Paul Konerko that night on the list of A.L. batting leaders.

headline: Clashes Erupt in Yemen, and a Sit-In Is Attacked
text: SANA, Yemen — Explosions rocked Yemen’s capital early Saturday morning as clashes broke out between security forces loyal to President Ali Abdullah Saleh and fighters aligned with opposition tribal leaders.

headline: Gordon Pursuing Cup and His Own History
text: Jeff Gordon turned 40 last month and is married with two young children. Ten years have passed since he won his last championship in Nascar’s top series, and only Richard Petty and David Pearson have won more races. Who could blame Gordon for downshifting now?

headline: Why I Am a Naturalist
text: Naturalism is the philosophical theory that treats science as our most reliable source of knowledge and scientific method as the most effective route to knowledge. In a recent essay for The Stone, Timothy Williamson correctly reports that naturalism is popular in philosophy. In fact it is now a dominant approach in several areas of philosophy — ethics, epistemology, the philosophy of mind, philosophy of science and, most of in all, metaphysics, the study of the basic constituents of reality. Metaphysics is important: if it turns out that reality contains only the kinds of things that hard science recognizes, the implications will be grave for what we value in human experience.

headline: After Open, Everybody Still Talking About the Weather
text: During another United States Open battered by rain, the world’s top players were full of suggestions on how to minimize the effect of bad weather that compressed the schedule, sent marquee matches to outer courts, caused the Louis Armstrong Stadium court to be unusable and forced the men’s final to Monday for the fourth year in a row.

headline: Dreams of Perfection Don’t Float
text: A sailboat is a beautiful thing, and you begin building it possessed by a vision of exquisite and perfect beauty. Then, across the sprawling hours needed to build it — 3,500 in my case — this perfect vision crashes into the rocky reality of uneven skills and imperfect character. In the end, unless you negotiate peace with the demon of perfectionism, you’re left with the ruins of a dream and a painful testament to personal shortcomings.

headline: The Joy of Making Things
text: MY mother was a German war bride. I was born in Albany, and my parents divorced when I was 2.

headline: Asking Why Employees of Solar Firm Lost Jobs

headline: Wall Street Protest Begins, With Demonstrators Blocked

headline: 30 Seconds With Nolan Ryan
text: Nolan Ryan threw baseballs past hitters for 27 years with the Mets, the Angels, the Astros and the Rangers, and set major league records with 5,714 strikeouts and 7 no-hitters. Ryan, 64, who was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1999, is part owner, chief executive and president of the Texas Rangers. He recently made an appearance at the Steiner Sports corporate offices in New Rochelle, N.Y.

headline: Chicago’s Mayor Challenges Teachers Union
text: CHICAGO — One by one, teachers at public elementary schools here have been voting to buck their own union and take Mayor Rahm Emanuel up on an unusual offer: to accept bonus pay in exchange for waiving union contract provisions and keeping children at some schools longer each day.

headline: Helping Revive Oklahoma on the Way to Texas Tech
text: This article, excerpted from “Swing Your Sword: Leading the Charge in Football and Life” (Diversion Books) by the former Texas Tech coach Mike Leach, recalls Leach’s season as offensive coordinator under Bob Stoops at Oklahoma. The Sooners, who are ranked No. 1, played at No. 5 Florida State on Saturday night.

headline: A Home in a Tree, at Least for a Night
text: One recent night, four travelers from Atlanta on their way to a wedding on the Georgia coast headed to a hostel on a friend’s recommendation. As they approached in the dark, mosquitoes buzzed and frogs croaked, and silhouettes of other guests appeared dimly.

headline: When Retirees Are Shortchanged
text: THE world needs more newspaper reporters like Ellen E. Schultz of The Wall Street Journal. For nearly a decade, Ms. Schultz and her colleagues have been rooting through the minutiae of accounting regulations, government filings and corporate retirement plans to expose how many of the largest American companies have systematically plundered their employees’ pension funds, at once robbing their workers of hard-won benefits and enriching their own profits. Her work has led to Congressional hearings, to a Washington investigation or two and to numerous journalism awards.

headline: The Impoverished States of America
text: Tom Kuntz and Bill Marsh are editors at The New York Times.

headline: Soviet Union’s Fall Gave Birth to a Host of New Rivalries
text: The Soviet Union dominated chess for so many years partly because it could tap the talent pool in such a vast area. But after the Soviet system collapsed two decades ago, many of those players began playing for the independent countries that rose from the ashes — nations that quickly assumed their own place among the elite.

headline: Rick Perry, Uber Texan

headline: Israel: Adrift at Sea Alone
text: I’VE never been more worried about Israel’s future. The crumbling of key pillars of Israel’s security — the peace with Egypt, the stability of Syria and the friendship of Turkey and Jordan — coupled with the most diplomatically inept and strategically incompetent government in Israel’s history have put Israel in a very dangerous situation.

headline: The Famine in Somalia, and How to Help
text: My Sunday column is about the famine in Somalia, threatening 750,000 lives in the coming months. I’ll probably have one more column from Dadaab Refugee Camp, and I should make the point that at Dadaab the conditions aren’t so bad, relatively speaking. The problem for the refugees is the starvation in Somalia and the difficulties getting to Dadaab.

headline: Leadership Crisis
text: As the economy faces the risk of another recession, and the 2012 campaign looms, President Obama has been groping for a response to the biggest crisis of his career. All he has to do is listen to the voters.

headline: Governor Perry’s Vaccine Tribulations

text: Norman Sunshine is an artist and the co-author, with Alan Shayne, of the forthcoming “Double Life: A Love Story From Broadway to Hollywood.”

headline: Runaway Spending on War Contractors
text: Tales of waste, fraud and mayhem by private contractors have been commonplace during 10 years of military operations in Afghanistan and Iraq. Now a Congressional study commission has put a “conservative” estimate on waste of between $31 billion and $60 billion in the $206 billion paid to contractors since the start of the two wars.

headline: The Facts on the Fed
text: David Leonhardt is the Washington bureau chief of The New York Times.

headline: How the Big Money Finds a Way In
text: Companies, unions and other interest groups poured about $300 million into campaign ads in the 2010 Congressional elections after the Supreme Court’s Citizens United decision opened the sluices to unlimited spending by independent groups. That will look like a trickle compared with the gusher coming in 2012.

headline: Autumn: Party Time Across the World
text: Richard Cohen is the author of “Chasing the Sun: The Epic Story of the Star That Gives Us Life.”

headline: Putting Parents in Charge
text: Peg Tyre is the author of “The Good School: How Smart Parents Get Their Kids the Education They Deserve.”

headline: Talking With ... André Leon Talley
text: ONLY city people think that no one interesting lives in the suburbs. Case in point: André Leon Talley, a contributing editor for Vogue who seems to represent everything urban: stylishly dressed, a force of nature who stands out visually even in a world filled with unceasing competition for the eye. After he’s finished with fashion shows in New York or Paris or Milan, Mr. Talley retreats to a quiet Westchester hamlet. His home there reminds him of his childhood in North Carolina, and happy moments on his grandmother’s front porch.

headline: The South Ain’t Just Whistlin’ Dixie
text: Karen L. Cox is an associate professor of history at the University of North Carolina, Charlotte, and the author of “Dreaming of Dixie: How the South Was Created in American Popular Culture.”

headline: A Hill Country Town That Whispers, Not Shouts
text: Each year thousands of vacationers flock to the Hill Country, the Central Texas destination that often draws comparisons to Tuscany for its tree-covered hilltops and rolling valleys. Fredericksburg is the hub of this tourist activity; there, crowds amble through antique shops, and boutique B&Bs fill up faster than an IHOP after church. But not all towns in this area require reservations for a plate of schnitzel.

headline: Paul Ryan
text: Kate Murphy is a journalist in Houston who writes frequently for The New York Times.

headline: Wait Wait... Don’t Tell Me
text: NPR’s “Wait Wait ... Don’t Tell Me!” is heard weekends on public radio stations across the country. (npr.org/waitwait)

headline: How Should New York Proceed on Hydrofracking?

headline: Reads & Reactions
text: In this edition: Romney’s strategy, Pennsylvania plans, special election tea leaves and hurricane-centered media criticism. Also, a special edition of Reads.

headline: How Privatized Social Security Works in Galveston
text: GALVESTON — Gov. Rick Perry has repeatedly called Social Security a “Ponzi scheme” and said that people ought to control their own retirement money. But if the social safety net program created in 1935 were eliminated — something President Eisenhower once said would be a politically stupid move — what might take its place?

headline: Sunday: Don’t!
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — DON’T QUOTE ME ON THIS, but I do believe this is one of my favorite Sunday puzzles in quite a while. I’m not much for negativity, but even with all of the DON’TS! it was a lot of fun hunting for the theme phrases. One word (O.K., several words) of warning: this kind of fun is what makes people get into constructing to begin with. Construct all you want, but whatever you do, DON’T QUIT YOUR DAY JOB. It’s a fun business, but not a lucrative one.

headline: Obama Tax Plan Would Ask More of Millionaires
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Monday will call for a new minimum tax rate for individuals making more than $1 million a year to ensure that they pay at least the same percentage of their earnings as middle-income taxpayers, according to administration officials.

headline: The Vital Importance of Manufacturing
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tumult of Arab Spring Prompts Worries in Washington
text: WASHINGTON — While the popular uprisings of the Arab Spring created new opportunities for American diplomacy, the tumult has also presented the United States with challenges — and worst-case scenarios — that would have once been almost unimaginable.

headline: Running Now for 2014, With Eyes on the Money
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: All Across Europe, a Long Summer of Discontent
text: After the European Central Bank and governments implemented bailouts and austerity measures to alleviate the debt crisis, citizens across the continent took to the streets.

headline: The Practice Round
text: A year with Justin Canha, a young man with autism who is part of an new transition program to ready him for an independent life as an adult.

headline: Justin's Paintings
text: Roger Ricco, co-owner of the Ricco Maresca Gallery, discusses Justin Canha’s paintings, many from a recent show at the gallery.

headline: Transitioning to Adulthood with Autism
text: Justin Canha is among the generation of autistic youth who are the first to have benefited throughout childhood from more effective therapies and education opportunities.

headline: Health Officials at Risk as India’s Graft Thrives
text: LUCKNOW, India — The first doctor to die, a senior government health administrator, was shot on his morning walk last October by two men on a motorbike. Six months later, his successor, a cardiologist, was shot to death while out on a predawn stroll. A third government doctor, accused of conspiring to murder the first two, was found dead in jail in June, lying in a pool of blood with deep cuts all over his body.

headline: Posada’s Not-So-Great Chances of Catching Rivera
text: TORONTO — Many Yankee fans, perhaps even most of them, would love to see Jorge Posada behind the plate to catch Mariano Rivera’s record-setting 602nd career save, whenever it comes.

headline: Dickey’s Knuckler Dances Again, but Brave’s Sinker Does in Mets
text: ATLANTA — R. A. Dickey, an avid reader, has for the length of this season personified a most unfortunate literary archetype: the gracious loser.

headline: Justin and Paloma
text: Justin Canha and his friend Paloma Kalisch, who is also autistic, draw cartoons and swap stories about their favorite shows.

headline: Julian Signs
text: A home video from the Canha family of Julian Canha using sign language to communicate with his brother Justin, who has autism and didn’t speak as a boy.

headline: Life
text: A short animated film by Justin Canha of cartoon cliché violence.

headline: Justin Teaches
text: Justin Canha volunteers as a grade school art instructor, teaching his technique for drawing dinosaurs.

headline: Recess Is Making a Comeback in Schools
text: As more Chicago public schools cash in on Mayor Rahm Emanuel’s longer-day financial incentives by adding 90 minutes to their school day, the previous votes by a dozen schools  to add about a half hour to the day by bringing back recess are going unnoticed.

headline: Valuing a Starting Pitcher Soon to Be a Free Agent
text: A September collapse featuring two straight series sweeps by Detroit has the enigmatic White Sox sinking toward the Cubs’ homely perch in the baseball standings, with less than two weeks remaining in an unsightly season.

headline: End Nears for a Pizza Landmark
text: The very first Ray’s Pizza in the Little Italy neighborhood in New York is slated to close.

headline: That Rare Political Debate: Both Civil and Full of Consequence
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Ray’s Pizza, the First of Many, Counts Down to Its Last Slice
text: It did not call itself the flagship Ray’s Pizza because it never really had a fleet. It was not Original Ray’s or Famous Ray’s or Original Famous Ray’s or Real Ray’s or Ray’s on Ice or any of the other cloned shops sprinkled like shredded mozzarella all over town. It was simply Ray’s Pizza, and in the great pizza wars of New York City, it was respected as having been the first, standing more or less above the fray at 27 Prince Street in Little Italy, with tree limbs holding up the basement ceiling and an owner whose name wasn’t even Ray.

headline: An Urban Garden Prepares Inmates for Green-Collar Jobs
text: As a boy, the only thing Darius Jones knew about what lies beneath the soil is that the ground is filled with the coffins of young men from his gritty West Side neighborhood.

headline: After a Relaxing Week of Golf, a Revived Rose Plays for Keeps
text: LEMONT, Ill. — Nothing like a week of fun, frivolity, adult beverages and golf with your friends at some of the top clubs on Long Island to prepare an elite professional for a return to form just in time to make a run at the FedEx Cup and a $10 million bonus.

headline: The C & H Sign
text: In 1906, the California and Hawaiian Sugar Refining Company opened a plant in Crockett, on the site of a former flour mill. The plant’s shimmering sign, with its porcelain “C” and “H” rising 22 feet high, went up in 1956. Thanks to 900 40-watt bulbs, the sign illuminates the spot where San Pablo Bay meets the Carquinez Strait.  LOUISE RAFKIN

headline: Marin County’s Efforts Against Whooping Cough Pay Off
text: Last year, California experienced its worst outbreak of whooping cough in more than 60 years, and the disease hit hardest in an unexpected place: bucolic Marin County.

headline: Joint Chiefs Chairman Presses Pakistan on Militant Havens
text: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, expressing “deep concerns” about violent attacks mounted by the Haqqani insurgent network, has again pressed the Pakistani military to take action against militant havens, American officials said on Saturday.

headline: Steely Powell Helps Liberty Stay Alive in the Playoffs
text: NEWARK — The Liberty have taken up residence across the Hudson River while Madison Square Garden is being renovated. The team has largely struggled to draw fans to home games outside Manhattan, but the Liberty have provided Prudential Center with something that it has lacked with the Nets: playoff basketball.

headline: Autistic and Seeking a Place in an Adult World
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — For weeks, Justin Canha, a high school student with autism, a love of cartoons and a gift for drawing, had rehearsed for the job interview at a local animation studio.

headline: Cautionary Lessons From Michigan
text: CHICAGO — In the search for models to navigate the nation’s unemployment misery and the states’ budget woes, Michigan is rarely mentioned.

headline: Bishop Walter C. Righter, 87, Dies; Faced Heresy Trial
text: Walter C. Righter, an Episcopal bishop who in 1996 was brought to trial and absolved of a charge of heresy for having ordained an actively gay man as a deacon, died on Sept. 11 at his home outside Pittsburgh. He was 87.

headline: Gavitt’s Influence and Friendship Are Recalled
text: The death of the basketball giant Dave Gavitt did not come as a shock to those who knew him best. Though he had been battling an extended illness, Gavitt still called his friend and protégé Mike Tranghese every day. Tranghese said that Gavitt refused to talk about himself and would insist on talking about how Tranghese was doing, supporting him through the death of his wife, Susan, 15 months ago.

headline: Ralph J. Lomma, Who Shaped Miniature Golf, Dies at 87
text: Ralph J. Lomma, who at midcentury helped set the static pastime of miniature golf in motion, letting players tilt at windmills, shoot across rising drawbridges and, at game’s end, watch the ball vanish forever into the maw of a voracious clown, died on Sept. 12 in Scranton, Pa. He was 87.

headline: Prosecutor Candidates Support ‘Restorative Justice’
text: On Wednesday, Betty Renee Ricks stood inside San Francisco County Jail and told 40 inmates how she was first prostituted at age 12, and how one pimp broke her teeth, beat her with hangers until she bled and poured Brut cologne into her wounds.

Whether they are playing under Texan Stadium’s bright lights on a Friday night or in the sweltering afternoon heat, boys clad in navy blue and white uniforms show up day after day to live out their dreams of gridiron glory.

headline: The Day’s Best in College Football
text: ORWIN SMITH The Georgia Tech running back, right, rushed for 157 yards and a touchdown on only five carries, caught two passes for 108 yards and another score and helped the Yellow Jackets accumulate a team-record 768 total yards, including 604 rushing, in a 66-24 victory over Kansas. Georgia Tech averaged 12.1 yards a carry, an N.C.A.A. record. “When we’re making our blocks, it’s like a video game,” said Embry Peeples, who had a 63-yard touchdown run.

headline: Oklahoma Fends Off Ambitious Florida State
text: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — Given their No. 1 ranking and national championship expectations, the Oklahoma Sooners will most likely face extra scrutiny for even allowing No. 5 Florida State to get within striking distance Saturday night.

headline: Syracuse and Pittsburgh Switch Conferences, Sowing Chaos

headline: Gains of Pro-Russian Party in Latvia Show Worries on Economy and Graft
text: MOSCOW — A pro-Russian party has gained the most votes in a snap parliamentary election in Latvia, with economic worries and anger over perceived government malfeasance trumping the anti-Russian sentiments that have kept such parties at bay since the small Baltic country gained independence from the Soviet Union 20 years ago.

headline: Stimulus, Austerity, and Double Standards
text: Just a quick thought: in much discussion of economic policy these days, the presumption is that stimulus had its chance, it failed, and that’s that. Never mind those of us who say that we actually didn’t do nearly enough — and were saying that from the beginning, not as an after-the-fact rationalization. It’s one strike and you’re out.

headline: Hysteresis Begins
text: The slump in the United States and other advanced economies is the result of a failure of demand — period, end of story. All attempts to claim that it is somehow structural, or maybe the result of reduced incentives to produce, have collapsed at first contact with the evidence.
