headline: Protesters Shot, Starting Battle in Yemen Capital
text: SANA, Yemen — Firing from rooftops and from the back of pickup trucks, security forces turned heavy-caliber machine guns and other weapons on demonstrators here on Sunday, setting off battles between army defectors and forces loyal to the government in the worst day of violence in the capital since March.

headline: As an MSNBC Host, Sharpton Is a Hybrid Like No Other
text: At 50 minutes to airtime, the Rev. Al Sharpton, in pinstripes and cufflinks, was sitting in his office at Rockefeller Center, tinkering with Tuesday’s introduction to “PoliticsNation,” his new nightly show on MSNBC.

headline: Greeks Discuss Drastic Moves to Receive Aid
text: FRANKFURT — Greek leaders struggled through the weekend to agree to a set of radical budget reductions that would satisfy foreign lenders’ demands even as they tried to stave off mounting resistance to those cuts at home.

headline: Chinese Protesters Accuse Solar Panel Plant of Pollution
text: BEIJING — In a fresh indication of growing public anger over pollution, hundreds of demonstrators in the eastern Chinese province of Zhejiang on Sunday were camped outside a solar panel manufacturing plant that stands accused of contaminating a nearby river.

headline: Strauss-Kahn Concedes ‘Error’ in Sexual Encounter With Maid
text: PARIS — Dominique Strauss-Kahn said Sunday that his sexual encounter with a New York City hotel chambermaid was “an error” and “a moral failure” he would regret his whole life, but not a criminal act.

headline: No New F-16’s for Taiwan, but U.S. to Upgrade Fleet
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has decided not to sell F-16 fighter jets to Taiwan but instead to help it refurbish its existing fleet, prompting criticism in Congress that the United States is buckling to pressure from China.

headline: Dominant Defense Propels Jets Over Jaguars
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — In the Jets’ locker room Sunday, the loudest team in football dressed in silence. There was no shouting or whooping or any other perceptible signs that the Jets had just dismantled the Jacksonville Jaguars, administering a 32-3 beating that featured about as much suspense as a romantic comedy.

headline: 16-Year-Old Becomes Youngest to Win on L.P.G.A. Tour
text: PRATTVILLE, Ala. — The historical record will show that 16-year-old Lexi Thompson became the youngest winner of a Ladies Professional Golf Association event with her victory Sunday in the Navistar L.P.G.A. Classic.

headline: Jellyfish Swarm in the South
text: Swarms of dinner-plate-size moon jellyfish are gathering in the Gulf of Mexico around the Mississippi and Alabama barrier islands in numbers and sizes so large that they look almost like steppingstones, The Press-Register in Mobile, Ala., reports.

headline: Fox Edits Phone-Hacking Joke From Emmys; Replaces Baldwin With Nimoy
text: The commercials for the Emmy Awards this year promised “unexpected” moments.

headline: A Lot of Schubert and a Touch of Poetry
text: As their engagements have become more prestigious, and their recording career has grown, the Knights, the excellent young chamber orchestra, have kept up their longstanding relationship with Bargemusic. On Friday evening members of the group returned to the idyllic performance space — which floats, sometimes gently and sometimes less so, next to the Brooklyn Bridge — for a program mixing old and new.

headline: Even Jeter, Having a Strong Second Half, Can Appreciate a Day Off
text: TORONTO — Derek Jeter was one of three regulars given the day off Sunday as the Yankees completed a challenging 11-day, four-city trip with a 3-0 loss to the Toronto Blue Jays. Normally, Jeter wants to play every day, but Manager Joe Girardi said Jeter and several of his teammates had showed signs of fatigue.

headline: Glimpses of Obama Among ‘Friends’
text: The portrait of the Obama White House that the veteran journalist Ron Suskind draws in his searing new book, “Confidence Men,” is that of a young, inexperienced president lacking the leadership and managerial skills to deal effectively with the cascading economic problems he inherited; a brainy but detached executive with a tendency to frame policy matters intellectually “like a journalist, or narrator, or skilled observer”; an oddly passive C.E.O. whose directive on restructuring the banks in the wake of the 2008 financial crisis was, the author says, ignored or slow-walked by his own economic team.

headline: Sweden Wins Both Events at the Men’s Elite in China
text: Immediately after the women’s tournament in Beijing the Tianjin Binhai Cup world men’s elite event took place from Sept. 10 to 14. The location was on the coast of the Yellow Sea, about 80 miles southeast of Beijing.

headline: A Minty Chewing Gum, Named for a Snowboarder
text: WHEN celebrities attach their names to products, it generally is for fashion-related items like fragrances or clothing lines that don’t come cheap. But the price for a new product that Shaun White, the gold medalist snowboarder, has licensed: $1.49.

headline: Austerity USA
text: Goldman Sachs (no link) has a nice chart showing just how much fiscal policy has been a drag on the economy since the second half of last year, and also shows that the Obama jobs plan, even if enacted in full, would only be enough to put it in neutral:

headline: I’ve Never Actually Seen the Resemblance
text: But several people have sent me this:

headline: Facebook to Offer Path to Media
text: For cloud-based digital music services like Spotify and Rhapsody, which stream millions of songs but have struggled to sign up large numbers of paying users, being friended by Facebook could prove to be a mixed blessing.

headline: I Need to Get Over This Canadian Thing
text: But haven’t yet.

headline: Shakespeare’s Words Echo Amid the Music Those Words Inspired
text: For an orchestra that has not yet opened its season, the New York Philharmonic has been awfully busy. In the last two weeks it played two performances of “West Side Story,” offered Mahler’s Second Symphony as a 10th anniversary commemoration of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and accompanied Andrea Bocelli in Central Park. It topped off the list on Saturday evening at Avery Fisher Hall with a program built around William Walton’s film score for Shakespeare’s “Henry V.”

headline: A Channel Woos the Man With Spare Cash for Toys
text: When Discovery Communications set out to reformat HD Theater, the nine-year-old home of high-definition documentaries, its executives assessed the crowded cable programming landscape and asked what was missing — where there was “white space,” as one later put it.

headline: Cigars? Cigarettes? Catty Rivalries?
text: At the end of the first episode of “The Playboy Club” on NBC Hugh Hefner, in voice-over, delivers a thesis statement: “It was the early ’60s, and the Bunnies were some of the only women in the world who could be anyone they wanted to be.”

headline: Monday: Immature Egg Cell
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — SHIVER ME TIMBERS, it’s international Talk Like a Pirate Day! This be an occasion for keelhauling, or swashbuckling, or whatever it is pirates do when they’re happy. All I know is, I won’t be able to keep this up for the entire post, or I’m going to wind up sounding like a character from SpongeBob.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Republican Calls for a More Honest Debate
text: WASHINGTON — Four months after he decided against jumping into the Republican presidential race, Gov. Mitch Daniels of Indiana says that he has occasionally been frustrated by the discourse in the campaign and that the field could benefit from at least one more contender whose candidacy was rooted in a message of fiscal discipline.

headline: New Crop of Sitcom Women Can Dish It Like the Big Boys
text: In “Romy and Michele’s High School Reunion” the heroines bicker over who is the Mary in their relationship and who is merely Rhoda. They are referring of course to “The Mary Tyler Moore Show,” which cemented the rule that the prettier, nicer friend is the star and the sarcastic one is the sidekick.

headline: As Consumers Tighten Belts, Advertisers Adjust
text: The economic downturn and high rates of unemployment have forced consumers to spend less, and advertisers have taken notice. Figures from Nielsen, to be released on Monday, show the amount of money that advertisers are spending to bring their message to consumers has increased in certain categories.

headline: After Disney, After Rehab, a Singer Tries Growing Up
text: “Good luck Demi” was trending on Twitter in New York on Saturday night as Demi Lovato — singer, actress, former Disney sparkplug, meltdown survivor — sang the morbid power ballad “Skyscraper” at the Hammerstein Ballroom: “Would it make you feel better/To watch me while I bleed?”

headline: Godhood Will Soon Become His Art
text: At New York City Ballet George Balanchine’s “Apollo” (1928) is a touchstone, the fountainhead of neoclassical values and a proving ground for generations of storied dancers. These facts exert pressure on a performer making his first appearance in the title role. Yet the role itself offers solace. Balanchine’s Apollo is a god also making a debut, just beginning to figure out what he can do.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: 30 Years on, Focus Remains on Opposites to Attract an Audience
text: New York’s dancegoers are learning to use a new name, New York Live Arts, for the place that used to be Dance Theater Workshop. No physical change is apparent in the theater or its foyer. The new institution, described as “an artist-led, producing, and presenting arts organization” that strives “to create a robust framework in support of the nation’s dance and movement-based artists,” has come about as a merger of the old Dance Theater Workshop and the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company. A busy season, looking lively on paper, lies ahead. I wish it well.

headline: Requiem for a New York Newsman
text: It’s one thing to sign a petition protesting an article that suggested a rape allegation had been a hoax, but when a friend of the Daily News columnist Mike McAlary casts aspersions on his motives as a journalist, McAlary grabs him by the lapels. “I don’t turn on my friends,” the newsman shouts defiantly. “I don’t sign petitions. I’m McAlary.”

headline: River Elegy That Covers a Wide Sonic Terrain
text: The Miller Theater at Columbia University has long been a hotbed of contemporary music and adventurous programming. The work that Melissa Smey, the executive director, chose to open this season, James Dillon’s “Nine Rivers,” was so long, complex and unconventional in its demands that it was presented over three nights, on Wednesday, Friday and Saturday. It was a co-production with the Guggenheim Museum’s Works and Process series.

headline: ‘Arias With a Twist’
text: Photos of Joey Arias’s show at the Abrons Arts Center.

headline: Nickelodeon’s Capital Play Day
text: Nickelodeon’s eight-year-old Worldwide Day of Play is going big time this year.

headline: A Movable ‘Sesame Street,’ Where Children Can Grieve
text: 6:42 p.m. | Updated Elmo danced alone beside the stage, flapping his arms as he waited for fans to approach. Cookie Monster tracked blue fuzz across the hardwood floors. The voice of Oscar the Grouch extolled the virtues of trash over the speaker system.

headline: Dead Sea Scrolls on View
text: A new exhibition of more than 500 ancient artifacts from Israel — including 20 of the Dead Sea Scrolls, four of which have never been made available for public viewing — is set to make its world premiere on Oct. 28 at Discovery Times Square in Manhattan, the producers announced. Ten scrolls at a time will be displayed in “Dead Sea Scrolls: Life and Faith in Biblical Times,” which has been assembled by the Israel Antiquities Authority. The producers describe the show as one of the most comprehensive of its kind ever mounted; it will also include an in-scale re-creation of the Western Wall in Jerusalem, with a three-ton block of stone from the wall itself.

headline: Now in 3-D, ‘Lion King’ Returns to Lead at Box Office
text: Take a 17-year-old animated movie, gussy it up with 3-D visuals, and give it a two-week stunt release in theaters when competition from other family films is weak. Presto: “The Lion King” roars again. This Walt Disney Studios movie, which sold $1.2 billion at the global box office in 1994 (after adjusting for inflation), was No. 1 over the weekend with an estimated $29.3 million in ticket sales, a result that significantly exceeded expectations. Second place went to “Contagion,” the Warner Brothers-Participant Media disease thriller; it took in about $14.5 million for a two-week total of $44.2 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office data. The violent crime drama “Drive” (FilmDistrict) was third with about $11 million, while “The Help” (DreamWorks Studios) was in fourth place, taking in $6.4 million for a six week total of $147.4 million. Rounding out the top five was a remake of “Straw Dogs” (Sony Pictures Entertainment) that sold an estimated $5 million in tickets.

headline: The Winners in Toronto
text: The Toronto International Film Festival announced its audience award winners on Sunday, with Nadine Labaki’s “Where Do We Go Now?” — a Lebanese drama about the lengths a group of women will go to in order protect their village — receiving the Cadillac People’s Choice Award, the most prestigious award at the festival. (Above, Ms. Labaki in a scene from the film.) The award for best documentary was given to Jon Shenk for “The Island President,” which follows Mohamed Nasheed, the president of the Maldives, as he battles to save his nation from the threat of rising sea levels. “The Raid,” directed by Gareth Huw Evans, won the Midnight Madness Award, and Philippe Falardeau’s “Monsieur Lazhar,” which took home the City of Toronto Award for best Canadian feature.

headline: Euro Bonds Unlikely to Solve Problems
text: Euro bonds are not the answer to Europe’s raging financial crisis. The idea behind the bonds, that euro zone countries would guarantee each others’ debts, won’t be agreed to in time to solve the problem. And, once the crisis is over, neither euro bonds nor fiscal union will be desirable. Market discipline is a better way of dealing with the current crisis and for running monetary union in the long run.

headline: TV Nostalgia Fans to Convene
text: Maybe it’s the battered economy that is driving the public’s longing for a different era. Or maybe it’s Hollywood’s own obsession with the 1950s and ’60s, as witnessed by the lineup of fall television offerings like “Pan Am” and “The Playboy Club” that are following on the success of “Mad Men.”

text: RAMS (0-1) at GIANTS (0-1), Monday at 8:30 p.m. Eastern, ESPN

headline: In Kabul, It’s Not MTV, It’s a Mission
text: Tom Freston is a pretty mellow guy, but sitting in the corner of a downtown Manhattan restaurant last week he was getting very excited as he talked about his new project. “Every time I go there, there are kids doing a bunch of new things, making all kinds of interesting programming,” he said. “The work they are coming up with is remarkable.”

headline: Can Jets’ Defense Keep This Up?
text: A few notes and a question from the Jets’ 32-3 victory against Jacksonville on Sunday.

headline: Jets Replay: Sept. 18
text: Behind four interceptions by their defense, and two touchdown passes from Mark Sanchez, the Jets improved to 2-0 with a 32-3 rout of the Jacksonville Jaguars.

headline: In E-Books, Publishers Have Rivals: News Sites
text: Book publishers are surrounded by hungry new competitors: Amazon, with its steadily growing imprints; authors who publish their own e-books; online start-ups like The Atavist and Byliner.

headline: Once Again, Mayweather Wins Lots of Money but Little Love
text: LAS VEGAS

headline: A Little Inflation Can Be a Dangerous Thing
text: IN all the commentary about Ben S. Bernanke’s recent speech in Jackson Hole, Wyo., little attention has been paid to six crucial words: “in a context of price stability.” Those words concluded a discussion by Mr. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, of what tools the central bank could consider appropriate to promote a stronger economic recovery.

headline: Turkey Predicts Alliance With Egypt as Regional Anchors
text: ANKARA, Turkey — A newly assertive Turkey offered on Sunday a vision of a starkly realigned Middle East, where the country’s former allies in Syria and Israel fall into deeper isolation, and a burgeoning alliance with Egypt underpins a new order in a region roiled by revolt and revolution.

headline: How to Stop the Drop in Verbal Scores
text: Charlottesville, Va.

headline: Plenty of Cheer All Around as Rookies Fuel Mets Victory
text: ATLANTA — The visitors’ clubhouse at Turner Field was bustling with energy Sunday. Hip-hop blared from two speakers as heaps of luggage bound for St. Louis barreled around the room.

headline: Djokovic Retires in Pain as Serbia Loses
text: It would have been a suitably grand finale to a memorable tennis season: Novak Djokovic and Serbia against Rafael Nadal and Spain for the Davis Cup in December.

headline: British Tourist, Kidnapped in Kenya, May Be in Central Somalia
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — A British woman kidnapped from an exclusive Kenyan resort last weekend was snatched by a Somali pirate gang and is being held in central Somalia, witnesses said on Sunday night.

headline: Changes to Police Lineup Procedures Cut Eyewitness Mistakes, Study Says
text: The push for procedures to help overcome the weaknesses of eyewitness identifications gains support with a new study being released on Monday that sees significant advantages in techniques promoted by many experts and a growing number of police departments.

headline: Wild-Card Gap Drops to Two Games as the Rays Hammer the Red Sox Again
text: BOSTON — The standings say that the Boston Red Sox have a two-game lead on the Tampa Bay Rays in the American League wild-card race with 10 games to play. On paper Boston is in good shape, but only on paper.

headline: Scrutinizing Google’s Reign
text: Google’s slogan may be don’t be evil, but a growing chorus of antitrust regulators in the United States and Europe want to know if the company has lived up to that creed.

headline: Friends of U.S., Terrorists in Eyes of Law
text: Nassir Al-Rifahe never thought his love for America would be questioned.

headline: On the Red Carpet at the Emmys
text: The 63rd Primetime Emmy Awards were held Sunday night in Los Angeles.

headline: In Blunt and Sometimes Crude Rap, a Strong Political Voice Emerges
text: DAKAR, Senegal — A revolution led by rappers says something about a country’s politics or its music, or maybe both.

headline: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include housing starts for August (Tuesday); existing home sales for August (Wednesday); and weekly jobless claims and leading economic indicators for August (Thursday).

headline: Great-Aunt Hattie’s ‘Little Book’
text: Harriet Beecher Stowe was my great-great-great aunt. My family was proud of her, and of the famous book she wrote. My mother used to say, “When Mr. Lincoln met Great-Aunt Hattie he said, ‘So you’re the little lady who started this big war.’” But I didn’t read The Book.

headline: Buying Local, Feeding Needy, Till Fordham Calls a Halt
text: The project seemed tailor-made for a university brochure: Students promoting locally grown food. A soup kitchen taking in the leftovers. An aspiring lawyer, from bucolic Essex, Vt., making Manhattan feel closer to some green space.

headline: Responding Before a Call Is Needed
text: EAGLE, Colo. — Emergency medicine carries a deep aura of romance in America, with its first-responder traditions of adrenaline, acuity and bravery. But here in this rural mountain area of the West, and in a handful of other places around the nation, a new vision is gaining ground — that emergency workers should not wait around for crises to happen, but rather go out and prevent them.

headline: For a Governor Partial to Corvettes, a Chance to Indulge His Inner Gearhead
text: EAST MEADOW, N.Y. — From a distance, he looked like any other middle-aged gearhead, gingerly parking his sleek Corvette, its tires freshly shined, and then making the rounds among scores of other muscle cars lined up at an auto show here.

headline: All Eyes, and All Hopes, Are on a Work in Progress
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

headline: Fed Runs Risk of Doing Less Than Investors Expect
text: WASHINGTON — Investors have concluded that the Federal Reserve will announce new measures to promote economic growth after a meeting of its policy-making committee ends Wednesday. Long-term interest rates have moved as if the Fed had already spoken.

headline: Rose’s Victory Creates a Lucrative Opportunity
text: LEMONT, Ill. — For all the seesawing of emotions, and possibilities that rose like the roars and fell like the rain at Cog Hill during the final round of the BMW Championship, the end result Sunday was as cut and dried as any in the brief history of the PGA Tour’s FedEx Cup playoffs.

headline: Adventurous Pets and Earthquake Experiences
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Flight Data Recovered in Crash at Air Race
text: RENO, Nev. — Federal officials announced on Sunday that they had recovered real-time flight information and a possible memory card from a video camera aboard the plane that crashed into a crowd at a Reno air race, killing nine people and injuring dozens of others.

headline: The Bleeding Cure
text: Doctors used to believe that by draining a patient’s blood they could purge the evil “humors” that were thought to cause disease. In reality, of course, all their bloodletting did was make the patient weaker, and more likely to succumb.

headline: Retiree Benefits for the Military Could Face Cuts
text: As Washington looks to squeeze savings from once-sacrosanct entitlements like Social Security and Medicare, another big social welfare system is growing as rapidly, but with far less scrutiny: the health and pension benefits of military retirees.

headline: China and India Making Inroads in Biotech Drugs
text: Chinese and Indian drug makers have taken over much of the global trade in medicines and now manufacture more than 80 percent of the active ingredients in drugs sold worldwide. But they had never been able to copy the complex and expensive biotech medicines increasingly used to treat cancer, diabetes and other diseases in rich nations like the United States — until now.

headline: Judge Considers Pledge for Jurors on Internet Use
text: As a federal judge looked over lists of proposed questions for prospective jurors in the case of Viktor Bout, a Russian businessman accused of planning to sell weapons to Colombian rebels, one question suddenly stood out to her: “Do you go on the Internet?”

headline: Packing Heat Everywhere
text: Some bad ideas refuse to die. Include in that category an extreme proposal percolating in the House to strip states of their authority to decide who may carry a concealed loaded firearm. This gift to the gun lobby, the subject of a hearing last week by a House Judiciary subcommittee, is nearly identical to a provision the Senate defeated by a narrow margin two years ago.

headline: The Last Days of the Old Parking Meter
text: Motorists’ bane, magnet for thieves, and memorialized in the Beatles’ “Lovely Rita,” the diminutive parking meter has led an outsize life. But its days in New York City are about to expire.

headline: No Room for Tolerance
text: There have been a slew of local controversies in the past decade over the proposed construction of mosques and Islamic community centers. Mayor Michael Bloomberg rightly stood up for religious liberty against vitriolic opposition to the construction of an Islamic center in Lower Manhattan. With the mayor’s support, the city’s Landmarks Preservation Commission unanimously allowed the project to proceed and it is, slowly.

headline: Murder Trial Hinges on Questions of Domestic Abuse
text: She stood outside the courthouse, emotionally spent but resolute, on trial for killing her husband — an act that she does not dispute. But there were extenuating circumstances, she said, and sometimes killing someone is not the same as committing murder.

headline: An Open Court
text: The Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press proposed last week that the Supreme Court adopt a new rule saying every document filed in or by the court “shall be available to the public for inspection” unless it orders that the document be sealed. That presumption of openness would be in the interest of everyone — the Supreme Court, lawyers who practice before the court, scholars who study the court and, of course, the American public.

headline: Brady and Patriots Make the Most of the Chargers’ Mistakes
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — If New England’s opponent Sunday were one that was less prone to self-inflicted mistakes, odd play-calling and general misfortune, maybe the Patriots would have been in danger of losing a game they appeared to have in hand.

headline: Postscripts to the Attica Story
text: It was eerie 40 years after the deadly riot at Attica state prison to hear the voice of the late Gov. Nelson Rockefeller of New York employing his breathless signature adjective — “fabulous!” He was speaking back then to President Richard Nixon and attributing “a fabulous job” to the state troopers hours after they took the prison in a barrage by rooftop riflemen who killed 10 hostages along with 29 inmates. The president is heard complimenting the governor for “the courage you showed,” their voices resounding from newly available White House tape recordings.

headline: A Superconference? Obstacles Remain for the Pac-12
text: The possibility that Texas, Oklahoma, Texas Tech and Oklahoma State will head to the Pacific-12 from the Big 12 is inching toward reality, though the formation of the first so-called 16-team superconference in major college sports still has significant hurdles to overcome.

headline: Ex-Giant’s Case Is a Window on N.F.L. Aid
text: Ron Johnson’s private room is large but sparse: a couch, two chairs, a flat-screen television and a computer that has been programmed to accommodate Johnson’s favorite games: chess, backgammon, poker.

headline: Home May Be Where Rivera’s Record Is
text: TORONTO — The Yankees’ 3-0 loss to the Toronto Blue Jays on Sunday meant that Yankees closer Mariano Rivera was not given the opportunity to break Trevor Hoffman’s career saves mark of 601.

headline: Glorifying the American, Uh, Alien
text: The revival on Broadway of “Follies,” a eulogy to the age of Ziegfeld, has refocused New Yorkers’ thoughts on a long-vanished star-spangled chapter in showbiz. That was the age when long-limbed beauties were goddesses, and stages were spectacle-filled altars to their, er, talents. Such a sensibility is as dead as the Brooklyn Dodgers, of course, though you can still catch some arch nods to it in the mega-concerts of mega-pop stars like Lady Gaga.

headline: Merkel’s Efforts in Euro Crisis Complicated by Berlin Vote
text: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel’s conservative party held its own in the closely watched Berlin regional election on Sunday. But her junior coalition partner is now in a political free fall, complicating her fight to contain the European debt crisis despite the infighting within her bloc.

headline: Fill In the Blanks
text: Just a few winters ago my wife and I took our daughters to witness the inauguration of a man who had campaigned on hope and embodied possibility. We are pretty immune to political euphoria, but, circulating among the footsore pilgrims, we could imagine our country had embraced the idea that we were all in this together. When the newly sworn-in president congratulated us all on choosing unity of purpose over recriminations and worn-out dogmas, we wanted to believe that we had done exactly that.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Paint Creek, the Town Perry Left Behind
text: PAINT CREEK, Tex. — In the early 1960s, at a tiny, rural school here in the rugged plains of West Texas, little Ricky Perry waged his first campaign. Seeking the office of Halloween King, he stocked up on penny candy at Ma’s convenience store and then doled it out to classmates.

headline: A British Soccer Team? What’s That? Say Scots, Welsh and Irish
text: LONDON — The plan seems eminently reasonable: field a soccer team to represent Britain at next year’s Olympics, which after all are being held here, the home of the modern game.

headline: Siemens Abandoning Nuclear Power Business
text: BERLIN — Siemens, the largest engineering conglomerate in Europe, announced Sunday that following the German government’s decision to phase out nuclear power by 2022, it would stop building nuclear power plants anywhere in the world.

headline: Palestinians Turn to U.N., Where Partition Began
text: UNITED NATIONS — The original two-state solution designed to establish separate countries for Jews and Arabs anticipated the day that both would seek United Nations membership.

headline: A Nervous Hamas Voices Its Issues With a Palestinian Bid for U.N. Membership
text: GAZA — As West Bank Palestinian leaders head to the United Nations to seek membership for a state of Palestine, their rivals in Gaza, the Hamas faction, are watching nervously, complaining of not having been consulted and warning against any recognition of Israel or yielding of a refugee right of return.

headline: Wilma Lee Cooper, Grand Ole Opry Singer, Dies at 90
text: Wilma Lee Cooper, a perennial favorite with the Grand Ole Opry and a member, with her husband, Stoney, of a popular tradition-steeped country singing duo, died on Tuesday at her home in Sweetwater, Tenn. She was 90.

headline: The Emmy Awards: ‘Modern Family’ and ‘Mad Men’ Win Again
text: “Modern Family” gathered up five awards at the 63rd Primetime Emmy Awards show on Sunday night, including best comedy, the second consecutive year the ABC sitcom won the top comedy award. And “Mad Men” received its fourth consecutive Emmy for best drama, staving off competition from the acclaimed HBO drama “Boardwalk Empire” and the last-ditch, sentimental push from “Friday Night Lights.”

headline: When Free Trips Overlap With Commercial Purposes
text: In recent years, the Pearson Foundation has paid to send state education commissioners to meet with their international counterparts in London, Helsinki, Singapore and, just last week, Rio de Janeiro.

headline: Frances Bay, Actress Known for ‘Old Lady’ Roles, Dies at 92
text: Frances Bay, a character actress who late in life became a mainstay of television — playing roles from Arthur Fonzarelli’s grandmother on “Happy Days” to the woman who scraps with Jerry Seinfeld over a loaf of marble rye — died on Thursday in Los Angeles. She was 92.

headline: Corrections: September 19
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Campaign Redux as Obama Pushes for Taxes on Rich
text: WASHINGTON — Four years ago this month, the candidate Barack Obama paused after a rally to reflect on his aspirations for economic change. His words still explain President Obama’s policies.

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Papers Today
text: An earthquake measuring 6.8 on the richter scale shook Sikkim, leaving eighteen people dead, of which 13 are Indian and five Nepali, and dozens injured (NDTV). Although the epicenter of the earthquake was 40-miles north-west of Gangtok, Sikkim, tremors were felt across North and East India. The three aftershocks “triggered massive landslides” causing National Highway 31, the only road link to Sikkim, to cave in in four places, disrupting rescue operations (Indian Express). Most telephone lines remain dead and the region faces extensive power cuts.

headline: The 2011 Emmy Awards

headline: Olympic Soccer and the Myth of Britishness
text: Jeré Longman and Sarah Lyall write for Monday’s Times on the efforts of British Olympic officials to create unified men’s and women’s soccer teams for the 2012 London Games, to compete under the flag of Great Britain. Not surprisingly, the idea has not been warmly received by Scots, Welsh and Northern Irishmen, who have cherished their soccer independence since the earliest days of the modern game, and who have chafed at English domination even longer.

headline: Sept. 19, 1881 | President Garfield Dies
text: On Sept. 19, 1881, President James A. Garfield died 11 weeks after being shot. The Sept. 20 New York Times reported: “At a few minutes after 10 o’clock last night, however, the sufferer complained of a severe pain in the region of the heart and almost immediately became unconscious. Dr. D. W. Bliss, who was hastily called, at once announced that he was dying, and Mrs. Garfield and the consulting surgeons were summoned. Within 15 minutes President Garfield had drawn his last breath and the sorrowful intelligence was being sent with lightning speed throughout the country. Everywhere, notwithstanding the lateness of the hour, the bells were tolled as a mark of respect and sorrow for the long-suffering, patient, and heroic president.”

headline: Hindi Cinema, in Poster Form, at a Mumbai Shop
text: It was Haji Abu’s grandfather, and then his father, who passed on their love for Hindi cinema to him. Mr. Abu turned his hobby into his profession, opening the Poster Shop some time in the early 1990s. Twenty or so years later, his tiny shop at Chor Bazaar (91-98704-40970) is crammed with thousands of old film posters, lobby cards and assorted film memorabilia, Mr. Abu explained as he showed off carefully preserved ticket stubs for blockbuster movies from the 1960s and ’70s.

headline: Who Made That Hudson’s Bay Blanket?
text: The multistripe Hudson’s Bay point blanket (also referred to as the Glacier National Park Blanket and the Chief Blanket) follows a very simple aesthetic pattern: green stripe, red stripe, yellow stripe and indigo stripe on a white background, mirrored on the top and bottom of each blanket. Lately, that recognizable motif has adorned a number of items from travel mugs to boots to Swiss Army knives to snow boards. The versatility of the pattern is a testament to the endurance of that basic color combination. While the palette is mainly prized today for its aesthetic value, back in the early 1800s, those colored stripes bore special significance for aboriginal people of North America, who were Hudson’s Bay’s original customers.

headline: China Shuts Solar Panel Factory After Antipollution Protests

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Marios Schwab
text: “Do you mean what was the hair meant to look like or what did it end up being?” said Duffy, laughing backstage at Marios Schwab as a few models arrived within 10 minutes of starting time. Turns out the style was to be 40s waves à la Veronica Lake, Ingrid Bergman or Rita Hayworth. This was achieved using Clairol ColorSeal Gloss to prep the hair and then Frédéric Fekkai mousse before blow-drying and creating a low side part. A large-barrel curling iron set the front wave, clamped very tight until the end (“really cooking the hair”), when it was brushed out. For makeup, Val Garland created what she called a “film noir Fellini-flick look”: liquid liner on the top of the lid, a sooty matte on the bottom and M.A.C.’s Carbon shadow in between. M.A.C. Creme Colour Base contoured the face at the corners of the cheeks, the temples, even the cupid’s bow of the lips.

headline: Complaint Box | Get Out of Line
text: A few weeks ago, on a muggy summer afternoon, I had to fight my way through the throng outside the Palace Theater. My Aunt Emma wanted tickets to “Priscilla, Queen of the Desert,” and I was getting them for her. An usher brushed against me, ordering people to stay back. Nearby, a young man in a pink boa, struggling to set up his souvenir program booth, was hemmed in by the crowd.

headline: Asked & Answered | Bruce Jay Friedman
text: If there is an advantage to being an underappreciated novelist, it might be that when you get around to writing a memoir, the anecdotes of your life have not already been trotted out ad infinitum by book reviewers the world over. Such is the case with Bruce Jay Friedman, whose memoir, “Lucky Bruce,” will be published next month. On the strength of his early novels — “Stern” (1962), “A Mother’s Kisses” (1964) and “About Harry Towns” (1974) — Friedman was a literary star, frequently mentioned alongside Bernard Malamud and Philip Roth. He hung out at Elaine’s; edited for legendary Magazine Management pulp journals, where he hired Mario Puzo onto the staff of True Action; and, later, moonlighted as a screenwriter (“Stir Crazy,” “Splash”), rubbing shoulders with Warren Beatty and Richard Pryor. Yet Friedman has always remained somewhat under the radar. In “Lucky Bruce,” readers get fresh, amusing stories from Friedman’s life in letters — the time he provoked Norman Mailer into a fistfight by mussing his hair at a party, say, or was hired to write a script and introduced to his new secretary, a between-marriages Natalie Wood. The Moment caught up with Friedman, now 81, at one of his favorite Chinese restaurants in Manhattan, Chin Chin, to talk about his latest book.

headline: As Folk Art Museum Teeters, a Huge Loss Looms
text: Please. Someone, everyone, do something to save the American Folk Art Museum from dissolution and dispersal. Or at least slow down the process, so that all options can be thoroughly considered. New York’s contemporary artists, and New York as a whole, need the creative energy of this stubborn, single-minded little institution, its outstanding exhibition program and its wondrous collection, an unparalleled mixture of classic American folk art and 20th-century outsider geniuses.

headline: Three Favorite Novels by Le Carré

He moved beyond that territory, of course, to tailors in Panama, Palestinian terrorists and, later, big pharma in Nairobi, but for me, Le Carré will always be synonymous with the Cold War. My three favorites are from that era:

headline: Vain Glorious | Antonia Burrell
text: Though we’d like to believe that there was a magic time between the youthful distress of pimples and the more mature worry of wrinkles, when skin simply behaved, the evidence points increasingly to the contrary. “Just because you’re 35 doesn’t mean you’re not going to have breakouts,” says Antonia Burrell, a straight-talking facialist-turned skin-care guru, whose namesake, all-natural year-old line has a rabid following in her native Britain. The problem, according to Burrell, is our higher levels of exposure to a host of complexion-wrecking factors like stress, pollution and the chemicals and hormones in food. “I’ve been doing this for 18 years and the phenomenon of older women breaking out is not something I would see 10 years ago,” Burrell says. “After having so many clients moan to me about their skin, I decided to do something about it — but I wanted products that were holistic and a pleasure to use, not harsh chemicals that would dry out your skin. And I wanted to make them anti-aging, too.” At Shen Beauty in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, the only store in the United States that sells Burrell’s products, her multitasking, plant-extract-packed Cream Supreme moisturizer and deep cleaning Natural Glow Cleansing Oil are perennial best sellers. The co-owner Jessica Richards first tried the line just before the store opened late last year. “My skin was completely broken out from the stress of launching a business, and this cleared it up in, like, three days,” she says. “It’s like a natural version of Proactiv. People cannot get enough of this line.” Burrell’s products are so popular at Shen that hers is among the 12 lines that will be available to order online when the boutique’s retail Web site goes live later this week. Also in the works are plans to get Burrell to Shen sometime this fall so she can work her facial magic on the Brooklyn faithful. For those unwilling to wait, Burrell has a standing gig as a guest facialist at Harrods and also sees clients at the Urban Bliss spa in Notting Hill; appointments can be made through her Web site. But be aware — she’s usually booked three months in advance.

headline: The Truth About What Your Business Is Worth
text: About two years ago I told a business owner a number of things she wasn’t ready to hear about the sale of her business. She was disappointed with our meeting, called later to tell me she disagreed with what I had said, then listed her business for sale with one of my competitors. I didn’t lose much sleep over it at the time. In fact, I happened to admire both her and her business, and I slept better knowing that I had told her what I thought.

headline: Consumer Liability Unlikely to Change With New Credit Cards
text: Recently, Bucks noted Visa’s plans to speed up adoption in the United States of credit and debit cards that use E.M.V. chip technology, which is considered more secure than the old-fashioned magnetic strip cards prevalent here. The new cards are widespread in Europe, and some globetrotting Americans have complained that their cards don’t always work  overseas.

headline: London Design Festival | Pawson’s Perspectives
text: The emphasis at the London Design Festival — as at any contemporary design exhibition — is on the new new new. But a number of L.D.F. installations explore the idea of seeing the old in a different way, including those at the Victoria & Albert Museum (the subject of my next post) and — most spectacularly — the collaboration between the London architect John Pawson and Swarovski Crystal Palace at St. Paul’s Cathedral, Sir Christopher Wren’s masterpiece, which is celebrating its 300th anniversary this year. “Perspectives” opens to the public today, and remains open until mid-January 2012.

headline: Cervelli Is Symptom-Free and May Return Soon
text: One of the many questions swirling around the Yankees’ clubhouse heading into the postseason may soon be answered as catcher Francisco Cervelli, who has been out since sustaining a concussion on Sept. 8, was given an ImPACT test before the game Monday and may be cleared to play soon.

headline: Soros Family Office Names a New Chief Investment Officer

headline: How Far Will Dolphins Go to Relate to Humans?
text: OFF THE BAHAMAS — In a remote patch of turquoise sea, Denise L. Herzing splashes into the water with a pod of 15 Atlantic spotted dolphins. For the next 45 minutes, she engages the curious creatures in a game of keep-away, using a piece of Sargassum seaweed like a dog’s chew toy.

headline: Air Race Fans, Despite Crash, Remain Steadfast
text: RENO, Nev. — The fans come here each year looking for, even craving, the thrill they say they get only from seeing planes race at speeds of more than 400 miles per hour. At a small airport at the edge of the city, they tilt their heads skyward for hours, relishing each roar overhead.

headline: Channel Surfing: ‘The Sing-Off’
text: The subset of words that cannot be said on network television seems to shrink every year, but there’s one that remains way, way off-limits. It’s the king of the cuss words. And “The Sing-Off,” NBC’s slick singing-competition show for a cappella groups, encounters (and avoids) it for the second time in two seasons when it returns on Monday night at 8.

headline: Iran Arrests Filmmakers Accused of Working for BBC
text: Judicial authorities in Iran have arrested six people, accusing them of working covertly for the British Broadcasting Corporation’s Persian-language service and supplying it with content, including films, that depict the country in a negative way, the state-run press in Iran reported on Monday.

headline: Preventing Sickness, With Plenty of Red Tape
text: Prevention has never been the cornerstone of American medicine. In this country, we tend to go to the doctor only when something is wrong, a habit long bemoaned by researchers and medical groups.

headline: Deaths of Infants and Young Mothers Are Declining, but Goals Are Missed
text: Deaths of infants and young mothers continue to decline around the world, but nearly not as quickly as the world’s health ministers hoped when they set targets in 2000, according to an analysis released Monday by University of Washington researchers.

headline: New Video of Reno Air Race Crash
text: New video emerged on Monday of a deadly crash at an air race in Reno, Nev., last week as the toll from the accident climbed to 10 after another hospitalized victim died late on Sunday, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Housing Chief Admits Driving While Intoxicated
text: The New York State housing commissioner, Darryl C. Towns, who was arrested in July after crashing his car in Westchester County, pleaded guilty on Monday to a misdemeanor charge of driving while intoxicated and will lose his license for six months.

headline: Sentence of the Week, Fall Harvest Edition
text: The sentences fell this week like plump acorns out of the slowly reddening oak tree of my reading, stirred by the brisk early autumn breeze of my admiration, into the woven wicker basket of my Twitter feed. Please huddle around the toasty fire of your Web browser and enjoy the harvest:

headline: S.E.C. Official to Join Sidley Austin
text: James A. Brigagliano, a major Securities and Exchange Commission official, is leaving the agency to join the law firm of Sidley Austin as a partner.

headline: A Summer of Humans vs. Grizzlies
text: The summer of grizzlies continues in the Rocky Mountain West.

headline: Aging: Health Gains From a Small Drink a Day
text: Middle-aged women who have an alcoholic drink every day may increase their chances of enjoying health in their old age, according to a new report.

headline: Prevention: Flu Shots’ Benefits Seen in Hospital Study
text: A federal government recommendation to give preschoolers the flu vaccine has resulted in a large decrease in emergency room visits among 2- to 4-year-olds, new research has found. And there were benefits for older children as well.

headline: Five Playwrights Named in Signature Theater Initiative to Stage New Works
text: In a considerable expansion of its Off Broadway profile Signature Theater Company announced on Monday that five respected playwrights – Annie Baker, Will Eno, Katori Hall, Kenneth Lonergan, and Regina Taylor – would be charter members of a program to develop and stage their new works.

headline: Repaying Buffett Has Its Upside
text: When Warren E. Buffett invests in companies like General Electric or Goldman Sachs, markets almost always interpret it as a great vote of confidence. But is it not an even more positive signal when those same companies, returned to health and flush with abundant profits, pay him back? If so, then investors might want to use G.E.’s decision to return Mr. Buffett’s money — which served as a life raft to the company during the 2008 crisis — to reflect on just how much better off the American financial system has become.

headline: Investor Who Talked to Mets Buys Part of Yankees
text: Ray Bartoszek, the wealthy former oil trader who spent his entire life rooting for the Mets, had a chance this spring to buy a large minority share of the team. He came close to doing so, but the Mets instead chose to team up with David Einhorn, the hedge fund manager whose $200 million deal with the Mets eventually collapsed amid accusations that the team changed the terms of the arrangement at the last moment.

headline: A Big Drip
text: Q. What can I do about postnasal drip, sometimes so severe that I cough, choke or vomit?

headline: Life-Changing Learning: Reading and Writing About Educational Experiences
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York City, the author Junot Díaz, the guitarist Amy Klein and 12 more people from varied backgrounds told The New York Times about the educational experiences that changed their lives for a special issue of the Sunday magazine.

headline: New York Top 5 | Patrik Ervell
text: Patrik Ervell, a member of Opening Ceremony’s extended fashion family, showed his signature military-inspired jackets and slim-fit trousers for spring, adding a bit of whimsy to his often neutral landscape with a vivid watercolor print that appeared on everything from silky bomber jackets to short-sleeved camp shirts and ties. My favorite look had was a Hawaiian-style shirt paired with slim trousers with a gathered elastic cuff — a look that was more rad than trad.

headline: Bimmers, a Briggs and a Band of E-Types at Fairfield County Concours d’Élégance
text: WESTPORT, Conn. — The best thing about the 2011 Fairfield County Concours d’Élégance was the classic cars. The worst thing was all those other cars.

headline: Study Finds Higher Number of Pedestrians Hurt by Bikes
text: More than 500 New York City residents are injured badly enough to be treated in hospitals after being struck by bicyclists each year, according to an analysis by Hunter College professors. The number, while small compared with the number of pedestrians injured by cars, is a much higher figure than an earlier study by the same researchers found.

headline: N.F.L. Beats Emmy Awards in Ratings
text: The 63rd Primetime Emmy Awards — television’s celebration of, well, television — performed to expectations on Sunday, up slightly when compared with last year in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic coveted by advertisers. But the show on Fox was down in total viewers, to 12.4 million from 13.5 million. Those are respectable numbers considering that last year’s ceremony did not have to compete for viewers against the National Football League. This time, “Sunday Night Football” on NBC dominated the night in both ratings categories, according to preliminary overnight Nielsen estimates (the Atlanta Falcons defeated the Philadelphia Eagles, 35-31). Final audience figures were unavailable on Monday.

headline: Glenn Beck, Joel Klein, Amar’e Stoudamire and Others Reflect on Their Education
text: Sometimes in the process of putting a magazine together, a late-breaking idea emerges that seems worth taking a flier on. In the case of our education issue, that idea — to ask all sorts of influential and creative and inspiring people about the formative educational moments of their lives — was very, very late-breaking, indeed. Too late, really, for us to have much faith that it was going to work out. People are busy, after all. They have metropolises to run and rock shows to rock in and explanations for the fabric of the universe to nail down. And yet . . . when they received a call or an e-mail from someone here (in most cases, that person was the great Tony Gervino), many of those we reached out to agreed to sit down more or less immediately and type something out. Fifteen of those submissions are in this week’s issue. What follows below are several bonus tracks, arguments for the necessity of doing your homework (Glenn Beck) and reading Thucydides (David Brooks). Read, enjoy, and feel free to leave a comment describing the educational experience that made the difference for you.

headline: Sentence for Terrorist Is Too Short, Court Rules
text: MIAMI — A federal appeals court ruled on Monday that the 17-year prison sentence imposed on Jose Padilla, who was convicted of terrorism conspiracy in 2007, was too lenient and sent the case back to the district court here for a new hearing.

headline: Popularity May Have Doomed Chinese TV Talent Show
text: BEIJING — In the end, it was not the overabundance of sequins or the cringe-worthy ballads that doomed “Super Girl,” one of China’s most popular televised talent extravaganzas.

headline: A visit with evolutionary biologist Richard Dawkins, speaking with dolphins and why racing brings out your personal best.
text: A visit with evolutionary biologist Richard Dawkins, author of “The Selfish Gene” and “The God Delusion”; speaking with dolphins and why racing brings out your personal best.

headline: On Our Radar: Asian Climate Refugees
text: More than 30 million people in Asia were displaced last year by environmental and weather-related disasters, the Asian Development Bank warns. It predicts that climate change will uproot tens of millions more through sea-level rise, droughts, floods and food shortages in decades to come, and that governments must start to prepare. [The Guardian]

headline: TimesCast | September 19, 2011
text: President Obama vows to veto deficit-reduction plans that don't increase taxes; violence escalates in Yemen's capital; and the United Nations General Assembly begins.

headline: Fatal Bar Shooting Exposes Burundi’s Instability
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — A group of gunmen clad in army fatigues and armed with military-grade weapons burst into a crowded bar in Burundi on Sunday night and opened fire, Burundian officials said, killing more than 30 people and laying bare how combustible the country is a year after a disputed election.

headline: Look of the Moment | Victoria Beckham
text: The Look: The Cat’s Meow — a whimsical print spiked with killer platforms and a serious, structured bag.

headline: Bats Turn Up the Volume to Find Food Amid Clutter
text: Fruit bats make a clicking sound with their tongues to help them navigate their way to the fruits they feed on. The clicking produces a fan-shaped sonar beam that bounces off an object and returns an echo to the bat.

headline: Examining the Charges Against a UBS Trader
text: The $2.3 billion trading loss at UBS shows once again how a single employee who knows how to game internal accounting and reporting systems can wreak havoc at a financial firm. A trader at the Swiss bank, Kweku M. Adoboli, has been accused of making unauthorized trades and charged with fraud and false accounting. The charges outline a type of white-collar crime that does not involve theft so much as what looks like an effort to cover up bad decisions that ultimately spiraled out of control.

headline: Reader Photos: New York Fashion Week
text: We asked readers to send us their favorite photographic moments during New York Fashion Week. Here is a selection of the top images.

headline: The Last of the Fresh Greens
text: Depending on how far north you live, in September and early October farmers’ markets may still offer a great mix of vegetables that includes the last of the produce we associate with summer -- eggplant, peppers, summer squash, tomatoes -- and a wide selection of greens that will continue well into winter. This week I’ll offer a few ideas for entrees made with some of my favorites: Swiss chard, broccoli rabe, beet greens and bok choy, among others.

headline: Drilling Off Cyprus Will Proceed Despite Warnings From Turkey
text: ISTANBUL — In the face of menacing warnings from Turkey on Monday, the Greek Cypriot government said it was proceeding with exploratory drilling for oil and gas off the coast of the disputed island.

headline: A Magnet for Women? Try a Deep Male Voice
text: It’s official: Women are drawn to low male voices, like the basso profundo of the actor James Earl Jones. And they are more likely to remember what the owners of those voices say to them.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Yemen and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Yemen, Bangladesh, New York and Libya.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Yemen and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Yemen, Bangladesh, New York and Libya.

headline: A Little Deception Helps Push Athletes to the Limit
text: The trained bicyclists thought they had ridden as fast as they possibly could. But Kevin Thompson, head of sport and exercise science at Northumbrian University in England, wondered if they go could even faster.

headline: Bachmann Takes Aim at Buffett and Obama
text: SHEFFIELD, Iowa – Representative Michele Bachmann’s message to the billionaire who inspired the so-called Buffett Rule is simple.

headline: Navigator in Russian Crash Was Drunk, Report Says
text: MOSCOW — The navigator on a passenger airliner that crashed in June because it missed the runway was drunk, Russian aviation authorities have found, and the navigator’s condition and other errors by the crew and on the ground were to blame for the accident that killed 47 people.

headline: Sexuality in 1950s Hollywood
text: The opening scenes of “Play It Cool,” a new musical about a gay jazz club in 1950s Hollywood, promise mystery, scandal, provocation, eroticism and moral outrage. Unfortunately, the show is so busy bragging about its potential for these enticements that it fails to deliver on any of them.

headline: Moscow’s Ousted Mayor Criticizes Russian Politics
text: MOSCOW — Yuri M. Luzhkov, the former mayor of Moscow who was once one of Russia’s most powerful politicians, dismissed his country’s political system as a charade in an interview published on Monday, comparing Russia to an outsize Byzantium beholden to the whims of the Kremlin.

headline: Lawyer for Accuser Calls Strauss-Kahn’s Interview a ‘Publicity Stunt’
text: Dominique Strauss-Kahn’s interview with a French television station was nothing but “a publicity stunt,” a lawyer for the woman who accused him of sexual assault said on Monday.

headline: Rivera Gets His Record 602nd Save in Classic 1-2-3 Fashion
text: Just before 10:30 a.m. Monday, Mariano Rivera walked into the Yankees’ clubhouse in street clothes. Less than 15 minutes later, he was dressed and ready to go. By 4:30 p.m., he had passed Trevor Hoffman as the major league career leader in saves with 602.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Peter Pilotto
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Tony Stewart Starts the Chase With First Win of 2011
text: Having only qualified for the Nascar Sprint Cup playoffs in the final race of the regular season, just nine days ago in Richmond, Va., Tony Stewart was not expected to threaten the 2011 season’s frontrunners at Chicagoland Speedway on Monday afternoon. But because of a conservative fuel strategy and perhaps the overeagerness of more highly ranked competitors like Kyle Busch, Jimmie Johnson and Matt Kenseth, Stewart cruised to a surprising victory at the Joliet, Ill., track.

headline: How to Make the Sauce Pan a Pasta Pot
text: In this week’s column, I wrote about an Italian technique for cooking pasta that calls for finishing it in a pan of simmering sauce. Ever since I learned how to make pasta this way, I haven’t gone back to the usual drain-dump-and-toss-in-a-serving-bowl method.

headline: Dolores Hope, Singer and Bob Hope’s Widow, Dies at 102
text: Dolores Hope, who gave up her singing career to spend 69 years at the side of her husband, Bob Hope, pursuing philanthropy and projecting with him the image of an enduring Hollywood marriage, died on Monday in the home she and her husband bought in 1940 in the Toluca Lake section of Los Angeles. She was 102.

headline: In London, Burberry Mixes Artisanal Details With High Tech
text: Burberry staged another of its big live-stream events Monday, under a clear plastic tent in bucolic Kensington Park. Pedestrians and joggers got to see the fashion people arrive, and, of course, celebrities like Rachel Zoe and Kanye West, who attended the Christopher Kane show earlier in the day. The scene at Burberry was one big camera-flashing moment before the designer Christopher Bailey sent out the clothes to music by Jeff Beck and George Harrison, among others. His idea this season was to give Burberry’s trenches and bags an artisanal dimension, with crochet, beading and latticed leather on collars and sleeves. Shapes included full linen skirts with smallish knits and super-slim coats, as ruched and knotted skirts.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Christopher Kane
text: “Dear Diary,” was the reference bandied about backstage at Christopher Kane. This girl was young and cool, and collected, well, stickers (flowers, holograms, etc.), to decorate her secret-filled notebooks. In beauty terms, this translated into youthful, easy rolled buns created by Anthony Turner with TIGI Catwalk Volume Mousse and dry shampoo. Makeup was “all about a gorgeous flushed cheek,” said Lucia Pieroni of the three Chantecaille shades (Laughter, Emotion and Joy) she used to make the models appear as if they’d “just run up a mountain.” For eyes and lips, it was taupe-shiny Valerian shadow from the beauty brand’s new Classic Palette for lids and Lip Sheer in Comet on the mouth. “Rose-tinted, very girly,” is how the model Romee Strijd described the look. “Nostalgic, fresh, suited to the season.” Did she once keep a diary? “Yes, but I only wrote insignificant things down,” she said, avoiding any further questions.

headline: Remark on HPV Vaccine Could Ripple for Years
text: During a debate last week for Republican presidential candidates and in interviews after it, Representative Michele Bachmann called the vaccine to prevent cervical cancer “dangerous.” Medical experts fired back quickly. Her statements were false, they said, emphasizing that the vaccine is safe and can save lives. Mrs. Bachmann was soon on the defensive, acknowledging that she was not a doctor or a scientist.

text: Q.

headline: In a Married World, Singles Struggle for Attention
text: Here’s a September celebration you probably didn’t know about: It’s National Single and Unmarried Americans Week.

headline: With Stricter Rule on Hits to the Head, Some N.H.L. Stars Are Split on a Full Ban
text: The N.H.L. began its preseason Monday with a tightened Rule 48, which outlaws most checks to the head as part of the league’s response to the spate of concussions in hockey.

headline: Before Panama Canal, Snails Hitched a Ride
text: Long before there was a Panama Canal, at least two marine snails made a fantastic journey between oceans, crossing not on land or water but in the air.

headline: A Few Strokes of the Past in an Artist Who Lost Her Memory
text: “Can I draw something for you — what should I draw?” Lonni Sue Johnson asked, but she didn’t wait for an answer. She drew a squiggly line that became a curly halo of hair around the cheerful face of a seated man stretching one leg upward, balancing a large bird on his foot.

headline: For Obama, Peer Pressure from Nobel Laureates
text: With his approval rating among American voters at an all-time low, President Obama could use a little support from his peers. But this month nine fellow recipients of the Nobel Peace Prize, including Archbishop Desmond Tutu of South Africa and the Dalai Lama, sent the president a letter urging him to veto the construction of a huge pipeline that would bring bring crude oil to the United States from Canada.

headline: Panthers’ Newton Exceeds Expectations With Fast Start
text: Just a few weeks ago, Carolina Panthers Coach Ron Rivera was despairing over all the preparation time his team — young and rebuilding — missed because of the lockout. The rookie camp, the minicamps, the hours of practices, the hundreds of repetitions.

headline: Family and United Airlines Settle Last 9/11 Wrongful-Death Lawsuit
text: The last remaining wrongful-death lawsuit stemming from the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks has been resolved, according to a lawyer for the victim’s family and court papers filed on Monday.

headline: B and C Lines Suspended After Morning Water Main Break
text: 11:19 p.m. | Updated The water main rupture at 106th Street and Central Park West in Manhattan continued to keep the B and C trains out of service on Monday night, and A and D lines were still knocked out in much of Manhattan.

headline: New Tick-Borne Disease Is Discovered
text: A new tick-borne disease that may be stealthily infecting some Americans has been discovered by Yale researchers working with Russian scientists.

text: Years ago, a new worker or an employee visiting the home office for a week or two might be put up in a bare-bones company-owned apartment.

headline: ‘Atys’ Returns to BAM
text: William Christie and Les Arts Florissants presented Lully’s 1676 opera at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Harvey Theater.

headline: It’s Not Easy to Be a Goddess’s Boy Toy
text: When William Christie and Les Arts Florissants presented Lully’s “Atys” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music for the first time, in 1989, it was as if a curtain had been pulled aside to reveal an alternative operatic universe. The work was so different in sound, spirit and look from the 19th-century Italian operas that dominate the mainstream opera world that it seemed almost a different art form.

headline: TimesCast | Protesters Killed in Yemen
text: Violence in Yemen's capital continues into its second day, the worst since pro-democracy protests began in the spring.

headline: Neil Young Joins the Rock Star Memoir Parade
text: Neil Young, easily one of the most influential and enigmatic musicians of his generation, will write a memoir, his publisher said on Monday. Blue Rider Press, an imprint of Penguin Group USA, acquired the book after several years of discussions with Mr. Young, said David Rosenthal, the president and publisher.

headline: The President’s Deficit Plan
text: Last week, in the wake of President Obama’s jobs speech, I wrote that the president seemed poised to campaign for re-election on an essentially centrist policy agenda: A short-term payroll tax stimulus, a plan for tax reform that would close loopholes while lowering corporate rates, and a long-term plan for deficit reduction modeled on the grand bargain that the White House and John Boehner were supposedly close to striking during the debt ceiling negotiations. The president’s goal in 2012, I suggested, would be to try to paint himself as the moderate bipartisan grownup, and dismiss the Republicans as extreme, intransigent, and hyper-ideological.

headline: Newsroom Diversity Groups in Partnership
text: Unity: Journalists of Color, an organization whose goal is to promote newsroom diversity, is forming a partnership with the National Lesbian and Gay Journalists Association, the two groups announced Monday. This will be the first time that the lesbian and gay association will be on the board of Unity, and it will participate in the Unity convention in Las Vegas in 2012.

headline: From the Fire Hose: Fukushima Examined; Extreme Weather Probed
text: Here are a couple of important reads snagged from the nonstop fire hose of news:

headline: Inside Amazon’s Very Hot Warehouse
text: Amazon.com did not create the notion of buying things online, but it has done more than any other retailer to move the experience into the mainstream. It has exceeded its customers’ expectations so often it must constantly struggle to top itself. “At first people were incredulous that the mouse on their computer was connected to their doorbell,” the Amazon executive Russell Grandinetti said recently. “Now they say: ‘It’s been 12 hours. Where’s my stuff?’ ”

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘A Face in the Crowd’
text: In “A Face in the Crowd,” Andy Griffith plays Larry Rhodes, a drifter who is taken from an Arkansas jail and turned into a media sensation. He is first tapped to sing on the radio, but then lands his own television program as “Lonesome” Rhodes. His down-to-earth sensibilities make him a hit with audiences seeking someone with a voice similar to their own.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Erdem
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#796", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

headline: Tops in the Ninth
text: Mariano Rivera’s career with the Yankees began with his days as a starter in 1995 to his record 602nd career save on Monday afternoon.

headline: Remembering All but a Sister’s Murder
text: Stop me if this sounds familiar: A former police detective who left the force after being unable to get over or solve the murder of a loved one is still a valuable consultant to the police because of freakish powers of observation, and is still driven by a determination to find that loved one’s killer.

headline: Prequel for a Heavyweight: Hero Gets His Back Story
text: Lee Child’s books usually concentrate on the strategic genius of Jack Reacher, who has long since earned his prominent place in the pantheon of cool, smart-talking American heroes. But “The Affair” shows off the gifts of a different strategist: the author himself. Mr. Child understood how and why the 16th book in this series had to be different from the first 15. He knew it was time for a big, exciting surprise.

headline: Austin City Limits Festival
text: The 10th installment of the three-day music festival happened in the city’s Zilker Park last weekend.

headline: Praying for High Hill Country Rain, and Other Austin Pursuits
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Win Butler, the lead singer of Arcade Fire, wasn’t just talking idly about the weather on Sunday night during the early stretch of the band’s closing slot at the Austin City Limits Music Festival. “I can honestly say that this is the first time we’ve ever been to a festival where we’re just praying that it’s going to rain the whole time,” he said, eliciting a cheer. “So it’s all happened now. Anything’s possible.”

headline: With Nods to Schoenberg and Dr. King
text: The new collaborative work “Black Moon (La Lune Noir) Act I,” which was performed at Dance New Amsterdam on Friday night, started out with a question: What was it like to be alive in the era of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.?” In the voice-over that followed, the answer had much to do with the strength of solidarity. At times, in the words of an unidentified woman being interviewed, it was an experience of “total unity.”

headline: TimesCast | The Deficit Debate
text: President Obama presents his deficit reduction plan, vowing to veto any plan that doesn't raise taxes on the rich.

headline: Elite, All-Male University of the Wild West To Go Coed
text: Deep Springs College, the historically all-male two-year institution located on a cattle ranch in California, voted on Saturday that it would admit women.

headline: Rick Perry Takes Upper Manhattan
text: Just as President Obama was landing at New York’s John F. Kennedy Airport, preparing to take a chopper to lower Manhattan before driving up the East Side to the United Nations, Gov. Rick Perry was wrapping up his own event at the opposite tip of the borough.

text: SUPERHEAVY

headline: Bolton’s Holden to Return on Tuesday
text: United States midfielder Stuart Holden, who has not played for Bolton since sustaining a knee injury in March, will return to the Premier League club’s first team on Tuesday for a Carling Cup match against Aston Villa.

headline: Delay in New Rules for Retirement Account Advisers
text: After receiving much criticism from the financial services industry and lawmakers, the Labor Department said Monday that it would rethink a proposed new rule requiring more investment professionals to take responsibility for the advice they provide to investors in retirement plans, including 401(k)s and individual retirement accounts.

text: It says everything about Tony Bennett that his Metropolitan Opera concert on Sunday evening was an intimate, no-frills affair: a great popular singer and his quartet casually doing what they do better than anybody else.

headline: U.S. Is Quietly Getting Ready for Syria Without Assad
text: WASHINGTON — Increasingly convinced that President Bashar al-Assad of Syria will not be able to remain in power, the Obama administration has begun to make plans for American policy in the region after he exits.

headline: Pirates’ Strong Showing in Berlin Elections Surprises Even Them
text: BERLIN — With laptops open like shields against the encroaching cameramen, the young men resembled Peter Pan’s Lost Boys more than Captain Hook’s buccaneers when they were introduced Monday as Berlin’s newest legislators: They are the members of the Pirate Party.

headline: Edible Selby | Next, by Grant Achatz
text: In our interactive feature, Grant Achatz discusses Next, a restaurant where the entire concept changes every three months.

headline: Restoring a Meadow to Grandeur
text: At six acres, the East Meadow is neither the largest nor the most heavily used of Central Park’s seven major lawns. But its reopening on Tuesday morning represents an important milestone for the park. It is the final meadow to be restored, in the culmination of a three-decade experiment in which an outside group, the Central Park Conservancy, was created to raise private funds, map out an ambitious restoration plan and then execute it.

headline: Philadelphia Frets as Eagles Take Their Time With Vick
text: PHILADELPHIA — Fans in this city awoke Monday with a sense of unease. Their beloved Eagles lost the night before. There were second-guesses about moves, or the lack thereof, by Coach Andy Reid. And it became worse: Michael Vick had sustained a concussion.

headline: Millions May Go to Girl’s Family in Hacking Case
text: LONDON — The family of Milly Dowler, the teenage murder victim whose voice mail messages were illegally intercepted by The News of the World, has been offered a multimillion-dollar settlement by the tabloid’s parent company, a person with knowledge of the negotiations said Monday.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,759 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

text: JARRITOS, a Mexican soft drink popular among Hispanics in the United States, is introducing new advertising to win over non-Hispanic young men in the hope that they will spread the brand’s message even farther.

headline: Good Enough, Not Old Enough, for L.P.G.A.
text: PRATTVILLE, Ala.

headline: Led by Demand in China, Energy Use Is Projected to Rise 53% by 2035
text: Global energy demand will increase 53 percent from 2008 through 2035, with China and India accounting for half of the growth, the United States Department of Energy said on Monday.

headline: Without Jobs, Apple Shares Hit All-Time High
text: At the end of regular trading Monday, Apple shares closed at $411.63, up 2.78 percent, with a new record-high market valuation of $381.62 billion. It is now clearly the most valuable company on the stock market, displacing Exxon Mobil, with a market capitalization of $358.34 billion.
