headline: 2010 Data Show Surge in Poor Young Families
text: WASHINGTON — More than one in three young families with children were living in poverty last year, according to an analysis of census data by the Center for Labor Market Studies at Northeastern University.

headline: Iraq: 11 Inmates Die in Prison Fire
text: A fire at the Rusafa prison in Baghdad killed 11 inmates and wounded 22 others on Monday, security officials said. “All the time we hear about these kinds of incidents and we have to put an end to them, and we will investigate it,” said Joma Ibrahim, a Parliament member. Another official, seeking to quell speculation that the fire might have been started in an attempted jailbreak, said the fire was caused by an electrical malfunction, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Republican Requests for Clean Energy Funding
text: Some of the letters sent by or signed by Republicans in support of aiding clean energy efforts who are now publicly criticizing the Obama administration over Solyndra.

headline: Chinese Official Calls for Korea Talks
text: The Chinese foreign minister, Yang Jiechi, called on Monday for the resumption of international talks over North Korea’s nuclear program. The negotiations, involving the two Koreas, the United States, Russia, Japan and China, stalled in 2009. In August, Kim Jong-il, left, the North Korean leader, said that he was willing to return to the talks as long as there were no conditions and that he would consider a moratorium on the nuclear program if talks resumed. The United States and South Korea have said they will resume the talks only if North Korea meets promises related to the nuclear program. The top nuclear envoys from North Korea and South Korea are scheduled to meet in Beijing on Wednesday.

headline: The Use of Internet Databases for Research
text: To the Editor:

headline: With Their All-Pro Center Hurt, Jets Are Turning to an Undrafted Rookie
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — On the morning when everything changed for Colin Baxter, nothing did. After arriving at the Jets’ facility Monday, he lifted weights, ate breakfast and watched videotape of their 32-3 mauling of Jacksonville.

headline: California: Tiny All-Male College Will Admit Women
text: Resolving decades of debate, the trustees of Deep Springs College, a tiny, free, all-male college in an isolated eastern California valley, voted over the weekend to admit women. In a Sunday e-mail to alumni, David Hitz, the president of the board, said the “earliest conceivable date” women might be admitted to the two-year liberal arts college is the summer of 2013, but added that it was too early to know whether that would be possible. The 26 students at Deep Springs, in Big Pine, have had unusual control over the college’s admission, hiring and curriculum since its founding in 1917. They are required to work at least 20 hours a week on the college’s farm or cattle ranch. Most graduates complete their bachelor’s degrees at Ivy League colleges.

headline: In Galleon Case, Prison Term Is Seen as Test
text: Peter Foley/Bloomberg NewsProsecutors want Raj Rajaratnam, who was convicted of securities fraud and conspiracy, to be sentenced to as much as 24 years.

headline: Georgia: Tyson Agrees to $32 Million Settlement
text: More than 17,000 workers employed by Tyson Foods at 41 poultry plants in 12 states will receive back pay as part of a $32 million settlement that ends a 12-year-old federal lawsuit, the United Food and Commercial Workers Union announced on Monday. The workers accused Tyson of violating the Fair Labor Standards Act by failing to pay them for time spent putting on and taking off gear they were required to wear to protect themselves and the poultry. The union, which helped bring the lawsuit, said that current and former Tyson workers would receive payments averaging about $1,000. A federal district judge in Georgia approved the settlement last Thursday.

headline: Israel Reoccupies Embassy in Cairo
text: CAIRO — The Israeli Embassy here appeared to reopen Monday, ending a 10-day shutdown after a mob broke into the building and its staff was hastily withdrawn.

headline: Massachusetts: Ex-Probation Commissioner Charged
text: The former commissioner of the Massachusetts Department of Probation was indicted Monday as part of a continuing investigation into patronage hiring there. According to the indictment, the commissioner, John J. O’Brien, conspired with the chief of staff to Timothy Cahill, then the state treasurer, to organize a fund-raiser for Mr. Cahill in 2005 in exchange for a job for Mr. O’Brien’s wife. Mr. Cahill’s former chief of staff, Scott S. Campbell, was also indicted. Mr. O’Brien resigned last year after an independent report detailed rampant patronage in the probation department.

headline: Republicans Sought Clean-Energy Money for Home States
text: WASHINGTON — On the Senate floor and the television airwaves, Senator Mitch McConnell has lambasted the Obama administration over what he has described as its failed efforts to stimulate new jobs through clean-energy projects backed with billions of dollars in federal loans or other assistance.

headline: Unquestionably Alone at the Top
text: In the early morning after the Yankees’ last championship, in 2009, Mariano Rivera sat beaming at a table in a conference room across from the home clubhouse in the Bronx. It was informal, a few writers gathered around, asking if Rivera really meant what he had just said on the field, that he wanted to play five more seasons. Yes, Rivera insisted, he was serious.

headline: Worry About a New Wave of Layoffs
text: Not again. That is the plea of many Americans fearful about their jobs as the economy falters.

headline: Obama Proposes $320 Billion in Medicare and Medicaid Cuts Over 10 Years
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s budget director said Monday that the president’s new deficit-reduction plan would impose “a lot of pain,” and that is clearly true of White House proposals to cut $320 billion from projected spending on Medicare and Medicaid in the coming decade.

headline: Proposition 8 Hearing Video Is Ordered Released by Judge
text: A federal judge has ordered the release of the video recordings of hearings on Proposition 8, California’s ban on same-sex marriage.

headline: Guess Who’s Not Coming to Dinner
text: Columbia University and Mahmoud Ahmadinejad might seem to be an odd couple, but for a while last week it looked as if they might be dating. A few years back, when an invitation (extended by a dean) to the Iranian leader generated outrage and bad publicity, Columbia’s president, Lee Bollinger, responded by trashing Ahmadinejad before introducing him. On Sept. 13 Fox News reported that an undergraduate organization — the Columbia International Relations Council and Association (CIRCA) — had set up a dinner, scheduled for the 21st, at which Ahmadinejad would interact with a group of students and, perhaps, with Bollinger.

headline: Tax Plan to Turn Old Buildings ‘Green’ Finds Favor
text: A business consortium that includes Lockheed Martin and Barclays bank plans to invest as much as $650 million over the next few years to slash the energy consumption of buildings in the Miami and Sacramento areas. It is the most ambitious effort yet to jump-start a national market for energy upgrades that many people believe could eventually be worth billions.

headline: Afghanistan: Province Hit by 2 Attacks
text: A suicide bomber on a motorbike blew himself up outside a district police headquarters in a generally peaceful area of northern Afghanistan near the Turkmenistan border, killing four people. The attack was in the Aqcha District of Jowzjan Province, known for its carpet weavers. In a separate attack in Jowzjan Province, five border police officers were killed by a roadside bomb. Mullah Khudai Nazar Qumsayee, the chief of the provincial elders’ council, accused the government of neglect. “The Taliban are now in the stage of infiltration in Jowzjan,” he said, “and are prodding mullahs to preach in their favor.”

headline: Voter Apathy Is Leaving Much of the City on the Sidelines of Democracy
text: I jumped in my car on the evening of last week’s special Congressional election in Brooklyn and Queens and switched to WCBS radio in hopes of catching some early returns.

headline: Bloggingheads: A Smarter War on Terror
text: Robert Wright, left, of Bloggingheads.tv and Scott Atran of the University of Michigan debate how to wage a better war on terror.

headline: A Desperate Overnight Drive to Get Out of Europe
text: AS an entrepreneur, I don’t have a lot of time to myself since I’m really focused on the business. So when I’m in that airplane, I try to unwind. I laugh at myself because I take that time to watch movies, including some really bad ones that I wouldn’t dream of seeing at a theater. But when I’m on the plane, I don’t care how bad a movie may be, I’m watching it.

headline: In Small Towns, Gossip Moves to the Web, and Turns Vicious
text: MOUNTAIN GROVE, Mo. — In the small towns nestled throughout the Ozarks, people like to say that everybody knows everybody’s business — and if they do not, they feel free to offer an educated guess.

headline: Spinoff Lesson Learned, Tyco Treads Carefully
text: Shareholders appreciate a good breakup story, and Tyco is giving them more to love. The company, an industrial manufacturing group, divided itself into three parts in 2007. Now one of them, Tyco International, is being carved into three more pieces. The company’s shares gained on Monday amid a broad market sell-off. But while equity investors often see value in a less sprawling conglomerate, the same isn’t always true for bondholders.

headline: With Big Paydays at Stake, College Teams Scramble for a Spot
text: Universities around the country are tossing aside longtime rivalries, geographic sensibilities and many of the quaint notions ascribed to amateur athletics in an attempt to cash in on billion-dollar television deals and the financial security they provide.

headline: Greece Nears the Precipice, Raising Fear
text: Slower economic growth throughout Europe, and probably in the United States. Huge losses by major European banks. Declining stock markets worldwide. A tightening of credit, making it harder for many borrowers to get loans.

headline: Airport Maps and Apps to Guide a Hungry Traveler
text: I WAS rushing for a flight early one morning and grabbed the first convenient thing I saw for breakfast — a big, gooey Cinnabon from a counter near the gate.

headline: A Glimpse of a Mayor’s Baronial Side, at Home
text: He has been known to serve tuna on crackers during cocktail hour. He prefers diners to power-breakfast spots like the Regency. His sartorial style remains buttoned down, with a salmon-color crew neck and matching socks about as gaudy as it gets.

headline: A Call for Fairness
text: This time, President Obama did not compromise with himself beforehand, or put out a half measure in hopes of luring nonexistent Republican support. This time, he issued an unabashed call for economic fairness in cutting the federal deficit, asking as much from those on the economy’s upper rungs as from those lower down whose programs may be trimmed.

headline: Hundreds of Civilians Flee the Struggle Over a Qaddafi Stronghold
text: SURT, Libya — During lulls between mortar and rocket barrages, hundreds of civilians fled this coastal city on Monday after five days of fierce clashes between fighters loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and former rebel fighters, which are settling into a stalemate and raising fears of another bloody siege in the still unresolved Libyan conflict.

headline: Fighting Over Last Qaddafi Strongholds Continues
text: Despite control of the capital, Tripoli, the former Libyan rebels have yet to secure several towns and areas still largely loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: New Buffett Manager Gets Higher Taxes and Less Pay, by Choice
text: How would you feel about taking a pay cut and paying more in taxes?

headline: 4 Insurers Will Supply Health Data
text: Several major health insurers have agreed to provide their claims data on a regular basis to academic researchers, in an unusual agreement that they say will open a window onto the rising costs of health care.

headline: Building a Safer Haiti
text: Post-quake Haiti is a dangerous place, as a new report from the International Crisis Group makes clear. Hundreds of thousands of displaced people still live in poorly policed camps where they fall prey to rapes, robberies and other violent crimes. Prison escapees have regrouped in urban slums; drug traffickers and armed gangs are back in business.

headline: Japan: Progress at Damaged Nuclear Plants
text: Japan is making progress in cooling the three damaged reactors at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant and should be able to shut them down by year’s end, at least a month earlier than expected, the minister in charge of the disaster said Monday. Speaking at an international nuclear energy meeting in Vienna, the minister, Goshi Hosono, also promised to strengthen oversight of Japan’s nuclear industry by creating a more independent regulatory body by next spring. The Japanese government is responding to growing criticism at home and abroad of its inability to bring the reactors under control, and also of lax oversight that many say played a role in the accident. Also on Monday, about 60,000 anti-nuclear protesters gathered in Tokyo, in Japan’s largest demonstration since a huge earthquake and tsunami crippled the plant on March 11.

headline: Fewer Teenagers in Lockups
text: Federal statistics released earlier this summer show that the number of juvenile offenders held under lock and key dropped by about 25 percent during the last decade, and by more than half in Vermont, Connecticut, New Mexico and Louisiana. That’s welcome news, given that young offenders who are locked up are more likely to become dangerous criminals than those who are supervised through community-based guidance programs.

headline: Our Hidden Government Benefits
text: Ithaca, N.Y.

headline: New Fields May Propel Americas to Top of Oil Companies’ Lists
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil has begun building its first nuclear submarine to protect its vast, new offshore oil discoveries. Colombia’s oil production is climbing so fast that it is closing in on Algeria’s and could hit Libya’s prewar levels in a few years. ExxonMobil is striking new deals in Argentina, which recently heralded its biggest oil discovery since the 1980s.

headline: Giants Hope Stokley Can Be the Playmaker They Need on Third Down
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants’ search during training camp for a replacement for receiver Steve Smith included a former undrafted free agent, a veteran recovering from a knee injury and an unlikely 6-foot-6 target.

headline: Obama Rejects Obamaism
text: I’m a sap, a specific kind of sap. I’m an Obama Sap.

headline: New Challenges for Obama and Turkey’s Premier
text: WASHINGTON — When President Obama sits down with Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey on Tuesday at the United Nations, he will mark another chapter in what is perhaps the most intense relationship that he has cultivated with a foreign leader.

headline: Tuesday: Echolocation Acronym
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — We haven’t seen Daniel Raymon around these American crossword parts since 2008 (Across Lite, Solution), although he does construct a cryptic crossword puzzle now and again.

headline: Deer Hunts and Dirt Bikes
text: Paul Ryan may not be running for president this time around, but if you have any doubt about his ambitions for a long, prominent future in government, just look at his comments in a Q. and A. published in Sunday’s Times. They’re a minor masterpiece of image calibration.

headline: Diplomats Scramble as Palestinians Plan to Apply for U.N. Membership on Friday
text: UNITED NATIONS — The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, said Monday that he would present an application for Palestine to join the United Nations immediately after he addresses the General Assembly on Friday, as diplomats worked frenetically to try to limit the fallout from the application.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Defections Won’t Sabotage Big East, Top Official Says
text: A defiant John Marinatto, the Big East commissioner, said Monday night that he was confident the league would emerge stronger from the loss of Syracuse and Pittsburgh to the Atlantic Coast Conference over the weekend.

headline: No Extra Credit
text: What if everything that is happening in Washington right now is just meaningless noise?

headline: Grand Jury Is Set to Act in Ticket-Fixing Inquiry
text: The grand jury that has been hearing evidence in the long-running police ticket-fixing investigation is expected to begin deciding on charges in the case as early as Tuesday, and people with knowledge of the matter said as many as 17 officers — among them a lieutenant and two sergeants —would most likely face charges.

headline: Queens Woman Testifies She Killed Her Husband in Self-Defense
text: A Queens secretary accused of killing her husband testified on Monday that she shot him in self-defense when he pointed a loaded pistol at her head after she had refused to accompany him on a Florida vacation.

headline: The Fallen Face of the Mets
text: ATLANTA — The emptiness of his team’s existence in the final weeks of baseball’s regular season has reduced David Wright, the tireless worker, the true company man, into something of an office drone, punching the clock, playing out the string.

headline: Moving Jobs Across Hudson, Company Wins Tax Breaks From Both Sides
text: Pearson Education could teach someone a few things about how to play one state off against another.

headline: TimesCast | Diplomats Arrive in New York
text: The Palestinian plan to apply for United Nations membership dominated conversations behind the scenes as world leaders gathered in New York.

headline: Pre-Election Polls Underestimate the Success of Women Candidates
text: In the run-up to 2008, there was no end of speculation about the so-called Bradley Effect or Wilder Effect — the theory that polls tend to overestimate the vote share of black candidates — and what it meant for Barack Obama. But the actual evidence for this effect is weak. Whatever effect may have existed when Tom Bradley and Douglas Wilder were running for office does not exist now.

headline: MacArthur Foundation Selects 22 ‘Geniuses’
text: An economist whose investigations into student achievement examined the impact of rewards for good grades; a Pulitzer Prize winner who was the country’s 16th poet laureate; and a clinical psychologist seeking to pinpoint who is at risk for suicide were among the 22 recipients of the $500,000 “genius awards,” to be announced on Tuesday by the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation.

headline: Kurt Sanderling, Eastern Bloc Conductor, Dies at 98

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Papers Tuesday
text: The effects of the 6.8-magnitude earthquake that struck Sikkim on Sunday evening continued to surface as the death toll in India, Nepal and Tibet reached 71, while many more are feared dead buried under the debris of buildings. (Hindustan Times)  At the epicenter of the quake, in north Sikkim, the count rose to 41 on Monday. Sikkim Chief Minister Pawan Kumar Chamling said that along with the national highway, state highway and other important linking roads, the electricity transmission lines and water supply have also been affected. Though nearly 6,000 army and paramilitary forces personnel were deployed, landslides and blocked roads hindered their ability to reach the most severely affected areas. (Times of India)Narendra Modi continues to dominate headlines as he ended his three-day fast with a speech urging India to “dream like Gujarat.”(Indian Express) He also announced a one-day fast in every district of the state “to strengthen the spirit of unity and brotherhood.” While his closing speech steered clear of the 2002 riots, he attempted to reach out to the Muslim population with claims to pluralism and Urdu advertisements drawing a parallel with Roza – the monthlong fast during Ramadan. (Hindustan Times) However, when a maulvi, or religious scholar, offered him a skullcap as a mark of respect Modi refused, accepting a shawl instead.

headline: My Struggle With Pricing
text: We had plenty of inquiries, but no sales in the last week of August and the first two weeks of September. Frankly, I’m a little bit nervous. Dry patches are not unheard of in this business, but three weeks is about as long as I have gone without a new order. Maybe it was just the end of summer, and decision makers weren’t around to make decisions. We could well get a clump of new business soon — we have lots of proposals sitting out there, the clients swear that the jobs are still alive, but still. Why don’t they pull the trigger? Is it fear of a recession? Or could it be our pricing? At the beginning of August, after months of good sales, I made a very slight adjustment to our pricing, adding in an extra 2 percent for the salesmen. Did that slight hike make a difference?

headline: Solar Installations Rise, but Manufacturing Declines

headline: Visions of an Age When Oil Isn’t King
text: Daniel Yergin is America’s most influential energy pundit, and the book that put him on the map was “The Prize: The Epic Quest for Oil, Money, and Power” (1991). It was a best seller, won a Pulitzer Prize and was tailored into a popular PBS mini-series. In the two decades since, Mr. Yergin, operating as a kind of one-man think tank, has had a virtual monopoly on the subject of energy and geopolitics. Such is his influence that one half expects his competitors to file antitrust litigation against him.

headline: Asked & Answered | Christopher Bollen
text: As the longtime editor of downtown magazines like V and Interview, the writer Christopher Bollen has lived for years at the center of New York life in all of its diverse iterations, from creative glitz through cutthroat entrepreneurialism to the desperation bred by failed dreams. In “Lightning People” (Soft Skull, $25), his first novel, Bollen turns his inside-as-inside-gets perspective and experience with young creative Manhattanites into fertile literary ground, cultivating a tale of the city as universal and globe-spanning as it is singular and all his own. Bollen will take part in a talk, and a reading, at the Union Square Barnes & Noble on Thursday. Following the release of his book last week — and the expected release party filled with art and fashion luminaries — The Moment sat down with Bollen to ask a few questions.

headline: Do I Have To Read Ron Suskind’s Book?
text: OK, obviously I do have to read his account of what went wrong. But I was tearing my hair out, very much in public, over the missed opportunities early in the Obama administration in real time, as they happened; I don’t see much point in dwelling on them again, at least for now — maybe I’ll want to do postmortems after Rick Perry is sworn into office.

headline: T Exclusive Video | ‘Honey Bunny’ by Girls
text: San Franciscans sometimes get a bad rep. On behalf of all of the Bay Area (or so it seems), watch the Girls’ frontman Christopher Owens play about town singing lyrics like, “They don’t like my bony body, they don’t like my dirty hair,” in their new video for the track “Honey Bunny,” off their recently released sophomore album, “Father, Son, Holy Ghost” (True Panther Sounds). Surprisingly, the title of this record, which was released last Tuesday to rave reviews, does not directly refer to Owens’s childhood in the infamous Children of God cult, he said. Instead, the moody album — filled with heavy metal riffs that channel Fleetwood Mac, and light ’60s strumming that brings you back to the Beach Boys, supported by hallowing gospels — reaches down deeper than that: to Owens’s relationship with women, primarily his mother. This record is no doubt less lo-fi than their first, but the straightforward and honest sentiment Owens and the bassist and producer J.R. White bring feels evermore present. Currently on a United States tour, Girls talked to The Moment about their new song “Honey Bunny,” which Owens initially wrote using his cellphone, and the video, imagined by White. Girls will play at New York’s Bowery Ballroom on Thursday and Friday.

headline: Georgia Pardons Board Denies Clemency for Death Row Inmate

headline: There Are Worse Things Than Inflation
text: Like me, Tim Duy comes down hard on Paul Volcker’s inflation-is-history’s-greatest-monster op-ed. I pointed out that the last time we were in an economic trap resembling our current predicament, inflation actually helped get us out. Duy adopts a somewhat different but complementary approach: he asks just how bad the evil inflationary 1970s actually were. And the answer is, not nearly as bad as the noninflationary 00s. text: Will this be the first Broadway musical where you’ll have to pass a football trivia contest before they let you take your seats? A singing, dancing version of “Diner,” Barry Levinson‘s 1982 coming-of-age comedy about a group of friends growing up in Baltimore in 1959, is headed to Broadway next year, its press representatives said on Tuesday. Mr. Levinson, who directed the original film and earned an Academy Award nomination for its screenplay, will write the book of the “Diner” musical, and Sheryl Crow will write the music and lyrics; Kathleen Marshall, a recent Tony Award-winner for her choreography of “Anything Goes,” will direct and choreograph this production.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Burberry
text: Consider Burberry’s history as a heritage brand and it follows that wind and weather were the inspiration for this season’s beauty. The hairstylist Neil Moodie wanted to make each girl look as if she’d just been out in the crisp air for a walk. He created loose, tousled strands by prepping with Bumble & Bumble Styling Lotion and then using a large-barrel curling iron. This easy approach was in contrast to the polished 1960s girl of last season — especially when topped off with cheery pompom hats. As for makeup, Wendy Rowe used Burberry Beauty’s new Fresh Glow foundation all over the skin with Russet Blush and Tulip Pink lip color. On the eyes were a trio of shadows: Almond, Taupe and Pale Barley, a gray-gold used at the inner corners.

headline: Disney to Add ‘Avatar’ to Theme Parks
text: 3:56 p.m. | Updated LOS ANGELES — The world of Pandora is coming to Walt Disney World. In a deal that underscores Disney’s continued spending on new theme park attractions, the entertainment conglomerate has obtained exclusive global theme park rights to the hit movie “Avatar” from 20th Century Fox, the two companies said on Tuesday morning. The partnership will include much more than a ride. “Avatar,” which sold $2.8 billion in tickets at the global box office, will form the foundation for a themed land at Animal Kingdom, the newest of the four major parks that make up Disney World in Orlando, Fla. Animal Kingdom is built around the theme of mankind’s responsibility to nature, which is also the core message of “Avatar.”

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Mary Katrantzou
text: It took five people to carry the finale dress for Mary Katrantzou backstage before the show, where it was to be sewn onto a model after she was finished with hair and makeup. When it arrived, the full beauty look remained undecided as Val Garland was still mixing M.A.C. pigments to sort out the perfect 10 holographic shades to be painted on lips. “If you look at the clothes, they are all really colorful and energetic,” she said. “Sam [McKnight] did great, sexy hair. It felt right to do a statement, but not makeup makeup.” This meant choosing to do simply a striking mouth to complement the collection. Garland’s been known to go on instinct when it comes to Katrantzou. It was during her first season that Garland decided to change up the makeup hours before the presentation. Twelve girls were sent out with 12 different versions of eyeliner, a look that ended up creating quite a stir. For spring, the bold lip needed little else save for a sheer, sparkling nail (Nailgirls Pink 19) and simple ponytail. “Incredibly naïve, childlike — and clean” is how McKnight described the hair, which was pulled back with pieces pulled out as “a veil all around the hairline, so that it wafts when she moves.” To start, he wanted models to have perfectly washed hair, which was achieved by shampooing and conditioning with Pantene Color Protection products in the bathroom sink. “The loo’s three floors over,” McKnight said. “They were not very happy about that.”

headline: In Rio de Janeiro, Juice Bars That Are More Than Juice

By some measures, Rio de Janeiro and São Paulo are now more costly than London or New York or Oslo — amazing considering that some of their municipal services are more like those in La Paz or Dakar.

headline: Emanuel to Headline Jefferson-Jackson Dinner in Iowa
text: Four years ago, Barack Obama stole the show –- and advanced his struggling candidacy -– at the Jefferson-Jackson dinner in Iowa.

headline: Repeal Day: The End of ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’
text: The 18-year-old “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy officially ended on Tuesday and with it the discharges that removed more than 13,000 men and women from the military under the old ban on openly gay troops. At War is providing updates in real time from the official Pentagon news conference where Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta and Adm. Mike Mullen, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, will usher in the new era, as well as reaction from around the Web.

headline: S.E.C. Hid Its Lawyer’s Madoff Ties
text: After Bernard L. Madoff’s giant Ponzi scheme was revealed, the Securities and Exchange Commission went to great lengths to make sure that none of its employees working on the case posed a conflict of interest, barring anyone who had accepted gifts or attended a Madoff wedding.

headline: In Trying to Walk Away From Deal, Cerberus Has Weak MAC Claim
text: Cerberus Capital Management and Chatham Lodging Trust have a court date.

headline: Reality Hits Some New York ‘Housewives': They’re Off the Show
text: Friends come and go, and so do housewives.

headline: Saudi Prince Rebuts Claim of Rape in Spain
text: MADRID — The office of Prince Alwaleed bin Talal bin Abdulaziz al-Saud, a billionaire investor and nephew of King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia, released documents to rebut an accusation that the prince raped a Spanish woman on a luxury yacht off the Mediterranean island of Ibiza three years ago.

headline: Islam Is More Ideology Than Religion, F.B.I. Analyst Says in Video
text: The video is dull — seminar room, dim lights, PowerPoint — but its message from an F.B.I. counterterrorism analyst is provocative: fighting Al Qaeda and other extremist groups is a “waste” compared to the broader threat posed by Islam itself.

headline: First Prize for a Child in Somalia: An AK-47
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — A typical prize for a children’s contest might be a backpack, a lunchbox or maybe some toys.

headline: Joseph Ogrodnek of Anella Is Opening Battersby in Carroll Gardens
text: Joseph Ogrodnek, who left his job as executive chef at Anella in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, in February, has teamed up with Walker Stern, a friend and chef who also was at Anella, to open Battersby, a 30-seat spot for locavore cooking with influences from all over the map.

headline: La Otra Cuba
text: Post-Fidel anticipation has tourists flocking to Cuba to bask in the sunset of the revolution: the patched-together Studebakers, the stuck-in-time streetscapes. But visitors often leave without a real sense of the island’s rich, pre-Communist past, much less its inscrutable present — both the subjects of new photo books. Michael Dweck’s “Habana Libre” (above left, Damiani, $65) is a sun-baked “Who’s Who” of Cuba’s cultural elite. Michael Connors’s “Splendor of Cuba” (above right, Rizzoli, $85) catalogs the country’s 450-year architectural history, casting a rosy eye on exquisitely preserved examples of Spanish-Creole colonial style.

headline: Of Beach Sand, ‘War’ and Carbon
text: Three years ago, my colleague Andrew Ross Sorkin caught the British entrepreneur Richard Branson on his private island in the Caribbean in a pensive moment. With a little help from his friends, he was thinking hard about the problem of global warming, and whether he might be able to help.

headline: Our Family’s Experiment in Extreme Schooling: a Postscript
text: How are they doing now?

headline: Google+ Opens Up to All Comers
text: Google on Tuesday opened its invitation-only social network, Google+, to anyone who wants to join at google.com/+.

headline: Photo Replay: Sept. 20
text: The day in sports included the Asian basketball championships in China and the Rugby World Cup in New Zealand.

headline: UBS Adds to Energy Banking Team With New Hires
text: While UBS is grappling with the fallout from a trader’s $2.3 billion loss, its American investment banking arm is continuing to rebuild with additional hires.

headline: Long Before ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell,’ I Suffered and Won
text: FORTY-THREE years ago, I peered out the door of a United States Army helicopter as it flew low over the smoking ruins of a Vietnamese village. Acrid fumes of still-burning thatch — hours earlier the rooftops of orderly houses — assaulted my eyes and nose as I stepped out onto a bed of ashes in a smoldering rice field.

headline: Sampling the Tastes of the Civil War
text: Daniel Mowles preparing roasted rabbits for a tasting of Civil War-era food at the Roger Smith Hotel on Monday.The chef, it turned out, was from southwest Virginia and grew up in a household that, he said, had inherited some of Robert E. Lee’s silverware.

headline: Battle of the Subs: Alvin vs. Jason
text: Jeffrey Marlow, a graduate student at the California Institute of Technology, writes from a workstation off the coast of Oregon, where he is studying life around deep-ocean vents.

headline: Poker Web Site Cheated Users, U.S. Suit Says
text: The millions of people who signed up for a Web site called Full Tilt Poker knew they were there to gamble. But it turns out they were taking on far more risk than they realized, even when they had no chips on the virtual table.

headline: The Ever-Shifting Balance Between Resources and Dreams
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

headline: American Is to Join the Bolshoi Ballet
text: Exactly 50 years after Rudolf Nureyev grabbed the world’s attention as the first major Soviet dancer to defect to the West, another symbolic journey is taking place — this time in reverse.

headline: Dining, Music and More Will Enliven La Rotonde in Paris
text: La Rotonde, the neo-Classical monument overlooking the Bassin de la Villette in the 19th Arrondissement in Paris, is finally seeing new life after sitting empty for years.

headline: Profile in Style | Perry Farrell
text: The notoriously wild frontman for Jane’s Addiction and Porno for Pyros may have settled down, but he’s still a rolling stone, thanks to a demanding tour schedule that includes Lollapalooza, the seminal music festival he founded in Chicago in 1991, and its off shoots in Chile and — starting next year — Brazil. Farrell and his wife, Etty, a dancer who often performs with him, are virtually inseparable. She auditioned for Jane’s Addiction in 1997, and ‘‘I fell in love with her at first sight,’’ he says. ‘‘We’ve been traveling together in one capacity or another ever since.’’ Their happy place? The cliff-top pineapple field in Maui where they tied the knot. Go to our interactive feature >>

headline: Reviewing St. Anselm
text: Reviewing St. Anselm

headline: Reviewing St. Anselm
text: This week’s restaurant review: St. Anselm, out on Metropolitan Avenue in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, across the street from Fette Sau, and next door to Spuyten Duyvil.

headline: Playing With Fire and Winning
text: ST. ANSELM is a restaurant on Metropolitan Avenue in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, right where Havemeyer Street doglegs out of its run of wig shops and bodegas to become residential. It is an offshoot of Joe Carroll’s barbecue restaurant Fette Sau, across the street, and of his bar Spuyten Duyvil, next door.

headline: Chinese Journalist Following ‘Gutter Oil’ Scandal Is Found Dead
text: A Chinese journalist reporting on a scandal surrounding illegal cooking oil was found stabbed to death this week, the journalism advocacy group Reporters Without Borders said on Tuesday.

headline: Iraq Calls for Change of Syrian Regime
text: BAGHDAD — After months of striking a far friendlier tone toward the government of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, the Iraqi government has joined a chorus of other nations calling on him to step down.

headline: G.M. Deal to Hire More at Low End
text: DETROIT — The new labor contract between General Motors and the United Automobile Workers will accelerate the hiring of lower-paid, entry-level workers at the company and bring jobs to the United States that were headed for Mexico.

headline: Character vs. Characterization: Examining How Candidates and Politicians Are Defined
text: Overview | Why do candidates for public office often become best known for just one action, stance or personality trait? How do narrow, popular definitions of politicians affect our electoral process? In this lesson, students examine how the current candidates for president of the United States have become defined in the media and create equally applicable alternate definitions for each candidate.

headline: Another View: Let’s License Corporate Directors
text: Jonathan F. Foster is the founder and managing director of Current Capital.

headline: Where to Look Up Dry-Hopping and Decoction
text: THE other night I put on my best suit and tie and went out to drink some beer. Sounds absurd, I know. Even the most dedicated beer lovers lean more toward T-shirts and comfy clothes, which is really as it should be. Yet the fact that beer can also be presented beautifully and appropriately for a dressed-up crowd signals that American beer culture has progressed far beyond what anybody but the most visionary beer fanatic ever imagined.

headline: Spotted on the Street | Heewon Kim
text: The Girl: Heewon Kim, a fashion stylist and the executive director of the store Qlosette, a women’s clothing boutique.

headline: A Satire of the Avant-Garde, With a Side of Fresh Food
text: “The avant-garde is meaningless” is the kind of thing that a character in a satire of the avant-garde, like “Conni’s Avant Garde Restaurant: The Mothership Landing,” would say. And yet the show — interactive theater featuring witless spectacle, stale comedy and fresh food — is arguably an argument for that point.

headline: Sheen, Then and Now, Gets Big Ratings
text: He may have made himself a pariah at his old studio and network, but Charlie Sheen proved Monday night that he remains a television ratings force -– or force field at least.

headline: Developers Cater to Two-Wheeled Traffic in Portland, Ore.
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — Christian Ettinger, the owner of Hopworks Urban Brewery here, is a longtime bicycle enthusiast. He grew up riding around the Portland suburb of Lake Oswego, and now owns six bicycles — ”two if my wife is asking” — and races in cyclocross events. So when he decided to open a second brewpub this summer, he settled on a location that reflected his passion: North Williams Avenue, one of the most-used commuter cycling corridors in a city already mad for all things two-wheeled.

headline: My Three Favorite Meals Within Walking Distance of the Times Building
text: Virgil’s BBQThe wings are undisputed. Smoked to perfection, served as an appetizer big enough to serve as a meal for two.

headline: Ex-Automotive Executives Select Start-Ups for Green Incubator
text: Greenstart, a San Francisco green technology start-up accelerator created by three entrepreneurs with backgrounds in automotive advertising, pulled the sheets off its first round of investments on Tuesday afternoon.

headline: Qaddafi Calls New Libya Government a Propped-Up ‘Charade’
text: MISURATA, Libya — As world leaders at the United Nations were embracing the rebels who overthrew him, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi broke nearly two weeks of silence on Tuesday, denouncing Libya’s new interim government and predicting its quick demise once NATO warplanes end their attacks on his forces.

text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#525", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

headline: Predicting Sex Life After Prostate Cancer
text: Treatments for prostate cancer take a significant toll on male potency, leaving a surprisingly high percentage of men unable to have a normal sex life, new research shows.

headline: Google+ for Everyone: What You Need to Know
text: Three months ago, Google launched an all-out, brazen competitor to Facebook called Google+ — pronounced “Google plus.” Google’s rival network offered several features that addressed frequent complaints about Facebook.

headline: America: Land of the Slow
text: 4:47 p.m. | Updated to clarify that the rankings in the report were condensed.

headline: Fragmented Dreams and a Send-Up of Celebrity
text: Sequitur, the new-music ensemble directed by the composer Harold Meltzer and the pianist Sara Laimon, opened its 15th season with a characteristically freewheeling collection of works on Monday evening at Merkin Concert Hall. An attentive listener would be hard pressed to deduce the group’s stylistic preferences, but maybe that’s as it should be, given the eclectic nature of the contemporary music world.

headline: Off the Runway: London Fashion Week
text: Scenes from London Fashion Week.

headline: Bank of America Cuts Include 13 Industrials Bankers
text: 5:43 p.m. | Updated Thirteen members of Bank of America Merrill Lynch‘s industrials investment banking group were among the 3,500 job cuts carried out by the firm earlier this month, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook on Tuesday.

headline: Pictures of the Day: California and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from the California, Afghanistan, Turkey and Pakistan

headline: Guilty Verdict Reached in Another Insider Trading Case
text: 8:22 p.m. | Updated  A former salesman at a Silicon Valley research firm was found guilty of conspiracy and wire fraud on Tuesday, the latest person to be convicted in the government’s sweeping investigation into insider trading at hedge funds.

headline: At Hotels, Perks You Can Pet
text: Some hotels seem to have gone to the dogs — literally. Canines are now on staff at hotels across the country, from urban addresses to rural retreats, as perks you can pet.

headline: TimesCast | September 20, 2011
text: A suicide bomber kills Kabul’s lead negotiator with the Taliban; a Georgia inmate loses his bid for clemency; and Roger Cohen on the diminished role of President Ahmadinejad of Iran.

headline: Red Bulls Need Rost to Stand Tall
text: LITTLE FALLS, N.J. — When he is walking alone as he makes his way to the practice field, or runs laps, Frank Rost looks deceptively diminutive. That feeling evaporates once you are standing next to the Red Bulls’ 6-foot-5 goalkeeper.

headline: Doom!
text: That’s the title of a new article by John Judis about how policy around the advanced world is now aggravating the slump — and how things look likely to get even worse looking forward. It’s not very different from what I’ve been saying, but Judis offers more historical depth in the comparison with the 30s.

headline: Former NPR Official Gets New Position
text: 6:20 p.m. | Updated Nine months after resigning as senior vice president for news at National Public Radio, Ellen Weiss has been named executive editor at the Center for Public Integrity, a non-profit investigative news organization in Washington.

headline: Laugh Lines | Revisiting William Steig
text: What a splendid gift it would be if the works tearing up the best-seller lists weren’t that of a Stieg Larsson, but a Steig, William. If, rather than girls with inadvisable tattoos playing with fire, we had “Sylvester and the Magic Pebble,” “Abel’s Island” or even “The Lonely Ones” clawing to the top in a fit of posthumous re-appreciation for a modest artist of tremendous ability. Alas.

headline: Adapting for New Timbres
text: The art of arrangement, in which musical works are retooled for instruments other than those indicated by their composers, is an old and venerable undertaking. Before the advent of recording, most listeners got to know new symphonies and operas through piano versions played at home. And poaching works meant for other players has been a prime source of enrichment for instruments with undernourished repertories, like the guitar and the saxophone.

headline: Noshing Down Mulberry Street
text: IN Little Italy it is time for deep-fried Oreos, for mozzarepas and banana daiquiris in tubular cups like bongs. Above, a tinsel bower of red, green and silver. Underfoot, oily napkins and the scent of Peronis.

headline: Svidler, Russian Grandmaster, Wins World Chess Cup
text: Peter Svidler, a Russian grandmaster, won the 2011 World Chess Cup on Monday by holding his opponent, Alexander Grischuk, a fellow Russian, to a draw. That clinched the match for Svidler by a score of 2.5 to 1.5.

headline: Financial District Protests Continue as 7 More Are Arrested
text: Seven protesters were arrested on Tuesday downtown in Zuccotti Park in the continuing unrest in the financial district, the police said.

headline: Oracle Posts Solid Gains in a Sector in Turmoil
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Strong corporate demand for software helped to lift Oracle’s sales 12 percent in its first quarter despite a choppy economy and sagging demand for its hardware.

headline: ConAgra Misses Profit Estimates
text: ConAgra Foods, the maker of Banquet frozen meals and Orville Redenbacher popcorn, reported a quarterly profit Tuesday that missed analysts’ estimates. And the chief executive, Gary M. Rodkin, said the company was looking at “a number” of acquisition targets after having withdrawn its offer for Ralcorp Holdings.

headline: Pictures of the Day: California and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from the California, Afghanistan, Turkey and Pakistan.

headline: Art at the Food Cart and in the Park
text: In “The Conspiracy of Performance,” the choreographer Trajal Harrell and the actress Perle Palombe have much to say about current movement-based art. Inspired by Jean Baudrillard’s essay “The Conspiracy of Art,” this work rages against mediocrity, unoriginality, banality and nothingness. Within it there are also echoes of Yvonne Rainer’s “No” manifesto from 1965, which fought against spectacle, virtuosity, camp and style.

headline: Wheelies: The Awkward Embraces Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: A ‘Climate Reality’ Presenter Weighs Gore Project
text: Katie Carpenter, a veteran producer of environmental documentaries (I first crossed paths with her while writing on deforestation in the Amazon in the late 1980s), was one of the presenters in the 24 Hours of Reality climate web-athon organized by former Vice President Al Gore. (Here’s his summary presentation.)

headline: Airline Trade Group Revises Its Profit Forecast Higher for 2011
text: PARIS — Worldwide demand for air travel remains well above average despite clear signs of a broad economic slowdown, a group representing most of the world’s airlines said on Tuesday, leading the group to raise its profit forecast substantially for the year.

headline: New U.S. Envoy Urges China to Relax Business Restrictions
text: BEIJING — The new United States ambassador to China, Gary F. Locke, warned China on Tuesday that its undervalued currency, its increasingly restrictive business environment and the rampant theft of intellectual property threatened both the country’s long-term economic prospects and American job growth at a time of continued weakness in the global economy.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Peter Pilotto
text: “What shape is a shoe box?” asked the hairstylist Duffy backstage at Peter Pilotto. “Oblong?” Duffy was trying to explain the rectangular woven patch he created at the top of the head to mimic the cross-hatch pattern on the collection’s clothes. “Clean, sleek and structured,” is how he described the textured “shoe box” secured into a tight, slicked-back ponytail, to contrast the “soft, feminine, fluid” hair left loose beneath it. Nails, like the hair, were intended to be polished, but discreetly so as not to compete with the bright colors of the clothes. This meant Essie’s Jazz on fingers and toes. Makeup, on the other end, was all about shine. M.A.C. Lustre drops were mixed with Strobe Liquid Lotion and applied all over the body by Adrien Pinault and team. Taupe blush and Creme Colour Base in Dusk were used on the face with the latter brushed onto the lips and coated with clear gloss. There was no mascara and brows were simply brushed, perhaps so as not to distract from the handiwork of the “shoe box” shape in the hair.

headline: Cathy Horyn Interviews Alber Elbaz
text: Ms. Horyn asks Alber Elbaz about his fall collection, the line’s promotional video and more. For the whole interview here.

headline: Response to Tropical Storm Irene Cost $55 Million, City Says
text: Tropical Storm Irene did not wreak the kind of havoc that was feared within New York City, but the storm was still expensive.

headline: Clowning Around
text: Barry Lubin, the 59-year old star clown known as Grandma, is saying farewell to the Big Apple Circus.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Mary Katrantzou
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Weaving ‘Climate’ Into ‘Corporate’
text: A new report finds more evidence that climate change is gradually moving to the center of corporate strategy. Virtually every big company in the world now pays at least lip service to sustainability, and many of them are starting to take real action to reduce their environmental footprint. The new report from the Carbon Disclosure Project finds that for the first time, a majority of companies in the United States responding to the group’s survey “now integrate climate change into core business strategy.”

headline: Pentagon Leaders Commend End of ‘Don’t Ask’ Policy
text: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon’s top civilian and military leaders hailed the repeal on Tuesday of the “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy as a historic event, saying that allowing gay men and lesbians to serve openly in the armed forces would preserve American values without diminishing the nation’s combat power.

headline: Neon City
text: Kirsten Hively goes around the city photographing neon. A sampling of her work follows.

headline: White House Deputy Communications Director Steps Down
text: President Obama is losing one of his longest-serving aides, Jennifer Psaki, who has been a witness to the varied crises of his campaign and presidency and the unflappable and genial point-person to reporters covering those events.

headline: Big Man of the Big Top Bids It Adieu
text: WALDEN, N.Y. — Some might think it an inappropriate beginning for a grand farewell tour, but certainly not Grandma, a k a Barry Lubin. Here was Mr. Lubin, the 59-year old star clown who began fooling around at the Big Apple Circus 29 years ago, being lassoed by two magicians at the show’s cavernous practice arena in this woodsy patch of the Hudson Valley.

headline: Top Restaurants Face Scrutiny Over Access to the Disabled
text: Many of Manhattan’s top restaurants will soon receive mailings from a federal prosecutor’s office in New York checking whether they are accessible to disabled patrons.

headline: Nevada’s Dean Heller Gives First Senate Speech
text: Senator Dean Heller, Republican of Nevada, who was promoted in the spring from the House, gave his maiden speech in the Senate on Tuesday. In a roughly 15-minute speech from the chamber floor, he channeled his inner Mark Twain and called for the lawmakers to come together to create jobs and address the government’s long-term fiscal problems.

headline: TimesCast | Inmate Denied Clemency
text: September 20, 2011 - The controversy surrounding the impending execution of Troy Davis highlights the rift in national opinion over the death penalty.

headline: The Caucus Click: Bachmann’s Red Meat
text: Representative Michele Bachmann visited a meat-packing plant in Iowa.

headline: Channel Surfing: ‘Workaholics’
text: Sometimes it’s best not to know too much about certain things. What your kids are looking at online. How hot dogs are made. What all those deductions on your paycheck stub are for. The happy idiots at the center of “Workaholics,” a pleasantly daffy bro-comedy that starts its second season Tuesday at 10:30 p.m. on Comedy Central, begin the episode by scrutinizing their check stubs, apparently for the first time, and come to the realization that they pay taxes. Their resulting assumptions lead to dragon theft, a trip back to high school and, of course, party time.

headline: Hungarian Rhapsody
text: A rich film tradition and low production costs have long brought stars to Budapest, among them Jeremy Irons, 63, pictured here on the shores of the Danube River. Irons made “Nijinski,” his first movie in the capital, in 1980, and returned to make “M. Butterfly,” “Being Julia” and Showtime’s “The Borgias.” When not on set, Irons explores the city’s “wonderful crumbling faded beauty” on his motorcycle. “It’s very hard to find the soul of a city,” he says, but he suggests starting at the Dohany Street Synagogue (011-36-1-413-5500), the Hungarian State Opera (right; opera.hu) and the Western Railway Station (Terez korut at Nyugati ter), designed by the Eiffel Company of Paris. Irons also recommends Cafe Kor (011-36-1-311-0053; cafekor.com), Pomo D’Oro (011-36-1-302-6473; pomodorobudapest.com) and Nobu (noburestaurants.com/budapest), inside the Kempinski Hotel (011-36-1-429-3777; kempinski.com), where he usually stays.

headline: Splashing Through Rain Toward a Silent Afterlife
text: From a sensory perspective, “Crane Story” is consistently gorgeous.

headline: Musings About Death, Joyce-Style
text: James Joyce is your father and Samuel Beckett is one of your boyfriends. How do you make your own path? You try to become an artist, of course, a dancer (be gone, words!), but instead end up institutionalized for almost 50 years. That’s the story of Lucia Joyce, thwarted artist, crazy person and subject of “Lucia’s Chapters of Coming Forth by Day,” a suggestive but unsatisfying Mabou Mines production written and directed by Sharon Fogarty that is having its New York premiere as part of the 1st Irish Theater Festival.

headline: Mets Recall a Time Rivera Blew One
text: On Monday, Mariano Rivera saved his record 602nd game.

headline: To Tourists, Greek Debt Crisis Is a Distant Concept
text: ATHENS — Despite all the gloom surrounding Greece and its battered economy, the sun has been shining on the country’s tourism industry, offering one of the few glimmers of hope for recovery.

headline: Food From North and South
text: The dishes below were served at a tasting at a Manhattan hotel, the Roger Smith, on Lexington Avenue near 47th Street.

headline: ‘I’m Proud to Be a Citizen': 18 Are Sworn In
text: Festus Cohill has earned many titles during his time in the United States: Vietnam War veteran. Cancer survivor. Bartender extraordinaire. Fiancé, twice, though never husband.

headline: Gary Johnson Earns Debate Spot
text: The Republican presidential field may be headed toward a two-man race between Rick Perry and Mitt Romney, but don’t tell that to Gary Johnson, the former governor of New Mexico.

headline: Singing Gladiator Time
text: Let’s have a look at the “absence” entry of a quotable quotes Web site to see what might apply to Simon Cowell. “Absence makes the heart grow fonder”? Too easy, and in this case of dubious accuracy. “God is absence” (Sartre)? Intriguing but irrelevant. “Barbarism is the absence of standards to which appeal can be made” (José Ortega y Gasset)? Has the word “absence” in it and actually nicely describes some of Mr. Cowell’s previous work as a judge on “American Idol,” but it’s not quite what we’re after.

headline: Away From the Limelight and Losing Her Grip
text: For Colleen West, the actress played by Ellen Barkin in “____ Year,” it was — as the unprintable title of this experimental narrative suggests — a long, lousy time, and now it’s gone, Baby, gone. Having announced that she’s retiring from acting, Colleen moves to a cabin in the country and into her memories of a younger man she calls her latest disappointment, Harvey (Luke Grimes), a beauty with a sensitive pout and fogged-over eyes. She also strikes up a friendship of sorts with a neighbor (Melora Walters) and is visited by her brother (a funny Bob Einstein). Every so often, Colleen appears to visit an extraterrestrial therapist. Or something.

headline: At Madison Square Garden, it’s Hey, Getcher Lobster Roll
text: ANDREW CARMELLINI leaned forward with some intensity at his window table in his restaurant the Dutch, reflecting on the culinary architecture of his new Cheddar brat. The Schaller & Weber sausage? It’s braised in Hoegaarden beer from Belgium, he said. The sauerkraut? Call it weinkraut please, since it’s cooked in riesling. The bread? That’s a Martin’s potato bun that must be warm, but not toasted.

headline: Recipes for Rosh Hashana
text: Festive and familiar dishes for celebrating the Jewish New Year.

headline: After His Brother’s Killing, a Chef Turns to Israeli Food
text: Philadelphia

headline: Photos of the Moment | Pringle of Scotland
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#784", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

headline: Not All Bones Go to the Dogs
text: A year ago, Poilâne, the Paris bakery, created a bone-shaped butter cookie called Pas Pour Les Chiens (“not for dogs”). Olivier Kuntzel and Florence Deygas, artists known for the playful cartoon dogs Caperino and Peperone, helped design them. With a mix of pink and Sichuan peppercorns, nutmeg and mace made by Lior Lev Sercarz, who specializes in spice blends for chefs, the cookies bridge savory and sweet, making them good with cheese, cocktails or ice cream. Mr. Sercarz also sells them at his gallery-shop in New York.

headline: Artichoke Basille’s Arrives in the Frozen-Food Aisle
text: About three years ago Francis Garcia took his artichoke pie from his family’s restaurant on Staten Island to the Artichoke Basille’s Pizza Company, which he opened on East 14th Street with his cousin Sal Basille. But even after opening more restaurants, Mr. Garcia nurtured a dream of seeing his pizzas in supermarkets. After months of trial and error, he found a family-owned company that makes frozen pizzas to his liking. The proportion of topping to crust on the frozen artichoke pizza is better balance than what’s sold at the pizzerias. A margherita version is well flavored but can use a few shreds of fresh mozzarella.

headline: Heritage Meat Shop Opens at Essex Street Market
text: Patrick Martins has opened the first shop, in the Essex Street Market, for his Heritage Foods USA, the online retailer. He has set up in space that had been Jeffrey’s Meat Market for more than 70 years, and hired Dionisio Silva (left), a Jeffrey’s butcher. The shop stocks smoked and fresh pork from different heirloom breeds, grass-fed beef, poultry (including the turkeys Heritage is best known for), and cured meats from domestic producers, including Armandino Batali in Seattle. It also has sandwiches, some packaged food, and, at the end of the day, “Staff Meal” cuts of meat for $3.99 a pound.

headline: Roger Cohen on Ahmadinejad
text: The Op-Ed columnist Roger Cohen on the diminished role of President Ahmadinejad of Iran as he arrives in New York for the United Nations General Assembly.

headline: Consumer Bureau Readies Its New Financial Rules
text: Raj Date, the former banker temporarily leading the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, outlined a timeline on Tuesday for the Wall Street watchdog to unveil a string of new regulations.

headline: Amorous Squid Seeks Partner: Any Sex Will Do
text: A five-and-a-half-inch deep-sea squid that lives a solitary life up to half a mile down in the dark waters of the Pacific Ocean is the latest addition to the hundreds of species that are known to engage in same-sex sex.

headline: What Are You Cooking for Rosh Hashana?
text: The Jewish New Year is approaching — will you be turning to your great-aunt’s brisket recipe, or this one from the chef Michael Solomonov, who braises the meat in pomegranate juice? Are you making matzo ball soup? Babka: cinnamon or chocolate?

headline: Bloggingheads: Is Perry Too Extreme?
text: Evan Smith, left, of The Texas Tribune and Joshua Trevino of the Texas Public Policy Foundation debate the 2012 election.

headline: Talks End in Greece With No Deal, but Progress Is Reported
text: Inspectors from top international groups will return to Greece next week to reassess the country’s progress in meeting the requirements for it to receive financial assistance, as talks ended Tuesday without an agreement in place.

headline: Would Al Gore Have Won in 2000 Without the Electoral College?
text: George W. Bush won the Electoral College in 2000 following the recount in Florida. But Al Gore received more popular votes — about 540,000 more than Mr. Bush nationally, or about 0.5 percent of all votes cast across the country.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,761 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: TimesCast | Afghan Peace Chief Killed
text: Burhanuddin Rabbani, the leader of Afghanistan’s High Peace Council, was assassinated Tuesday night by a suicide bomber with explosives tucked in his turban.

headline: $16 Muffins, and Taxpayers Pick Up the Tab
text: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department on Tuesday came under criticism for “extravagant and potentially wasteful” spending on conferences at the end of the Bush administration and early in the Obama administration, including paying $16 per muffin and $8 per eight-ounce cup of coffee at certain events.

headline: G.M. Plans to Develop Electric Cars With China
text: HONG KONG — General Motors said Tuesday that it would develop electric cars in China through a joint venture with a Chinese automaker, and would transfer battery and other electric car technology to the venture.

headline: A Weak Board at Yahoo Stumbles in a Series of Missteps
text: Yahoo’s board is arguably not the worst in America.

headline: Yankees in Position to Do Red Sox a Favor
text: Yankees center fielder Curtis Granderson reported to the ballpark Tuesday afternoon claiming to have no idea what his team’s magic numbers were. (They were four for clinching a playoff spot and five for clinching the American League East title, by the way.)

headline: UBS Senior Staff Should Feel Losses
text: Will UBS’s rogue trader leave the bank’s staff members with “doughnut” bonuses? The investment bank’s employees, already facing thousands of job cuts, fear that the $2.3 billion trading loss will wipe out this year’s payouts. Loading the cost onto the staff could appease shareholders and regulators, but it would risk causing another exodus. Clawing back deferred bonuses from senior staff members might be a better option.

headline: Congress Reacts to ‘Don’t Ask’ Repeal
text: For lawmakers on Capitol Hill, reaction Tuesday to the end of the /a>“don’t ask, don’t tell” policy largely followed the lines of the years-long debate over banning gay men and lesbians from serving openly in the military.

headline: Capital One Denies ING Deal Would Make It ‘Too Big to Fail’
text: 8:08 p.m. | Updated  Capital One on Tuesday delivered a sweeping defense of its proposed $9 billion takeover of ING Direct USA, aiming to allay concerns that the deal would create another “too big to fail” banking giant.

headline: Giants’ First Win Brings Sighs, Not All of Relief
text: Beginning in training camp and continuing through last week’s season-opening loss to the Washington Redskins, injuries severely hobbled the Giants’ defense.

headline: A Banker’s Secret Wealth
text: Emilio Botín is a billionaire Spanish banker renowned for running a tight ship. He asks that his top credit officers at Santander — one of Europe’s largest banks — make a trek to his vacation home each summer to report on loan exposures. And he queries the head of his charitable foundation, euro for euro, on its smallest donations.

headline: Digg Introduces Genre-Specific ‘Newsrooms’
text: Digg, the social news Web site, opened a series of online newsrooms Tuesday that will use social networks to determine the importance of a news story.

headline: A Grievous Wrong
text: Troy Davis is scheduled to be executed on Wednesday for the 1989 killing of a police officer in Savannah, Ga. The Georgia pardon and parole board’s refusal to grant him clemency is appalling in light of developments after his conviction: reports about police misconduct, the recantation of testimony by a string of eyewitnesses and reports from other witnesses that another person had confessed to the crime.

headline: A Year of Living, Working and Grieving on Tour
text: ATLANTA — Volunteering is about helping others. In the best case, it also helps the volunteer.

headline: William F. May, 95, Dies; Helped Found Film Society
text: William F. May, who led the American Can Company during a 15-year period of expansion beginning in 1965 and helped found the Film Society of Lincoln Center, died on Sunday in Greenwich, Conn. He was 95.

headline: Risks Seen for Children of Illegal Immigrants
text: Children whose parents are illegal immigrants or who lack legal status themselves face “uniformly negative” effects on their social development from early childhood until they become adults, according to a study by four researchers published Wednesday in the Harvard Educational Review.

headline: To Address a Reshaped Market, Grey Adds a Unit
text: EXECUTIVES at one of the world’s largest agencies are making a business choice that they hope will turn out to be a healthy choice.

headline: TV Chefs Through the Years
text: A survey of chefs who have taught Americans to cook, from James Beard and Julia Child to the current generation of Food Network stars.

headline: Throwing Out the Recipe for Daytime TV
text: UNDER the hot lights of ABC’s Studio 2 last week, a mound of hamburger meat glistened, as pink and moist as the chef Mario Batali’s forehead. Dozens of assistants, makeup artists and publicists watched in rapt silence as Carla Hall, a “recovering caterer” who has competed twice on Bravo’s “Top Chef,” rehearsed a segment on turkey wraps.

headline: One in Three Texters Would Rather Text Than Talk
text: My 3-year-old told my husband the other day to send me a text message. She intuitively understood that I prefer to see his words on my screen than hear his voice. Texts are discreet. Texts are pithy.

headline: West Hollywood to Ban Sale of Fur Garments
text: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.— This is a small city, a mere 1.9 square miles, with about 36,000 residents. But lawmakers here nonetheless see themselves as national trendsetters.

headline: Time to Boycott Tuna Again?
text: I wish I’d been in La Jolla a couple of weeks ago to see the green inflatable airship flying overhead with a cartoon mermaid on one side. She was curvy and blonde, with a cigarette in her mouth and a bloody fish impaled on her trident. Around her was text that read, “Chicken of the Sea: Carnage in a Tuna Can.”

headline: The Health Payoffs of Time Banks
text: Friday’s Fixes post about time banks resonated with readers.  Time banks are local organizations that allow people to use their skills to help others by exchanging hours instead of money. You earn time dollars by, say, taking a neighbor to the doctor, and spend those time dollars on the same number of hours’ worth of other services, such as computer repair or singing lessons.  Strikingly, very few readers talked about what they could get from time banks; most  responded to the possibility of giving.  “The chance to help others and feel good about myself makes the bargain seem better than I thought possible,” wrote Ajasys from Vancouver, Wash. (41)  — a typical comment.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: A 'Boatload’ of Wines

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: Joe Dressner, Wine Importer, Dies at 60
text: Joe Dressner, an importer whose advocacy of Old World wines made without chemicals or manipulation inspired a sort of natural wine avant-garde, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 60.

headline: Inter’s Gasperini: Dead Man Coaching
text: Inter Milan Coach Gian Piero Gasperini may be out of a job by the time you read this. The final nail in his coffin was almost certainly Inter’s 3-1 loss at newly promoted NovaraTuesday, though there has been so much hammering of nails into that box in the past month that it’s hard to say which one finally did him in.

headline: Nevada: Air Crash Toll Rises to 11
text: The death toll from a plane crash at the National Championship Air Races in Reno rose to 11 on Tuesday, officials said. The police said that the latest victim, who was not identified, died from injuries when a World War II-era P-51 Mustang fighter plane nosedived into the crowd Friday. Medical examiners have identified 10 victims.

headline: Red Meat for N.F.L. Fans: Football Channel Sees All
text: Like many N.F.L. fans, Mike Tanenbaum grew up watching games each Sunday with his father. They gathered around their television and cheered on their team, the Jets, in an act of shared familial devotion — to sport, franchise and the standard network broadcast.

headline: For Zimbabwe Premier, Optimism and Caution
text: The prime minister of Zimbabwe, one of southern Africa’s poorest and most politically anxious countries, expressed hope on Tuesday that elections for a new government could be held next year, bringing an end to an awkward and rancorous power-sharing partnership between him and his rival, the country’s legendarily autocratic president, Robert Mugabe.

headline: Outside Baseball Stadiums, a Solid Lineup
text: Statues depicting bygone baseball players seem to be multiplying, dressing up stadium grounds and serving as meeting places for fans.

headline: Political Shift in California Trips Brown
text: SACRAMENTO — Jerry Brown ran for governor on the argument that his age and experience — the son of a governor, he has spent a lifetime in politics, including two terms as governor himself 30 years ago — was what California needed to rescue it from a spiral of partisanship and financial decline as destructive as anywhere in the nation.

headline: In Cuts to Health Programs, Experts See Difficult Task in Protecting Patients
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama and some members of Congress assert that, in cutting Medicare and Medicaid, they can whack health care providers while protecting beneficiaries. But experts say it is not so simple.

headline: A Tax Others Embrace, U.S. Opposes
text: President Obama’s proposal for a new tax on millionaires echoes a call in many countries struggling with budget deficits and overwhelming debts to make the wealthy pay more.

headline: New York Judge Seeks New System for Juveniles
text: New York State has long dealt with 16- and 17-year-old defendants more severely than almost every other state, trying all of them as adults in criminal courts. Now, New York’s chief judge is calling for a less punitive approach that would focus on finding ways to rehabilitate them.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Obama’s Plan to Raise Taxes on the Rich
text: To the Editor:

headline: Anger and Suspicion as Survivors Await Chinese Crash Report
text: WENZHOU, China — When a high-speed train rammed into the rear of a second train on July 23 on a viaduct outside this eastern coastal city, the impact cost Chen Lihua, a 38-year-old father of two, eight broken ribs, a punctured lung and one shattered kneecap. His brother died of head wounds.

headline: In Baseball’s Bronze Age, Statues Are Becoming Bigger Part of Landscape
text: ATLANTA — Rob Warnock lingered last week in the shadow of a striking bronze sculpture just outside Turner Field. He had been assigned to hand out Braves tickets for his company’s employee-recruitment gathering at that night’s game, and, thinking about where to rendezvous, had said to his boss, “Which gate?”

headline: Google Says It Plays Fair
text: In written testimony to a Senate antitrust panel where he will testify Wednesday afternoon, Eric Schmidt, Google’s chairman, describes the search giant as a company facing fierce competition on many fronts, a relentless innovator in a dynamic industry and a creation of the open Internet so consumers can easily switch to competing services.

headline: Pac-12 Decides to Stay at 12 Teams
text: With two unexpected plot twists emerging Tuesday in the seemingly endless drama of conference realignment, the turbulent world of college athletics has suddenly appeared to stabilize.

headline: In 7-Page Note, Drug Lord Asks a Judge for Leniency
text: “Good day to you, sir,” the letter to the judge began. “I am humbly asking if you could be lenient on me.”

headline: After Disclosures by WikiLeaks, Al Jazeera Replaces Its Top News Director
text: CAIRO — Al Jazeera, the pan-Arab news network financed by Qatar, named a member of the Qatari royal family on Tuesday to replace its top news director after disclosures from the group WikiLeaks indicating that the news director had modified the network’s coverage of the Iraq war in response to pressure from the United States.

headline: Anger as Chinese Await Crash Report
text: A government panel is expected to release a report on the high-speed train crash but survivors say they have already reached their own conclusions.

headline: Nickel Sales Just the Tonic for a Soda Fountain’s Revival
text: AVA, Mo. — A child takes a stool at a soda fountain, drops a nickel on the counter and orders a chocolate ice cream cone. This nostalgic tableau — backed by ’50s tunes piping out of a jukebox — is fodder for the brush strokes of Norman Rockwell paintings and when-I-was-your-age stories spun by grandparents.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Despite Wiretaps and Economic Woe, Berlusconi Endures
text: ROME — In the latest round of wiretaps to emerge in the Italian news media, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi is heard ordering up young women for his parties — allegedly flying some in on state planes — and complaining in 2008 that official meetings with President Nicolas Sarkozy of France, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and Pope Benedict XVI were getting in the way of his social life.

headline: How to Weaken the Power of Foreign Oil
text: OUR country has just gone through a sober national retrospective on the 9/11 attacks. Apart from the heartfelt honoring of those lost — on that day and since — what seemed most striking is our seeming passivity and indifference toward the well from which our enemies draw their political strength and financial power: the strategic importance of oil, which provides the wherewithal for a generational war against us, as we mutter diplomatic niceties.

headline: Recounting the Dead
text: Even as Civil War history has gone through several cycles of revision, one thing has remained fixed: the number of dead. Since about 1900, historians and the general public have assumed that 618,222 men died on both sides. That number is probably a significant undercount, however. New estimates, based on Census data, indicate that the death toll was approximately 750,000, and may have been as high as 850,000.

headline: Red Sox Exude That Old-Time Sinking Feeling
text: BOSTON — On a gray and gloomy September afternoon, on the 20th day of what may be memorialized as the Great Red Sox Collapse of 2011, came a rude intrusion from 2004.
