text: Los Angeles

headline: Tenants Fret Over Big Debt at a Top Address
text: In 1994, a little-known real estate investor, Gary Barnett, bought the Belnord, a 1909 landmarked 12-story apartment building on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, bringing an end to one of the city’s longest and most acrimonious tenant-landlord battles. He paid around $15 million and agreed to settle a slew of pending lawsuits.

headline: Snared Into Prostitution at 13, and Now Given a Chance for a Clean Legal Slate
text: The summer she was 13, before she went into eighth grade, the child who would come to be known on police blotters under a half-dozen names began to stand on sidewalks in the Bronx and wait for men in cars to give her money for sex. Call her Leni Johnson.

headline: Turkey’s Leadership
text: The Arab Spring tour taken this month by Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey demonstrated the good and the bad of his increasingly confident leadership.

headline: Promoting City’s Efforts on Health, to the World
text: Early in his political career, Michael R. Bloomberg confessed that a few positions interested him besides mayor of New York, including president of the World Bank and secretary general of the United Nations.

headline: Ways to Prevent Cheating
text: The Board of Regents took an important step this month when it directed the New York State Education Department to develop a plan for eliminating glaring weaknesses in the state testing system. As a first move, the Regents voted to require that state tests for third through eighth grades be given on the same day all over the state. And, from now on, teachers and administrators will have to certify that they have received and will follow the same administrative protocols.

headline: Father’s Role in Bank Venture Poses Test for Cuomo
text: ALBANY — At age 79, former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo wants to become a banker.

headline: Marines Hit the Ground Running in Seeking Recruits at Gay Center
text: TULSA, Okla. — Master Sgt. Anthony Henry, a top Marine recruiting trainer for the southwestern United States, pulled up to Tulsa’s biggest gay community center on Tuesday morning and left his Chevy where he could make a fast getaway. “I have an exit strategy,” he said. “I know where my choke points are, I’ve strategically parked my car right on the curbside, I have an out.”

headline: Wednesday: Trouble Spots?
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — It’s hard to believe that this puzzle by Peter A. Collins is only a Wednesday. It’s not that it’s difficult; there is just so much to appreciate here that it feels more like a Thursday or later week grid.

headline: PepsiCo to Foster Chickpeas in Ethiopia
text: PepsiCo plans to announce a new venture on Wednesday aimed at increasing its access to chickpeas, which play an increasing role in its food products, and expanding production of the crop in Ethiopia.

headline: Pursuing Identities, Police Disclose Details About L.I. Victims
text: YAPHANK, N.Y. — There were 10 bodies in all, thought to be the work of one or more serial killers, inexorably connected by the proximity of where they were found.

headline: 8 Children Abducted by Mother, Police Say
text: Eight children were abducted from foster care in Queens on Monday during a visit with their mother, the police said on Tuesday.

headline: Unusual Question to Jurors: How Do You Like the Mayor?
text: One after another, they stitched together a collage of thoughts about Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, responding as to whether they had formed opinions about him.

headline: Woman Shot Her Husband in Hatred, Prosecutor Says
text: Prosecutors sought on Tuesday to portray Barbara Sheehan, the Queens woman accused of killing her husband, as having been a deeply unhappy wife who resented her sexless marriage and now was grossly exaggerating what she has called decades of physical abuse.

headline: Lawyer for Man in Bomb Plot Sees No Conflict in Work for Undercover Detective
text: One of the lawyers representing a Queens man accused of plotting to blow up a synagogue also briefly represented the undercover detective who helped bring the case against the man.

headline: Kansas City, Mo., School District Loses Its Accreditation
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — The struggling Kansas City, Missouri School District was stripped of its accreditation on Tuesday, raising the possibility of student departures and a state takeover. The action follows weeks of tumult that included another round of turnover of top leadership.

headline: Outside Baseball Stadiums, a Solid Lineup

headline: Fill In the Blanks, Continued
text: My debut Op-Ed column on Monday, which attempted a dispassionate appraisal of what I called the Great Disappointment, prompted an outpouring of comments and e-mails and Tweets. There’s no way I can reply to all of them, but my plan with this and future columns is to sum up some of the main points from my many in-boxes, and respond as best I can.

headline: Solyndra Executives to Invoke Fifth Amendment Rights
text: WASHINGTON — The top two executives of a solar-energy company that filed for bankruptcy after getting $528 million in loan guarantees from the Obama administration said Tuesday that they will invoke their constitutional rights against compelled self-incrimination when they appear at a Congressional hearing.

headline: That Old Heritage Moon
text: From Earth, the Moon looks as though it is constantly changing. But, on the lunar surface where the only breeze is the solar wind, there is an eerie permanence. Witness the photographs of three of the Apollo landing sites taken recently by NASA’s Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter. They show the undisturbed trails left by American astronauts on foot and in their moon buggy four decades ago.

headline: The Re-election Tango
text: Whether Bill Clinton is being mischievous or helpful is never entirely clear. But the former president often manages to show the current president just how the game should be played.

headline: Are We Going to Roll Up Our Sleeves or Limp On?
text: It becomes clearer every week that our country faces a big choice: We can either have a hard decade or a bad century.

text: Q.

headline: Battle for Libya | September 20, 2011
text: Libyan interim government forces stormed a house in Tripoli and friends and family buried the commander of a group of former rebel fighters in Misurata.

headline: House G.O.P. Tightens Its Bond With Netanyahu
text: WASHINGTON — When the Obama administration wanted to be certain that Congress would not block $50 million in new aid to the Palestinian Authority last month, it turned to a singularly influential lobbyist: Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu.

headline: Japan: Typhoon Approaches
text: Authorities in Nagoya, Japan’s fourth-largest city, advised more than one million people to leave on Tuesday as a powerful typhoon approached the densely populated region of central Japan. The city asked the military to assist in evacuating residents from low ground before the storm, Typhoon Roke, which was expected to reach the area on Wednesday. Heavy rains and flash flooding have been reported in mountainous areas.

headline: Instagram Upgrades, Adds Filters and Increases Image Size
text: Fans of Instagram, the popular free iPhone photo-sharing app, has given users at least four new reasons to snap and share: It has added four new filters in an update.

headline: Italy: 7 Go on Trial Over Quake
text: Seven Italian seismologists and scientists went on trial on manslaughter charges on Tuesday, accused of not adequately warning residents of a central Italian region before an earthquake that killed 309 people in April 2009. Prosecutors say that the seven defendants, members of a national panel that assesses major risks, played down the risk of a major earthquake’s occurring even though there had been significant seismic activity near L’Aquila, the capital of the Abruzzo region, in the months before the quake. The case has drawn the attention of the international scientific community, which argues that it is impossible to predict an earthquake. Prosecutors, in actuality, charge that the panel did not fulfill its mandate and instead conveyed “incomplete, imprecise and contradictory information.”

headline: Russia: Ruling on Oil Company
text: Both sides in the convoluted legal battle over Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky’s now-defunct Yukos Oil were claiming victory on Tuesday after the European Court of Human Rights ruled that Russia had violated the rights of company representatives to a fair trial, but failed to find evidence that Russian authorities had intentionally misused legal proceedings to bankrupt and dismantle the company. Yukos representatives had accused the Russian government of applying tax laws selectively in an effort to assume control of the company after Mr. Khodorkovsky was arrested in 2003.

headline: A Change in Statehouse Politics

headline: A.L. Race Rages, but Yankees Stay Above It
text: The Yankees have higher priorities on their agenda than helping their old friends, the Boston Red Sox, hang on to their wild-card spot. The Yankees have yet to clinch their own playoff berth, let alone the American League East title, so for now, beating any opponent will do.

headline: Rested Mets Can’t Cool Off Cardinals
text: ST. LOUIS — The Mets have found themselves in the thick of the playoff hunt after all.

headline: G.O.P. Urges No Further Fed Stimulus
text: Even though the financial markets have been counting on the Federal Reserve to take action, Republican Congressional leadership sent a letter to the Federal Reserve chairman on Tuesday evening urging it not to engage in further stimulus.

headline: Rethinking the Exercise ‘Talk Test’
text: Many of us rely on the so-called talk test to gauge a workout’s intensity. It is such a simple measure, consisting of only one question: Can you speak aloud while working out? If so, conventional wisdom says, you are exercising at the right intensity to improve both your health and fitness.

text: cloying •\ˈklȯi-iN, ˈklȯiN\• adjective

headline: Tom Wilson, Cartoonist Behind ‘Ziggy,’ Dies at 80
text: Who is this comic-strip character named Ziggy? He can’t be placed in time, location or economic status, and seems to be — but may not be — an adult male. It is known that he was created in 1969 by the cartoonist Tom Wilson, who died on Friday, and who suggested that Ziggy can be whatever you want him to be.

headline: Mohammed Ghani Hikmat, Iraqi Sculptor, Dies at 82
text: Mohammed Ghani Hikmat, the Iraqi sculptor who created many of Baghdad’s most famous landmarks and who led the effort to recover works of art looted from the National Museum of Iraq after the fall of Saddam Hussein, died on Sept. 12 in Amman, Jordan, where he had gone for medical treatment. He was 82.

headline: Christopher Coke’s Letter to Sentencing Judge
text: A letter from Christopher Coke, the convicted Jamaican drug dealer, to Judge Robert P. Patterson Jr., asking for lenience in sentencing.

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Wednesday
text: Congress General Secretary Rahul Gandhi will travel to Sikkim on Wednesday to meet victims of Sunday’s devastating earthquake and their families.(CNN-IBN) The official death toll in Sunday’s powerful temblor has shot up to 68 in India, including 53 in the Himalayan state, while more than 3,000 people have been rescued by defense forces. Many parts of northern Sikkim are still inaccessible, and hundreds of people are still searching for relatives. (Hindustan Times)

headline: Universities Seeking Out Students of Means
text: Money is talking a bit louder in college admissions these days, according to a survey to be released Wednesday by Inside Higher Ed, an online publication for higher education professionals.

headline: If Citi Field Changes,  ‘It Won’t Be Subtle’
text: General Manager Sandy Alderson on Tuesday night offered the strongest indication yet that the Mets would make significant alterations to the dimensions of the field at their home stadium during the off-season.

headline: In Turkey, Game Day Becomes Ladies’ Night
text: The Turkish soccer federation’s new answer to fan violence — barring men from the games of teams punished for it — got its first test on Tuesday at a game between Fenerbahce and Manisaspor in Istanbul.

headline: Sept. 21, 1938 | Giant Hurricane Lashes Long Island and New England
text: On Sept. 21, 1938, a giant hurricane roared up the Eastern Seaboard, causing extensive damage and loss of life on Long Island and much of New England, not relenting until it had crossed into Canada.

headline: News Quiz | Sept. 21, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Common Moments That Still Exist
text: Farzana Wahidy graduated from the photojournalism program at Loyalist College in Ontario, Canada. Ms. Wahidy, 27, was born in Kandahar, Afghanistan, and raised in Kabul, where she is a freelance photographer. Her conversation with Kim Nowacki, part of the Turning Point series, has been edited and condensed.

headline: How Much Do You Gossip?
text: How much time do you spend every day gossiping, or listening to gossip — whether in person or online? Do think think gossiping is dangerous? Do you think you could refrain from gossip for an entire day? (A 2008 Times article reported on a school in which students were asked to stop for just an hour at a time.) What are some the consequences of gossip that you’ve observed in your own life?

headline: Tip of the Week: Safari’s New Reading List
text: The latest version of Apple’s Safari browser for Windows and Mac OS X includes a Reading List feature that lets you quickly save Web pages for later perusal. To save a Web page on screen, go to Safari’s Bookmarks menu and choose the “Add to Reading List” option. You can also press Control-Shift-D in Windows or Command-Shift-D on a Mac to save the current page to the Reading List. And you can Shift-click on a link within a Web page to save that article to the Reading List without opening it.

headline: American Hikers Leave Iran After Prison Release
text: Two American hikers imprisoned on espionage charges in Iran were released Wednesday after days of conflicting signals, ending diplomatic skirmishing that complicated the United States’ already fraught relationship with Tehran for more than two years.

headline: Line2 HD Adds Phone Features To The iPad
text: Line2 HD may not be the first app to turn your iPad into a phone, but it is an easy-to-use addition that puts phone calls, texts, voicemail and e-mail on a single screen—and offers a stack of other features as well.

headline: A New York Artist Takes the Long View of Customizer Culture
text: “Decepción,” the title of Luis Gispert’s show at the uptown Mary Boone Gallery, at 745 Fifth Avenue, translates from the Spanish not to its English cognate, but more literally to disillusionment or disappointment. The word applies to the effect of the huge photographs in the show, which depict fantasy landscapes seen through the windshields of luxury vehicles.

headline: 8 Months After First Protests, Yemen Enters Dangerous New Phase
text: SANA, Yemen — Eight months after the first protesters began calling for revolution in Yemen, the beleaguered country has entered a new round of violence, in which street demonstrators appear to have become little more than sacrificial pawns in a long-term rivalry among members of Yemen’s political elite.

headline: The Logic of Cutting Payroll Taxes
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: At Berlin Show, One Photographer’s View of the Post-Sept. 11 World
text: As 9/11 memorials go up around the globe, one of Berlin’s pre-eminent spaces for photography is focusing on the era of global unrest that resulted from that fateful day. Through Dec. 10, C/O Berlin (Oranienburger Strasse 35/36; 49-30-28-44-41-661; www.co-berlin.info) will host “At War,” featuring pieces by Anja Niedringhaus, a German Associated Press photographer — and the only woman on a team of 11 A.P. photographers that won a Pulitzer in 2005.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Erdem
text: Erdem’s girl is no longer estranged from her paramour, as she was for fall. Instead, this spring, she’s channeling the film “In the Mood for Love” and hair and makeup are following suit. For the show, Andrew Gallimore created what he described as a cinematic “blurry lip” using M.A.C.‘s new Scarlet Ibis lip color set with powder and then patted with Pigment in Red. Hot n’ Saucy Tendertones served as allover blush to complement “roughed-up, more boyish brows.” For hair, Marc Tringer created a clean, bouncy ponytail using Charles Worthington Front Row Heat Defence Spray before blow-drying and separating the hair into three or four sections and curling with a small-barrel iron to create a slight bend at the ends. It was romance all the way.

headline: New Designer Alert | Jennifer Chun
text: The starting point for Jennifer Chun‘s spring collection was a grainy, paparazzi-style photo of the Yves Saint Laurent muses Betty Catroux and Loulou de la Falaise casually flanking Laurent on a London sidewalk. “It shows how real women wore his designs on the street,” says Chun, who worked at Michael Kors, Derek Lam and Brian Reyes before starting her namesake line of practical and “utilitarian” clothes. Making her New York Fashion Week debut at the recent Gen Art show, a group runway that spotlights emerging designers, Chun presented spring looks that elegantly mix fashion’s masculine and feminine. “I definitely wouldn’t say they’re androgynous. They aren’t literal interpretations of men’s pieces,” she explains. “You don’t want it to become too costumey. I’m more interested in functionality.” In Chun’s gender blender, a khaki boyfriend blazer is paired with a cropped top; a long, creamy silk dress bears a baseball raglan. Everything appears to be designed for women who don’t spend all day planning outfits. “This is for a city girl,” she says. “I never leave the house without a blazer, without a trench coat — so those will be my signatures.”

headline: Generic Drug Savings Promoted by Industry Group
text: Generic drugs saved consumers and the government $931 billion over the last decade, an industry group said on Wednesday in a report promoting policy changes to increase savings further.

headline: Unfinished Business
text: On paper, business is about marketing, management and finance. In reality, it is also about relationships: the good, the bad and the ugly.

headline: The Other India: The Weavers of Varanasi
text: Since the beginning of this year, Sonia Faleiro has been traveling across India’s small towns and villages, meeting farmers, weavers, teachers, tamasha troupes, small-time politicians, Panchayat members, pickle-makers, housewives, and circus artists to gather reporting for her next book. In this regular feature for India Ink she will send postcards from her travels, providing a glimpse of the people and places whose stories are seldom told.

headline: Pessimism Fills Kabul During Mourning for Slain Peace Council Chief
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Hamid Karzai landed at Kabul International Airport as dusk fell here Wednesday and faced a country even more fearful and divided than the one he had left just three days ago.

headline: On Our Radar: Typhoon Buffets Tokyo
text: A powerful typhoon lashes Tokyo, halting trains and stranding tens of thousands of commuters. It seems headed toward the nation’s tsunami-ravaged northeastern coast, raising fears of another inundation at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant. [Associated Press]

headline: U.S. Ready to Face Wounded Australia
text: WELLINGTON, New Zealand — Playing one of rugby’s superpowers was never going to be easy for the United States Eagles, and their task Friday might have become a lot tougher when Australia lost to Ireland last weekend in the Rugby World Cup.

headline: And Now a Word From the Director
text: IN 1938, a month after the Nazi assault on German Jews known as Kristallnacht made headlines across the world, Walt Disney gave Hitler’s pet filmmaker, Leni Riefenstahl, a tour of his studio. He showed her some Mickey Mouse sketches, and she offered to show him “Olympia,” her cinematic slog through the 1936 Berlin Olympics. He turned her down because he was worried it would get out that he was playing host to a woman most of Hollywood shunned. In his biography “Leni” Steven Bach writes that when she returned to Germany, she praised Disney for receiving her, saying, it “was gratifying to learn how thoroughly proper Americans distance themselves from the smear campaigns of the Jews.”

headline: Billy Beane of ‘Moneyball’ Has Given Up on His Own Hollywood Ending
text: Billy Beane has a wonderful story. At 18 he was a strapping young baseball prospect, raised in San Diego by a Naval-officer dad and drafted fresh out of high school in the first round by the New York Mets. He was a sure star — until he suddenly wasn’t, his playing career faltering for reasons few could understand, least of all him. Then, at 27, a journeyman outfielder with a lifetime average of .219 who’d bounced from the Mets to the Twins to the Tigers to the A’s, he walked out of the dugout and into the team’s front office, looking for a job. He became a scout, and eight years later, he was promoted to general manager of a losing team. Under his watch, the A’s, a small-market underdog with a minuscule payroll, made the playoffs five times in the next eight seasons.

headline: The Surreal Ruins of Qaddafi’s Never-Never Land
text: On the evening of Aug. 23, during the final hours of the battle for Tripoli, a 26-year-old lawyer named Mustafa Abdullah Atiri was lying, exhausted, against the back wall of a filthy tin-roofed warehouse crammed with 150 prisoners. He had been beaten and tortured every day since Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s soldiers arrested him four days earlier. It was just after the muezzin’s first call to evening prayer — about 10 minutes before 8 — when a pair of guards walked to the door, raised their AK-47 rifles and began spraying the men with bullets. Another guard threw a grenade into the densely packed crowd. Bodies fell on top of Atiri with the first fusillade, protecting him from the blast. Then the guards opened fire again. Blood began seeping down from the bodies above, soaking his jeans. As the officers walked back across the yard to reload, a guard named Abdel Razaq, who had shown the men some small mercies over the previous days, went to the door and shouted at the survivors: “Run! Run!”

text: They called it the “Greenspan put,” and it reassured a generation of traders. If economic storms were gathering, the top central banks — most important the Federal Reserve, then led by Alan Greenspan — could and would step in to prevent disaster.

headline: Samurai Shopper | Nailed It
text: The Samurai Shopper is happy to close the book on summer, especially the part where everyone wears open-toed shoes or flip-flops and I have to look at tawdry toenails done up in honky-tonk hues. Why am I looking at toenails? Not for dark, pervy reasons: usually to avoid eye contact with the unhinged element that has, of late, turned mass transport and many sidewalks into halfway houses.

headline: New Developments in the Political Business Cycle
text: There’s a well-established line of work in economics on the political business cycle, starting with a paper by my original mentor Bill Nordhaus (pdf). The basic idea was that since voters tend to have short memories, it pays for a government to reflate the economy centering on the proposition that government have an incentive to reflate the economy in the period leading up to an election, even if this imposes costs that will have to be paid later. Concern about this issue is one reason for central bank independence.

headline: As World Leaders Meet, Global Unemployment Is Topic No. 1

headline: Does Moving to the Cloud Pay Off?
text: I’ve just written a small-business guide to the pros and cons of moving to the cloud — that is, to enlisting information-technology services that you access via a Web site instead of installing software that runs on your computers. One of the crucial issues for small-business owners, as always, is cost, and though I look at cost trade-offs in the guide, I’d like to say just a bit more here specifically on the question of how expensive it is to transition to the cloud.

headline: A More Perfect Union: Tom Six Discusses ‘The Human Centipede II’
text: It is entirely possible — maybe even likely — that you know the plot of Tom Six’s horror movie “The Human Centipede (First Sequence)” without having seen a single frame of it. After receiving a modest theatrical release in the United States last year, the film has become a cult sensation as a video-on-demand offering and been referred to on mainstream shows like “South Park” and “The Colbert Report” because of its simple, memorable and thoroughly unnerving premise: a mad doctor who surgically combines three human captives into a single organism by stitching them together, mouth to anus.

headline: JBird, a New Speakeasy in Midtown
text: THE saturation point for speakeasies was breached several years ago, but they continue to sprout up behind taco stands, coffee shops and beauty salons. The latest is JBird, a hidden cocktail bar that opened in August just north of Times Square. While it lacks novelty, it doubles down on absurd inconvenience: guests must navigate a velvet rope shared with a nightclub, a dark hallway, an elevator, another corridor and a bleak staircase humming with ice machines.

headline: Try a Private Jet, at Public Prices
text: FLYING in a private jet may not be as far out of reach as you think. Though it’s still not cheap, prices are rivaling first- and business-class tickets — and even, occasionally, coach — thanks in part to new Web sites, social media and a greater willingness by charter companies and private jet brokers to negotiate in an era of high fuel prices.

headline: London Design Festival | Site Specific
text: For the third year in a row, the London Design Festival has made its headquarters at the Victoria & Albert Museum, with designers creating installations that are contemporary responses to aspects of the museum’s building or collections. Ben Evans, the director of the L.D.F., and Suzanne Trocme, its curator, work closely with the museum’s curators on the project. “It takes 51 weeks of planning for the 10 days of the festival,” Trocme says, only half in jest.

headline: What’s Happening in This Video?
text: Our colleague J. David Goodman is seeking help from readers in deciphering the above video above. The video shows a dramatic moment of gunfire in the suburbs of the Syrian capital, Damascus. Mr. Goodman asks: Is there an exchange of fire from off camera? Or Are the security forces on screen the only ones shooting?

headline: Dressing for Excess | Daphne Guinness at F.I.T.
text: It’s tempting to dismiss the “Daphne Guinness” exhibition at the Museum at F.I.T., which features the extraordinary wardrobe of one of the fashion world’s most visible eccentrics, as an attempt to cash in on the public’s appetite for narcissistic excess. But the truth is that the pint-size brewery heiress’s passion for design is not only inimitably extreme, it’s completely sincere. Her funds might run as deep as her walk-in closets, but unlike countless other couture clotheshorses, Guinness doesn’t fetishize fashion as a status symbol. Instead, over the years, she has developed a sartorial persona that’s one part Victorian damsel, one part sci-fi geisha and 100 percent off-the-wall.

headline: Moody’s Cuts Ratings on Three Big Banks
France Breaks With Obama on Palestinian Statehood Issue
text: UNITED NATIONS -- President Nicolas Sarkozy of France broke sharply on Wednesday with the effort by the Obama administration and some Europeans to quash the effort by the Palestinians for recognition here, instead calling for enhancing their status in the General Assembly to that of an observer state.

headline: Giants React to Talk of Faking Injuries
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — When the Giants’ Deon Grant and Jacquian Williams simultaneously fell to the ground clutching their legs in the first quarter of Monday night’s victory over St. Louis, Rams quarterback Sam Bradford was visibly perturbed. He screamed toward the Giants defense as he walked off the field during the injury timeout.

headline: A Different View of Munch at Paris Exhibition
text: PARIS – The Norwegian artist Edvard Munch has long been associated with emotional instability, melancholia, bursts of paranoia, recurring illnesses and alcoholism. The exhibition “Edvard Munch: The Modern Eye” that opened at the Pompidou Center here on Wednesday certainly reflects the torment he suffered throughout his life.

headline: Clyfford Still Paintings to Go to Auction
text: In August officials of the City and County of Denver announced that they had chosen Sotheby’s to sell four canvases by the Abstract Expressionist painter Clyfford Still to raise money for the endowment of the new Clyfford Still Museum, which is to open there on Nov. 18. The agreement called for Sotheby’s to try to sell the four as a group to a museum by Monday; if it were unable to do so, the works — which together are estimated to be worth more than $50 million — would then go to auction separately. Christie’s, the rival auction house that had competed for the sale, was so miffed by Denver’s selection of Sotheby’s that it hired lawyers and lobbyists in an unsuccessful effort to stop the arrangement.

headline: White Lies and Worse
text: My friend Roberta has been looking after her mother for years. She’s been concealing the truth from her for years, too. Roberta’s mother is pretty healthy at age 92, exuberantly odd but lucid — “wildly wrong about many things, but she’s not demented,” her daughter told me. But she’s prone to periods of severe anxiety, which then produce stomach pain and indigestion.

headline: The Caucus | Israel and the 2012 Race
text: Sept. 21, 2011 — A look at complicated politics concerning Israel playing out in the campaign. Also, Mitt Romney’s attempt to beef up his credentials as a “regular guy.”

headline: Caucus Video: Israel and the 2012 Race; Mitt Romney’s ‘Regular Guy’ Credentials
text: Mark Landler looks at the complicated politics around Israel playing out in the campaign. Also, Mitt Romney’s attempt to beef up his credentials as a “regular guy.”

headline: Well-Grounded Ambitions in London
text: London

headline: Martino Gamper’s Home Away From Home
text: To New Yorkers, the word “condo” can bring up cringe-worthy thoughts of the characterless, paper-thin new builds going up in every unclaimed inch of Manhattan. But “Condominium,” a new exhibition by the designer Martino Gamper at the Franco Noero gallery in Turin, Italy, is anything but characterless.

headline: Stone Links
text: A gathering of philosophy-related links from the past week.

headline: Lobbyists Line Up to Sway Special Committee
text: WASHINGTON — With television cameras rolling last week, aerospace executives warned of dire consequences if Congress cuts hundreds of billions of dollars in Pentagon spending, and they promised a full-throttled campaign to stop it.

headline: Gucci’s New Deco: Hard Going
text: Tom Ford left such an indelible mark at Gucci that when he showed fringed leather skirts and sexy peasants top in London this week, a few guests were surprised, and naturally thought of his Gucci years. My take on the London show was that while it was not as loaded with personality and ageless styles as his first Tom Ford women’s line a year ago, the show suggested that he might have felt the need to beef up the day clothes and evening separates. Some of those styles might need a better reinterpretation, looking ahead, but why completely reinvent the Ford look?

headline: Photo Replay: Sept. 21
text: United States golfers retained the Junior Solheim Cup with a dramatic victory in Ireland, and the Rugby World Cup continued in New Zealand.

headline: Conviction of Syrian Arms Dealer Is Upheld
text: A federal appeals court in Manhattan on Wednesday unanimously upheld the convictions of a Syrian arms dealer and two associates who had been charged in an international sting operation run by the government that defense lawyers had criticized as having unfairly ensnared people.

headline: The Caucus | 'Regular Guy' Romney
text: Sept. 21, 2011 - Ashley Parker on Mitt Romney's attempts to beef up his credentials as a "regular guy."

headline: The Daily Shoe | Gucci
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Back for More: The Disturbing Mushroom of Lincoln Place

headline: Pictures of the Day: Palestine and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Palestine, India and Mexico City.

headline: Fed Will Shift Debt Holdings to Lift Growth
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve announced an unconventional plan on Wednesday to reduce borrowing costs for businesses and consumers, trying once more to spur economic growth despite urgings from Republicans that it refrain from any expansion of its stimulus program.

headline: NATO Extends Libya Bombing Campaign
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — With armed loyalists of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the fallen Libyan leader, still ensconced in his hometown and a few other redoubts as the seven-month-old Libyan conflict winds down, NATO announced a three-month extension of its bombing campaign on Wednesday.

headline: Workshop Production May Help ‘Yank!’ March on Broadway
text: “Yank!,” a musical that gained a following during its 2010 Off Broadway run, in part because of its provocative love story between World War II servicemen, has lead actors in place for a four-week developmental workshop this fall that might be a prelude to a Broadway production.

headline: Daphne Guinness Finds a New Talent, Hogan McLaughlin
text: The style icon arrived at a show of her wardrobe at F.I.T. in a coat by a young talent whose work bears a striking affinity to the otherworldly designs of Gareth Pugh and Alexander McQueen.

headline: Allowing Teenage Boys to Love Their Friends
text: IT is occasionally true that the spark that ignites one’s grand, all-consuming work is struck early in life — even by happenstance.

headline: Updates on Greenland’s Ice
text: New research on the dynamics of Greenland’s ice sheets complicates efforts to forecast sea level rise in this century, as the Green Blog reports. Expanding fields of crevasses appear to be limiting the flow of water to the base of the ice through tube-like moulins. That flow has been thought to ease the seaward movement of the ice over bedrock. But the crevasses also warm the ice as liquid water descends deep inside the frozen mass, with that process also potentially speeding its flow. This diagram shows the two types of plumbing:

headline: New Dresser, Made to Order
text: DAPHNE GUINNESS sauntered into the exhibition of fashions from her wardrobe at the Fashion Institute of Technology last week wearing a gunmetal cutaway coat that lent her an astral glow. Its designer? Why, Hogan, she casually dropped.

headline: The End of R.E.M., and They Feel Fine
text: R.E.M., the underground band from Athens, Ga., that helped invent the alternative-rock sound of the 1980s, said on Wednesday that its members were splitting up after 31 years of making music together.

headline: Response to ‘Poor Parents’
text: 11:44 a.m. | Updated On Motherlode on Tuesday, the Harvard psychologist Richard Weissbourd took issue with, among other things, an article my colleague Motoko Rich wrote for the Week in Review last spring. Many of you disagreed with Dr. Weissbourd’s interpretation of Ms. Rich’s piece. So did Ms. Rich, who sent along this clarification and response:

headline: Vick Joins Eagles at Practice but Status Is Unclear
text: PHILADELPHIA — Eagles quarterback Michael Vick, who is recovering from a concussion, participated in the team’s walk-through practice Wednesday morning, but his availability for Sunday’s game against the Giants remained unknown.

headline: Watch This | The ‘Only Watch’ Auction in Monaco
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#523", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);On Sept. 22, The Only Watch charity auction benefiting Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy will be held in the principality of Monaco at 4 p.m. — Greenwich Mean Time +1, to be exact. Now in its fourth edition, this prestigious auction will feature one-of-a-kind timepieces from 40 of the world’s greatest watchmakers. With the Monaco Yacht Show also on site, expect this already dense part of the Cote D’Azur to be gridlocked with luxury travelers and watch connoisseurs, auction paddles in hand, though bidding online and by phone is also an option for those staying stateside. Here are a few of the show’s expected highlights. Window shoppers are welcome.

headline: Emilio Romano Named President of Telemundo
text: 11:15 a.m. | Updated Emilio Romano, the former chief executive for Grupo Mexicana de Aviación, the Mexican airline carrier, has been named president of Telemundo, the Spanish language network division of NBCUniversal.

headline: Lady Antebellum Grabs Top Spot With New Album
text: Lady Antebellum, the country-pop trio that swept the Grammy Awards this year, opened at No. 1 on the Billboard chart this week with its new album, “Own the Night” (Capitol Nashville). It sold 347,000 copies in the United States in its first week out, according to Nielsen SoundScan.

headline: Pressuring the Fed Can Backfire
text: In a statement this afternoon, the Federal Reserve announced that it was engaging in more stimulus, by extending the average maturity of the securities on its balance sheet. This was basically what markets had expected, even though the Republican Congressional leadership wrote a widely reported letter to Ben S. Bernanke, the Fed chairman, urging him not to engage in any more easing.

headline: S.E.C. Stumbles Over Its Lawyer’s Ties to Madoff
text: Bernard L. Madoff’s enormous Ponzi scheme badly damaged the reputation of the Securities and Exchange Commission, which missed numerous opportunities to stop it. Now, a report by the S.E.C.’s inspector general is likely to tarnish the agency further by dissecting an apparent conflict of interest of its former general counsel, David M. Becker, who advised the S.E.C. on how it should deal with Mr. Madoff’s investors even though he and his family inherited a Madoff account in his mother’s estate.

headline: Teaching and Learning About Evolution With The New York Times
text: A profile of the evolutionary biologist Richard Dawkins in the Sept. 20 edition of Science Times encapsulated his thinking about evolution:

headline: Why It’s Not Easy to Freeze Your Child’s Credit File
text: In her job as an analyst specializing in the retail banking world, Julie McNelley talks to a lot of bank executives. Recently, she says, she has heard concerns about child identity theft involving the use of a minor’s Social Security number to commit financial fraud.

headline: ‘New Girl’ a New Hit for Fox in Its Debut
text: The series premiere of “New Girl,” starring Zooey Deschanel, charmed its way to a ratings victory for Fox on Tuesday night, becoming the highest-rated program of the evening among the broadcast networks in the advertiser-coveted 18-to-49-year-old demographic and drawing in more than 10 million viewers.

headline: Doodling Away on Our Cover
text: It’s very easy to fall into clichés for an issue on education. Lined notebook paper, chewed pencils and stacks of books were all out of the question. We knew that designing something original for the magazine would be a challenge.

headline: The Place | Budapest, Part One
text: PERIOD PIECESAs retro mania sweeps through Budapest, the remnants of socialism are taking on an ironic sense of style.

headline: Longevity Gene Debate Opens Trans-Atlantic Rift
text: A trans-Atlantic dispute has opened up between two camps of researchers pursuing a gene that could lead to drugs that enhance longevity. British scientists say the longevity gene is “nearing the end of its life,” but the Americans whose work is under attack say the approach remains as promising as ever.

headline: Echoes of ‘Top Gun’ at Iraq’s Navy Day Ceremonies
text: UMM QASR, Iraq — Twenty five years ago, I woke up early on a Saturday morning, watched the movie “Top Gun” and began dreaming of becoming a heroic naval aviator like Tom Cruise’s character Maverick.

headline: Judge Sets February Start for Trial on AT&T Deal
text: The federal judge overseeing the Justice Department’s lawsuit seeking to block AT&T‘s takeover of T-Mobile USA has set a Feb. 13 date for a six-week trial.

headline: For Smith, Time With Giants Is in the Past
text: PHILADELPHIA — The loss of Steve Smith to the Philadelphia Eagles has been evident for the Giants this season in everything from the play of Eli Manning to the comments of the offensive coordinator Kevin Gilbride. Smith, however, does not seem to share the Giants’ sense of longing.

headline: On 100th Birthday, a Salute from San Diego State
text: Hugh McArthur won Southern California’s coveted Dudley Cup interscholastic tennis championship in 1929, led the 1932 San Diego State tennis team, and played competitive tennis in seven decades as he built a career in small business.

headline: R.E.M. Remembered
text: It was the summer of 1983. I was just out of high school, and I had by this point repudiated all my Ted Nugent, Led Zeppelin and Rush records. I was a “new waver” now — at least as much as you could be in suburban Pittsburgh. There were exactly two record stores that sold “good music.” The best one, Jim’s Records in Bloomfield, a working-class neighborhood in eastern Pittsburgh, was about a 45-minute drive for me. I had only $10, and I had narrowed my choices down to “Care,” the debut LP of a British band called Shriekback, and “Murmur,” R.E.M.’s debut LP. For no reason that I recall, I went with the Shriekback. It was a good record. The next week, I picked up “Murmur.”

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Ex-Goldman Employee of Insider Trading
text: 8:16 p.m. | Updated

headline: Experimental Treatments for Macular Degeneration
text: Millions of Americans live with macular degeneration, a leading cause of vision loss among older people, and Stargardt’s disease, a similar condition that arises in late childhood. Stephen Rose, chief research officer for the Foundation Fighting Blindness, recently joined the Consults blog to answer reader questions about these retinal degenerative diseases. Here, Dr. Rose responds to reader questions about potential treatments for macular degeneration and Stargardt’s disease that are currently under investigation.

headline: Draw Your Own Citi Field Blueprints
text: Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson made it pretty clear this week that changes would be coming to Citi Field. Changes to the dimensions of the playing field, that is, if not to the lineup the team puts on that field.

headline: Musicals Festival Diary: Money Worries
text: The New York Times asked the actress Donna Lynne Champlin, who is also a new mother, to be a guest blogger as she rehearses for “Jane Austen’s Pride and Prejudice, a Musical,” part of the New York Musical Theater Festival. Here she recounts a meeting about a week ago that helps explain what happens when actors meet paperwork.

headline: Will Developers Adopt Adobe Flash 11?
text: Adobe, the software company, introduced on Wednesday the latest version of the Adobe Flash Player, which it hopes will broaden the appeal of the software to televisions and 3-D gaming. But the company will have to persuade developers to adopt the software for interactivity on the Web and online video as many opt for HTML5 instead.

headline: This Year’s Hot TV Trend Is Anatomically Correct
text: Forget the singing competitions, cop shows, fairy-tale dramas and the “Mad Men”-style melodramas. For network television this is the season of the vagina.

text: In the subway tube the other morning, my car whooshed past a billboard with a veiled threat: something bad is happening to my eyes.

headline: The Crustacean-Covered Volvo and Other Oddities That Thrive in Queens
text: “It’s a 1984 Volvo,” said Richard Carter, crimping a wire on a plastic lobster while the strains of “Rock Lobster” by the B-52’s drifted through Flushing Meadows Corona Park.

headline: Suicide Draws Attention to Gay Bullying
text: Five months ago, Jamey Rodemeyer, a Buffalo junior high school student, got on his webcam and created a video urging other gay teenagers to remain hopeful in the face of bullying.

text: Plenty of companies would love to get their hands on our wallets. But Google wants to go one step further: it wants to be our wallets.

headline: Doubts Gone, Yankees Take Title in East
text: After a quiet off-season in which the Yankees failed to sign the elite pitcher Cliff Lee and saw their bitter rival acquire two marquee hitters, many predicted they would finish behind the Boston Red Sox in the American League East.

headline: A Model Professor
text: At a time when tree climbing and the “Lord of the Rings” language Elvish are both taught at the university level, who could argue that the world of fashion modeling is not also worthy of academic scrutiny? Ashley Mears, a young assistant professor of sociology at Boston University, just came out with her first book, “Pricing Beauty” (University of California, $27), which succeeds at dissecting the multibillion-dollar global modeling industry not only through traditional methods like interviews and data analysis, but also by resorting to a more gonzo means of academic inquiry. To study models, Mears actually became one.

headline: Bose’s New SoundLink Wireless Speaker
text: There are two schools of thought about the audio equipment maker Bose.

headline: Incumbency a Nonfactor in Party Fund-Raising
text: Incumbency, it turns out, does not always have its privileges.

headline: TimesCast | September 21, 2011
text: President Obama addresses the United Nations General Assembly; the Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof interviews Iran’s president; and Israel’s role in the 2012 presidential race.

headline: Peace Now, or Never
text: Jerusalem

headline: Starter Chic for the Stubbled
text: DIRTBAGS gone legit: New York wouldn’t be what it is without them. You know the kind: four days of beard, late lunches at the Smile, late nights at the Boom Boom Room, a getaway house in a shambled corner of Duchess County chosen equally for its anti-Hamptons statement as for the fact that it reminds their renters — we’re still renting here — of the hellholes they left behind to get to the city in the first place. They’re creators, if indeed the occasional tangible product, and a very intangible life, can be called creation.

headline: Art and Islam
text: A look at the new Islamic galleries at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Apps Can Help Make Dessert, and Won’t Sneak a Cookie

headline: Excerpt: 'Unforgettable'
text: The CBS drama is about a police consultant who remembers almost everything.

headline: An Eloquence in Groping for Words
text: Whether plain or fancy, all words are destined to fail on occasion. That’s why so many of us freeze up when we try to write a condolence letter to someone who has just lost a partner or family member. Whatever phrases spill out look so vain, so entirely not up to the occasion. Death, with its conferral of permanent emptiness, swallows up and spits back anything we might say to put it in its place.

headline: Browsing the Web by text message; a recent multimillion-dollar hack attack; tech news.
text: Stefan Gromoll, a co-founder of the DOTGO, explains how his company’s technology allows people to get information from Web sites by text messaging. David Perry, the global director of education at Trend Micro, offers a security perspective on a recent hacking operation that hauled in three million dollars in six months — and may have compromised several corporate internal networks along the way. This week’s Tip of the Week highlight’s the Safari Reading List and tech-news roundup of the week takes a look at Google Wallet and the grand opening of the Google Plus social network to the masses, as well as Netflix’s new split personality and satellite parts falling from the sky.

headline: Survival and Second Chances in Untamed Appalachia
text: Like Charles Frazier’s earlier novels, “Thirteen Moons” (2006) and the best-selling “Cold Mountain” (1997), his suspenseful, if often heavy-handed, new book, “Nightwoods,” conjures the untamed land of southern Appalachia with a native’s unsparing love and wary respect. Although this novel is set in the early 1960s — not the 19th century like its predecessors — it too recounts both a love story and a story of survival and endurance.

headline: For Women’s Road Records, No Men Allowed
text: BERLIN — Now added to the list of banned performance-enhancing substances for female distance runners: men.

headline: All the News You Want, When You Want It
text: Each morning, bleary-eyed, I retrieve the newspaper, glance at the headlines and toss it on the coffee table to read later.

headline: Want More Information? Just Scan Me
text: DURING New York Fashion Week earlier this month, Quick Response (QR) codes — square, checkered symbols that can be scanned with one’s smartphone — were as omnipresent as chunky black booties.

headline: With $6 Million in New Financing, Zimride Has Some Car Seats to Fill
text: Zimride, a Silicon Valley start-up looking to bring carpooling into the age of social media and smartphones, announced this week that it closed $6 million in its first round of venture capital investment.

headline: The Kings of Studios Now Revel in the Road
text: Steely Dan rested suavely on its laurels at the Beacon Theater on Tuesday night. The concert was part of a seven-night stand featuring live versions of full albums, among them “The Royal Scam,” from 1976, performed on Tuesday and also slated for the last Beacon show on Friday.

headline: Korean Nuclear Envoys Hold ‘Constructive’ Talks
text: BEIJING — Meetings between the chief nuclear envoys of North and South Korea were “constructive,” negotiators said, even though the talks did not produce any breakthroughs on the longstanding impasse over the North’s refusal to give up its nuclear program.

text: The CBS sitcom stars Beth Behrs and Kat Dennings.

headline: A Shifting Electorate: The Vanishing Rural Voter
text: Voters who live in rural areas are often at odds with their suburban and urban counterparts when it comes to national politics. And as the number of rural voters dwindle, so does their influence — which could have broad implications for how the Republican primaries and the general election play out in 2012.

headline: More Interior Scientists Are Taking Heat
text: Scores of scientists work for the Interior Department on issues involving birds and bees, foxes and foxgloves, and all manner of other species and their habitats. But in the eyes of the general public they tend to be virtually anonymous, at best names in italics at the end of a Federal Register notice.

headline: Chinatown to Join Roster of Business Improvement Districts
text: The twisting, bustling streets of Chinatown have been given that ubiquitous bureaucratic designation, “business improvement district,” by a unanimous vote Wednesday of the City Council.

headline: Lars von Trier Says Actually, He Isn’t Sorry
text: The Danish film director Lars von Trier, who found himself at the center of controversy for saying he was a Nazi at a Cannes Film Festival press conference in May, told GQ magazine that although he had apologized for the remark at the time, he was not sorry about the remark — only that he didn’t make it clear that he meant it to be a joke.

headline: For Shapely Brows, Put Down the Tweezers
text: “TAKE your tweezers,” Maribeth Madron, a makeup artist and eyebrow specialist in New York, will say to about a quarter of her clients, “and put them in a glass jar and freeze them.”

headline: YouTube Will Now Convert Videos to 3D
text: YouTube is announcing today a new feature to convert existing uploaded videos to 3D. By tonight, users clicking the “Edit Info” button on an upload’s “Watch” page will see the option to convert already-uploaded or new standard two-dimensional clips to 3D.

headline: Excerpt: 'Charlie's Angels'
text: The ABC series is a remake of the 1970s show.

text: Andrew Haigh, the writer and director of "Weekend," discusses his film.

headline: AOL’s Stock Plummets, Again
text: Another day, another AOL stock plunge.

headline: Peter Gatien, Club King Without a Club
text: TORONTO is not New York. The streets are too wide and clean, the subway too straightforward, the street fashion seemingly nonexistent. It’s not the kind of city where you’d expect to find someone who once made a fortune off New York’s freakish glamour and lust for late-night fun.

headline: Trial Run
text: The hair wars are heating up. Last Friday, Drybar — the West Coast-based blow-dry chain — opened at 4 West 16th Street in Manhattan, featuring chick flicks (subtitled so they can be enjoyed despite the din) and iPhone charging. It’s the first of two Manhattan outposts slated for fall (the other will be in Midtown), offering $40 blowouts — regardless of hair length. Since the price is set, “there’s no pressure,” Alli Webb, a Drybar founder, said at the press preview as she masterfully styled me.

headline: TV Chat: Ask the Critics
text: Which new TV shows are worth a try? Which returning ones deserve a second look? The New York Times critics Mike Hale and Neil Genzlinger were discussing all things television Thursday afternoon with Times readers. Mr. Genzlinger, wondering if he needs a therapist, or perhaps a priest, or maybe a neurosurgeon, reported that two of his favorite new shows so far this season were aimed at demographics that he is decidedly not in: “The Secret Circle” on CW, and “2 Broke Girls” on CBS. But to Mr. Hale those choices were perfectly understandable.

headline: Excerpt: 'Prime Suspect'
text: The NBC series is a remake of a British series.

headline: Kindle Connects to Library E-Books
text: For years the availability of free e-books from libraries was something of an underground secret.

headline: Excerpt: 'Revenge'
text: The ABC series stars Emily VanCamp as a vengeance seeker in the Hamptons.

headline: House Rebukes G.O.P. Leaders Over Spending
text: WASHINGTON — House Republican leaders suffered a surprising setback on Wednesday when the House rejected their version of a stopgap spending bill, leaving unclear how Congress will provide money to keep the government open after Sept. 30 and aid victims of a string of costly recent natural disasters.

headline: Views of Perry Turn More Negative Since First Debate
text: Whether Mitt Romney has gained ground on Rick Perry in the Republican primary race is questionable. Polls released since Mr. Perry’s first debate on Sept. 7 show him leading Mr. Romney by an average of 8 percentage points. By contrast, Mr. Perry led Mr. Romney by 11 points in polls released between the announcement of his candidacy on Aug. 13 and the Sept. 7 debate.

headline: Female Detectives Revived: One Tough, Others Stylish
text: The heroine of “Prime Suspect” takes a punch. Actually, she is beaten and almost killed after single-handedly confronting a crazed suspect. The next day, her face is swollen and bruised.

text: Four questions for Nadine Ferber Abramcyk, workwear with girlish touches, hybrid shoot books, and more.

headline: Jeter Gets the Last Laugh

headline: New Ways to Dance, Found in the Eyes of Others
text: As experimental choreographers and dancers working in New York in the 1990s, Wally Cardona and Jennifer Lacey knew each other without truly knowing each other. But they did share one heady dance experience: before Ms. Lacey moved to Paris in 2000, they took part in an improvisation in the East Village. “My memory of it was like: ‘Ah! She’ll cut me!’ ” Mr. Cardona said. “That was my image of Jennifer. She was so sharp. She was like a knife.”

headline: Angry Birds
text: Although ostrich ﬂesh is promoted as a leaner, more healthful alternative to other meats, the bird itself can be a health hazard to ostrich farmers.

headline: Striving for Objectivity, First in Molecular Biology, and Then in Choreography

headline: Bermuda Bowl Competitors Fight Online in a Practice Bout
text: Last Sunday the two American teams in next month’s Bermuda Bowl world team championship played against each other over 48 boards on Bridge Base Online.

headline: ‘Hey, You Look Familiar’
text: REALITY television could not hold a candle to the piece of reality theater presented on Monday. Why bother with a housewife or anything like a Snooki, when you could see John Lithgow, Morgan Freeman, Christine Lahti, Ellen Barkin and Cheyenne Jackson playing the real people in a dramatization of the Proposition 8 trial in California?

headline: Peters Mountain Works
text: When John Peters, the guy who created the modern messenger bag, invites you up to his home in Saugerties, N.Y., to see his latest project, you go and look. But mostly you listen. Peters, whose tall and skinny frame can be attributed to the years he spent climbing in New York, New Hampshire and beyond, touches on about 20 things at the same time — from A.T.V.’s to Levon Helm’s Midnight Rambles. But it’s talk about his latest collection of bags, called Peters Mountain Works, that overshadows all. The line is the culmination of many things: the sewing skills that Peters’s mother taught him growing up in Poughkeepsie, N.Y.; the collection of packs he later started in New York with a fellow climber he met at the Shawangunks; the now ubiquitous line of cordura messenger bags that Peters created (that line, with the red and white skyscraper logo), which would begin its takeover of Manhattan in the early 1980s — “a little hillbilly line from Upstate,” he calls it, though it was anything but.

headline: Green Houses Grow on the National Mall
text: Free for dinner in Washington? Nineteen groups of architecture students will be serving meals next week at houses they have built in West Potomac Park, adjacent to the National Mall, as part of the Department of Energy’s biennial Solar Decathlon, a kind of “America’s Got Talent” for green architecture. The ambience at their dinner parties is one of 10 areas the students will be rated on. Others include market appeal, design, adequacy of hot water and affordability (a category added after a $2 million house from Germany won the 2009 competition).

headline: Poker Site Fires Back Over ‘Ponzi Scheme’ Charge
text: Prosecutors are throwing the book at Full Tilt Poker. A lawyer for the embattled online poker company is throwing a book back: the dictionary.

headline: A ‘Sweet Little House’ in Toronto
text: Dating to the 1930s and covering 2,442 square feet of space, the house recently underwent a complete renovation.

headline: Wall St. Protests Continue, With Arrests at Morning March

headline: My Three Favorite Novels to Read as a Teenager
text: Once you move past “Are You There God? It’s Me, Margaret,” by Judy Blume, which is the perfect thing to read (if you’re a girl) right before full teenagerness sets in, these three books immediately come to mind. Thinking back, I couldn’t remember much about the plots, but what stayed with me through the years is the feeling they left me with. A sense of unsettled discomfort, but also an excitement at the realization that they provided a window onto the next more complicated, confusing — and perhaps cruel — phase of life.

headline: On the Case: Investigator, Billionaire and Some Nosy Software
text: “Person of Interest” represents a reunion: J. J. Abrams, executive producer, and Michael Emerson, star, together again and hoping to recapture some of that “Lost” magic.

headline: Twitter Starts Selling Political Ads
text: Twitter began selling political advertising on Wednesday to about a half-dozen presidential candidates and national party committees under a pilot program that allows specific posts to appear in the timelines of people who follow campaigns and to pop up when certain search terms are used, Twitter officials announced.

headline: On Location | Sweden
text: The narrow, triangular house, built in a lakeside suburb of Stockholm, has all three facades obscured by trellises and is surrounded by gardens.

headline: A House Enveloped in Greenery
text: VIKSBERG, Sweden — For nearly three decades, there was little about their surroundings that Elisabeth Krausz and Peter Sjogren found disagreeable when they lived in Ostermalm, an affluent enclave in Stockholm. They were near ornate castles, cobblestoned streets and harbors dotted with pristine white boats.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Person of Interest’
text: The CBS series stars Michael Emerson and Jim Caviezel.

headline: Robert Wilson, Director, on His Passion for Chairs
text: While he is best known for his theatrical work, the avant-garde stage director and playwright Robert Wilson is an all-around creative soul who, among other things, also paints, draws, sculptures and designs lighting and furniture. Mr. Wilson earned a degree in architecture from Pratt Institute and at one point studied with the architect Paolo Soleri in Arizona. And his furniture — mostly chairs — are at museums like the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis and the Centre Pompidou in Paris.

headline: Produce Importer in Food Safety Fight
text: When health investigators identified imported cantaloupes as the source of a salmonella outbreak early this year, the importer agreed to a recall. But now that company, Del Monte Fresh Produce, is trying to block additional restrictions on melon imports, setting off an unusually public battle between the produce industry and food safety regulators.

headline: Homes for $1 Million
text: A contemporary in Boulder, Colo., a condo in an 1890 building in Boston, and a circa 1780 house in Virginia.

headline: What You Get for ... $1 Million

text: A Lakeville couple created a loftlike home from a prefabricated shell and filled it with furniture of their own design.

headline: Sales at Missoni Home, Alessi and Others
text: Calico Corners is taking 20 percent off fabric, trimmings and furniture, through Sept. 24 (Manlius fabric by Thom Filicia, regularly about $53 a yard, is about $42); (800) 213-6366.

headline: For Michele Varian, Roomier Quarters
text: Michele Varian was an early adopter of Crosby Street. Her home furnishings store has had two spots on the now-coveted block between Broome and Grand Streets in the last decade. Last week, she moved again, to a space on Howard Street recently vacated by Ted Muehling (who opened his new store two days ago at 52 White Street).

headline: KleinReid’s New Chalices and Goblets
text: Prime, a series of voluptuous hand-turned porcelain vessels with walnut pedestal bases, is the newest collection from the New York design studio KleinReid. “We’ve been in a chalice-and-goblet phase,” explained David Reid, one of the designers.

text: This is the first in a regular series of articles on strategic home repairs and redecorating that can be done to prepare a home for sale.

headline: For Kids, a D.I.Y. Web Site
text: Last winter, Timothy Dahl, founder and editor of the six-year-old home improvement blog Charles & Hudson (charlesandhudson.com), and his wife, Laura, a fashion designer, learned that she was pregnant. In addition to the usual prenatal preparations, they developed Built by Kids (builtbykids.com), a Web site devoted to do-it-yourself projects that parents and children can collaborate on, like herb gardens planted in a wheelbarrow, refurbished tatami tables and handmade wagons. The tasks were tested and refined during a series of daylong workshops with friends at the couple’s Los Angeles bungalow.

headline: Art Deco Objects
text: WHEN the ballroom at Claridge’s hotel, one of London’s oldest Art Deco buildings, was in need of refurbishment not long ago, the powers that be called on Guy Oliver. Mr. Oliver, 42, is the managing director of the interior design firm Oliver Laws and an authority on the period. He did the interiors of Bryanston Court, the hotel where Wallis Simpson once lived, and is consulting with the Cleveland Museum of Art about a future exhibition on the 1920s style.

headline: Designers and Their Kickstarter-Funded Projects

headline: On Kickstarter, Designers’ Dreams Materialize
text: PAULA PATTERSON was back in her studio the other night, where she has spent nearly every weeknight and too many weekends to admit since January. From her day job as a graphic designer at an executive search firm in Midtown, she takes the subway and the fickle B61 bus to Brooklyn (“I don’t know why they print a schedule,” she said). That leaves her about two hours to build another V-Luxe, the iPad stand she designed as a birthday gift for her boyfriend last summer and soon after decided to market online.

headline: Millionaires, The Middle Class, and Taxes — Actual Numbers
text: Further to this post about whether the Obama/Boo-Fay — sorry, Obama/ Buffett with two t’s – claim is true: the Tax Policy Center has new numbers about the distribution of average tax rates by income class. headline: Belge Epoque
text: Before Christina Vantzou, a Kansas City, Mo.-born art student, fell in love with an American expat during a layover in Brussels seven years ago, she had never given the city a second thought. She assumed it was as bland as everyone said, and when she packed her bags and moved there soon after, she found plenty of Europeans who agreed. “The people I was hanging out with at the time referred to it as the Mexico of Europe,” she says. “Everyone wanted to go to Paris or London or Amsterdam, and Brussels was just this weird place in the middle.”

headline: New Round of Measures for Austerity in Greece
text: ATHENS — Facing mounting pressure from the foreign lenders keeping it solvent, the Greek government on Wednesday announced additional — and deeply unpopular — austerity measures, including scaling back the public sector and cutting pensions.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Browsing by Texting
text: Smartphones and tablets have changed the way people get information from the Web, but not everyone has, wants or can afford an expensive mobile device. But what if you could use a basic feature available on almost every cellphone to get information from Web sites just by sending simple text messages? Stefan Gromoll, a former astrophysicist and now a co-founder of the company Dotgo, explains just how to do that with the technology he helped develop.

headline: Ranger’s Concussion Was Not Disclosed
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The disclosure by the Rangers this week that defenseman Marc Staal sustained a concussion last February has put a spotlight on the N.H.L.’s policy on public disclosure of injuries.

headline: Nunez Fills In With a Homer
text: Yankees infielder Eduardo Nunez has done a lot of filling in this season. In Wednesday’s first game, he did his part to fill in part of the playoff picture, stroking an 0-1 pitch over the left-field fence to tie the score, 2-2, in the eighth, helping the Yankees to a 4-2 win over Tampa Bay and a postseason berth.

headline: Moody’s Downgrades Credit Ratings of Three Large Banks
text: Moody’s cut its credit ratings Wednesday on three large banks — Bank of America, Citigroup and Wells Fargo — underscoring the challenges the sector still faces three years after the onset of the financial crisis.

headline: A Disruptive Force for Opposing Offenses
text: It was just another play in a long season, late in the first half on a sunny Sunday during a forgettable game last year between Oakland and Arizona. The Cardinals were driving, with a second-and-10 on the Raiders’ 33-yard line. The All-Pro Larry Fitzgerald was in the left flank, with nothing but grass and a lone Raider near him. At the snap, Fitzgerald took a hard step inside, setting up that solitary Raider to be beaten outside when Fitzgerald broke back toward the sideline, the route designed for a lobbed pass over his defender’s head.

headline: Ohio Woman Describes Becoming a ‘Suspicious’ Person
text: On the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, Shoshana Hebshi, 35, a freelance writer and stay-at-home mother of 6-year-old twins from a suburb of Toledo, Ohio, was on a plane flying from Denver to Detroit when something she — or another passenger in her row of seats — had done caused the government to scramble F-16 fighter planes and escort Frontier Airlines Flight 623 until it landed safely. The plane was taken to a remote part of the airport, and armed federal authorities handcuffed Ms. Hebshi and her seatmates and took them off the plane. She was placed in a jail cell, strip-searched and interrogated by the F.B.I. before eventually being released. The two men in her row were also allowed to go. Ms. Hebshi says she believes she was detained because she is “dark-skinned” — she is half Arab, half Jewish. She described her seatmates as Indian. The F.B.I. says it was responding to reports that Ms. Hebshi and the men were behaving suspiciously. But Ms. Hebshi said she was never told what about her behavior, or that of her seatmates, had been alarming to others on the plane. Ms. Hebshi discusses:

headline: The Place | Hollywood’s Budapest
text: On film, Budapest rarely plays itself. In “Evita,” it was Buenos Aires. In “Munich,” it was Munich. Last year, The New York Times called the Hungarian capital “Hollywood on the Danube.” But while Budapest stands in for many different cities, Rome is increasingly becoming one of its more convincing performances. The city is transformed into Rome in this year’s Anthony Hopkins thriller “The Rite,” while Etyek, just west of Budapest, serves as the Eternal City for “The Borgias,” a Showtime series about a 15th-century Italian dynasty, in which Jeremy Irons stars as Pope Alexander VI.

headline: TimesCast | Obama Speaks at U.N.
text: President Obama addresses the United Nations General Assembly and the Palestinian Authority’s bid for statehood.

headline: PGA Finale Sends Players Back to Math Class
text: ATLANTA — This week’s farewell event of the PGA Tour season is two competitions wrapped in one. For fans, and even some contestants, it can be as puzzling as an enigma wrapped in a riddle.

headline: After Weeks of Jitters, a Sense of Calm

headline: Tampa Bay Is Hampered by Struggling Offense
text: The San Francisco Giants last season called it torture, and watching the Tampa Bay Rays, you understand why. It really is hard to win without scoring many runs. The Giants somehow won the World Series last fall with an offense that scored fewer runs than the league average. Now the Rays hope to squeeze into the playoffs the same way.

headline: Taking a Stand, and Shedding Arafat’s Shadow
text: UNITED NATIONS — At the baronial Morgan Library in Midtown Manhattan the other night, President Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian leader, stood quietly along the edge of a diplomatic reception, avoiding the animated gossip and flowing Champagne.

text: SAN FRANCISCO — As speculation swirled Wednesday that Meg Whitman might be brought in to save the troubled Hewlett-Packard, the tech world rendered a verdict: You have got to be kidding.

text: BERLIN — Instead of a pleasant visit to his native land, the trip to Germany this week by Pope Benedict XVI promises to be a journey to one of the front lines in the battle over the future of the Roman Catholic Church.

headline: Goodrich Sale for $16 Billion Is Confirmed
text: 11:14 p.m. | Updated  United Technologies has agreed to buy the Goodrich Corporation for $16.4 billion in cash, the companies said late on Wednesday, in an effort to expand in the fast-growing commercial aviation business.

headline: Breaking News: The Civil War Is Over
text: Judicial opinions on the constitutionality of the new health care law are pouring out of the federal courts. With the general expectation that the Supreme Court will have to resolve what is now a clear conflict between two federal courts of appeals, the individual lower-court decisions have pretty much ceased to make news. By the time the Supreme Court rules, if and when it does, a decision earlier this month by the federal appeals court in Richmond, Va., throwing out Virginia’s challenge to the statute without reaching the ultimate constitutional question, will be all but forgotten.

headline: An Interview With Mahmoud Ahmadinejad

headline: Baby Steps
text: My parents left New York City in 1979 and moved north to a Mayberry manqué in Westchester called Irvington. That was just what bourgeois couples did when they were expecting. You can’t really blame them. They had spent three years as interns and residents in hospitals in the South Bronx, taking care of patients with gunshot wounds and reviving heroin addicts. The apartment they’d lived in had been burglarized, and besides, they were children of the suburbs themselves.

headline: Radical Cleric’s Path, Now at a Crossroads, Could Turn Iraq, Too
text: BAGHDAD — In a classroom in Sadr City, the bustling neighborhood of the Shiite poor, dozens of men in white shirts and black pants received the most basic of Islamic religious instruction: how to wash before praying.

headline: Opposing Views on Perry as Job-Creating Master
text: During Rick Perry’s first political campaign almost 30 years ago, a supporter at one stop suggested he take credit for the rain that had broken a dry spell the night before. But his father warned, “Son, you can take credit for the rain if you want, but they’ll blame you for the drought.”

Mangold Stows Crutches, but Jets Have Their Doubts

headline: Judge Rejects Challenge to Voting Rights Law by County in Alabama
text: Ruling that the intentional voter discrimination that led to the passage and multiple extensions of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 still exists, a federal judge in Washington on Wednesday dismissed an Alabama county’s claim that portions of the act were unconstitutional.

headline: Lurid Confession, Delivered in Calm Tones, Shocks Court
text: NEW HAVEN — The judge at the Cheshire triple-murder trial abruptly sent jurors home about 10 minutes early on Wednesday, saying that one of the panel members was having a tough time with the evidence.

headline: Children of the Corn
text: By late summer, most of the corn in America is head high and bristling. The stalks stand shoulder to shoulder like an army without rank, their sharp-edged, swordlike leaves forming a nearly impenetrable wall. A modern cornfield would have rebuffed Cary Grant in “North by Northwest” because there are no rows to speak of, only a dense lattice of intersecting spears. This corn — grown by the tens of millions of acres — has been genetically engineered, altered by having stacks of apparently desirable traits wedged into its genetic code. Saving the kernels of engineered corn in the fall to plant in the spring is both illegal, because of company patents, and largely irrelevant, since the plants they yield, which contain a packet of foreign genes, won’t necessarily resemble the parent crop. Nearly all the corn you see anywhere in our nation of corn is this year’s model, new and, so they say, improved.

headline: Obama Rebuffed as Palestinians Pursue U.N. Seat
text: UNITED NATIONS — A last-ditch American effort to head off a Palestinian bid for membership in the United Nations faltered. President Obama tried to qualify his own call, just a year ago, for a Palestinian state. And President Nicolas Sarkozy of France stepped forcefully into the void, with a proposal that pointedly repudiated Mr. Obama’s approach.

headline: Free Speech on the Sidewalk
text: The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in a ruling that should cause some cities and towns across the country to snap awake and reread the Constitution, has upheld the rights of day laborers to gather and speak freely in public as they look for work.

headline: $5 Million Payment to End Suits Over Death of 13-Year-Old Boy in State Care
text: ALBANY — The State of New York has agreed to pay $5 million to settle two civil suits brought by the family of a boy with autism who died in state care, among the larger wrongful-death settlements ever paid by the state.

headline: Bill to Legalize Fireworks Awaits Cuomo’s Decision
text: In much of the country, the Fourth of July is synonymous with backyard fireworks displays. Not so in New York, which is among the dwindling number of states where such fireworks are illegal.

headline: After the Hard Life of Prison Comes the Hard Life of the Outside World
text: The mundane business of choosing a toothbrush evokes a small crisis in the confusing new life of Monty (Alfredo Narciso), the ex-convict hero of “After.,” a quiet new drama by Chad Beckim that opened Wednesday night at the Wild Project in the East Village. Monty isn’t prepared for the daily onslaught of decision making required in civilian life. He’s been incarcerated for 17 years — just about half of his life — and the task of reintegrating into a world he barely recognizes leaves him feeling alienated at every turn.

headline: Illinois Redistricting Forces Republican Face-Off
text: CHICAGO – Voters in at least one Illinois congressional district will have to choose between two Republican incumbents next year after Representative Joe Walsh announced Wednesday that he will seek re-election in a new district, pitting him against a fellow Republican, Representative Randy Hultgren, in a primary.

headline: The Return of the Elwha River
text: Over the next three years, two huge hydroelectric dams on the Elwha River in Washington State, built early in the last century, will be dismantled to restore ancient salmon runs. This is a tribute to the tenacity of the citizens and environmental groups who helped make it happen. It is also an example of the good that can be done with genuine bipartisan collaboration.

headline: Selling Travel With Words, Not Images

headline: Cyprus: Turkey Announces Rival Gas Deal
text: Turkey and the breakaway Turkish part of Cyprus signed a deal on Wednesday to prepare legal grounds for gas exploration around the disputed island in an immediate response to drilling by Greek Cypriots that started early this week. “Since the Greek Cypriot Administration has started the drilling activity on Sept. 19, as already announced, a continental shelf delimitation agreement has been signed today,” a statement from the Turkish Foreign Ministry statement said. The deal signed by Turkey’s Prime Minister, Tayyip Erdoðan, and Dervis Eroglu, the leader of the Turkish Cypriots, while attending the United Nations General Assembly in New York, “takes into account the legitimate, equal and inherent rights of the Turkish Cypriots like those of the Greek Cypriots over the whole continental shelf of the Island,” it said. Turkey has called the search for gas reserves in Eastern Mediterranean by the internationally recognized Greek Cypriot state a provocation, when Ankara supports sharing the region’s natural resources equally between the Turkish and Greek communities. The energy reserves in the area have also been explored recently by Israel, which is likely to increase diplomatic and military tensions in the region. SEBNEM ARSU

headline: LivingSocial May Postpone I.P.O. and Focus on Fund-Raising
