headline: New Enrollment Dips a Bit at U.S. Graduate Schools
text: Enrollment of new students at graduate schools in the United States dropped slightly from 2009 to 2010, despite an 8.4 percent increase in applications. It was the first decline in first-time graduate enrollment since 2003, according to the Council of Graduate Schools, and came after a 5.5 percent increase the previous year.

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Thursday
text: Is there a war raging within the government about who failed to properly monitor the sale of valuable mobile phone spectrum? The Indian Express reports that the Finance Ministry sent a letter saying the home minister, P. Chidambaram, who was finance minister at the time of the sale, agreed to sell the mobile phone spectrum at fixed prices rather than auction it. Congress quickly said that Mr. Chidambaram’s integrity was not in doubt, but the letter raised questions about who knew what, and when, during India’s biggest corruption scandal. (Indian Express)The cost of the damage in the Sikkim earthquake is likely to top $20 billion, state officials said, and the death toll may yet rise. In one North Sikkim village, 120 people have vanished. The government is pledging compensation for those killed and injured and those who lost their property. (NDTV)

headline: Data Show County’s Pain as Economy Plummeted
text: GREENWOOD, S.C. — The Greenwood Mills Matthews Plant once employed three generations of Frances Flaherty’s family. Her grandmother, father and brother made textiles there — denim for jeans and khaki for military uniforms.

headline: 35 Seconds
text: Landslide season was supposed to be over.  The wet weather had lingered last week as we waited for the monsoon’s final retreat and the clear skies of October. In Sikkim, landslides are the earth’s accompaniment to the monsoons, but this year had been merciful, so far.

headline: Injuries, Most of Them Real, Continue to Plague the Giants
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Starting in training camp, and continuing through the preseason and into the regular season, the Giants have been dealing with a seemingly never-ending deluge of injuries. Season-ending injuries. Nagging injuries. Knee injuries. Foot injuries. And now even fake injuries.

headline: Drama at a Georgia Prison
text: Troy Davis filed an eleventh-hour plea Wednesday asking the United States Supreme Court to stop Georgia authorities from executing him for the murder of an off-duty police officer.

headline: One in Five New York City Residents Living in Poverty
text: Poverty grew nationwide last year, but the increase was even greater in New York City, the Census Bureau will report on Thursday, suggesting that New York was being particularly hard hit by the aftermath of the recession.

headline: India: Sikkim Quake Toll Now Put at 68
text: A company building a hydroelectric power plant confirmed Wednesday that 17 of its workers had died and seven were critically injured as a result of the earthquake that shook the Himalayas in and around the northeastern Indian state of Sikkim on Sunday. The state’s chief minister, Pawan Chamling, told reporters that 68 people had been killed in Sikkim, and that the property damage exceeded $20 billion. Indian soldiers and rescue workers raced to clear debris and rescue those who remained trapped by landslides. “Relief work is going on at war footing,” Mr. Chamling said. “All the roads are broken and damaged. All the water pipelines are damaged. All the electric lines are damaged and disrupted. It will take months to repair all that.” Officials at the company building the plant on the upper reaches of the Teesta River said in a statement that none of the workers had been on duty because it was a Sunday, but had been killed by landslides.

headline: In Uganda, Losing Land to Planted Trees

headline: Britain: Memoir of WikiLeaks Founder Arrives, but Without Its Author
text: The autobiography of the WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange will be released on Thursday, despite his withdrawing cooperation for the book, his British publisher said Wednesday. The publication of “Julian Assange: The Unauthorized Autobiography” follows a contentious battle, according to a statement from the publisher, Canongate Books. Mr. Assange said last December that he had reluctantly signed a book deal worth as much as $1.7 million. “I don’t want to write this book, but I have to,” he told reporters, citing a costly continuing legal battle to avoid extradition to Sweden from Britain to face allegations of sexual abuse there. According to the Canongate statement, Mr. Assange gave 50 hours of interviews to a writer enlisted to help him. But when he saw the first draft of the book in March, he declared “All memoir is prostitution,” and sought to cancel the contract. In New York, Alfred A. Knopf canceled its contract for the Assange memoir.

headline: Unesco in Partnership to Train School Principals in 3 Nations
text: The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization is to announce Thursday a partnership with the Varkey GEMS Foundation to train 10,000 school principals in India, Ghana and Kenya. The foundation is the philanthropic arm of GEMS Education of Dubai, United Arab Emirates, a provider of for-profit, private education in Europe, Asia and Africa. By training principals, the program aspires to benefit thousands of teachers and “up to 10 million children.” The foundation will contribute $1 million toward the partnership.

headline: California: Police Charged in Killing
text: Two Fullerton police officers face felony charges in a beating in July that left a homeless man dead, the Orange County district attorney said Wednesday. Officer Manuel Ramos was charged with second-degree murder and involuntary manslaughter in the beating of Kelly Thomas, 37, a drifter with schizophrenia who died five days after the encounter with the police, who were responding to reports of attempted break-ins to cars. Cpl. Jay Cicinelli was charged with involuntary manslaughter and excessive use of force.

headline: Better Screening Test Is Sought to Detect Infections in Organ Donors
text: Improvements are needed in the screening of organ donors to protect transplant patients from hepatitis B and C, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said Wednesday. Transplant centers already test both living and dead donors for those diseases, but many centers use an older type of blood test that cannot detect an infection that was acquired very recently. A newer technique, nucleic acid testing, can find infections earlier. For hepatitis C, for instance, the older test cannot detect the disease during the first 70 days after infection. But nucleic acid testing can find it after seven days. The newer test is already used to detect H.I.V. Infections in organ recipients prompted the new recommendations. From 2007 to 2010, the C.D.C. confirmed dozens of cases of hepatitis B and C and H.I.V. caused by transplants; some patients died.

headline: A $42 Million Gift Aims at Improving Bedside Manner
text: CHICAGO — Carolyn Bucksbaum still bristles about an arrogant physician who brusquely dismissed her intuition about her ailment decades ago. It turned out she was right. The physician was wrong.

headline: Loan Ranger
text: On a hot summer day in Manaus, Brazil, Diana Taylor, the former banking superintendent of New York and longtime companion of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, was strolling through a slum. A city of about two million in the middle of the Amazon, Manaus is where the Boston-based microfinance group Acción International started an ambitious lending operation in February, and Taylor, who is chairwoman of the group’s board, had flown down with a delegation of staff and investors to observe how the experiment was coming along on the ground. Nearly six feet tall, thin and wearing large, round sunglasses, khaki pants and leather driving moccasins that had the kind of distressed effect only years of wear can produce, Taylor did not blend in.

headline: Sept. 22, 1862 | Preliminary Emancipation Proclamation Announced

headline: How Impulsive Are You?
text: Forty years ago, a researcher tested the self-control of 4-year-olds by offering them the choice of one marshmallow immediately or two marshmallows 15 minutes later. Years later, the 4-year-olds who delayed their gratification were more successful and less likely to abuse drugs than their more impulsive peers. Do you have good self-control? Does your level of self-control seem to resonate in other areas of your life?

headline: Changes to OnStar’s Privacy Terms Rile Some Users

For years, some G.M. car and truck owners have posted elaborate instructions to Internet forums and user groups detailing how to disable built-in OnStar equipment to prevent any tracking of their vehicles.

headline: Globalization Meets Beethoven in Mumbai
text: Recently, this story about how dairy farms in northern Italy had come to rely heavily on the labor of Punjabi immigrants generated a lot of interest. But the traffic hasn’t flowed only one way. As India’s economy has expanded, guest workers from around the world have flocked to the subcontinent. Dancers from Eastern Europe frequently appear in Bollywood films; pilots from the United Kingdom are in the cockpits of Indian planes; and the offices of some of Bangalore’s computer companies could be mistaken for the sets of a Benetton advertisement.

headline: The War on Insider Trading: Market-Beaters Beware
text: How much time should Raj Rajaratnam spend in prison? Rajaratnam is the hedge fund founder who was convicted in May of trading on illegal stock tips — tips that produced fantastic results for his Galleon Group. Federal authorities compare him with notorious white-collar crooks like Bernie Madoff and Jeffrey Skilling, and they argue for a long time behind bars. His lawyers, however, say Rajaratnam is a lesser-order felon — “not . . . as culpable as a defendant who affirmatively steals,” as they put it in a pre-sentencing memorandum. The lawyers raise a problem of culture and law: Is insider trading merely an illicit version of a common American cleverness, trading on gossip from a colleague or friend that helps the trader and hurts no one? Or is it the quintessential Wall Street crime, one that has undermined Americans’ faith in the markets?

headline: Romance and Reflection, Hand in Hand
text: MOST romantic movies are so determined to chart the course of a love story — how boy meets girl leads to happily or unhappily ever after — that they miss the intensity and import of beginnings. But the new British film “Weekend,” like its closest American predecessor “Before Sunrise,” lingers on the initial sparks of an erotic and emotional connection. As a one-night stand turns into something more, the film explores the notion that to meet someone new, not least a potential partner, is also to rethink who you are, an invitation to shape and refine the self you wish to project. A story about falling in love that is also a tale of identity and self-definition, it is perhaps all the more resonant for taking place between two gay men.

headline: One-Stop Shopping in Milan
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#283", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);London has Selfridges, Harvey Nicks and Liberty; New York has Bergdorf Goodman, Barneys and Saks; and Paris has Le Bon Marché, Les Galeries Lafayette and Au Printemps. Milan, on the other hand, has been conspicuously lacking in luxury department stores. But that all changed earlier this month, with the opening earlier of Excelsior, a multilevel shopping destination with a fashion sense that runs the gamut from Dries Van Noten to Balmain (the renowned local boutique owner Antonia Giacinti is a consultant), a trio of restaurants from the local celebrity chef Davide Oldani and departments stocked with everything from retro-fabulous meat slicers to flower arrangements by the edgy florist Numero 9. The former cinema has been reimagined by the architect Jean Nouvel as an ode to the history of film: floors are laid out as parapet balconies, and wraparound L.E.D. screens show a continuous stream of film stills. Even the sales clerks dress the part. The women who work in the cosmetics and fragrance hall on the first floor wear stripy Breton tops, cropped black trousers and ankle-strap heels and the guys who sell men’s clothes on the second floor sport tartan shirts, chinos and solid ties. Despite the inauspicious location, right next to a low-end mall, and the coy facade (Nouvel hid the entrance behind a giant louvered blind, and there are no window displays), we foresee a flurry of fashion-week pilgrimages.

text: SINGAPORE – Traveling to the so-called “flyaway races” in Formula One can be a big adventure on its own. Most of the Formula One paddock travels by air to the races around Europe, but traveling to the far-flung races, like this weekend’s Singapore Grand Prix, can be far more interesting.

headline: Showing His Mastery Just by Standing Still
text: The flamenco dancer Israel Galván combines complete command of his medium with a phenomenally fertile range of off-beat stylistic ideas. He gives you — deliberately — the impression that traditional flamenco is too small to contain all he needs to do in terms of rhythm and drama. You see him suddenly balance on one leg and turn the sole of his raised shoe upward so that he can slap out a beat with his hands; he even taps one percussive phrase on his front teeth. These are gimmicks. As with many of the greatest flamenco dancers, the intensity with which he presents himself is always on the cusp of absurdity. But he makes his effects feel both enjoyable and necessary. They work because they’re part of the witty, odd flamboyance that characterizes his dance theater, but even more because they’re part of the rhythmic outpouring that turns his dance into music. Though he shows that he can do quite an assortment of the foot trillings that abound in flamenco, he refuses to indulge himself in that kind of bravura: he steers clear of flamenco cliché. It’s extremely rare in any genre to see a dancer of this singular imagination and authority.

headline: The Elephant in the Room, at a Vuitton Celebration
text: Katie Grand, the British stylist and magazine editor who has worked with Marc Jacobs on his Louis Vuitton collections for nearly a decade or, as she said, “like a million years,” walked into an exhibition of his designs at 8:30 p.m. on Wednesday and saw, for possibly the millionth time, a video in which she describes the collaborative process.

headline: My Three Favorite People Named Greg
text: I’ve always had a bit of trouble with the extended version of my first name. Gregory. It just feels a little too proper, doesn’t it, as if it would be silly for me not to receive a dozen Fabergé eggs upon the occasion of my birth. (When you combine it with my middle name, you get Gregory Paul. I think we can all agree that’s pretty papal-sounding for a Jew.) Anyway, another bummer about my name, especially when I was young and cared about this sort of thing, was that I had very few other Gregorys to look up to. The name didn’t have the famous person starting lineup of a Michael or Matthew or David. I mean, Greg Gumbel seems nice and all.

headline: Pakistan’s Spy Agency Is Tied to Attack on U.S. Embassy
text: WASHINGTON — The nation’s top military official said Thursday that Pakistan’s spy agency played a direct role in supporting the insurgents who carried out the deadly attack on the American Embassy in Kabul last week. It was the most serious charge that the United States has leveled against Pakistan in the decade that America has been at war in Afghanistan.

headline: We Must Cooperate on Nuclear Safety
text: A nuclear accident anywhere has the potential to be a nuclear accident everywhere. headline: Support the Palestinian Bid for Statehood
text: THE United States should support the Palestinian Authority’s bid for statehood at the United Nations. The Palestinian people deserve a state now. As the current debate unfolds, I am reminded of what the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said in 1965: “The time is always right to do what’s right.”

headline: Israel’s New Labor Leader Faces a Party in Decline
text: JERUSALEM — The election of a new leader of Israel’s historic but severely diminished Labor Party prompted talk of a possible revival on Thursday. But analysts were predicting a modest comeback in the best case, with a special emphasis on socioeconomic issues.

headline: Getting Cash in Exchange for a Short Sale

The Academy occasionally tweaks its rules for conduct leading up to the Oscars, and the changes this time covered a range of topics.

headline: After Flopping on Broadway, ‘High’ Is Hitting the Road

Having lost its entire investment of $1.8 million in New York, why is “High” now poised to become the relatively rare Broadway play to go on national tour?

headline: Classroom Overcrowding at 10-Year High, Union Says
text: After years of staff attrition and budget cuts, the number of overcrowded classrooms in city schools is now the largest it has been in 10 years, the teachers union says. Nearly 7,000 classes are over their contractual limits this year, according to the union, the United Federation of Teachers, an increase of almost 1,000 from last year. The union’s president, Michael Mulgrew, cited the numbers in pleading for the city not to cut the school budget again. “We have to stop this craziness,” he said. Read more on SchoolBook »

Somehow, though, their spring collections brought us all to Italy, or at least our idea of an Italian holiday. Neither show was a movie-still occasion, but the cottony, upswept hair and glitter-coated eyelids at Fendi might make you think of a 1960s film star. The collarless, knee-length satin coats and pleated chiffon dresses at Prada did the same.

headline: 36 Hours in Perugia, Italy
text: IF Italy were a dartboard, the city of Perugia would most likely be its bull’s-eye. Equidistant from Florence and Rome in the bucolic, central Italian region of Umbria, Perugia is an enchanting hilltop city with a compact historic center that is a rambling maze of medieval streets. Although many associate Perugia with the controversial murder trial of the American Amanda Knox, this forward-thinking city maintains a friendly appeal. In 2008, an eco-friendly high-tech light rail line called the MiniMetrò made its debut, zipping visitors into the city center from outer areas and keeping its historic streets mostly car-free. Instead, the streets jam with visitors during two popular annual events: a summer jazz festival that attracts the music world’s biggest acts, and Eurochocolate, a huge autumnal chocolate festival that this year runs Oct. 14 to 23.

headline: 36 Hours in Perugia, Italy
text: Perugia is equidistant from Florence and Rome in the bucolic, central Italian region of Umbria.

headline: ‘Oh My God’ Artworks to Visit Neue Galerie
text: Ronald S. Lauder rarely lets a day go by without looking at paintings, sculptures, drawings, decorative objects or beautiful books. He peruses catalogs from around the world, visits dealers and auction houses, views countless images that pour into his office from everywhere. Mentally he divides what he sees into three categories: “There’s the Oh, the Oh My and the Oh My God,” Mr. Lauder said this week, perched on a Josef Hoffmann sofa in his commodious office on the 42nd floor of the General Motors building, with staggering views of Manhattan and walls filled with paintings by Egon Schiele, Gerhard Richter, Oskar Kokoschka and Joseph Beuys. “I’ve chosen only the Oh My Gods.”

headline: David Hallberg to Appear on ‘The Colbert Report’
text: Stephen Colbert better brush up on his pliés. On Dec. 7, the Comedy Central pundit will play host to David Hallberg, the American dancer who announced earlier this week that he will join the Bolshoi Ballet — the first time an American has enlisted with the Russian company. Mr. Hallberg, a principal dancer at The American Ballet Theater who hails from Rapid City, S.D., will start at the Bolshoi on Nov. 4. The Colbert Report has previously featured dance luminaries like Savion Glover and cast members from the Broadway musical “Fela.” Mikhail Baryshnikov has showed up too, but not to dance, so Mr. Hallberg will be the first ballet dancer to perform on the show. A spokeswoman for the show suggested that viewers might be surprised at Mr. Colbert’s dancing abilities too.

headline: In Reversal, Bachmann’s Struggles Now Include Fund-Raising

headline: Silence From the Court

But the real crime on Wednesday night was the action — or really the lack of action, the absolute radio silence — of the United States Supreme Court, which, as the nation watched and waited, did nothing for 203 minutes past the scheduled execution time. Or at least nothing anyone could see.

headline: Genny Is Back on the Runway
text: For much of the 1970s, for all of the 1980s and for part of the 1990s, Genny was an Italian label you could rely on for structured tailoring that felt like sportswear. Part of its success was because of the special relationship between Gianni Versace, who consulted on the line, and Donatella Girombelli, who ran the manufacturing company that produced Genny and several other labels, like Byblos. Shortly after Prada acquired the label in 2001, it sort of fell off the fashion map, and hasn’t been produced since 2004.

headline: Slavery Museum Files for Bankruptcy
text: The United States National Slavery Museum, an organization founded by the former Virginia governor Douglas L. Wilder to build a museum in Frederickburg, Va., that would discuss that chapter in American history, has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The Richmond Times-Dispatch reported that the museum indicated in its bankruptcy filing that it had $3 million in unsecured debts. Among its unpaid bills is one for more than $215,000 in property taxes owed on the 38-acre parcel where the museum was to have opened several years ago. Since then, the proposed museum’s director has departed, its board has stopped meeting and some people who gave artifacts to the museum have asked for their return.

headline: Filings for Jobless Benefits Fell Last Week, Data Shows
text: Applications for jobless benefits decreased 9,000 in the week ended Sept. 17 to 423,000, Labor Department figures showed Thursday. The average number of claims in the past month rose for a fifth straight week, to the highest level since July 16.

headline: Throwing a Digital-Age Curveball
text: The hungry heart of “Moneyball,” a movie about baseball in the digital age, is a beautiful hard case named Billy Beane. Coiled yet cool, Billy has the liquid physical grace and bright eyes of a predator. He was built to win. Even his name, with its short syllabic bursts, sounds ready for ESPN exultations. That he’s played by Brad Pitt giving the quintessential Brad Pitt performance just seals the deal. It didn’t turn out that way, and in 2001 this high school star turned major-league washout was no longer a player but the general manager of the Oakland Athletics, the little team that could but didn’t.

headline: A Morning After That Turns Into a Dance of Discovery
text: The collapse of sexual taboos has caused some trouble for love, or at least for love stories. That sex often precedes emotional intimacy — or proceeds without it — is a fact of life that movies, with their deep and longstanding investment in romance, especially have a hard time dealing with. Contemporary sexual mores tend to be explored either with grim, punitive realism (as in Steve McQueen’s “Shame,” soon to play at the New York Film Festival) or with cute and careful wishful thinking.

headline: In Whitman, H.P. Gains a Prolific Deal Maker
A High-Minded Pavilion for a Day on the Sand
text: THE grand pavilion at Orchard Beach is worthy of Mussolini or Speer — a vast, spare arcade, dwarfing the human figure. Overlooking Long Island Sound in the Bronx, it also has a humanistic side, as an ennobling public work of democratic ambition. Neither is enough to keep the seaside air from destroying this 1936 bathing complex.

headline: A Skateboard Shop Where Visitors Challenge Gravity
text: A few blocks from the waterfront in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, skateboarders swoop and cluster in front of a warehouse like so many shore birds with their sights on a big fish. Long-haired, debonair and often handsome, these flocks — urban warriors who live by the board — seem oblivious to the cars rushing down North 11th Street, or to anything else, because they’ve landed at home base: KCDC Skateshop, a nucleus of New York’s skateboarding scene.

headline: Not So Ugly Betty
text: For over a decade, the British fitness line Sweaty Betty has been sold almost exclusively on its home turf. This fall, the collection — favored by fit and fabulous stars like Victoria Beckham, Elle Macpherson, Julianne Moore and Amber Valletta — arrives stateside for the first time via quarterly catalogs and its new Web address, sweatybetty.com. The brand’s co-founder, Tamara Hill-Norton, said she had always dreamed of expanding to the United States. “In the U.K., exercising is still often seen as a chore,” says Hill-Norton, who started the company with her husband, Simon, in 1997. “In the U.S., people push the boundaries and look for exciting new ways to keep it fresh.” So now we Yankees can sweat in style with black and white printed pants — “In the Hamptons, everyone seemed to love them” — or a killer kickboxing number (as seen here on the model Flaviana Matata).

headline: Relief and Optimism At the Folk Art Museum
text: When the American Folk Art Museum was considering dissolving altogether and dispersing its art, New York City faced the prospect of losing a 50-year-old cultural institution that houses a major collection of important works by self-trained and outsider artists. So the city’s cultural affairs commissioner, Kate D. Levin, was understandably relieved when the museum’s board voted Wednesday evening to continue as an independent operation. “This is a wonderful outcome,” Ms. Levin said in a telephone interview on Thursday. “It’s great for the institution to be able to keep its mission intact and keep its collection under its own stewardship.” Having been driven by financial straits to default on its construction bonds and sell its building on West 53rd Street, the museum had been considering a transfer of its collections to the Smithsonian along with a possible long-term loan to the Brooklyn Museum. Now, the museum said, it will attempt to move forward in its smaller building in Lincoln Square. The museum was rescued by pledges of donations from its trustees and from the Ford Foundation. The museum would not specify the terms or amounts of these gifts. The museum also announced on Wednesday that a number of institutions are interested in collaborations. “People are increasingly recognizing the value and the excitement of folk art, outsider art,” Ms. Levin said. “Other museum directors are realizing how this could make a meaningful contribution to the kind of shows they want to curate.”

headline: Vetting the Lender
text: BEFORE buying a house, borrowers will undoubtedly do a thorough check of the property, examining its structural soundness and the surrounding neighborhood, among other things; they will research the best type of loan, comparing interest rates, terms and fees. But not all borrowers do due diligence on their lenders.

headline: Responding to the Anniversary of 9/11 With a Call to Erode Cultural Borders
text: It would have been inconceivable to let the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks pass without commentary from the Kronos Quartet, a group that has long insisted that embracing the breadth of the world’s music can be the key to peace and understanding.

headline: Dickens the Man, Foibles and All
text: Devotees know these sketched figures almost as if they were relations: the lean urchin approaching his shocked overseer with an empty bowl, begging for more; the dreamy girl on a wind-swept sea coast, a beached boat for her home; the bald, vested gentleman with an ornate pocket watch, pontificating while waiting for something to turn up. There are dandified Pickwickians, ethnic villains, wide-eyed innocents, all part of an immensely rich exhibition of manuscripts, photographs, letters, illustrations and artifacts that opens on Friday at the Morgan Library & Museum, to honor the 200th anniversary in 2012 of Charles Dickens’s birth.

headline: ‘Invitation to the Voyage’
text: Algus Greenspon

headline: Sterling Ruby and Lucio Fontana
text: Andrea Rosen

headline: Ann Pibal: ‘Drmn’ ’
text: Meulensteen

headline: Haim Steinbach: ‘creature’
text: Tanya Bonakdar Gallery

headline: TimesCast: Slipping Into Poverty
text: The newest figures from the Census Bureau show that poverty grew nationwide last year. New York City was hit especially hard, reported Sam Roberts today’s Times.

headline: The Post-Black Condition
text: Much has been written on the benefits that accrued to the generation of African-Americans reaping the rewards of the civil rights revolution. But we have heard surprisingly little from those in the post-civil-rights age about what these benefits have meant to them, and especially how they view themselves as black people in an America now led by a black president. In his new book, Touré’s aim is to provide an account of this “post-black” condition, one that emerged only in the 1980s but by the ’90s had become the “new black.”

headline: After a Life Shakeup, Physician, Reveal Thy True Self
text: Is there a displaced doctor in the house? Yes; more than one, actually.

headline: One Town, but Two Markets
text: OVER the last six months or so, it seems several New Jersey towns have developed symptoms of split personality — at least when it comes to their real estate markets.

headline: Good Works With a Bad Attitude
text: There are some real people and some true stories that seem to have been dreamed up by committees of eager Hollywood screenwriters. Sam Childers is one such case. A former drug dealer and a member of a Pennsylvania motorcycle gang, Mr. Childers underwent a religious conversion and has, since the late 1990s, devoted himself to helping orphans in war-torn East Africa. His approach to humanitarianism is unorthodox, to say the least. Rather than stay out of the fight, he has sometimes embroiled himself in combat, particularly against the Lord’s Resistance Army, a militia led by Joseph Kony that has long terrorized parts of northern Uganda and southern Sudan.

headline: Exploration of Stillness and a Lightsaber Battle
text: Stillness is a rare commodity in New York, with its eight million residents and the commuters and visitors who move through the city every day. The Guggenheim is striving to achieve it in “stillspotting nyc,” a two-year exhibition by architects, composers and other artists that explores sound in the urban environment.

headline: Italy’s Troubling Earthquake Prosecutions
text: 11:09 p.m. | Updated below |You may be aware of the effort under way in Italy to convict six scientists and a public official for manslaughter for statements they made about the improbability of a big earthquake as low-level tremors unnerved citizens in the Abruzzo region of central Italy in late March 2009. On April 6, the medieval town of L’Aquila was devastated by a 6.3-magnitude earthquake.

headline: A Wing Where Contemporary Art Can Converse
text: Last weekend, the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, celebrated the opening of its new Linde Family Wing for Contemporary Art, which would seem to represent a major commitment to collecting and exhibiting the art of our time. It should be noted, however, that the new wing is not actually new. It is the old, I. M. Pei-designed wing from 1981, formerly used for rotating exhibitions, now refurbished, repurposed and renamed. And while a lot more contemporary art is now on view, you don’t get the feeling that the old, small-city provincialism has been replaced by a new, fiercely ambitious cosmopolitanism.

headline: Google Wallet
text: David Pogue offers a parody look at how Google Wallet intends to replace the credit cards in our actual wallets. (Don’t cut up your plastic quite yet.)

headline: Ingenuity Is a Thing With Feathers
text: Hats. Most of us have had a few. Some have been loyal standbys, providing a modicum of style while shielding us from the elements. A few have consistently, perhaps inexplicably, buoyed our spirits and sense of savoir-faire. Still others have been, well, humbling. The outcome of misguided infatuations in stores or at street vendors, hats tend to fester in the upper reaches of our closets. My most memorable hat failure was a molded white linen number of rather Amish severity by Comme des Garçons, long since deaccessioned. I’m proud to have been its owner, actually, even though I think I wore it exactly once, in Europe, to and from which it traveled in its own hatbox.

headline: A World of Influences, but Still Self-Possessed
text: The first newish song in Beirut’s show at Terminal 5 on Wednesday night was “Vagabond,” a perky testimonial about finding oneself alone and unmoored, despite what sound like some diligent precautions. Against a backdrop of accordion, electric bass, trumpet and drums, Zach Condon sang the first verse in a steady voice, applying vibrato to the very end of each line:

headline: Coffee, Tea or Nostalgia?
text: Younger siblings know how hard it is to live up to a gifted firstborn.

headline: Obama Takes Jobs Fight to His Adversaries’ Turf
text: CINCINNATI — President Obama was back on the road on Thursday to sell his jobs plan — at an aging and overtaxed bridge connecting the home states of his chief Republican antagonists in Congress, Speaker John A. Boehner of Ohio and Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Senate minority leader.

headline: A Sound Reverberating Far Beyond Seattle
text: There’s a lot of terrific music in “Pearl Jam Twenty,” Cameron Crowe’s documentary about the Seattle band Pearl Jam, honoring its two-decade career. And excellent concert footage. But before viewers learn this venerable ensemble’s story, much less see its members rock out on screen, they are subjected to Mr. Crowe’s voice-over account of his own early discovery of the Seattle scene.

headline: On Our Radar: Solar Venture Misses Loan Deadline
text: The manufacturer First Solar says it will not be able to meet a Sept. 30 deadline to receive a federal loan guarantee for a solar power plant it is building in California. [Reuters]

headline: Does That New Honda Announcer Sound Familiar?
text: American Honda Motor is changing the announcer in its commercials again, hiring the actor Jason Bateman to be the voice of its national brand advertising.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Prada
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#110", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

headline: Common Application to Get Electronic Facelift
text: 9:11 p.m. | Updated This post has been updated to reflect comments this evening from Rob Killion, executive director of the Common Application Inc.

headline: Perry Calls Prayer Vital to His Life
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Gov. Rick Perry of Texas appeared in front of religious conservatives here before the Republican presidential debate, telling the crowd of hundreds that prayer had helped him succeed in life and politics.

headline: Director Hates Stupidity, Hypocrisy and Critics
text: Apparently fed up with the traditional system of film distribution — and in particular with the critics who insist, out of spite or inertia, on reviewing whatever opens in theaters — Kevin Smith is taking his new movie, “Red State,” directly to its audience. The film, which was shown at the Sundance Film Festival last January, has been available for home viewing since Sept. 1, via cable television, iTunes and other platforms. For those who insist on seeing it the old-fashioned way, on a big screen from an upholstered seat with a cup holder attached to the arm, there will be screenings in select cities on Sunday night, with Mr. Smith making an appearance to do what he does best, which is rant, tell stories and shoot the breeze with his fans.

headline: African Chronicles
text: Images from “Heroic Africans: Legendary Leaders, Iconic Sculptures” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: In Praise of the Teenage Brain
text: The developing teenage brain – “stupid, irrational and reckless” – is best suited to select a college, so suggested Jonah Lehrer, a neuroscience writer and an author of “How We Decide,” in his keynote speech Thursday kicking off the 67th annual convention of the National Association for College Admission Counseling, or Nacac, in New Orleans.

headline: Joe Nocera On the Economy
text: The Op-Ed columnist Joe Nocera compares Washington’s current handling of the economy to conditions in 1931, when the country was struggling during the Great Depression.

headline: Finding a New Tail for Winter
text: “Dolphin Tale,” the story of a maimed dolphin named Winter and the people who rescue her, is pitched awfully young, without a shred of the satire or subtlety that is generally found in films aimed at tweeners and above. That’s not a bad thing; it just means accompanying grown-ups or older siblings will have to choke down a sizable dose of schmaltz with their fish milkshakes.

headline: Starchitects on Parade
text: Gehry and Ando and Nouvel, oh my! How a sleepy vineyard in Provence landed the biggest names in architecture.

headline: Could Have, Should Have: What Composers Wished They’d Written
text: In 1995 the Library of Congress asked Stephen Sondheim to draw up a list of songs he wished he had written, some of which were performed at a concert in honor of his 70th birthday. This weekend a passel of would-be Sondheims (and Larsons, and Porters) will unveil their work as part of the New York Musical Theater Festival, which runs through Oct. 16. In the spirit of the Sondheim list (published in The New York Times in 2000), we asked composers in this year’s festival: What song do you wish you had written? Which song in your show expresses your voice? And why? Many of their responses follow. Information about the festival is at www.nymf.org.

headline: Turning a Blighted Area in Central Suffolk Into a Hub
text: Ronkonkoma

headline: Rise and Fall of a Nightclub Impresario
text: As druggy as the club scene it depicts, “Limelight” shapes the career of Peter Gatien, the Canadian entrepreneur who ruled New York City nightlife in the 1980s, into a ball of confusion and hyperbole.

headline: Good Riddance, Irene
text: IN mid-August, a moving company delivered Jason and Kristis Cartozian’s belongings to the three-bedroom Tudor they had just bought in Port Chester. It had passed all building code inspections with flying colors. Among other things, inspectors deemed the house, the couple’s first, watertight and fit to withstand a strong storm.

headline: Problems? Talk to the Parrot
text: A man with little to say falls for a woman who says too much in “A Bird of the Air,” an offbeat romance fueled by pets and pithy aphorisms.

headline: No News Is Bad News in N.B.A. Labor Talks
text: The time to broker an N.B.A. labor deal without harming the preseason had most likely already passed by the time negotiators gathered Thursday morning in Manhattan. When they parted ways in the afternoon, a deal still out of reach, it guaranteed that training camps and exhibition games would be canceled for the second time in league history.

headline: Bloomberg Defends Livery Cab Proposal
text: With Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo expressing doubt about legislation allowing street hails of livery cabs in much of New York City, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg vociferously defended the measure on Thursday as crucial to the city’s economic well-being.

headline: Goldman Names New Head of Europe and Asia Pacific Mergers
text: Goldman Sachs has named Gregg Lemkau, a longtime deal maker, as its head of mergers and acquisitions for Europe, the Middle East, Africa and Asia Pacific countries, the firm announced in an internal memorandum obtained by DealBook on Thursday.

headline: Washington, D.C., 4:43 P.M.
text: Representative Charles B. Rangel, the Harlem Democrat, at the unveiling of his portrait in the hearing room of the House Ways and Means Committee, which he led until 2010.

headline: Kidnap Victim Sues U.S. Over Abductor’s Parole
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The kidnap victim Jaycee Dugard filed a complaint for damages against the federal government on Thursday, charging that its parole agents did not adequately monitor Phillip Garrido, a convicted sex offender who was on federal parole when he abducted Ms. Dugard in 1991.

headline: In Early Stages of Marathon, Burress Is Still Finding His Way
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Plaxico Burress spent two hours each day he served in prison running 300-yard sprints and catching passes from inmates who regarded themselves as some of the N.F.L.’s legendary quarterbacks.

headline: Rays Roll Over Yankees’ Reserves
text: 11:10 p.m. | Updated  The names of five Yankees regulars were missing when the lineup for Thursday night’s game against Tampa Bay was posted on the clubhouse door at 5 p.m. The starters who played in a dreary 15-8 loss to the Rays did poorly and were out of the game in a hurry.

headline: Warner’s (Real) Big Tent on Deficit Reduction
text: Senator Mark R. Warner, a first-term Democrat from Virginia, just will not give up on the idea of a grand deficit-reduction bargain between the two parties. He is even providing the table.

headline: In a Hungarian Town, Faces of the Diaspora
text: Documentaries have become so involving, entertaining and provocative that we almost forget the genre’s root purpose: to document. Leave a record. Preserve the facts.

headline: Special Ops Agent, Lured Back From Retirement
text: Don’t let the title fool you. “Killer Elite” has next to nothing to do with the 1975 film “The Killer Elite,” which had both an extra word in its title and an openly dissatisfied Sam Peckinpah (“We have no script”) in the director’s chair. The old thriller was based on the novel “Monkey in the Middle”; the new one originated with “The Feather Men,” a British book that was sold as nonfiction but may not have been. The earlier film starred James Caan and Robert Duvall as professional killers; the new one has Jason Statham and Robert De Niro as elite mercenaries. Peckinpah tried to turn his into a mockery of itself, while the new flick’s director, Gary McKendry, has stumbled into accidental near-parody.

headline: Breaking Barriers to Ride the Waves
text: Ted Woods’s documentary “White Wash” wants you to know that white guys aren’t the only ones who surf. Mr. Woods’s movie — part history lesson, part sports film, part polemical essay — has a complicated story to tell, about black surfers and, more broadly, about African-American history and the history of surfing.

headline: Q & A
text: No Co-op Fee for the Kitty

headline: Stephen Mueller, Color Field Painter, Dies at 63
text: Stephen Mueller, a New York painter who expanded and refined the vocabulary of 1960s Color Field painting into deliriously buoyant mystical-comic works, died on Sept. 16 in Manhattan. He was 63.

headline: In Europe, a Chorus of Outrage Over a U.S. Execution
text: PARIS — Even in a region long disdainful of American attitudes toward the death penalty, public officials, editorial writers and activists across Western Europe reacted with fury on Thursday to news that Troy Davis was executed in Georgia on Wednesday night.

headline: A Mideast Moment at the United Nations
text: To the Editor:

headline: Filmmaker’s Explorations of Sex and Jealousy
text: Somebody must think Joe Swanberg’s mumblecore mush is worth the time it takes to watch it, because he keeps making it. But anyone who sees his insufferable “Art History” and doesn’t wish for the 74 minutes back has an empty life indeed.

headline: ‘Follies’ Will Be Still Here For Three Weeks Longer
text: The critically acclaimed Broadway revival of “Follies” will extend its limited engagement by three weeks, through Jan. 22, 2012, the show’s producers plan to announce on Friday. The slightly longer run will give the musical a better chance of turning a profit — a benchmark of success that has long eluded the show, beloved by many musical theater fans for its score by Stephen Sondheim.

headline: Dealing a Blow to the Cardinals, the Mets Storm Back Late to Prevail
text: ST. LOUIS — Terry Collins, a postgame outburst or two aside, has been an unconditional champion of his players this season. They made him proud, persevering through major trades and cosmically unfortunate injuries.

headline: Fake-Injury Issue Puts Giants on the Defensive
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The practice of faking injuries is not a recent phenomenon in the N.F.L. Defenders have long flopped on defense in order to slow the game or disrupt offensive momentum. If coordinated correctly — and rarely is it not — the ploy can be effective. It is, however, supposed to go unnoticed. But when scrutiny is focused on the tactic, a question arises: is the strategy good old-fashioned gamesmanship or does it go beyond the bounds of fair play?

headline: Son Takes His Famous Father Out of the Shadows
text: Carl Colby’s smart, fact-packed film “The Man Nobody Knew” operates on many levels, all riveting. Primarily an account of the career of his father, William Colby, director of the Central Intelligence Agency from 1973 to 1976, it traces a history ending in 1996, when his body washed ashore eight days after he embarked on a late-afternoon solo canoe outing in Maryland. While reviewing the turbulent period spanning Vietnam and President Richard M. Nixon’s resignation, we also witness the arc of a marriage, the death of a daughter and the seeming disillusionment of a selfless, if steely-eyed and implacable, civil servant.

headline: Trekking Mountains to Get to School
text: More bittersweet story than compelling documentary, “Journey From Zanskar” follows a Tibetan monk, Geshe Yonten, whose vow to help liberate beings from suffering starts at home, in Zanskar. High in the mountains in the northwest corner of India (in the troubled state of Jammu and Kashmir), Zanskar is a small island of Tibetan Buddhism (population less than 14,000) surrounded by a sea of Hinduism and Islam.

headline: Questioning the Morality of the Death Penalty
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tiny Neutrinos May Have Broken Cosmic Speed Limit
text: Roll over, Einstein?

headline: Solheim Cup Generation Gap
text: Juli Inkster, the nine-time Solheim Cup veteran, is older than the parents of her rookie teammate Ryann O’Toole. Still, the golfers have a lot in common, as is made plain in the feature I wrote on them.

headline: Adoptions From China: Seeking the Truth
text: To the Editor:

headline: The latest Republican debate and moves by the Federal Reserve that caused the stock markets to plunge.
text: The latest Republican debate and moves by the Federal Reserve that caused the stock markets to plunge. Chief correspondent for The Caucus at NYTimes.com Michael Shear, chief financial correspondent Floyd Norris, and Deputy Political Editor Gerald Mullany join Sam Roberts in New York.

headline: Idiocy and Advocacy
text: The medical community was outraged after the Republican presidential candidate Michele Bachmann called a vaccine to prevent cervical cancer “dangerous,” and then passed on a know-nothingism from a stranger who said it could lead to “mental retardation.”

headline: From a School Band, Soul and Funk, and Heart
text: You may never have heard of the Kashmere Stage Band, but by the end of “Thunder Soul” you will wonder why. A big-hearted, back-in-the-day tribute — and a stand-alone argument for public-school music programs — Mark Landsman’s bittersweet documentary has designs on your feet, heart and mind.

headline: Low Testosterone Levels
text: To the Editor:

headline: Flawed Lawyer, Fighting the Good Fight
text: Movies with agendas can be tough to pull off, and “Puncture” is no exception. Notable at least in part for its fumbled potential, this health-care-industry melodrama possesses all the right ingredients: an idealistic young lawyer, a corrupt corporate villain and a sympathetic victim. It just fails to assemble them into a compelling whole.

headline: Republican Candidates Debate in Florida
text: Nine candidates in the presidential race gather for a debate in Orlando, Fla.

headline: No Right to Anonymity
text: To the Editor:

headline: Suit Throws Open Window Into Mets Owners’ Holdings and History
text: Over the 30 years that Fred Wilpon and Saul Katz have owned part or all of the Mets, their other business interests had remained largely out of view. Even as Wilpon’s profile in baseball grew, he and Katz were rarely referred to as anything more than real estate moguls who gave generously to charities.

headline: Partner Says Inquiries Into Madoff Stirred Relief
text: Arthur Friedman oversaw the hundreds of accounts the owners of the Mets opened with Bernard L. Madoff during their decades of investing. He distributed annual statements, handled deposits and on occasion even tried to replicate Madoff’s strikingly consistent returns.

headline: A Spiritual Quest
text: With a title like “In Search of God” you can bet that this documentary, directed and conceived by Rupam Sarmah, isn’t afraid to ask the big questions: What is the purpose of life? What happens after death? And, of course, where do you find God?

headline: Port Authority Not Liable in Bombing, Court Rules
text: In a sharply divided decision, New York’s highest court ruled on Thursday that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey was not liable for damages in the 1993 terrorist bombing of the World Trade Center, which killed six people and injured about 1,000 others.

headline: The Washington Report with David Sanger and Kerry Nolan
text: The Washington Report with David Sanger and Kerry Nolan

headline: Lost Baby Orca’s Rich Social Life
text: There is a gossamer lyricism to “The Whale,” a documentary about an orca that became separated from its pod and adopted the residents of Nootka Sound in British Columbia as much as they did him. Like humans, orcas are highly social creatures, and Luna, as he was called, was the life of the party. The nuance of his gestures were wondrous to behold: playful, exuberantly extending the fin of friendship, he even helped timber workers in the area, pushing logs through the water with his nose.

headline: Mark Varian
text: Mr. Varian, 62, is the president of John Gallin & Son, a family-owned construction company that specializes in commercial building interiors for both landlords and tenants. Its client list has included major developers like the Durst Organization and the Rudin Management Company, as well as corporations like Disney and NBC Universal.

headline: Europe Denies 2 Nations Entry to Travel Zone
text: BRUSSELS — Preoccupied with fears of increased migration from the south, the European Union told its two newest members, Romania and Bulgaria, on Thursday that they would have to wait to join the bloc’s passport-free travel zone.

headline: Fall
text: A film by Shirin Neshat, an artist, addresses the famine in Somalia. It is one in a series of films that marks the changing seasons.

headline: Personality for Him; Practicality for Her
text: FOR most of his six years in New York, Paul Pinizzotto leased a three-bedroom duplex in a squat, no-frills building in Red Hook, Brooklyn. The rent ended up at $2,250 a month. Over the years, he rented out the extra bedrooms to a series of roommates.

headline: September Swoon Torments Red Sox
text: With a loss Wednesday night at home to the last-place Orioles (the third in four games), the Red Sox fell to 5-16 in September. On Sept. 1, they started the day with a division lead of one and a half games and a wild-card lead of seven and a half games. Given their lead of two games over the Tampa Bay Rays, the Red Sox appear capable of making the postseason, but only while stuck in reverse.

headline: Rape Case Is a Rarity in Chinese Justice System
text: BEIJING — One morning in May, government officials assembled the 700 students of Ashi township’s middle school, in the southeastern Chinese province of Guizhou, for a lesson on the importance of abiding by the law. Rule No. 1, they said, was simple: If you break the law, you will be punished.

headline: Bullying as True Drama
text: THE suicide of Jamey Rodemeyer, the 14-year-old boy from western New York who killed himself last Sunday after being tormented by his classmates for being gay, is appalling. His story is a classic case of bullying: he was aggressively and repeatedly victimized. Horrific episodes like this have sparked conversations about cyberbullying and created immense pressure on regulators and educators to do something, anything, to make it stop. Yet in the rush to find a solution, adults are failing to recognize how their conversations about bullying are often misaligned with youth narratives. Adults need to start paying attention to the language of youth if they want antibullying interventions to succeed.

headline: A Couple Meet in a Bar. Where Could This Lead?
text: There’s only a shred of plot in “Noah and the Tower Flower,” but there’s plenty of energy to spare. More often than not, that’s enough to carry this bittersweet, 75-minute play.

headline: Freedom Through Bondage
text: In the spring of 1861, two men appeared before the St. Louis County clerk to sign a document. One of the men, as described in detail in the document’s margins, was a “barber and boathand,” 37 years old and 5 feet 7-and-a-half inches tall. Other such documents described signees as “light,” “dark,” “copper,” “high yellow,” “bright” — and even though it did not say so here, everyone knew the man who signed his name in a wide script, Moses Dickson, was a free African American.

headline: Cunningham’s Legacy Lives On in Classes
text: Merce Cunningham’s artistic heirs plan to offer classes in his technique after his dance company ceases operations at the end of the year, company officials said on Thursday. The Merce Cunningham Trust said Robert Swinston, the company’s director of choreography, would teach classes starting in April at City Center, where the trust will take up offices. Jean Freebury, a former company member, will also teach Cunningham technique at the Mark Morris Dance Center starting in December, and a course will be offered at Dance New Amsterdam. Cunningham died in 2009, several months after a plan had been put in place to phase out the company. The trust is assuming oversight of Cunningham’s work and is taking over for the Merce Cunningham Dance Foundation, which will close next year. Plans for teaching Cunningham’s technique had been unclear until now. The foundation’s executive director, Trevor Carlson, was also appointed as the fifth trustee, the trust said.

headline: Feeling at Home in Atlanta, P.G.A. Champion Is Back in Lead
text: ATLANTA — As Keegan Bradley flew into his favorite new town this week and rode on its congested highways, fond memories came flooding back.

headline: The Amateur Ideal
text: The 1910s and 1920s were the golden age of the amateur ideal. On the golf courses, Bobby Jones, the greatest amateur golfer of all time, won a string of major championships.

headline: Haiti Leader Is Opposed to Reduction of U.N. Force
text: A plan to cut the number of United Nations peacekeepers in Haiti drew a rebuke on Thursday from its president, Michel Martelly, who said in an interview that he “would not even think of reducing” the force because the country remained unstable and the national police were not ready to take over.

headline: Recalling a Cruel Father, and Defending the Woman Who Killed Him
text: The question was not quite a taunt, but kind of an eyebrow hoisted noisily, theatrically and tactically in a Queens courtroom.

headline: Panic Over Bedbugs Can Create More Health Risks Than Their Bites
text: As bedbugs have made a comeback, aided by resistance to pesticides and spread by worldwide travel, scientists have found that panic over the blood-sucking pests may be more dangerous than their bite. Some people are misusing poisonous chemicals in a desperate bid to eradicate the pests, federal officials said Thursday.

headline: New Condos: ‘Survivor’ Edition

It’s not easy; there are bound to be constructors whose styles I am more in sync with than others. Still, we make every effort to be fair and balanced here, don’t we?

headline: Week 3 N.F.L. Matchups
text: Packers (2-0) at Bears (1-1)Sunday, 4:15 p.m.Line: Packers 3.Jay Cutler is a 50-Tesla, super-cooled, solenoid-style electromagnet for criticism. He can attract scorn from hundreds of miles away. Everything about Cutler’s career is polarizing: the gaudy statistics that contrast his 35-35 win-loss record; his penchant for turnovers; his snippy, irritable public demeanor; and his career-long association with mercurial offensive masterminds like Mike Shanahan, Josh McDaniels and Mike Martz, who only magnify his peculiar attraction-repulsion effect.Last season’s N.F.C. championship game became Ferris Cutler’s Day Off, with the (somewhat) injured quarterback looking less willing than able on the sideline as his backups got battered by the Packers. It was the type of nonperformance that defines a career, fairly or not, and a win Sunday could deflect a tiny bit of criticism. Unfortunately, Cutler’s Bears are 1-4 against the Packers in the past two seasons, and their offensive line is still bad enough to make even the toughest quarterback consider using a sick day. Pick: Packers

headline: Within Him, Without Him
text: TO the fans who thought they knew him George Harrison was both omnipresent and enigmatic. Of the four members of the world’s most famous band, the Beatles, Harrison made the least effort at being a public figure, and though he shared himself in recordings as disparate as the catchy pop of “Taxman,” the desolate strains of “While My Guitar Gently Weeps” and an album of spiritual chants and music that he produced for the Radha Krishna Temple, he could be inscrutable and distant behind it all. Even as he sang “Got My Mind Set on You,” his consciousness seemed to be focused somewhere else entirely.

headline: Speaking for the Quiet Beatle: Olivia Harrison Discusses the George Harrison Film
text: The four men who made up the Beatles are, to the vast majority of us, larger-than-life figures who made a tremendous and lasting impact on music, film and fashion and in numerous other arenas of popular culture. But to a select few, they are just – or are also – people: friends, siblings, parents, husbands. Among the members of that exclusive club is Olivia Harrison, who married George Harrison in 1978 and remained with him until his death in 2001. Ms. Harrison, who is the mother of Harrison’s son, Dhani, does not consider herself a celebrity and does not fully embrace the spotlight, but she has become a guardian of her husband’s legacy and of the mementos and artifacts he left behind at Friar Park, their sizable estate in Henley-on-Thames, England.

headline: Origins of the Euro Crisis

headline: Giving: The Magic Bus Auction in Mumbai
text: Charitable giving in India surpasses Brazil and China, but pales in comparison to most Western countries, a fact that has prompted criticism and prodding by other philanthropists, particularly given the vast disparity in wealth here. The question “Are rich Indians turning their back on the poor?,” is asked often, even here in our own comment section. Talk to charity organizers, executives starting NGOs, doctors who do hours of volunteer work or hundreds of others, though, and a very different picture emerges.

headline: Flight or Fight
text: My husband and son took a New York-to-Milwaukee flight that was supposed to leave Friday at 11:29 a.m. The flight boarded after 4 and didn’t leave the gate until 4:40, and a half-hour later the pilot announced it would be another hour until takeoff. At that point a devout Jewish family, worried about violating the Sabbath, asked to get off. Going back to the gate cost the plane its place in line for takeoff, and the flight was eventually canceled. Was the airline right to grant that request? M. W.,NORWALK, CONN.

headline: ‘Did I Know You at Camp?’
text: Toshi Ito, 86 years old but still bright-eyed and striking, contemplated a life-size photograph of herself that hung on the museum’s wall. She was 18 at the time it was taken. “I’m wearing my red boots,” she pointed out.

headline: A Serious Case of Hiccups
text: THE PATIENT'S STORY A 46-year-old man came to the Metropolitan Hospital on Manhattan’s Upper East Side early one afternoon. He had a case of the hiccups that wouldn’t go away. The problem started two days earlier. In the midst of what seemed a perfectly ordinary day, he started to hiccup and wasn’t able to stop. He tried all the usual treatments. He held his breath. He drank glass after glass of cold water. He thought scary thoughts. But no matter what he did, every 20 to 30 seconds, his chest would jump, and then his throat would close, cutting short the involuntary intake of air. After two days of nonstop hiccupping, he went to the hospital.

headline: The Soap Opera Is Dead! Long Live the Soap Opera!
text: The soap opera, one of the nation’s most under–appreciated art forms, is in serious trouble. On Sept. 23, “All My Children” concludes its 41-year run, and with it, unthinkably, will disappear the genre’s most celebrated siren, Susan Lucci’s Erica Kane Martin Brent Cudahy Chandler Montgomery Montgomery Marrick Marrick Marrick Montgomery.

headline: The Fogies of ‘South Park’
text: You guys have long taken pride in being iconoclasts. But last night I watched elderly people literally dance out of the theater after “The Book of Mormon.” Is it upsetting to be the toast of Broadway? Matt Stone (sitting): We’re solidly middle-aged ex-iconoclasts. And it’s not like kids have great taste.

headline: The Iron Lady as Anti-Muse
text: In the endlessly popular musical “Billy Elliot,” the villain is played not by an actor but by a larger-than-life puppet with a gigantic head, an effigy of the kind that sometimes still appears at European protest rallies. This one has a beaked nose, a pronounced overbite and upswept blond hair, a visage immediately familiar to anyone who remembers the 1980s, and one that theatergoers — paying $100 a ticket for a dose of solidarity with the beleaguered British proletariat in the age of late capitalism — are eager to boo. “Who was that lady?” one of my children asked as we departed a recent matinee performance, not having recognized the Iron Lady.

headline: The Closer
text: When a lender forecloses on a property, one of the first things he does is send somebody out to see if there is a house still standing and whether there’s anybody living there. That’s my job. Sometimes the houses are crack dens or meth labs, sometimes the sites of cock- or dog-fighting operations, sometimes the backyard is filled with pot. And sometimes the house is a waterfront mansion in a gated golf community worth well over seven figures. Variety is the rule.

headline: A Long Day at ‘The Office’ With Mindy Kaling

headline: Model-Morphosis | Bette Franke at D&G

headline: Dancing on the Edge
text: On a balmy night this April, when young people in Egypt, Syria, Yemen and Bahrain swarmed the streets to protest repressive regimes, Beirut’s 20-somethings were partying on the rooftop of a new American-style restaurant. It was opening night for this latest branch of the country’s popular Crepaway restaurants, and because it sits right on the city’s former Green Line — the no man’s land that separated the Christian East from the Muslim West during Lebanon’s 15-year civil war, which ended in 1990 — there were slickly designed posters depicting army tanks with the words the art of peace on every wall.

headline: Friday Reading: Report Assails Single-Sex Education
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Fill-In | Extreme Fitness
text: Fill in the blanks in the opening paragraphs of “The Cult of Physicality.” Use your own words and phrases, or choose from a scrambled list of the words or phrases that were removed.

headline: Amid Statehood Bid, Tensions Simmer in West Bank
text: QUSRA, West Bank — In this Palestinian village where a mosque was defaced and cars were burned, young men now patrol nightly against settler intruders. Nearby, Jewish settlers worry that Palestinian militants buoyed by international support of their statehood will step up attacks. Settler rapid response teams are practicing with M-16s; women are learning to shoot handguns.

headline: Amid Warning Signs, Hints That Europeans May Step Up Action
text: WASHINGTON — Rising alarm that Europe is not addressing its economic problems with sufficient speed or force pervaded and soured the annual gatherings here on Friday of economists and policy makers from around the world.

headline: ‘Parent Trigger’ Law to Reform Schools Faces Challenges
text: COMPTON, Calif. — The promise sounded alluring and simple: if enough parents signed a petition, their children’s struggling school would be shut down and replaced with a charter school.

headline: My Unfinished 9/11 Business
text: Bill Keller’s belated conclusion that the Iraq war has been a “monumental blunder” is welcome to this reader, who marched with hundreds of thousands to protest the impending attack. As the old saying goes, it takes a big man to apologize, and the recent denials of reality and culpability from Dick Cheney, John Yoo and others show that some are not so open to evidence — or ethics. But given the many tragic consequences in terms of lives lost, our economy derailed, our reputation besmirched and more, even Keller’s candidness elicits a long sigh and the resigned sentiment “better late than never — I guess.”

headline: The Buildup
text: On the day of the earthquake, I was in Lower Manhattan, at St. Paul’s Church, looking out at One World Trade Center. I had ferried up from New Jersey on this spectacularly clear day to take a Patriot’s Walking Tour of Lower Manhattan, and, like Sam Anderson, I was immersed in comparisons and contrasts of the present to the past, a living history packed into a square mile of real estate. The tour covered 26 years, including Washington’s installation as the first president. The big theme was that a relatively small number of people in this intensely important area made a crucial difference, not just to the city but to the world. The current architecture is designed to be tall. I believe it is also designed to be optimistic and a continuum of change in typical American style.

headline: U.S. Pushes Europe to Act With Force on Debt Crisis
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration, increasingly alarmed by the spillover effects of Europe’s financial crisis, has begun an intensive lobbying campaign to persuade Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and other leaders to ramp up efforts to stem any contagion from the debt crisis in Greece.

headline: Debate Reinforces Republican Concerns About Perry
text: Prepare yourself for at least one news cycle filled with questions about whether Gov. Rick Perry of Texas has lost his status as the Republican presidential front-runner.

headline: Romney Leads Endorsement Race
text: In their book, “The Party Decides: Presidential Nominations Before and After Reform,” the political scientists Marty Cohen, David Karol, Hans Noel and John Zaller find that endorsements — not polls, fund-raising numbers or media hits — are the best early indicators of success in the presidential primaries.

headline: Making the Case for Detroit’s Future
text: It’s far too early to say Detroit is on the way back; its property values are still falling and its debt is still rated as speculative. But as he approaches the midpoint of a four-year term, Mayor Dave Bing is pointing to signs that the city’s breathtaking decline may have bottomed out.

headline: Under One Roof
text: One afternoon with the 12 members of the Lee family — the grandfather, his children, their spouses and their children — in their shared Chinatown building.

headline: Life in the Lee Family
text: Scenes from the Lee family’s household, where three generations live together in one building in Chinatown, an arrangement both retro and revolutionary.

headline: Three Generations Under One Roof
text: SEVEN o’clock on a Thursday morning: time for bao, Chinese breakfast buns. Dressed for school in striped leggings and a pink shirt, Mebrat Yong, 9, waited for the baby sitter to arrive at her family’s building in Chinatown with a red shopping bag filled with the steaming treats from her uncle’s bakery a few blocks away. Mebrat was dividing up this day’s buns.

headline: Taking Sides on Syracuse’s Big East Exit
text: John Wallace and Pearl Washington, the former Syracuse basketball stars, are on opposite sides regarding their alma mater’s decision to leave the Big East for the Atlantic Coast Conference in the midst of major realignment.

headline: Ashley Fiolek | Dirt Devil
text: The dirt-bike racer Ashley Fiolek, 20, is the first woman in motocross to be signed to a major corporate team, the youngest to win the American women’s motocross championship and the only woman to twice take home the gold in motocross at the X Games. And in a sport in which sound is essential, she has done all of this without the ability to hear. “I have been told that most people use sound to know when to shift,” says Fiolek, who has been deaf since birth. “I feel when my motorcycle needs to shift. The engine’s vibrations change and I know it’s time.” At 5-foot-2 and 110 pounds, Fiolek might be Honda-Red Bull’s most petite team member, but her next goal is decidedly large: to be the first woman to compete in a men’s race. “My fans really want to see me qualify,” she says.

headline: Bill Keller on Religion
text: In a recent article, The New York Times Magazine implied that Pastor John Hagee has a favorite candidate in the 2012 presidential election. Like most Americans, Hagee has not yet decided whom he will support. Contrary towhat is written, Hagee has never referred to Catholicism as a ‘‘godless theology of hate.’’ When he used those words, Hagee was referring to general Christian anti- Semitism, not to any particular denomination.Further, the coverage asserts that Hagee has a poor relationship with the Catholic community. This is also untrue. Bill Donohue, the president of the Catholic League, very recently put out a press release entitled ‘‘Pastor John Hagee Deserves Better Than False Accusations,’’ in which he directly refutes such assertions.The article also grossly oversimpli!es a sermon Hagee gave concerning the Holocaust and the rise of modern Israel. While some took offense to the sermon, the coverage fails to mention that in Hagee’s subsequent reconciliation with the Anti-Defamation League, its national director, Abe Foxman, thanked Hagee, the founder of the largest pro-Israel group in America, for having ‘‘devoted [his] life to combating anti-Semitism and supporting the State of Israel.’’

They wanted to see Angelos Bratis and Stella Jean, and nearly a dozen designers whose names are largely unrecognizable.

headline: Palestinians Request U.N. Status; Powers Press for Talks
text: UNITED NATIONS — President Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian leader, formally requested full United Nations membership for his as yet undefined country on Friday. But before the thunderous applause greeting his announcement in the General Assembly had faded, international powers laid out a new plan to resume direct Israeli-Palestinian peace talks that was designed to delay a contentious vote on the Palestinian request as long as possible.

text: “EXCUSE me,” the Russian soprano Anna Netrebko declared at a recent dress rehearsal of Donizetti’s “Anna Bolena,” the operatic melodrama about Henry VIII’s unlucky second wife, which will open the Metropolitan Opera’s 128th season on Monday evening. She walked to the edge of the stage and peered into the dark, near-empty auditorium.

headline: Sant’Angelo Raises Arizona
text: For nearly three decades beginning in the 1960s, the designer Giorgio Sant’Angelo held fashion insiders in his sway. Among these was the editor Diana Vreeland, who famously urged Sant’Angelo, an architect and industrial designer by training, to make accessories and clothes. “She sent me to Arizona,” Sant’Angelo once said, ”with Veruschka, the model, four suitcases full of fabrics, wires and tape and told me to wrap and tie everything as I wanted and then she gave me eight pages in the magazine.” That editorial, set in the Painted Desert, photographed by Franco Rubartelli, and published in Vogue in 1968, forged Sant’Angelo’s career. Now, 22 years after his death, Sant’Angelo’s creative force returns to Arizona in the form of a retrospective — the designer’s first — at the Phoenix Art Museum.

headline: Tea Party Group to Form Super PAC
text: The Tea Party-linked conservative group FreedomWorks will create a Super PAC with the goal of raising $20 million during the 2012 election cycle, exploiting shifts in campaign law that permit independent groups to collect and spend unlimited amounts of money advocating for and against candidates.

headline: Stars Add New Tunes to Country King’s Lyrics
text: BOB DYLAN has long claimed Hank Williams as an influence and an inspiration. In his 2004 memoir, “Chronicles Volume One,” Mr. Dylan recounted his discovery of that country giant’s music in the 1950s. “I became aware that in Hank’s recorded songs were the archetype rules of poetic songwriting,” he wrote. “The architectural forms are like marble pillars.”

headline: The N.B.A. Cancels 43 Preseason Games
text: Forty-three exhibition games were wiped from the N.B.A. calendar Friday, the first significant fallout from a labor crisis that could soon threaten the regular season.

headline: It Started With a Book
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Etiquette of Autographs
text: A nice side effect of being invited to speak at literary festivals as a writer is that you enjoy privileged access as a reader. Writing, if you like, is the Trojan horse of reading. At the Jaipur Literature Festival in India last year, I met Steve Coll (“Ghost Wars”) and Lawrence Wright (“The Looming Tower”). What struck me — and I mean this as a compliment — was the speed with which Lawrence (to you) went from being the author of a stonking great masterpiece to just “Larry,” a guy I was hanging out with. Ditto Bobby (Roberto) Calasso. Well, that’s not quite true. I didn’t exactly hang out with Calasso and I never called him “Bobby,” but I did meet him, several times. I’d love to say I can prove it, but I can’t. That is, I didn’t get any books signed.

headline: The Roger Ebert Show
text: Roger Ebert could be a cocksure prat.

headline: Neal Stephenson’s Novel of Computer Viruses and Welsh Terrorists
text: Let us say that novelists are like unannounced visitors. While Norman Mailer and Saul Bellow pound manfully on the door, Jonathan Franzen and Zadie Smith knock politely, little preparing you for the emotional ferociousness with which they plan on making themselves at home. Neal Stephenson, on the other hand, shows up smelling vaguely of weed, with a bunch of suitcases. Maybe he can crash for a couple of days? Two weeks later he is still there. And you cannot get rid of him. Not because he is unpleasant but because he is so interesting. Then one morning you wake up and find him gone. You are relieved, a little, but you also miss him. And you wish he’d left behind whatever it was he was smoking, because anything that allows a human being to write six 1,000-page novels in 12 years is worth the health and imprisonment risk.

headline: A Noncollegial Debate About Bicycles
text: It is nothing new, of course, for the subject of bicycles in New York City to provoke impassioned arguments. From bike shares to bike lanes, the battle lines are often clear.

headline: How Do You Get to Broadway? Go to a Basketball Camp
text: During rehearsals last fall the actors in the Broadway play “Lombardi” learned virtually every inspirational maxim uttered by the legendary Green Bay Packers coach. But at least they didn’t have to run drills – unlike the cast of the coming Broadway musical “Lysistrata Jones,” a comic look at a college basketball team on a long losing streak.

headline: How Will We Fuel the Future?
text: At the influential TED conference last year, Bill Gates declared that if he were allowed one wish to improve humanity’s lot over the next 50 years, he would choose an “energy miracle”: a new technology that produced energy at half the price of coal with no carbon dioxide emissions. He explained that he’d rather have this wish than a new vaccine or medicine or even choose the next several American presidents. To help understand the reasoning behind Gates’s thinking, one should read Daniel Yergin’s intelligent new opus, “The Quest: Energy, Security, and the Remaking of the Modern World.”

headline: Some Actors Work Both Sides of a Script
text: AT the end of a 90-minute conversation Jesse Eisenberg announced that what he really would like to do is write a musical. To which Zoe Kazan responded, “That’s the most impressive thing you’ve said this whole time.” Mr. Eisenberg answered back by listing other comments he had made. “Musical theater totally trumps that,” she retorted.

headline: It’s Safe to Go Outside: NASA Says Its Falling Satellite Will Miss the U.S.
text: Hours after it was supposed to have made a fiery plunge back to Earth, a wayward NASA satellite was still in orbit, and space experts were still uncertain when exactly it would fall.

headline: The Less Than Heroic Christopher Columbus
text: In 5,000 years of recorded history, scarcely another figure has ignited as much controversy. Each second Monday in October, the familiar arguments flare up. Christopher Columbus, rediscoverer of America, was a visionary explorer. He was a harbinger of genocide. He was a Christianizing messiah. He was a pitiless slave master. He was a lionhearted seaman, a rapacious plunderer, a masterly navigator, a Janus-faced schemer, a liberator of oppressed tribes, a delusional megalomaniac. In “Columbus,” Laurence Bergreen, the author of several biographies, allows scope for all these judgments. But Christopher Columbus was in the first place a terribly interesting man — brilliant, audacious, volatile, paranoid, narcissistic, ruthless and (in the end) deeply unhappy.

headline: At Home With Karl Marx
text: “I first encountered the Marx family story in the back of a London magazine,” Mary Gabriel writes in the opening line of her intimate account of Karl Marx and his family. It is not a reassuring start for the reader, particularly when the publisher promises a book that uncovers “the unyielding love that bound together a man and woman in the midst of history’s whirlwind.” Gabriel should try to have whoever came up with that one fired.
