headline: The Case for Countering China’s Rise
text: It seems inevitable that Chinese-­American relations will increasingly come to preoccupy the world. The United States continues to be the only global superpower, but in the not-too-distant future China promises to acquire the status of an equal or near equal. How this relationship evolves during a period when the balance of power between them is shifting so rapidly is inevitably a cause for concern.

headline: A British Town Under Close Surveillance
text: As he demonstrated in his 2008 novel “The Northern Clemency,” which was a finalist for the Man Booker Prize, Philip Hensher knows how to populate his fiction with a range of characters whose stories are kept moving by deft shifts in perspective. Before we can tire of one character, we’re observing the scene from the point of view of that person’s child or spouse or neighbor. The result is a portrait of a community in which we’re delighted not to live: a milieu that makes our own seem, by contrast, paradisiacal.

Irma is a Mennonite living on an isolated farm near the city of Chihuahua, Mexico, where her family fled from Canada after the death of Irma’s older sister.

headline: Weekend Fare

headline: A Novel of Stormy Children and Angry Parents in Upstate New York.
text: A good three-­quarters of the way through Justin Torres’s first novel, “We the Animals,” readers might find themselves wondering how the narrator — 7 years old at the start and unnamed throughout — keeps his sanity in check. He has seen his mother, delirious and half-deranged from working the overnight shift at the local brewery, scream at him and his two older brothers at 8 on a Sunday evening: “Why aren’t you in school?” He’s seen her make a meatloaf one morning and then call them to dinner as they come down to breakfast, half asleep. He’s seen her carried into the house by his father, her cheeks swollen purple, and been told that “the dentist had been punching on her after she went under.” He’s seen her dragged and forced, by that same father, into a bedroom, behind the door of which the word “stop” has no meaning. And when his father disappears for a time, he’s seen his mother take to the couch for days, miss work, stop eating, stop cooking for them, and drop her head and fall asleep at the kitchen table, surrounded by full ashtrays and empty bottles.

headline: ‘We the Animals’
text: NEVER-NEVER TIME

headline: Inside the List
text: OPEN MIKE: Michael Moore scores his fifth best seller this week with “Here Comes Trouble: Stories From My Life,” which enters at No. 8. The cover shows the pie-faced provocateur as a sweetly smiling toddler on a tricycle, but inside, Moore is as pugnacious as ever, inveighing against familiar targets like George W. Bush and corporate stooges, along with the crazed New Yorker who tried to stab him with a No. 2 pencil after a news conference for “Fahrenheit 9/11,” not to mention the more heavily armed crazies who forced him to seek protection from ex-Navy Seal members after he denounced Bush at the 2003 Academy Awards. Moore also briefly wanders into the Mommy Wars, denouncing the pushers of baby formula. “An entire generation of us were introduced in our very first week to the concept that phony was better than real, that something manufactured was better than something that was right there in the room,” Moore writes. “Later in life, this explained the popularity of the fast food burrito, neocons, Kardashians and why we think reading this book on a tiny screen with three minutes of battery life left is enjoyable.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE GRIEF OF OTHERS,  by Leah Hager Cohen (Riverhead, $26.95.) Complex but fundamentally decent characters hurt one another and are hurt by forces greater than themselves in Cohen’s novel, as a family sinks beneath the weight of a terrible secret.

headline: Living In | Hell’s Kitchen North
text: As memories of street crime have receded, and luxury developments have risen, the name Hell’s Kitchen has acquired a kind of gritty cachet.

headline: With All Its Contrasts, It Needed an Alias
text: NOT long ago, a Midwestern couple arrived at 48th Street near Ninth Avenue to inspect the $399,000 co-op that their 20-something son wanted them to help buy. After looking over the place, a railroad one-bedroom in a tenement walk-up, the mother looked quizzically at the agent, Donald Kemper, and said, “Now tell me, am I in Hell’s Kitchen, or am I in Clinton?” Mr. Kemper, a Prudential Douglas Elliman vice president who lives in the area, replied, “It depends which one you’re more comfortable with.”

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE PAIN CHRONICLES: Cures, Myths, Mysteries, Prayers, Diaries, Brain Scans, Healing, and the Science of Suffering,  by Melanie Thernstrom (Picador, $17.) This expansive mix of medical reportage, history and memoir explores our relationship to pain — from the horrors of surgery before anesthesia to today’s subtler problems of misdiagnosis. Thernstrom also reflects on her own battle with a degenerative spinal condition.

headline: When a Dictionary Could Outrage
text: “A passel of double-domes at the G. & C. Merriam Company joint in Springfield, Mass., have been confabbing and yakking for 27 years — which is not intended to infer that they have not been doing plenty work.” Thus began an editorial that appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 12, 1961, excoriating the recently published Webster’s Third New International Dictionary.

text: As I report in Friday’s Times, many landowners who leased their lands for natural gas drilling in upstate New York are now having second thoughts.

headline: Coach’s Mission: Selling Temple in a Pro Sports Town
text: PHILADELPHIA — When Steve Addazio looks out from his corner office on the second floor of the soon-to-be-expanded football facility at Temple, he often sees one of this city’s many commuter trains rumble past his window.

headline: Rachel Katz and David Darwin
text: AS a shy and awkward teenager, David Matthew Darwin learned to juggle, play the harmonica and wrap his legs around the back of his head — sometimes all at once — as a way to attract the attention of girls.

headline: Stirring the Pot | Time/Food at Abrons Art Center
text: Over the past three years, the New York-based, itinerant art organization e-flux has been cultivating a large-scale micro-economy through a project called Time/Bank. Physical branches at museums in Den Haag and Frankfurt circulated an alternative currency whose notes, designed by the artist Lawrence Weiner, are printed in denominations of hours. During these exhibitions, anyone could spend time helping others to earn bills, which are redeemable for daily items, groceries, art books and other staples. Julieta Aranda and Anton Vidokle, the artists who founded Time/Bank, call it “a platform that enables people to get things done without using money” — indeed, to this day the bank is still functioning, globally, with more than a thousand users who deposit time into the Time/Bank Web site and withdraw it in the form of skills performed by others.

headline: Ex-UConn Star Charged in Ponzi Scheme Case

headline: Wrapped in Plain Brick
text: THE leafy streets of Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, are lined with gracious brownstones and town houses built in the 19th century for well-to-do families who appreciated their stately proportions and exquisite detailing. Interspersed with these showstoppers are more modest three-story apartment buildings, home to the servants who tended to those grand single-family homes and to the dockworkers who toiled at the nearby Brooklyn Navy Yard.

headline: Judges Compete for Law Clerks on a Lawless Terrain
text: Federal judges are entrusted with interpreting and applying rules fairly and consistently. Except, it seems, when it comes to hiring their own staff.

headline: World’s Oldest Operating Car Returns, Under Steam Power, to the Auction Dais
text: There are classic cars, and there are cars pulled from motoring’s fossil record. And when this 1884 automobile built by De Dion, Bouton & Trépardoux crosses the auction block on Oct. 6 in Hershey, Penn., it will do so as the oldest road-going original car in the world.

headline: About That Crush ...
text: One of my good friends has had a crush on a guy for several months. It’s become clear to her that he is not romantically interested. I met the guy separately, at a party, and we’ve become involved. It looks as if it may last. I haven’t told my friend yet, and have no idea if, when or how to tell her. What’s the etiquette here?

headline: Generation X in a Time Capsule
text: EVERY generation gets the rock documentary it deserves. As he followed the young Bob Dylan in 1965, D. A. Pennebaker captured a singer-songwriter in transition from boyish folkie to wary, druggy and dandified rebel in “Don’t Look Back.” Martin Scorsese’s “Last Waltz” found the Band, Van Morrison, Joni Mitchell and Mr. Dylan under the influence of money and the effects of a long ’60s hangover. The ’80s brought Penelope Spheeris’s “Decline of Western Civilization Part Two: The Metal Years,” a sort of real-life “Spinal Tap.” With the long-delayed DVD release this month of David Markey’s Sonic Youth tour documentary, “1991: The Year Punk Broke,” Generation X, characteristically tardy, finally gets its shot.

headline: ‘Romneycare’ Cost Massachusetts Jobs, Perry Tells Conservatives

headline: Discovering Lund, Sweden
text: Thick with history, both modern and ancient, making it an ideal overnight visit from Copenhagen.

headline: A College Town With a Bit of Viking Mayhem
text: WITH its cobblestone streets, vibrant intellectual community and relaxed ambience, Lund is an archetypal college town in Sweden’s southernmost county of Skane (pronounced SKOH-nah). Surrounded by farmland and rolling fields, the town — founded sometime around 990, when the region was still part of Denmark — is thick with history, both modern and ancient, making it an ideal overnight visit from Copenhagen.

headline: Red Bulls Suspend Marquez for a Match
text: Red Bulls Coach Hans Backe on Friday suspended defender Rafael Marquez for Saturday’s match against visiting Portland after the club’s Mexican international was critical of his teammates after Wednesday’s 3-1 loss to Real Salt Lake. The Major League Soccer club confirmed Backe’s decision to banish Marquez, who has appeared in only 15 of the team’s 29 league matches because of injuries and international duty. The decision will probably will spare Marquez another negative reaction from the club’s fans. The match is expected to be sold out in the 25,000-seat Red Bull Arena. Marquez was booed by the fans in the Arena’s South Ward, home to the team’s most dedicated fans.

headline: Franca Sozzani Hates Fashionistas
text: Franca Sozzani, the outspoken editor in chief of Italian Vogue for 23 years, has been in the news a lot lately after publishing issues with provocative themes, like one with only black models in 2008, or the so-called curvy issue this summer. She also pushes a lot of hot-topic buttons on her blog and Twitter accounts.

headline: Woven Stories of War in Washington
text: The National Gallery of Art in Washington recently unveiled “The Invention of Glory: Afonso V and the Pastrana Tapestries,” four enormous pieces created by Flemish weavers in the 1470s. Commissioned to applaud King Afonso V of Portugal, who invaded Moroccan coastal cities in the mid-15th century, the tapestries never made it to Lisbon. Instead, they languished in the Spanish town of Pastrana: moth-eaten, faded and rarely seen.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Sept. 23
text: Subjects include Wall Street protests, a building collapse in Harlem, and Manhattan’s last old-style parking meters.

headline: From Boston Blogs, the (Discouraging) Word on the Red Sox
text: On Bostondirtdogs.com, the most recent Red Sox score is listed this way: Baltimore 6, Choking Dogs 4. On Survivinggrady.com, a fan named Denton offers this assessment: “As much as it pains me to say it, the Red Sox are done. I will root for them as tirelessly as I have all season, but today’s game tells the tale. This team is missing whatever it is; heart, guts, mental toughness…that makes a championship team.” The headline on a Sept. 19 post on Sawxblog.com: Dead Team Walking. And over at Soxaholix.com, Hart Brachen gets darkly comic.

text: Don’t let the décor fool you: the stylists at the newly opened Tommy Guns salon in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, are as skilled at tending to women’s tresses as they are to men’s. “Despite the fact that the space looks very masculine, like a traditional barbershop, 60 percent of our clientele are women,” says the Tommy Guns founder Russell Manley. “Highlights, single process color, keratin blowouts — we excel at everything a salon does.”

headline: An Untethered Approach Is Back in Style
text: JOHN CORIGLIANO had no illusions about the difficulty of the project he had agreed to undertake for the New York Philharmonic. The commission was for a work to commemorate the anniversary of Sept. 11, and it was the orchestra’s second request. Soon after the terrorist attacks the Philharmonic asked him for a first-anniversary tribute to those who had perished. Mr. Corigliano declined, feeling that the shock was too fresh, and the orchestra turned to John Adams, who provided the luminous, deeply moving “On the Transmigration of Souls.”

headline: Fall Cooking With Greens
text: We may be seeing the first burnt-orange and fiery reds of fall foliage, but farmers’ markets and Community Supported Agriculture baskets are still laden with deep greens like Swiss chard, broccoli rabe and bok choy. If your produce basket is overflowing, here are five new recipes from Martha Rose Shulman that will get you cooking with greens.

headline: City’s Top Lawyer Details Payouts of $561 Million in Lawsuits

headline: Minds on the Seafloor, Eyes on the Ice Ahead

headline: Zuckerberg’s Unspoken Law: Sharing and More Sharing
text: One of the most telling moments of Mark Zuckerberg’s presentation Thursday morning in San Francisco was a reference to a technology company he said he deeply admired. It wasn’t Apple, though his turn on stage seemed to lift several pages from the Steve Jobs playbook. It wasn’t Google, from which he has plucked some of his key lieutenants.

headline: The Castles of Moravia
text: THE dark forest felt familiar enough, alternating raggedy oaks and silver beech trees in the dense array found throughout Central Europe. Along the trail, the ubiquitous woodland plants of the Old World — nettles, burdock, fennel and sorrel — grew in their standard summertime abundance. But when we rounded a corner into a meadow, we suddenly seemed to have entered another country, if not another era. Above us soared a stone triumphal arch, perhaps 100 feet tall, topped with life-size nudes. Four immense decorative columns faced us, with ornate bas-relief plasterwork and a mysterious inscription reading “Has tibi, blanda soror Phoebi, sacravimus aedes. Intactus semper crescat tibi lucus honori.” It looked like an ancient Roman monument, but of far more recent vintage and located about 700 miles too far north.

headline: Tackling Maine’s Rugged Side by Bike
text: OUR ragged band of bike riders pedaled down Crooked Lane in search of a rest stop. In front of an old stone barn, amid a pastoral setting that is part Rockwell and part Cézanne, Harry Owen and his dog Rufus were waiting for us.

headline: Restaurant Report: Septime in Paris
text: Before he surrendered to his love of cooking, Bertrand Grébaut already had a degree in literature and had worked as a graphic designer. So it’s no surprise that the delicious market-driven contemporary French dishes that have been tantalizing Paris at his restaurant, Septime, are aesthetically flawless and come seasoned with a subtle literary sensibility.

headline: In Brazil, a Second Life for the Favelas of Rio de Janeiro
text: ON a recent Friday night in Rio de Janeiro, a mix of young locals and tourists sipped caipirinhas and danced along to a samba-infused rock band at the Maze, a combination bed-and-breakfast and night club. The moonlit vistas of Sugar Loaf and Guanabara Bay commanded nearly as much attention as the music; between sets, partiers flooded up to the roof for fresh air and to take in a view that bests those of any hotel on Ipanema Beach.

headline: In Massachusetts, Hints of a Town, Now Revitalized
text: Pittsfield, Mass., which had fallen on hard times, has begun to reawaken with the openings of galleries, boutiques and restaurants.

headline: My Favorite Place: Little Compton, R.I.
text: MY favorite places, like my favorite people, tend to be complicated. Perhaps even difficult. I like strong character, with an I-dare-you-to-like-me attitude, cut with the zest of simple charm. I know, I know. You can waste a lot of time with these types, going nowhere fast. But I’ve come to appreciate the value in going nowhere. Which is why my favorite place in the world happens to be just down the street from me — the public beach in Little Compton, R.I.

headline: Edible Selby | Tokyo Calling
text: Yoshiyuki Okada was the manager of a theme-park-like izakaya, or Japanese-style tapas bar, when, in 2001, he decided he wanted more freedom — like the freedom to dye his hair platinum and play punk music at full volume. Okada ventured to Tokyo’s modish Daikanyama neighborhood to open his own, much smaller izakaya, Tatemichiya, where customers dine on yakitori and deep-fried octopus balls to the blaring guitars of the Ramones, the Sex Pistols and Japanese punk bands like the Stalin and Cobra. Though many of Tokyo’s izakayas have switched to gas or electric cooking, Okada insists on grilling with live coals. Go to interactive feature >>

headline: A Steady Presence Out of the Limelight
text: AT a recent press luncheon in Manhattan to promote both the PBS documentary “Prohibition” and the HBO series “Boardwalk Empire,” a fictionalized treatment of the era, all attention was on two men at the head of one very long table: Terence Winter, the HBO show’s creator, and Ken Burns, the PBS filmmaker.

headline: ‘X Factor’ Holds Steady in the Ratings
text: The ratings for “The X Factor” premiere on Wednesday may not have met expectations, but the second episode last night at least held steady. With 12.5 million viewers, the overall ratings matched the debut episode, while the 18-to-49-year-old audience dropped off by just 2 percent. It was enough to give Fox a victory in the advertiser-coveted 18-to-49 demographic for the night, representing Fox’s first ratings win ever for a Thursday during premiere week. CBS once again finished first in total viewers, led by two episodes of “Big Bang Theory” (averaging 14.4 million viewers) and its new drama “Person of Interest” (13.2 million), according to Nielsen data. However, “Person of Interest” fell in its second half-hour and was fourth in the 18-to-49 category for its 9 p.m. time slot, behind “X-Factor,” “Grey’s Anatomy” on ABC and “Whitney” on NBC.

headline: His Fans Campaign for a Tombstone for the Original King of Mambo
text: Arsenio Rodríguez was the original mambo king, one of the inventors of that genre as well as of the music that later came to be known as salsa. But no tombstone marks his grave at the Ferncliff Cemetery in Westchester County, and with the centennial of his birth having arrived, a group of his admirers have begun a campaign both to remedy that lapse and to get a street named for him in New York City.

headline: Pages From the Glossies
text: In addition to Prada, Jil Sander, Dolce & Gabbana, Gucci, et al, a must-see on this season’s Milan fashion week calendar is “Lei e le Altre,” an exhibition at the Museo della Permanente, culled from the archives of RCS Periodici, the publishing company behind titles like Max, Amica, L’Europeo and the legendary but defunct Lei. Curated by Maria Luisa Frisa and designed by Arabeschi di Latte, the dense, labyrinthine installation presents style milestones at every turn, including Jackie Kennedy on a Roman holiday, Françoise Hardy in 1970s-era Yves Saint Laurent and fashion’s current patron saint, Lady Gaga. But the view is ultimately panoramic: “Fashion can be used to read and interpret society, and to tell stories about the evolution and emancipation of women,” Frisa says. Here fashion acts not only as a reflection of social change, but as a driving force behind it — and not just on paper.

headline: Designing Sustainable Structures From the Land Up
text: The Solar Decathlon, an Energy Department competition in which college teams design and build energy-thrifty solar-powered structures, kicked off today on the National Mall. (The video above is the entry from the University of Maryland; background below.)

headline: Crafting an Application Essay That ‘Pops’
text: Stanford University’s application for admission includes a prompt directing students to write a letter to their future freshman roommates. The exercise is a good one for all applicants – regardless of their interest in Stanford – as a fun, fresh jumping-off point in the essay writing process, Rebecca Joseph, a professor of education at California State University, said on Friday.

headline: Never Too Old to Quit
text: Perhaps you’ve heard of the “damage is done” scenario. An elderly family member started smoking as a young person, maybe a teenager, tucking a pack of cigarettes into his rolled-up shirtsleeve or into her purse. Decades later, despite wall-to-wall anti-smoking ads, despite smoking being outlawed in nearly every public space, perhaps despite family pleas or doctors’ admonitions or even a heart attack, that person remains a smoker.

headline: Late Trade by Diamondbacks Recalls Deal From the Past

headline: A Sweeter Side of Focaccia
text: My first taste of Concord grape focaccia was at Gramercy Tavern. I was working on a cookbook with the pastry chef Claudia Fleming and the dish was one of her specialties — with a few tweaks. Instead of the traditional olive oil, she used melted butter in the dough, which gave it a milder, less assertively savory flavor. She always said the focaccia reminded her of hot buttered toast with Concord grape jelly on it, and I would have to agree.

headline: My Three Favorite Food Delivery Systems, Japan
text: It was that first visit to Japan, in 1992, during a journalism fellowship. We checked into the Y.M.C.A. hotel in Tokyo, a bunch of rubes from the States, and there on the sixth floor was a vending machine that dispensed . . . beer. We swooned. Regular cans, tall boys and what looked quarter-size kegs. After the long flight from the East Coast, there could have been nothing more beautiful. Since then I’ve collected impressions of unusual food- and drink-dispensing systems in Japan. My favorites:

headline: The Stelvio Pass in an Audi R8 5.2 FSI V-10 Quattro: Paradise or Purgatory?

headline: Focaccia That’s Worth a Little Extra Effort
text: SCHIACCIATA CON L’UVA, a rustic, focaccialike flatbread enriched with olive oil and studded with grapes, is the kind of harvest snack traditionally baked in Tuscany when the wine grapes are inky purple on the vines and the people hungry in the fields.

headline: Channel Surfing: ‘Family Guy’ Returns, Zingers Intact
text: Seth MacFarlane drew a lot of notice early this week as roast master of the let’s-cook-Charlie-Sheen extravaganza on Comedy Central, but how’s he doing in his day job? We find out on Sunday when “Family Guy,” his long-running animated hit, starts a new season on Fox. And the season premiere is a shocker, in a sense: Can it be that this show, now nearing its zillionth episode, has never done a Peter-wins-the-lottery story line before?

headline: Pop God Dives Into World of Ballet
text: Paul McCartney’s first ballet score, “Ocean’s Kingdom,” is in no way an important addition to the corpus of ballet music, but it deserves a better staging than the one it’s been given by New York City Ballet. Never less than agreeable, it has plenty of color and melody. Curiously, it sounds as if it had been composed in the neo-Romantic era before the Beatles: some of its most expansive tunes have hints of Borodin and Samuel Barber; some of its atmospheres evoke Ravel; and its jolliest passages are on the cusp of Bernstein’s “Candide.”

headline: How to Revisit an Iconic Photograph
text: This fall is a busy one for the photographer Alec Soth, who most recently shot “Portraits From a Job-Starved City” for the magazine. Soth is showing new photographs at the International Photography Festival of Rome and at the Wattis Institute for Contemporary Arts in San Francisco. And later this month, at the NY Art Book Fair, Soth’s publishing company, Little Brown Mushroom, will introduce three new books: “A Head with Wings,” by Anouk Kruithof, “The Little Brown Coloring Book,” by Jason Polan and “Bunny Boy Goes to Rome” by the Soth family. In a series of e-mail exchanges, condensed below, I asked Soth about his latest work.

headline: For a Bills Fan, a Glimmer of Hope
text: On Sunday, the Bills (2-0) will try to reverse a humiliating 15-game losing-streak against the mighty Patriots (2-0) at Ralph Wilson Stadium in Orchard Park. Since beating the Pats, 16-13 in an overtime thriller on Nov. 5, 2000, the team has lost 20 of its last 21 games to their division foe in a stretch where the Patriots have taken home the Vince Lombardi trophy three times while the Bills have failed to make the playoffs even once.

headline: Icahn Withdraws From Proxy Fight at Clorox
text: Carl C. Icahn has cut short his effort to replace the board at Clorox, he disclosed in a securities filing on Friday, after failing to win enough support from other shareholders.

headline: Kicking Out of Bounds Easier Said Than Done
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Once the weeping subsided and rationality returned, most Giants fans were left with one simple question in the aftermath of last season’s Week 15 loss to the Philadelphia Eagles, a game that will always be remembered for DeSean Jackson’s game-ending 65-yard punt return for a touchdown:

headline: A Tax Plan That Might Not Be So Painful
text: If you’re among the households with earnings of $200,000 to $350,000 or so, you can be forgiven at this point for thinking that you have a giant target on your back.

headline: Michele Bachmann and the Making of an Acolyte
text: ANNANDALE, Minn. — At first glance, Bradlee Dean seems straight out of a casting call for aging rockers — the hair cascading down his back, the arms wrapped in tattoos and the passing of years that have filled out his face, now in sharp contrast to the slender features in the soft-focus studio portrait from his younger days.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Sept. 23
text: More Photographs

headline: When Your Therapist Is Only a Click Away
text: THE event reminder on Melissa Weinblatt’s iPhone buzzed: 15 minutes till her shrink appointment.

headline: Now Online | T Travel Fall 2011
text: The fall travel issue of T explores the art of the tour, starting with the model Lara Stone, who heads home to the Netherlands for a romp through her old stomping grounds. The performer Casey Spooner, of the art-rock group Fischerspooner, takes us from stage to stream on his whirlwind trip through four countries. And Diana Taylor, the board chairwoman of the microfinance group Acción — and Mayor Bloomberg’s longtime companion — leads the way to Manaus, Brazil, where the organization recently began making loans. Along the way we stop in Beirut to find the city eternally optimistic in the wake of the Arab Spring; Provence, where one of the world’s most reclusive patrons has turned his vineyard into an architectural theme park; and the Tuscarora Reservation in New York State, for a look at how the tribe’s heritage corn has survived the ages, and why it matters to agriculture. Elsewhere, Daphne Merkin looks for retail therapy in Jerusalem, The Selby discovers punk-rock tapas in Tokyo, and Jeremy Irons reveals his Budapest, part of an up-to-the-minute guide to “Hollywood on the Danube.” See all the stories here.

headline: Opposition Leader Is Handed Reins in Zambia
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The Zambian opposition leader Michael Sata, a 74-year-old veteran politician who had whipped up not-so-subtle anti-Chinese sentiment (China runs several big mines in Zambia), handily won the presidency in election results announced Friday.

headline: Dancing of the Streets, Stripped Down to Its Art
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — It’s easy to imagine Sonia Destri rehearsing with Companhia Urbana de Dança, her all-male Brazilian troupe that specializes in contemporary dance and hip-hop. Or at least this is my fantasy: the moment just before a dancer is about to spin on his head or whip a leg around in a windmill, she hollers, “Freeze!”

headline: Snooping in the Age of E-book
text: I RECENTLY attended a chaotic, kid-friendly gathering at the home of a friend. On my way to the bathroom to seek some solace, I decided to indulge in one of my favorite antisocial activities: scrutinizing someone else’s bookshelf. For a veteran sleuth, a bookshelf can offer a trove of insights worthy of any Freudian’s couch. Does a person alphabetize the books or clump them? Do they arrange their books by genre, order in which they were purchased, or color? Are these books unopened hardcovers or dog-eared paperbacks?

headline: Debt Levels Alone Don’t Tell the Whole Story
text: AS the world’s central bankers and finance ministers gather in Washington this weekend for the annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, government debt is at the top of the agenda. Some governments can no longer borrow money and others can do so only at relatively high interest rates. Reducing budget deficits has become a prime goal for nearly all countries.

headline: With the Help of Unusual Outsiders, Finding Love in Strange Objects
text: The process behind “Tool Is Loot,” the collaboration between Jennifer Lacey and Wally Cardona that had its premiere at the Kitchen on Thursday, was willfully, even perversely circuitous.

headline: ‘Buffett Rule’ Is More Complicated Than Politics Suggest
text: WHAT percentage of your annual income do you pay in taxes — as much as Warren Buffett’s secretary? If not, what is the likelihood that you will soon?

headline: #trendingnyc: The Week on Twitter
text: With the Yankees’ almost-annual trip to the postseason officially booked, and the rival Red Sox fading fast, Yankees fans did their best to explode Twitter this week in a fit of joy and schadenfreude.

headline: Staring the Audience Down to Send a Message
text: “Shy Showoff,” the title of the piece for three that Heather Olson presented at the Chocolate Factory on Wednesday, almost works as a self-description of her intriguing stage persona. When she stares spectators down, as she often does, she projects a feeling of distrust, her head retracting into her elegant neck. You could say she’s a deer caught in the stage lights, if the idiom connoted animal alertness rather than dumb paralysis. This deer has some De Niro in her: You lookin’ at me?

headline: Accounting Change Cuts Groupon’s Revenue
text: Groupon disclosed a major accounting change on Friday, essentially halving its once-jaw-dropping revenue after it encountered resistance from regulators with its filing to go public.

headline: A Marilyn Obsession
text: SINCE her death in 1962, Marilyn Monroe, whom Norman Mailer called the American man’s “sweet angel of sex,” has never wandered far from popular imagination or the souvenir shop. Yet with the 50th anniversary of Ms. Monroe’s mysterious death approaching, her image is experiencing something of a cultural moment, even by ageless icon standards.

headline: Noticed: Marilyn Monroe
text: With the 50th anniversary of Ms. Monroe’s mysterious death approaching, her image is experiencing something of a cultural moment, even by ageless icon standards.

headline: Groupon C.O.O. Quits to Return to Google
text: The chief operating officer of Groupon, Margo Georgiadis, has stepped down after about five months at her post, the chief executive, Andrew Mason, announced on the company’s blog on Friday.

headline: Break Is Found in Manhattan’s Eruv, a Crucial Aid to Observant Jews
text: A detail of a map of the Manhattan eruv, showing the area where a gap was found, near the United Nations. View Manhattan Eruv Map in a larger map.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Versace
text: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Grades Slip in Annual School Progress Report
text: More schools received low marks in New York City’s School Progress Report after a rule that kept their grades from dropping too quickly was lifted. The annual evaluation also used a new curve that assigned more D’s and F’s than last year’s system did. The end result: More schools can be considered for closing or transformation.

headline: An Uptick, but Is It Enough?
text: Six months ago, Keli Goff, a blogger, political commentator and self-appointed fashion industry watchdog, chided designers for their near-exclusion of black models on the runways. Most shows, she wrote on her Web site, Loop21.com, “were about as diverse as a Tea Party rally.” Of 144 shows last spring, she reported, 25 featured no black models at all, while others included only one or two.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Sept. 23
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include Wall Street protests, a building collapse in Harlem and Manhattan’s last old-style parking meters.

headline: In a Chinese Tournament, the Visitors Lead the Way
text: Just before the Tianjin Binhai Cup world men’s elite tournament in China, there was a three-day event for the Zhejiang Huamen Cup, from Sept. 7 to 9. In it, four foreign teams joined eight Chinese teams to play a round robin of 16-board matches.

headline: Global Arms Sales Dropped Sharply in 2010, Study Finds
text: WASHINGTON — The global economic crisis may set off upheaval and even unrest, but the ability of the world’s governments to buy new military hardware was sharply curtailed last year by strains on their national treasuries, according to a new Congressional study.

headline: Liberating Viewers, and the World, With Silliness
text: Fed up with being hounded by the New York State attorney general’s office over alleged zoning violations in the early 1970s, George Maciunas, the real estate developer, graphic artist and leading light of Fluxus, the international network of Conceptual artists, created an artwork that doubled as a defense against subpoena-wielding enforcers. He attached four industrial-size paper-cutting blades to the grungy yellow front door of his Manhattan apartment.

headline: The Curls Carrie White Left Behind
text: Ms. White, who styled the hair of Marlon Brando, Elizabeth Taylor and Elvis Presley, played a part in originating the look of her time.

headline: Oysters Take a Dip in Butter
text: IT’S a funny thing about oysters. It’s O.K. to eat them elsewhere than by the sea. They travel, a boon for many a landlocked diner.

headline: Red Pepper Mayonnaise, Nearly Effortless and Worth It
text: While raw oysters are wonderful, a good fried oyster is a pretty fine thing too. And though restaurant versions can be fine, often they just get a roll in some corn meal or dry crumbs before getting tossed in the deep-fryer. It is too bad. There is a tastier, better way.

headline: Dodging the Proposed 2013 Tax Increase
text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I use the president’s efforts to have the six-figure set pay more in taxes as an excuse to remind the world about the mysterious under-use of flexible spending accounts.

headline: The Possible Unintended Consequences of Higher Taxes
text: Paul Sullivan writes in his Wealth Matters column this week about President Obama’s proposal to make Americans who make more than $1 million a year pay at least the same percentage of their earnings as middle-class earners.

text: THE teenage girl wearing jean shorts and a bikini top sunbathing at Long Beach, N.Y., on a recent hazy Saturday found her friends hilarious — if you’re willing to take her word for it.

text: Bill Keller’s article, “My Unfinished 9/11 Business,” provoked a lot of responses.

headline: Medal of Honor Nominee Picks Up a Supporter

headline: A Game That Honed the Skills of Writers

headline: Taco Truck Operator Honored as ‘Most Heroic Vendor’
text: The Vendy Awards, founded to recognize the city’s mobile vendors selling the most delicious food, have named the first winner of the “Most Heroic Vendor” award. It is Paty’s Tacos, an uptown stalwart that is leading the legal challenge to a city law prohibiting sales of merchandise from metered parking spots.

headline: A Look at PolitiFact Grades of Candidates
text: In politics, sifting for the truth can be a difficult endeavor. Black and white are rare commodities, and most often voters, the press, politicians and political observers are left trading in grays.

headline: Strauss-Kahn Will Face French Accuser
text: PARIS — Dominique Strauss-Kahn will come face to face with the French writer who has accused him of attempted rape as part of an investigation into the woman’s accusations, the Paris prosecutor said Friday.

headline: Data as Art, as Science, as a Reason for Being
text: Anyone walking past Lincoln Center during the last few days, and glancing downward at its new access road, Jaffe Drive, would have seen what seemed to be a slightly eccentric art installation. A long band of animated colored lights would snake across a 123-foot-long wall of LEDs as a digital clock counted backward. Then that band might suddenly twist and wind around itself, erupt into curves, contort into waves, and, just as unexpectedly, subside again into temporary linear calm.

headline: The Menil Is to Return Frescoes to Cyprus
text: ROME — The Menil Collection in Houston announced on Friday that next year it would return to the Greek Orthodox Church of Cyprus 13th-century Byzantine frescoes that have been one of the museum’s main attractions for more than a decade.

text: 8:32 a.m. | Updated In the battle of the book reports between Rick Perry and Mitt Romney, score one for the Texas governor.

headline: Saying It With Flowers, but Still Putting Anguish Front and Center
text: There’s no hiding in Girls, the two-man project of Christopher Owens and J R White, though it’s really just the showcase for the self-lacerations of Mr. Owens, whose shaky and piercing vocals slice neatly through whatever else is happening around them.

headline: Mad for Metro-North, a Rail Rider Is on a Mission
text: EVERY weekday, Emily Moser rides the Metro-North Railroad from Goldens Bridge to White Plains, N.Y., and unlike most of the other passengers, she relishes every moment of the round trip, which takes an hour and 10 minutes. Where others see generic train stations whose functional, if uninspired, construction hides hints of past glory, Ms. Moser sees art.

headline: Footnote
text: The critically acclaimed Broadway revival of the 1971 musical “Follies” will extend its engagement at the Marriott Marquis Theater by three weeks, through Jan. 22, the producers announced Friday. The slightly longer run will give the musical a better chance of turning a profit — a benchmark of success that has long eluded the show, beloved by many musical theater fans for its score by Stephen Sondheim.

headline: Philadelphia Orchestra Is Heading to China
text: The Philadelphia Orchestra will spend a week in China next May, giving performances, coaching sessions, master classes and workshops, the orchestra said. The visit is the first of what the orchestra called a “pilot partnership” with the National Center for the Performing Arts in Beijing. (Its president, Chen Ping, pictured, shakes hands with Allison Vulgamore, president of the orchestra.) The Philadelphia Orchestra was the first major American orchestra to perform in China, in 1973, and now joins a growing number of Western cultural institutions establishing ties in a country with a hunger for Western classical music. As China builds more and more halls in its many big cities, the need for high-level performers has increased, and in many cases engagements in China provide much-needed cash for Western ensembles.

headline: This Sunday: Our Man in Tripoli
text: This week, we have Robert F. Worth’s third cover story in 6 months. In the spring, he was in Libya just as the revolution against Qaddafi was exploding. Then he went to Yemen, where he explored the fierce rivalries that are driving that country apart. And now he’s back in Libya, reporting on the bizarre vacuum created by the tyrant’s collapse. A safe, functioning democracy seems a long way off, to say the least.

headline: Journalist Is Detained in China for Article on Sex Slaves
text: BEIJING — For a nation not yet inured to lurid and senseless crime, a report that a former civil servant in central China kept six women enslaved in an underground bunker — and that he killed two of them — was shocking enough.

headline: Horse Therapy and Vitamin Smoothie
text: Mike Repole built his fortune in the food and beverage industry — he was a founder of Vitaminwater and is the chairman and primary shareholder of Pirate Brands snacks and Energy Kitchen fast-food restaurants. Seven years ago, he found a sure way to spend that fortune, buying a thoroughbred racehorse, but it was not his style to stop at one. Repole Stable has 78 horses based at Belmont, N.Y., two of them stars: Uncle Mo, whose Triple Crown season was derailed by a liver ailment; and Stay Thirsty, who ran second in the Belmont Stakes and won the Travers at Saratoga in August. Both are entered in races on Saturday — Uncle Mo in the Kelso Stakes and Stay Thirsty in the Jockey Club Gold Cup — to prepare for the Breeders’ Cup at Churchill Downs in November. Mr. Repole, 42, who grew up in Queens, lives on the North Shore of Long Island with his wife, Maria, 40. ROBIN FINN

headline: A Tryout Program for the Unemployed
text: ATLANTA — Desperate to find a way to get the nation’s long-term unemployed back to work, President Obama and Republican leaders are supporting the expansion of a novel jobs program in Georgia to any other state that wants it.

headline: Yelling ‘Fire’ on a Crowded Runway
text: Milan

headline: Obama Turns Some Powers of Education Back to States
text: With his declaration on Friday that he would waive the most contentious provisions of a federal education law, President Obama effectively rerouted the nation’s education history after a turbulent decade of overwhelming federal influence.

headline: Tales of Two Presidents and a Crooner
text: IT is well known that President Grover Cleveland, once governor of New York, probably fathered a son while still a bachelor. In “A Secret Life: The Lies and Scandals of President Grover Cleveland” (Skyhorse Publishing), Charles Lachman, a television producer and author of a book about the Lincolns, delves deeply into the affair (immortalized in the rhyme “Ma, ma where’s my pa? Gone to the White House, ha, ha, ha”), its aftermath and Cleveland’s subsequent marriage to a woman 28 years younger than he was.

headline: Tropical Storm Is Long Gone, but an Evacuation Still Holds
text: It is like something out of one of its namesake’s novels. The classic dark and stormy night. A cliffside collapse leading to a dramatic post-midnight evacuation and now, almost a month later, poetic types wandering homeless. And the setting is appropriately literary: The Villa Charlotte Bronte, an elaborate, eccentric sand castle of co-op apartments perched majestically on a cliff 150 feet above the Hudson and Harlem Rivers in Spuyten Duyvil, the Bronx.

headline: Investing in Helping Adults With Autism
text: To the Editor:

headline: When Storms Rush In, a Waiting Game Begins
text: In the old days, nothing delayed or postponed a college football game. Athletes played through blizzards, 60-mile-per-hour winds and pounding rain.

headline: At UBS, It’s the Culture That’s Rogue
text: When Kweku Adoboli was arrested for an illicit trading scheme that cost his employer, the global bank UBS, $2.3 billion in losses, he was instantly labeled a “rogue trader,” suggesting he was an unprincipled scoundrel acting alone.

headline: Accused of Fighting for Qaddafi, a Libyan Town’s Residents Face Reprisals
text: SURT, Libya — On the edge of this city where Libya’s war goes on, several men from the town of Tawerga sat on the patio of a mosque, having fled their homes and traded one war zone for another. Rockets fell nearby, but that was just one of their problems. Men with guns, their former neighbors from the city of Misurata, stood above them, accusing them of grave betrayals.

headline: Stance on Immigration May Hurt Perry Early On
text: With a single phrase implying his opponents are heartless, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas plumbed a profound divide between his views on illegal immigration and those of many grass-roots conservatives, who up to now have been the core of his support for the Republican nomination.

headline: A Big 12 Rivalry Game That Could Be No More
text: The passion in his voice is unmistakable when Oklahoma State Coach Mike Gundy speaks about the dysfunctional mess the Big 12 has become. Gundy’s emotion reflects the belief among his fellow coaches that the Big 12, with three conference teams ranked among the top eight in the nation, should be celebrating instead of negotiating its future.

headline: Yahoo Review Will Take Months
text: Yahoo‘s co-founders and its chairman have acknowledged that it would take “months, not weeks” to complete a strategic review of company’s business, implying that any decision about reviving or selling the Web portal could take some time.

headline: State Says It Analyzed Test Erasures for Cheating; 62 Schools Proved Suspect
text: Cheating scandals have been rolling up the East Coast like a hurricane this year, from Atlanta to Washington, Pennsylvania and New Jersey.

headline: On a Mission to Help Chile Until the Very End

headline: Students Battle a Dallas Cowboys Unit Over College Apparel
text: The Dallas Cowboys have a new merchandising arm that recently jumped into the business of producing college-logo apparel for leading universities, but the Cowboys subsidiary has already encountered a stubborn opponent — student groups that contend it is using overseas sweatshops.

headline: How Do You Say ‘Economic Security’?
text: IN the face of nothing but bad economic news, Americans often take heart in remembering that we have been here before — during the Great Depression, when conditions were far worse than they are today — and we survived.

headline: Orlando Brown, Who Sued N.F.L. Over Errant Flag, Dies at 40
text: Orlando Brown, a bruising offensive tackle for the Cleveland Browns and the Baltimore Ravens who was temporarily blinded in one eye by a referee’s errant penalty flag, leading him to file a $200 million lawsuit against the National Football League, was found dead Friday in his Baltimore apartment. He was 40.

headline: U.S. Quietly Supplies Israel With Bunker-Busting Bombs
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has quietly supplied Israel with bombs capable of destroying buried targets, like terrorists’ arms caches or perhaps sites in Iran suspected of being part of that nation’s nuclear weapons program, American officials said Friday.

headline: In Need of Win, the Red Sox Get Only Questions
text: Under the gray sky and soggy conditions that washed out Friday night’s game against the Yankees, Boston Red Sox General Manager Theo Epstein sat in the visitors’ dugout and refused to accept that his team’s fortunes were just as gloomy.

headline: Perry’s Bad Night
text: Gloom pervades the land. Some people believe it’s the economy. Others blame the weather. I think it’s because the country is gradually coming to grips with the fact that Mitt Romney is going to be the Republican nominee for president.

headline: Gunning for Wall Street, With Faulty Aim
text: By late morning on Wednesday, Occupy Wall Street, a noble but fractured and airy movement of rightly frustrated young people, had a default ambassador in a half-naked woman who called herself Zuni Tikka. A blonde with a marked likeness to Joni Mitchell and a seemingly even stronger wish to burrow through the space-time continuum and hunker down in 1968, Ms. Tikka had taken off all but her cotton underwear and was dancing on the north side of Zuccotti Park, facing Liberty Street, just west of Broadway. Tourists stopped to take pictures; cops smiled, and the insidiously favorable tax treatment of private equity and hedge-fund managers was looking as though it would endure.

headline: After Defecting to Turkey, a Top Syrian Army Officer Mysteriously Reappears
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Some say he went shopping and never returned. Others say he was a bargaining chip in a clandestine prisoner swap between Syria and Turkey. Still others insist that he was betrayed.

headline: M.L.B. Seeks Approval of Judge to Sell Dodgers
text: Major League Baseball objected Friday to a plan proposed by the Los Angeles Dodgers to auction their media rights and asked a bankruptcy court judge to authorize the sale of the team owned by Frank McCourt.

headline: Allies of French President Are Questioned in Graft Inquiry
text: PARIS — Three allies of President Nicolas Sarkozy of France on Friday found themselves the focus of an expanding investigation into a 17-year-old case involving suspected corruption in the sale of submarines to Pakistan.

headline: In Time of Scrimping, Fun Stuff Is Still Selling
text: With a flat job market and an economy that will not improve, Americans are once again buckling down and cutting back.

headline: The Phony Solyndra Scandal
text: If Brian Harrison and W. G. Stover, the two Solyndra executives who took the Fifth Amendment at a Congressional hearing on Friday, ever spend a day in jail, I’ll stand on my head in Times Square.

headline: Lean Toward the Sunny Side, but Don’t Overdo It
text: I HAVE trouble with optimism. I would like to be a more optimistic person, and sometimes I can be. But there’s a long tradition of pessimism in my family; our attitude is that looking on the bright side, or expecting the best, is naïve at best and folly at worst.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,765 American service members who have died since the start of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Money on Mind, Points Leaders Stumble
text: ATLANTA — It would be the elephant in the room, if East Lake Golf Club had walls and a roof.

headline: After Report on Speed, a Rush of Scrutiny
text: Once upon a time, the only thing that traveled faster than the speed of light was gossip.

headline: An Air of Sophistication, and Aiming for More
text: THE WOODS AT HOLLOW BROOK, which opened to the public several months ago, has both the advantages and disadvantages of being a restaurant in a private golf club.

headline: Giving New Life to Brick Ovens Where Hippies Once Roamed
text: The list of things tinctured by the earth in this tiny central Colorado town might well start with Kyle McKelligott’s face, and his T-shirt — both streaked on a recent afternoon with a working mason’s signature stone dust and mortar.

headline: Lieutenant Ingraham’s Short ‘Commish’
text: The monotony of Army life often left Aaron Ingraham lonely and bored. His thoughts typically turned inward, where he fixated on two topics: money and position.

headline: No Flash, Just Smash From Eagles Fullback
text: PHILADELPHIA — In the Philadelphia Eagles’ locker room, a succession of stalls along one wall includes spaces for the high-profile stars DeSean Jackson, Jeremy Maclin and Steve Smith. Owen Schmitt takes his place in the middle.

headline: Transatlantic and Validus Sign a Confidentiality Agreement

headline: Borough President Seeks Limits on Stop-and-Frisk
text: The Manhattan borough president, Scott M. Stringer, arguing that Police Department practices are creating a “wall of distrust” between officers and minorities, plans to call this weekend for a major re-examination of the department’s stop-and-frisk policy.

headline: Trailing G.O.P. Rivals Hope for an Opening
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — As they toil in the shadow of the front-runners, the other Republican presidential candidates are offering starkly different visions of how the party might win the White House without Mitt Romney or Rick Perry.

headline: The Latest Ugly Truth About Pakistan
text: Adm. Mike Mullen, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, is a truth teller. He led the way among senior uniformed officers in urging repeal of the unconscionable “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy on gays in the military and pressed to shift more troops from Iraq to Afghanistan.

headline: Mets Rained Out at Citi Field, Which in Their Case May Be a Good Thing
text: The Mets’ presence Friday at Citi Field, where they will play the final six games of their season, served as a reminder of how different their fortunes have been this season at home and on the road.

headline: Cuban Minister Leaves a Door Open to American’s Release
text: A week after an effort to gain the release of an American jailed in Cuba ended in recriminations, the Cuban foreign minister said Friday that the door remained open to free him on humanitarian grounds, but only with a reciprocal effort from the United States.

headline: Corrections: September 24
text: BUSINESS DAY

headline: A Vintner Gets Personal
text: Like chefs hungry to start their own restaurants, many winemakers thirst to have personal labels. Adam Suprenant, who is working on his 14th Long Island vintage this year, has been one of them.

headline: Finding a Place at the Greek Table
text: FALLING between Long Island’s casual gyro spots and the high-priced Greek palaces serving fish priced by the pound, Neraki Greek Mediterranean Grill filled a niche when it opened in May in Huntington.

headline: A Career Criminal’s Prints Link Two Lives Upended Decades Apart
text: In 1983, a police officer from Bushwick with scars from six gunshot wounds from his right shoulder to his left hip was lucky to be alive, and he darn well knew it, so he put in his papers after 22 years on the job. In the next neighborhood over, Greenpoint, an immigrant jeweler arrived that year, eager to work. They were both Polish, both Brooklyn family men, but at the time, their similarities ended there.

headline: State of the Republican Field
text: At a few points in their careers as governors, Rick Perry and Mitt Romney used the powers of state government to help their citizens. Mr. Romney helped create a health insurance system to cover his state’s uninsured population; Mr. Perry provided in-state college tuition for some illegal immigrants. At every presidential debate, however, each attacks the other for these accomplishments, unaware of how ridiculous they sound.

headline: Do Admissions Interviews Matter?
text: Interviewing with a college is a signal of an applicant’s interest in actually attending, said Karen Richardson, associate director of admissions at Tufts University, on Friday.

headline: Another Ridiculous Standoff
text: Congress has lapsed into its now familiar crash-and-burn mode as House Republicans and Senate Democrats continue to fumble what should be the simple task of passing a temporary spending measure needed to prevent the government from shutting down after next Friday.

headline: Saturday: Bum Rap
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — So, for years and years, the deal was that the early to midweek New York Times crossword puzzles had themes, the Friday and Saturday ones did not, and then we got our theme back on Sunday. Lately, however, I feel like I’ve been seeing an increasing number of entries that have enough in common that one could consider them a minitheme of sorts. This does not bother me; it almost seems like value added to an already challenging puzzle. It’s just interesting to note how puzzle styles evolve over the years.

headline: Grandmotherly Bangladesh Leader Unfazed by Problems at Home
text: While Bangladesh’s prime minister has been attending the United Nations this week, stock market investors back home rioted over steep losses, the police arrested hundreds of Islamist protesters and the main political opposition party threatened a general strike for Saturday, when it is her turn to speak at the annual General Assembly.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Yankees Dodging Weather and Juggling Lineup in Push for Home Field
text: The Yankees’ game Friday night against the Boston Red Sox was postponed because of rain, resulting in a day-night doubleheader Sunday at Yankee Stadium that will be their fifth this season, their third in the last month and their second in five days.

headline: Time for Bratwurst, Beer and Lederhosen
text: HOBOKEN, N.J.

headline: For Bloomberg, Waste Mars Another Digital Project
text: Soon after becoming mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg announced a plan to modernize the computer system that handles personnel information for New York City’s vast work force. The $66 million project was to be one of the signature technological innovations of his tenure.

headline: British Lawyer Wants U.S. Hearing on Phone Hacking
text: LONDON — A lawyer representing some of Britain’s phone hacking victims said on Friday that he was planning legal action in the United States against the News Corporation, the parent company of Rupert Murdoch’s global media empire.

headline: Flushing Meadows Welcomes the Aztecs
text: If you happen to be in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens on Saturday morning, head to the shores of Meadow Lake and find the little wooden boat that looks like it was painted by parrots. If it’s yellow, green, red, orange and blue, that’s the one: a trajinera, a replica of a traditional Mexican flat-bottomed barge.

headline: Police Memo on Marijuana Warns Against Some Arrests
text: Amid criticism about the way New York City police officers enforce marijuana laws, Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly issued a memo to commanders this week reiterating that officers are not to arrest people who have small amounts of marijuana in their possession unless it is in public view.

headline: Gilding the Lobster to Celebrate a Watch
text: We had to squint. The light bouncing off the more than 30 carats of tooth-size diamonds on our wrist seared our retinas. Then we had to sit down. The wristwatch we tried on at the opening party for the Swiss watch company Vacheron Constantin’s first American shop, on Madison Avenue, on Tuesday night cost $905,000.

headline: Distinctive Mission for Muslims’ Conference: Remembering the Holocaust
text: One afternoon this week, President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran addressed the United Nations General Assembly, once again casting doubt that the Holocaust had occurred. Almost exactly 24 hours earlier, an otherwise obscure college student in Morocco named Elmehdi Boudra was convening a conference devoted not to denying the Holocaust but to remembering it.

headline: Cuomo Rejects Bill Legalizing Fireworks Sales
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo vetoed on Friday legislation that would have legalized sparklers and other similar types of small fireworks across the state, except in New York City, citing safety concerns.

headline: California: Muslim Students Guilty
text: A jury in Orange County found a group of 10 Muslim students guilty of two misdemeanors for conspiring to interrupt a speech by the Israeli ambassador to the United States at the University of California, Irvine. Prosecutors argued that the ambassador, Michael Oren, had been silenced after several students interrupted with coordinated shouts of protest. The defense lawyers for the group of Muslim students said that they had simply engaged in a typical form of protest and were being unfairly singled out by the district attorney. The judge ruled that the students would have to serve 56 hours of community service and up to three years of probation.

headline: Big 12 Exploring Options
text: Chuck Neinas, the Big 12’s interim commissioner, said there was some resistance among Missouri’s Board of Curators about remaining in the conference. “You’ve got to be concerned about it,” he said, adding, “I do believe in the end it will be resolved and that those issues are going to be addressed.”

headline: Labor Department Postpones Guest Workers’ Wage Increase
text: The Labor Department late Thursday announced a 60-day delay in wage increases for foreign guest workers under the federal H-2B program. Employers in the program have argued that the steep and sudden increases, scheduled to take effect Sept. 30, could put many of them out of business, costing American jobs. Louisiana employers sued the department, and Senators Mary L. Landrieu of Louisiana and Barbara A. Mikulski of Maryland, both Democrats, said they would try to have the wage increases canceled.

headline: 35 Cookies, 7 Biscotti and ...
text: For several years, Beldotti Bakery has been one of the most popular stands at New Canaan’s Saturday Farmers Market. So its nondescript home in the Newfield Shopping Plaza in Stamford is a bit surprising. Even with three small tessera-topped tables out front, Beldotti, tucked next to a vacant storefront at the far left end of the strip, is easy to overlook. Until you get inside, that is, where the talents of its bakers are immediately evident.

headline: Spain’s Big Flavors, in Small Portions
text: SMALL plates are not the only offerings at Bistro Mediterranean and Tapas Bar, but the kitchen turns out such a delicious and diverse collection that they are impossible to resist.

headline: Rhode Island: New Fiscal Plan for Bankrupt Central Falls
text: The state-appointed receiver in Central Falls has submitted a plan to return the bankrupt city to solvency over the next five years, in part by sharply reducing benefits for public employees and retirees. The plan needs approval from a bankruptcy judge, and could change, depending on the outcome of negotiations with the city’s labor unions. In addition to cutting pension and health benefits, it seeks to raise property taxes and restructure certain city departments. The city has already reduced its work force by 32 percent since May 2010. The receiver, Robert G. Flanders, said the plan would ensure balanced budgets starting in 2013.

headline: Congress Questions Union on H.G.H. Test Timetable
text: With negotiations to begin a program to test N.F.L. players for human growth hormone at a standstill, 14 members of Congress, led by the former N.F.L. quarterback Heath Shuler, have sent a letter to Commissioner Roger Goodell and the union chief DeMaurice Smith asking for an explanation of their positions on the test and an expected start date for the testing.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
text: An Activist and a Canal

headline: Tribute in White for Cricket Patriarch
text: THE crisp white of the cricket uniform is a familiar sight on Sundays in Richmond Hill, Queens, but on Monday it was mixed with black. Traffic clogged the roads around the stately St. Paul’s Lutheran Church as hundreds of people streamed in for the funeral of the cricket umpire everyone knew as Uncle Jerry.

headline: It Takes a Village
text: Around the corner came a little golden ball of sunshine named Madison, dressed head to toe in pink, hair arranged in Afro puffs, one wrist covered in turquoise beaded bracelets, arms opened wide. She wrapped those arms around a teacher’s legs, hugged them close and looked up with the kind of smile that sets the world right.

headline: Midwest Farmers Are on Alert Against Pig Thieves
text: LAFAYETTE, Minn. — Here in pig country, the pigs are vanishing.

headline: Reyes Playing What Could Be Final Games as a Met
text: The Mets’ six-game homestand to close their season may represent Jose Reyes’s final games in the team’s uniform. And Reyes, who will be a free agent after this season, said it was inevitable for such thoughts to cross his mind.

headline: It’s a Giant Person! And It’s a Tree? It’s Art
text: Katonah, N.Y.

headline: Bloggingheads: Are Green Jobs a Scam?
text: Katherine Mangu-Ward, left, of Reason and Erica Grieder of The Economist debate the economics of "green jobs."

headline: Jets’ Defense Wounded With Loss of Revis
text: A capsule look at the Jets’ 23-20 win in overtime against the Dolphins on Sunday.

headline: ‘Much Ado,’ With Summer Suits and Sundresses
text: Imagine a pretty patio outside an Italian villa on a summer day in the 1920s (or at least in some calm, more gracious time between the world wars). An aria is playing on the gramophone. A tray full of wine glasses is on the dining table. The men are in light summer suits; the women in sundresses or sportswear. In this bucolic setting, two couples fall in love, although it takes some work to get one of the couples to admit it.

headline: In Picasso Etchings, a Focused Look at an Artist in Flux
text: Pablo Picasso needs no introduction, but you do have to orient yourself whenever you touch down on a body of his work. After all, he lived through multiple wars, artistic revolutions and domestic regimes. He worked in several mediums, helped invent one (collage) and marveled over another (cinema). However, the beauty of “Picasso’s Vollard Suite: The Sculptor’s Studio,” on view at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich, is that it doesn’t require an extensive Picasso review to understand. Instead, it focuses on a small body of work — a group of etchings made from 1933 to 1934 — that encapsulate many of the artist’s concerns during that period.

headline: Invitation to an Exhibition: Let the Mentoring Begin
text: Juried exhibitions, in which the works have been selected from a pool of submissions, used to be more common, although artists have long expressed conflicted feelings about them. They are one of the best ways for little-known artists to get their work shown in major museums or galleries, yet charges of favoritism and nepotism have dogged juried exhibitions for centuries.

headline: Oscar Handlin, Historian Who Chronicled U.S. Immigration, Dies at 95
text: Oscar Handlin, a prolific, Pulitzer Prize-winning historian whose best-known book altered public perceptions about the role of immigration in the arc of American history, died on Tuesday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 95.

headline: A Minister With an Eye for Images
text: THE title of the current exhibition at the Southold Historical Society, “The Versatile Reverend,” aptly describes its subject, a man who was both a clergyman and a professional photographer. “He was a very busy minister,” said Geoffrey K. Fleming, the director of the Southold Historical Society, discussing the Rev. Loren A. Rowley (1858-1918), a Baptist minister and sometime photographer whose work is on display at the Society through Oct. 9.

headline: Fleeing Home, With the Promise of Safety Uncertain
text: As Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s forces left Tawerga, virtually all estimated 30,000 residents fled, fearing reprisal from neighbors in Misurata.

headline: Pope Visits Venerated Lutheran Monastery
text: BERLIN — Pope Benedict XVI made a historic visit on Friday to the monastery where Martin Luther studied before he initiated the Reformation that led to a split from the Catholic Church nearly 500 years ago.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
text: A look at some of the long-form journalism we have been reading this week:

headline: Being Comfortable in Your Own Skin (Tone)
text: I am Indian – but after more than 15 years of living abroad, some aspects of Indian life feel fresh, if not new or altogether welcome.

headline: Gunmen Storm Police Training School in Pakistan
text: Elite police forces recaptured a police training school after four gunmen took it over in an eight-hour siege near Lahore, Pakistan.

headline: Satellite Ends Fall, Likely in the Pacific
text: A dead NASA satellite, intently tracked by people around the world over the last couple of days, finally fell back to Earth — and it may turn out that no one will ever know when and where it fell.

headline: New York on the Sound Stage
text: New York is a changeling, a different city to everyone who passes through. The premiere of the fall TV season will reflect that: Just last month, a record 23 prime-time shows filmed here, thanks in part to recent tax breaks.

headline: Violence Surges in Yemen Despite Call for Cease-Fire
text: SANA, Yemen — A day after President Ali Abdullah Saleh returned to this battered country calling for a cease-fire, his forces escalated attacks on the opposition on Saturday, leaving more than 40 people dead across the capital.

headline: The Weekend Word: Sequel
text: Today’s Times

headline: The Case for Buying Low on Perry
text: The political betting market Intrade, as of this writing, gives Mitt Romney a 44 percent chance of winning the Republican nomination. I have been pretty bullish on Mitt Romney’s chances of securing the nomination for several months now, and I would probably be a buyer at that price.

headline: Rogue Trading Leads UBS Chief to Resign
text: LONDON — The Swiss banking giant UBS said on Saturday that its chief executive, Oswald J. Grübel, had resigned over a rogue trading scandal that shook the European banking sector and raised new questions about the adequacy of financial regulation.

headline: Putin Once More Moves to Assume Top Job in Russia
text: MOSCOW — Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin, who transformed post-Soviet Russia by imposing Kremlin control over most aspects of public life, moved on Saturday to return to the presidency and could remain until 2024, giving him a rule comparable in length with that of Brezhnev or Stalin.

headline: Arrest in Air Gun Shooting Near Pope’s Mass in Germany
text: BERLIN — The German police said Saturday that they had arrested a man suspected of shooting a security guard with an air gun in the eastern city of Erfurt shortly before Pope Benedict XVI was about to celebrate Mass.

headline: Bookshelf
text: The Italian auteur Paolo Sorrentino’s first novel,  “Everybody’s Right” (Europa Editions, $15), is about an aging musician, a nightclub crooner who loses his mind in Brazil after his starlight begins to dim. It has parallels with his latest film “This Must Be the Place,” a similarly strange tale in which Sean Penn plays a catatonic, lipsticked rock star in the Robert Smith mold.

headline: Radioactivity in Japan Rice Raises Worries
text: TOKYO — Government officials on Saturday ordered more tests after detecting elevated levels of radiation in rice crops near the crippled nuclear power plant at Fukushima.

headline: Solving the Financial Crisis
text: Never mind all the bleak stuff I’ve been writing lately. A solution is at hand! All we need to do is use some of those faster-than-light neutrinos to send a message to the past, warning them not to deregulate (and not to let Greece join the euro).

headline: Europe Seeks to Ratchet Up Effort on Debt
text: WASHINGTON — Under increasing pressure from global investors and world leaders, European government officials indicated Saturday that they were working to intensify their response to the continent’s growing debt problems. It was an acknowledgment, after weeks of public stonewalling, that a plan announced in July had failed to calm financial markets.

headline: Bully for the Baltics?
text: I’ve noted that Tyler Cowen and others seem, mysteriously, to believe that any uptick in Irish GDP somehow refutes Keynesian analysis; I’ve been seeing a lot of similar stuff about the Baltic nations, whose experience is supposed to prove that austerity works.

headline: The Unsinkable Donatella Versace
text: A nice aqua glow bathed the stone walls of the Versace headquarters on Via Gesu, formerly the palazzo home of Gianni Versace. The runway was a white glassy streak and the first models — Lindsey, Nyasha, Abbey Lee — came out with bouncy curls and pure white outfits tipped in pale sea prints.

headline: Old-School Cornerbacks Have Taught a New Generation
text: One day during his rookie season with San Diego in 2006, Antonio Cromartie sat mesmerized in front of a television. His position coach, Kevin Ross, had summoned him to watch two cornerbacks who set the standard for excellence. Finding videotape was easy: they played for the same team, at the same time.

headline: After Cancer, an Ex-Prodigy Was Undrafted but Unbowed
text: WAYNE, Pa. — Before Mark Herzlich became the linebacker who overcame cancer, he was another football prodigy with a familiar dream.

headline: Actually, Citi Field Is Not That Bad for the Mets
text: It appears that three seasons of pinning the Mets’ offensive problems on the ballpark have finally led to action. General Manager Sandy Alderson said last week that the team would decide next month about adjusting the dimensions of the widely criticized Citi Field, and “If we do something, it won’t be subtle.”

headline: Vettel Takes Pole, Moves Closer to Title
text: SINGAPORE — It is a good thing that the images on local television of the Formula One track and cars and the Singapore skyline at night were beautiful. Because the qualifying session of the Singapore Grand Prix was not.

headline: Variety:  A Calculating Acrostic
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — Setting aside how much I hate calculus and never understood a thing they tried to teach me in that class (I think they passed me mostly because they just felt sorry for me), I really enjoyed this Acrostic. It’s always intriguing to hear personal anecdotes about people who lived so long ago, and it’s confirmation that while times may change, people stay relatively the same.

headline: Live Analysis: College Football Week Four
text: Paul Myerberg will be reporting on all of the day’s action in college football. Check back throughout the day for updates and analysis, to ask questions or to give us your observations, whether from your couch or from the bleachers. You can also follow Paul on Twitter for additional updates throughout the afternoon and evening.

headline: New Zealand and England Roll to Wins in World Cup
text: Host New Zealand beat France, 37-17, on Saturday in the Rugby World Cup to take control of its group, while England moved clear in its group by routing Romania, 67-3.

headline: N.F.L. Sees Signs That Players Think Before They Hit

headline: Road Food, Bad Food
text: The photographer Daniel Borris found that American road food is one long highway of plastic sameness — not only is nothing healthy, but nothing is different.

headline: Sport Grows, and Grows More Perilous
text: MONTREAL — When the Belgian cyclist Wouter Weylandt was killed in a crash during the Giro d’Italia in May, the commemoration began immediately. Each rider wore a black ribbon, and Weylandt’s initials and race number, 108, were painted across the remaining finish lines and appeared at the bottom of the official results with the slogan Always With Us.

headline: With Woods in, 3 on Bubble for Presidents Cup
text: ATLANTA — After the second round of his final audition for the United States’ Presidents Cup team, Bill Haas met the squad’s assistant captain, who told him, “You played really well.”

headline: Who’s That Girl?
text: As I was walking down Via Bigli just before noon, on my way to a Ferragamo preview appointment, a black sedan pulled up outside a gray stone building and a pair of bodyguards materialized on either side of the car. I saw a flash of blond hair through the side window, on a woman drinking from a water bottle, and thought for a moment that it was Donatella Versace. But as soon as the doors opened, I realized that it was Lindsay Lohan.

headline: 30 Seconds With Joe Namath
text: Joe Namath led the Jets to an upset over the Baltimore Colts in Super Bowl III, the team’s only championship. This year’s Topps football cards capture the greatest players and moments in Super Bowl history. Some cards contain codes that can be entered in the Super Bowl Legends Giveaway at toppslegends.com for a chance to win prizes, including a card signed by Namath, 68, who was in Manhattan recently to promote the contest.

headline: Remembering Orlando Brown the Football Player
text: He may be remembered more for his lawsuit against the N.F.L., but few players got more out of what they were given than Orlando Brown. He achieved his potential. Brown was found dead on Friday in his apartment in Baltimore. He was 40 years old:

headline: Libyan Fighters Renew Attack on Qaddafi’s Hometown
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Fighters trying to root out loyalists of the fugitive Libyan leader Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi renewed their attack on his hometown, Surt, on Saturday as his daughter Aisha became the latest family member to broadcast a recorded taunt of the provisional authorities struggling to replace his government.

headline: Speculators Get a Break in New Rule
text: A LOAF of whole wheat. A gallon of gasoline. A pair of Levi’s. Americans are paying more for many basic items this year, making tough economic times even tougher.

headline: As Red Sox Keep Sinking, True Fans Suffer With a Smile
text: The torrential rain that ultimately doomed Friday night’s Yankees-Red Sox game was gloomy enough. But the atmosphere in the grand ballroom of the Yale Club, where the Blohards had assembled that afternoon for their semiannual luncheon, seemed grimmer still: greeting diners on a gigantic screen by the dais was a picture of a man in a Red Sox shirt, poised to jump off Boston’s Tobin Bridge.

headline: Robots Extract Coolant From Old Refrigerators
text: RECYCLING refrigerators — especially those made more than 15 years ago — is a tricky job. The coolant in old appliances (now banned from newer versions) can cause serious trouble, warming the atmosphere and depleting the ozone layer.

headline: Amid Baseball’s Ups and Downs, a Definite Drop
text: The string of numbers looks as if it could have come from any major league baseball season in the past decade. Batting average: .266. On-base percentage: .336. Runs per game: 4.51.
