text: LONDON — Scotland’s chief prosecutor has asked Libya’s new government to assist in tracking down documentary evidence and witnesses for a possible new trial for those responsible for the Lockerbie airliner bombing.

headline: Sharing Burdens of Living With AIDS
text: NKONDEDZI, Mozambique — Rogerio Bernardo slung a black satchel over his shoulder and waited by the roadside in the morning mist for a bush taxi. In dusty wingtips, frayed pants and a gray pinstripe suit coat so big it swallowed his slender frame, he looked like any peasant farmer dressed up for a trip to town.

headline: Netflix to Stream DreamWorks Films
text: David Carr and Brian Stelter discuss a new deal whereby Netflix will stream DreamWorks Animation movies for home viewing. The agreement is billed by the companies as the first time a major Hollywood supplier has chosen Web streaming over pay television.

headline: City Opera Fills In Blanks in Its Schedule
text: The New York City Opera on Monday filled in some blanks in the schedule for its peripatetic season. Its fall concert, on Nov. 17, will feature the songs of Rufus Wainwright at the Rose Theater. Opera singers and Mr. Wainwright will perform. The company is giving his opera “Prima Donna” its American premiere in February at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. City Opera said on Monday that Jayce Ogren would conduct “Prima Donna,” and that Rebecca Taichman would direct the previously disclosed production of Telemann’s “Orpheus” at the Museo del Barrio in May. The company, which announced in the spring that it was leaving Lincoln Center, presented most of its sharply reduced season at a news conference in July.

headline: Chelsea Clinton Joins Board of Diller’s IAC
text: Chelsea Clinton has joined the board of IAC/InterActiveCorp, the Internet media company controlled by Barry Diller.

headline: That’s a Lot of Veggies
text: Dolce & Gabbana’s prints of zucchini and other vegetables brought to mind Prada’s bananas (and monkeys) as well as Stella McCartney’s lemons from a year ago, in both color and spirit. Apparently the planting season isn’t over.

headline: Huntsman Spot in Oct. 18 Debate Endangered
text: Jon Huntsman, the former governor of Utah, has been in every presidential debate since he threw his hat in the ring last June.

headline: Cuomo Vows to Broker Deal for Hailing Livery Cabs
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo pledged on Monday to help broker a deal on a bill that would make it legal to hail livery cabs on most New York City streets, giving new momentum to a plan whose political support had flagged in recent days.

headline: Dialing Back the Clocks to the Court of Louis XIV
text: The landmark production of Lully’s “Atys” that the expatriate American early-music pioneer William Christie conducted at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in 1989 and 1992 was a groundbreaking experience for many listeners, offering tantalizing insights into the relatively unfamiliar genre of French Baroque opera. The work’s sumptuous delights made a similarly impressive splash last week, when Mr. Christie and his ensemble, Les Arts Florissants, returned to the academy with a re-creation of this decadently costumed and choreographed production.

headline: Far From Any Lab, Paper Bits Find Illness
text: BOSTON — While other scientists successfully shrank beakers, tubes and centrifuges into diagnostic laboratories that fit into aluminum boxes that cost $50,000, George Whitesides had smaller dreams.

headline: Christie Blocks Tax Credit for ‘Jersey Shore’
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey on Monday blocked a $420,000 tax credit that the state’s Economic Development Authority had approved last week.

headline: Jets Bring Injuries Back From Oakland
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. – The Jets announced Monday that quarterback Mark Sanchez sustained a minor break in his nose in the Jets’ 34-24 loss to the Raiders on Sunday and will have to wear a visor for a few weeks.

headline: Mining the Mother Lode of Elizabethan Composers
text: Kenneth Weiss, though born and trained in New York, has built a distinguished career in Europe as a harpsichordist and opera conductor. Lately, he has also spent a lot of time at the Juilliard School, where he is on the faculty of the historical performance program and where his performances both as a continuo harpsichordist in Juilliard Baroque and as a recitalist have been ear-catching and edifying: most notably, in a dramatic traversal of Bach’s “Goldberg” Variations in January.

headline: Discriminating Against the Unemployed?
text: The Times has just published an article about a provision in President Obama’s jobs bill that would prohibit employers from discriminating against job applicants because they are unemployed. The article reports:

headline: Autonomy C.E.O.: We Are Still H.P.’s Future
text: If Hewlett-Packard’s ouster last week of its chief executive means software is no longer front and center in the company’s future, no one told Mike Lynch, the chief executive of Autonomy.

headline: Message Meets the Marketplace
text: Take debut albums with a grain of salt these days, especially in hip-hop, where the robustness of the mixtape circuit and the Internet as a promotion vehicle have ensured that artists begin to form their identities and have entire careers long before the vampiric record business has its way with them. As they are, debut albums — with other people’s hands in the pie — tend to show artists who’ve been reformed and remolded. What other people want from them, it often turns out, isn’t what they wanted from themselves.

headline: On Obama Turf, A Plea for Clinton Intervention
text: LOS ANGELES—As the president’s motorcade whisks him from Los Angeles International Airport to West Hollywood for the first of two fund-raisers on Monday night, he may notice signs of dissatisfaction: Posters of Mr. Obama’s secretary of state, Hillary Rodham Clinton, have been plastered around the city, with the caption “Save Us Hillary.”

headline: Seduction, Sometimes With a Shout
text: A veneer of dreaminess hangs over the music of Porcelain Raft, the one-man project of Mauro Remiddi. He sings emotional declarations with a quaver, over gentle and astral music that sounds as if it were being played at a distance, just out of direct earshot.

headline: TimesCast | Protesting to What End
text: September 26, 2011 - Protesters occupy a park near Wall Street for a second week, despite arrests and no clear message.

headline: Framing Works With Dance, Words, Screens and Web Browsers
text: Musicians who grew up in the age of television and rock shows have become increasingly intent on replacing the stand-and-play recital format with technologically and conceptually fresher approaches. The Kronos Quartet, Ethel and the cellist Maya Beiser have been presenting semistaged programs for years, often with video and computer sound, and productions of that sort have become the standard at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Next Wave Festival.

headline: For Neonatal Jaundice, a New Option in Resource-Poor Nations
text: Neonatal jaundice, a condition caused by excess bilirubin in the blood, affects most babies in the first few days of life when their livers are just beginning to function. It gives the skin a yellowish tint, but normally it goes away after a week or two without treatment, and the condition has no lasting consequences.

headline: Safe Birth Kits to Reduce Infant Mortality
text: Babies arrive in this world on their own blissful schedules, regardless of war or natural disasters — or the availability of a doctor.

headline: The Small Fixes Challenge
text: Do you think you could help solve one of the world's health problems? Take our Small Fixes Challenge!

headline: Brewing Up Double-Edged Delicacies for Mosquitoes
text: On what food do mosquitoes live? Orgiastic gouts of human blood that distend their abdomens and render them almost unable to move — right?

headline: Folding Saris to Filter Cholera-Contaminated Water
text: Rural Bangladeshi women often pour sweetened drinks through a piece of sari cloth to get rid of leaves, insects and other visible debris. But disease-causing micro-organisms are thousands of times smaller than the pores in the fabric and slip right through.

headline: Self-Adjustable Eyeglass Lenses
text: In developed countries, getting glasses is a simple matter: Visit an optometrist, get a prescription and have it filled at a corner store. Not so in the developing world, where there are few optometrists and little money for luxuries like eyeglasses.

headline: LifeStraw Saves Those Without Access to Clean Drinking Water
text: More than a billion people don’t have reliable access to clean drinking water. Boiling kills most germs in water, but requires fuel and doesn’t remove dirt. In recent years, sand and ceramic filters have become more common, but these tend to be more expensive and usually don’t catch all the microbes.

headline: A Way to Check That Drugs Are Not Counterfeit
text: Counterfeit drugs are a $200 billion industry worldwide. In some countries, up to half of all medicines available at pharmacies are fake or low-quality. Each year more than half a million people worldwide die while using bad drugs to treat malaria and tuberculosis alone.

headline: The PeePoo, a Biodegradable Toilet for the Developing World
text: It looks like a plastic bag, but in fact the PeePoo is a single-use biodegradable toilet for the developing world. After it is used, the bag is knotted and then buried or sold back to the manufacturer. A lining of urea crystals in the bag helps transform the waste into fertilizer.

headline: An Entrepreneur Creating Chances at a Better Life
text: If necessity is the mother of invention, Paul Polak is one of its fathers.

headline: Kits Using Naloxone Revive Addicts After Opiate Overdose
text: Next to car crashes, opiate overdoses are the leading cause of accidental death in the United States. In Europe, a lethal overdose occurs every hour.

headline: Fighting Cervical Cancer With Vinegar and Ingenuity
text: POYAI,  Thailand — Maikaew Panomyai did a little dance coming out of the examination room, switching her hips, waving her fists in the air and crowing, in her limited English: “Everything’s O.K.! Everything’s O.K.!”

headline: The Simplest Health Solutions? It’s Complicated
text: It’s not that the American health system is completely deficient in small, clever, inexpensive fixes. It’s just that sometimes they’re awfully hard to find.

headline: Shades of Race
text: Our design director, Arem Duplessis, designed this week’s cover of the Book Review. Take a closer look here.

headline: Like a Wetsuit, but It Can Save a Hemorrhaging Mother
text: In poor countries, women tend to give birth at home or in small clinics. If a mother suffers from bleeding in such a setting, she risks shock, organ failure and eventually death. Short of an airlift to a hospital where transfusions and surgery are available, there is often little to be done.

headline: Volunteers Forge Better Care in Thailand’s Villages
text: BAAN MAE PING, Thailand — The ailments that bedeviled past generations in this mountainside hamlet are fading away. The parasite that causes malaria has been vanquished from the surrounding jungles, and villagers say it has been years since a baby died before turning 1 year old, once a common heartbreak.

headline: A Household Shower From Hardware-Store Staples
text: Showering with soap and water is more than just comforting; it can reduce the chances that a child who plays in filthy gutters gets sick. But for many people in developing countries, showers are an unaffordable luxury.

headline: Obstacles Slow an Easy Way to Prevent H.I.V. in Men
text: One of the most promising, proven methods for preventing H.I.V. in Africa is being implemented much more slowly than international health authorities recommended.

headline: Micronutrient Vitamin Powders for Children
text: Babies cannot swallow vitamin pills, but in the developing world, there are many who need the nutritional boost that vitamins can provide.

headline: How Tiny Errors in Africa Led to a Global Triumph
text: When I helped run a measles immunization program in West Africa in the 1960s, I learned that in global health small things can spell the difference between a major success and a colossal failure.

headline: Helping Newborns Breathe, No Spanking Required
text: Many babies, especially premature ones, have trouble breathing. They can sometimes be jump-started by massage (which replaced the old tradition of smacking a baby’s bottom to make it cry) or with a neonatal respirator.

headline: Drugs to Curb a Deadly Inheritance
text: The medicines that prevent the transmission of H.I.V. from mother to child are highly effective when they are used properly — that is, taken at the right time in gestation and in the right doses by both mother and newborn. But in resource-poor countries, mothers often give birth at home and rarely visit health clinics. So the problem is getting the medicines to the mothers and babies who need them, and making sure the doses and timing are right.

headline: Setting the Stage Alight With Fleeting Flames
text: The Brazilian artist Michel Groisman devises what could best be described as intimate performance installations. In “Porta das Mãos,” or “Door of Hands,” he shows the possibilities of hand movement when certain fingers are restricted. His interactive pieces encourage family attendance; two of the works he presented at the Invisible Dog Art Center in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, last weekend were recommended for those 6 to 12. (This is hardly the norm in experimental performance.) On Friday night he presented his solo “Transferência” (“Transference”), a corporeal conversation between fire and air.

headline: An Aid Worker Writes: Hope and Exasperation at a Kandahar Hospital
text: Each time I walk along Mirwais’s crowded corridors, or visit the wards bustling with mothers and sick children, it is a new experience. No two visits are ever the same. There are more patients, more anxious mothers, more men gathered in gossiping groups on the stairwells; more prayer beads turning, more busy staff, more noise.

headline: Brunch, With a Menu of Ballads
text: A pianistic meteor shower prefaced the jazz pianist Barbara Carroll’s searching performance of the title song of Kurt Weill and Maxwell Anderson’s 1949 musical “Lost in the Stars” on Sunday afternoon at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel. Even if you didn’t know the words, to hear Ms. Carroll, and her longtime colleague Jay Leonhart on bass, explore this ballad of cosmic loneliness and desolation was to be transported on a metaphysical voyage through time and space toward an unknown destination.

headline: So Far, So Good
text: From Oct. 7 to July 2012, the Centre Pompidou-Metz will present “Bivouac,” a retrospective dedicated to the work of the designers Ronan and Erwan Bouroullec. “It’s like a big family dinner where everybody shows up,” says Erwan (above, seated). The family, in this case, is the brothers’ radically original work, from “Lit Clos” of 2000, a raised, semi-enclosed bed like a bird cage, to “Ploum,” a new sofa for Ligne Roset, which they compare to a very ripe fruit. This is the Bouroullecs’ first major show in their native France, organized by ambience and demarcated by supersize versions of their room-divider designs, including the plastic seaweed-inspired “Algues” and their textile “Clouds”; one long wall will hold nearly 300 drawings. To coincide with the show, Phaidon is releasing a new monograph of their work. “We’re still young, so a celebration of our career is nice but a little anxiety-inducing,” said Ronan, the older of the two, who recently turned 40. “Each time we do an exhibition it feels like: that’s done, let’s move on to something else.” That something else will be a permanent lighting installation for the Gabriel staircase in the Château de Versailles.

headline: Investigations Into the Aggressive Use of Beats
text: Though Greg Fox isn’t a singer, he has been the lungs of the sort-of-metal band Liturgy, from Brooklyn. His drumming often comes in blast-beats, long runs of eighth notes played on snare and cymbal and kick drum, all of them stressed. His playing, like that of Keith Moon and Tony Williams, isn’t just a bottom layer, but a dramatic arc that keeps rising in the song. His beats bounce and swing and breathe, and break out of their own enclosures.

headline: Print Crush
text: Carla Sozzani has been celebrating the 20th anniversary of her shop Corso Como 10, which is still a magnate for editors and retailers attending the shows in Milan. She sent over a little package — I knew instinctively it was chocolates. But the circle-print paper, repeated for the bag and box and candy wrapping, could almost make you forget what was inside. Almost. Happy birthday, Corso Como 10!

headline: For the Bears, a Fake That Was Almost Fabulous
text: Coming soon to a playing field near you is a trick play so clever it’s likely to be imitated on punt returns throughout the land. Green Bay quarterback Aaron Rodgers, speaking for the team that got duped, called it “the most incredible play I’ve ever seen,” a convincing pantomime that left people “wondering what the heck just happened.” His teammate Greg Jennings thought it was “the best play I’ve ever seen.”

headline: Solar Oven Outhouse for Safer Fertilizer
text: Human waste makes good fertilizer, but it can be smelly and dangerous to handle when fresh.

headline: Angry Reaction to Spotify’s New Facebook ID Requirement
text: For months various digital music services have been jealous of the close link that appeared to be developing between Facebook and Spotify, the European company whose cloud music player finally arrived in the United States in July. Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, was a vocal fan of Spotify, and when the social media giant announced a string of new features on Thursday, Daniel Ek, Spotify’s chief, was right there on stage with him.

headline: Oil Spill Affected Gulf Fish’s Cell Function, Study Finds
text: A minnowlike fish that is a major source of food in wetland marshes along the Gulf of Mexico is showing early signs of biological damage from the BP oil spill, a peer-reviewed study published on Monday found.

headline: Touring the Ruins of the Old Economy
text: Michael Lewis possesses the rare storyteller’s ability to make virtually any subject both lucid and compelling. In his new book, “Boomerang,” he actually makes topics like European sovereign debt, the International Monetary Fund and the European Central Bank not only comprehensible but also fascinating — even, or especially, to readers who rarely open the business pages or watch CNBC. The book could not be more timely given the worries about Europe’s deepening debt crisis and the recent warning issued by Christine Lagarde, managing director of the I.M.F, that “the current economic situation is entering a dangerous phase.”

headline: History That’s Written in Beads as Well as in Words
text: Distressed by most historians’ overwhelming preoccupation with the modern world, an unusual coalition of scholars is trying to stage an intellectual coup, urging their colleagues to look up from the relatively recent swirl of bloody conflicts, global financial exchanges and technological wonders and gaze further back, toward humanity’s origins.

headline: Obama and ‘Young Guns’ Make Silicon Valley Pitches
text: 8:15 p.m. | Updated Six miles from where President Obama held a Town Hall on Monday with LinkedIn’s executives in Mountain View, Calif., to discuss his jobs plan, the House Republican leaders who describe themselves as “The Young Guns” gathered at Facebook’s headquarters for a 6 p.m. ET live discussion on their vision of what needs to be done to jumpstart the economy.

headline: TimesCast: Wall Street Protests Continue
text: Protesters in downtown Manhattan continued to occupy a park near Wall Street and have organized themselves for a prolonged stay.

headline: cancer embed
text: cancer embed

headline: Albums by Mindless Behavior and LeAnn Rimes
text: MINDLESS BEHAVIOR

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘The Gambler’
text: In this week’s Critics’ Picks video, A. O. Scott looks back at the 1974 film “The Gambler,” directed by Karel Reisz.

headline: It’s Easy to See It Raf Simons’s Way
text: MILAN

headline: Sheen Settles ‘Two and a Half Men’ Suit
text: The protracted conflict betweenCharlie Sheen and Warner Brothers Television ended quietly on Monday when the two sides agreed to settle a lawsuit the actor filed after the studio fired him from the hit CBS sitcom, “Two and a Half Men.”

headline: Wall Street Ties Bring Peril for Democratic Lawmaker
text: Jim Himes, a second-term congressman from Connecticut, is a surviving member of one of Washington’s most endangered species: a Democrat with Wall Street ties.

headline: Facebook Forms a PAC
text: Facebook wants more friends. And it’s willing to pay for them.

headline: Four Syrian Soldiers Reported Killed in Escape Attempt
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian security forces killed four soldiers on Monday as they attempted to escape a military camp, and the army tightened its grip on towns across the country to quell dissent against the government of President Bashar al-Assad, activists said.

headline: After the Palestinian Bid at the U.N.
text: To the Editor:

headline: KidTech: Glasses With a Videocamera Inside
text: The dream of concealing a tiny video camera inside a pair of glasses dates back to the days of Dick Tracy, but these days a child can have the real thing, with the Spy Net Stealth Recording Video Glasses, in toy stores this month from Jakks Pacific. And they really work.

headline: Turkish Paper Lists Israelis It Says Were in Flotilla Raid
text: ISTANBUL — A Turkish newspaper published the names and photographs on Monday of more than 140 Israeli soldiers who the paper said took part in the raid on a Turkish flotilla to Gaza last year that ended with the death of nine passengers and created a diplomatic standoff between Turkey and Israel.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,468 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,769 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Full Appeals Court Won’t Be Asked to Rule on Health Care Law
text: The Justice Department announced on Monday that it would not ask the full Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit to reconsider a three-judge panel’s ruling against the 2010 health care law. That presumably leaves the government to appeal its loss directly to the Supreme Court, although Tracy Schmaler, a Justice Department spokeswoman, declined to comment on the next steps. The Supreme Court has already received one of the multitude of federal cases challenging the constitutionality of the law’s individual insurance mandate. It arrived in July from the Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, in Cincinnati, which upheld that provision on a 2-to-1 ruling. A month later, the Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, in Atlanta, ruled 2 to 1 against the mandate.

headline: Indiana: Five Bodies Found In Two Neighboring Houses
text: Law enforcement officers on Monday were investigating the deaths of five adults whose bodies were found on Sunday afternoon in a rural area of southeast Indiana. The bodies were discovered near Laurel, southeast of Indianapolis, after someone noticed a child wandering alone in a roadway and called law enforcement authorities for help. Officials searching the area found five bodies — one man at one house, and two men and two women at another house across the street. At least some of them had been shot, the authorities said. The state police said it was unclear whether more than one person had fired a gun, or whether anyone who fired the gun was among the dead. Still, they advised local residents to take extra precautions as the investigation continued.

headline: Nikon Joins the Mirrorless Movement
text: Nikon has joined the ranks of camera manufacturers trying to pull of a neat trick — building a compact camera that combines the photographic quality of an SLR with the simplicity of a point-and-shoot.

headline: Doctors Who Give Good Care, and Are Caring
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Group Treatment for AIDS
text: Patient groups share the burdens of living with AIDS.

headline: The Wall Street Protest
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rangers Land in Winter Classic, Then in an On-Ice Controversy
text: PHILADELPHIA — Monday was a busy day for the Rangers: a lunchtime visit to Citizens Bank Park here for the announcement of the Jan. 2 Rangers-Flyers Winter Classic and the HBO “24/7” series leading to it; a final preseason game before a late-night flight to Europe and a hectic series of matches crisscrossing that continent; and new questions about the status of defenseman Marc Staal.

headline: In Defense of Pakistan
text: To the Editor:

headline: When Comics Depict Mental Illness
text: To the Editor:

headline: Making Title Easier to Figure, if Not to Win
text: ATLANTA

headline: Alabama Inmate Sues to Read Southern History Book
text: The past is never dead, though at the Kilby Correctional Facility outside of Montgomery, Ala., it seems it is not particularly welcome.

headline: Japan: Aides Convicted in Campaign Finance Case
text: A court on Monday convicted three former aides of Ichiro Ozawa, the embattled Japanese political kingmaker, of charges related to political campaign financing. The convictions dealt Mr. Ozawa a setback just as his own trial in the scandal was set to begin next week. The aides were sentenced to as many as three years in prison for misreporting almost $6 million in Mr. Ozawa’s political funds. Widely credited with engineering the governing Democratic Party’s historic victory two years ago, Mr. Ozawa’s backroom-style of politics has made him the target of repeated investigations by prosecutors.

headline: China: Officers Suspended in Sex Slave Case
text: Four police officers in the city of Luoyang in Henan Province have been suspended because of negligence in the case of a former firefighter who imprisoned six women in a dungeon, raped them and forced them to be prostitutes and perform erotic shows on the Internet, according to an article in China Daily, an English-language newspaper. The suspect, Li Hao, has been accused of killing two of the women.

headline: MSNBC Is Close to Falling to Third Place in Cable News Ratings
text: How badly has MSNBC been hurt by the loss of Keith Olbermann? Enough, apparently, to be on the verge of falling back into third place among the cable news networks.

headline: Kodak Stock Dives After Credit Line Is Tapped
text: Eastman Kodak has been struggling to reinvent itself for decades. So when Antonio M. Perez, the chief executive, announced in July that he was confident that Kodak could transform itself into a profitable and sustainable digital company by 2012, many investors were skeptical.

headline: Dylan Paintings Draw Scrutiny
text: The freewheeling artistic style of Bob Dylan, who has drawn on a variety of sources in creating his music and has previously raised questions of attribution in his work, is once again stirring debate — this time over an exhibition of his paintings at the Gagosian Gallery on the Upper East Side.

headline: Replacements Help Re-energize Giants
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Mario Manningham was confined to the sofa Sunday, a concussion leaving him little choice but to watch his team play the Philadelphia Eagles alongside his girlfriend and his 15-month-old son, Mario Jr.

headline: Alcohol Isn’t Worth the Trouble for Some Chain Restaurants
text: Some restaurant chains are turning to the bottle during the rough economy, but the liquoring up has produced mostly headaches, not happiness.

headline: Bloggingheads: Endless Progress
text: John Horgan, left, of Scientific American and David Deutsch of the University of Oxford discuss the future of human progress.

headline: A Better Way to Fix No Child Left Behind
text: Washington

headline: A ‘Diversity Bake Sale’ Backfires on Campus
text: BERKELEY, Calif. — A bake sale sponsored by a Republican student group at the University of California, Berkeley, has incited anger and renewed the debate over affirmative action by asking students to pay different prices for pastry, depending on their race and sex.

headline: To Save on Health Care, First Crack Down on Fraud
text: Santa Barbara, Calif.

headline: Gas Flaring in North Dakota
text: Every day across the western half of North Dakota 100 million cubic feet of natural gas is deliberately burned by oil companies rushing to extract oil from the Bakken shale field and take advantage of the high price of crude. The gas bubbles up alongside the oil, and with less economic incentive to capture it, the drillers treat the gas as waste and simply burn it.

headline: Declaring an Arrival, With a Little Help From New Yorkers
text: EVERYONE recognizes “I ♥ NY” and its variants like “I (Red Cross) NY,” “I (Tropicana orange) NY” and “I (Apple) NY.” An initiative to mark the arrival of a Chicago agency in New York City takes the form of “I (cursor) NY.”

headline: Facebook iPad App Still Snagged in Negotiations
text: It was almost ready to make its long-awaited debut.

headline: Factory Field Trip
text: Charlotte, N.C.

headline: Hotel Rates, in Some Cities, Seem Fully Recovered
text: MONDAY morning, I was looking out my home office window in Tucson at Big Red, parked beside a 25-foot saguaro. Big Red is my beloved 1994 Ford F-150 pickup truck, purchased last winter for $500 from friends who were no longer using it. It has 298,818 miles on the odometer, and it still runs beautifully — like any good old F-150.

headline: A Governing Coalition, Increasingly, of the Unwilling
text: LONDON — With the leaders of both parties in the governing coalition pledged to uphold their pact until a new election in 2015, Britain, at least on the face of it, has the basis for political stability as it wrestles with the financial crisis roiling Europe and the apparent drift of Britain’s own economy toward stagnation.

headline: Red Sox Stagger, Trip and Fall Into a Tie
text: BALTIMORE — Boston Red Sox fans were already making their presence felt by midafternoon Monday, in the bars across the street from Camden Yards, or circling the ballpark perimeter, red-shirted and red-faced over their sad September state of affairs.

headline: After Feisty Fund-Raising, a More Sociable Obama
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — President Obama met his dream date on Monday at a town hall meeting in Silicon Valley: a balding, soft-spoken former Google employee who said he was so rich he did not have to work anymore and begged Mr. Obama to raise his taxes.

headline: Managers Pushed for Fake Job-Placement Numbers, Ex-Workers Say
text: “Despite the downturn in the economy, our Workforce1 career centers are on pace to match last year’s record-setting total of more than 17,000 job placements. But we can do more.”

headline: In Turn to Politics, Facebook Starts a PAC
text: Facebook wants more friends. And it is willing to pay for them.

headline: Medal of Honor Recipient Gets Extension for Fire Dept. Application
text: A Marine who fought his way into an ambush in Afghanistan to rescue dozens of people wants to continue to save people by becoming a New York City firefighter.

headline: Braves Feel Pressure but Can’t Avoid a Loss
text: ATLANTA — The Braves were laughing early Monday evening. If such behavior sounds odd for a team in free fall, well, you have not seen the backup catcher David Ross’s impressions of characters from the comedy “Major League.”

headline: Alimony in Massachusetts Gets Overhaul, With Limits
text: BOSTON — Gov. Deval Patrick on Monday signed into law new limits on alimony in Massachusetts, sharply curbing lifetime alimony payments in divorce cases and making a series of other changes to a system that critics considered outdated.

headline: Wealthy, Influential, Leaning Republican and Pushing a Christie Bid for President
text: They are rich. They are unattached. They are looking for a little excitement.

headline: Contract Negotiations With Ford Intensify as the Union Prepares for a Strike
text: DETROIT — Contract talks between the United Automobile Workers and the Ford Motor Company intensified Monday, but the union was preparing for a strike in case a deal could not be reached.

headline: How to Mimic Berkshire’s Bet
text: Warren Buffett isn’t too old to try something new. His Berkshire Hathaway conglomerate said on Monday that it might buy back an unlimited amount of both classes of shares, at up to a 10 percent premium over book value. Many investors like to copy what Mr. Buffett does, but stock repurchases are best left to the Oracle of Omaha. If shares of other companies were truly undervalued, Berkshire probably wouldn’t be buying its own.

headline: The Lost Decade?
text: If you want a big swig of despair, listen to the people who know something about the global economy. Roger Altman, a former deputy Treasury secretary, is arguing that America and Europe are on the verge of a disastrous double-dip recession. Various economists say it will be at least another three years before we see serious job growth. Others say European banks are teetering — if not now, then early next year.

headline: Freezing in the Arctic and Sweating in Sudan, but on Time in Chicago
text: I’VE been traveling all my life. It’s part of my DNA, and in many ways defines me and the work of my family.

headline: Lottery Numbers
The Pentagon Budget and the Deficit
text: It was not just two mismanaged wars and trillions of dollars in misconceived and poorly supervised weapons contracts that drove Pentagon spending to unsustainable levels over the past decade — about $700 billion for last year alone. Military pay, benefit and retirement costs rose by more than 50 percent over the same decade (accounting for inflation). Leaving aside Afghanistan and Iraq, those costs now account for nearly $1 out of every $3 the Pentagon spends.

headline: Trouble With Marijuana Arrests
text: Commissioner Raymond Kelly of the New York Police Department came forthwith too little, too late when he issued a memo directing officers not to arrest people caught with small amounts of marijuana unless the drug is in plain public view. A 1977 law decriminalized minor possession, yet tens of thousands are arrested every year.

headline: Critiqued by Namath, Ryan Stands Ground
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Rex Ryan has never been one to bite his tongue. His unconditional confidence borders on irritating cockiness to some, and he is not afraid to express his opinion that the Jets are the best team in the N.F.L.

headline: ‘Bully for Garibaldi’
text: The tiny Mediterranean island of Caprera, near Sardinia, was not the sort of place to find an American diplomat in the late summer of 1861, but that’s precisely where Henry Shelton Sanford landed late in the afternoon of Sept. 8. It had been a long, involved trip: he came from Brussels to Genoa by train, secretly chartered a ship to avoid public notice and, on the night of Sept. 7, sailed through the Ligurian Sea to Sardinia. Landing late the next day, he hired a small boat to take him to Caprera, then walked more than a mile on a narrow path across the rocky, windswept island.

headline: Saudi Arabia and Its Women
text: King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia deserves credit for his long overdue decision to give women the right to vote, to run in municipal elections and to be appointed as full voting members of the Majlis Al-Shura, a government advisory group. It is a first step toward moving his country into the modern world but not nearly enough.

headline: Pakistanis Tied to 2007 Border Attack on Americans
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A group of American military officers and Afghan officials had just finished a five-hour meeting with their Pakistani hosts in a village schoolhouse settling a border dispute when they were ambushed — by the Pakistanis.

headline: Council Plans to Investigate Digital Effort by the Mayor
text: The City Council said Monday that it would investigate cost overruns and delays in the Bloomberg administration’s project of modernizing the personnel system for the municipal work force.

headline: In North Dakota, Flames of Wasted Natural Gas Light the Prairie
text: NEW TOWN, N.D. — Across western North Dakota, hundreds of fires rise above fields of wheat and sunflowers and bales of hay. At night, they illuminate the prairie skies like giant fireflies.

headline: Climate Change and the Exodus of Species
text: To most humans, so far, climate change is still more of an idea than an experience. For other species, it is an immediate reality. Many will be left behind as the climate alters, unable to move quickly enough or with nowhere to move to. Others are already adapting. An iconic example of these swift changes is the recent discovery that Atlantic and Pacific populations of bowhead whales — long kept apart by the frozen Arctic — are now overlapping in the open waters of the Northwest Passage.

headline: Cities With the Highest Poverty Rates in 2010
text: Percentage of the population living in poverty.

headline: Reading, Pa., Knew It Was Poor. Now It Knows Just How Poor.
text: READING, Pa. — The exhausted mothers who come to the Second Street Learning Center here — a day care provider for mostly low-income families — speak of low wages, hard jobs and an economy gone bad.

headline: Can I Get One Sheet of the Lady Gagas ...
text: Let’s face it: the United States Postal Service has not been known for its pizazz in stamp design. But starting next year, along with weather vanes and bonsai plants, there may be some startling new options for those who choose to pay their bills by mail and send their love letters sealed with a kiss.

headline: Mets’ Loss Takes Back Seat to Reyes’s 3 Hits
text: The final series of the Mets’ season opened Monday night at Citi Field, and even though the outcomes will be irrelevant, the games have taken on an added dimension because of the interest surrounding a singular player: Jose Reyes.

headline: Fighters Enter Qaddafi Stronghold City as Toll Rises
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Fighters battling Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s loyalists on Monday entered the coastal city of Surt from the east as residents fleeing the besieged city, one of the loyalists’ few remaining strongholds, warned of an escalating toll from the fighting.

headline: Leaders of Labor Coalition Deny Bat-Swinging Extortion
text: Two leaders of a minority labor coalition pleaded not guilty on Monday to charges that they used their organization, United Hispanic Construction Workers, as a baseball-bat-wielding criminal enterprise that threatened and extorted its way onto construction sites across Manhattan and the Bronx over the last 16 years.

headline: Paying for Security
text: The Obama administration’s proposal to raise the security fee for air travelers — part of its overall plan to reduce the budget deficit — has reignited a debate over who should pay the bill for aviation security: airlines and their passengers, or all taxpayers.

headline: Doors Swinging Open
text: Boca Raton, Fla.

headline: Palestinians’ Security Council Application Goes to a Committee
text: The Security Council decided to meet on Wednesday morning to refer the Palestinian membership application to the Council’s membership committee. All 15 Council members have a representative on the committee. Given the sensitivity and interest of the issue, it will be heavy with ambassadors this time around, diplomats said. Even as the review is proceeding, both the United States and the Palestinians have been lobbying over the eventual vote in the Council, which is still weeks if not months away. Should the Palestinians fail to muster the nine votes they need to move their application forward, the United States will not be put in the awkward position of vetoing the membership bid.

headline: Tuesday: Beatle Lover
text: Administrivial Comment Alert!  It’s time once again to feed the moderating emus in the back room, so the comment section of Wordplay will be down from 11:30 P.M. E.T. Monday through mid-morning E.T Tuesday. You will be able to read comments during that time, but will not be able to leave a comment. Thanks for your patience and please feel free to discuss the puzzle both before and after those times. UPDATE: The emus are still hungry, so commentary might be sparse for the time being. Thanks for your patience and we hope to have this restored soon.

headline: In Consultant’s Trial, Defense Attacks Mayor
text: The story of how a Republican political consultant came to be accused of stealing more than $1 million from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg in 2009 can be traced to the mayor’s re-election campaign in 2005, a lawyer for the consultant said on Monday.

headline: Jessy Dixon, Gospel Singer and Songwriter, Dies at 73
text: Jessy Dixon, a singer and songwriter who helped popularize gospel music with his energetic style and who found a wider audience touring and recording with Paul Simon, died on Monday at his home in Chicago. He was 73.

headline: Lawyers Say Strauss-Kahn Is Covered by Immunity
text: Lawyers for Dominique Strauss-Kahn are asking a judge to dismiss a sexual-assault lawsuit against him, saying he was entitled to immunity under a United Nations convention that protects the heads of specialized agencies.

headline: On Defense, Jets Resolve to Restore Reputation
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Through three games, a pattern has emerged for the Jets’ defense. When it faces an overmatched quarterback playing without his top receiving option, the Jets win by 29 points. When it faces experienced quarterbacks flanked by multiple big-play threats, the Jets wobble and lurch, casting their reputation into doubt.

headline: Obama Aide Takes Top Spot in Re-election Campaign
text: Another senior aide to President Obama plans to leave the White House for a top spot in his re-election campaign as the White House continues to shift into election mode.

headline: Goldman Sachs Draws Up Deeper Cuts
text: Goldman Sachs, bracing for what could be one of its worst quarters since it went public 12 years ago, is preparing to expand its cost-cutting initiative by hundreds of millions of dollars, a move that could lead to additional job losses at the Wall Street bank.

headline: Thefts of Electronic Devices on Subways Rise
text: If the sight of New Yorkers using their iPhones and iPads on the subway has become ubiquitous, so too has a criminal corollary: thefts of such devices on the subway continue to rise, especially on weekends.

headline: Video Shows Washington Monument During Earthquake
text: The National Park Service said Monday that the Washington Monument would remain closed indefinitely because of damage sustained in a 5.8-magnitude earthquake that rattled the East Coast in August.

headline: Wall Street Demonstrations Test Police Trained for Bigger Threats
text: When members of the loose protest movement known as Occupy Wall Street began a march from the financial district to Union Square on Saturday, the participants seemed relatively harmless, even as they were breaking the law by marching in the street without a permit.

headline: Douglas LaChance, Who Led Newspaper Deliverers’ Union, Dies at 69
text: Douglas LaChance, who led the powerful union that represented New York City newspaper deliverers in the 1980s and ’90s and whose crafty, two-fisted approach led to a prison term on racketeering and extortion charges, died on Wednesday, in Long Beach, N.Y. He was 69.

headline: SecondMarket, an Exchange Without the Volatility
text: Francis Specker/Bloomberg NewsBarry Silbert, chief executive of SecondMarket.

headline: Wangari Maathai
text: Dr. Maathai, the first African woman to win a Nobel Peace Prize, died at the age of 71.

headline: Is New York’s Tech Boom Sustainable?
text: The battle royale brewing between New York and Silicon Valley to be the nation’s dominant epicenter for tech innovation and hot start-ups wages on.

headline: Mo Rothman Dies at 92; Revived Interest in Charlie Chaplin
text: Mo Rothman, a film executive and entrepreneur who was instrumental in reviving interest in Charlie Chaplin’s movies in the 1970s, and who orchestrated the aging star’s triumphant return to the United States in 1972 after a bitter, self-imposed exile of 20 years, died on Sept. 15 in Los Angeles. He was 92.

headline: Yanks Set Own Agenda as Division Rivals Battle to Finish
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — It was a night for cheering at Tropicana Field on Monday — for the exploits on the field and for events taking place in Baltimore that were illuminated on the out-of-town scoreboard.

headline: A Way to Make Motor Fuel Out of Wood? Add Water
text: A Georgia company says it has overcome a major roadblock in turning agricultural waste into vehicle fuel and other useful chemicals by experimenting with a technology that treats the waste with compressed water heated to very high temperatures.

headline: Freddie Mac Loan Deal Defective, Report Says
text: Freddie Mac used a flawed analysis when it accepted $1.35 billion from Bank of America to settle claims that the bank misled it about loans purchased during the mortgage boom, according to an oversight report scheduled for release on Tuesday.

headline: More Gloom Lies Ahead for Cities, Report Says
text: Nearly a third of the nation’s cities are laying off workers this year. More than half have canceled or delayed infrastructure projects. And two out of five have raised their fees.

headline: College Graduation Rates Are Stagnant Even as Enrollment Rises, a Study Finds
text: A report to be released on Tuesday by a group seeking to raise college graduation rates shows that despite decades of steadily climbing enrollment rates, the percentage of students making it to the finish line is barely budging.

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Tuesday
text: 10 Janpath was abuzz on Monday as Congress Party President Sonia Gandhi held separate meetings with Finance Minister Pranab Mukherjee and Home Minister P. Chidambaram (Indian Express). The meetings were related to controversy over a note sent by the Finance Ministry, which suggested that Chidambaram – in his previous role as finance minister – failed to check ex-Telecom Minister A. Raja, the man at the heart of the 2G scam. Will Sonia’s involvement “quell war” (Times of India)?

headline: Australia Says It Will Open Combat Roles to Women
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Australia’s female soldiers will soon be able to serve in all front-line combat roles, the government announced on Tuesday.

headline: Champions League Tuesday Preview: City’s Strutting, Bayern’s Cruising, United’s Limping
text: Tuesday brings eight more games on the second matchday of the group stage in the UEFA Champions League. Manchester City will be out to prove something, Manchester United will be out to avoid more injuries, and Ajax and Real Madrid will get together and talk about the good old days when everyone agreed they both played prettier soccer than Barcelona.

headline: September 27, 1964 | Oswald Acted Alone, Says Warren Commission Report
text: On Sept. 27, 1964, the Warren Commission released its 888-page report on the assassination of President John F. Kennedy. It dismissed any conspiracy theories, concluding that Lee Harvey Oswald had acted alone shooting Kennedy and Texas Gov. John Connally, and that Jack Ruby had acted alone in killing Oswald days later.

headline: Saudi Women Win the Vote
text: WHO announced Sunday that women would be able to vote and run in municipal elections for the first time in the history of Saudi Arabia?

headline: The Most Dangerous Celebrities on the Web
text: Heidi Klum is a Victoria’s Secret model and the host of the hit reality-TV show “Project Runway.” But her admirers should beware: Searching online for her name with terms like “hot pictures” and “free downloads” can bring a cold shower.

text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul.

headline: Metro Pucks: Devils’ DeBoer on Adam Larsson
text: The Devils moved up in the 2011 draft from pick No. 8 to 4 with a long-shot victory in the league’s lottery for teams that did not qualify for the playoffs. Then Adam Larsson, widely regarded as the one premier defensive prospects available, was passed by Edmonton, Colorado and Florida in favor of forwards. That’s two fortunate breaks at a time of need for New Jersey’s club.

headline: At Mumbai Theater Festival, Concision Is the Key

headline: Gas Flaring in North Dakota
text: Every day across the western half of North Dakota 100 million cubic feet of natural gas — enough energy to heat nearly half a million homes for a year — is deliberately burned by oil companies rushing to extract oil from the Bakken shale field and take advantage of the high price of crude.

headline: Greek Vote Approves a Despised Property Tax
text: The Greek Parliament voted late Tuesday in Athens to back a hugely unpopular property tax, one of a series of new austerity measures. The vote could clear the way for a crucial injection of international financing meant to at least temporarily stave off a default on government debt.

headline: Palin ‘on the Verge’ of a Decision About Presidential Run
text: Sarah Palin has been quiet recently. Surprisingly quiet.

headline: Flames Light the Prairie and Warm the Planet
text: In Tuesday’s Times, I write about the flaring of natural gas from pipes, pits and hundreds of oil wells in the Bakken shale field of North Dakota and Montana, which emits a couple of million tons of carbon dioxide annually. It’s a big waste and it contributes to global warming, as even oil executives concede.

headline: Lessons From Britain’s Health Information Technology Fiasco
text: Government press releases tend to be bland, earnest blather. But not one posted on the British Department of Health’s Web site last Thursday. Its headline: “Dismantling the NHS National Programme for IT.”

headline: A Queen’s Delusion and Defiance Opens the Met Season
text: Since arriving at the Metropolitan Opera as general manager in 2006, Peter Gelb has been angling to make the soprano Anna Netrebko a house prima donna in the old-world sense: a first among equals. On Monday night Mr. Gelb must have felt that the plan was working.

headline: Humor Comes of Age in India
text: Mumbai: When I asked Ashok Chakradhar, a respected poet and comic, how India’s sense of humor has changed over the years, he answered with a joke about physical intimacy in relationships.

headline: Barcelona Changes Jerseys and Its Values
text: Barcelona had long resisted temptation to sell its team shirt the way other soccer teams around the world had done.

headline: Abducted Foster Children Found in Pennsylvania, Police Say
text: After nearly a week on the run, two fugitive parents and their eight children, who were abducted from foster care in Queens during a visit with their mother, were apprehended in Harrisburg, Pa., the authorities said Tuesday. The children, who the police said were living in a van with their parents, were described as being disheveled but in apparently good condition.

headline: Far North of Selma, an Allotment of Civil Rights History
text: They came from fraying binders, from forgotten boxes in storage units, from cobwebbed closets. They had been in Mississippi and South Carolina and Georgia, and included a wallet-size photograph of a familiar preacher with a dream. Their destination was a drab office space in the back of a library in Queens.

headline: Markit Drops Out of Race for London Clearinghouse
text: LONDON — The financial data provider Markit Group said on Tuesday that its bid for the LCH.Clearnet Group failed to receive the necessary support from the clearinghouse, paving the way for a rival offer from the London Stock Exchange.

headline: Official Survives Attack in Yemen
text: SANA, Yemen — Yemen’s defense minister survived an assassination attempt on Tuesday in the volatile southern port city of Aden, where a suicide attacker detonated a car bomb next to his convoy.

headline: Low Consumer Confidence Suggests Hiring Is Still Weak
text: Confidence among the nation’s consumers stagnated near a two-year low in September, and the share of households that said it was difficult to find a job climbed to the highest level in almost three decades, a research group said on Tuesday.

headline: After War, From Wife to Caregiver
text: April Marcum has joined a community of spouses, parents and partners who drop most everything in their lives to care for injured loved ones returning from war.

headline: Looking After the Soldier, Back Home and Damaged
text: RAY CITY, Ga. — April and Tom Marcum were high school sweethearts who married after graduation. For years, she recalls, he was a doting husband who would leave love notes for her to discover on the computer or in her purse. Now the closest thing to notes that they exchange are the reminders she set up on his cellphone that direct him to take his medicine four times a day.

headline: Wife, Mother, and Now, Caregiver
text: A growing community of spouses, parents and partners, confronted with damaged loved ones returning from war who can no longer do for themselves, drop most everything in their own lives to care for them.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Coffee Linked to Less Depression in Women
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Report Says Vehicle Fuel Should Be the Priority, Not Electricity
text: Research on solar and wind power is all well and good, but a self-assessment by the Department of Energy has found that in the great scheme of energy needs, the government is not investing enough in transportation energy, an area in which those renewable power sources do not play a role.

headline: Guns N’ Roses and Eric B. & Rakim Are Nominated for  Rock and Roll Hall of Fame
text: Guns N’ Roses, the hard rock band whose glory days were in the 1980s, and Eric B. & Rakim, one of the most influential rap groups of that era, were among the 15 artists nominated for induction into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame next year, the hall announced this morning. Both were nominated in their first year of eligibility.

headline: Shanghai Subway Accident Injures Hundreds
text: SHANGHAI — Hundreds of people were injured here on Tuesday when a subway train slammed into the rear of another train in a sprawling transit line that opened just last year. The accident cast new scrutiny on the safety record of China’s rapidly modernizing mass transit rail systems.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Goldman Sachs Draws Up Deeper Cuts | Goldman Sachs, bracing for what could be one of its worst quarters since it went public 12 years ago, is preparing to expand its cost-cutting initiative by hundreds of millions of dollars, a move that could result in additional jobs being eliminated.

headline: Work in Progress
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#924", 592, 500, true, chameleonData);Paul Barbera shoots slick interiors for clients like Elle Decoration and Vogue Living. But before he ventured into the studios of the 32 designers in his new book “Where They Create” (Frame Publishers, $45), he begged them not to clean up. “It’s not like messy wall, messy table, pencil on floor and rubbish near door equals great artist,” Barbera insists, but those intimate details make for rich material. Matali Crasset’s personal library, Maarten Baas’s prototypes and even the crudely fashioned cardboard strip that keeps Confetti System’s air-conditioner from jostling its hand-cut garlands reveal what it’s really like inside a designer’s world.

headline: September Collapse of Red Sox Could Be Worst Ever
text: After beating the Texas Rangers on Sept. 3, the Boston Red Sox were 84-54. Although half a game behind the Yankees in the American League East, the Red Sox had a nine-game lead over the Tampa Bay Rays for the wild card and roughly a 99.6 percent chance of making the playoffs.

headline: Q&A: Guided Tours Through Europe

Some of these tours can be very expensive. I am wondering if there are any reputable tour operators that organize small tours for active people who want to experience the real people and culture of Europe at moderate prices.

headline: Rooting for the Opponent, but Which One?
text: Having secured home-field advantage through the first two rounds of the playoffs, the Yankees have their eye on two races at the moment: the wild-card race between the Tampa Bay Rays and the Boston Red Sox, which is tied and which the Yankees continue to be a big part of; and the race between the other two division champions, the Texas Rangers and the Detroit Tigers, for home-field advantage in the American League division series. The loser of that battle will face the Yankees in the first round.

headline: A Trader’s Truth, or a Prank?

headline: High-Tech Companies to Invest $4 Billion in New York State, Cuomo Says
text: ALBANY — I.B.M., Intel and three other technology companies agreed Tuesday to pour $4 billion into computer-chip research in New York, promising to hire thousands of workers and giving a major boost to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo as he campaigns for companies to invest in the state and create jobs.

headline: Health Insurance Costs Rising Sharply This Year, Study Shows
text: The cost of health insurance for many Americans this year climbed more sharply than in previous years, outstripping any growth in workers’ wages and adding more uncertainty about the pace of rising medical costs.

headline: Fearing Change, Many Christians in Syria Back Assad
text: SAYDNAYA, Syria — Abu Elias sat beneath the towering stairs leading from the Convent of Our Lady of Saydnaya, a church high up in the mountains outside Damascus, where Christians have worshiped for 1,400 years. “We are all scared of what will come next,” he said, turning to a man seated beside him, Robert, an Iraqi refugee who escaped the sectarian strife in his homeland.

headline: At High Volume, and Higher Salary, Ozzie Guillen Is on the Move
text: Ozzie Guillen left Chicago the only way he could: in a blaze of candor. Six years after managing the White Sox to their first World Series title since 1917, Guillen left the organization Monday night. He is widely expected to soon be named manager of the Florida Marlins.

headline: Art and Science in a Tiny Island Village
text: Jack Dumbacher, curator of ornithology and mammalogy at the California Academy of Sciences, writes from Milne Bay, Papua New Guinea, where he is studying island birds and their diseases.

headline: Capital One Says ING Direct Deal Will Create Jobs
text: Capital One, under fire from consumer groups and competitors for its $9 billion bid to acquire ING Direct USA, is hoping to sweeten the deal and stem the controversy with a big promise: job creation.

headline: Boston Museum Returns Bust to Turkey
text: After two decades of negotiations, the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston has returned the broken-off bust of a famous statue of Herakles to Turkey, where it will be reunited with its lower half, the museum announced.

headline: The Red Sox Unravel; the White Sox Get Real Quiet
text: If you expected to turn on the television Monday night and find a wheezing sound coming from Cowboys quarterback Tony Romo and his much-debated ribs, the first potential flaw in that logic was assuming you could stand to listen to a broadcast filled with Jon Gruden soliloquies without diving for the mute button. And as it turns out, the inescapable wheezing sound was emanating from someplace entirely different, that being whatever dugout the Red Sox are slouching in at a given moment.

headline: Climate Change Takes a Toll on Cultures
text: There are nearly 7,000 known languages in the world today. It is predicted that half of these, in many cases vessels of indigenous cultures, will vanish over the next 50 years.

headline: Taking Risks to Cut Drug Costs
text: Americans are spending less money out of their own pockets each month on prescription drugs, probably because of greater use of lower-cost generics, the third annual drug survey from Consumer Reports finds.

headline: Larger, Private Spot Is Found for TriBeCa Sukkah
text: The Great Sukkah Controversy in TriBeCa has been amicably settled in time for the Jewish holidays, with a new location found nearby for the sukkah and an offer by opponents of its placement in a park to cover the costs of staffing.

headline: A Worried City Father Seeks Wholesomeness
text: As you’re wincing your way through “Suburgatory,” an unpalatable sitcom that has its premiere on ABC on Wednesday night, ponder the question that no studio executives apparently did: Who is the audience for this show?

headline: Rival Views of Jackson as Doctor’s Trial Begins
text: LOS ANGELES — A desperate, drug-addicted insomniac racked with anxiety about his coming concert series: that is how a defense lawyer portrayed Michael Jackson in his last days during opening statements on Tuesday in the involuntary manslaughter trial of the singer’s personal doctor.

headline: Setting the Stage for Romance
text: The artist Karen Kilimnik tends to work in small, intimate canvases and props, tackling subjects like Kate Moss or the battles of Napoleon with seeming fairy tale romance. For “Psyché,” a new production choreographed by Alexei Ratmansky for the Paris Opera Ballet, Kilimnik started from a selection of pre-existing paintings to create five massive, dreamlike backdrops, including an enchanting, moonlit forest and a garden resplendent with clouds, flowers and perfume bottles. She then augmented these with rhinestones, glitter and, for good measure, a host of two-dimensional objects like the five-foot snail that enters and exits the stage at various points during the performance. Being able to work on this scale was a dream in itself. “It was wonderful,” she said.

headline: Colbert vs. Yorke: The ‘Report’ Host Talks Economics With Radiohead Frontman
text: Radiohead, the influential British progressive rock band, gave an unusually long televised performance Monday night, playing songs from its new album, “King of Limbs,” and others on an hourlong special of The Colbert Report, the comedian Stephen Colbert’s political satire show.

headline: Walgreen Projects Loss Without Express Scripts
text: The Walgreen Company on Tuesday braced Wall Street for a projected loss in 2012 of more than $3 billion in revenue because of the planned loss of business from customers who have their prescription drug coverage managed by Express Scripts.

headline: Spending Less on Entertainment and Charity
text: Americans ratcheted down their spending on entertainment and philanthropic donations in 2010, according to a new report from the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

headline: Johnnie Wright, 97, Singer and Country Bandleader, Is Dead
text: Johnnie Wright, a singer and bandleader who was among the first country musicians to use Latin rhythms and who managed the singing career of his wife, Kitty Wells, died on Tuesday at his home in Madison, Tenn. He was 97.

headline: Bomber Aims at Merchant Used by Police in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A suicide car bomber in southern Afghanistan took aim at a local merchant who sold his goods — cooking oil, bread and wood — to the local police, exploding a car in front of his grocery and bakery, killing a father and son on Tuesday.

headline: Anti-Qaddafi Fighters Edge Closer to Taking Surt
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Fighters for Libya’s new government claimed to have seized the port in Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s tribal hometown of Surt on Tuesday, tightening their noose around the stubbornly resistant Mediterranean coastal enclave devoted to the fallen Libyan leader.

headline: A Climate Analyst Analyzes His Own Approach to CO2
text: 7:23 p.m. | Updated Robert Socolow of Princeton University has written “Wedges Reaffirmed,” an essay published today by The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists and Climate Central.  The piece examines lessons he’s learned since he and a colleague, Stephen Pacala, co-authored “Stabilization Wedges: Solving the Climate Problem for the Next 50 Years with Current Technologies” in 2004. The influential paper, published in Science, divided the challenge of keeping emissions of greenhouse gases through mid-century at levels prevailing in the 2000s into seven “wedges” of carbon dioxide reductions — through switching to renewable and nuclear power, ramping up energy efficiency, ending deforestation and taking action in other areas. (The new essay adds two wedges because the scope of the challenge has grown in the last seven years.)

headline: Do-Good Design | The Pink Swan Project
text: For the second year in a row, an iconic modernist chair has been transformed by a star-studded roster of designers to benefit the Breast Cancer Research Foundation. Following the success of its Pink Wishbone Project, in which designers put their own spin on Hans Wegner’s classic Wishbone chair, SUITE New York, the Manhattan design showroom that is the project’s mastermind, organized the Pink Swan Project for 2011. It lets 18 A-listers in design, fashion and architecture loose on Arne Jacobsen’s Swan chair, which is manufactured by the Danish company Fritz Hansen. The one-of-a-kind chairs will be up for auction from Oct. 1 to Oct. 31 on CharityBuzz.

headline: After Official Is Ousted, Kremlin Adds a Warning

headline: Kennedy Center to Replace Its Pipe Organ
text: The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington said it would replace the long-maligned organ in its concert hall with a new 5,000-pipe instrument built by Casavant Frères of St-Hyacinthe, Quebec. The existing organ, which was built by Aeolian-Skinner and installed in 1972, has been criticized by performers and reviewers for its poor functioning and musical inadequacy. A 1997 renovation of the hall made the problems worse. “It was getting to the point where it was ruining performances,” said Jeff Weiler, an organ consultant hired by the Kennedy Center. The new organ will be installed starting next summer, with a 61-pipe stop incorporated from its predecessor.  The instrument will cost more than $2 million, the Kennedy Center said. David M. Rubenstein, the Kennedy Center’s chairman and the managing director of the Carlyle Group, a private equity firm, is paying for the new organ and its installation.

headline: Koch Endorses Obama in 2012
text: Former Mayor Edward I. Koch, who recently used the forum of a special Congressional election to broadcast his criticism of President Obama’s Israel policy, announced in an e-mail on Tuesday that Mr. Obama’s United Nations speech opposing the Palestinians’ bid for statehood had satisfied all his concerns, and that he was now prepared to support Mr. Obama’s re-election.

headline: Looking for the Next Cool Kid

headline: Reviewing Coppelia, Reviewing Miss Lily’s
text: This week’s restaurant review is a doubleheader: Coppelia, on West 14th Street, and Miss Lily’s Favourite Cakes, on West Houston Street. Have you been to one or the other restaurant? Have you been to both? You may, as always, discuss your experiences in the comments below. My take is that both restaurants in some way speak to the void left in Manhattan by the closing of Florent a few years ago. You may agree or disagree. But keep your language clean!

headline: Latin Grammys to Honor Shakira
text: Shakira, the pop diva from Colombia, will be honored as the person of the year at the Latin Grammys in November. The president of the Latin Recording Academy, Gabriel Abaroa Jr., said the singer was being honored for her philanthropic work as well as her successful recording career. At 34, Shakira is the youngest person to receive the tribute from the 12-year-old group, which was formed to present a Latin version of the Grammy awards. Past recipients have included Carlos Santana, Julio Iglesias, Gloria Estefan and Ricky Martin. One of the most successful Latin artists to cross over into English-speaking radio, Shakira has won two Grammys and three Latin Grammys. She enjoyed a world-wide smash hit in 2006 with “Hips Don’t Lie.” She has done charity work since she was 18 years old, when she started the Pies Descalzos Foundation, an organization that provides schools to poor children in Colombia.

headline: The Mexican Drug Wars, on Twitter: Using Social Media for Social Action
text: Overview | How can social media be used to promote public safety? When does using media become dangerous? In this lesson, students examine how social media is being used by various factions in the Mexican drug wars and then draw comparisons to other examples where people have used social networks for other causes and actions. They then develop proposals for how digital media can be used to address an issue of concern.

headline: Profile in Style | Paul de Zwart
text: No stranger to brand building (he was a co-founder of Wallpaper magazine and Winkreative), the London-based entrepreneur crystallized the concept for his fledgling furniture company, Another Country, while searching for some simple bedside tables and stools for his country house. “I realized there was a dearth of well-made, well-priced design with a modern craft heritage,” he says. His solution? An affordable line of pared-down pieces that are handmade in England from sustainable woods. “We’re going for timeless over trendy.” Go to anothercountry.com. See our interactive feature >>

headline: Will High-Deductible Health Insurance Plans Become the Norm?
text: As the cost of health insurance continues to rise, workers can expect to see high-deductible plans, with ever-higher deductibles, becoming the norm, the president of the Kaiser Family Foundation predicts.

headline: OnStar Backtracks on Collection of Data From Ex-Subscribers
text: Having been criticized by customers and United States senators for a week, OnStar announced Tuesday afternoon that it would not track the vehicles of customers who had canceled their subscriptions to the service. Instead, those subscribers who wanted to retain the two-way cellular connection between OnStar and their vehicles would have to opt in for the feature.

headline: As ‘Like’ Buttons Spread, So Do Facebook’s Tentacles

headline: Thinking About Sovereign Bankruptcy
text: I am just back from presenting a paper at the European Law and Economics Association annual meeting, held this year in Hamburg, Germany. And of course the topic on everyone’s lips at every coffee break, lunch and paper session was the Greece-French-Bank-Generalized-Euro-Zone Panic of 2011.

headline: Does Economics Still Progress?
text: In a few hours Sylvia Nasar and I will have an on-stage dialogue at the 92nd Street Y, centered around her new book The Grand Pursuit, which offers a set of fascinating portraits of the makers of economics. (Irving Fisher invented the Rolodex?) But as I was reading her book I have to admit that I found myself wondering whether there’s much to celebrate.

headline: Another Round of Nice Chianti: ‘Silence! The Musical’ to Reopen
text: Fewer tap-dancing lambs? Less cannibalism? The creators of “Silence! The Musical,” a theatrical parody of the 1991 film “The Silence of the Lambs,” have sliced 10 to 15 minutes from the production that had a popular run Off Broadway this summer in preparation for a new, open-ended engagement starting Oct. 25 at a slightly larger theater downtown, the producers of the show announced on Tuesday.

headline: New Transatlantic Suitors Said to Include Former Treasury Official
text: A former government official who helped bail out the American International Group and a onetime head of General Re are part of a group that has begun merger talks with Transatlantic Holdings, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Tuesday.

headline: Mix and Maxed
text: “I’ve always made stuff and wanted to know how things worked,” says Bethan Laura Wood, a 28-year-old British product designer who studied under Martino Gamper and Jurgen Bey, and whose work was featured with that of her mentors at the cutting-edge Milan gallery Nilufar in April. Wood takes nuts-and-bolts materials to fantastic places; her Moon Rock tables are inlaid with laser-cut plastic laminate, as is her Particle jewelry (shown here), inspired by lowly particle board. Wood’s own look, a confection of glitter, pattern and wrapping, has evolved since her teen years from a defense against bullying classmates (“I thought I’d give them a reason”) into a form of play. Look for Wood at the Pavilion of Art & Design London show this month.

headline: James Rubin Abruptly Departs Bloomberg
text: 5:03 p.m. | Updated James P. Rubin, a former assistant secretary of state hired by Bloomberg News just 10 months ago to help lead its new opinion-writing section, has left his job after a rocky start.

headline: Battle for Libya | Sept. 27, 2011
text: Fighters for Libya’s new government claimed to have seized the port in Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s tribal hometown of Surt on Tuesday.

headline: What Do Small-Business Owners Want?
text: Small-business owners are often described in monolithic terms. But as I rediscovered during a conversation with three women who run companies, their goals and motivations tend to vary. When I met recently with Jessica Johnson, Susan Parker and Carissa Reiniger of our newly formed business group, we talked about their long-term goals. (Alexandra Mayzler, the fourth member of the group, couldn’t make the meeting.) I was particularly curious about their thoughts and attitudes about eventually exiting the companies that they or their families — in the cases of Ms. Johnson and Ms. Parker — built.

headline: Summer Squash, Tahini and Yogurt Dip
text: Just when I thought I would never find anything new to do with the two small summer squash that were lingering in my refrigerator I came across this dish in Paula Wolfert’s book “The Cooking of the Eastern Mediterranean.” A simple combination of cooked squash, drained yogurt, garlic and tahini, it’s another example of how you can make yogurt dips with just about any vegetable.

headline: D.M.V. to Drop Eye Exam for License Renewals
text: New York drivers worried about having to read a line on an eye chart to renew their license can rest easy.

headline: TimesCast | September 27, 2011
text: Leaders from Greece and Germany meet to avert a Greek default; Republican donors look to Gov. Chris Christie as a presidential candidate; and engineers assess the Washington Monument for quake damage.

headline: The Creations of Interpreters: Conductors as Composers
text: Unlike pianists and violinists, conductors don’t start perfecting their technique as 5-year-olds. They usually start with an instrument and undertake the full rigors of musical training, including theory and composition studies, before they take up the baton for the first time. Some abandon composition early; some continue to compose throughout their conducting careers, hoping to leave a legacy that will survive them in ways that their performances will not.

headline: Mâche Salad With Yogurt Dressing
text: Mâche is a delicate green also known as lamb’s lettuce, and it’s now available in many Whole Foods stores and other supermarkets in the United States. It has a rich nutritional profile: It is very high in vitamin C, beta carotene, omega-3s and iron (it has even more than spinach). I love the contrast here between the mild, subtle mâche and the sharp, pungent garlic-spiked yogurt.

headline: Israel Angers Palestinians With Plan for Housing
text: JERUSALEM — Israel announced plans on Tuesday for 1,100 new housing units in an area of South Jerusalem outside Israel’s pre-1967 boundaries. The move reflects Israel’s continued rejection of Palestinian demands for a halt in settlement construction as a condition for peace talks.

headline: Suge Knight to Produce Soundtrack for Showtime Documentary About Suge Knight
text: Suge Knight, the founder of Death Row Records who played a leading role during a turbulent and violent period of hip-hop history, will the be subject of a feature-length documentary on Showtime, the network announced Tuesday. The filmmakers said Mr. Knight had agreed to give extensive interviews about his life and the rapid rise and slow fall of his record label; he is also producing a soundtrack for the film. The film will be directed by Antoine Fuqua, who directed “Training Day” and “Brooklyn’s Finest,” and will be produced by Bradley J. Fischer, who produced “Black Swan” and “Shutter Island.” No release date has been announced.

headline: For Investors, Russia’s Putin Is Good for Business
text: MOSCOW — A consensus is emerging among bankers, economists and companies that evaluate market risk that the return of Vladimir V. Putin as Russia’s president will be a net positive for foreign investors — regardless of whether they support the politics of it.

headline: For Christie, Speculation Has Rewards – and Risks

headline: Reduced Role for Rooney on “60 Minutes”
text: Andy Rooney, whose folksy and often curmudgeonly essays have been a staple of “60 Minutes” for more than three decades, will end his regular weekly appearances on the program, CBS said Tuesday.

headline: Blending the Unfamiliar With the Ordinary Is a Recipe for Selling Out the Show
text: Among the reasons that the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center could call the concert at Alice Tully Hall on Monday a gala was that it opened a new season. That was accurate, but also mundane. Looking around the auditorium, you were confronted with a more compelling cause for celebration: on a Monday night, offering a program largely comprising unfamiliar works, the society had sold every available seat.

headline: A Blurry Look at the Child Prisoner of Guantánamo
