headline: Foo Fighters in Concert
text: On Monday night at the Izod Center Dave Grohl stood on a 20-foot riser alone with an acoustic guitar. His vulpine teeth flashed, and his black dress-shirt was soaked through. He hadn’t changed it during the break.

headline: They’ve Arrived, Like Old Times
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — In the second half of “This Is a Call,” the forthcoming biography of Dave Grohl written by the British journalist Paul Brannigan, the narrative shifts completely and some new motifs emerge. That shift comes after the violent end of Nirvana, in which Mr. Grohl played drums, loudly and elegantly; it’s when the book becomes the story of the Foo Fighters, the band Mr. Grohl started in 1994 and built into a major work of commerce.

headline: Wrap Yourself in Noodles
text: ONE thing that makes New York a great food city: last year’s exotic becomes this year’s everyday. Now, news that an excellent ramen joint with house-made broth has opened in Midtown can be processed calmly, without the hysterical excitement that can lead to disappointment.

headline: How Climate Change Could Hurt Yellowstone National Park
text: Before the end of the century, Yellowstone National Park could experience summers that feel like Los Angeles’s, according to a report released Tuesday. These warming temperatures will imperil everything from native cutthroat trout to aspen forests and the $700 million in annual economic activity that they and other gems in the park generate by attracting tourists, the report said.

headline: ‘Anna Bolena’ at the Metropolitan Opera

headline: Girardi Flips Cano and Teixeira in Yankees Lineup
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Only four days before the start of the playoffs, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi switched around his lineup Tuesday night, swapping Mark Teixeira and Robinson Cano in the batting order. Teixeira, who had batted third most of the season, was dropped to fifth, with Cano taking Teixeira’s place as the No. 3 hitter.

headline: ‘Mr. Watson. Come Here. The A Train Is Running Late.’
text: For Kym Bernazky, it began with a familiar bubble. She sent back a bubble of her own.

headline: Europe Nears Agreement on Bailout Fund That May Be Inadequate
text: PARIS — Angela Merkel, Germany’s chancellor, finds herself once again in the politically perilous position of balancing the future of Europe and its common currency against a German public that is unhappy at the price the country will have to pay. And, as before, as the euro crisis has unfolded, she finds herself fighting for measures that most experts have already dismissed as inadequate.

headline: The Visual Languages of an Emmy Award Winner
text: On Monday night, The New York Times’s multimedia project “A Year at War“ won an Emmy Award in the “New Approaches to News and Documentary Programming” category for current news. The interactive series chronicles the lives of a single American battalion over their yearlong deployment in Afghanistan.

headline: Excerpt: 'Suburgatory'

headline: Old World Flair for American-Made Cheese
text: Everyday mozzarella seem dull next to burrata, a pouch of mozzarella enclosing cream and mozzarella shreds. It’s mainly been imported. But Maplebrook Fine Cheese in Bennington, Vt., is one of a growing number of American cheesemakers doing their own stretching and filling. Domenico Marchitelli who came here from Apulia, the home of burrata, makes an excellent one for them.

headline: Brief Dramatic Encounters
text: One measure of success for a festival of microplays is how much it frustrates. Each work is so short, the theatrical equivalent of speed dating. How often do you find yourself wishing for more time with the disparate characters whizzing by?

headline: Ruling Limits Financial Exposure of Mets’ Owners
text: A federal judge awarded both sides a partial victory Tuesday in the $1 billion lawsuit brought against the owners of the Mets by the trustee for the victims of Bernard L. Madoff — allowing the suit to go forward, but limiting how much money the trustee may ultimately be able to recover.

headline: Drugs, Risk and the Myth of the ‘Evil’ Addict
text: My column on making Naloxone available over-the-counter to reverse overdoses drew many plaudits and two main strands of criticism.  One group argued that addicts aren’t worth saving and we need to cut the drug supply; the other said that Naloxone, also known by its brand name, Narcan, is too risky to be available without a prescription.

headline: The Sticks, With Jet Propulsion
text: It’s no coincidence that the last two months have brought television shows with “Hillbilly,” “Truck Stop” and “Rednecks” in their titles. Or that seemingly half the new reality series this summer and fall are set in Texas.

headline: Mitten Alert: Canadians Come to SoHo
text: IN the 1960s, the United States underwent the “British invasion,” experienced sartorially via white go-go boots, Mary Quant miniskirts and jagged haircuts by Vidal Sassoon. Fifty years later, we have the mop-topped Canadian Justin Bieber and the concomitant fashion contributions of — what? American Apparel, founded by the puckish Montrealer Dov Charney? Club Monaco, conceived in Toronto? Clompy John Fluevog footwear?

headline: Newsboy Strike? Sing All About It
text: With its spring-loaded backflips, airborne spins, rambunctious kicks and balletic pivots, the athletic ensemble in “Newsies the Musical,” which opened on Sunday at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, N.J., puts up a persuasive struggle against corporate greed. But the irrepressible physicality of that scrappy band of ragamuffins is just part of what turns this canny stage transformation of Disney’s 1992 big-screen misfire into a crowd pleaser.

headline: ‘Little Miss Sunshine’ and ‘American Psycho’ Musicals Get Starry New York Readings
text: Two closely watched musicals under development – stage adaptations of the film “Little Miss Sunshine” and of the novel-turned-movie “American Psycho” – have been moving forward recently, theater executives familiar with both projects said on Tuesday.

headline: TimesCast | Euro Debt Crisis
text: Greek and German leaders meet in Berlin to bolster confidence and avert a Greek debt default.

headline: Our New Emmy
text: Last night, we were thrilled to win a News and Documentary Emmy for our portfolio “Fourteen Actors Acting.” Congratulations are also in order to the New York Times team that won an Emmy for the series “A Year at War.”

headline: Making Sense of a Tidal Wave of Data
text: Bernard Coakley, a marine geologist with the University of Alaska at Fairbanks, writes from the Arctic Ocean, where his team is reconstructing the geologic history of the Chukchi Shelf and the Chukchi Borderland.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: The Flavors of Africa

headline: Reactions to a New Plan for CO2 Progress
text: Earlier today I posted an essay by Robert Socolow, a seasoned energy and climate analyst at Princeton University, in which he proposes a new approach to overcoming resistance to actions that could limit emissions of greenhouse gases even as humanity’s energy appetite grows in coming decades.

headline: Bosnian Food in St. Louis
text: Inside a few of the food shops and restaurants that Bosnians have opened in St. Louis, nearly two decades after refugees fled the former Yugoslavia.

headline: Foods of Their Homeland, Now Mainstreamed
text: ST. LOUIS

headline: Roger Ebert: What Is Criticism For?
text: Part 2: The celebrated film critic reflects on the purpose of film criticism and explains what he’s tried to achieve with his reviews.

headline: Roger Ebert: An Instant Mutual Sympathy
text: Part 10: The celebrated film critic discusses his friendships with the filmmakers Werner Herzog and Ramin Bahrani.

headline: TimesTalks | Roger Ebert: Preview
text: The celebrated film critic talks about his illness, his long career writing about the movies and his memoir, “Life Itself.”

headline: Roger Ebert: 3-D Is an Abomination
text: Part 9: The celebrated film critic shares his thoughts on whether there are any good 3-D movies and if video games can be art.

headline: Roger Ebert: Talking Through the Camera
text: Part 6: The celebrated film critic explains the factors that made reviewing films on a TV show a challenge.

headline: Roger Ebert: Life Is a Learning Process
text: Part 11: The celebrated film critic shares which movies have meant the most to him during his illness and throughout his life.

headline: Roger Ebert: Learning on the Job
text: Part 4: The celebrated film critic reminisces about his early days as a movie reviewer and talks about how the discipline has evolved.

headline: Roger Ebert: The Siskel and Ebert Game
text: Part 5: The celebrated film critic reflects on his relationship with the critic Gene Siskel.

headline: Roger Ebert: There’s Always Been Junk
text: Part 8: The celebrated film critic talks about his nostalgia for classic films and how streaming technologies are changing the way people watch movies.

headline: Roger Ebert: ‘Life Itself’
text: Part 7: The celebrated film critic talks about what his illness has taught him, and explains what led him to write a memoir.

headline: Roger Ebert: Becoming a Blogger
text: Part 3: The celebrated film critic talks about how his illness led him to discover a new medium and transformed his writing.

headline: Roger Ebert: Intro
text: Part 1: Carol Olsen Day, director of TimesTalks, introduces the film critic Roger Ebert.

headline: ‘Newsies the Musical’
text: Photos of the show at the Paper Mill Playhouse.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: Salad With Stone Fruit, Blue Cheese and Chicken Skin
text: Adapted from Mitch Prensky, Supper, Philadelphia

headline: Flooded Farmers Learn to Be Creative
text: NEW PALTZ, N.Y.

headline: All About Apples (and Eating Them)
text: Autumn is not only apple season, it’s also apple book season. The handsome “Apple Lover’s Cookbook” has a section covering 59 kinds of apples with a description and color portrait of each. A one-page rundown lists apples according to taste and texture; there is apple history, and summaries of apple festivals, apple products, ciders and apples by mail. The heart of the book gives savory and sweet recipes, including an adaptation of Michael Field’s chicken liver pâté with apple. And the challah baked with diced apples and raisins falls into the category of “Why didn’t I think of that?”

headline: In Debate About Food, a Monied New Player
text: LAST week, a new public-relations campaign about agriculture got off to a splashy start. With full-page ads in newspapers and panel discussions live-streamed on the Internet, the newly formed U.S. Farmers and Ranchers Alliance began what it called a bid to “reshape the dialogue” about the American food supply.

headline: Upstate Butchers Come to Brooklyn
text: Jessica and Joshua Applestone made their name butchering pasture-raised beef, pork and lamb, and teaching others the art, in their shop in Kingston, N.Y. Now they have a store in Park Slope, Brooklyn. Fresh meat from upstate is available as steaks or chops, or cut to order. They also carry organic poultry, 14 kinds of sausages, offal and veal from time to time, and will have turkeys for Thanksgiving. They cure their own bacon. Prepared foods like chili, stocks, pot pies and meatloaf are also sold. The manager, Jason Fox, above right, with Mr. Applestone, above left, and Bryan Mayer, a butcher, encourages customers to order in advance.

headline: Chicken’s Attraction Is Truly Skin Deep
text: THERE are white-meat people and there are dark-meat people; there are those who swear by the drumstick, thigh or breast.

headline: Trailer: ‘Footloose’ (2011)
text: A preview of the 2011 remake of "Footloose."

headline: Seizing Populist Mantle, Obama Pushes Jobs Bill
text: DENVER — After two days of energetically raising money in the rarefied precincts of Hollywood and Silicon Valley, President Obama stopped at a big-city high school here on Tuesday to push for new ways to spend money.

headline: A Grittier Soul, but a Remake Fans Will Recognize
text: FOR members of a certain generation there are few movie moments more perfect than the scene of Kevin Bacon in a white tank top and jeans working out his adolescent angst against a warehouse backdrop. His compact body slides by the grimy walls, and his white sneakers pop while Moving Pictures’ “Never” blares. (Listen closely, and you can still hear the echo of squeals in response.) But almost 30 years have passed since “Footloose” came out and teenagers of a new era are more likely to ask: Kevin who?

headline: A $50 Billion Claim of Havoc Looms for Bank of America
text: Bank of America’s potential liability for bad mortgages — in the tens of billions of dollars — is well known. But Bank of America is haunted by other demons from the financial crisis, the most significant one being a lawsuit arising from its troubled Merrill Lynch acquisition.

headline: Hitting Machine Slows: Suzuki’s Streak Nears an End
text: It was the first thing that Raul Ibanez wanted to discuss. It was all that Jack Wilson was thinking about, too.

headline: Justices Will Hear Appeals on Immigrants’ Residence
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday agreed to decide whether the length of immigrants’ lawful residence in the United States should be considered in determining whether their children may be deported.

headline: Governing by Crisis
text: Thanks to some good luck and expert government accountants, the Federal Emergency Management Agency will limp, exhausted and nearly broke, to the end of the fiscal year on Friday. That removes its budget as the latest excuse for House Republicans to slash domestic programs they don’t like and momentarily defuses their threat to shut down the entire government to get their way.

headline: Three-Pronged Plan to Rescue Europe
text: For the rest of Europe to protect itself against a Greek default, it needs a three-pronged plan of attack. It ought to include as much as 200 billion euros to recapitalize banks across the region; extra liquidity, again for banks; and a beefed-up bailout fund to help Italy, if needed. The drumbeats suggest Europe is moving in that direction. But, as always, the fear is that it will be too timid.

headline: Which Putin Will Emerge in New Presidency?
text: MOSCOW — We know Vladimir V. Putin will rule Russia for the foreseeable future. The question is, which Mr. Putin?

headline: Google’s Biggest Threat Is Google
text: Google faces antitrust inquiries and competition from all corners. But its biggest threat is Google itself, Larry Page, its chief executive and co-founder, said Tuesday.

headline: Backing Indie Bands to Sell Cars
text: A crowd of young music fans gathered outside the Roxy Theater in Hollywood one Saturday afternoon recently, jostling for free T-shirts. As Repulsion, a band of the grisly heavy-metal style known as grindcore, blasted through songs like “Pestilent Decay” and “Splattered Cadavers,” dozens of fans on their way in and out of the club scooped up the garments, printed with a gory design typical of the genre.

headline: The Assassination Next Door
text: FOR the last nine years, I have lived part time in Afghanistan, in a house in the Wazir Akbar Khan neighborhood of Kabul. In the past, when I gave directions to my house, I mentioned the well-known landmark next door: the home of Burhanuddin Rabbani, the head of the High Peace Council and a former president and leader of the mujahedeen. As Afghanistan’s security situation has steadily deteriorated, people have been more and more hesitant to visit me; few of my acquaintances wanted to risk being near the home of the man responsible for trying to negotiate peace with the Taliban.

headline: Placing a Bet on Brazil
text: MEXICO CITY — As the United States and Europe face a bleak financial reality, Latin America hums along with continued growth and optimistic predictions for the next few years.

headline: This War Can Still Be Won
text: Washington

headline: Short-Term Fixes That Take Time and Resolve Little
text: WASHINGTON — It was a telling moment Monday night when Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the majority leader, called a deal to keep the government open for a few more weeks “a win for everyone.”

headline: Political Waves From a Solar Deal
text: To the Editor:

headline: Researching the Sneeze and How to Handle It
text: THE paper products aisle generally is not seasonal, with consumers using about the same amount of toilet paper, napkins or paper towels every month. But not so with facial tissue: as cold and flu season rears its congested head, monthly sales increase as much as 65 percent over the summer months.

headline: Cellphones in the Subway
text: To the Editor:

headline: Street Stops by the Police
text: To the Editor:

headline: Medical Data and the Quality of Care
text: To the Editor:

headline: Florida: Customs Chief Arrested in Pornography Case
text: The head of Immigration and Customs Enforcement for South Florida was arrested Tuesday on child pornography charges. Anthony V. Mangione, 50, who led the Miami-based office since 2007, was placed on paid administrative leave in April after federal agents seized his home computer and began to investigate images of alleged child pornography. Mr. Mangione, a 27-year veteran of ICE and its precursor, the United States Customs Service, is expected to appear in federal court in Fort Lauderdale on Wednesday. The agency has made cracking down on child pornography a priority, and as chief of the South Florida regional office, Mr. Mangione was aggressive in his efforts. “Too many children are victimized by predators that target the most vulnerable among us — our children,” Mr. Mangione said in a 2009 news release about the sentencing of a man on pornography charges. The Justice Department and the F.B.I. declined to comment on the case.

headline: For Hackers, the Next Lock to Pick
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Hackers have broken into the cellphones of celebrities like Scarlett Johansson and Prince William. But what about the rest of us, who might not have particularly salacious photos or voice messages stored in our phones, but nonetheless have e-mails, credit card numbers and records of our locations?

headline: Shared Meals, Shared Knowledge
text: This year, Slow Food USA, which defines “slow food” as good for its eaters, its producers and the environment — a definition anyone can get behind — set out to demonstrate that slow food can also be affordable, not only a better alternative to fast food but a less expensive one. The organization issued a $5 Challenge with the inspired rallying cry of “take back the ‘value meal’,” which in most fast food restaurants runs somewhere around five bucks.

headline: Mets Have Major Objection to a Yankee Team in Newark
text: On paper, it was the perfect solution. The Yankees’ Class AAA affiliate would play next season in Newark while its stadium near Scranton, Pa., was renovated. Players would be a short drive from Yankee Stadium, and fans would be able to see the team’s budding stars for a fraction of the price of going to a game in the Bronx.

headline: Survey Sees Major Expansion of World’s Data Centers
text: The next great expansion of the world’s digital infrastructure is under way in developing markets like those of China, Brazil and Argentina, according to a global census of the industry released on Monday.

headline: F.D.A. Lifts Restrictions on Melons
text: Faced with a lawsuit by a major produce grower, the Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday lifted import restrictions on cantaloupes from a Guatemala farm that had been linked to a multistate salmonella outbreak.

headline: The Fundamental Right
text: The right to vote is sometimes said to be the most fundamental in American democracy. Yet legal challenges to the federal voting rights law are increasing even as they highlight the racial injustices that make it essential.

headline: A Lifeline for Refugees
text: One year ago, Congress gave a temporary lifeline to thousands of older and disabled refugees. It extended for another 12 months their eligibility for cash assistance under the Supplemental Security Income program, which, for many, was their only source of income. That Congress had to do this was an unfortunate side effect of a 1996 law that placed strict time limits on benefits for refugees who did not become citizens within seven years.

headline: Gov. Christie vs. ‘Jersey Shore’
text: We share with Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey a dim view of the MTV reality show “Jersey Shore.” It is a classic example of tasteless programming that tediously mocks Italians and the State of New Jersey.

headline: A Political Wife’s Influence on an Issue
text: Four years after Gov. Rick Perry issued an executive order that would have made Texas the first state to require that sixth-grade girls be vaccinated against a sexually transmitted disease linked to cervical cancer, its genesis remains a mystery. Opponents, including Representative Michele Bachmann, suggest the governor was influenced by close ties to lobbyists for the vaccine maker, Merck, or donations from the drug company.

headline: Recipes for Chicken Dishes
text: Unexpected ways to prepare chicken at home: steamed in sake, glazed with pomegranate, rolled with scallions and more.

headline: Backlog Found in Action on Presidential Pardons
text: The president’s power to reduce sentences and grant pardons is infrequently used, and backlogs in responding to clemency petitions are common, according to a new audit report from the Department of Justice.

headline: 2 for 2, or 2 for 1?
text: Prime Minister Bibi Netanyahu of Israel, the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, and President Obama all spoke at the U.N. last week and, honestly, it is hard to decide whose speech was worse. Netanyahu’s read like a pep rally to the Likud Central Committee. Abbas’s read like an address to an Arab League meeting. Obama’s read like an appeal to Jewish voters in Florida. The president meant well, but domestic politics required that he whisper where he once spoke bold truths to both sides.

headline: Grand Jury Begins to Vote in Bronx Ticket-Fixing Case
text: The Bronx grand jury that has been hearing evidence on allegations of widespread ticket-fixing by police union officials began Tuesday to vote on whether to bring charges against those suspected of helping other officers and friends evade summonses, according to two people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Lightning Strikes for Red Sox and Rays
text: BALTIMORE

headline: U.S. Reduces Estimate of Same-Sex-Couple Households
text: The Census Bureau on Tuesday greatly lowered its estimate for the number of same-sex-couple households in the United States, saying an inconsistency in the responses on census forms had inflated the numbers.

headline: The Online Powerhouses Get Comfortable Orbiting Madison Ave.
text: Next week, when 60,000 people in marketing and communications are expected to descend on New York for Advertising Week, some of the world’s largest tech companies will be taking center stage.

headline: Filling the Void Left by Borders
text: It is tempting to view the demise of the Borders Group as a dark cloud over the future of bookselling, and certainly the disappearance of hundreds of bookstores leaves a lot of vacancies where readers once browsed the aisles.

headline: Cathy Horyn’s Milan Report
text: Cathy Horyn discusses the standout collections from Milan Fashion Week.

headline: Rights Collide as Town Clerk Sidesteps Role in Gay Marriages
text: LEDYARD, N.Y. — Rose Marie Belforti is a 57-year-old cheese maker, the elected town clerk in this sprawling Finger Lakes farming community and a self-described Bible-believing Christian. She believes that God has condemned homosexuality as a sin, so she does not want to sign same-sex marriage licenses; instead, she has arranged for a deputy to issue all marriage licenses by appointment.

headline: Instead of Waiting for Storm Aid, Going Online in a Do-It-Yourself Movement
text: For Rob Hastings, it began when a fellow farmer offered him a pig.

headline: Private School Fights Tutoring Firm’s Tactic
text: The battle against high-priced tutors is heating up at Riverdale Country School.

headline: Decoding the God Complex
text: WASHINGTON

headline: N.B.A. Talks Resume, but Little Is Revealed
text: David Stern was smiling Tuesday afternoon — not because the N.B.A. ended its lockout, but because he has become mindful that every facial tic now fuels a dozen interpretations about the state of labor talks.

headline: State Workers’ Union Rejects Contract, Risking 3,500 Layoffs
text: ALBANY — The second-largest union of New York State employees has rejected a package of wage and benefits concessions negotiated by the Cuomo administration, blowing a hole in the state budget that could now prompt the largest wave of layoffs in two decades.

headline: Christie Adds Little New, but Fails to Quell the Talk
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey failed to address intense speculation about his presidential ambitions on Tuesday night during a foreign policy address at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library in California.

headline: In Pakistani Media, the U.S. Is a Target for Acrimony
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The United States might still be weighing its options about how to deal with Pakistan, but many politicians, retired army generals and popular television talk show hosts here have already made up their minds that America is on the warpath with their country.

headline: Collins Is Signed Up; Reyes Keeps Lighting It Up
text: On the day the Mets exercised Manager Terry Collins’s club option for the 2013 season, Jose Reyes provided a jolt of excitement in what could be his next-to-last game in a Mets uniform.

headline: Champions League Wednesday Preview: Messi Chasing History, Torres Chasing Goals
text: Matchday 2 of the UEFA Champions League’s group stage comes to a close with eight games on Wednesday. Across the continent, perhaps the most interesting games will be in Spain, where Fernando Torres will be trying to score in his third straight game; and in Belarus, where another hat trick for Barcelona’s Lionel Messi (he has two in his last three games) will put the 24-year-old Argentine into second place among the club’s career goal-scorers, surpassing Laszlo Kubala.

headline: Wednesday: Miser’s Cry
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — What kind of CLOUT do you have in your everyday life?

headline: An Interview With Frida Giannini
text: Suzy Menkes, the fashion editor of The International Herald Tribune, speaks with the creative director of Gucci as it celebrates its 90th anniversary with a new museum in Florence.

headline: He’s Written a Play. Who’s the Author?
text: Early in “The Submission,” Jeff Talbott’s perky tale of racial pride and prejudice in the theater, a fledgling playwright praises a friend’s recently completed script. “It’s so ... producible,” he says in wonder. “Four characters? One set? I mean, it could be done, you know?”

headline: A Family Tries to Blend Despite Some Curdling
text: California dreams wither under a blazing sun in “Lemon Sky,” a 1970 drama by Lanford Wilson that has been affectionately revived by the Keen Company at the Harold Clurman Theater. Among the most autobiographical works by Mr. Wilson, the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright who died earlier this year, this simultaneously wry and plaintive memory play explores a painful passage in the life of a 17-year-old Nebraska boy who is reunited with his estranged father for an uneasy late attempt at father-son bonding.

headline: A Spray Like a Punch in the Face
text: Last week, a girl in the Bronx pulled out a can of pepper spray and used it in a fight with two other girls in her high school, an event that resulted in her arrest, her mother’s arrest and a report on WNBC.

headline: As Thousands Leave Libya, and Jobs, Niger Feels Impact
text: NIAMEY, Niger — For tens of thousands of people from Niger, the downfall of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi has been an economic catastrophe, plunging them suddenly from a world of good pay in Libya back into the precarious universe of their home country, one of the poorest and most dependent nations on earth.

headline: Documenting the ‘Watch List” Process
text: F.B.I. documents open a window into the secretive process by which officials place the names of people suspected of links to terrorism on a “watch list.”

headline: Even Those Cleared of Crimes Can Stay on F.B.I.’s Watch List
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Bureau of Investigation is permitted to include people on the government’s terrorist watch list even if they have been acquitted of terrorism-related offenses or the charges are dropped, according to newly released documents.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,770 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

headline: Virtual World Surges in New York
text: The rapidly shifting partnership between online giants and Madison Avenue has driven the move from back-office cubicles to elaborately designed corporate suites in New York intended to impress advertisers.

headline: N.H.L. Will Not Discipline Player Over Slur Allegation
text: The N.H.L. ruled Tuesday that it lacked sufficient evidence to determine whether Flyers forward Wayne Simmonds directed a homophobic slur at the Rangers’ Sean Avery during a preseason game Monday night in Philadelphia.

headline: As a Consultant Stands Trial, Bloomberg’s Style Comes Under Scrutiny
text: Kevin Sheekey, a former deputy mayor and now a gilded operative for Bloomberg L.P., sat in a witness chair in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on Tuesday and affected a political handler’s insouciance.

headline: A New Look Is Coming to Times Square: Minimalism
text: Times Square, whose fiery neon signs and jumbo billboards make it the epitome of larger-than-life New York, is about to get a modern, minimalist sprucing up.

headline: Lottery Numbers
As Scorn for Vote Grows, Protests Surge Around Globe
text: MADRID — Hundreds of thousands of disillusioned Indians cheer a rural activist on a hunger strike. Israel reels before the largest street demonstrations in its history. Enraged young people in Spain and Greece take over public squares across their countries.

headline: NYT Front Page for 09/28/11
text: NYT Front Page for 09/28/11

headline: Health Insurers Push Premiums Sharply Higher
text: Major health insurance companies have been charging sharply higher premiums this year, outstripping any growth in workers’ wages and creating more uncertainty for the Obama administration and employers who are struggling to drive down an unrelenting rise in medical costs.

headline: Corrections: September 28
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Real Madrid Outshines Ajax
text: MADRID — On Saturday, Real Madrid beat its newly promoted neighbors Rayo Vallecano, 6-2. But with Barcelona’s awe-inspiring 5-0 thrashing of Atletico Madrid later that evening, it was up to Real Madrid to return serve and deliver the message that the two giants of Spain still tower over La Liga — and perhaps of all soccer.

headline: With Yankees Looking Ahead, the Rays Keep Pace
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — The most critical moments of the Boston Red Sox season flickered on television in the Tampa Bay Rays’ clubhouse. Most players sipped beer and rooted loudly for their new favorite team, the Baltimore Orioles.

headline: Appeal Trial Nears End for American Student
text: PERUGIA, Italy — Femme fatale or hapless young American woman abroad? Sex-starved “she-devil” or bright-eyed ingénue who liked to affectionately rub noses with her new Italian beau?

headline: Braves Stumbling as Two Veterans Struggle With Slump and Injury
text: ATLANTA — On a night of desperation for the Braves, the spotlight was trained Tuesday on their two deans.

headline: New Jersey Fugitive Is Caught in Portugal After 41 Years
text: The search for George Wright had long ago gone cold. A convicted murderer, Mr. Wright escaped from prison in New Jersey, hijacked a plane to Algeria and disappeared — all back in the early 1970s.

headline: Saudi Arabia: 10 Lashes for Driving
text: Two days after King Abdullah granted women the right to vote and run for public office, starting in 2015, a court on Tuesday sentenced a woman to 10 lashes for violating religious rules prohibiting women in the kingdom from driving, activists and local news media said. The woman, Shaimaa Ghassaneya, was found guilty of driving in Jidda in July. Her sentence was unusually severe for the crime, which typically results in several days of detention. Activists said she planned to appeal. More women have been encouraged to violate the driving ban in recent months, as part of the social media-driven Women2Drive campaign. At least two more were expected to stand trial in the coming months.

headline: Egypt: Pipeline to Israel Attacked
text: Militants on Tuesday attacked a pipeline carrying natural gas from Egypt to Jordan and Israel. It was the sixth attack on the pipeline since the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak in February. Security officials said the militants set off an explosion at a pumping station outside the town of Al Arish in the northern Sinai Peninsula. Two people were killed and several buildings were damaged. Israel usually relies on Egyptian gas to meet 40 percent of its electricity needs, but damage from an attack in July brought shipments to a halt. The authorities did not name suspects in the attack.

headline: Turkey Seeks Mediation on Drilling
text: Turkey is proposing that the United Nations create a commission to mediate an agreement on revenue sharing between Greek and Turkish Cypriots before any gas exploration begins off the divided island in the Mediterranean. Prime Minister Najib Mikati of Lebanon said he had agreed to hold off on any accord in an area of ocean where the claims of Cyprus, Lebanon and Israel overlap until the mediation is completed. Diplomats said that an agreement between Lebanon and Cyprus would virtually assure that the three countries agreed to the demarcation of their exploration zones. Turkey has threatened to use warships to prevent any drilling until there is an agreement between the Cypriots about the proceeds.

headline: Dries Van Noten: Spring 2012 RTW
text: Paris

headline: Rochas: Spring 2012 RTW
text: Paris

headline: Gareth Pugh: Spring 2012 RTW
text: Paris

headline: How Exercise Can Strengthen the Brain
text: Can exercise make the brain more fit? That absorbing question inspired a new study at the University of South Carolina during which scientists assembled mice and assigned half to run for an hour a day on little treadmills, while the rest lounged in their cages without exercising.

headline: I.I.H.S. Study: Redesigned Front Ends of S.U.V.’s Have Led to Fewer Crash Deaths
text: Sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks on the road today are far less deadly in frontal and side-impact collisions with passenger cars and minivans than earlier models, according to a study released Wednesday by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.

headline: Word of the Day | connubial
text: connubial •\kə-ˈnü-be-əl, -ˈnyü-\• adjective

headline: Start-Up in California Plans to Capture Lithium, and Market Share
text: A start-up company will announce on Wednesday that it is beginning commercial operations at a factory in Southern California to capture lithium from existing geothermal energy plants, a technology it says has the potential to turn the United States into a major lithium exporter.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: A Father Loses Strength
text: The Challenge: Can you solve a medical mystery involving a middle-aged father who suddenly loses strength in his arms and legs?

headline: After Speech, Christie Revels in Pleas to Run
text: SIMI VALLEY, Calif. — When Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey took the lectern at the Reagan library here on Tuesday night, he initially stuck to his script, a mostly dry speech that took a few swipes at President Obama.

headline: Witness, Expert and Inmate Statements in Jails Report
text: Civilian witnesses, prison experts and former inmates enter their statements in an American Civil Liberties Union report. Some of the documents contain graphic reports of abuse.

headline: Report Details Wide Abuse in Los Angeles Jail System
text: LOS ANGELES — One inmate said he was forced to walk down a hallway naked after sheriff’s deputies accused him of stealing a piece of mail. They taunted him in Spanish, calling him a derogatory name for homosexuals.

headline: A Letter to Seward and Morelle
text: A letter from Health Care for All New York regarding health insurance rate increases.

headline: Scuffle at United Nations Caught on Video
text: In the halls of the United Nations, where decorum and diplomacy usually reign, something decidedly more surly happened on Friday: a shoving match.

headline: Students’ Knowledge of Civil Rights History Has Deteriorated, Study Finds

headline: D.I.Y. Steaks on the Battlefield in Afghanistan
text: It was cold and quiet up on the Abas Ghar ridge. The soldiers were on the third day of a combat operation aimed at flushing out insurgents in the Korengal Valley — widely considered one of the deadliest places for American soldiers in Afghanistan. Many took the lull in fighting as an opportunity to open up an MRE (Meal, Ready-to-Eat) ration pack. Sergeant Stichter sat beside a large tree, spreading the contents of a tube of jelly over a beef patty. Sterling Jones watched the process and chuckled to himself, “We eat our boredom.”

headline: A Crisis of Confidence Deep in the Heart of Texas
text: Back in 1944, an advertising executive named John Randolph put together a booklet called “Texas Brags.” It was an offshoot of an ad campaign for Jax beer, and it contained some fun facts about my home state, including “If all the hogs in Texas were one big hog, he could dig the Panama Canal with three roots and a grunt.” Or “The King Ranch is so big that there is a month’s difference in seasons between the northern and southern parts.” And “Son, it is very rude to ask a man where he is from. If he is from Texas, you will find out, and if he’s not, don’t embarrass him.”

headline: Tip of the Week: Browser Shortcuts
text: Live hyperlinks are great for whisking you to the Web in a hurry, but addresses formatted as regular text still require cutting and pasting into the browser to get you to the page. If you use Mozilla Firefox or Google’s Chrome browser, you can save a step. After copying the Web address from text, right click on the browser’s address bar and choose the “Paste and Go” option to automatically zip over to that page.

headline: Mother Modern
text: Getting a read on the city of Los Angeles has never been easy. Twenty years ago, when my husband was offered a job in L.A., we left New York. I figured that as a writer, my work was portable, and as an urbanite, I would easily adjust. But Los Angeles, with its shifting perspectives and unwieldy size, was perplexing. When we first arrived, I spoke with an architectural historian on the verge of relocating. He offered me one salient tip before making his exit: “The two most interesting things about Los Angeles,” he said, “are the domestic architecture and the ephemeral population.” He was right: the stream of characters is constant, and the number of exceptional houses is astonishing. And as the critic Reyner Banham had so famously done before me, I got my driver’s license, began reading Esther McCoy and learned to love Los Angeles.

headline: American Ballet Theater to Begin Training Course in Russia
text: American Ballet Theater is taking its traditions into a center of the dance world. The company said on Wednesday that it would present a weeklong course on its training techniques in St. Petersburg, Russia, home of the Mariinsky Theater — the former Kirov — and a venerable part of ballet history. Ballet Theater will hold the five-day session starting on Oct. 31 to present its national training curriculum, which the company said had certified 550 teachers across the United States since 2008, when it began. The curriculum combines “artistic training with the basics of dancer health and child development,” Ballet Theater said. The news follows a recent announcement that one of the company’s stars, David Hallberg, would take on a principal dancer position with the Bolshoi Ballet in Moscow, the first American in such a role.

headline: Four Legs and an Eye for Landscaping

There had been a stepdog, Rudy, my girlfriend’s large black, placid Labrador and German shepherd mix, and it is true that my dad loved Rudy because he was the only member of the family willing to share his luncheon meats. But Rudy had driven me to a Jungian analyst after I had yelled, “What is this dog doing on the bed?” and Lois had replied, “What are you doing on the bed?”

headline: Polls Agree: Food ‘System’ Needs Fixing
text: With the Farm Bill fast approaching, and the congressional Super Committee taking a hard look at which farm programs to cut and which to preserve, this is a good moment for Americans to let their feelings on these things be known. The Environmental Working Group (EWG) has just released a compelling comparison of two brand new polls detailing Americans’ views of our current food system. One poll was commissioned by the conservation-minded David and Lucile Packard Foundation, the other by the U.S. Farmers and Ranchers Alliance, (USFRA) a well-funded group intent on advancing the interests and restoring the image of big agriculture.

headline: Signature Theater Company Announces Plays and Discounted Tickets

James Houghton, artistic director of Signature, also announced on Wednesday that all tickets for the regular runs of productions would be sold for $25 during the next decade, an extension of this nonprofit theater company’s landmark program to make shows more affordable to audiences.

headline: Tiebreaker Mania: Let’s Play Two?

Should the race for the wild card end in a tie in each league — an outcome easy to picture because both races are tied entering the final games Wednesday night and none of these teams are playing each other — Thursday could feature two tiebreaker games, which would be a first.

headline: Once Again, They Like Ike

Their outpouring of springtime sheaths, cocktail frocks, camp shirts and circle skirts, all emblems of late 1950s bourgeois chic, seemed worthy at times of Suzy Parker, their collections like outtakes from a Slim Aarons shoot.

headline: My Three Favorite Teams — Despite Everything
text: Losers. I love them. That’s why my three favorite sports teams are the Cleveland Cavaliers, the Cleveland Indians and the Cleveland Browns. As every Cleveland sports fan knows, we haven’t finished on top in a major sport since 1964, when the Browns won their last NFL championship — before it was even the Super Bowl. The Indians last won the World Series in 1948, and the Cavaliers have never been champions.

headline: Seattle Firm Struggles in the Biggest Market

Ms. Rhodes projects that revenue for the company this year will be $6 million.

headline: Center Stage
text: With its shimmering vision of a fairy-tale realm where grace and good manners prevail, Oliver Messel’s production of “The Sleeping Beauty” for Sadler’s Wells (later the Royal) Ballet, in 1946, raised the curtain on London’s postwar recovery and held a mirror to England’s sense of pride. When the ballet was performed at the Metropolitan Opera House in New York three years later, applause greeted the scenery — a magnificent palace extending into the wings and beyond, set in a stately park among ancient trees. “The Sleeping Beauty” was such a success that Messel never lived it down. For decades, it has been the basis of his reputation, and so irresistible and magical is its spell that, had he done nothing else, it would have been enough.

headline: The Buzz
text: A   PREVIEW of the must-attend parties, talked-about openings and fashionable night spots for the week ahead.

headline: N.F.L. Says Players Union Delaying H.G.H. Testing This Season
text: A program for human growth hormone testing in the N.F.L., which the league promoted last month as a done deal, appears highly unlikely for this season. It has become bogged down in a technical dispute among the league, the players union and the international testing agency advising both groups.

headline: Tony Bennett Sells Great for a Man His – or Any – Age
text: Billboard’s headline says it all: “Tony Bennett Becomes Oldest Living Artist to Top Billboard 200.”

headline: The Caucus | Readers on Anita Perry
text: Sept. 28, 2011 — Susan Saulny looks through reader feedback on the wife of Gov. Rick Perry of Texas.

headline: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from India, Pakistan, Libya and Germany.

headline: The Almost-Lost Poem That Changed the World
text: History can be fatal to literature. Aeschylus wrote 80 or 90 plays, and Sophocles 120, yet we have just seven of each. Didymus Chalcenterus of Alexandria reportedly wrote 3,500 books; not one exists today. Between classical antiquity and us, there has been a hecatomb of words. They have been burned, thrown away, lost to mold or pulverized. They have been rubbed off so that vellum and papyrus could be reused. Bookworms have eaten them by the dictionary-load.

headline: Talking With Massimiliano Giornetti of Ferragamo
text: MILAN

headline: Starz Gives ‘Boss’ Second Season Even Before the Series Premiere
text: Sensing – or at least fervently hoping – that it has a hit on its hands, Starz Entertainment, the premium cable service, announced Tuesday that it would renew the drama series, “Boss,” starring Kelsey Grammer, for a second season even before the show has its premiere on Oct. 21. The show features Mr. Grammer as the fictional mayor of Chicago, suffering from a degenerative brain disorder that is causing his world to slowly collapse.

headline: Doctor Said Jackson Was in ‘Perfect Health,’ Witness Says
text: LOS ANGELES — Prosecution witnesses testified Wednesday at the trial of Dr. Conrad Murray, Michael Jackson’s personal physician, that Dr. Murray had insisted that the singer was in “perfect health” in the days before Mr. Jackson’s death and had originally sought $5 million for his services during a series of concerts.

headline: How Weird Can It Get?
text: All through the baseball playoffs, Mike Tanier will provide the Bats blog with daily updates on less-than-important developments from around the league. He vows to keep Phillies homerism to a minimum.

headline: Tucson Shooting Suspect to Have More Treatment
text: TUCSON — A federal judge ruled on Wednesday that Jared L. Loughner would undergo four more months of treatment in a federal psychiatric facility to see if he recovers enough to stand trial on charges that he killed six people and wounded 13 others, including Representative Gabrielle Giffords, on Jan. 8.

headline: Pace to Bring Performances to Lower Manhattan
text: Responding to what it sees as a cultural need in Lower Manhattan as plans for a proposed performing arts center at the World Trade Center site remain up in the air, Pace University announced this week that it will begin a new annual series of performing and visual-arts programs at its 650-seat Michael Schimmel Center for the Arts on Spruce Street near City Hall.

headline: Nowhere to Go but Up? Analyzing Economic Measures in a Downturn
text: Overview | How do we know when the economy is in a recession? How do key economic indicators perform in a downturn? In this lesson, students create graphs of various economic measurements, using quantitative and qualitative reasoning skills to compare, contrast and correlate the performance of measures like gross domestic product, unemployment and personal income.

headline: Global Athlete
text: The IHT editor Tom Sims runs the Berlin Marathon as he begins his journey to meet global athletes finding inspiration and fitness while experiencing different countries and cultures.

headline: Eurofile | We Dare You to Get a Reservation
text: Though la rentrée, or the fall season, which begins when privileged Parisians return to work in September after their long summer holidays, traditionally sees the city’s gastronomic calendar come to a roiling boil, a spate of midsummer openings stole some of autumn’s usual heat: notably, Au Passage, a hip new bistrot a vins; Neva Cuisine, an excellent modern bistro behind the Gare Saint Lazare; and Agapé Sustance, a tiny but brilliant contemporary French table in the heart of touristy Saint-Germain-des-Pres. Still, the coming of that delicious season when Paris gutters start filling up with bronze-colored chestnut leaves just wouldn’t be the same without a new restaurant or two to create to create a reservations frenzy, and distinguish for all the world those who are in the la loop.

headline: Is This Man the G.O.P.’s Best Bet for 2012?
text: Gail Collins: David, are you reconciled to the fact that Mitt Romney is going to be the Republican presidential nominee?

headline: SAT Fraud in New York State Exposed
text: A 19-year-old college student from Long Island allegedly charged local high school students up to $2,500 each to sit for the SAT in their name, the Associated Press reported on Wednesday.

headline: Tigers Awaiting Playoff Fate
text: The Detroit Tigers know just about everything about their upcoming playoff run, except for one big thing: their opponent. The Yankees, Red Sox, Rays are factors in the unsolved equation, but much can still be revealed about what the Tigers intend to do in their first post-season since 2006.

headline: In Arizona, a Sly Form of Flattery
text: PHOENIX — Most of the fans had left the ballpark by the time the Diamondbacks’ Ryan Roberts came to the plate Tuesday night in the bottom of the tenth inning with his team down to its final out in a game with enormous postseason implications.

headline: A Century of New York in Color
text: Color Photographs of New York City

headline: If a Close Shave Is Just Too Close
text: IN a world where men sport permanent stubble on their faces, the capacity to grow a thick, bristly beard in just 48 hours can be considered an evolutionary advantage. Alas, not one conferred upon Clinton Weber, the smooth-cheeked runway model forced to endured a futile “stubble trim” backstage at the Duckie Brown show during New York’s Fashion Week.

headline: Trial Run
text: LIKE strawberries in winter, 24/7 stubble was not what nature had in mind. These new stubble trimmers — electric razors engineered to reduce facial hair to a shadow — help subdue nature’s intent, but not without a battle. The question is whether the occasional war wounds (red skin, uneven stubble, precious minutes squandered over the sink) are worth the spoils. (Prices listed are provided by the manufacturers.) DOUGLAS QUENQUA

headline: In Trading Scandal, a Reason to Enforce the Volcker Rule
text: As a draft of the Volcker Rule has made the rounds in the last several weeks, it has alternatively caused fits of despair and cries of exultation. And that’s just among the proponents of the regulation.

headline: Embracing a Snow Bowl
text: When the N.F.L. decided the site of the 2014 Super Bowl would be the new Giants/Jets stadium in the Meadowlands, an involuntary shiver went through the league, visions of snowplows and Eskimo masks dancing through everyone’s heads.

headline: Inspector May Have Used Pepper Spray on Others, Video Shows
text: The deputy police inspector accused of sending a blast of pepper spray toward four female protesters on Saturday may have used the spray on others that day.

headline: U.S.: 5 Guys for 2 Friendlies
text: Coach Jurgen Klinsmann of the United States may have an impressive pedigree and a million-dollar smile, but he also has a 0-2-1 record and an increasingly anxious fan base. Klinsmann needs to start winning games (or does he?), and the upcoming exhibitions against Honduras and Ecuador would be an ideal time to start.

headline: Charisma and Chris Christie
text: Last night’s quasi-campaign speech at the Reagan Library notwithstanding, Chris Christie almost certainly isn’t running for president. If he were to run for president, he could easily end up proving a kind of Fred Thompson-Rudy Giuliani hybrid — a late-entering Northeastern moderate savior figure who never figures out how to campaign effectively and ends up being consigned to a spoiler role. No candidate looks as appealing the day after they get in the race as they did the day before, and a relatively inexperienced blue state governor running for the Republican nomination at a moment of national crisis is unlikely to prove an exception to this rule.

headline: Rocking the Palazzo With Gucci
text: FLORENCE, Italy

headline: Scene City: Gucci Museum
text: For Milan Fashion Week, Gucci celebrates its new museum in Florence.

headline: Greek Bonds Lure Some, Despite Risk
text: LONDON — Greece may never be able to pay off its huge debts, but its bonds, long scorned by investors, are suddenly being gobbled up by hedge funds.

headline: Iran Mass-Produces New Missile and Rejects ‘Hot Line’ Idea With America
text: Iran announced the mass production of a new cruise missile on Wednesday, the latest in a series of belligerent-sounding proclamations from that country in the face of its increased isolation by a Western-led group of nations worried about Iran’s nuclear program and avowed hostility toward Israel.

headline: Supreme Court Is Asked to Rule on Health Care
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration asked the Supreme Court on Wednesday to hear a case concerning the 2010 health care overhaul law. The development, which came unexpectedly fast, makes it all but certain that the court will soon agree to hear one or more cases involving challenges to the law, with arguments by the spring and a decision by June, in time to land in the middle of the 2012 presidential campaign.

headline: Credit Cards Aimed at College Students
text: The new rules restricting aggressive credit card marketing on campus, included in the CARD Act of 2009, seem to have reduced the practice, says a report from Credit.com.

headline: Romney Keeps Sights on Obama
text: GOFFSTOWN, N.H. — Though Republican Party leaders have spent the last week casting about for an alternative to the current crop of 2012 presidential hopefuls — Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey comes to mind — Mitt Romney used a town-hall-style at Saint Anselm College on Wednesday to attack President Obama, mentioning his Republican rivals only when asked.

headline: If Holly Golightly Had a Grandson
text: AT 30, Ari Seth Cohen already possesses a vintage soul. Neatly coiffed, sporting a polka-dot shirt and dapper sport coat, he has a tidy, calm mien that evokes the days before leisure became an extreme sport.

headline: Stone Links
text: A gathering of philosophy-related links from the past week.

headline: A Detective Who Gazes Into the Abyss
text: IN the increasingly bland, featureless landscape of TV crime drama it is somehow heartening to come upon a homicide detective who can be called, as the hero of “Luther” is, His Satanic Majesty — by a co-worker, no less. That tantalizing sobriquet pops up early in the first episode of the series’s second season, now on BBC America, and it should be music to the ears of genre fans who prefer their crime fighters tormented.

headline: Fashion Bloggers, Posted and Represented
text: LINDSEY CALLA, the 27-year-old behind the fashion blog Saucy Glossie, sat in a Midtown cafe one recent afternoon and offered a guiding career principle: “You should work and make money.”

headline: Reyes Hits, Then Sits and Eventually Celebrates
text: Citi Field was expected to be the stage Wednesday for a bit of drama featuring one of baseball’s most effervescent characters.

headline: Perry Walks Back on Heartless Remark
text: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas said Wednesday that it was “inappropriate” of him to have branded as heartless those who oppose tuition breaks for the children of illegal immigrants.

text: Amazon introduces a new tablet; lawyers assess the competency of the accused Gabrielle Giffords shooter; and Al Qaeda urges Iran to stop promoting 9/11 conspiracies.

headline: Now Pitching for the Yankees: Dellin Betances
text: The Yankees are putting a fairly representative lineup on the field Wednesday night in a game that means everything to their opponent, the Tampa Bay Rays, and very little to them.

headline: Quiet for Years, Italian Church Blasts Behavior of the Nation’s Political Elite
text: ROME — Over the last several years, the Roman Catholic Church in Italy has largely looked the other way as reports emerged of sex and corruption scandals among the country’s political elite, many of them centered on Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi. But a recent published account of a party at Mr. Berlusconi’s home, where one female guest was said to have performed a striptease dressed as a nun, might have been more than the church could stand.

text: A Victorian near Philadelphia, a house in Chattahoochee Hills, Ga., and a loft in a former industrial building in Chicago.

headline: UBS’s New Chief: We Will Keep Our Investment Bank
text: In case UBS employees still doubted the Swiss bank’s plans to keep its investment banking operations, the firm’s new interim chief executive reiterated that the division was not going anywhere.

text: On Thursday and Friday,

headline: Reliable Sources in an Age of Too Much Information
text: A few days ago I was interviewed about the challenges and opportunities in reporting on complicated, but consequential, science (climate change being a prime example) for the Journalist’s Resource project of Harvard’s Joan Shorenstein Center on the Press, Politics and Public Policy. The center’s Web site is full of useful background and tools for writers, including a journalist’s primer on statistical terms used in research studies and a short reflection on online research by Alexis Madrigal of The Atlantic.

headline: Myths and Legends Open Paris Ballet
text: PARIS — History and tradition, the present and the new. That seems to be the thinking behind the Greek-myth pairing of Serge Lifar’s 1950 “Phèdre” and Alexei Ratmansky’s new “Psyché” with which the Paris Opera Ballet has just opened its season here. (In another nod to tradition, the opening-night gala last week was canceled because of a technicians’ strike. Plus ça change, etc.)

text: Ferragamo starts a trend; the southern end of the High Line becomes a fashion draw; and other items.

headline: Fixed-Gear Bicycles are an American Fixture in Paris

headline: Fukushima’s Contamination Produces Some Surprises at Sea
text: Six months after the accident at Fukushima Daiichi, the news flow from the stricken nuclear power plant has slowed, but scientific studies of radioactive material in the ocean are just beginning to bear fruit.

headline: ‘Coal + Ice’ in Beijing
text: A behind-the-scenes video of the "Coal + Ice" exhibit presented by the Asia Society at Three Shadows Photography Art Center in Beijing. (Video courtesy of the Asia Society.)

headline: Reports About Australia’s Privately Run Immigration Detention System
text: No country has more completely outsourced immigration enforcement — with more troubled results — than Australia. Two investigations, from 2011 and 2004, identified areas of noncompliance and breaches of detainees’ human rights.

headline: Costumes for a Kid-Cool World
text: LEGGY Blake Lively look-alikes pressed their lips to martini glasses, wearing sequined designer dresses with plunging necklines. Wall Street guys in untucked dress shirts hassled bull-necked club managers for prime tables. Deafening dance music blared, as swirling searchlights swept the crowd.

headline: Clip: ‘Carnage’
text: A scene from “Carnage,” the new film from Roman Polanski.

headline: In California, a New Lemon Law to Protect Used-Car Shoppers
text: A new California law, the first of its kind in the nation, is requiring new- and used-car dealers to check their used vehicles against a federal government database and mark them with a red warning sticker if they find a serious problem.

headline: Announcement of 2017-25 Federal Fuel Efficiency Standards Delayed Until November
text: The federal government has delayed its release of 2017-25 targets for Corporate Average Fuel Economy, or CAFE, until mid-November, according to the Environmental Protection Agency. The news marks a delay from the Obama administration’s original intention to have the standards out by the end of September.

headline: Israelis Happy at Home but Glum About Peace
text: JERUSALEM — With the start of the Jewish New Year at sunset on Wednesday, a traditional time for stock-taking in Israel, the public mood seemed paradoxical: a growing disillusionment with the prospect of Middle East peace yet a marked sense of satisfaction with life here.

headline: In Venice, a Home Ensconced in Glass

headline: Old Venetian Meets Modern
text: VENICE — As the director general of the City of Venice, Marco Agostini is more knowledgeable than many Venetians about the 15th-century Palladian palaces and decorous Gothic villas that make up some of the most striking examples of Italian architecture.

headline: Watchdogs Call Out 4 Nonprofits as Too Political for Tax Exemption
text: 6:04 p.m. | Updated Advocates of tighter campaign laws asked the Internal Revenue Service on Wednesday to examine the activities of four tax-exempt organizations that are expected to play a major role in influencing the 2012 elections, arguing that the groups should be required to register as political organizations, lose their tax exemptions and disclose their donors.

headline: Joe Jonas Comes of Age
text: THERE is power in numbers, and so a lone Jonas walking into a Midtown Manhattan restaurant does not have nearly the oomph of a threesome. Joe Jonas, middle child of the phenom Jonas Brothers, went nearly unrecognized over a long lunch at Asia de Cuba recently, perhaps because most of the other diners were, you know, adults.

headline: Attack Kills Police Officers in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Eight police officers were killed overnight at a hilltop checkpoint in the fourth episode in three months taking aim at the police in Helmand Province.

headline: Not Just Made in China, But Designed There, Too
text: Beijing Design Week, which runs from Sept. 26 to Oct. 3, will showcase more than 2,000 works from some 30 countries — and, perhaps more significant, it will highlight China’s resolve to become a cultural superpower. Installations span the city, from the 751 industrial district and the sleek Sanlitun neighborhood to the China Millennium Monument, where the British designer Paul Cocksedge’s massive piece — 30 sheets of rolled steel engraved with classical Chinese and English poetry — anchors this year’s “Guest City” and embodies the week’s spirit of aesthetic exchange. The week also marks the opening of the First Beijing International Design Triennial, organized around the theme of “Ren: Good Design” and held at the National Museum of China. Ren, which loosely translates as “caring for others,” locates curatorial efforts in a communal context that jibes, at least ideologically, with the country’s political principles and sets a positive agenda for the hothouse environment of contemporary China.

headline: Skin-Deep Beauty? It Looks Like Chicken
text: This is not your typical come-hither pinup. Nor does it fit neatly into the category that most would call “food porn.”

headline: Colbert: ‘Global Warming is Real, Folks’
text: Stephen Colbert spent some time on Monday night, between Radiohead songs, dissecting realities on global warming and energy using very sharp satirical tools:

headline: TV Chat: Ask the Critics
text: Are you watching “Terra Nova” or any of the other lavishly produced dramas of the new fall television season?

headline: Mom’s a Drunk, Dad’s a Writer: A Recipe for Disaster and a Memoir
text: It’s all about the wisecracks for Jeanne Darst, a memoirist who sticks to the crazy-family template in “Fiction Ruined My Family.” Ms. Darst grew up with her parents’ alcoholism, social pretensions, delusional behavior and financial instability. She and her three sisters played peculiar games. (“You’re Patty Hearst, and we’re the S.L.A.”) She began drinking heavily herself and took temporary jobs (like hydrangea window-box gardener), failing at all of them. She watched as her parents’ marriage broke up and tried not to mimic their behavior.

headline: Council Will Not Require Mayor to Disclose Travel
text: A bill that would have required New York City mayors to disclose when they make long-distance trips will not get a hearing in the City Council, the bill’s sponsor, Peter F. Vallone Jr., said on Wednesday.

headline: In Bratislava, an Apartment With Castle Views

headline: Clashing Over a Landmark
text: The former Manufacturers Hanover Trust building, a Modernism landmark on Fifth Avenue at 43rd Street, is the subject of a disagreement between the city and architectural preservationists.

headline: Bolton’s Holden Out Six More Months
text: Midfielder Stuart Holden, who returned to Bolton’s first-team lineup last week after missing six months with a knee injury, will miss at least six more months after a setback.

headline: A Warning as Wall Street Moves Into Emerging Markets

headline: TimesCast | Amazon Fire Tablet
text: Personal technology reporter Sam Grobart reports on Amazon's new tablet device, Kindle Fire, which sells for $199.

headline: Crooks Onstage (Madoff, et al.) in Washington
text: WASHINGTON — Bernard L. Madoff, the reviled mastermind of the Ponzi scheme that appalled the world just as the financial tailspin began, has faded from the front pages, his monstrous crimes overshadowed by the continuing financial woes that lack easily identifiable (and imprisonable) villains. He will doubtless serve the rest of his life in prison. But here he was onstage, in the form of a fictionalized facsimile, in Deb Margolin’s long-aborning play, “Imagining Madoff,” which ended its run at Theater J here over the weekend.

headline: In the Mideast, Tech Start-Ups Seek Support
text: When Lebnan Nader introduced his iPhone app in late August, the game was an instant hit. Within four days Birdy Nam Nam — think Angry Birds meets Arab Spring — had been downloaded more than 400,000 times.

headline: ‘New Girl’ Gets Full Embrace
text: While it may be too early to crown “New Girl” on Fox as the first hit of the season, the show held strong on Tuesday with 9.3 million total viewers, finishing first for the night in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic. That was enough to earn Zooey Deschanel, who plays the “adorkable” Jess, and her colleagues the embrace of the network, as Bill Carter reported on Media Decoder: “The network ordered 11 more episodes, for a total 24 for the year, a signal that it wants as much ‘New Girl’ as it can possibly get.”

headline: Fall Design | The Source
text: Designs that make the ideal dinner companions. Go to interactive feature >>

headline: An Investment Banker’s Fortunes Rise With Brazil’s
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — In this city, where conspicuous consumption is common, André Esteves is virtually anonymous among the suits of the financial district.

headline: With Growing Confidence, India Pursues Mergers Abroad
text: MUMBAI, India — WHEN the Ssangyong Motor company, a South Korean sport utility vehicle maker, came up for sale twice in the last seven years, the Indian auto company Mahindra & Mahindra passed both times.

headline: Emerging Markets Offer Banks Profits, but Headaches Too

text: Burdened by slowing consumer spending at home, Wal-Mart Stores sought another jolt to its sales.

text: Globalization has been kind to Wall Street.

headline: For Deals, Wall Street Goes East
text: In 1902, the International Banking Corporation, a predecessor of Citigroup, went in search of the next big gold rush. But it did not go west. It opened up small outposts in Shanghai, Calcutta and Manila. In 1914, another Citigroup ancestor opened a branch in Buenos Aires, becoming the first big American player in the city.

headline: The value of e-mail; new solid-state hard drives; Amazon’s new tablet; tech news.
text: David Streitfeld of The Times technology desk provides commentary on the current state of the tablet-computer wars and what Amazon’s entry into the fray means for Apple’s stranglehold on the market. Jeff Hardy and Derek Curtis, two vice-presidents of SmarterTools, Inc., explain why an e-mail address is a valuable piece of currency to companies and advertisers. Larry O’Connor, the founder and president of Other World Computing, discusses the technical advantages of solid-state drives. This week’s Tip of the Week offers shortcuts for working with plain-text Web addresses. The tech-news roundup takes a look at Facebook’s latest privacy flap and Spotify integration — as well as upgrade announcement this week for the Firefox browser, Adobe Photoshop Elements and Microsoft’s Windows Phone operating system.

headline: Tutu and Dalai Lama Criticize South Africa Over Visa Delay
text: South Africa’s failure to issue a visa to the Dalai Lama, or even respond to his repeated requests for one, was sharply criticized on Wednesday by the Dalai Lama and by Desmond Tutu, the former Archbishop of Capetown. The two men called the failure disrespectful.

headline: Mondo Collection in the Flatiron District
text: As its name implies, the Mondo Collection, a new showroom in the Flatiron district, carries the work of designers from around the world.

headline: Beijing Gallery Puts a Focus on Global Warming
text: BEIJING — When George Mallory made a reconnaissance trip to the gargantuan glaciers at the foot of Mount Everest in Tibet before his ill-fated attempt to climb the mountain, he took photographs and noted the splendor: “Here is a pure beauty of form, a kind of ultimate harmony,” he wrote.

headline: Reflections of Rugby Underdogs
text: In Wednesday’s paper The Times ran an article on the large number of blowout games at the Rugby World Cup. The American team finished 1-3 at the Cup, beating Russia and putting in creditable performances against Italy and Ireland, but was on the wrong end of one blowout, losing, 67-5, to Australia.

headline: Hedge Fund Manager Gets 60 Years for Fraud
text: A hedge fund manager convicted of running a $100 million scheme that preyed on retired investors was sentenced on Wednesday to 60 years in prison, the latest eye-popping penalty to come from a federal white collar case.

headline: Christie, Clinton and the Calendar
text: I’m sympathetic to the media’s obsession with Gov. Chris Christie’s possible-but-unlikely entry into the Republican nomination race in one sense: he is one of the most natural communicators since Bill Clinton. (Also, it’s a slow news week.) He has superstar talent, something that some of the other Republican candidates have lacked, and it’s the kind that could appeal to both primary and general election voters.

headline: Tiny Cameras, Big Tricks
text: Why doesn’t everyone buy an S.U.V.? So much space, so much power!

headline: In ‘Chewed,’ Dog Toys Loved to Pieces
text: Arne Svenson and Ron Warren’s 2002 book, “Sock Monkeys,” effectively elevated the status of a simple toy, showcasing 200 portraits of sock monkeys. Their new book aims to do the same thing for dog toys.

headline: Lively Morgue: Baseball Umpires
text: Photographs of baseball arguments from the New York Times archive.

headline: Charles Isherwood on the new play “Imagining Madoff” by Deborah Margolin.
text: Charles Isherwood on the new play “Imagining Madoff” by Deborah Margolin.

headline: Classic Designs From Greta Magnusson Grossman
text: Fans of the late Swedish designer Greta Magnusson Grossman’s lighting, which was introduced in the late 1940s and ’50s, have long had to content themselves with searching for vintage pieces at antiques stores and auctions, and paying often exorbitant prices.

headline: H.P. Hires Goldman to Defend Against Activists
text: Hewlett-Packard has hired Goldman Sachs as an adviser to help defend against potential activist investors or hostile bidders seeking a break-up of the troubled technology giant, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Wednesday.

headline: Amazon’s Silk Browser Plays Another Role
text: With access to books, movies, and other media, Amazon’s Kindle Fire tablet may look like another consumer toy. However, an important part of the product, an advanced Web browser, is at the heart of where business computing is going.

headline: Paris: Altered Fashion States
text: Tonight I met Stella McCartney for a drink at the Hemingway bar at the Ritz and a waiter chattily expressed the view that the buildup for the Paris collections had been begun days before the actual shows. I’m inclined to agree, though I’m not sure what accounts for the buildup or even if there is anything to it.

headline: Standout Season Amid a Trying Year
text: PHOENIX — Dodgers outfielder Matt Kemp was running out of time in his quest for the triple crown. It was a sensitive area, and there was an obvious way to manage it, but when Don Mattingly found Kemp in the trainer’s room Tuesday at Chase Field, he opted to do nothing.

headline: Shopping for Door Knockers
text: The San Francisco designer Grant K. Gibson shopped for distinctive door knockers.

headline: Where the Going Is Rough, the Giants Hold Their Ground
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — A standard short-yardage running play is the rough equivalent of Grand Central Terminal at 5 p.m. The offensive players are the sea of people headed home, shoulder to shoulder as they move toward the tracks in unison. The defensive players are the unlucky reverse commuters, straining against the surge and struggling to get up the platform stairs amid an onrushing mass of humanity.

headline: Door Knockers
text: GRANT K. GIBSON is an interior designer, but that doesn’t stop him from thinking about what homes look like on the outside. Particularly when it comes to the front door. Or the door knocker, to be precise.

headline: Regulators Seek More Information on Google-Motorola Deal
text: Antitrust regulators have asked for more information on Google’s proposed $12 billion acquisition of Motorola Mobility, the two companies disclosed on Wednesday.

headline: Engineered Floors Are Getting Serious
text: WHEN Joshua Davis and Rebecca Ascher, partners at Ascher Davis Architects in Manhattan, were renovating a 19th-century house on Nantucket, they needed new floors that would complement the vintage architecture. At the same time, they had to satisfy their clients, whose many requirements included floors that would not warp or squeak.

headline: Man Is Held in a Plan to Bomb Washington
text: BOSTON — A 26-year-old man from a town west of Boston was charged Wednesday with plotting to blow up the Pentagon and the United States Capitol using remote-controlled aircraft filled with plastic explosives.

headline: U.S. Mortgage-Aid Program Is Shutting Down, With Up to $500 Million Unspent

His fingers had done dazzling things: fingerpicking that could be pristine and meditative or pointedly aggressive, counterpoints of staccato thumb-picked bass lines and gliding melodies, quasi-Baroque austerity leading into frenetic strumming.

headline: Flamenco Aflame
text: It’s easy to overlook the many thrilling features of purely formal beauty in Soledad Barrio’s dancing. Though wrist-circlings abound in flamenco, she can accentuate them so that they become spirals of smoke. Raising both arms with elbows sharply bent, she creates a geometry that’s very satisfying. She can also soften those elbows so that the raised arms become a single compelling crescent, facing up to the sky or down to the earth. As she stands with legs apart, the lines of her arms and legs answer each other like the bowl and base of a grand goblet. Her walk seems not a succession of steps but a single flowing movement.

headline: On Ducking Challenges to Naturalism
text: In response to the question posed in my previous essay in The Stone — “What is naturalism?”  — Alex Rosenberg defines it as “the philosophical theory that treats science as our most reliable source of knowledge and scientific method as the most effective route to knowledge.” His post, “Why I Am a Naturalist,” nicely exemplifies one of my main complaints, by leaving it unclear what he means by “science” or “scientific method,” even though it is crucial for what he is committing himself to as a “naturalist.” Still, there are clues. He describes “the test of knowledge that scientific findings attain” as “experimental/observational methods,” which suggests that theorems of mathematics would not count as scientific findings. The impression is confirmed by Professor Rosenberg’s phrase “mathematicians and scientists,” as though he doesn’t see mathematicians as scientists. That’s bad news for his naturalism, for mathematical proof is just as effective a route to knowledge as experimental/observational methods. Of course, since the natural sciences depend on mathematics, Rosenberg desires to find a place for it — but admits that he doesn’t know how.

headline: Mexico: Uncertain Ruling on Abortion
text: After a closely watched debate, Mexico’s Supreme Court refused to throw out a state anti-abortion amendment on Wednesday. Although 7 of the 11 justices agreed that the Baja California State amendment was unconstitutional, the court was one vote shy of the supermajority needed to strike it down. After Mexico City became the only place in the country to legalize abortion in 2007, 17 states altered their constitutions to declare that life begins at conception. President Felipe Calderón and his wife, Margarita Zavala, intervened in the debate, urging the justices to let the state laws stand. The court will consider a challenge to another state’s anti-abortion law on Thursday.

text: Iran announced the mass production of a new cruise missile on Wednesday, the latest in a series of belligerent-sounding proclamations from that country in the face of its increased isolation by a Western-led group of nations worried about Iran’s nuclear program and avowed hostility toward Israel. Brig. Gen. Ahmad Vahidi, Iran’s defense minister, said the new missile, first unveiled a month ago and known as the Qader, which means able in Persian, had been mass-produced “as quickly as possible,” the country’s state-run media reported. The missile, designed to destroy warships and coastal targets, has a range of about 125 miles, the news media said.

Northern tribesmen loyal to opponents of President Ali Abdullah Saleh have been battling government forces in the area since March, when they prevented a brigade of Republican Guards, a division of the armed forces led by Mr. Saleh’s son, from entering the capital.
