headline: With Cross-Country Trip, Hyundai Highlights Need for Hydrogen Fueling Infrastructure
text: The Hyundai Tucson Fuel Cell Electric Vehicle parked in a third-floor lobby at the Hilton New York on Wednesday was no show car. It spent much of September on the road, traveling more than 4,500 miles from San Francisco to New York to promote awareness of childhood cancer, as well as the need for a hydrogen fueling infrastructure.

headline: Myanmar Backs Down, Suspending Dam Project
text: BANGKOK — In a rare concession to public pressure, Myanmar’s government on Friday ordered the suspension of a controversial hydroelectric project financed and led by a state-owned Chinese company.

headline: Do Apps Help You or Just Waste Your Time?
text: On Monday, a mobile phone app that reports all things related to the trial of Conrad Murray, Michael Jackson’s personal doctor, was released. By Thursday, it had become a top seller. Did you or anyone you know buy it? Do you or anyone in your family use apps on your mobile phones? If so, what do they help you do?

headline: The Other India: Mangalaji’s Tamasha Party
text: Tamasha artist Mangala Bhansode is all curves and ample bosom and when she hollers in English “I know you want it, but you’re never going to get it,” lyrics from the hit Bollywood song Sheila ki Jawani, the audience responds with frenzy. Flinging in the air their homespun Gandhi caps, woolen scarves and gloves, even the blankets they’d brought along, they yell back in English: “Once More! Once More! Once More!”

headline: Taking It to the Streets
text: There’s a reigning joke that commands everyone to “set their clocks to Pacific Standard Time” this weekend, as the decade-in-the-making horde of exhibitions and events in and around Los Angeles chronicling the area’s postwar art scenes finally kicks off. Perhaps the most countercultural and sunshiny of the opening parties will be the Tresspass Parade barnstorming Downtown L.A.’s historic Broadway district on Sunday morning. The event — helmed by the genre-bending artists Arto Lindsay and Rirkrit Tiravanija, and organized by former the Milan gallerist Emi Fontana’s Pasadena project space West of Rome — is a celebration of Southern California’s time-honored tradition of festive dissidence. Floats, costumes and other parade paraphernalia should be done up in subversive style. And there will be T-shirts! — onto which 2-D luminaries like John Baldessari and Barbara Kruger will emblazon call-to-action slogans.

headline: Customers Say the Darndest Things
text: As you might have suspected, I have had many opinions about restaurants over the years, but I have never approached the owner of one of them and told him or her how I would improve his or her life’s work. So it is with admiration and puzzlement that I listen to all the guests who call me to their table or track me down to offer their sage suggestions. While 95 percent of the comments are insightful and positive, those other 5 percent stick to the ribs like a good porterhouse, which we do not serve and which is a constant source of contention.

headline: Why Magazine Publishers Like the Fire
text: Magazine publishers see tremendous potential in the Fire and hope that the device can do for their business what the Kindle did for books: bring droves of new customers into a business that is having difficulty retaining its traditional print readers.

headline: S.&P. 500 Declined 14% in 3rd Quarter
text: Stocks fell on Friday, sending the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index to its biggest quarterly drop since 2008 — 14 percent. Reports from China and Germany fueled the decline on concerns that the global economy is slowing.

headline: Global Warming Could Cost Canada Billions, Study Warns

headline: Leading Off: It’s (Useless) Prediction Time
text: Baseball’s playoff prediction season is mercifully short, which is almost impossible to say about anything else about the game, and we should all be grateful for this. If the events of the past few weeks have taught us anything, it’s that we know nothing. That’s all of us, pundits, casual observers, former players now wearing TV makeup and hairspray. We all had as good a chance as the fish in our living room tank of predicting what happened at the end of this season.

text: A good designer is like an attentive waiter: he is there to serve his guests and quietly depart. Fashion, as Cristobal Balenciaga famously and sourly observed at the end of his career, is a dog’s life. Ah, but if only he had known Hussein Chalayan, he might have at least savored the human comedy.

headline: N.H.T.S.A. Investigates 20,000 Honda Odysseys for Power Liftgate Failures
text: Early in 2010, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration gave up trying to force Honda to recall defective liftgates on its 2005 minivans. That hasn’t prevented the agency from opening a new investigation into a similar problem on 20,000 Odysseys from the 2009 model year.

headline: A Stylish Spin on Web Fashion
text: It’s a pleasure to see Alessandra Facchinetti back on the runway. You may remember her from her brief moment at Gucci, in 2004, when she succeeded Tom Ford. Then, following Valentino’s retirement, she took over the creative direction at that house. It was, let us say, an impossible job, and her first ready-to-wear collections were tentative. At the time I thought: too many hands in this kitchen. But then she delivered a gorgeous haute couture collection for Valentino that I still vividly remember, the kind of witty femininity that could let in some much-needed air.

text: Or, maybe not.

headline: Kurdish Protesters Enter Newspaper’s Office in London
text: Nearly a dozen Kurdish nationalists burst into the London office of The Guardian newspaper on Friday, demanding greater coverage of Kurdish issues and creating a chaotic scene that briefly alarmed the staff.

headline: Up Front: John Sayles
text: In 1975, Raymond Sokolov wrote in the Book Review about a first novel, “Pride of the Bimbos,” in which a midget named Pogo seeks “happiness and self-fulfillment as the shortstop of a softball team that plays in drag.” The book (“an oddly unsettling satire of American machismo,” Sokolov concluded) was by a young man named John Sayles, who quickly brought out another novel, “Union Dues,” and a story collection, “The Anarchists’ Convention,” before going on to become one of America’s best-known independent filmmakers.

headline: William Kennedy Goes to Cuba and Back
text: William Kennedy’s new novel, “Changó’s Beads and Two-Tone Shoes,” is his most musical work of fiction: a polyrhythmic contemplation of time and its effects on passion set in three different eras, a jazz piece unafraid to luxuriate in its roots as blues or popular ballad or to spin out into less melodic territory.

headline: Are You My Father, Orson Welles?
text: One of the first interviews I ever did, in the mid-1980s for Elle magazine, was with Michael Lindsay-Hogg, who had just directed the original New York production of Larry Kramer’s “Normal Heart.” This, I must admit, interested me less than office gossip alleging him to be the unclaimed son of Orson Welles, by his mother, the actress Geraldine Fitzgerald.

headline: Jim Harrison Stalks a Cult Leader
text: It is now 55 years since my last book report, which is a long time to live with a guilty conscience. So here it is: In the spring of 1956 I wrote a highly favorable review of the Bible without reading a word of it, and it was the last A I ever got in English. Why it has taken so long to come clean I’m not sure, except I have always been extremely sensitive about my academic reputation.

headline: The Money May Be Lacking, but a Library Refuses to Go Quietly
text: CENTRAL FALLS, R.I.

headline: The Indomitable Will of Gustav Mahler
text: Idealistic, fantastic, grotesque, violent, tender, sarcastic, confrontational, confessional, the symphonies of Gustav Mahler (1860-1911) are among the most profoundly autobiographical of all composed music. “I have written into them, in my own blood, everything that I have experienced and endured,” he confided to a friend after finishing the Second Symphony. For all its professional, emotional and physical crises, Mahler’s life was exemplary for an artist who, no matter how loud the outside world might pound on the walls of his concentration, vigilantly maintained an unobstructed direct line to his creative self, keeping it uncorrupted and unblocked to the end.

headline: Growing Up With Irène Némirovsky
text: On Dec. 17, 1941, a year and a half into the Nazi occupation of France, an “Aryan” French governess named Julie Dumot, living in the quiet provincial village of Issy-l’Évêque, received a contract from a Parisian publisher for a novel called “Les Biens de ce Monde” (“All Our Worldly Goods”). That governess worked in the household of a 38-year-old Russian-born Jewish author who saw herself as culturally French but who, under the restrictive laws of the Vichy regime, was no longer permitted to publish under her own name. The book’s chapters had already appeared serially in the spring of 1941, without a byline, in the far-right newspaper Gringoire, which blended virulent opinion pages with apolitical literary content. But “Les Biens de ce Monde” appeared in book form only in 1947, five years after the death of its true author, Irène Némirovsky, at Auschwitz.

headline: The Doctors Who Killed a President
text: "Charlie said, 'Hell,If I am guilty,Then God is as well.'But God was acquittedAnd Charlie committedUntil he should hang."

headline: T. S. Eliot’s Rattle of Miseries
text: Grover Cleveland was still president when T. S. Eliot was born. His earliest surviving letter was written to his father from the family summer home in Gloucester, Mass. The 9-year-old Tom Eliot was deferential, curious in a boyish way, concerned about some missing sunflowers and a broken microscope. A shy child, he suffered from a congenital hernia and once asked his nurse why the naked boy in a book wore no truss.

headline: The Criminal Genius of Caravaggio
text: In one of the last pictures he ever painted, a grim and startling “Resurrection” altarpiece, Caravaggio showed a scrawny, bedraggled Jesus Christ slipping out of the tomb and making off alone by night, “like a criminal escaping from his guards,” in the words of an 18th-century Frenchman. Shock was the conventional response to this painting (eventually destroyed by earthquake, along with the church where it hung). The artist himself was on the run at the time, wanted for murder and so jittery that he slept in his clothes with a dagger always at hand. “Whatever he set out to paint,” Andrew Graham-Dixon writes in his gripping biography, “he always ended up painting himself.”

headline: The Obama White House That Couldn’t
text: Bloated, portentous, reeking of self-­importance, Ron Suskind’s “Confidence Men” is the most frustrating of books. A truly groundbreaking inside account of the first two years of economic policy making in the Obama White House, “Confidence Men” is at least 200 pages too long. Suskind tosses off contentious opinions about the economy as if they were accepted wisdom. He intro­duces characters who lack even a marginal connection to his narrative. There’s not a blind alley he won’t stroll down, at least for a while.

headline: Pursuing Palin
text: Sarah Palin's sprint from Wasilla housewife to national political sensation may have no parallel in modern American politics, but Joe McGinniss’s book “The Rogue: Searching for the Real Sarah Palin” proves that she didn’t come out of nowhere. God gave Palin her first push toward politics when she was a mere 24 years old, as her spiritual mentor Mary Glazier explained at a religious conference in June 2008.

headline: The Weapons That Were Not There
text: Every attentive reader of “Intelligence and U.S. Foreign Policy,” Paul R. Pillar’s long-needed examination of just what the Central Intelligence Agency got right or wrong before the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, and the invasion of Iraq in 2003, will find one observation or another that seems more disquieting than the rest. I haven’t quite decided which of two deserves pride of place on my own list: The fact that the Bush administration never formally debated whether it was “a good idea” to invade Iraq? Or that Pillar, who ran the National Intelligence Council’s shop for the Middle East during both events, cannot tell us “the true reasons the Bush administration invaded”?

headline: The Origins of Religion, Beginning With the Big Bang
text: In October 1963, the sociologist Robert N. Bellah gave a lecture at the University of Chicago on the subject of “religious evolution.” Clifford Geertz, the widely respected American anthropologist, was only partially impressed. “I loved your talk even though I disagree with it entirely,” he told Bellah afterward.

headline: Eight-Feet Female and Working for P. T. Barnum
text: We just can’t get enough of the sideshow. Bearded ladies, wolf boys, giants: in the sideshow’s heyday, their physical differences made them objects of fascination, gawked and giggled at. In contrast, novels like Darin Strauss’s “Chang and Eng” and Katherine Dunn’s “Geek Love” have evoked the rich inner lives of those on display rather than their visible differences. Stacy Carlson’s first novel, set in P. T. Barnum’s American Museum, aims for, but doesn’t quite reach, similar insights.

headline: On the Wrong Side of the New Ireland
text: So many people have emigrated from Ireland over the centuries that the diaspora far outnumbers those in the home country. The old joke goes that if all Irish returned, the island would sink under their weight. Most departed to seek jobs. Others, like the narrator of “On Canaan’s Side,” Sebastian Barry’s new novel, were chased out with I.R.A. henchmen in hot pursuit.

headline: Life Onstage With John Lithgow and Hal Holbrook
text: Two new actor memoirs follow a similar script, from regional dues-paying to career triumph. Both authors learn their craft on small stages throughout America, spend time at Harvard, occasionally talk about themselves in the third person and grow apart from their first wives. But where one book is warm and generous, the other is cold and bleak.

headline: An Unrepentant Adulterer
text: As “The Forgotten Waltz” opens, a young married woman named Gina Moynihan is kissing an older man, Sean, upstairs in his house, when Gina realizes they are being observed by Sean’s daughter, Evie. Sean’s wife calls up to Evie to rejoin the party downstairs, and despite what she has just witnessed, the child, who has burst out laughing at the sight of her father and Gina embracing, seems reassured.

headline: Reading Alberto Moravia in Silvio Berlusconi’s Italy
text: In its culture as in its politics, Italy lives under the shadow of Silvio Berlusconi. With his endless legal entanglements and sexual imbroglios and his colorful manner of governing (or not governing), it often feels as if the prime minister has taken all the oxygen out of the room, the airwaves, the entire republic. “How did we get here?” is the dominant — indeed often the only — topic of conversation in Italy today.

headline: Calculated Murder
text: Wouldn’t it be nice, Leonard Rosen asks in his first novel, ALL CRY CHAOS (Permanent Press, $29), if the broken world we live in could be mended by the application of some universal mathematical formula? James Fenster, a Harvard professor who’s in Amsterdam to deliver a paper before the World Trade Organization, has been working on that very thing. But before he can deliver his remarks on “The Mathematical Inevitability of a One-World Economy,” a bomb charged with rocket fuel delivers a surgical strike on his hotel room.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: Tickets are still available for some events during this weekend’s New York City Wine and Food Festival, which is sponsored by the Food Network and runs through Sunday. There are tastings, cooking demonstrations, seminars, special dinners and cook-offs throughout the city. Tickets are $20 to $250, with the proceeds benefiting the Food Bank for New York City and Share Our Strength.

headline: Across the Ocean, With Five Small Children
text: When you have five children under the age of 6, every family outing becomes an exercise in logistics. When planes and passports are involved, you might as well be planning to invade Normandy.

headline: Buffett Takes His Case to Wall Street
text: Few billionaire investors possess the influence of Warren E. Buffett, chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway. With his company’s stock buybacks making waves and a tax proposal dubbed the “Buffett Rule” aimed at the wealthy, Mr. Buffett has thrust himself in the headlines.

headline: Perry Suggests Romney Inspired ‘Obamacare’
text: 12:46 p.m. | Updated Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, still reeling from a debate performance that upset many of the bedrock conservatives he considers his base, came out swinging Friday against his rival Mitt Romney, accusing  the former Massachusetts governor of backing policies indistinguishable from those of President Obama and having “paved the way for Obamacare.”

headline: Cooking With Yogurt
text: At my house, yogurt is a snack food, a dessert or something to be mixed in a smoothie. But as Martha Rose Shulman explains in this week’s Recipes for Health, yogurt can add flavor and texture to a number of savory dishes. She writes:

headline: Owner Goes All In on the Brewers
text: MILWAUKEE — Mark Attanasio was born in the Bronx, lives in Los Angeles, owns a first-place baseball team in the Midwest and runs a company that manages $11 billion in investments. He did not get all that by being superstitious, so when Attanasio arrived at his ballpark on Sept. 23 dressed for a postgame celebration, it should not have been surprising. He knows what he is doing.

headline: What’s Going On Below Murray’s Cheese Shop
text: There are five caves underneath Murray’s Cheese Shop, the downtown magnet for fromage fanatics in the West Village. Day after day, hour by hour, wheels of cheese are ritually flipped and rinds are carefully washed in temperature-and-humidity-controlled environments that are meant to follow the precise cheese-aging principles of affinage.

headline: North Korea’s ‘Dear Young General’ Has Made His Mark
text: SEOUL, South Korea — It is a telling sign of who is the rising star in North Korea: state-run television showing octogenarian party secretaries bowing to a man their grandchildren’s age before accepting the smiling man’s handshake or kowtowing to his instructions.

headline: Judging a Long, Deadly Reach

headline: The New Kid in Town: Charlie Cox on ‘Boardwalk Empire’
text: Joining an acclaimed series already in progress can be a fraught proposition. But the British actor Charlie Cox faced an additional obstacle when he signed on to HBO’s “Boardwalk Empire” for its second season: He’d never seen the show.

headline: E.P.A. Charts Risks of a Ubiquitous Chemical
text: So you wanted to clean grease off a bit of machinery. The year was 1956 or 1971 or even 1993. Your cleaner of choice was probably the industrial degreaser trichloroethylene, a petroleum-based clear liquid that was as common in mid-20th-century America as Ipana toothpaste, Crackerjack and asbestos. It was used in dry-cleaning, in machine shops and on military bases.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: WHO’S AFRAID OF POST-BLACKNESS?WHAT IT MEANS TO BE BLACK NOW,  by Touré (Free Press, $25.) Interviews with 105 prominent African-Americans suggest that today’s “black identity” has cleared the way to a liberating pursuit of individuality.

headline: Paperback Row
text: BEFORE YOU SUFFOCATE YOUR OWN FOOL SELF,  by Danielle Evans (Riverhead, $15.) Following girls and young women who are intelligent, gutsy and black, Evans’s whip-smart first story collection charts the universal pitfalls of coming-of-age in 21st-century America. In “Virgins,” the bittersweet opening story set “the day after Tupac got shot,” two 15-year-olds yearn to be more grown-up while preserving something of their innocence.

headline: Fill-In | October Events in History
text: Stock market crashes, home runs, peace treaties and assassinations: Fill in the blanks in these 31 summaries of famous historical events that took place in the month of October.

headline: Inside the List
text: SAY IT AIN’T SO, JOE: Ron Suskind’s “Confidence Men: Wall Street, Washington, and the Education of a President,” new at No. 2 on the hardcover nonfiction list, may have grabbed all the serious news headlines, but Joe McGinniss’s Sarah Palin tell-all, “The Rogue” (No. 10), has made for way better copy, much of it scabrously negative. Janet Maslin, writing in the daily New York Times, dismissed its scoops as “dated, petty and easily available to anyone with Internet access,” shamelessly padded out with pointless details about the pet birds McGinniss kept in his temporary home next door to the Palins in Alaska (“The grebe chicks have hatched!”) and hearsay about the condition of the Palins’ toilet. Palin filed her own review in the form of a letter to McGinniss’s publisher threatening to sue. Even Palin’s mullet-loving near-miss son-in-law, Levi Johnston, took time out from promoting his own anti-Palin book, “Deer in the Headlights,” to trash McGinniss’s feebly sourced claim that the former Alaska governor had used cocaine.

headline: An Open Invitation to Eat in Copenhagen

headline: A Ballet Star Leaps Into the Unknown
text: WOMEN love Charles Askegard. Or at the very least, the women of New York City Ballet do. Since joining that company in 1997 he has performed with almost every ballerina in the company’s esteemed ranks. But after next Sunday those dancers are going to have to do without their tall, elegant partner, when Mr. Askegard retires from City Ballet at the last matinee of the season, in a program that features some of his favorite roles.

headline: Old and New, a Tale of Heroes and Villains
text: THERE is a rich legacy of recordings of Beethoven’s opera “Fidelio,” including the 1962 account on EMI with Otto Klemperer conducting the Philharmonia Orchestra and Chorus in a majestic performance. The colossal tenor Jon Vickers sings Florestan, a Spanish nobleman unjustly imprisoned for his liberal sympathies by a tyrannical governor, and the distinguished mezzo-soprano Christa Ludwig is Florestan’s wife, Leonore, who, disguised as a young man, finds a job in the prison where her husband is held in order to rescue him.

headline: Cuomo Talks Tough on Union Layoffs and Redistricting
text: An uncompromising Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, facing a union that has refused to agree to wage and benefits concessions and a Legislature that is insisting on redrawing the state’s political map, said Friday that he would follow through on threats to lay off several thousand state workers and to veto the lawmakers’ redistricting plan.

headline: In Brooklyn, A New Leader Who Knows No Boundaries
text: IT’S not as if Alan Pierson were hunting for a new job. A lean, sharp and energetic 37-year-old conductor, Mr. Pierson has made an enviable name for himself over the last decade as the artistic director of Alarm Will Sound, a vital, omnivorous 20-member chamber ensemble formed in 2001 by graduate students at the Eastman School of Music in Rochester.

But he has also been keeping a worried eye on the situation back home, where a pirated DVD version of his film, a box office and critical success, has suddenly gone on sale.

text: From the hubbub at Dior, with vamping socialites and a front row of LVMH brass, including its chairman, Bernard Arnault, and the habitually leather-clad architect Peter Marino, one would have thought de Gaulle had come back from the dead. I guess Dior is France. The flying colors, though, were the grays and creams of the house, mixed with palest blue and a dash of poppy red.

headline: Stuck in Bed, at Hospital’s Expense
text: ON Jan. 4, 2010, Raymond Fok was changing trains on his way to kidney dialysis treatment when he collapsed on the Canal Street subway platform. Emergency medical technicians examined him and took him by ambulance to the nearest hospital, New York Downtown, near the foot of the Brooklyn Bridge. Workers in the emergency room recorded that Mr. Fok’s speech was slurred and that he was lurching from side to side when he walked.

headline: Fighting Erupts on Somalia’s Border With Kenya
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Intense fighting erupted along the Kenya-Somalia border on Friday as the Shabab militant group tried to take back a slice of strategic territory from militias allied with the Somali government. At the same time, Shabab fighters are breaking up camps for victims of Somalia’s famine, sending tens of thousands of starving people straight back into drought-stricken areas.

Wilson, two players who crushed the Rays’ hopes in last year’s American League division series.

headline: Remixing Trivia With Music Videos

headline: Workouts From Church and the Afterlife
text: “This May Be My Last Time Singing”

headline: Ska-Punk Rockers, Way Ahead of the Curve
text: FOR more than a quarter century the Los Angeles band Fishbone has been making music critics reach for their hyphens. It’s been called ska-punk, punk-funk and ska-punk-funk-metal. “The Rough Guide to Rock” deemed Fishbone’s music “jazz/hard rock/ska/funk”; a Rolling Stone writer threw up his hands and went with “orgasmic urban gumbo.” None of these labels aptly sum up the sound of a band that seems to have ingested a century’s worth of American and Caribbean popular music, nor do they capture the manic spirit of the group’s concerts, which earned Fishbone a reputation as one of the world’s great live acts. In a new documentary, “Everyday Sunshine: The Story of Fishbone,” the record producer David Kahne dispenses with the hyphens altogether. Fishbone, he says, is simply weird.

headline: On Our Radar: Dam Halted in Myanmar
text: A day after Brazil’s controversial Belo Monte dam was halted by a court order, Myanmar’s president says he is suspending construction of the Chinese-backed Myitsone dam on the Irrawaddy River. He cites “the desire of the people.” [The Guardian]

headline: An Indie Queen Cranks Up Opera’s Amps
text: IN a studio on the far West Side of Manhattan a gaggle of young women, numbering close to 40, almost all under 25, sat splayed in slumber party mode on a rehearsal room floor. Dressed mostly in leggings and the appropriate American Apparel accoutrements, hair coolly mussed, they kept their eyes focused on one woman in the room while they quietly sang. Their voices were soft until joined by the guttural force of Karen O and her undeniably female yelp. It’s a sound that has filled arenas but will next be heard on a theatrical stage.

headline: In Europe, Cooking Classes for Every Palate
text: As much as the Eiffel Tower or the Sistine Chapel, food is a bona fide European tourist attraction. Alas, the pleasures of the table are fleeting. Participate in a cooking class, however, and you can extend the experience far beyond your flight home. The following programs from around Europe, all given in English, focus on regional cuisines and seasonal ingredients, allowing you to bring the tastes of your trip back to your home kitchen.

headline: Tasting Istanbul, From Humble to High Cuisine
text: SOMETIMES I think it’s no accident that Istanbul’s telephone area code is 212. Despite its minarets and its hilly cobblestone streets, its Grand Bazaar and the sapphire waters of the Bosporus that glide through the city like a liquid sash, this eastern metropolis has a New York state of mind.

headline: Unforgettable Foods, from Austrian Apricots to Parisian Butter
text: Is there anything more intrinsic to a place than its food? Yes, we can order up slices of Italian prosciutto in Chicago and buy French butter in Brooklyn, but in Parma or Paris those foods take on a special significance. For travelers, food conveys the essence of a place. With that in mind, we asked correspondents with decades of culinary experience across Europe among them to share a few of the foods that are worth traveling for.

headline: Bellying Up to the Time When America Went Dry
text: Tune in a documentary about the Civil War and you expect it to resonate in the present, since the racial issues that emanated from the era of slavery are still very much with us. But a program about Prohibition? Flappers in speakeasies and biddies beating temperance drums: hardly seems a recipe for modern-day relevance.

headline: Photographer Declares Bridge-Clambering Days Done
text: “After 18 long years,” the e-mail began, “I photographed my last bridge.”

headline: Edible Selby | A Movable Feast
text: When Caroline Burnett decided to open Heroes, in Berlin’s Neukölln district, her initial emphasis was not on food. “The cafe was a pretext for the art,” says Burnett, an American editor who curates art shows in a dynamic exhibition space in the back. Today she and her partner, Damien Poinsard, a French-born cook who helps run a theater group on the side, are drawing regulars as much with their down-home fare as with their roster of up-and-coming artists. Crepes and quiches are standards; specials depend on who’s cooking. If Poinsard is in the kitchen, the menu might include pot au feu or stewed chicken; when Burnett is in, she says, the special is likely to be meatloaf, reflecting her nostalgia for home. Go to interactive feature >>

headline: Channel Surfing: ‘Hunt for the I-5 Killer
text: The Lifetime network may be on no one’s list of prestige television outlets, but give it this: It’s getting better and better at the women-in-jeopardy movie. It serves up another on Sunday night, “Hunt for the I-5 Killer,” and solid performances in the central roles make this one of its better offerings.

headline: When ‘Glass Ceiling’ Is a Positive
text: THE craze for panoramas swept America in the 1840s, inspiring both P. T. Barnum and Henry Wadsworth Longfellow.

headline: Austria Passes Expansion of Euro Bailout Fund, With Opposition Limited but Loud
text: BERLIN — Austria on Friday became the latest country to sign off on the expansion of the euro currency zone’s bailout fund for heavily indebted countries, following a bruising debate in Parliament that underscored the political tensions behind the search for a solution to Europe’s financial woes.

headline: Mystery at Martin Margiela
text: Waiting for the Maison Martin Margiela show this afternoon, I was horrified, and slightly entertained, to hear the tale of Drew Elliott’s amazing adventure ride into Paris from the airport that morning. First, Mr. Elliott, of Paper Magazine, was on a delayed flight that arrived six hours late. Then his cab driver, halfway into the city, received a cellphone call alerting him that his wife had gone into labor. The driver pulled over and deposited Mr. Elliott and his luggage on the side of the road.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $20,000,000
text: A condominium at 988 Fifth Avenue that closed for $20 million was the highest sale of the week, according to Streeteasy.com.

headline: Short-Termism and Energy Revolutions
text: The calls these days for a technological “energy revolution” are widespread. But how do you spark breakthroughs when the natural bias of businesses, investors and governments is toward the here and now?

headline: Pasta With Cauliflower
text: Mark Bittman reaches back into the Minimalist vault to share one of his favorite recipes.

headline: The Minimalist: Pasta With Cauliflower
text: I’ve been making this pasta for a very long time, probably since the 1980s, since it’s derived from a Marcella Hazan recipe. It’s dead simple — one of the things that I love about it — and you can precook the cauliflower a day ahead or so if you’d like. I usually do the whole thing at once: cook the cauliflower in water, scoop it out and then, later, cook the pasta in the same water. It’s already boiling, and you want the taste of the cauliflower anyway, so why not?

headline: Sports of The Times: Reyes Wins, Mets Lose
text: Jose Reyes has his batting title, but what good does that do Mets fans who have to spend another October watching other teams play, says William C. Rhoden.

headline: Image slideshow Battle for Libya | September 30, 2011
text: Fighters for Libya’s new rulers were forced to regroup Friday on the edge of Surt, as pro-Qaddafi snipers halted a two-week-old assault on the ousted leader’s hometown.

headline: Are Barefoot Shoes Really Better?
text: Barefoot running may be trendy, but for scores of runners who train on urban streets or rocky trails, running without foot cover isn’t an option. As a result, many runners have switched to minimalist sports shoes that add a thin layer of protection without detracting from the feeling of running barefoot.

headline: Channel Surfing: ‘Around the World in 80 Ways’
text: You might not think of a zip line as a mode of transportation, and in the opening episode of “Around the World in 80 Ways,” Dennis Anderson and Robert Mariano sure look as though they wish that whoever arranges the adventures for this new program hadn’t thought of it as one either.

headline: Can a Dinner Party Be Stress-Free?
text: For experienced cooks, seeing what’s in your fridge and thinking of a simple way to prepare it is a terrific weeknight strategy. But a dinner party is rarely the time for spontaneity, even for veterans, and for those who are unsure of their skills, a dinner party can be downright terrifying.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Christian Dior
text: At around 12:30 backstage at Dior, a model let out a shriek just as Pat McGrath was discussing products necessary for fatigued or bug-bitten skin (as was the case in mosquito-ridden Milan). The timing was uncanny, as the provocateur was a large grasshopper that managed to make his rounds all the way over to where Orlando Pita was working on hair. Mosquitoes in Milan and grasshoppers, er sauterelles — not the garden variety — at the Musee de Rodin: oh my! The look, according to Pita was “very fresh and modern, turning a page from the past,” at least for this season. This meant a twist of a bun with a side part and slight wave in the front created by using Pita’s Plump for volume, control hairspray and dry shampoo. The trick was that there was no ponytail beneath to hold the hair; it was deceptively simple. For makeup, McGrath went with a contoured eye and “classic, beautiful red lip.” One of the 28 members of McGrath’s team brought a face by for her approval. “Don’t forget, kids: not a hard lip with pencil, I prefer the finger, it’s softer.” This is what made the lady modern. Three of Dior’s reds were used, chosen based on the clothes: red orange, blue orange and pinky red. Nails were also a mix of five shades: Incognito, a nude; Riviera, an orange; Waterlily, a green; Forget me not, a lavender; and Lucky, a red.

headline: Recipes | Starters
text: Dinner party starters.

headline: Yesterday’s Vision Of Tomorrow
text: Filmmakers have long been imagining the near future, and it is rarely bright.

headline: Recipes | Main Courses

text: Paul Tough’s article on teaching character and Cliff Levy’s article on putting his kids in a Russian school were our most-discussed stories last week.

headline: The Food & Drink Issue
text: Everything you ever wanted to know about food (but didn’t know whom to ask).

headline: The Money Is Gone, but the Winery and a Woman’s Resolve Remain
text: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — Patricia Kluge appeared for years to be one of the nation’s wealthiest divorcees, with a breathtaking Virginia mansion known as Albemarle, an ample jewel collection and a river of cash from her ex-husband, the late media magnate John Kluge.

headline: ‘Mythbusters’ on Cars vs. Motorcycles: Which Is Greener?
text: In a revelation sure to disquiet Vespa-riding urbanites and independent streamliner engineers, a study conducted in conjunction with a recent episode of “Mythbusters,” the Discovery Channel program, found that cars were greener than motorcycles.

headline: Anita Hill’s Long Memory
text: Your new book, “Reimagining Equality,” deals with how race and gender intersect. How do you think the reception to your testimony during Clarence Thomas’s confirmation hearings would have been different if you were a white woman accusing a white employer of sexual harassment?  Let’s not be entirely deceived about this. I’m not sure that the Senate Judiciary Committee and the Senate at large were really ready to deal with gender discrimination no matter who was alleging it. I don’t know that they understood how important the issue was to the integrity of the Supreme Court and to the fitness of the individual who was going on the court. Think about how it might have been different if I had been white and Thomas were, as he is, an African-American male. And just think about one particular senator, Strom Thurmond. Given his history and his constituency, I think he would have been hard pressed to treat a white woman accusing a black man in the same way he treated me.

headline: The Motivational-Speaker Smackdown
text: Jock Elliott paced the events room of Bally’s Hotel in Las Vegas. Sixty-four years old, with a silver mustache and mild features, Elliott flew in a week before from Brisbane, Australia. The jet lag had worn off, but it was 6:10 a.m., and he had had only one cup of coffee — in a paper cup no less. “I hate coffee in paper cups,” he said. “It’s appalling. So uncivilized.”

headline: Vicious Cyclist
text: A food-delivery person who couldn’t find a spot on a pole chained his bike directly to mine instead. I only had an hour for lunch, so when he didn’t return after a few minutes, I removed my chain and locked both our bikes to the pole. Then I walked to lunch instead of cycling. When I returned, I freed both bikes. He was predictably upset. Was my instinct to teach a lesson unethical? ANTHONY B., NEW YORK

headline: Future Shock
text: Since Georges Méliès took audiences on a trip to the Moon in 1902, filmmakers have been putting their visions of the future on the big screen. While some have focused on extremely distant time frames, many have tackled eras not too far from their own. The latest to look at the near-future is “Real Steel” (opening Friday), which sets its sights on 2020. By then, according to the film, the new sport of robot boxing will have emerged, with machines replacing people in the ring. The director, Shawn Levy, said he was more interested in telling a humanistic story (featuring Hugh Jackman, right, and the young Dakota Goyo) than creating a heavily sci-fi feel.

headline: The First Pear Salad of Fall
text: FICKLE consumers that we are, the next seasonal beauty is what we fall for. Not to slight late-season peaches, or the good tomatoes, eggplants and peppers that may remain, but it’s the early autumn fruits that now beckon. Succulent grapes, new-crop apples, quinces, pomegranates and persimmons are all parading their cool-weather costumes. Why resist?

headline: Troubled Poker Site May Be Bought by French Entrepreneur
text: Full Tilt Poker players may yet be able to cash out.

headline: AT&T Moves to Dismiss Lawsuits by Sprint and Cellular South
text: The legal fusillades have continued in the battle over AT&T‘s proposed $39 billion acquisition of T-Mobile USA, as the company sought on Friday to take shots at competitors seeking to stop the takeover.

headline: Boubacar Traoré in Brooklyn
text: Jon Pareles looks at the Malian Singer

headline: Video: Boubacar Traoré in Brooklyn
text: An excerpt from this week’s ArtsBeat video captures the Malian singer and songwriter Boubacar Traoré playing a song during sound check for a recent show at the Bell House in Brooklyn. Born in Mali in 1942, Mr. Traoré first came to prominence in the early 1960s. His humble background made it difficult for him to make money as a musician. He dropped out of the music scene until he reemerged with a surprise appearance on Malian television in 1987. He has been recording and touring intermittently ever since.

headline: Car Bomb at Funeral in Iraq Kills at Least 7 and Hurts Scores
text: BAGHDAD — A large car bomb exploded Friday evening at a funeral in the southern Shiite town of Hilla, leaving several people dead and more than 60 wounded. It was a deadly reminder that even as American forces prepare to withdraw and officials claim success in stabilizing Iraq, random attacks and assassinations are still daily occurrences.

headline: A Lego Game Where Your iPhone Is the Judge
text: How quickly can you build a fish out of Legos? How about a ship, or a tree? Lego: Life of George, available in stores tomorrow, lets you test your pattern-matching skills under pressure, providing you have a camera-equipped iPhone or equivalent, and a free app called Life of George which is your blueprint, timer, progress tracker, and — most interestingly — your judge.

text: I HAD always thought that schnitzel came in one flavor — veal — until a trip to Vienna several years ago set me straight.

headline: Homemade Tonkatsu Sauce
text: If you don’t have a bottle of tonkatsu sauce in your pantry but want to experience its sweet and tangy flavor with pork katsu, there are several good-looking recipes floating around the Internet. Here are a few likely candidates. I haven’t tried them, so if you do, we would love the feedback!

headline: No Fins? No Problem: Jellyfish Have Their Ways
text: For animals that drift through the sea without the benefit of eyesight, jellyfish have managed to survive remarkably well. In fact, in areas where overfishing and habitat destruction have reduced fish populations, jellyfish are now becoming the dominant predators.

headline: With Nebraska in Town, Madison Gets Ready to Jump
text: When Nebraska travels to Wisconsin for its Big Ten inauguration Saturday night, the game will resonate as a cultural event as much as a sporting contest. Wisconsin is bracing for the presence of some 30,000 Nebraska fans in Madison this weekend, many of whom do not have tickets and are just tagging along for the revelry and history.

headline: Sweet Pears, Good Cheese and Bitter Greens
text: With cool weather at hand and, with it, early autumn produce, I’m almost completely ready to leave summer behind. I will still be cooking with tomatoes, but they have been banished from the salad bowl. Now I want pears.

headline: Reporter Threatens to Name Names in Phone Hacking Scandal
text: LONDON — A reporter who is among the 16 people arrested and then freed on bail in the phone hacking case that has shaken Rupert Murdoch’s media empire in Britain warned his former bosses on Friday that he planned to break his silence on the scandal in a civil court case. He said that he would reveal those who were responsible for the phone hacking.

headline: Cuomo Said to Have a Leading Candidate to Run the Port Authority
text: Patrick J. Foye, a longtime figure in the public life of the New York City region, is a leading candidate to become executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, according to a person familiar with the selection process.

headline: My Three Favorite Out-of-the-Way Spots
text: Exiting an airport in a foreign country is one of the world’s best feelings. The air smells different, the signs are mostly incomprehensible. Sometimes confusion or the occasional panic sets in. Where do I go? Who’s going to take me there? But that is all part of the rush. Here are my three favorite out-of-the-way spots.

headline: The Character Test
text: The formula presented in Paul Tough’s article of allowing an insulated child to experience little failures might improve his or her resilience a notch, but I disagree that it will result in grit. If possession of grit can lead to much greater rewards in life, why would we presume that you can attain grit through a low-risk strategy of relatively innocuous negative experiences? Go find a kid who has been exploited or abandoned, and you will find a soul with grit to spare. Provide that kid with resources for his goals, and you’ll manufacture a success story. But don’t imagine that a caring parent will ever be willing to employ a strategy in advance that allows a child to undergo the searing experiences required for the formation of real grit.

headline: Strangers in a Strange School
text: I read Cliff Levy’s article with great interest, because I, too, lived in Russia and put my children in Russian schools. Like the author’s children, my two daughters didn’t know a word of Russian. They did not, however, find themselves “bewildered and isolated.” They spent four years in public schools, enjoying every moment of their time with Russian classmates and teachers. They were never teased or mocked, as Levy’s children were in their private school. Another difference was cost. Annual tuition at the private school was $10,000. The education that my children got in public schools was gratis.

headline: Not All Superheroes Are Equal (At Least the Second Time Around)
text: The critical response to the introduction of 52 new No. 1 issues in the DC Comics universe has varied wildly, from excitement to outright disdain. Since the initiative began at the end of August, two staff members of The New York Times have reviewed each No. 1 on the ArtsBeat blog. Here the two, George Gene Gustines and Adam W. Kepler, sum up their responses and offer a list of the 10 books that drew their sharpest reactions, sometimes for the wrong reasons.

headline: Reviewing the Bentley Mulsanne
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich drives the Bentley Mulsanne, a luxury saloon in the classic British heavyweight mold, clocking in at nearly three tons.

headline: F.D.A. Approves Breathing Device for A.L.S. Patients
text: The Food and Drug Administration has approved a device that stimulates the diaphragm to assist breathing for some people with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, better known as A.L.S. or Lou Gehrig’s disease.

headline: Clashes Continue as Thousands Protest in Syria
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Thousands of Syrians took to the streets on Friday in demonstrations that seemed to be dwindling in size, while clashes continued between security forces and army defectors in central Syria, residents and witnesses said.

headline: Puzzling It Out
text: I love how Rick Owens continues to find expression in couture volume and small gestures. Here are two examples from his spring collection: cotton tunics or jackets (some with a hint of a peplum) with a drawstring at the waist that can be released for a different shape, and the geometric show-closers in paper-thin leather. Mr. Owens said the idea evolved from working with his fur atelier. Obviously the process was quite laborious.

headline: Francona Out as Red Sox Manager
text: The Boston Red Sox announced Friday that they would not pick up their option on Terry Francona’s contract, parting ways with the manager who led them to the World Series championships in 2004 and 2007 after decades of failure. Francona, who managed eight seasons in Boston, oversaw a collapse this season in which the Red Sox lost 20 of 27 games in September to lose their playoff spot to the Tampa Bay Rays.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Isabel Marant
text: No product was used by Stephane Lancien backstage at Isabel Marant to create mussed hair meant to look as if a girl had just been for a spin in a convertible. “Sexy — but by mistake,” said Lancien of the messy, haphazard style. The face was more low key. “It’s my makeup in real life,” said the model Snejana Onopka of Karim Rahman’s work. A longtime collaborator with Marant, Rahman managed to make sense of the designer’s taste for duality. “She likes color; she doesn’t like color. She likes lipstick; she doesn’t like lipstick,” he said. “It’s a fine balance.” This effect was created using foundation mixed with moisturizer and a flush of L’Oréal Glam Bronze in Golden and Universal Sun all over the face and close to the nose “like sun marks.” There was no mascara, but brown kohl was penciled between upper and lower lashes and blended with the finger. Lips were a bright salmon — L’Oréal Colour Riche Pink Passion — apparently the anti-color, anti-lipstick of lipsticks.

headline: Signaling Can Win the Game, So Brush Up on Your Defense
text: When you and your regular partner get together, what aspect of your game do you discuss?

headline: Out of the Box
text: Several years ago, in the late ’80s, I met my friend Tim Blanks over lunch at the Fiera in Milan. In those days, most of the designers, with the notable exception of Giorgio Armani, showed in the Fiera, including Gianni Versace, and it was convenient to stay for lunch; the food was good, too. Afterward, Tim and I walked to the Romeo Gigli store, then in a Renault garage that in time became Corso Como 10. Everyone seemed to make that pilgrimage, so popular were Mr. Gigli’s trousers, coats and sari-colored shirts that they became a fashion uniform.

headline: The Young Gallerists
text: TO describe the retrospective of Richard Hambleton’s art that was recently held at the Phillips de Pury & Company galleries as a zoo doesn’t even take into account the woman who strapped a bug-eyed monkey puppet to her chest. About 2,000 partygoers were crowding two floors at the auction house on Park Avenue, including wealthy Upper East Siders and a parade of models from New York Fashion Week, many sipping from flutes of Champagne.

headline: The Freedom to Choose Your Pronoun
text: A FEW weeks ago, Katy Butler, 16, updated her status on Facebook with an enthusiastic shout-out for Google+, the social network’s latest rival. “Oh my God Google! I love it! I was signing up for Google+ and they asked me my gender and the choices were male, female or OTHER!!!!! Oh ya Google!”

headline: At the Center of a Trial, a Shabby Queens Home
text: In the gilded, leafy confines of Forest Hills Gardens in Queens, the house on Greenway North and Puritan Avenue stands out for its shabbiness.

headline: Now Online | T Design Fall 2011
text: The fall issue of T Design goes all over the map, visiting an 18th-century fantasy in Chicago, a contemporary art-filled aerie in Manhattan, a supernatural lighting installation in Munich and an off-the-grid vacation spot in Uruguay. It also recalls a chronicler of California Modern architecture and a young London designer who performs alchemy on unlikely materials. See all the stories here.

headline: Question: Why Pay Bank Fees?
text: The news on Thursday that Bank of America is imposing a $5 monthly fee on people who have the nerve to use their debit card to buy things probably should not have come as much of a shock.

headline: A Rising Fear of an Extended Downturn
text: MORE Americans think the job market is bad now than at any time since 1982, when the country was in a severe recession.

headline: Why Haven’t You Switched Banks?
text: In this gig, I run into all sorts of examples of mystifying consumer behavior. One of the big ones, however, is why people keep their checking accounts at big, national banks.

headline: App Smart Extra: An App for Deer Hunters
text: This week’s App Smart column identified new apps that help people maximize their success in an activity largely dominated by carnivores – namely the tailgate party.

headline: For $35,800, Obama Is the Only Constant
text: AND so, it turns out, not all $35,800-a-plate fund-raisers are created equal.

headline: Fast Vocal Muscles Are Behind Bats’ Skill
text: The last thing an insect hears before it is eaten by a bat is what scientists call the terminal buzz, a sonar-based call that bats use to track their prey. Bats can produce these echolocation calls at a rapid rate, up to 190 calls per second; they also use the buzz to navigate.

headline: D.M.V. Quickly Reviews Policy to Waive Vision Test for Renewals
text: New York drivers might not get a pass on taking a vision test to renew their licenses for very long.

headline: California Quits States’ Talks With Banks on Mortgages
text: A decision on Friday by a California official to withdraw from negotiations with large banks over their mortgage practices threatens to derail a broad settlement that the Justice Department has been brokering for nearly a year.

headline: Substance, Captured With Style
text: Much of the time, a documentary is a movie with something to say and a lot of people talking. The current boom in nonfiction filmmaking has been fed, to a large extent, by the impulses of advocacy journalism, according to which the job of the filmmaker is to bring attention to a problem in the world and to assemble experts and eyewitnesses qualified to explain it. While there is nothing wrong with this model — and much to admire about films that seek to instruct and inspire their audiences — it can be wearying and limited. There is so much social concern, so many talking-head interviews wrapped around snippets of archival footage, and, too often, not enough art.

headline: Iceland, Rising From Its Ashes With Films
text: REYKJAVIK, Iceland — Iceland is a country of upheavals, natural and artificial, literal and figurative, so it should be no surprise that the featured Icelandic selection at the eighth annual Reykjavik International Film Festival is “Volcano,” directed by Runar Runarsson, which opens with spectacular scenes of the Eldfell volcano chewing the bones of a small island town in 1973.

headline: Well Fed but Not Stuffed
text: PARIS

headline: So Far, Sales for New DC Comics Are Super
text: In June DC Comics fans were left shaking in their Superman skivvies after the publisher announced that it would reset all its continuing series and reintroduce their heroes, as if they were appearing for the first time. The hope was to entice new readers by simplifying decades of lore.

headline: Channel Surfing: ‘Free Agents,’ the British Version
text: There’s no law that says British television has to be better than American. The science-fiction series “Outcasts,” a “Terra Nova” forerunner recently shown on BBC America, was pretty dreadful. The American “Office” was sometimes better than its British counterpart.

headline: A Chicago Cautionary Tale: Fan Is Still Short for Fanatic
text: “Taxi to the Dark Side,” the title of Alex Gibney’s best-known film (an Oscar winner in 2008), is also a good general description of his documentaries. As a sports film, “Catching Hell” might sound like a change of pace for a director whose subjects have included torture, fraud, influence peddling, terrorism and Eliot Spitzer. But as usual, Mr. Gibney wants to take us to a frightening place.

headline: Yemenis Say They Have Bigger Problems Than Al Qaeda
text: SANA, Yemen — On the streets of Sana, the nation’s conflict-stricken capital, the news of the death of Anwar al-Awlaki, the Yemeni-American propagandist for Al Qaeda who inspired jihadists around the world, was largely overshadowed by the continuing domestic turmoil here.

headline: Moving Out of New York Is Just a Bad Idea
text: Whenever a movie character decides to abandon a successful career to “spend more time with my family,” scenes of domestic bliss rarely follow. “Dream House” is no exception, though this crackpot thriller from the usually competent Jim Sheridan leaves only one mystery unsolved: what on earth was he thinking?

headline: Very Late in His Career, a Composer Tries a Flute
text: Elliott Carter completed his Concerto for Flute and Ensemble in March 2008, back when he was only 99. The astonishingly prolific Mr. Carter is about 10 weeks shy of 103. Since he turned 100, he has written 14 works.

headline: With Bach as Innocent Bystander, Message for the Senses, Not the Mind
text: Say you’re a person who adores Bach. Say you rarely go to see dance (too busy listening to Bach). Given these circumstances, you might logically conclude that there is no such thing as too much Bach.

headline: Burning the Diaries
text: I JUST burned 40 years’ worth of diaries. I didn’t plan to — or rather, I had always planned to, once I knew I was dying, or so old that I would soon lack the energy to gather wood. But I woke one morning and knew it was time to let it all go.

headline: Blend of Music and Mystery: A Mixed Bag
text: ARLINGTON, Va. — The cross-pollination of the mystery and the musical theater does not have a fertile history. There was Rupert Holmes’s “Mystery of Edwin Drood,” of course, about half of “City of Angels” and, more recently, John Kander and Fred Ebb’s “Curtains.” But even that great puzzler fan Stephen Sondheim, co-writer of both a mystery play and a mystery movie, has never actually concocted a true mystery musical, although his Grand Guignol masterwork, “Sweeney Todd,” is rich in suspense and richer still in bloody murder.

headline: With Paris on Her Mind
text: LOLA BURSTEIN RYKIEL, 25, the United States director of public relations for Sonia Rykiel, is the designer’s granddaughter. Her father is Simon Burstein, the chief executive of Browns fashion boutique in London. Raised in Paris, Lola now lives in New York. BEE-SHYUAN CHANG

headline: Band Kicks Up a Sweat Storm Onstage
text: Need housing for the night: six men, either shirtless and moist or sweating through their shirts; carrying instruments, some of them large; unlikely to stay still for long periods of time.

headline: Look of the Moment | Kanye West
text: The Look: Jeans and a Jacket — one would hardly recognize the reliable gray T-shirt and everyday black denim under that dazzling red blazer.

headline: Every Action Produces Overreaction
text: During their first week, members of Occupy Wall Street, the ideologically vague and strategically baffling effort to redress social inequities, put together a library on the north end of Zuccotti Park whose disparate offerings included “Last Exit to Brooklyn”; Gay Talese’s article in The New Yorker on the collaboration of Tony Bennett and Lady Gaga; and Abbott’s Digest of New York Statutes and Reports, Volumes 4, 9, 33 and 34. By the middle of last week, as the numbers entrenched in the park grew, copies of “Animal Farm,” Barbara Ehrenreich’s “Nickel and Dimed” and “Meltdown,” a book outlining the 2008 financial crisis, were well placed. Specific ambitions still had not emerged, but a new intensity had begun to replace the limp theatrics.

headline: Despite Upgrades, L.I.R.R.’s Reliability Issues Return With a Bolt of Lightning
text: This was supposed to be the year that the troubles on the Long Island Rail Road came to a halt.

headline: Airborne
text: My median altitude tomorrow will be around 37,000 feet. Expect no posts.

headline: N.F.L. Denies Pryor’s Appeal
text: N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell affirmed Friday the five-game suspension he gave the former Ohio State quarterback Terrelle Pryor, saying he had improperly manipulated the N.F.L.’s eligibility rules when he “intentionally took steps to ensure that he would be declared ineligible for further college play and would be able to enter the N.F.L. via the supplemental draft.”

headline: Jets Face an Imposing Obstacle in Ngata
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Because the Jets face the Baltimore Ravens on Sunday, and probably because he used to coach him, Rex Ryan has spent part of this week making Haloti Ngata sound more like an action hero than a 6-foot-4, 330-pound defensive tackle.

headline: Week in Pictures for Sept. 30
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the Wall Street protests, cellphone service in the subways, and a private island for sale, off the coast of the Bronx.

headline: Umenyiora May Return Against the Cardinals
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Osi Umenyiora has been the Giants’ All-Pro defensive end in absentia this season. But there is a strong possibility that Umenyiora, who is recovering from knee surgery, will return to the business of playing football.

headline: Espresso and the Incredible Hulk
text: As chief creative officer of Marvel Entertainment, Joe Quesada, 49, keeps fans of the Incredible Hulk, Spider-Man and the rest happy. Part of his job is to make sure that the characters’ stories have a smooth transition to film and television. On Sundays, he becomes the fan, cheering for his daughter at figure-skating tournaments or rooting for the Mets. He lives with his wife, Nanci, 49, and their daughter, Carlie, 10, in a loft in the Flatiron district, along with their yellow Lab, Zoe, and two cats, Mucha and Nutley. They also have a house in New Jersey.  ELISA MALA
